HEADLINE: Union at Modern Museum To Meet Over Strike Vote

BYLINE: By GRACE GLUECK

 BODY:
The professional employees' union at the Museum of Modern Art will meet tomorrow evening to seek a strike authorization vote against the museum. The three-year contract between the museum and the union, the Professional and Administrative Staff Association, known by its acronym of Pasta, expired Oct. 31.
The open-shop union, which has 220 members, cites wages and proposed cutbacks in health insurance as its chief grievances. But museum spokesmen say their wage offering agrees with comparable salaries in the field, and they insist that escalating costs of health insurance force a reduction in what they can pay for benefits. 
 The union's members range from bookstore and information clerks to editors and associate curators and conservators. At the present time, full curators do not belong. Union spokesmen say that, despite what they view as a healthy economic outlook for the museum, the average salary for the group is $20,000 a year, with some earnings as low as $11,500 annually.
 
Givebacks in Health Insurance
 "We're asking for a 12 percent across-the-board increase in the first year of a two-year contract, with a raise of 10 percent the second year," said Mikki Carpenter, a photo archivist at the museum and the union's treasurer. "But they've only offered us 3 percent. They've also asked for givebacks in the health insurance plan that would amount to a 5 percent reduction in salary."
Ms. Carpenter also said that at the last negotiating session on Oct. 31, the museum had told the union there would be nothing in the way of further discussions "until we are ready to give back health benefits."
But Robert Batterman, outside counsel for the museum and its spokesman in labor negotiations, said the museum's health care program was "out of control," that the premiums paid for hospital and major medical insurance had risen 108 percent in the last three years.
"Compared with our sister institutions, such as the Metropolitan Museum and the Whitney, we are way out of line in terms of the scope of benefits and premiums paid," he said. And he added that the reductions sought by the museum would apply not only to the staff but to management officials as well.
 
'An Opening Proposal'
 Mr. Batterman also said that the museum's offer of a 3 percent wage increase was not intended to be final. "We have characterized that as an opening proposal," he said. "We are hoping that negotiations proceed so that we may increase that offer. But we cannot meet a demand for double-digit increases."
He added that while the average salary for the bargaining unit -- that is, the unionized employees -- was $20,500, the figure included a "significant number of bookstore clerks and visitor-desk attendants who are working at comparatively low but nevertheless market wages."
The average for professional positions was "significantly higher," Mr. Batterman said, citing figures of $35,700 as the average for incumbent associate curators, $28,600 for curatorial assistants, and $22,900 for entry-level curatorial assistants. He said that the museum was proposing "major increases" in the minimums for these three categories, but that the union itself had put lower caps on the proposals.
 
'A Red Herring'
 But Daniel Starr, associate librarian at the museum and president of the union, said the argument about minimums was "a red herring, because adjusting the minimums would not affect the salaries of anyone currently here."
"Besides," he added, "we represent people who work in many titles throughout the museum, both professional and administrative, and the average salary when you look at the whole picture means that those at the lower end of the scale are living in near-poverty conditions in New York City."
While the union painted a prosperous picture for the museum's future, Mr. Batterman said, the truth was that it faced a deficit for fiscal 1991, and that the recession had cut into its endowment and investment programs. But he added, "Since the one Pasta strike in 1973, we've had a very good relationship with the union, and no one in management is looking to damage that relationship."
Mr. Starr said, "We've managed in those years to settle our contracts without a strike, but the situation this time is quite different. We've never been faced with a proposal for such drastic cutbacks with the museum in sound financial shape. We've always had the bad salaries justified by the good benefits, but now they're trying to eliminate the benefits and leave the salaries back where they've been all along."

HEADLINE: Toss the Rascals Out; Just the Rascals

 BODY:
California, Colorado and Kansas City vote today on proposals to limit terms of elected officials. Indeed, Californians are voting on two such proposals, one stricter than the other, and both are expected to carry. The very idea is a bad omen.
Public frustration with entrenched politicians who don't perform is understandable. But arbitrarily throwing out the good with the bad is simplistic and, worse, undemocratic. It is far more important that voters be free to make choices. 
 According to a Gallup poll last winter, the term-limitation idea is popular nationwide. The driving premise is that long-term incumbents lose touch with their constituents but are virtually unbeatable. So the answer is to force them all out after a specified time; the maximum term most commonly proposed is 12 years.
The premise itself is faulty. While it's true that some 98 percent of incumbent Congressmen who seek re-election have been successful in recent years, it's also true that, over time, there is substantial turnover. Two-thirds of the House's members in 1990 weren't there in 1980.
Proponents of term limitation claim to be politically neutral, but the most active tend to be Republican, conservative and anti-tax. President Bush, reflecting his own problems with the Democrats' seemingly unbreakable control of Congress, has endorsed the stricter of the two California proposals, which would impose a lifetime limit of eight years for state legislators.
The advocates of limitation have clearly touched a sensitive nerve. The budget gridlock in Washington this year is one good reason for public unhappiness. But rising taxes, shrinking public services and the spreading pain of a slack economy create discontent with all levels of government.
So why don't dissatisfied voters cast the ins out? Because incumbents have enormous advantages -- abundant campaign funds to overwhelm underfinanced challengers, large staffs that tend to constituents' problems no matter how trivial, free-mail franking privileges for self-promoting newsletters that pretend to be "official business," and carefully gerrymandered districts that insure solid blocs of support on Re-Election Day.
The proper answer to these built-in advantages is reform, starting with the disgraceful gusher of political action committee contributions and special-interest honorariums. Alas, despite growing public pressure for a healthy cleansing of campaign finance laws, there is little evidence that legislators are interested. As long as they resist reform they invite the public attitude that's embodied in term limitation.
But term limitation is the wrong response. At every level, the nation needs good men and women in government. Term limits make no distinction between the worthy and the undeserving. They deny America its right to the continued service of experienced leaders. And they deny Americans the right to make up their own minds.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Japanese Challenge Will Increase

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Japan, Land of the Setting Sun" (Op-Ed, Oct. 24), Roy Smith contends that Japan has peaked as a financial superpower. Many American corporate leaders and policy makers may find solace in this assertion, but they would be better served instead by gearing up for an increasing Japanese economic challenge.
Mr. Smith focuses on declining Japanese trade surpluses and stock markets as evidence that Japan's financial superpower days are over. While imports have decreased the trade surplus of Japan, the trend has been to the benefit of Japanese producers, who have increased competitiveness by using lower priced inputs. Japan's trade surplus with the United States is stuck at $50 billion and shows no signs of further significant decline.
Mr. Smith contends that growing overseas production by Japan is breaking up the "monolithic Japanese manufacturing system." Rather, Japanese overseas investment is expanding the manufacturing system to take better advantage of the enormous American and European markets. Japan is also exporting its Keiretsu system, the intercompany relationships that bind producers and suppliers, spelling serious trouble for United States suppliers in numerous industries.
No one would argue with Mr. Smith that the Japanese have bought high during the last few years -- in art and real estate and corporate securities -- and have also suffered enormous foreign-exchange losses. But given the long-term perspective of these increasingly global investors, their paper losses seem less important.
Mr. Smith states that the "strategic content of Japan's enormous foreign investments has been especially thin." However, that Toyota and Nomura neglected to buy a controlling interest in Chrysler or Merrill Lynch might say more about the undesirability of those American companies than about a lack of strategic planning by the Japanese. The Japanese have made enormous strategic investments in the United States: semiconductor and biotechnology companies, investment banks such as the Blackstone Group and Shearson Lehman Hutton. Mr. Smith need not be reminded of Sumitomo Bank's 12.5 percent equity stake in his own Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The term superpower has absolute and relative implications. In an absolute sense, Japan does not seem as financially invincible today as it did before its stock market decline and rise in interest rates. But in relative terms, its economy is still awe inspiring. Its growth rate this year, in excess of 5 percent, can only be the envy of a United States sliding into recession. Japan's savings rate is still one of the highest in the world. Its Government is looking at a budget surplus this year, and its reduction of debt in the last few years leaves it able to manage future recessions. Corporations are only beginning to reap the benefits of massive productive investments that have outstripped United States competitors.
With the yen near a record high in relation to the dollar, and with an
economy more energy-efficient than ever, Japan seems set to weather these turbulent times with fewer dislocations than any other economy. By almost any measure, Japan remains a financial superpower in its own right, but certainly so when compared with the troubled United States economy.
 
ISOBEL COLES
Research Fellow, Foreign Policy
Brookings Institution
Washington, Oct. 25, 1990

HEADLINE: Young, Successful But Between Jobs

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER

 BODY:
IT was the ideal pairing of young urban professionals: two careers on Wall Street, a wedding, a slice of cake, a short honeymoon and back to the office grind.
He paid the mortgage out of his bank account and she made the auto and Bloomingdale's payments out of hers. Each kept credit cards from the bachelor days. 
 Then the roof fell in. His job was terminated this summer. Hers was in jeopardy. Their investments in stocks and real estate, which still looked golden in the spring, had turned to dross by autumn.
This is not a screenplay. It is straight from the current files of Budget and Credit Counseling Services of New York, which helps its clients to rein in binge spending. Luther R. Gatling, the service's president, says the case is far from unusual these days.
In New York and other Northeastern cities, where 50,000 jobs in the securities business have vanished since the 1987 stock market collapse and tens of thousands of additional white collar positions were cut this year, economic adversity is shoving many people under the age of 35 out of extended adolescence and into something like a midlife crisis, questioning their self-worth and values.
"He's been jolted into reality but she's still on her fantasy trip -- she still believes in the tooth fairy," Mr. Gatling said of the newlyweds. The man was a banker and the woman a marketing analyst and the marriage remained threatened unless she accepted the new limits on their lives.
"The panic is on, and it's happening this time in upper-middle-class neighborhoods and high-income brackets where the 1987 stock market crash hardly made a dent," said Mr. Gatling, who serves clients referred to the service by American Express and other creditors seeking payment on delinquent accounts.
The panic comes just as many members of the younger half of the generation born after 1955 have been deepening their social and financial commitments: -- forming families and taking on mortgages. For those who thought they had bought the ultimate insurance when they chose to study business administration -- or law, in anticipation of tough competition from their peers -- the pain of diminished professional prospects is almost too great to bear, especially when the value of investments like real estate is also crumbling.
"If they lose their job, they lose their center of gravity," said Dr. Mari Terzaghi, a midtown Manhattan clinical psychologist with a number of patients who have lost ousted from powerful positions in the financial industry. "Everything in their lives has been a quick fix and they are bewildered by the world closing in on them," she said.
For women, changing assumptions about careers may reinforce doubts about trade-offs between work and family.
"My friends say if my career's not working out, maybe I should settle down and have kids," said 30-year-old Carolyn Fielding of White Plains, who lost her job as a marketing and sales representative last spring. "But I don't want to wake up five years down the line,." she went on, "and say I took the easy way out and the only reason I'm married is that I lost my job in 1990."
In these times, many decisions have, it turns out, rested on shaky foundations. Mel Rottkov, who is single and, 37 and lives in Manhattan, left a $50,000 public-relations position last year to earn a graduate degree that would move his career in another direction. In the spring, nervously watching the economic slide, he decided to go back to work, to discover that jobs paying $50,000 were no longer available to him. He took up driving a cab to tide him over until the right offer came along.
"I was the only guy in my taxi school whose first language was English," said Mr. Rottkov. Now, he said, he is looking for positions paying $25,000 and is still stuck behind the wheel 12 hours a day.
"I used to be a yuppie," he said., "Nnow I am a puppy: -- a poor urban professional."
That prospect is still unreal for the legions of well-paid young people who are unencumbered by children and mortgages, though they may not have to look farther than the nearest T-shirt to see that the mood has shifted to the "underachiever" of Bart Simpson from such 80's statements as "When the going gets tough, the tough go shopping."
"The yuppie image of being self-centered and somewhat arrogant is not something I am proud of, but it did seem that hard work produced a lot of money and good times," said Mark Santino, a single 28-year-old Pittsburgh stockbroker. Rumblings of bad times ahead caused him to curtail some spending, like "going into a bar and buying rounds for your buddies," but not much, he said. commented. Mr. Santino said he earned a six-figure income last year.
Said his friend, Nori Passavino, a 30-year-old marketing officer for a Pittsburgh bank, also single: "If worse came to worst and I lost my job I'd just jump in my car and head to Aspen, ski all winter and wait on tables,"
And what if there were still no jobs when the snow melted?
A note of surprise filled her voice at the prospect. "My attitude is to roll with what happens," she responded.
"There's no question our attitude was we were put on this earth to have fun," said Susan Lamoureaux, a 31-year-old job recruiter with D. J. Hertz employment service in New York. "A lot of people looked at us like we were spoiled brats and deserved a comeuppance. But the boom was just normal for us; -- we never knew anything different.
Now she is married and expecting a baby next year. "I'm getting used to carrying lunch to work and treating vacations like a luxury instead of a routine," she saiId.
Older and more battered by the shrinking economy is Charles Goodgal, a 36-year-old New York options trader who has a master's degree in business administration from the Wharton School of Finance of the University of Pennsylvania. "In 1986 and '87 it was a gravy train; -- they were giving money away on Wall Street," Mr. Goodgal recalled.
The 1987 market crash put him out of business for five months but he resumed trading "and made a few dollars -- not in Fat City, but luckier than most."
Feeling financially secure again, he and his wife, Nita Silverman, a successful businesswoman who said she earned a six-figure income as president of marketing for a large cosmetics concern, decided to have a baby. Last January she quit to devote herself to raising her son, Matthew, now 2. In June they sold their Greenwich Village apartment and bought a house in Ridgewood, N.J.
"Emotionally it was the right thing, because we wanted to get away from the city and all its problems, but we went into it blindly," said Ms. Silverman, who is also 36. Four weeks into their new home, they find found a new word in their vocabulary: budget.
"When I was working, we never bothered to consult each other about a purchase of $500 or so," she said. "Now we do. We are also postponing purchases like new furniture for our bedroom and putting things we thought we had earned -- a baby grand piano for me and a Porsche sports car for Chuck -- on the back burner.,"
And they are discussing whether to have a second child or whether Ms. Silverman should return to work, though she has no assurance she can could re-enter the job market at her previous income figure.
The sweeping layoffs, especially in the financial and retail industries, have dealt a disproportionate blow to managers of Ms. Silverman's age or younger, not just by eliminating jobs but by reining in the ambitions of those still employed.
"People of high caliber are not risking going to another firm that wants them," said Adele Ribolow-Berk, head of a Manhattan job-recruitment firm specializing in the publishing field. "They stick with the security of the old company."
That means channels within a corporation or firm may be clogged by executives in their 40's and 50's, creating additional agitation among junior members.
"My patients are very bitter," said Brian McDonald, a psychoanalyst to whom patients are referred from employee assistance programs in troubled Wall Street organizations. "Many of them came from upper-middle-income families and went to all the correct schools and felt they had a passport to success. Now they're 30 years old and making $30,000 a year and they'll never do as well as their parents. The only benefit they see is now they can get a seat on the subway at rush hour because there've been so many layoffs below Chambers Street."
If the economy remains stagnant for an extended length of time, these new limits may hasten the process of re-evaluation and cultural change, market researchers and other analysts say.
"It becomes a good excuse to get out of the rat race and focus on more solid concerns," said Hy Mariampolski, president of QualiData Research, a New York market research concern.
"We are already seeing a turning toward more conservative and practical spending," he said. "In gift-giving the trend is toward more useful items for the home than throw-away stuff that was the hallmark of the 80's."
Clinton Sanders, a University of Connecticut sociologist who specializes in popular culture, says he hopes that young professionals, notorious known as they are for lack of interest in social or political issues, activism, will use the recession to reassess their own lives and tackle larger social issues, a trend -- something he says he already sees in growing concern for the environment. He said,
"A group so singlemindedly focused and habituated by work would be a potent leadership force," he said, "if it turned away from success and acquisition and put itself to work on the more problematic issues out there."
Dr. Douglas LaBier, a Washington psychologist who is working on a book he calls "Reclaiming the Promise: Growing Up at Mid-life," says he believes the generation is yearning for deeper moral values.
"The young men and women I see as patients and in my research want to mix career competency with vision and purpose but are absolutely lacking models," he said. "This generation has to create its own."
Marilee Hartley, co-author with Marissa Piesman of the satirical appraisal of the baby-boom generation's love affair with materialism and trends, "The Yuppie Handbook" (Long Shadow Books, 1984), said she believed the coincidental move of people in their late 20's and 30's into marriage and child-rearing will provide them with the grit to survive hard times.
"They're already scaling back, devoting less time to brunching and finding the celebrity chefs," said Ms. Hartley, 45, who writes a newsletter for the office of Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York City. "Maybe it's about time we started calling the baby boomers 'adults'; -- their long adolescence is over."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 9, 1990, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article and a picture caption in The Living Section on Wednesday about young professionals worried about the economic downturn misidentified one. He is Richard Rottkov, not Mel Rottkov.

HEADLINE: A Move to Define Teaching A Cut Above the Average

BYLINE: By SUZANNE DALEY

 BODY:
What does it take to make a great teacher? And once you have one, how do you know?
The National Board for Professional Teaching Standards will announce tomorrow that it has hired a research team to design the first of 34 tests to measure excellence in teaching. 
 The board, an independent group that has been trying for four years to toughen the standards of the teaching profession, wants to create the first national system for identifying the best teachers in various fields. It plans to begin its certification system by 1993.
The research team, headed by a University of Pittsburgh professor, is expected to come up with a test for English teachers that will include the use of videotaped classroom activity and exercises in which teachers would face simulated problems, a spokesman for the board said.
"Nobody is going to get board-certified with a No. 2 pencil in their hand," said Joan Baratz-Snowden, the board's vice president for assessment and research. "We've got to break the idea that assessment is a row of five bubbles."
 
 Raising Status and Salaries
 The aim of the project is to eventually form a distinguished cadre of board-certified professionals who will enhance the status of teaching, raise salaries and by their example attract more talented people into the field.
The research team, headed by Prof. Anthony R. Petrosky of the University of Pittsburgh, a poet who is also a leading researcher in assessment models, has been awarded a $1.5 million contract to develop a test for English teachers who work primarily with students from the ages to 11 to 15, the board said. Around the country there are about 100,000 such teachers.
Professor Petrosky will be working in conjunction with Connecticut's Department of Education, which has been in the forefront of state efforts to overhaul licensing practices by using assessments based on performance. The team will also have several teachers as participants throughout the research.
"I'm particularly interested in a videotape portfolio," Professor Petrosky said, "in seeing a seqence of lessons, so that you could get a sense of the narrative or story that the lessons would tell."
The use of videotapes instead of observations by a local principal, for instance, would allow the board to use a team of very experienced teachers to review large numbers of candidates for certification. The team would have established and uniform criteria for judging the work.
 
 Supplement to a License
 Professor Petrosky said teachers might be able to choose their own tapes and to include a written statement explaining what the tapes were meant to show.
The 63-member board, created in 1986 by the Carnegie Forum on Education and the Economy, intends to use its certification procedures to supplement, not replace, teacher certification tests that are administered by individual states.
State education departments now grant teaching licenses to graduates of an accredited teacher training program, in most cases after they have passed tests of general knowledge and knowledge of teaching.
The new credential, by contrast, is to be voluntary and will be designed to set a standard of excellence for experienced teachers. A teacher will need at least three years' experience before he or she can take the test. The board hopes teachers who gain certification will be paid more.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
The Push to Recycle Newsprint

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
With environmental concerns rising and a growing number of governments requiring publishers to use recycled paper, makers of newsprint in North America are rushing into recycling. After showing little interest for years, they are investing $1.5 billion to $2 billion in equipment that will allow them to use scrap paper as well as trees as raw material.
"At the begining of 1989, of the 43 newsprint mills in North America, only 9 used recycled fibers," said John Ruston, a solid-waste specialist at the Environmental Defense Fund. "With the announcements that have been made since then, there will be at least 26 mills with that capability." 
 Many suppliers of newsprint had been reluctant to get involved in recycling because of the difficulty and expense of collecting old newspapers in cities and shipping them to mills in remote locations.
But with seven states having adopted laws requiring recycled paper in newspapers and legislation pending in other places, newspaper publishers have been pushing their suppliers to act. In the last year close to two dozen newsprint recycling projects have been announced or declared under consideration in the United States and Canada.
For example, Atlantic Packaging Ltd., is scheduled to open a mill later this year in Whitby, Ontario, that will produce 135,000 tons of newsprint a year, solely from old newspapers.
Industry officials say the number of announced projects understates the level of interest. "From the number of inquiries we get, we know there are a lot more feasibility studies under way," said J. Rodney Edwards, a vice president of the American Paper Institute. "We are going to see a lot more recycling of newspapers, corregated board and pre-sorted office white papers."
Carl C. Landegger, chairman of the Black Clawson Company, an equipment supplier, said, "The chief executive of every newsprint company in North America, without exception, has quotations for recycling equipment sitting on his desk."
 
Too Much Paper
 Newspapers represent 8 percent of all solid waste, and have become an early focus of many programs in which homeowners separate their trash. But last year recycling programs, particularly in the Northeast, ran into a jam. The amount of paper collected overwhelmed the plants available to process it.
As a result, warehouses were filled and the value of used paper plunged. Homeowners who had faithfully separated their newspapers for recycling were dismayed to learn that their communities were paying upward of $100 a ton to have it hauled to landfills. Since then, the glut has eased because of increased exports.
Prices paid for old newspapers vary greatly by region. A ton of old newspapers brings $25 to $35 in California while in the New York City area recently a ton brought $3, and in some cases cost $7 to haul away.
Despite the problem, many paper companies hesitated about making investments in new plants and equipment because new production capacity already planned, largely for virgin newsprint, was expected to saturate the market and hold down prices.
To force the pace of recycling, state legislatures in Connecticut, California, Florida, Minnesota, Maryland, Wisconsin and North Carolina adopted laws requiring newspaper publishers to use recycled paper and imposed fines and taxes if they did not. And some local governments, including Suffolk County's on Long Island, have mandated that newsprint have a 40 percent content of recycled fiber by 1996. Federal legislation has also been introduced, but Congress adjourned without taking action.
 
Voluntary Agreements
 In other states, including New York, publishers and state officials reached voluntary agreements to use more paper with recycled content. The goal is to increase the use of recycled newsprint to 40 percent of all newsprint by the end of the decade, provided the material is available.
With the New York agreement assuring a ready market for its product, the Jefferson Smurfit Corporation announced in September that it would build a mill in upstate New York to produce 250,000 tons of newsprint a year from 330,000 tons of waste paper that would come from the New York City and Boston areas, among others. Jefferson Smurfit, which is based in St. Louis, is already the nation's largest producer of recycled newsprint.
But most of the newsprint industry is taking a more conservative approach -- adding recycling machinery to existing mills. Known as de-inking equipment, it reduces old newspapers to a pulp of wood fibers in a large vat of water and removes the particles of ink. The cleaned fiber can be formed into new paper that is 100 percent recycled or combined with virgin fibers.
This is the technology in use at the Garden State Paper Company's plant in Garfield, N.J., the only newspaper-recycling plant in the New York area.
According to the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association, the new equipment will increase the North American demand for waste paper in newsprint production from 1.55 million metric tons in 1989 to 3.07 million by 1992. About 60 percent of the 13 million tons of newsprint consumed in the United States annually is imported from Canada.
 
Jump in Market Share Seen
 "By last April we could see that the market share for recycled newsprint would increase from 14 percent to 28 percent by 1992," said Tonda F. Rush, vice president for industry affairs at the American Newspaper Publishers Association. Since then the announcement of new mills and equipment "makes it clear that the share will go as high as 35 percent, as long as the economy is O.K. and the collection systems do not collapse," he said.
Industry officials say that adding de-inking equipment to an existing mill costs $60 million to $80 million, compared with $400 million to $450 million for a new mill. But new recycling mills can be placed close to urban areas, as they do not need vast expanses of trees for raw material, and so transportation costs are lowered. Industry people said the new Jefferson Smurfit mill would probably be along the Hudson River north of Albany.
Transportation will still present a problem for distant mills, but Canadian producers are counting on the fact that Canada ships more bulk commodities, like paper, to the United States than is shipped back. "If railroad cars and trucks are being backhauled empty, then you can fill them with with waste paper," said Mr. Edwards of the paper institute.
 
A Concern About Supply
 Newsprint producers contemplating investments in recycling equipment are concerned about insuring a steady supply of old newspapers and the quality of the waste they receive. Mr. Ruston of the environmental fund said some are negotiating with city sanitation commissioners who will have large amounts of material available as trash separation programs take hold across the country.
But the quality of municipal collection is often not good, Mr. Edwards said. "People tend to interleaf the newspapers with mail and magazines as a way to get rid of them," he said. These other paper products can act as contaminants in the recycling process, forcing mills to add costly operations to separate them.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Precious Metals Advance On Heightened War Fears

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Heightened fears of war in the Middle East spurred a rally in the precious metal markets yesterday.
Gold futures settled $7 to $7.40 higher on New York's Commodity Exchange, with the active contract for delivery in December at $388.10 an ounce. The November contract climbed $7.10, to $386.60. Silver was 3 cents to 3.2 cents higher, with December at $4.257 an ounce. 
 Platinum futures finished $6.10 to $10.20 higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with November at $426.80 an ounce.
Analysts said speculation was mounting that the United States-led military force in Saudi Arabia would soon attack Iraqi troops in occupied Kuwait. Randolph Donney, chief commodities analyst with the Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J., said some analysts expected an offensive as early as this weekend.
He said the rally was fueled by signs that the Soviet Union might send troops to the region to bolster the United Nations force and by perceptions that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d was "laying down the ground rules" for an attack during his visit to allies in the Middle East.
Other analysts cited the views of some military strategists that a strike would best be started in November, before the desert winter sets in.
"There are lot of things coming into play and I think you're getting a little bit of a war scare there," Mr. Donney said. Gold is often viewed as an investment haven in times of international crisis.
Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst with Paine Webber Inc., linked further buying to signs of firming demand for gold at the recent low prices and to evening of positions in advance of Friday's expiration of December gold options on the Commodity Exchange.
Pork futures rallied strongly on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, helping to lift the cattle markets. Near-term hog futures rose the permitted daily limit of 1.5 cents a pound and all pork belly contracts soared the 2 cents-a-pound limit on signs of slow slaughter rates and ideas that the markets have reached a seasonal bottom.
Prices of soybean futures prices fell to their lowest levels in eight months on the Chicago Board of Trade as signs of slack demand and large yields prompted selling and profit taking. Wheat futures ended slightly higher. Corn was slightly lower.
A survey of grain analysts disclosed that most experts expect the Agriculture Department to raise its 1990 soybean crop estimate tomorrow from last month's projection of 1.82 billion bushels.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Simulating Competition

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
DO consumers still benefit from the regulation of long-distance phone rates? Not so long ago the American Telephone and Telegraph Company was almost universally regarded as a puma amidst newborn kittens -- a powerful beast, whose predatory instincts made it untrustworthy out of sight of its Government keepers.
But in the last few years A.T.&T.'s rivals, notably the MCI Communications Corporation and U S Sprint, have grown claws of their own. And with the support of the Bush Administration, the Federal Communications Commission is proposing to lengthen A.T.&T.'s leash, with the thought of one day letting free markets rather than regulation protect consumers' interests. 
That would suit A.T.&T., which would like to move aggressively to shore up its 60 percent-plus share of the lucrative large-customer business market. But the proposal is drawing howls of protest from competitors that have only recently grown comfortably profitable.
A.T.&T.'s rivals score a few points in the resulting war of words between distinguished economic consultants. But to the degree that the hired guns succeed in raising doubts about the potential for healthy competition in long-distance phones, a larger, unspoken question becomes more difficult to ignore: How does the simulated rivalry between a handful of phone companies that apparently cannot be allowed to fail better serve the public better than a plain old-fashioned regulated monopoly?
Under current rules, all long-distance phone companies are free to set rates, offer new services and negotiate special deals for valued customers. Check that: all but one. As a "dominant carrier"A.T.&T. cannot raise or lower rates by 5 percent or more without permission from regulators. And it must provide plenty of notice to its rivals in case they want to match the offer.
The commission argues that the rationale for this discrimination against A.T.&T. is losing its force. A.T.&T.'s rivals are now big enough, rich enough and competent enough to deter a predatory price-cutting attack.
What is more, the commission says, U S Sprint and MCI's enormous investments in excess capacity make it unlikely that A.T.&T. would be able to gouge customers. If the phone giant raised prices, competitors would be well positioned to take away their business.
Three consultants for U S Sprint, Steven Salop, Steven Brenner and Gary Roberts of Charles River Associates demur. The costs of transforming the smaller phone companies' maze of fiber-optic cable into a functioning network would exceed the commission's estimate by billions of dollars. Moreover, for some A.T.&T. customers -- notably those with 800 numbers that would have to be changed --leaving the A.T.&T. family would be expensive.
But it is not rate increases that U S Sprint fears. Just the opposite: A.T.&T.'s rivals worry about price cuts that would force them to sacrifice profits in order to hang onto valued customers. And here the Charles River trio offer a novel argument in defense of their client.
Many potential customers, they assert, including some who were burned after Ma Bell's breakup, incorrectly believe that non-A.T.&T. service is inferior. Thus if A.T.&T. were free to price as it wished, it would discriminate, lowering rates to gain savvy price-sensitive customers and raising rates for customers who believed A.T.&T's advertisements. At the very least, Steven Salop argues, deregulation should be delayed until customers are given time to see how good non-A.T.&T. service can be.
The best guess now, analysts argue, is that the F.C.C. will find a politically acceptable compromise, deregulating at a sufficiently cautious pace to keep U S Sprint and MCI from taking their case to their friends in Congress. Indeed, the one near certainty in the not-so-brave new world of long-distance telephone regulation is that, once established, every company will be given sufficient support by regulators to stay in business.
Therein lies the rub. As the architects of telephone divestiture in the early 1980's understood, it takes competitors to create and maintain a competitive market. But the addition of profitable service providers was a means of insuring competition, not an end in itself. The F.C.C. now finds itself running a cartel, favoring smaller companies over the larger one in the expectation that the market will someday be self-sustaining.
But what happens if, as seems increasingly likely, that someday never comes? Is America really better off with a telephone cartel regulated in the interests of its weaker members than with a monopoly that must justify its pricing policies to the Government?

HEADLINE: Productivity on the Increase But Hours Worked Decline

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6

 BODY:
The productivity of American workers climbed at the fastest pace in two years during the July-September quarter, but hours worked fell, the Government said today, in a sign that the economic slowdown is forcing businesses to make do with fewer employees.
"The good news is that productivity is up; the bad news is we're in a recession," said Michael K. Evans, a Washington-based economic consultant. 
 In the third quarter, non-farm productivity -- output per hour of work -- advanced at a 1.6 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate compared with the previous three-month period. It was the third consecutive improvement and the best pace since the July-September quarter of 1988.
Productivity rose three-tenths of a percent in the second quarter, fell 1.3 percent in the first quarter and dropped 2.5 percent in the fourth quarter of last year.
However, the number of hours worked edged down one-tenth of 1 percent in the third quarter, the first decline in more than four years. Economists say this shows that employers are coping with economic sluggishness with layoffs, hiring freezes and limits on overtime.
 
'Better, but Subpar'
 "What's happened here is that in 1989 the economy was very weak, but business optimism was still strong and businesses didn't lay off people," Mr. Evans said. "Productivity has picked up because they are laying off people who should have been laid off last year."
Despite the improvement, productivity is still well below the level needed to increase Americans' living standard significantly, according to most economists.
"It's better, but subpar," said Allen Sinai, an economist with the Boston Company.
Increased productivity, or getting each worker to produce more during each hour of work, is vital to increasing the nation's standard of living without inflation.
Non-farm productivity is increasing at an average annual pace of two-tenths of 1 percent so far this year, compared with a seven-tenths of 1percent decline for all of last year.
Since 1982, productivity growth has averaged 1.6 percent a year -- better than the 1.2 percent average in the 1970's but far worse than the 2.5 percent annual gain posted from 1947 to 1967.
Mr. Sinai said manufacturing, where productivity leaped at a 5.6 percent annual rate in the third quarter, compared with 2.6 percent for all of last year, is making impressive gains. However, productivity growth in the service sector, which accounts for a much larger share of the economy, remains dismal, he said.
Meanwhile, hourly labor costs, a major indication of inflation for businesses, shot up 4.5 percent in the third quarter. That was an improvement over the 5 percent rate in the second quarter but still worse than the 3.2 percent increase for all of 1989.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Auction Starts Off Well

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The largest auctions of Treasury debt ever started off well yesterday, as a wide spectrum of investors easily absorbed a record $12.5 billion in three-year notes.
But traders said strong demand for the first leg of the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions did not necessarily mean that sales of 10-year notes and 30-year bonds today and tomorrow would be as successful. A total of $34.25 billion in new notes and bonds will be sold this week. 
 With the forthcoming debt sales, the prices of long-term bonds and notes dipped slightly in the secondary market for Treasury securities, nudging interest rates higher.
 
Traders Are Confident
 Recession fears and the short maturity of the notes sold yesterday made traders confident that the three-year auction would go well.
At the auction, just under $47 billion worth of bids were placed for the securities, which were sold at an average yield of 7.78 percent.
The rate is down from the average yield of 8.10 percent at the last three-year note auction on Aug. 7, and is the lowest yield on a three-year note since Nov. 9 of last year, when three-year notes were sold at an average yield of 7.77 percent.
Market participants said yesterday that demand for the securities came from a broad range of investors, including banks, insurance companies and foreign investors, particularly Middle Eastern accounts.
But demand from Japanese investors, who have bought large chunks of Treasury securities at past auctions, was minuscule, traders said, with the four largest Japanese securities houses purchasing only 5 percent of the notes sold yesterday.
"The three-year was the easy one," said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a firm in Princeton, N.J., that provides research and commentary on developments in the foreign exchange and credit markets.
"Interest rates may have to rise a bit to sell the 10-year and the 30-year, but not a lot," he added. "There is plenty of cash available to finance these auctions if investors are in the right mood, and I think they are."
 
Looking to Fed Action
 Weak economic conditions are encouraging investors to buy Treasury securities. Most analysts are forecasting that the Federal Reserve Board will move quickly to push down interest rates to prevent a prolonged recession. Such conditions tend to favor fixed-income securities.
"In the wrong environment, new supply can be terrible for the market," a Government bond trader said.
"But right now, it is great. The consensus view is that the Fed will move to ease policy again in the next 10 days, and perhaps once more after that before the end of the year. From that perspective, that means that while current yield levels are not a value now, they will be soon."
Late yesterday, the $11 billion worth of 10-year notes to be auctioned today were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.51 percent, up from 8.48 percent late on Monday. The $10.75 billion in 30-year bonds to be sold tomorrow were offered at a price to yield 8.64 percent, compared to 8.62 percent late on Monday.
 
Secondary Rates Down
 Profit taking and preparations for the remaining two auctions depressed note and bond prices in the secondary market for Treasury securities. Some market analysts said prices had reached unrealistically high levels even if a recession was on the horizon.
"Recession does not equal a bond rally," said Joel Marver, chief fixed-income analyst at Thomson Financial Networks Bond Data Technical Service in Boston.
"In seven out of the last nine years, the bond market has rallied in October and November," Mr. Marver added. "But I wouldn't expect this rally to persist through the end of the month, and would convince clients to get much more defensive."
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 101 7/32 late yesterday, down by 5/ 32, to yield 8.63 percent. Late Monday, the benchmark issue was offered at a price to yield 8.61 percent. Since mid-October, bond yields have fallen by more than 40 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point.
Among note issues, the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at 101 19/32, down by 2/32, to yield 8.09 percent. And the 7 3/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 6/32, down by 2/32, to yield 7.64 percent.
 
Short-Term Rates Up
 Short-term Treasury bill rates rose.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.07 percent, up by 3 basis points. Six-month bill rates rose by a like amount, to a late offered rate of 7.06 percent. And one-year bill rates rose by 4 basis points, to a late offered rate of 6.88 percent.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of three-year Treasury notes:

HEADLINE: A Risky Business for State Farm

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BLOOMINGTON, Ill.

 BODY:
In normal times, Edward B. Rust Jr., chairman and chief executive of State Farm, would be euphoric about taking policyholders away from rival insurance companies. But times are far from normal in the car insurance business.
Competitors ranging from Aetna to Travelers to Cigna are curtailing or abandoning their auto coverage in many states, but Mr. Rust is anything but euphoric. The reason, as he is all too aware, is that the companies believe that state-mandated rate cuts, rapidly escalating car repair bills and skyrocketing injury awards by juries are making it hard for them to make much money on auto policies. 
 That puts the State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Company, the nation's largest auto insurer, with more than 33.6 million policies in force, at a crossroads. As many companies retrench, tens of thousands of new customers will be coming State Farm's way in the next few years. But many of the motorists will either have poor driving records or live in states like California and New Jersey, which insurers consider the most regulated and least profitable in which to do business.
If State Farm declines the new business, the company risks losing market share to other big insurers like No. 2 Allstate and No. 3 Farmers Group, which it strongly wants to avoid. But if State Farm pursues the business aggressively, it could find itself stuck with a large number of high-risk, money-losing policies. Still, the company plans to forge ahead, counting on its 17,500 agents to make the new business profitable by taking in enough money from premiums to outweigh any added losses.
To be sure, State Farm is not alone. Farmers, Geico, Allstate, the Nationwide group and the USAA group are among other large insurers that remain committed to writing automobile policies. They, too, could also face mounting claims if they rush too fast to add new business.
But Mr. Rust has more reason than most of his counterparts to be worried. The auto insurance business has been a big loser of late, and State Farm, which was founded here in 1922 to provide low-cost auto coverage to farmers, has done worse than the average. It also has some of the lowest rates of any major insurer, typically 10 percent to 15 percent below its competititon. That makes the company, with its longtime "Just Like a Good Neighbor" marketing theme, attractive to consumers, but leaves it with less room for mistakes.
 
'Worried by the Turmoil'
 Finally, State Farm is accustomed to dealing with a broad cross-section of drivers and culling out the worst. This time the available pool of new business will consist heavily of drivers with blemished records, because independent insurance brokers not paid by State Farm will place many of the better ones with other companies. That leaves the company facing the higher risk of picking the least bad from the bad.
"'m just not saying, 'Hot dog, let the business come!' Mr. Rust said in a recent interview at his Bloomington office. "I'm worried by the turmoil out there."
On State Farm's side is that its agents have excelled historically at separating out poor risks. But this time they are heading into mostly uncharted waters.
While in most cases the agents will have access to the driving records of potential customers, it still typically takes a year or longer for a new insurer to really know how well a motorist drives.
And some states require insurance companies to write automobile policies if they also want to offer more lucrative homeowners and business insurance.
Last year, companies selling auto-liability policies to individuals paid $1.17 in claims, agent commissions and other selling expenses for every dollar in premium revenue they took in, according to the A .M. Best Company, the big research firm based in Oldwick, N.J. While 10 cents earned on the dollar in investment income helped reduce the losses, most auto insurers still had a net loss of about 7 cents on every dollar of premium revenue.
While many of State Farm's private-passenger auto liability policies were profitable, over all the company lost 17.9 cents on these policies for every dollar in premium revenue it took in. Investment income restored 10.5 cents, making State Farm's net losses on these policies 7.4 cents on every dollar.
 
More Business, More Losses?
 "It does not take much imagination to see that more business could mean more losses, particularly in places like California," said Barbara Stewart, a partner in Stewart Economics, a leading industry consulting firm based in Chapel Hill, N.C.
Automobile insurers often point to California and New Jersey as emblematic of states in which it is tough to operate because of sharp rate reductions and strict state regulations on coverage. Consumer advocates note that many of the rules were made because of motorists' outrage over high premiums and what they saw as other corporate abuses.
The industry has also faced similar actions in Pennsylvania, Virginia, Michigan, Massachusetts and Arizona.
As a result, some insurance experts are saying there is another important issue: What will happen if companies like Aetna give up on auto insurance and others like State Farm balk at picking up this freed-up business?
"Long term, if insurers continue abandoning the market, the capacity simply won't be there to serve individuals," predicted Edward Young, a group vice president at Allstate.
State Farm, Allstate and Nationwide are among the leading direct writers, companies that sell policies directly to the public by mail, telephone, or a field sales force that works exclusively for that insurer. By contrast, independent-agency companies like Travelers, Cigna and the Hartford group sell through freelance brokers.
Because direct-writer companies pay sales commissions that are a fourth to a third less than those paid by independent agencies, they have been able to undercut the prices of the Aetnas of the world and gain market share. In 1985, according to A. M. Best, the direct writers took in 52.6 percent of auto-insurance premiums, with the agency companies' generating the remaining 47.4 percent. By the end of 1989, the direct writers' share of the market had grown to 56.3 percent. State Farm's share during this period rose to 16.9 percent from less than 15 percent.
"It does appear that the direct writers are positioned to take an even bigger portion of the personal lines of insurance," said Robin Campaniano, the insurance commissioner in Hawaii and the chairman of the personal-lines committee of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners.
This new business would normally be a bonanza for the direct writers, allowing them to streamline operations to reduce costs and to charge less. And a larger policyholder base generally yields actual results closer to what actuarial tables predict. In the insurance industry, this is known as the law of large numbers.
But in this case, executives industrywide say that to make sure the new business is not more trouble than it is worth, they are working overtime to try to minimize the losses that could result.
Their main approach so far has been to try to control internal expenses. Insurance companies say that with the costs of car repairs and hospitalization still climbing, holding down their own expenses may be the best way to control overall costs.
 
State Farm Prepares
 Nowhere is this more true than at State Farm. Benefiting from its lower sales commissions, State Farm's administrative costs for handling auto policies are already about a third less than the industry average. But to keep from losing ground if claims rise as expected, State Farm will have to widen that gap further. It is already cutting back on awards, trips and certain cash bonuses for employees. And new offices are built with an eye toward saving on costs.
"We are building functional offices, not palaces," said Mr. Rust, who became State Farm's chairman in 1987 and whose father, Edward B. Rust Sr., also headed the company.
State Farm is also trying to curry favor with its agents, apparently in the hope that happy agents are more likely to identify and root out bad risks.
State Farm's latest push is to hook up about 2,500 agents not already linked to State Farm's computer system. The system provides each agent with an up-to-date electronic record on policyholders, including policy provisions, claim histories and property inventories. This way, for example, the computer system might reveal that a motorist insured by State Farm might also need boat insurance.
But before long, the computer system's biggest benefit could be to help State Farm reduce its claims rate by prompting agents to obtain information that is sometimes overlooked but important to assess coverage and premium rates.
The question remains whether even State Farm's computers will prove to be enough to hold down or offset claims expenses. Many of the company's future expenses, like paying for car repairs and hospitalization of accident victims, will be out of the company's control. That makes it hard to say anything beyond that State Farm could end up being a big winner or a big loser.

HEADLINE: 4 Exchanges Spurn Moving To New Jersey

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
Spurning an offer to cross the Hudson to New Jersey, leaders of New York's commodities exchanges said yesterday that they would recommend that their new headquarters be built in lower Manhattan, home to the exchanges for more than a century.
To keep the exchanges, the hub of an industry that generates $1.3 billion a year in goods, services and salaries, New York City and the state offered what was described as an unprecedented array of incentives, including a construction grant of $82 million, tax and rent subsidies worth $56 million and energy savings of nearly $7 million. 
 The package would bring the exchanges' operating costs to a little less than $23 million a year in the early years of the 25-year deal, officials said. That is about $7 million less than under New York's initial offer but slightly higher than the exchanges' costs would have been if they moved to the Harborside Financial Center in Jersey City.
 
'The Deciding Factor'
 Still, exchange leaders said the higher costs of remaining in New York were offset by what they saw as the advantages of doing business in the city.
"The deciding factor is that New York is the financial capital of the world," said Martin Greenberg, chairman of the Commodity Exchange. "We belong here."
Yesterday's decision by the exchanges' chairmen requires approval by a majority of their boards and a majority of their members. If, as officials expect, the recommendation is adopted, construction could begin by 1992 at the site, bounded by Murray, Greenwich, Warren and West Streets. If not, the exchanges would remain where they are, at least for the time being.
Exchange officials had received final offers from New York and Jersey City last Thursday, analyzed them over the weekend and met from late Monday afternoon until 2 A.M. yesterday.
At one point, people close to the process said, the exchanges, which share a trading floor and had decided to relocate as a group, were split, with the New York Cotton Exchange and the New York Mercantile Exchange favoring moving and the Commodity Exchange and the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange favoring staying in New York.
The New York Futures Exchange, in the same building as the others, has not made a formal commitment to move.
 
'Pretty Touch and Go"
 "Last night was pretty touch and go," said Vincent Tese, a former commodities trader who, as chairman of the State Urban Development Corporation, was credited with a crucial role in the negotiations.
The decision was a rare bit of encouragement for a city enduring its worst year economically since the late 1970's and for its Mayor, David N. Dinkins.
Before the Mayor arrived for the announcement at the exchanges' headquarters at 4 World Trade Center, he attended a meeting called by the New York City Partnership at the headquarters of The New York Times, where a group of city and state officials and business and civic leaders met with officials of Morgan Stanley, which, with 4,200 employees in New York, is also considering leaving the city.
The exchanges' decision was a setback for Mayor Gerald McCann of Jersey City. In in terviews over the last week, however, he confidently predicted that, with corporate profits under pressure and costs on his side of the Hudson so much lower, Jersey City would be more and more attractive to companies seeking to save money.
New Jersey's Commerce Commissioner, George R. Zoffinger, said, "We knew all along that the exchanges were really using New Jersey as leverage to get a better deal out of New York."
 
Extraordinary Incentives
 The incentives provided to the exchanges -- $95 million from the city and $43 million from the state -- were the most ever awarded for a relocation in Manhattan and involved an extraordinarily large grant, city officials said, though the deal was not as large as the one that accompanied the Chase Manhattan Bank's shifting of 5,000 back-office workers to Brooklyn, where tax abatements are higher to begin with.
The commodities exchanges employ 11,700 people, a figure expected to grow, and generate $84 million in city tax revenues and $80 million in state tax revenues annually.
Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero, the city's deputy mayor for finance and economic development, said the city and the state could recoup their investment in three and a half years.
Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan, who has opposed some tax-incentive deals, said she liked this one. "The number of jobs, the time in the city's economic cycle and most importantly the fact that this is a tax break for an entire industry is what makes the difference," she said.
 
Tunnel Plan Dropped
 In 1985, the commodities exchanges negotiated a deal with the city to build a new headquarters atop the Manhattan entrance to the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel, but the project was dropped after the stock market's plunge in 1987.
The Jersey City site would have allowed the exchanges to have a 100,000-square-foot trading floor. At the Manhattan site, a few blocks north of the Trade Center, the trading floor can only be as large as 75,000 square feet. But that is still three times the size of area traders must squeeze into now.
As traders streamed onto the floor at the start of business yesterday, the Mercantile Exchange chairman, Z. Lou Guttman, announced the decision over a public-address system, though his words were barely audible over the din.
Interviewed later, several brokers said they were relieved that they would finally be moving to bigger quarters.
"I think the reaction is very positive," said Robert Fink, a floor broker near the gold futures ring. "People are very happy to be staying in the city."

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Saudi Women Take Driver's Seat in a Rare Protest for the Right to Travel

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Wednesday, Nov. 7

 BODY:
In daring defiance of the Saudi tradition against women driving, about 70 veiled Saudi women gathered on Tuesday in front of a supermarket in Riyadh, dismissed their drivers and drove in a convoy of cars before being stopped and and detained by the police a short time later.
Saudis said the demonstration for the right to drive was the first known open protest by Saudi women and an exceedingly rare manifestation of public sentiment in this conservative Islamic nation. 
 Equally startling was that virtually all of the women received the support of their husbands or close male relatives before undertaking the action, several organizers said.
 
Plush Sedans
 The cars -- about 40 dark, plush Lincoln Continentals, Mercedes-Benzes, Buicks and Japanese luxury sedans -- were intercepted by the Saudi police at intersections after the convoy had broken into smaller groups, about a half-hour after the protest began. Some of the women in the cars refused to lower their windows or communicate with the police before they were taken away.
Saudi officials said early this morning that the women had been released after signing a pledge that they would not repeat their action elsewhere.
The demonstration came at a time when the presence of American and other Western forces is stirring considerable debate here about whether to bring this country more in tune with the modern world. But many of the women involved in the demonstration were eager to emphasize that it had nothing to do with the large presence of Westerners here since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. The protest was not publicized in advance to Western news organizations.
 
Barred by Tradition
 Although some Saudi women have pressed for a wider array of rights, organizers said the protest was focused narrowly on the right to drive as a matter of convenience and household economics.
Although there is no written law that prevents women from driving here, they are barred by tradition from doing so and must use a paid driver or a relative to go anywhere. Under severe Islamic strictures, Saudi women are veiled and robed from head to toe, forbidden from appearing in public with men and from traveling anywhere without permission from husbands or male relatives.
Organizers of the demonstration said many of the women had gotten driver's licenses while in the United States or Europe. They said that many were highly educated and came from prominent families, a factor that may have figured in their treatment by the authorities.
It was doubtful, however, that the Saudi authorities would react more harshly because the status of women here, while inferior to men, is also highly protected by tradition and paternalism.
 
No Official Mention
 The protest became the talk of this the country Tuesday evening, evidently through word of mouth. In phone interviews from places around the country, Saudis used words like "amazing" and "astounding" to describe the incident. There was no mention of it on any Saudi news reports, however, and many Saudis were certain that the Saudi authorities would suppress any information about it.
The organizers said they sent dozens of telegrams to senior Saudi officials explaining that their intention was for the greater good of Saudi Arabia.
The incident began late Tuesday afternoon with women, some accompanied by daughters, converging on the Al Tamimi Safeway supermarket parking lot, driven there by their chauffeurs. There, the drivers were left behind as some of the women got into the driver's seats and the rest occupied passenger seats. At least one woman's husband followed in another car from a distance -- for "moral support," he said.
 
'Couldn't Believe My Ears'
 "I couldn't believe my ears when madame asked me for the car keys and told me to get out and then drove away with the others," said a Sri Lankan driver who identified himself as T. R. Zein.
Another chauffeur, an Indonesian who said his name was Asmara, said his employer brought her 15-year-old daughter along and left the house while her husband was present and presumably informed about her intentions. "I think he knows," the Indonesian man said of the husband.
Mr. Zein, who sat on the sidewalk next with about 25 other, mostly Asian drivers, said he drove his employer, whom he described as a 35-year-old schoolteacher, along with her teen-age daughter.
"There were about 40 cars here and they left us all here," he said as other drivers nodded. "They drove together. I think the police caught them later."
 
'We Wanted to Be Heard'
 The Saudi religious police known as the Committee for Commendation of Virtue and Prevention of Vice rounded up all of the cars and the women at intersections. They prevented curious onlookers from approaching an area where they were stopped on King Abdel Aziz Road.
The police could be seen asking women to get out from driver's seats and to sit in back seats, as more police cars converged on one site where the women's cars were stopped.
The women were deliberately trying to draw attention and fully expected to be arrested, one of the organizers said. "We wanted to be heard by the authorities, loudly and clearly," she said in a telephone interview a few hours later.
Later, in separate telephone interviews, two of the women who helped organize the demonstration and who insisted on not being identified explained that they spent a week planning the event.
They all agreed that a leading figure behind the protest was Aisha al-Maneh, a sociology professor who received her doctorate from the University of Colorado in Boulder. They described her as an outspoken advocate among hundreds of other educated women in Saudi Arabia who have argued that there were no edicts in Islam that ban women from driving.
 
'Patriotic' Protest
 Mrs. Aisha, who taught for some time at the university here before she reportedly quit in frustration over other restrictions imposed on women, could not be reached for comment.
The two women who participated in the organization of the demonstration said they meant no harm to Saudi Arabia and strongly defended their action as "patriotic" and "necessary."
"It is important for the authorities to understand that as educated women who have driven themselves abroad while we pursued graduate studies, we cannot be reduced to being dependent on strangers to drive us," said a 36-year-old woman who asked not to be identified by name.
"In addition to being humiliating, this is anti-Islamic," she said. "Islam says that a woman should not be left alone in the company of a man who is not her relative and that is exactly what happens everytime I am driven in my car by a Pakistani, Sudanese or other person who is a driver. Besides, this is very expensive on our family budget."
Such complaints have been heard many times here and are openly discussed on Saudi television programs, but they have failed so far to bring about change.
 
'Supporting Islam'
 "We wanted to send the message with this drastic action we were forced to undertake that we are not breaking the rules of Islam, but supporting Islam," one protester said. "All those who participated today were veiled and accompanied by other women. They drove slowly and well. They did not break any laws."
The participants said they would repeat their actions again.
Several senior Saudi officials interviewed Tuesday night said they supported the women's goals, although they took exception with the protest itself.
"We have been debating this issue for quite some time and some of the most senior people in the country are in favor of allowing women to drive for perfectly handsome reasons," said a senior official who asked not to be identified. "But in our country everything happens through evolution, not revolution."
It was significant that the demonstration took place in Riyadh, which is the heart of the conservative religious establishment.
Najd, the region in which Riyadh lies, is largely populated by the descendants of the inner tribal desert Bedouins. Geographically isolated, it has been the region most resistant to the gradual modernization urged by the Saudi Government and the royal family.
By contrast, Jidda, a Red Sea port that lies in the region known as Hijaz, has been the most liberal city because of its exposure to travelers and foreigners. Saudi women can be seen there walking without their faces veiled and frequenting public restaurants in the company of their husbands, something that rarely occurs here.

HEADLINE: THE 1990 ELECTIONS: The Implications;
Much Ventured, for Little

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

 BODY:
Like many a President before him, George Bush proved unable to move the political heavens on Tuesday.
Hoping to point his party toward a brighter future in the 1990's, he poured his energy into a prodigious effort to elect Republican governors in the three Sun Belt behemoths -- Florida, Texas and California -- each of which will gain new seats in the House of Representatives because of redistricting. He failed in Florida, failed even more dramatically in his adopted home state of Texas, and went to bed unsure about the outcome of the close contest in California. 
 At best, then, one out of three -- not much to show for a lot of hard work in the Southern and Western states where the future of American politics will clearly unfold, just as it unfolded 50 years ago in New York and Pennsylvania and Illinois.
 
A Message on Taxes
 Elsewhere, the electorate sent a message that President Bush once transmitted as his own: No new taxes. Most Republican strategists believed from the start that Mr. Bush made a mistake by abandoning his pledge and sowing confusion within his party, and so it proved as the returns poured in.
In New Jersey, for example, voters were positively apoplectic with rage about the tax increases imposed by Gov. Jim Florio, but they could not vote against Mr. Florio, whose name was not on the ballot. So the Governor's fellow Democrat, the usually popular Senator Bill Bradley, was very nearly defeated by a little-known opponent who raised only 4 percent as much money as he did.
Every New England state except Maine got a new governor as the region, gripped by recession, struggles to find adequate governmental revenue.
 
Surprise for Gingrich
 Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, a Republican who broke with Mr. Bush to lead a revolt against the budget accord reached two weeks ago, was locked in a totally unexpected life-and-death struggle, and Representative Peter Smith of Vermont, another Republican who bravely supported the plan but then distanced himself from Mr. Bush, lost his seat.
But a tax rollback in Massachusetts was decisively defeated.
In a day of balloting characterized more by cross-currents than by tidal waves, a day when trends were difficult to discern, voter resentment proved to be less potent than expected. Many were frightened, but few were defeated. The political thunder rolled and the electoral lightning crackled on Tuesday night; first Mr. Bradley and then Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina, the Republican arch-conservative, seemed headed for defeat, but each of them finally managed to pull out a victory.
When the storm had cleared, relatively little had changed on Capitol Hill, as the magical potions of incumbency -- money and name recognition and services rendered for constituents great and small -- did their work again.
 
No Movement in Senate
 With only the Minnesota contest remaining to be decided, not a single Senate seat had moved from one party to the other, and it appeared possible that for the first time since World War II every Senate incumbent seeking relection would manage to achieve it.
A few House members lost, mostly because of local circumstance: Roy Dyson, a Maryland Democrat, because of links to Pentagon produrement scandals; and Stan Parris, a Virginia Republican, partly because of his views on abortion; and John Hiler, an Indiana Republican, who also has close races and finally ran out of luck; and Bill Grant, a Florida Republican who switched parties and offended his constituents.
The most astonishing reversal came in the distrcit centered on the longtime liberal stronghold of Madison, Wis., where Representative Robert W. Kastenmeier, a 16-term Democratic incumbent, tied for 11th in seniority in the House, was ousted by a former television news reporter, Scott L. Klug. Mr. Klug described the 66-year-old Mr. Kastenmeier, whose seat was once held by Robert LaFolette, as "torn, worn and outdated."
In Oregon, Representative Denny Smith, a Republican with ties to the savings and loan scandals, went down to defeat, but another politician tarred with that brush, Representative Frank Annunzio, Democrat of Illinois, survived.
Others seats seemed likely to change, including several in California, perhaps, and one in Minnesota, where a sex scandal turned politics upside down.
 
A Weak Starting Position
 In an average midterm election, the party holding the White House loses 28 seats, and it seemed highly unlikely that Mr. Bush would do that badly. But he had relatively few seats to lose; no President in history has ever taken office with his party holding as weak a position in the House. And the losses he did suffer, perhaps as many as 10 seats net, presented him with the prospect of an even stronger Democratic opposition on Capitol Hill.
A change of that size could make it harder for Mr. Bush to govern. The recent employment discrimination bill, for example, passed the House by a margin of 273 to 154, which was 17 short of the margin needed to override the President's veto. The changes on Tuesday would put the Democrats within reach of a "veto-proof" margin in the House.
But it was governors of both parties, buffeted by the beginnings of a recession, closer to the voters than Washington lawmakers, who had the hardest time of all.
Democrats took statehouses away from Republicans in several parts of the country, from Florida to Kansas to Rhode Island, although in the Midwest, the Republicans ran strongly in states like Michigan and Ohio where Democrats had controlled statehouses for considerable periods.
It was a trade much to the benefit of the Democrats, who will now be in a position to draw the new lines of power to suit themselves in four of the five largest states -- New York, Texas, Florida and Pennsylvania -- and perhaps even in California, the grand prize.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Harvey Gantt conceding defeat last night in Raleigh, N.C. Jesse Helms won the race with 54 percent of the vote, providing some of the Republican Party's limited good news (Alan S. Weiner for The New York Times) (pg. B6)
