HEADLINE: THE 1990 ELECTIONS: Congress;
Helms and Other Incumbents Manage to Hold On

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

 BODY:
In a day of dramatic struggle and unexpected twists, Senator Jesse Helms prevailed over his Democratic opponent, Harvey Gantt in North Carolina yesterday, while Senator Bill Bradley beat back a surprisingly powerful challenge from Christine Todd Whitman, a Republican, in New Jersey.
Mr. Helms, the 18-year incumbent and conservative firebrand, declared gleefully last night, "The mighty ultraliberal establishment struck out." Mr. Gantt, the first black Mayor of Charlotte, whose underdog campaign for the Senate drew worldwide attention, said, "I do not regret a single day of this campaign." 
 With 91 percent of the vote counted in North Carolina, Mr. Helms had 54 percent to Mr. Gantt's 46 percent.
 
Struggle for Political Life
 In New Jersey, Mr. Bradley, widely considered a likely Democratic Presidential contender in 1992, spent Election Day struggling for his political life against an opponent who was not expected to pose much of a threat. With 99 percent of the vote counted, he had 52 percent to Ms. Whitman's 48 percent.
These results came as incumbents generally managed to hold on against an angry electorate who, in many areas, clearly wanted to send a message. In Massachusetts, Senator John Kerry, a Democrat, turned back a challenge from Jim Rappaport, a businessman, that had deeply worried many Democrats in this autumn of discontent. In Kentucky, Senator Mitch McConnell, a Republican, claimed victory over his challenger, Harvey Sloane, after complaining that from news accounts, "you'd have thought every incumbent had horns."
One incumbent in serious trouble was Senator Rudy Boschwitz, Republican of Minnesota, who has served in the Senate since 1978. His opponent, Paul Wellstone, a political science professor dismissed by many political insiders, claimed victory last night. But with less than half the votes counted, only two percentage points separated the two candidates.
It appeared that all the other Senate incumbents would survive. And while there were some upsets in the House, including the defeat of a 32-year veteran, Representative Robert W. Kastenmeier, Democrat of Wisconsin, most members won re-election.
Still, the volatile electorate made itself felt in many areas, with Representative Newt Gingrich, the second-ranking Republican in the House, suddenly confronted with a battle for political survival in his suburban Atlanta district. Mr. Gingrich openly feuded with the White House in the recent budget negotiations.
Democrats, confident of a solid majority for the next two years, voiced a new assertiveness toward President Bush.
 
'Must Come to Congress'
 Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader, said last night: "The results are very clear: George Bush could not win the Congress, and he can no longer rule by veto. Next year, he must come to the Congress with an action plan for reviving this economy and reworking the system to the benefit of working families."
Continuing the pattern of midterm elections, Democrats expected to add to their already hefty 258-to-175 majority in the House. At the same time, several Democratic senators who were targets for the Republicans earlier this year, including Senator Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island and Senator Paul Simon of Illinois, handily turned back those challenges. Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan, prevailed over Representative Bill Schuette, and Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, defeated Representative Tom Tauke, a Republican.
In one of the closest races this fall, Senator Daniel K. Akaka, a Democrat, turned back a strong challenge from Representative Patricia Saiki, the Republican thought to have the best chance of wresting a seat from the Democrats.
Democrats, who have controlled the House since 1954, won at least four seats from the Republicans, and probably more. In Virginia, Stan Parris, a Republican, was handily defeated, while in Florida, Bill Grant, a Democrat turned Republican, also lost. Moreover, the threat to Mr. Gingrich, one of the most militant conservatives and a longtime spokesman for the young turks of the Republican Party, was certain to drive jolts through the ranks of House Republicans.
But Democrats did not emerge unscathed. Roy Dyson, a five-term Democrat from Maryland, went down in defeat. His office had been embroiled in ethical controversies.
Voters were electing 34 senators and 435 House members yesterday, although many of the contests were mere technicalities. In the Senate, the political struggle came down to a handful of states in the final weeks of the campaign, including North Carolina, Hawaii, Iowa, Kentucky, Massachusetts, Minnesota, Oregon and Rhode Island.
Democrats began the election season with hopes of maintaining their 55-to-45 margin in the Senate. Republicans began with high hopes of chipping away at it, in preparation for an all-out assault on Democratic control of the Senate in 1992. Democrats have 20 members up for re-election in that Presidential election year, while Republicans have only 14.
 
Unexpected Game of Defense
 But Republicans found themselves playing an unexpected game of defense this autumn. Democrats used the budget negotiations and President Bush's repeated reversals on the issue of taxes to portray the Republicans as the tribunes of the rich.
Some of the most senior Republicans found themselves struggling against the year's angry, anti-incumbent mood. Senator Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon, a 24-year-veteran of the Senate, survived a stiff challenge from the businessman and scientist Harry Lonsdale.
Mr. Gantt's challenge to Mr. Helms became far more competitive than many political insiders expected. Only three blacks have served in the United States Senate, all of them Republicans. Edward W. Brooke of Massachusetts was the only black to serve since Reconstruction.
Several senior incumbents were returned to office with little or no strain, including Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who heads the Senate Armed Services Committee; Senator Strom Thurmond, the 87-year-old South Carolina Republican; Senator John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia; Senator Thad Cochran, Republican of Mississippi, and Senator David Pryor, Democrat of Arkansas.
Also re-elected handily were Senators Al Gore of Tennessee, John D. Rockefeller 4th of West Virginia and Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, all Democrats. Senator Howell Heflin, an Alabama Democrat considered vulnerable by some Republicans early on, was also returned to Washington.
Senator J. Bennett Johnston, a Democrat, won his seat in Lousiana's unusual open primary earlier this year, turning back an unexpectedly strong challenge from David Duke, a former leader of the Ku Klux Klan.
The House of Representatives has seemed largely immune to the anti-incumbent mood regularly registered in public opinion polls this year. Over the last two election cycles, the re-election rate in the House was 98 percent; the last time it dropped below 90 percent was 1974. Incumbents have enormous advantages in the House, from fund raising to the perquisites of office. Moreover, both national parties have focused their attention on 1992, when redistricting and retirements are expected to open as many as 80 seats in the House.

HEADLINE: THE 1990 ELECTIONS: The Nation;
DEMOCRATS RETAIN GRIP ON CONGRESS, TAKE TOP POSTS IN TEXAS AND FLORIDA; CUOMO RE-ELECTED, BRADLEY SURVIVES

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES

 BODY:
Democrats captured the governorships of two Sun Belt states that will play key roles in the battle over reapportionment, while retaining their strong hold on the Congress yesterday in midterm elections.
Despite furious last-minute efforts by President Bush to rally Republican support, Ann Richards, the liberal State Treasurer, was elected governor of Texas, and Lawton Chiles, the former Senator, was elected governor of Florida. 
 The victories gave Democrats two of the three biggest prizes of 1990, with the battle for the governorship of California still unresolved early today.
Ms. Richards defeated Clayton Williams, whose intemperate remarks alienated many moderate Republicans. Mr. Chiles tapped a vein of voter anger to unseat Gov. Bob Martinez, who was trying to become the first Republican ever to win re-election as governor of Florida.
 
Cuomo, Bradley, Weicker Win
 Voter discontent was apparent around the country in narrower-than- expected victories for many prominent candidates, including two of the Democratic Party's top national prospects, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York and Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey.
Voter resentment was also at work in Connecticut, where Lowell P. Weicker, the former Republican Senator ousted in 1988 and now running as an independent, was elected governor in a campaign which attacked both political parties. He became the first independent elected governor of an American state since the Watergate-inspired voter rebellion of 1974.
In Massachusetts, anxiety and anger over taxes and the sagging economy overwhelmed other issues. But John R. Silber, the Democratic candidate for governor, fell just short in his attempt to ride that wave of anger. He conceded early today to the Republican, William F. Weld.
 
Fitting a Pattern
 Mr. Weld's victory fit a national pattern in contests for governor in which voters turned to whichever party had not been in power in the last few years of economic stress and tax increases. Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts has been increasingly unpopular as the economy has worsened.
Senator Bradley survived an unexpectedly tight race against the Republican, Christine Todd Whitman, as voters took out on Mr. Bradley their anger at another Democrat, Gov. Jim Florio, who sponsored the biggest tax increase in state history.
One of the hardest-fought races in the country was the battle for the Senate in North Carolina. Election Day began with the Republican incumbent, Senator Jesse Helms, chastising reporters at his polling place and ended with Mr. Helms claiming victory over his Democratic opponent, Harvey Gantt, the former Mayor of Charlotte.
The Republican Governor of Rhode Island, Edward DiPrete, whose standing was hurt by tax increases and a corruption scandal, was defeated by the Democrat, Bruce Sundlun, a wealthy businessman.
 
Fights in Middle West
 While Democrats were making gains in the Sun Belt, Republicans were in fierce races from the Northeast and throughout the "rust belt."
Gov. Rudy Perpich of Minnesota, a Democrat, was in a virtual dead heat with Arne Carlson, a Republican who entered the race only last week after the original Republican nominee dropped out after disclosures he had once swum in the nude with his daughters' teen-age friends.
In Illinois, where Gov. Jim Thompson, a Republican, is retiring, Jim Edgar, the Republican candidate, narrowly beat Neil Hartigan, the Democrat.
Terry Branstad, the Republican Governor of Iowa, was easily re-elected despite an effort to rally supporters of legal access to abortion against him.
 
Referendum on Bush?
 The first elections of the 1990's were watched as a possible referendum on Mr. Bush and on issues such as abortion and race.
The Republican defeats were blows for President Bush, reflecting a trend that politicians say began to build in recent weeks as concern about recession deepened and Mr. Bush dropped his long stand against new taxes in pursuit of a defecit-reduction deal.
Even as returns rolled in from Eastern states, voters in the West were continuing to vote in some of the biggest and most closely fought races -- for governor of California and for the Senate in Oregon and Hawaii.
"We're very encouraged by Democratic vote all over the country," said Howard Schloss, spokesman for the Democratic Congressional Campaign.
President Bush voted yesterday morning in Houston, after a weekend of campaigning for the Republican candidate for governor, Mr. Williams.
 
Big Stakes in Florida
 Florida was a crucial prize, one of the nation's biggest and fastest-growing states. Florida will probably gain four Congressional seats after reapportionment next year, and Mr. Chiles's victory means that the new political map in the state will be drawn entirely by Democrats, who control both houses of the state Legislature.
Mr. Chiles ran a strong campaign as a political outsider despite his 18 years in the United States Senate, which he left in 1988, saying he was burned out.
Mr. Martinez had two big problems: the political damage done by tax increases he supported and an ill-fated legislative session that rejected Mr. Martinez's proposal to restrict abortion.
Abortion was an important issue aiding Mr. Chiles, who supports legal access to abortion. But his media consultant, Frank Greer, emphasized Mr. Chiles's "anti-politician" appeal.
"We were outspent five to one. but Lawton Chiles had a very clear message," Mr. Greer said. "That he was running against politics as usual, that he was running for change, that he was limiting contributions to keep special-interest money out of politics and that he was running a positive campaign."
 
Voinovich Wins in Ohio
 Democrats also picked up Republican-held governorships in Oklahoma and Kansas. But in Ohio, where Gov. Richard F. Celeste, a Democrat, is stepping down, George Voinovich, the Republican, defeated Anthony Celebrezze.
Mr. Voinovich, the former Mayor of Cleveland, ran well ahead of the usual Republican performance in Cleveland, normally a Democratic stronghold. Mr. Celebrezze had hoped to make an abortion a key issue, abandoning his opposition to legal abortion at the start of the campaign. But Mr. Voinovich painted him as a waffler and tried to assure Ohio voters he did not plan to impose his personal opposition to abortion on the state.
Elsewhere in the Middle West, Gov. James Blanchard of Michigan, a Democrat, was in a race so tight that he predicted the outcome would not be known until absentee ballots were counted. His opponent is John Engler, Republican leader of the State Senate.
 
Turned Out in Kansas
 In Kansas, Gov. Mike Hayden, a Republican who has been blamed for large property tax increases, was defeated by State Treasuerer Joan Finney, a Democrat who will become the state's first woman governor.
Senator Don Nickles, chairman of the Republican Senatorial Campaign Committee, said Republican hopes for a stronger showing this year had been set back in recent weeks. "The budget debacle was pretty hard on us," he said.
But nothing more dramatically illustrated the anger of voters than the race one Democrat, Senator Bradley of New Jersey, found himself in against Ms. Whitman, whom he outspent by 12 to 1.
Mr. Bradley had expected to coast to victory, but was caught in the furor created when Governor Florio pushed through the big tax increase.
Despite repeated demands from Ms. Whitman, who was viewed as a sacrificial lamb by most New Jersey politicians six months ago, Mr. Bradley refused to take a stand on the tax increases, asserting that it was a state issue.The polls in New Jersey suggested that some voters were voting against Mr. Bradley as a surrogate for Mr. Florio. Supporters of Ms. Whitman said that taxes was the issue.
 
Race Was a Factor
 Among voters leaving the polls in North Carolina, nearly three in 10 of Mr. Helms's voters said race was a factor, and just over two in 10 of Mr. Gantt's supporters said it was. Whites were slightly more likely than blacks to say race was a factor in their vote.
Much of the Massachusetts contest for governor had centered on a debate over a tax-cutting initiative which would have rolled back more than a year of tax increases. Mr. Weld supported it, while Dr. Silber opposed it as an extreme measure which, he said, would wreck state services and cause a "meltdown" of the economy.
A significant number of voters accepted Dr. Silber's view of the tax measure, voting against the initative but then voting for Mr. Weld.
Dr. Silber, whose image as an angry outsider carried him to victory in the Democratic primary, was hurt in the general election campaign by more of his "Silber Shockers," including a suggestion that women who put their children in day care could be perpetrating child abuse. A television interview in which Dr. Silber pounced, figuratively and almost literally, on a well-known Boston television anchorwoman, was replayed repeatedly by Mr. Weld's campaign.
"Our campaign was not just about winning votes," Dr. Silber said. "We stood for the proposition that politics was about straight talk, about common sense."
 
Running on Anger
 Asked what were the most important factors in their vote, Mr. Weld's supporters cited their desire for change and their perception that Dr. Silber was too extreme. One Democratic analyst said that Dr. Silber, having won the primary on anger, continued to campaign on it, rather than moving to the political center and moderating his harsh image. Dr. Silber's supporters cited what they saw as his honesty and leadership quality.
A significant number of voters who supported Dr. Silber in the Democratic primary as a protest against the Democratic establishment in Massachusetts abandoned him when their vote would actually have made him governor. More than one out of 10 of Mr. Weld's supporters said they had voted for Dr. Silber in the Democratic primary.
 
'Elect This Dress'
 Among voters surveyed outside polling places in California, men favored Senator Pete Wilson, the Republican, while Dianne Feinstein, the Democrat whose final appeal included a call to "elect this dress," won a majority of women in the race for governor.
Supports of Ms. Feinstein, the former Mayor of San Francisco, cited the environment most often as the issue which mattered most in their vote. Among Mr. Wilsons' supporters, the issues that mattered most were crime and drugs.
In Texas, Mr. Williams, a millionaire businessman with interests in oil, cattle and banking, was hurt among voters who considered ethics an important issue. He was favored among voters who viewed crime and drugs as key issues.
The Texas race was probably the nastiest in the nation this year. Both candidates succeeded in hurting the other's image badly. The last pre-election poll, for The Houston Chronicle, found that a majority of voters had a negative opinion of both candidates.
Voters leaving the polls were divided over who had been the more negative in the campaign, with about one in four citing Ms. Richards, one in four citing Mr. Williams and one in four saying they were both the same.

HEADLINE: The 1990 Elections: Governor - Texas;
Fierce Election for Governor Is Narrowly Won by Richards

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 6

 BODY:
Sounding the populist themes tonight that carried her to a fiercely fought victory in the Texas governor's race, Ann Richards, the Democratic candidate, invited her supporters to join her in a march to the State Capitol and proclaimed, "We're going to take back the Capitol for the people of Texas."
With more than 80 percent of the vote counted, Ms. Richards, the State Treasurer, led with 52 percent of the vote to 48 percent for her Republican opponent, Clayton Williams. 
 Mr. Williams conceded defeat in an appearance before his supporters, who booed repeatedly when he offered his congratulations to Ms. Richards.
 
A Winning Coalition
 In one of the closest elections in recent Texas history Ms. Richards put together a winning coalition of women and minority voters, according to a survey conducted at polling places around the state today.
Acknowledging these consituencies as she claimed visctory, Ms. Richards held up a T-shirt that bore a picture of the State Capitol building and the slogan, "A woman's place is in the dome."
In her victory speech she said that the people of Texas had announced today that "they want a governor that remembers that this state is principally made up of working people who live from paycheck to paycheck."
Mr. Williams appears to have been seriously damaged by a number of gaffes. In March he joked that the only thing to do about rape or bad weather was to "relax and enjoy it." That remark apparently alienated a large number of women voters, and Mr. Williams said tonight that one lesson he had learned from the campaign was "not to joke about the weather."
In a New York Times/CBS News Poll, conducted by Voter Research and Surveys, Ms. Richards was favored by 6 female voters of 10. Among men, Mr. Williams was favored by just over half of those surveyed.
 
The Vote Tally
 With more than 80 percent of the vote counted, the vote was:
 
Richards . . . 1,583,204 (52%)
Williams . . . 1,463,261 (48%)
 Returns showed that Ms. Richards was holding traditional Democratic strongholds in East and South Texas while running surprisingly strong in the major cities, including Dallas, usually a stronghold for Republican candidates.
A 57-year-old, white-haired grandmother, Ms. Richards relentlessly attacked Mr. Williams for his cowboy image, his lack of governmental experience and his privileged status as a multimillionaire. Even as she claimed her victory, Ms. Richards emphasized these points. She said that the people of Texas "want a governor that gets up and goes to work in the morning. They want a governor that isn't distracted by other business."
By contrast, Ms. Richards campaigned on populist and economic themes, focusing much of her effort on a program to bring down insurance rates and to favor consumers over corporate interests.
Mr. Williams, a West Texas oil man, spent twice as much on the campaign as did Ms. Richards, including $8 million of his own money. Throughout the summer and early fall he led in the polls by substantial margins, but the race began to tighten in the last three weeks.
Support for the two candidates was sharply split along racial and ethnic lines, according to the poll of voters conducted today by Voter Research and Surveys.
 
Whites Voted Republican
 Mr. Williams apparently carried a substantial majority of the white vote, which makes up about 70 percent of the total. In the exit poll, well more than half of the whites surveyed said they had voted for Mr. Williams.
But Ms. Richards overwhelmingly carried the historically Democratic minority vote. In the poll, Ms. Richards was favored by 9 black voters of 10 surveyed. She took two-thirds of the Hispanic vote even though Mr. Williams, who speaks Spanish, campaigned extensively in Hispanic areas.
Ms. Richards, a speaker known for her sharp tongue and quick wit, repeatedly slashed at Mr. Williams, asserting that he had engaged in unethical business dealings and that he was a captive of corporate interests.

HEADLINE: The 1990 Election: Nonvoters;
Turned Off by Campaigns, Or Just Too Busy to Vote

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

 BODY:
Stephen Smith, a 22-year-old garbage collector in Utica, Mich., is tired of watching candidates "cutting each other down." He liked Ronald Reagan, but looks at the current crop of politicians and says, "You don't know who to believe."
He could try to vote them out, he acknowledges, but: "Who am I voting in? I'm voting another bum in." So Mr. Smith is not voting at all. 
 Nonvoters account for the real majority in a midterm election. In 1986, just 36.4 percent of the voting-age population went to the polls, the lowest turnout since 1942. The Committee for the Study of the American Electorate, a Washington study group, predicted that yesterday's turnout could be just as low.
Few questions are as fiercely debated among political experts as why so many Americans do not vote. Some analysts point to institutional barriers, like the procedures for registering to vote. Some blame the nature of modern American campaigns, arguing that a season of slashing television commercials offers little incentive to go to the polls. And some blame a broader breakdown in the nation's civic culture, a sense among many Americans that politics has little to do with their lives.
 
Turned Off by Politics
 A New York Times/CBS News Poll suggested that all these elements, and others, helped shape the nonvoting electorate. The poll, conducted Oct. 28-31, was based on telephone interviews with 1,445 adults nationwide and had an overall margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
In follow-up interviews with those adults and in conversations with other people on Election Day, many nonvoters seemed dismayed by campaigns and turned off by politics. They often voiced feelings of powerlessness, a sense that their ballot would make little difference on the issues they cared about. And they often cited more everyday concerns, saying they were too busy to vote, had forgotten to register or were worried that voting would translate into jury duty.
The explanations were often simple. "I believe voting is important, but I just haven't had time to register," said Ervin Harvey of Seattle.
But the explanations were often more complex.
Tony Bowe, a 37-year-old house painter from Rhinebeck, N.Y., said he cared about voting but simply felt overwhelmed. "With these politicians, I don't know who I'd vote for," he said. "I've heard ads for one judge bad-mouthing the other. Then, a little later, the other gets on with his spiel, knocking the first guy. I don't know who to trust.
"I have to judge who comes across the best on radio or television. And I don't know enough to figure out what is the truth. I kind of throw my hands up in the air and say that there's no hope."
 
'Vote for Nobody'
 Survey after survey has shown the American public in an angry, cynical mood this year, giving rise to predictions that incumbents were in for a rough time on Election Day. But interviews with nonvoters suggested that much of that anger might be expressed another way -- by simply staying home.
In Houston yesterday, for instance, a pickup truck bore a large hand-lettered sign: "Silent Revolt: Vote for Nobody."
Many nonvoters said they simply did not believe that replacing one set of politicians with another would make much difference.
"You could take all the politicians, put them all in a hat, shake it up and it would come out the same," said Homer J. Lewis, a retired salesman in Orlando, Fla.
Ethel H. Bolte, a retiree in Westchester, Ohio, said that this would be the first election she could remember when she did not plan to vote. "It won't make a difference anyway," she said. "They've all disappointed me too many times."
Mrs. Bolte suggested that she had simply lost faith. "I don't think things are any different; it's just that I'm wiser," said the 70-year-old longtime Republican. "They're all just concerned with their own parties."
 
Cynicism Toward Government
 Still, the New York Times/CBS News survey indicated that nonvoters were no more cynical toward government than the people considered likely to vote. For example, 77 percent of the likely voters said government was run by a few big interests looking out for themselves, while 76 percent of the nonvoters felt that way. But the survey did find that nonvoters tended to feel more powerless: 47 percent of the expected nonvoters said that "things would go on as before no matter who is elected," while 37 percent of the likely voters felt that way.
This theme was strong among many nonvoters who expressed concern about a variety of issues, but did not see voting as a way of acting on that concern.
Elizabeth T. Lee of West Covina, Calif., said she worried about the environment but does not think that voting can do much to protect it. "No one has been able to stop the polluting," said the 35-year-old housekeeper. "I don't think my vote is going to stop them. It's too big for me."
James E. Glasker Jr. of Murray, Utah, a 44-year-old supervisor at a copper smelting plant, said he thought "things were getting worse" and "poor and middle-class workers" were "going down the tube."
But he added: "It doesn't seem that voting matters. It seems that it's the money groups that win. There hasn't been an encouraging race for years."
The tenor of the modern campaign seemed to do little to encourage many of the nonvoters interviewed. "I can remember when it wasn't this bad," said Barbara Nagy of Stephens City, Va., a 51-year-old show dog breeder. "Maybe they'd have a debate. But anymore, it seems like they're hunting dirt on the other guy -- that's all they're doing.
"Instead of saying, 'This is where I stand and this is what I'll do,' it's 'The other guy is dirty so you should vote for me.' "
Interviews suggested that nonvoters were particularly turned off in Texas, scene of one of the roughest races of the year, the battle for governor between Ann Richards, a Democrat, and Clayton Williams.
 
'This Isn't Politics'
 "I'm not going to vote beause there's too much flimflam going on," said Charlie Randle, 29, a building engineer for Harris County in Houston. "This isn't politics; this is a dogfight. If people don't vote, the politicians might wake up the day after the election and ask, 'What did we do wrong?' "
Fred Guinn, a 50-year-old police officer in Virginia Beach, Va., said simply, "All it is is mudslinging."
Like most other research on the issue, the New York Times/CBS News Poll found that the nonvoting public tends to be younger, more mobile, less likely to have attended college and more likely to have an annual income under $30,000 than the voting population. Thirty-nine percent of the nonvoting group were under 30, as against just 16 percent of the voting group.
The poll estimated the likely voting public and the likely nonvoting public from their answers to questions about registration, past voting history and intention to vote.
Nathan K. Goodrich, an 18-year-old electrician living in Las Vegas, Nev., seemed genuinely distressed that he had not registered to vote but said: "People my age probably aren't registered because no one tells you what to do. I have no idea what the process is."
The Government spells out the procedures to register for the draft, he said, and added: "Selective Services sends a card and says that you have to do this. If the Government sent you a card and said that you had to register to vote, a lot more kids would be registered."
But many scholars of American voting say there are deeper forces at work. In the 19th century, "politics became a kind of social activity as well as political activity," said Paul Kleppner, director of the Social Science Research Institute at Northern Illinois University and author of "Who Voted." "It was deeply embedded in everyday life."
In contrast, many of the people interviewed after the New York Times/ CBS News survey talked of politics and politicians as distant and disconnected from their lives. "I've seen some of the candidates on television but it hasn't interested me," said Jenny Dorius, 21, of Salt Lake City. "My kids are more on my mind than voting."

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 7, 1990

SECTION: Section B; Page 5; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1566 words

HEADLINE: The 1990 Elections: State By State;
Midwest

 BODY:

ILLINOIS
Senator Paul Simon easily defeated Lynn Martin, a Republican Congresswoman who once had high hopes of an upset.
In a tight gubernatorial race, Neil Hartigan, a Democrat who promised tax cuts, battled James Edgar, a Republican who emphasized the need for money for better schools. Mr. Hartigan is the State Attorney General and was a two-term Lieutenant Governor, while Mr. Edgar, the Illinois Secretary of State, is a former state legislator and aide to Gov. James R. Thompson, who is retiring.
Representative Frank Annunzio, a 75-year old Democrat who is a senior member of the Banking Committee, won his 14th term, fighting off a challenge from Walter W. Dudycz, 40, a Republican State Senator who portrayed Mr. Annunzio as a lax regulator who ignored wrongdoing. Mr. Annunzio said he had been working to bring to justice those who looted the savings and loans.
In the 16th District, John Cox, a county prosecutor, faced State Representative John Hallock, a Republican.
 
 INDIANA
Although it appeared for a time as if the Democrat, Baron Hill, would mount a serious challenge to Senator Daniel R. Coats, the incumbent battled back with commercials that raised questions about Mr. Hill's consistency in opposing new taxes.
Representative Jill Long of Fort Wayne, a Democrat who won Mr. Coats's seat in the House, was challenged by a television evangelist, Rick Hawks. He attacked the incumbent as a big-spending liberal; she retorted that she had consistently opposed new taxes.
Representative John Hiler of the South Bend area, a Republican, faced Timothy J. Roemer, a former aide to Senator Dennis DeConcini of Arizona. Mr. Roemer tried to link Mr. Hiler to the savings and loan crisis: the Republican sits on the House Banking Committee, which oversees the industry. But Mr. Roemer's former boss, Senator DeConcini, has been linked to the scandal as well.
 
 IOWA
 Tom Harkin, a Democrat, met the difficult challenge of being re-elected Senator in Iowa; six years ago Mr. Harkin ousted the Republican incumbent, Roger Jepsen, who himself had ousted the Democratic incumbent six years previously.
 Mr. Harkin spent more than $5.5 million in a successful bid to blunt the campaign of Tom Tauke, a six-term Rep resentative from the "Field of Dreams" country of northeastern Iowa. Mr. Tauke said the incumbent backed liberal spending policies, abused mailing privileges and spent too much time outside Iowa.
Gov. Terry Branstad, a Republican seeking a third term, defeated Donald Avenson, Speaker of the State House.
 
 KANSAS
Gov. Mike Hayden, a Republican, lost to Joan Finney, who has spent the last 16 of her 65 years as State Treasurer. As in the Democratic primary, Ms. Finney stormed from far behind in the polls, making much of the Governor's tax changes, which hit small businesses and homeowners hard.
Kansas' junior Senator, Nancy Landon Kassebaum, a Republican, reconsidered her promise to serve only two terms, and her resulting campaign had history on its side. For one thing, Kansas last elected a Democrat to the Senate in 1932. For another, she faced Dick Williams, who backed into the race when the primary winner, Bill Roy Sr., declined his victory, citing fatigue. She won.
 
MINNESOTA
Minnesota proved to be one state where the heralded anti-incumbent mood took hold. State politics, once as homespun as the fictional Lake Wobegon, turned melodramatic as Peyton Place this year.
The Democratic Senatorial candidate, Paul Wellstone, claimed victory over the incumbent Republican, Rudy Boschwitz. Mr. Wellstone held a small lead, but many votes were still uncounted.
In the governor's race, the incumbent, Rudy Perpich, had a harder time after the Republican candidate, Jon Grunseth, made a last-minute exit from the race while dogged by accusations of sexual improprieties. Mr. Grunseth's replacement, Arne Carlson, gave Mr. Perpich a strong challenge.
In the Seventh Congressional District, State Senator Collin C. Peterson beat the Republican incumbent, Arlan Stangeland. The Democrat took advantage of disclosures that Mr. Stangeland had made hundreds of calls to a woman who is a lobbyist. Mr. Stangeland said the calls were business related.
 
MISSOURI
Two House races and an environmental measure dominated this state in the absence of campaigns for governor or the Senate.
Representative Jack Buechner, a Republican seeking his third term in the western St. Louis suburbs, faced Joan Kelly Horn, a Democratic campaign consultant and former head of the Missouri Women's Political Caucus. Ms. Horn sought to make abortion rights a major issue against Mr. Buechner, who opposes abortion.
In southeastern Missouri, Representative Bill Emerson, a five-term Republican who represents the Eighth Congressional District, was re-elected despite a challenge by Russ Carnahan, a Democrat who tried to ride the anti-incumbency issue. He is the son of Mel Carnahan, the Lieutenant Governor.
 
 MICHIGAN
The governor's race seemed a straightforward waltz to re-election for the two-term incumbent, James J. Blanchard, but the 48-year-old Democrat managed to tread on a few toes. He dumped the popular 78-year-old Lieutenant Governor, Martha W. Griffiths, from the ticket, and his two terms coincided with the worsening of the state's economy.
But the Republican, John Engler, did not capitalize on the economic issue, and his opposition to abortion rights brought out legions to campaign for Mr. Blanchard.
 
 NEBRASKA
Senator Jim Exon, the Democrat who won narrowly six years ago against a little-known challenger, faced another tough race, this time against Hal Daub, who was well known after four terms in the House of Representatives.
Gov. Kay A. Orr, a Republican, has been criticized over her refusal to block a proposed radioactive-waste warehouse that would store low-level waste from five states. Ben Nelson, the Omaha lawyer who ran against her, won the Democratic nomination by only 42 votes.
In the Omaha area, Representative Peter Hoagland, a freshman Democrat, campaigned in dozens of town meetings and mailings to fend off a challenge from Ally Milder, a former Senate aide.
 
NORTH DAKOTA
The state's only member of the House of Representatives, Byron L. Dorgan, easily won re-election against his Republican challenger, Edward T. Schafer, heir to a detergent fortune.
While Mr. Schafer tried to tie the Democratic incumbent to the savings and loan crisis and criticized Mr. Dorgan's reliance on out-of-state campaign funds, the Democrat offered himself as a populist who would fight to preserve family farms and expand health care programs in rural areas.
Three ballot initiatives would allow gambling in the state, including the use of video gambling machines.
 
OHIO
Republicans gained the Ohio Statehouse Tuesday when George V. Voinovich, the former Mayor of Cleveland, overcame a late surge of support for Anthony J. Celebrezze, the Attorney General. Gov. Richard F. Celeste, a Democrat, was required to step down after two terms.
Several House races were close. In the Eighth District, State Representative John A. Boehner, Republican, defeated Gregory V. Jolivette, a former Mayor of Hamilton. This is the seat once held by Donald E. Lukens, who was convicted in 1989 of sexual misconduct. In the First District, the Democrat, Charles Luken, the Mayor of Cincinnati, ran against former Mayor J. Kenneth Blackwell.
 
SOUTH DAKOTA
In the Senate race the incumbent, Larry Pressler, narrowly defeated two opponents: a well-financed Democrat and a vituperative newspaper.
Although the challenger, Ted Muenster, a Sioux Falls businessman, was well connected politically and commanded campaign funds approaching $1.6 million, Mr. Pressler mustered enough money to pay for a media campaign that stressed his independence from Republican Party politicking.
Mr. Muenster, who served as chief of staff under Richard F. Kneip when he was Governor, seemed to take his campaign script from The Sioux Falls Argus Leader, the state's largest newspaper. At times the Senator reacted more stridently to the newspaper's criticisms than to his opponent's.
The Democratic candidate was identified with the state's largest city, Sioux Falls, his biggest obstacle to unseating Mr. Pressler, who was strong in rural areas. Mr. Pressler regularly reminded the electorate of his 4-H membership and his John Deere tractor, which he uses to till his 80-acre farm.
 
WISCONSIN
 Wisconsin's popular Governor, Tommy G. Thompson, a Republi can, swept to victory over his Democratic challenger, Assembly Speaker Tom Loftus. Mr. Loftus was unable to mount much of a challenge, despite cam paigns stands that would seem to appeal to much of the state's normally liberal electorate.
 Representative Rob ert W. Kastenmeier of the Madison area, a Democrat who was first elected to the House 32 years ago, was challenged by Scott Klug, a newscaster.
Representative Toby Roth, a conservative Republican from the Green Bay area, defeated State Senator Jerome Van Sistine, overcoming the Democrat's well-financed campaign.
Mr. Van Sistine, popular in organized labor circles, had questioned whether Mr. Roth, a member of the House Banking Comittee, which oversees savings and loans, should bear some responsibility for the industry's crisis.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 7, 1990

SECTION: Section B; Page 5; Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 1955 words

HEADLINE: The 1990 Elections: State By State;
West

 BODY:

 ALASKA
In the three-way race for the Governor's mansion, candidates squared off on what restrictions should be placed on development of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge and the best way to deal with the impact of a projected decline in oil revenues.
All three candidates have lengthy political records. The Republican candidate, Arliss Sturgulewski, spent 12 years in the State Senate and ran unsuccessfully for governor in 1986. Wally Hickel, who served as Alaska's Governor from 1966 to 1968, differentiated himself from Mrs. Sturgulewski on abortion, which he opposes.
The Democratic candidate, Tony Knowles, 47, made his first bid for governor by emphasizing his role as Mayor of Anchorage. Gov. Steve Cowper did not seek re-election.
Personality upstaged policy in the race for Alaska's sole seat in the House of Representatives. The Republican candidate, Don Young squared off against a former Mayor of Valdez, John S. Devens.
 
ARIZONA
Notable among the state's Congressional races was the Second District's. The Democratic incumbent, Morris K. Udall, head of the House Interior Committee, defeated Joseph D. Sweeney, a law school administrator. Mr. Udall, who suffers from Parkinson's disease, said in May that he planned to retire in 1993.
J. Fife Symington, a Republican and a developer, and Terry Goddard, a Democrat and former Mayor of Phoenix, ran a hotly fought race for Governor.
In winning the Republican nomination, Mr. Symington beat out Evan Mecham, who was impeached and removed as Governor in 1988.
Mr. Goddard, the son of a former Governor, resigned as Mayor to run for the post, after serving as the head of the National League of Cities.
 
COLORADO
In the most hotly contested race in Colorado, Republican Representative Hank Brown won the Senate seat left open by the retirement of William L. Armstrong. Mr. Brown, who raised a large campaign treasury, defeated Josie Heath, a former Boulder County Commissioner who expended nearly all her campaign funds to win a rough primary race.
Mr. Brown's run at the Senate left open his Fourth District seat. The Republican candidate there was State Senator Wayne Allard, a veterinarian who managed Mr. Brown's re-election campaigns in 1984 and 1986. His opponent, State Representative Dick Bond, is a professional biologist and former president of the University of Northern Colorado.
The Governor, Roy Romer, is a popular Democrat who never faced any serious competition. He easily defeated the Republican candidate, John Andrews.
 
CALIFORNIA
 Two former Mayors, Dianne Feinstein and Pete Wilson, fought a tough race for governor. Ms. Feinstein is a Democrat and a former Mayor of San Francisco; Mr. Wilson is a Republican, a former mayor of San Diego and currently a United States Senator.
 Gov. George Deukmejian, a Republican, did not run for re-election.
 In three major Congressional races, incumbents faced strong challenges: Charles Pashayan, a Republican, from the Democratic candi date, Calvin Dooley; George E. Brown Jr., a Democrat, from the Republican candidate, Bob Hammock, and Alfred A. McCandless, a Republican, from the Democratic candidate, Ralph Waite.
There were 28 ballot issues. "Big Green," as one environmental proposition was called, was defeated, as was another proposition to limit terms of state officials.
 
HAWAII
Senator Daniel K. Akaka, a Democrat appointed to the seat after the death in April of Spark M. Matsunaga, defeated Representative Patricia Saiki, a Republican in her second term in the House. Republicans had seen this state as perhaps their best chance to pick up a seat in the Senate, as they hoped Ms. Saiki could make inroads into the customary support Democrats enjoy among Hawaiians of Japanese descent.
State Senator Neil Abercrombie, a Democrat, beat Mike Liu, leader of the Republicans in the State House, for one Congressional seat. Former Representative Patsy Mink, a Democrat who was appointed to Mr. Akaka's seat when he was named to the Senate, defeated former State Representative Andy Poepoe for the other seat. Gov. John Waihee, a Democrat, won re-election.
 
IDAHO
The incumbent Governor, Cecil D. Andrus, a 59-year-old Democrat, defeated Roger Fairchild, a Republican and former majority leader of the State Senate.
He served as Governor from 1971 to 1977 and as President Jimmy Carter's Interior Secretary from 1977 to 1981 before becoming Governor again.
Earlier in the year he vetoed what would have been a highly restrictive state abortion law. For his part, Mr. Fairchild was a declared foe of abortion before winning the Republican gubernatorial nomination.
With incumbent Republican Senator James A. McClure, 65, retiring, the race for his seat was between Representative Larry E. Craig, a Republican, and Ron Twilegar, a Democrat and former state legislator. The victor was Mr. Craig.
Competing for Mr. Craig's Congressional seat were Larry LaRocco, a Democrat and stockbroker, and State Senator C. A. Smyser, a Republican.
 
MONTANA
Senator Max Baucus, a Democrat, won a third term after shunning the complacency of his former colleague, Senator John Melcher. Mr. Melcher, a Democrat, ignored his campaign until the summer of 1988 and was defeated by Conrad Burns, a little known Republican.
Mr. Baucus spent more than a year barnstorming the state and raised more than $2 million in his campaign against Lieut. Gov. Allen C. Kolstad, his Republican opponent. Mr. Kolstad evoked criticism last July by calling threats of acid rain and global warming "scare tactics."
Representative Pat Williams, a six-term Democrat who was co-author of a compromise measure that continued Federal funding for the National Endowment for the Arts while leaving decisions on obscenity to the courts, was re-elected in the First District race by Brad Johnson, a former state party official. Mr. Johnson accused Mr. Williams of supporting pornography.
 
NEVADA
Bob Miller, the Democrat who stepped into the Governor's office two years ago when the incumbent, Richard H. Bryan, was elected to the Senate, sought his own gubernatorial victory to run one of the country's fastest-growing states. He got it.
Mr. Miller, the 45-year-old former two-term District Attorney from Las Vegas, stressed improving education and diversifying the state's economy.
He won easily over Jim Gallaway, a 50-year-old lawyer and former Marine who achieved considerable financial success with his own telecommunications companies.
In the Second District, four-term Representative Barbara F. Vucanovich, a Republican, defeated Jane Wisdom, a State Assemblywoman.
 
NEW MEXICO
With the incumbent Governor, Garrey Carruthers, ineligible to try for re-election, former Gov. Bruce King was the Democratic candidate for the post.
In an energetic race, he beat former State Representative Frank Bond, the Republican candidate.
The 66-year-old Mr. King, a rancher and businessman, was Governor from 1971 to 974 and again from 1979 to 1982. In this year's campaign, he stressed education, the environment and economic development. To spur economic development, he called for steps to create more growth in the state's private business sector.
Mr. Bond, a 47-year-old lawyer and rancher with land interests, also stressed economic policies, calling for various measures to promote diversfied development and create additonal jobs in the state.
Senator Pete V. Domenici, a third-term Republican, crushed his challenger, Democratic State Senator Tom R. Benavides.
 
OREGON
After four terms in the Senate, Mark O. Hatfield, the Republican once best known as a dove on defense issues, defeated Harry Lonsdale, a wealthy Democratic businessman with environmental credentials. But Mr. Lonsdale's appeal forced Mr. Hatfield into an aggressive and uncharacteristically negative campaign.
In the race for governor, Attorney General David Frohnmayer, a Republican, went into the campaign a favorite to succeed Gov. Neil Goldschmidt, a Democrat who is retiring. But by the end of the campaign, Secretary of State Barbara Roberts, a Democrat, came on strong.
Support for Mr. Frohnmayer was partly eroded by a third candidate, Al Mobley, a conservative-independent who emphasized his opposition to abortion.
In the northwest corner of the state, Mike Kopetski, a Democrat, mounted another strong campaign against Representative Denny Smith, a Republican. Mr. Kopetski fell just 707 votes short of Mr. Smith two years ago. This time, Mr. Smith was hurt by a combination of bad publicity over his links to the savings and loan industry, a heavy-handed radio advertisement that featured sound of a Hitler rally as Mr. Smith accused Mr. Kopetski of "appeasement," and Mr. Smith's support of the timber industry.
Democrats currently control both the House and Senate, but the loss of only two House seats would cost them control there and give the Republicans a chance to influence redistricting next year.
 
UTAH
Representative Wayne Owens of Salt Lake City, who has been the only Democrat in Utah's delegation, defeated a challenge from Genevieve Atwood, a 44-year old Republican who is a former state representative and former state geologist.
Another Democrat, Bill Orton, will join the delegation, in the Provo seat left open by Representative Howard C. Nielson, a Republican who is retiring. Mr. Orton, a tax lawyer and first-time candidate, won a battle for the traditionally Republican seat by defeating former State Senator Karl Snow, a professor and administrator at Brigham Young University, who was the subject of a Provo Herald investigation into his ownership of certain stocks and his business association with a convicted felon.
 
WASHINGTON
 Two spirited House contests and ballot refer endums on tax limita tions and the environ ment confronted the voters.
 From the moment that Representative Jolene Unsoeld was elected to Congress in 1988 by only 618 votes, she became a leading target of the Republicans. Her opponent was Bob Williams, a former State Representative. He accused Mrs.Unsoeld of being a typical "tax and spend liberal." She said Mr. Williams was anti-environment and conservative.
 In another contest, Representative John Miller, a conservative Republican in his third term representing the First Congressional District in northern Seattle, was challenged by Cynthia Sullivan, a member of the King County Council. She said Mr. Miller had neglected local problems, including traffic congestion, and voted wrong on environmental issues. But his endorsement by the Sierra Club and the League of Conservation Voters deflated that issue.
The ballot included proposals to limit property taxes to 1 percent of the true value of property and to give preferred treatment to properties that complied with safety and health standards or had low-income housing.
 
WYOMING
Wyoming Democrats conceded they never had much chance of defeating Senator Alan K. Simpson, a national figure who is the second most powerful Republican in the Senate. The best candidate they could come up with was Kathy Helling, a 32-year-old sociology major at the University of Wyoming who defeated five other equally unknown primary candidates.
It was a lopsided contest. Mrs. Helling spent about $6,000 on her losing campaign, compared with more than $1 million raised by Mr. Simpson.
In Wyoming's sole Congressional district, Craig Thomas, a Republican who was chosen in a special election last year to replace Dick Cheney when he was named Secretary of Defense, ran against Peter Maxfield, a Democratic lawyer.
Gov. Michael Sullivan, a Democrat, won re-election, defeating Mary Mead.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 7, 1990

SECTION: Section B; Page 4; Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 1466 words

HEADLINE: The 1990 Elections: State By State;
South

 BODY:

ALABAMA
Senator Howell Heflin, 69 years old, a Democrat, beat Republican, State Senator Bill Cabaniss, 52.
Mr. Cabaniss sought to depict Mr. Heflin as lacking concern for the environment. In rebuttal, Mr. Heflin emphasized his own concern for a forest in the state.
The Republican Governor, Guy Hunt, 57, overcame his Democratic opponent, Paul Hubbert.
Democrats contended that Mr. Hunt's campaign had a racial component meant to stir his conservative supporters.
 
ARKANSAS
Bill Clinton won a fifth term as Governor, defeating Sheffield Nelson, a former executive at a natural gas company. Mr. Clinton, a Democrat, was the beneficiary of a bruising Republican primary that left the Republican nominee weakened.
Senator David Pryor, the Democratic incumbent, ran unopposed, and the state's three incumbent members of the House of Representatives -- Democrats Bill Alexander and Beryl Anthony Jr., and Republican John Paul Hammerschmidt -- all won. In the 2d Congressional District encompassing Little Rock, former Representative Ray Thornton, a Democrat, beat Jim Keet, a Republican State Representative.
 
FLORIDA
Former Senator Lawton Chiles defeated the incumbent Republican Governor, Bob Martinez, in a race that in its final weeks focused largely on abortion.
Supporters of abortion rights were upset last year when Mr. Martinez tried to have the Legislature place new restrictions on abortions. The effort failed.
Senator Chiles, a Democrat who is one of the most popular political figures in the state, reluctantly supports abortion rights. Although he was widely seen as the victor in last week's televised debate with Governor Martinez, he was hurt among some voters because of his acknowledged use of a powerful anti-depressive drug.
In another hotly contested race, Representative Bill Grant of Tallahassee was defeated by Pete Peterson, a Democrat who is a retired Air Force colonel. Shortly after his re-election in 1988, Mr. Grant switched parties and became a Republican, a move Mr. Peterson painted as a breach of faith with voters.
Florida is expected to be one of the big winners in Congressional reapportionment next year. The state could pick up as many as four seats in the House, and Democrats in the Legislature will control the redistricting.
 
LOUISIANA
Democrats had hopes of defeating Senator Mitch McConnell, who won a narrow victory in 1984 in this heavily Democratic state. But Mr. McConnell, who showed himself to be a deft campaigner and used his incumbency to his advantage, won easily over his Democratic challenger, Havey I. Sloane, former Mayor of Louisville. Incumbents won all seven of their House races.
 
GEORGIA
 Senator Sam Nunn, the Democrat who heads the Armed Services Com mittee, was unopposed in his quest for a fourth term, but there were enough bruising races to excite the voters. Zell Miller, the Democratic Lieutenant Governor, won the contest for governor against Johnny Isakson, the State House Minority Leader, the strongest gubernatorial candidate that the Republicans have fielded in years. The incumbent, Joe Frank Harris, was ineligible to run for a third term.
 Representative Newt Gingrich, the House Republican whip who led a revolt against a White House-approved budget compromise, ran in a tough race against David Worley, whom he handily defeated in 1988. In another race, Representative Doug Barnard, a Democrat, won re-election to an eighth term despite his problems explaining his ties to savings and loan institutions, which became a major issue raised by Sam Jones, his Republican opponent. Mr. Barnard is chairman of a subcommittee that oversees savings institutions. He had to explain why he accepted $20,000 in campaign contributions from Charles H. Keating Jr., who has been indicted for his role in the savings and loan scandal.
 
MISSISSIPPI
After defeating a strong Democratic opponent, former Gov. William F. Winter, to win a second term in 1984 vote, Mississippi's senior Senator, Thad Cochran, was in such a strong political position this year that no serious candidate chose to oppose him. Mr. Cochran was the first Republican to win a Mississippi Senate seat in the 1900's and the first Republican to win a statewide majority since Reconstruction. He did it again this year.
Republican Trent Lott, is elected in 1988 to replace the retiring John C. Stennis, is the other senator.
 Jamie L. Whitten, a veteran Democratic Representative first elected in 1941, was relelected once more.
 
NORTH CAROLINA
In the nasty Senate race, the incumbent Republican, Jesse Helms, defeated Harvey Gantt, the former Mayor of Charlotte, with about 54 percent of the vote. Mr. Gantt had hoped to become the first black Senator from the South since Reconstruction.
Political analysts said Mr. Gantt had been hurt by Senator Helms's late television commercials portraying the Democrat as an advocate of racial employment quotas. Democratic organizers said Mr. Helms's campaign, with its dependence on racial themes, offended black and white voters alike.
Representative David E. Price, a Democrat, was re-elected despite a well-financed campaign by a Raleigh businessman, John H. Carrington. Mr. Carrington scored with some voters by focusing on Mr. Price's ties to the savings and loan industry. The incumbent relied on a strong Gantt turnout.
 
OKLAHOMA
 In a three-way guber natorial contest that was bitterly contested, Democratic candidate David Walters was the winner. A 38-year-old Roman Catholic, Mr. Walters supported a woman's right to choose an abortion and took a hard line against new taxes.
 Republican Bill Price, a former United States Attorney, opposed new taxes and abortion. The dark horse in the racewas Thomas Ledger wood, a lawyer who has been a registered inde pendent since he was 21.
 Democratic Senator David L. Boren easily won a third term with popularity that transcended party lines and a $1 million campaign fund.
 
SOUTH CAROLINA
An F.B.I. bribery investigation transformed normally routine elections for the State Legislature into competitive races as voters screamed for new state ethics and disclosure laws.
Republican Senator Strom Thurmond, who has 45 years of experience in the Senate, defeated the Democratic contender, Bob Cunningham, a retired intelligence officer. At the end of his new term, Mr. Thurmond would be be 94 years old and the oldest man ever to serve in the Senate.
Democratic Representative Butler Derrick won his ninth term in Congress, despite Republican strength in neighboring districts. Democratic Representative Liz J. Patterson overcame similar odds against Ray Haskett.
 
TENNESSEE
Despite all the talk of the perils of incumbency, a number of office holders were easily re-elected. Senator Al Gore trounced his Republican rival, William R. Hawkins, a Knoxville economist, while Gov. Neal McWherter, was the victor over Dwight Henry, a Republican state lawmaker. All nine members of the House from Tennessee, expected to win re-election, including including Harold E. Ford, a Democrat from Memphis whose trial on Federal bank and mail fraud charges ended in a deadlocked jury in April.
 
TEXAS
In one of the nation's most rancorous gubernatorial contests, Ann Richards, the State Treasurer, a Democrat, defeated Republican Clayton Williams, a wealthy rancher and businessman. Ms. Richards won a bitter three-way primary in which she was accused of past drug use, while Mr. Williams admitted going to prostitutes as a youth and joked about rape. In the last week of the campaign, Mr. Williams acknowledged that he paid no income tax in 1986 and confessed his ignorance of a proposed constitutional amendment.
Senator Phil Gramm, a Republican, easily won re-election in a well-financed campaign against State Senator Hugh Parmer, a Democrat. Mr. Gramm is best known as a sponsor of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget bill.
 
VIRGINIA
Republican Senator John W. Warner easily won a third term, with no Democratic candidate opposing him. Senator Warner's only opposition was Nancy B. Spannaus, a supporter of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., who was listed on the ballot as an independent and took only a small fraction of the vote.
Former Gov. Gerald L. Baliles, a Democrat who left office early this year, would not run for the Senate, and his successor, L. Douglas Wilder, advised his party to abandon the race rather than run a candidate who would be crushed.
Stan Parris, a 61-year old conservative Republican, lost his House seat to James P. Moran Jr., the 45-year-old Democratic Mayor of Alexandria. In Charlottesville, Representative D. French Slaughter Jr., a Republican, won his fourth term in Congress, fighting off David M. Smith.

THE ECONOMY
 Savings and loans are trying to get state laws enacted to allow them to convert into savings banks. Regulators see an attempt to evade strict new Federal rules -- laws the S.& L.'s say are so onerous they can no longer do business under them. [Page D1.]
The productivity of American workers climbed at the fastest pace in two years during the July-September quarter, but hours worked fell, the Government said. [D24.]
 
COMPANIES
Burger King took out large newspaper ads to say it "wishes to go on record as supporting traditional American values on television," thus ending a boycott by a religious group. [D1.]
Columbia Savings reported a $352 million loss for its third quarter after taking a large write-down in "junk bonds." [D5.]
CS Holdings will help bail out First Boston by buying as much as 44 percent of the firm's outstanding bridge loans. [D6.]
Prudential-Bache is dismissing as many as two-thirds of its 180 investment bankers, raising questions about the future of its chairman, George Ball. [D6.]
The National Association of Black Journalists rescinded a decision to provide The Daily News with its mailing list. [B12.]
Wal-Mart Stores will acquire Wholesale Club, which operates 27 membership clubs, for $21 a share, or $178 million. [D4.]
 
 INTERNATIONAL
Members of the European Community agreed that reductions in agricultural subsidies should be part of their negotiating position in the current trade talks. [D1.]
The European Community's agreement on the terms of a proposal for cutting barriers to farm trade was greeted with cautious enthusiasm at GATT. [D7.]
 
 BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY
Newsprint makers are rushing into recycling. After showing little interest for years, they are investing $1.5 billion to $2 billion in equipment that will allow them to use scrap paper as well as trees as raw material. [D9.]
The lonely cashier in the one-hour photo booth may become even lonelier after automated machines are installed in several malls and supermarkets next year. [D9.]
 
 MARKETS
The price of oil meandered in slow trading but finished with a gain of 67 cents, to $32.63. [D2.]
Stocks tumbled after an unexpected rise in commodities prices that pushed bonds lower. The Dow lost 17.08, to 2,485.l5. [D10.]
The largest auctions ever of Treasury debt started off well, as a wide spectrum of investors easily absorbed a record $12.5 billion in three-year notes. [D16.]
The dollar rose on worry about the Middle East and on technical buying. [D17.] Precious metals markets rallied. [D17.]
Leaders of New York's commodities exchanges said they would recommend that their headquarters be built in Manhattan. [B11.]

Ralph R. Papitto is leaving Nortek, a company he built on debt and whose continued operations, some analysts say, are threatened by that debt. As a going-away present, Mr. Papitto is receiving $16 million. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D1.]
A regulatory proposal to lengthen A.T.&T.'s leash is drawing howls of protest from competitors that have only recently grown comfortably profitable. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
Mexico is trying to change its image and has enlisted the singer Linda Ronstadt in a $10 million tourism campaign emphasizing its cultural heritage. Kim Foltz: Advertising. [D19.]

HEADLINE: Upset by Beggars, Washington Is Arresting Them

BYLINE: By IRVIN MOLOTSKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6

 BODY:
Responding to complaints about panhandlers on the street, District of Columbia police officials said today that they had been using an almost-forgotten law to arrest beggars.
Capt. Bruce McDonald, a police commander, said that nine panhandlers had been arrested since Oct. 3 in the affluent business and residential areas of Georgetown and Dupont Circle. 
 There have been complaints that the arrests are unconstitutional. The Supreme Court has ruled in several cases that charitable solicitation is protected by the First Amendment's guarantee of free speech.
But the Justices have not applied those precedents to panhandling for personal benefit. When a Federal district judge in New York, Leonard B. Sand, ruled that begging in the subway was protected by the First Amendment, the ruling was overturned by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. The Supreme Court will decide later this year whether to hear the case.
 
Upholding of Law Predicted
 The Washington Police Department's general counsel, Geraldine R. Gennet, said today that the local ordinance, which has been on the books for decades, "should withstand scrutiny and be constitutionally valid."
There was no public announcement of the decision to make the arrests, but Captain McDonald told a Dupont Circle neighborhood association about it Monday night and confirmed his account in an interview today. The maximum penalty for panhandling is 90 days in jail and a $300 fine, but Captain McDonald said all the charges in the arrests had been dropped.
At the civic association meeting, Captain McDonald was asked if the police had heard any complaints from the American Civil Liberties Union. He replied, "No, but I'm sure we will."
Asked about it today, Arthur B. Spitzer, legal director of the local chapter of the civil liberties union, said he had not heard of the arrests but asserted, "It sounds unconstitutional to me."
"If somebody says to you, 'Buddy, can you spare a dime?' that's no less free speech than if he says, 'Buddy, can you spare a dime for cancer research?' " Mr. Spitzer added that his group was likely to challenge the ordinance.
An illegal vagrant is defined by the ordinance as "any person wandering abroad and begging, or who goes about from door to door or places himself in or on any highway, passage or other public place to beg or receive alms."
 
Public Complaints Increasing
 Ms. Gennet said the Police Department decided to start using the ordinance because of rising complaints from the public about begging. She added that the police were encouraged by the Federal appeals court decision in the New York City case against soliciting on the subway.
Then a City Council member, John Wilson, proposed a law outlawing abusive panhandling. The city's lawyers, while researching his request, found that the old statute, passed in 1941 and modifed in 1953, was still on the books.
Regarding the position that the courts have held that begging is constitutionally protected as a manifestation of free speech, Ms. Gennet said: "The concern is that free speech be protected. The Court has never held that begging under any circumstance has to be protected free speech."
Officer Quentin Peterson, a Police Department spokesman, said the citywide arrest totals for begging had not been calculated, but Captain McDonald said there were more in police districts other than his.
"It's gotten out of hand in D.C.," he said. "We've got a lot of complaints."
Mr. Spitzer of the civil liberties union said of the increase in panhandling: "That's an unfortunate cost of urban society and the economy -- problems of homelessness and unemployment. The District of Columbia jails are overflowing. It is hard to justify putting a lot of police and prison resources into panhandling.
"People aren't panhandling for fun."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The District of Columbia police, responding to complaints about homeless people, have been arresting beggars for the past month. A panhandler sat with his sign in 1987 at an intersection in Washington. (Marty Katz for The New York Times)
