HEADLINE: The 1990 Elections: State By State;
Northeast

 BODY:

CONNECTICUT
Lowell P. Weicker Jr., erstwhile Senate maverick, used his strong local appeal to capture the anti-incumbent fever that swept through the electorate and win the election.
Running as an independent, the three-term former Senator defeated the Democratic nominee, Representative Bruce A. Morrison, and the Republican candidate, Representative John G. Rowland.
The House seat abandoned by Mr. Morrison was won by Rosa DeLauro, 47, a Democrat who has never held elective office, in a close contest with State Senator Thomas Scott, 32, a conservative Republican.
Mr. Rowland's vacated seat was filled by fellow Republican Gary Frank, a 37-year-old alderman from Waterbury who beat Toby Moffett. a former Democratic Representative, in a close race.
 
DELAWARE
In the "Small Wonder" state, two well-established, well-financed incumbents faced political neophytes who were trying to take advantage of voters' feelings against career politicians.
In the race for the United States Senate, the 47-year-old Democratic incumbent, Joseph R. Biden, Jr., faced M. Jane Brady, a 39-year-old Republican who is chief prosecutor for Sussex County. Ms. Brady called for Congress to be transformed into a citizens' Legislature with a two-term limit; Mr. Biden campaigned on his record. Delaware has only 297,000 registered voters; Democrats hold a slight advantage.
Fighting over Delaware's single seat in the House was the three-term Democratic incumbent, Thomas R. Carper, and Ralph O. Williams, a real estate developer. The savings and loan crisis was a primary issue in the campaign. Mr. Carper is a member of the House Banking Committee, and Mr. Williams is a former president of a savings and loan association.
 
DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA
District of Columbia voters put an outsider, Sharon Pratt Dixon, into the Mayor's seat while turning back Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr.'s bid for electoral redemption in the wake of his misdemeanor conviction on a drug possession charge.
With Democrats outnumbering republicans 9 to 1, Ms. Dixon had no trouble defeating former Police Chief Maurice T. Turner to become the first black woman chosen to run a major city.
Mr. Barry, sentenced to six months in prison last month, ran a distant third in his bid to take one of the two at-large seats on the City Council.
Eleanor Holmes Norton, a Democrat plagued by her failure to file local tax returns, defeated Harry M. Singleton, a Republican, to take the job as the District's non-voting delegate in the House.
The Rev. Jesse Jackson easily won the job as the city's "shadow senator" post to lobby in the Senate for statehood for the city.
 
MAINE
 The contest for gover nor was termed a race between two incum bents. And indeed, the candidates -- Gov. John R. McKernan Jr., the Republican, and Representative Joseph E. Brennan, the former Governor -- are well known and well financed.
 Mr. Brennan excoriated his opponent in 30-second television advertisements for his handling of the state budget. Mr. McKernan charged that Mr. Brennan had flip-flopped on his sup port for Maine Yankee, the state's nuclear power plant.
Senator William S. Cohen, the Republican incumbent, defeated State Representative Neil Rolde. In the race to replace Mr. Brennan in Maine's First Congressional District, Thomas H. Andrews, a liberal Democrat who had built one of the strongest grass-roots organizations in the state, easily defeated David F. Emery, a conservative Republican, who held the seat from 1975 until he engaged in a disastrous run for the Senate in 1982 against George J. Mitchell.
Mr. Emery angered anti-abortion advocates by switching from an anti-abortion stance to one supporting a woman's right to an abortion.
 
MARYLAND
The incumbent Governor, William Donald Schaefer, a 69-year-old Democrat and ex-Mayor of Baltimore, defeated his Republican opponent, William S. Shepard, a retired Foreign Service officer.
In the state's First Congressional District, the five-term incumbent Democrat, Roy P. Dyson, 41, was defeated by his Republican challenger, Wayne T. Gilchrest, a 44-year-old high school teacher who also ran against him in 1988.
Mr. Dyson had been renominated by his party despite the dislosure that he had been a conscientious objector at the time of the Vietnam War.
Mr. Gilchrest won a Purple Heart as a Marine in Vietnam.
Mr. Gilchrest's support for abortion rights was earlier thought to have lost him some Republican backing.
In addition, Mr. Gilchrest had more liberal positions than Mr. Dyson on some other issues.
 
MASSACHUSETTS
 After a duel that riveted the state's atten tion, John R. Silber, the Boston University presi dent, who ran as the tart-tongued Democratic candidate, conceded vic tory to his Republican opponent, William F. Weld, the former United States Attorney, who served in the Justice De partment in the Reagan Administration.
 Mr. Weld was helped by Dr. Silber's blunt personality, which drove many of the state's Democratic voters to abandon their party.
 Both gubernatorial candidates favored approval of Question 3, a tax rollback referendum that would have slashed state revenue by about $1.1 billion through cuts in various fees and taxes, but the voters defeated the proposition.
Senator John Kerry, a Democrat, managed to distance himself from Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, whom he served as Lieutenant Governor from 1982 to 1984, and defeat the Republican, Jim Rappaport.
Only one House member, Chester G. Atkins, a Democrat from the Fifth District, had faced a serious threat. His opponent was State Representative John F. MacGovern.
 
NEW HAMPSHIRE
Representative Robert C. Smith, widely considered the heir apparent to retiring Republican Senator Gordon J. Humphrey, defeated former Senator John A. Durkin to keep the Senate seat for the Republicans. This was one of three Senate seats around the country that had been left open by retiring Republicans.
The Democrats also were not able to unseat the Republican Governor, Judd Gregg, who easily outpaced his Democratic challenger, Joseph Grandmaison.
Pounding rain and heavy winds kept some voters away early Tuesday. There was a close fight for Mr. Smith's First District seat, which was won by the Republican, William Zeliff, an innkeeper who carried a jar of pennies on the campaign trail and portrayed himself a penny-pinching tightwad.
 
NEW JERSEY
Senator Bill Bradley defeated Christine Todd Whitman by an unexpectedly slim margin even though he had greatly outspent the virtually unknown Republican candidate.
Throughout the campaign, Mrs. Whitman, a former state official, tried to link Mr. Bradley to the $2.8 billion tax package pushed through the Legislature by Gov. James J. Florio, a Democrat, in his first six months in office.
The new taxes triggered a taxpayer revolt that became the focus of every state, county and local race on Tuesday. Mr. Bradley often found himself ducking attempts to be aligned with Mr. Florio and the tax changes.
Incumbents in 12 of the 14 Congressional Districts were considered safe, but there were tough races in the districts once held by Mr. Florio and his opponent in last year's election for governor, Representative Jim Courter. In Mr. Florio's former First District seat, the Democrat, Robert E. Andrews, the Camden County Freeholder Director, won despite being criticized for his connection to the Governor. In the 12th District, State Senator Richard Zimmer, a Republican, outdistanced Marguerite Chandler.
New Jersey lost one Congressional seat after the 1980 census and is expected to lose another this year.
 
NEW YORK
Without a Senate race this year, considerable attention focused on New York's campaign for governor. But this was not because Mario M. Cuomo, the Democratic incumbent, was in any kind of jeopardy of losing his bid for a third term.
Opponents for the 58-year-old Governor and Queens native were Pierre A. Rinfret, a Republican reluctantly running on the Republican ticket, and Herbert London, a Republican running on the Conservative Party ticket. Mr. Rinfret was trying to stave off a third-place finish for the Republicans, which would cost the party its prized spot on the second row of all ballots in New York for the next four years as well as joint control with the Democrats of every County Board of Elections in the state.
 
PENNSYLVANIA
In an upset, Representative Doug Walgren, a seven-term Democratic Congressman from Pittsburgh, lost to a political neophyte, Richard Santorum, a 32-year-old Republican lawyer who ran on an anti-incumbent theme.
Gov. Robert P. Casey, a popular Democrat and Pennsylvania's first Governor in 43 years not to raise taxes, was re-elected to a second term. His Republican opponent, State Auditor General Barbara Hafer, failed to win much support or money, even from within her own party in this largely Democratic state.
The race initially appeared to be referendum on abortion, with Mr. Casey opposing almost all abortions and Mrs. Hafer supporting a woman's right to abortion. But the issue largely faded behind more immediate concerns like education and the economy.
Redistricting is expected to cost Pennsylvania 2 of its 23 seats in the House, and how the political map will be redrawn depended on a handful of close races for the State Legislature.
Ballot initiatives sought voter approval for selling bonds to build prisons and buy equipment for firefighters and ambulance services.
 
RHODE ISLAND
Bruce G. Sundlun, a 70-year-old Democratic broadcasting executive, was elected Governor, defeating the incumbent, Edward D. DiPrete, a 56-year-old Republican in a heavily Democratic state.
Mr. Sundlun lost to Mr. DiPrete in the last two races for governor, but only by a narrow margin in 1988.
Mr. DiPrete's popularity began a free fall that year, after his family made $2 million in a single day on a real estate transaction in Cranston, where Mr. DiPrete had served as Mayor.
Claiborne Pell, a Democrat who has spent 39 of his 71 years in the Senate, won another term. He defeated Claudine Schneider, a 43-year-old Republican, who gave up her seat in the House.
The state has only two seats in the House. Ronald K. Machtley, the Republican incumbent, defeated Scott Wolf, a Democratic political consultant. In the contest over the seat vacated by Ms. Schneider, State Representative Jack Reed, a Democrat, defeated Trudy Coxe, a Republican who has been involved in environmental issues.
 
VERMONT
Bernard Sanders, a socialist who ran as an independent, won Vermont's only Congressional seat, upsetting the incumbent, Peter Smith, a Republican. Mr. Sanders, who was Mayor of Burlington from 1981 to 1989, toned down his Marxist slogans and ran on a populist platform attacking Washington politicians.
Richard A. Snelling, the popular four-term Republican Governor from 1976 to 1984, was elected to another term. He defeated Peter F. Welch, the first Democratic President pro tempore of the Republican-controlled State Senate.
Mr. Snelling, who is 63 years old and owns an investment business, tried to project an image as a fiscal conservative and prudent manager. Mr. Welch, 43, sought to undermine Mr. Snelling's campaign with negative advertising that portrayed Mr. Snelling as a wealthy businessman out of touch with the concerns of most Vermonters.
Governor Madeleine M. Kunin, a Democrat, did not seek re-election.
 
WEST VIRGINIA
Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th coasted into his second term, handily defeating John Yoder, a lawyer from Harper's Ferry.
 Mr. Rockefeller, who spent most of his first term working on unglamorous health, transportaion and economic issues affecting the state, defused Mr. Yoder's campaign charges that he was a "captive of special interests."
 Voters in the mountains of the Second Congressional District rejected Oliver Luck's attempt to capitalize on his fame as a quarterback at the University of West Virginia.
 He was defeated by Representative Harley O. Staggers Jr., who will return to Washington for a fifth term in the House.

HEADLINE: Burger King Ads Help End Boycott by Religious Group

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
It was a puzzling declaration with an even more puzzling provenance. The Burger King Corporation, without explanation, took out large advertisements in newspapers all over the country to say that the fast-food company "wishes to go on record as supporting traditional American values on television."
The advertisements, which ran Sunday and Monday, grew out of a skirmish between Burger King and a religious group, the Christian Leadership for Responsible Television. Earlier in the year, the group had accused the company of sponsoring television shows that were "against family values" and began a boycott of the chain on Sept. 1. 
 One of the founders of the group, known as Clear-TV, was Donald Wildmon, who has successfully lobbied other major corporations over what he regarded as objectionable programming.
Clear-TV had complained that the "anti-family" programs that Burger King commercials helped to support showed "gratuitous sex, violence and anti-Christian stereotyping." Neither Billy Melvin, chairman of Clear-TV, nor Cori Zywotow, a Burger King spokeswoman, would identify the programs.
After two meetings lasting nearly three hours each at Burger King's Miami headquarters last week, Clear-TV and Burger King settled their differences. As a result, Burger King ran the half-page ads, with the title "An Open Letter to the American People," in several hundred newspapers, including The Los Angeles Times, The Miami Herald, The New York Times and USA Today.
"We were pleased with the results of the talks," Ms. Zywotow said. "It's better not to be boycotted than to be boycotted." She said Burger King did not change its advertising policy as a result of the talks.
But some said they were shocked by Burger King's action. "This is unbelievable," said Jeff Cohen, executive director of Fairness and Accuracy in Reporting, a media-monitoring group. "It's the equivalent of a loyalty oath. A major corporation takes out a major advertisement nationwide to say nothing, except the magic code words to assuage these interest groups."
 
Responding to Protest
 The skirmish also illustrates how, in an uncertain economy, and in this case, in the slow-growing fast-food industry, large corporations are quick to respond to even a flicker of consumer protest to keep from losing any potential sales.
This appears to be so even though Burger King and the group agreed that the two-month-old boycott was ineffective. Ms. Zywotow of Burger King said the protest had "no impact" on Burger King's restaurant revenue, which analysts estimate will total $5.9 billion this year.
Burger King is a division of the Pillsbury Company, which is owned by Britain's Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. The chain has more than 6,000 restaurants worldwide, about 90 percent of which are in the United States. It is the world's second-largest hamburger chain after McDonald's.
Mr. Melvin of Clear-TV agreed that the boycott led by his group, which claims millions of members, had little economic effect. "Burger King wanted to talk to us so fast that we just didn't get a chance to hype the boycott," he said.
 
Coalition of Groups
 Clear-TV, based in Wheaton, Ill., is a coalition of 1,600 Protestant ministers, Roman Catholic priests and other Christian leaders. The group says these leaders' congregations and parishes represent 60 million people.
In January, Clear-TV planned pressure on corporate advertisers by having 3,000 members in 33 states watch prime-time television during the spring "sweeps" season. This is the period when advertising rates are determined on the basis of network studies of viewership.
Clear-TV identified what it called the 10 worst offending corporate sponsors of what it considered objectionable television shows. Except for Burger King, Mr. Melvin did not identify the companies.
The group said seven companies persuaded it that they were just as interested in family values as Clear-TV. Burger King was not among the seven because it said letters from Clear-TV were sent to an office of its corporate parent in New Jersey instead of Burger King's Miami base.
 
'Pre-Screening' Policies
 Mr. Melvin did not say why Clear-TV had made Burger King a target for a boycott out of the three companies that did not respond. He said one of the goals of Clear-TV was to pursuade corporations to "pre-screen" individual shows they sponsor for objectionable content.
Burger King, which said it pre-screens all shows it sponsors, plans to spend about $215 million this year on advertising and promotions. Its advertising is handled by D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, and Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising, both of New York.
Louis E. Bradley, vice president of Advertising Information Services Inc., said he was not aware of an upsurge in corporate concern over things like "anti-Christian stereotyping." His company uses screeners to alert advertisers to potential problems: for instance, a beer maker advertising on a show that depicts drunken driving.

HEADLINE: C.D.'s and Bank Funds Fall

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on bank certificates of deposit and money market accounts fell for the week that ended yesterday.
The Chase Manhattan Bank said its customers were still attracted to the shorter maturities, those of less than a year, because of the uncertainty of the times. 
 At the Treasury's Department's regular weekly bill auction on Monday, where the results often indicate what many banks may eventually pay on money market accounts and certificates of deposit, rates were down for the second straight week.
 
3-Month Bill at 7.07%
 The average discount rate at auction for a new three-month bill this week was 7.07 percent, down by 5 basis points from the previous auction. For a six-month bill, the average rate was 7.05 percent, down by 8 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
In its weekly survey of New York area commercial banks and savings institutions, The Bank Rate Monitor said that yields on certificates of deposit at commercial banks declined more than those at savings institutions. The average commercial bank money market account fell by a basis point, to 6.15 percent, while three-month and six-month certificates fell 2 basis points each, to 7.64 percent and 7.70 percent, respectively.
Yields at savings institutions, though lower, were still higher than those at commercial banks. The average money market account was off by a basis point, to 6.35 percent and a three-month certificate down by 2 basis points, to 7.75 percent, and a six-month certificate unchanged at 7.82 percent.
Outside the New York area and among 20 large banks nationwide, the yields were also down. The average yield on a money market account fell by 2 basis points, to 6.23 percent, and the average on a six-month certificate was down by the same, to 7.42 percent.
 
More Institutions Cutting Rates
 Among the more than 100 leading banks and savings institutions in 10 large markets nationally, the number of institutions lowering rates on deposits in the last two weeks has risen dramtically.
Meanwhile, the Treasury, which competes with banks for deposit money through the issuance of savings bonds, said it had set the semiannual market-based interest rate for United States savings bonds, in effect from Nov. 1, 1990, through April 30, 1991, at 7.19 percent. The new rates were up from the previous rate of 7.01 percent, which was in effect from May through October 1990.
Savings bonds semiannual rates are adjusted each May 1 and Nov. 1 to reflect market activity during the preceding six months.

HEADLINE: Conference on Climate Singles Out U.S. as Wastrel of Energy

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, Nov. 6

 BODY:
The United States was depicted as the great polluter among rich nations today at a gathering of about 80 environment ministers, environmental campaigners and industry specialists.
All industrial nations except the United States have come to the Second World Climate Conference here with freshly set targets to slow down or to reverse their output of carbon dioxide, the gas thought to be the main culprit in what could be a dangerous warming of the earth's atmosphere. 
 While renewed warnings from scientists, gathered here last week, set the tone for today's debate, most politicians from industrial countries said they had made their pledges because it is good business.
Government representatives from Western Europe, Japan, New Zealand and Australia said that studies in the last year had shown that they could stabilize and eventually cut back carbon dioxide output at no extra cost to the overall economy. They said they could achieve their targets through new laws and regulations that would force people and industry to use energy more efficiently.
 
Thatcher Criticizes U.S. Approach
 Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, who has departed from the Bush Administration's skepticism about the need for immediate action, today chided Washington at the conference by saying a clear case already existed for taking immediate precautions. "The need for more research should not be an excuse for much needed action now," she said.
She seemed to express a majority view here when she argued that in any event, it was sensible to improve energy efficency and use energy prudently, to develop alternative sources of supply, to replant forests, to re-examine industrial processes and to tackle waste disposal. France's Prime Minister, Michel Rocard, and Germany's Environment Minister, Klaus Topfer, made similar pleas.
European officials here complained that American energy prices were too low and provided no incentive for conservation.
Rather than setting back industry, Germany and Japan have argued, the new program will stimulate industry through the development of new technology.
"What we are all talking about is straightforward energy policy," said Pier Vellinga, who is in charge of climate policy in the Netherlands. "It will mean redirecting investments, not building more power plants or digging more coal, and becoming less dependent on oil."
 
All Getting Similar Findings
 Referring to studies on the economic impact of reducing carbon dioxide emissions made in the European Community, Scandinavia and other areas, he said, "We have all done them and we are all coming up with the same results."
Under the programs to combat global warming announced in more than 20 nations in recent days, governments have committed themselves to targets ranging from slowing down emissions of carbon dioxide to reversing the rate. These nations together account for close to 19 percent of the world's carbon dioxide output, while the United States accounts for close to 22 percent.
Germany has the most drastic objectives. Outlining a plan already approved in part by the German Parliament, Mr. Topfer said steps would include new laws requiring greater insulation of buildings, improvements in public transportation and making power plants more efficient. It would also mean levying taxes on most carbon dioxide emissions, including additional taxes on fossil fuels.
Next on the scale of cutbacks is Denmark, which hopes to produce 20 percent less carbon dioxide than it does today by the year 2005, and 50 percent less by 2030. The Netherlands intends to stabilize its output by 1994 and cut back to 5 percent of present levels by the year 2000.
The United States has calculated that if present trends continue, the nation's carbon dioxide emissions will have increased 15 percent by 2000.

HEADLINE: Islamic Politics Drive Away Allies of the Sudan

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Nov. 2

 BODY:
Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, came here not long ago for what was supposed to be a celebration of his Sudanese neighbors' decision to adopt, in part, his political system.
Instead, Colonel Qaddafi delivered a frosty lecture to the Islamic fundamentalist junta last month about the folly of mixing religion and politics. Surprisingly, Colonel Qaddafi became the instant hero of the Sudanese underground opposition. 
 Colonel Qaddafi's disdain for much that the 16-month-old Government stands for underlined the increasing political isolation of the Sudan in the Arab world and among its longtime allies in the West.
The Sudan's growing isolation is a product of its Islamic fundamentalist politics, with the accompanying drive to establish a theocracy, and its sympathetic stand toward Iraq. The fact that the Sudan is one of only two countries to be declared not to be cooperating with the International Monetary Fund does not help either, diplomats here said.
The largest country on the African continent and a nation dominated by a mostly Arab population, the Sudan was until 1985 one of the largest recipients of Washington's economic and military aid in the Arab world. After the Government of President Gaafar al-Nimeiri was overthrown in 1985, the aid gradually diminished until this year, when Washington refused to deliver any new economic aid and cut the last remnants of military aid.
Washington has said it will help the Sudan with food to help it avert what many relief officials say will be a devestating famine next year, but only on the condition that the Sudan stop its obstruction of humanitarian aid.
The Sudan's traditional Arab allies, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Egypt, angered at the junta's refusal to join the alliance against Iraq, have also turned away from the Sudan. The Saudis and the Kuwaitis feel particularly bitter, Arab diplomats said, because it was through relationships with Saudi banks and Kuwaiti financial institutions that the Muslim Brotherhood, the fundamentalist organization behind the junta, won its extraordinary wealth.
Much of the Brotherhood's money is kept outside the Sudan but is used to recruit an increasing number of young followers, many of whom are turning up in important positions in Government ministries, the Arab diplomats said.
Others are members of Sudan Security, a new Islamic security group that has been arresting suspected opponents, imprisoning them and in some cases applying torture, according to United States officials. The Sudan has about 300 political detainees, and while some have been released, new detainees have been arrested, said Jeffrey Davidow, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs.
Even before the gulf crisis, the Saudis had begun to reduce their oil supply to the Sudan, and now it has been cut to zero, the diplomats said.
The isolation of the Sudan seems to be so complete, the diplomats said, that the Iranian authorities canceled a visit planned for this week by the Sudanese leader, Lieut. Gen. Omar Hassan Ahmed al-Bashir, apparently because the Iranians were not prepared to help out with his shopping list of oil and other requirements.
Diplomats here said Colonel Qaddafi declared his disapproval of the mixture of politics and religion because he is concerned about the surge of Islamic fundamentalism around him, including increases in the strength of fundamentalist parties in Tunisia, Algeria and Egypt as well as in the Sudan, where fundamentalists have succeeded in taking over the Government.
"Qaddafi finds himself surrounded by fundamentalism and he is uncomfortable with this state of affairs," an Arab diplomat said. "They will deprive him of an audience on Arab unity, which he thinks should happen as a counter to the new House of Europe."
The Libyan leader specifically told the Sudanese that they did not need the Muslim Brotherhood to tell them when to pray.
"People here are good Muslims," he was quoted as saying. "I see them praying. What do they need the Muslim Brotherhood for?"

HEADLINE: Book Notes

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell

 BODY:

A Committed Independent
Seymour Lawrence started his independent imprint in 1965 with only one book on his list, "The Ginger Man," by J. P. Donleavy. But before long he published "Ship of Fools," by Katherine Anne Porter, "Selected Poems," by Jorge Luis Borges, "Slaughterhouse-Five," by Kurt Vonnegut, "Trout Fishing in America," by Richard Brautigan, "Going After Cacciato," by Tim O'Brien, "Little Big Man," by Thomas Berger and "Selected Poems" of Pablo Neruda.
Nearly as impressive as the list, however, is the fact that Sam Lawrence has survived as an independent for 25 years, into the era of merger, consolidation and turmoil. Mr. Lawrence did not entirely escape the turmoil; in 1983, after 17 years of association with Dell Publishing, his imprint fell victim to the economy ax wielded by the troubled management team at Doubleday, Dell's owner. After a stop at E. P. Dutton, Mr. Lawrence's imprint has been at Houghton Mifflin for almost three years, still an independent operator. 
 At a party for Mr. Lawrence last week, given by Houghton Mifflin, a handful of authors paid tribute to him, including Mr. O'Brien, Mr. Vonnegut, Jim Harrison and Jayne Anne Phillips. Houghton Mifflin even invited a bookstore owner, John Evans of Lemuria Bookstore in Jackson, Miss., who was described as probably having sold more of Mr. Lawrence's books than any single bookseller. "Sam," he said, "has given the reader a fine bowl of literary gumbo."
Mr. Lawrence's writers described him as a publisher who is passionately committed to writers and writing, but who is not always tolerant of "misguided reviewers" or the publishing bureaucracy. Joseph Kanon, the director of the trade and reference division at Houghton Mifflin, said in his tribute:
"The first time I met Sam Lawrence, he was making an argument on behalf of one of his authors. The last time I spoke with him (this morning) he was doing the same thing. On both occasions, as usual, he got what he wanted."
 
Life in a Greenhouse
 Penguin USA has acquired "Biosphere 2: The Human Experiment," by John Allen. Biosphere 2 is a futuristic ecological project under way in Arizona, run by Space Biosphere Ventures, a private ecological research company Four men and four women, in a test of a possible space environment, will attempt to spend two years in an eight-story greenhouse that contains some 3,800 species of plants as well as fish, chickens, goats and pigs.
The book, by the director of research and development of Space Biospheres Ventures, will be published as a simultaneous Viking hardcover and Penguin paperback in March 1991.
 
Contracts at Penguin
 Penguin figured in the publishing news in a different way this week when the National Writers Union released a copy of the letter that a group of Penguin authors recently sent to Peter Mayer, the company's executive chairman.
The authors who signed the letter, including David Garrow, Ursula Le Guin, Dan Wakefield, Lynne Sharon Schwartz, Gloria Naylor, Jessica Mitford and Grace Paley, asked the house to begin discussions on changes in book contracts. Their letter noted that the Penguin Group had recently signed an agreement with the Society of Authors and with the Writers' Guild of Great Britain, establishing minimum guarantees for a wide range of provisions in contracts signed with members of those organizations.
Among other things, that agreement said that publishing rights must be renegotiated after 10 years. In the United States, the hard-cover publisher retains publishing rights as long as the book is kept in print.
In a reference to Salman Rushdie, the novelist who is under a Muslim threat of death, the letter to Mr. Mayer added, "The Writers Union has great respect for your company, especially in light of your brave stance in the Rushdie affair -- a stance that the Writers Union was outspoken in supporting."
Mr. Mayer is out of the country and could not be reached yesterday for comment. A Penguin spokesman acknowledged receipt of the letter, however, and said the house was studying it.
 
Vintage Ventures
 Vintage Books has had success with an unusual book recently, and it is publishing another book in an unusual manner.
The successful book is "The Road From Coorain," by Jill Ker Conway, a memoir of the author's childhood on an Australian sheep farm. After a first printing of 28,500 copies last August, there are 77,000 in print and it has been on the paperback best-seller list for two months. Around the Vintage offices, it is known as "The Little Book That Could."
LuAnn Walther, the Vintage executive editor, who acquired the paperback rights from Alfred A. Knopf, said it was the quintessential word-of-mouth book; that is, people who have read it recommend it to friends and often buy copies for gifts. But sales have also been helped by many personal appearances and lectures by the author, a historian who was the first woman to be president of Smith College, from 1975 to 1985. "She's strong and brainy without being apologetic about it, and that's inspiring to her audiences," Ms. Walther said.
The other Vintage title is "Six Degrees of Separation," by John Guare, a copy of which critics will find in their press kits tomorrow night when the play opens in Broadway's Vivian Beaumont Theater. While plays are usually profitable to book publishers over a long period of time, as this one is also likely to be, Ms. Walther said that Vintage had rushed the Guare play into print in a couple of months to coincide with its Broadway opening.

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
Reagan, the Author, Tours TV Talk Shows

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
Ronald Reagan is observing the publication of his memoirs, "An American Life," in American style. He is appearing every day this week on ABC's "Good Morning America," where Charles Gibson propels him through his career in five-minute segments. Last Friday, he submitted to Barbara Walters on "20/20." And the next two Saturdays will find him on Channel 13 at 10 A.M., participating in "Two Friends Talk: Ronald Reagan and William F. Buckley Jr." These encounters, which are not so much interviews as ceremonial gestures, reveal as much about the performing styles of the hosts as about the condition of the guest. 
 Mr. Reagan is treated like a well-loved uncle who needs a little help these days in keeping the conversation going. He looks fit; his smile still comes easily, and the unkindest termhe finds for Democrats past is "mean spirited," in reference to Jimmy Carter's 1976 Presidential campaign.
His show business anecdotes are painless, and he genially declines the invitations of Mr. Gibson and Ms. Walters to expand on the reasons for his divorce from his first wife, the actress Jane Wyman. Words, however, do not come easily or always in the right order; when dealing with his time in the White House, he often reaches into past scripts for some phrase that has done proven service.
The phrases he finds are not always directly on the mark of the questions, but no one calls him to task. When Ms. Walters speaks of criticisms that "you walked through the Presidency," he reminds her that he was for two terms the Governor of California, which he notes would be the seventh biggest nation in the world, if it were a nation. He says exactly the same thing to Mr. Buckley. He tells both of them without quite being asked that when he arrived at the White House, he discovered that half of America's military aircraft could not fly for want of spare parts.
In response to references to the budget deficit, which reached grand proportions during his Presidency, he explains to both that the Constitution requires that the President submit a budget to Congress and that he submitted seven of them. Neither Ms. Walters nor Mr. Buckley pursues the point with much energy. He also tells them, with a practiced twinkle, that he received a degree in economics in college. His eight years in office, he informs both, in virtually the same words, marked the longest economic growth period in the nation's history, and in rebuttal to the canard that he favored the rich, he tells both that the top 1 percent of the nation's earners pay more than 20 percent of the total income tax.
Mr. Buckley, like a Samaritan assisting a nearsighted pedestrian across a busy street, hastens to add that that does not take into account the value of the public services rendered to the poor. Well, what's a friend for?
When he cannot come up with a comfortable line, Mr. Reagan tends to flounder, but his questioners are unfailingly solicitous. Ms. Walters plugs his book: "Ronald Reagan's recollections, like the man himself, are humorous and gentle." She manages a chuckle at a remark like "California isn't a place; it's a way of life." She asks, "What makes a marriage work as well as yours does?" She brings up delicate questions, such as the one about his estrangement from his daughter Patti Davis, with apologies. Mr. Reagan is at his most dignified in not taking such bait, and leaves it to Ms. Walters to supply her preferred answer: "It must be very painful today." So experienced is Ms. Walters at her line of work, that it sometimes seems she doesn't need an interviewee at all.
Like Ms. Walters, Mr. Buckley chuckles at Mr. Reagan's little jokes and supplies leading questions to light his guest's way. For example, he explains to the former President that when he asked for a line veto while in the White House, he was not really seeking more power. That is phrased as a question and Mr. Reagan does not take exception.
Compared to Ms. Walters and Mr. Gibson, Mr. Buckley is a veritable Torquemada or even a Mike Wallace, and he disdains to mention broken marriages or disaffected daughters. Yet these editions of "Firing Line" are about as fiery as a couple of armchair clubbies seconding each other's views over their brandies. On the matter of why he insisted on visiting the Bitburg cemetery in West Germany, the former President says he was told that the SS storm troopers buried there had been executed for being kind to inmates. Whereupon Mr. Buckley explains to Mr. Reagan that President Reagan also felt that after 40 years of democracy in West Germany, it was time to make such a visit of reconciliation. Mr. Reagan allows that that is what President Reagan must have felt.
 Left on his own, Mr. Reagan occasionally finds himself in deep syntactical waters. "Well," he tells Mr. Buckley, "you can't have the gross national product (pause) here's a thing for the return to the people and so forth on that without it reflecting those who are paying the taxes." What this means, his friend deduces, is that everyone profited from lower taxes. After listening to Mr. Reagan for a while, even less friendly viewers may accept his explanation regarding the Iran-contra activities, that "I am still one of the ones who doesn't know what really happened."
Given Mr. Buckley's taste for the polysyllabic and the Latinate (he is particularly drawn to "quintile" this time out) and his pleasure in abstract ideas, the conversation takes an odd shape. Mr. Reagan may or may not understand the longer words, but he is plainly most at ease in the first person: his spirits seem to rise as he tells of going to church with Nancy in Leningrad, of a letter he received from a man explaining that anyone in America can become an American, of the lesson he learned when he was a Hollywood star in the highest tax bracket, "Who's going to work for 6 cents on the dollar?"
When Mr. Buckley tries to get the subject onto the endemic problems of the Soviet Union, Mr. Reagan sticks with expressions of confidence in Mikhail S. Gorbachev, based on their personal accord. Tomorrow on "Good Morning America" he allots credit for some of the changes in the Soviet Union to "a kind of chemistry" he achieved with Mr. Gorbachev.
Mr. Buckley, however, goes his airy way. Just before asking Mr. Reagan whether he believes that the United States is providentially blessed and guided (he does), Mr. Buckley says, "So much for the cosmological questions addressed in your book." Neither man chuckles.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
BRITISH WARNINGS TO IRAQIS ON WAR

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 6

 BODY:
With expectation growing here that the United States is preparing for an attack against Iraqi forces in Kuwait as early as December, the British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, warned President Saddam Hussein today, "Time is ticking on."
Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher also met today with King Hussein of Jordan in Geneva and told him that she could not rule out force to end Iraq's occupation of Kuwait, British officials said. 
 Mr. Hurd told BBC television this morning that international forces in the Persian Gulf were not yet "at the point of deciding exactly how the military option might be used."
"You do not want to signal your punch in any precise way," he said.
 
Early Attack Dismissed
 When force might be used, if Iraq continues to refuse to pull out without a fight, is something the allies clearly prefer to keep President Hussein guessing about.
Several British officials and military experts dismissed a report circulating among Members of Parliament that an American attack could come even before Thanksgiving, when President Bush is planning to visit American troops in the gulf.
But they also said that sufficient American and British forces, and command and control structures to coordinate them, would be in place for a successful operation by late this month.
Mr. Hurd did not discuss deadlines, but he told the BBC that the international coalition was "approaching the stage when we all take stock and see if the peaceful pressures which we have been constructing are going to be good enough."
 
'Time Is Ticking On'
 Asked if an allied attack against Iraq was imminent, Mr. Hurd answered: "I don't say soon. We keep the military option going; Saddam Hussein knows that it exists; he knows that it is not a bluff; and that is the greatest incentive on him to go in peace."
But the Foreign Secretary added: "I don't think that he can expect to remain there indefinitely. He knows that. Time is ticking on."
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, saying in Saudi Arabia on Monday that the gulf crisis was entering a new phase, also reached agreement with Saudi leaders that American forces in any operation against Iraqi troops in Kuwait would be under United States command.
British and French officials here and in Paris have said that they assumed this would be the case for them as well if it came to battle.
 
Sounding Out the Allies
 Mr. Baker talked with Egyptian officials and the Chinese Foreign Minister in Cairo today before leaving for Turkey, and will stop in Moscow before coming here to see Mr. Hurd and Mrs. Thatcher on Friday. His last stop is Paris on Saturday.
Mr. Baker said at the beginning of his trip that he would be laying the foundations for a possible joint military operation against Iraq if the existing policy of militarily enforced economic sanctions did not work. He may also be sounding out his allies on their views of the need for specific United Nations resolutions authorizing the use of military force if sanctions fail.
Asked if Britain thought additional United Nations approval would be needed, Mr. Hurd today repeated earlier Government assertions that it was not required under international law.
The British have sent 15,000 troops, warships, tanks, artillery and squadrons of combat aircraft to the Persian Gulf to reinforce the 220,000 Americans and about as many Egyptians, Syrians, Saudis and other Arabs there. Mrs. Thatcher has said that existing United Nations resolutions would cover any decision to use force to drive Iraq out of Kuwait.
 
Creating a Command Structure
 "December would be a pretty good time," said Francois Heisbourg, director of the International Institute for Strategic Studies, who recently returned from a trip to Saudi Arabia. "I think it would be dangerous to go in in less than two weeks, because I got the sense that they were still in the early stages of putting together an effective command structure."
Air Chief Marshal Michael Armitage, chief of British defense intelligence in 1986-87, writing in The Independent newspaper today, also said the best time for military operations in the gulf was drawing near.
"Statements by President George Bush, as well as by senior British and American military commanders, make it clear that allied preparations for a war in the Middle East are almost complete," he wrote. "The opportunity for military operations will end when the hot season returns in April. If there is going to be military action it has to be before that date."
A Member of Parliament who recently returned from Washington said today that he had found the Administration's mood to be cautious and circumspect. "I saw no evidence of people wanting to start a war," he said. "And if you're going to send in up to another 100,000 troops I think it's unlikely you'll go to war very soon.
"I've always thought that economic sanctions would take at least a year to work," he said. "As soon as Americans start killing Arabs, the consequences will be with us for the next century."

HEADLINE: Moscow Journal;
Soviet Students Study the Art of the Deal, Avidly

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 6

 BODY:
Night school has commenced at Moscow State University, and brilliant malcontents are plotting oligopoly and other coups de grace for Communism.
The Soviet nation's pioneer class of M.B.A. candidates in capitalism is hitting once-forbidden books, gratefully absorbing Western economics by the chapterful, the air rife with sugarplum dreams of free enterprise. 
 "The deal is the main thing," Kirill Tkachev confided tersely, putting aside oligopoly's involved concern with the number of market producers and such.
He is a 27-year-old student busy memorizing all the economic models but mainly watching the bottom line, the Deal, at the hottest new curriculum being offered at Moscow State University. It is being devoured by an elite gathering of 62 scholarship students screened from a rush of 1,200 applicants.
"The Deal," Mr. Tkachev said slowly with the sort of glint that used to be faked onto visionary billboard posings of Lenin.
 
Emigre Is the Founder
 He was savoring a simple enriching notion he appears to be learning well at the new Russian-American University, an independent school opened this fall in Moscow State classrooms by Edward D. Lozansky, a Soviet-born physicist and dissident who emigrated to the United States.
The school is running on American contributions and Soviet cooperation, notably from Dr. Yuri A. Osipyan, the physicist who is vice president of the Academy of Sciences and adviser to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The plan is to enlarge the school to a full university curriculum within four years, buttressed by a consortium of American universities.
It is an outgrowth of an "underground university" that Mr. Lozansky ran informally in apartments in recent years with Soviet friends after he was permitted to visit his homeland. He found that the current state of Soviet depression cried out for economics as the inaugural discipline.
Previously, the subject of free enterprise was touched on harrumphishly in Soviet graduate schools as a branch of Marxist apologetics under such titles as "the economics of foreign trade." And in recent years there have been more than a few brief, fee-fleecing seminars by visiting Westerners arriving like rainmakers and promising inside knowledge of the free market, currently the Soviet public's main mystique, with the possible exception of U.F.O.'s.
The attraction at M.S.U., where 35 unofficial students are auditing lectures with the privileged 62, is the idea of a full 10-hour weekly curriculum on Western economics dedicated to American M.B.A. teaching methods, free-market textbooks and pragmatic business lessons. In two years, it is to produce graduate capitalists, ready to deal, assuming the nation's economic planners ever catch up with the students' hope for unfettered market dealings.
 
Plotting the Future
 "I intend to become director of a new business firm or start my own if I have to," said 24-year-old Vladimir Shnol. He is a daytime computerware designer and night student who, like most at the new university, already has a strong background in applied and theoretical sciences.
Those disciplines, with their many military applications, had been the major field for ambitious Soviet students until these post-cold-war times of shifting economic gears. Most of the students who made it through the new admission tests already have full-time jobs or avocations in the joint venture and cooperative businesses now permitted as limited market exercises.
In the new university the students see an almost priceless chance to fully switch mindsets as much as careers to Western economics as the discipline of the future. Their only fee is 75 rubles, which in the "real market," the Moscow black market, the new business majors note, is about $5.
The entrance test for the 1,200 applicants was math-heavy and fashioned in part from the type of questions used at screenings for the Harvard Business School, Mr. Lozansky said. The top 200 scorers then were put through an English language examination to produce the freshman class.
"This group already feels pretty elite and has a lot of cohesiveness," said Edwin G. Dolan, an economist and visiting American professor. He finds the students are a high-I.Q., achievement-oriented group that scored the reverse of the average in taking a standard test of entrepreneurial promise, with 85 percent scoring well, rather than the usual 15 percent.
 
A Hunger for Lessons
 The sense in the classroom is one of absolute attentiveness, a hunger for lessons that include such basics of the economics curriculum as the Cournot Model, the Nash Equilibrium and the "prisoner's dilemma." The last one drew students' smiles of appreciation at the once decadent notion of how enterprise advertising can force competitiors to advertise even at the price of reduced profits.
Professor Dolan also mixes in such pragmatic themes as the precise economics of waiting in line, a subject at which the students already are expert.
Pragmatism, not ideology, drives their curiosity, and cautionary lessons on possible drawbacks of capitalist economics are not noticeably appreciated.
"I tried a lesson the other night about the current budget troubles in the United States, and I have never seen so many bored looks," said Katherine Dolan, a political scientist and communications specialist who teaches English courses in conjunction with her husband's economic classes.
Mr. Lozansky said: "I stress that their academic background will be great when they get out of here. But most important of all will be the business contacts they'll be getting in the Western world." He added that the university would award a minimum of 20 internships of up to six months each in the United States.
Even so, the students talk of being most challenged by the idea of staying at home to succeed in what is still largely a contradiction in terms, the Soviet business deal.
"I can see it is necessary to be dynamic," said Mr. Tkachev, a delighted student of the Deal. "To think about business all the time, even when you're taking a shower."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Vladimir Shnol, left, and Kirill Tkachev, right, who are attending night school at Moscow State University to earn master's degrees in capitalist economics, talking with Edwin G. Dolan, a visiting American professor.
(Francis X. Clines/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New Store On 5th Ave. Is Not Just Any Shop; It's Dior's

BYLINE: By ANNE-MARIE SCHIRO

 BODY:
NEW YORK'S first Christian Dior boutique opened to the public yesterday at 703 Fifth Avenue, at 55th Street. But to the city's worlds of fashion and society, it was a bit anti-climactic. More than 400 people had been given a preview of the shop at a champagne reception Monday evening, and 250 privileged guests attended a black-tie dinner later at the Frick Collection on East 70th Street.
Bernard Arnault, the chairman of Christian Dior, along with Beatrice Bongibault, the company's chief executive officer, and Charles Ryskamp, the director of the Frick Collection, were hosts of the dinner and formed a receiving line at the mansion's entrance along with Gianfranco Ferre, the Dior designer. 
 Dior hired Glorious Food to prepare the dinner of caviar, veal and chocolate cake, and brought Christian Benais from France to decorate the garden courtyard with tables draped in pleated white silk and centered with five-arm candelabra twined with white roses.
"Isn't this a rare treat to be here?" asked Cecile Zilkha, who was wearing a black and red Dior dress, circa 1975. "This house is so beautiful."
It was indeed rare for the museum, once the home of the industrialist Henry Clay Frick, to be the scene of a dinner party. "But we're not renting out the house," Mr. Ryskamp said. "We're doing it to call attention to our endowment campaign, to which Dior made a generous contribution."
The Helen Clay Frick Foundation of Pittsburgh has pledged $18.75 million toward the goal of $34 million for the Frick Art Reference Library, and Mr. Ryskamp was hoping the party guests -- among them Carroll and Milton Petrie, Blaine and Robert Trump, Evelyn and Leonard Lauder, the Baroness Philippine de Rothschild, Enid Haupt, Georgette Mosbacher and Marcella Perez de Cuellar -- would get out the word that more is needed.
Editors of fashion magazines and top retailers from stores that carry Dior products rounded out the group, most of whom had toured the boutique earlier in the day. Mr. Ferre pronounced himself pleased with the shop, the third in the United States and the 27th in the world.
The New York boutique is like a little bit of Paris, specifically Dior's headquarters at 30 Avenue Montaigne, with the same gray and white decor, sweeping staircase, crystal chandelier and furniture in the style of Louis XVI. There are 4,500 square feet of selling space on two floors.
"The difference between us and other boutiques," Mrs. Bongibault said, "is that we look French. For us it is very important to be in New York. New York is a special place, an international city. And with the ready-to-wear of Ferre we have the product we want to present.
"In this shop we have space enough to have a large collection and show exactly the look of the runway, with the jewelry, hats, shoes and gloves. It's a way for us to show the complete Dior look."
Jewelry, handbags, scarfs, cosmetics and men's accessories are on the street level, where the brass-banistered stairway with the "CD" monogram on black rails is reflected in a wall of mirrors. On the second level is the main attraction: the women's ready-to-wear from Paris designed by Mr. Ferre, who joined Dior last year to design both the haute couture and ready-to-wear lines.
For the opening, there are clothes from the winter and cruise collections, along with showcases of accessories. The emphasis is on clothes for going out. And they are for women who go to very special places.
The closest thing to sportswear is gray flannel trousers at $1,020. A white silk shirt with a scarf neckline is $1,340. One of the simplest suits, in red wool with a one-button jacket and a button-front skirt, is $2,945. A slim, belted wool crepe day dress with a high neck is $1,885. A pink cotton suit with black buttons is $2,300.
For evening, there are simple sleeveless sheaths in black or pink silk, but that isn't what a woman goes to Dior for. More typical is a black strapless dress with yards of pink satin draped across one shoulder and tied in a bow on the chest ($5,245). Even more luxurious are brocade satin jackets decorated with gold embroidery and beadwork inspired by Faberge eggs ($10,620 and $12,655).
With the New York retail scene in a selling slump, will such rarefied fashion find an audience? Mrs. Bongibault is optimistic. "It is a difficult time," she said, "but it's a cyclical economic situation. We want to be in New York for the century coming."

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
Lehman Leads New York Issue

 BODY:
Lehman Brothers announced yesterday that it had been chosen by New York City to be the lead manager of the city's $1.3 billion offering of revenue anticipation notes on Nov. 19.
Lehman, which will head a syndicate of 29 brokerage firms for the short-term financing, said the notes have a maturity date of June 28, 1991.
The American Express Company subsidiary said it expected investor demand to be relatively strong, despite concerns regarding fiscal problems the city has experienced because of a shortfall in revenues and weakness in the local economy.
Normally there are expectations on Wall Street regarding the pricing ahead of a major issue, but many firms said that with the offering still two weeks away any speculation about a price would not be realistic. Analysts said the offering might be a barometer of how Wall Street will react to future city issues.
Bear, Stearns & Company, the First Boston Corporation, Goldman, Sachs & Company and Merrill Lynch Capital Markets are senior co-managers for the issue.

HEADLINE: Louisville Gas Bonds

 BODY:
A $100 million issue of tax-exempt bonds for Trimble, Ky., was priced yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The pollution-control revenue bonds, due in 2020, were issued on behalf of the Louisville Gas and Electric Company and were given an interest rate of 7.625 percent to be offered at par. HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
America's Real Deficit

BYLINE: By TOM WICKER

 BODY:
Are you one of those many Americans who regard driving your car as an inalienable right?
Then you should know that the nation needs to double, from $13 billion to $26 billion, its current annual spending to maintain just those highways already existing and bring them up to minimum standards. That doesn't include the $50 billion needed, and soon, to repair or replace 240,000 bridges that might come tumbling down anytime now. 
 Or maybe you prefer to travel in the friendly skies. If so, be warned that about $1 billion a year, over and above another $1 billion of aviation trust fund expenditures, will be needed in each of the next 10 years just to maintain existing flying conditions -- which, despite glitzy airline advertising, are mostly grim to ghastly -- and only minimally relieve airport congestion.
Even if you are one of the above, chances are good that you're also one of the many who believe the recent "budget deal" was necessary -- although President Bush and Congress proposed in that shotgun wedding to reduce Federal spending by $40 billion in this fiscal year and by $500 billion over the next five.
The hard truth is that you can't have it both ways. If you think Federal spending has to be cut, transportation and a lot of other genuine national necessities -- such as housing and toxic waste disposal -- will suffer too. If you want safe bridges, a decent environment and a host of other desirable physical and social effects -- a better educated work force, for instance, and a lower child mortality rate -- then the Government needs to invest more, not less, in American society.
In fact, the Center for Community Change reports that additional Federal spending of at least $130 billion annually is needed to cope with what it cogently calls "America's third deficit" -- the shortfall in the nation's investments to solve or lessen some of its most grievous problems.
The center's cost estimate totaled those of numerous earlier reports by reliable authorities (both private and governmental) on national requirements in various fields. The figures cited for transportation are from the Congressional Budget Office, the General Accounting Office and the Federal Aviation Administration.
A precise price tag on national needs was not the purpose; rather the report seeks to concentrate the national mind on national neglect rather than on the spurious but widespread belief -- enshrined in the misguided budget deal -- that the Federal Government taxes too much, spends too much and borrows too much.
The opposite of the first proposition is true, despite popular myth. The second raises the wrong question -- how much? -- rather than making the right point -- what for? National debt, meanwhile, is growing at about the same pace as gross national product; that's not only reasonable but permits an annual deficit of about 3 percent of G.N.P.
Here are just a few of the yearly unmet needs reported by various reputable studies:
Head Start and early education, $2 billion (Ford Foundation); repair existing public housing, $4 billion (Housing Department and private studies); subsidies for very low income families, $11.1 billion (C.B.O.); education for "at-risk" youth, $5 billion (W. T. Grant Foundation); subsidies for long-term health care insurance, $7.2 billion (Ford).
If all that's too "social" for your hard nose, how about these additional annual costs for neglected physical needs:
Clean up nuclear and nonnuclear military waste, $11 billion (G.A.O. and Energy Department); compliance with Clean Water Act, $2.4 billion (Environmental Protection Agency); clean up non-military hazardous waste sites, $3 billion (E.P.A.).
The report of the Center for Community Change disposes of numerous familiar excuses for these failures. This rich nation isn't taxed too much, for example; total Federal taxes as a percentage of G.N.P. are lower than in 20 other industrialized nations. Nor is all social spending "money down a rathole." Head Start saves an estimated $4.75 in welfare and prison costs for every tax dollar spent, while funded to reach only 18 percent of eligible children; the WIC supplemental food program saves, in reduced health charges, about three times its cost.
That's why meeting these and other needs reflected in America's real deficit would not be "wasteful spending" but useful investment. Nor is it the wallet that's lacking; it's the will.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Don't Retreat Now on New York City Housing

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"New York City Will Rise Again" (Op-Ed, Oct. 27), Peter D. Salins's attack on the city's housing, health and social programs, is shortsighted and dangerous. 
 In 1987, New York City responded to the disastrous Federal withdrawal from urban programs with a major housing initiative. The city committed $5.1 billion to housing. The funds came from the capital budget, state sources and excess income produced by Battery Park City.
The results are beginning to show. Major complexes of vacated buildings in Harlem, Brooklyn and the Bronx have been renovated, and others are under construction. Families have moved back to these neighborhoods and are joining with the police to patrol their buildings and with parent-teacher associations to demand better schools. The beginnings of solutions are being put into place.
This is the wrong time to retreat. Middle-income families, low-income families and the homeless must have access to decent housing, job training and health care to make the city an attractive place to work, live and even visit.
The state is doing little, if anything, to assist the city in this time of financial crisis. The Federal Government's abandonment of housing resulted in a loss of more than $12 billion in subsidies that could have created new apartments in the 80's.
To New York City's credit, it is making a valiant attempt to solve its most severe problems -- housing, education and crime. The housing policies are paying off. Mayor David N. Dinkins and former Mayor Edward I. Koch deserve our thanks.
Neighborhoods are reviving. The economic crisis has brought down the cost of housing construction, making 1990 the ideal time to continue programs that will end homelessness and bring a modicum of hope to all New Yorkers.
 
CAROL LAMBERG
Executive Director
Settlement Housing Fund
New York, Oct. 29, 1990

HEADLINE: For Support on Iraq, Syria Gets Lebanon

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "After the Killing in Lebanon" (editorial, Oct. 20), you seem to mourn the harsh pacification of Lebanon at the hands of the Syrian Army, because the root problem of foreign intervention is alive and well. 
 That the occupation of Lebanon (small and weak) by Syria (a mighty tyranny) was at the request of the Lebanese is only a myth. The Arab League, as well as the Lebanese, had to accept Syria's invasion in 1976, irrespective of whom the Syrian Army sided with.
Successive United States administrations have endorsed Syrian control of Lebanon, for a variety of reasons: there is no oil in Lebanon; United States hostages can only be recovered by Syria, not by a free Lebanese government, and Lebanon was a cheap price to pay to bring Syria to the negotiating table with Israel.
The timing of the final assault by Syria against its detractors in Lebanon (that is, Gen. Michel Aoun), which was almost coincidental with Syria's contribution to the United States anti-Iraqi front, is essentially a reward to Syria. Egypt was forgiven its $7 billion debt; Syria was awarded Lebanon.
If Syria's takeover of Lebanon has not come about by naked aggression, it certainly has been achieved by a subtle combination of destroying the Lebanese infrastructure and finely tuned hostage holding by Syria's pro-Iranian proxies. Syria's Hafez al-Assad has been settling the northern city of Tripoli with members of his Alawi tribe; ask the Sunnis of the city. Syrian Army trucks have carried more loot from Lebanon than the entire Syrian economy has produced in decades. The Lebanese who have been assassinated by Syria's Moukhabarat secret service are beyond statistics, and those who continue to languish under torture and who have perished in Syrian jails have been forgotten even by their loved ones.
On the other hand, those who have not held hostages, who have not resorted to worldwide terrorism, and who have resisted Syria's hegemony have constantly been branded hard-liners and suicidal renegade rebels by the news media and the United States Administration.
It seems proper for the United States to mobilize support of the anachronistic monarchies of Kuwait and Saudi Arabia, but improper to take the principled stance that Lebanon's many struggles were to restore its once thriving democracy and get rid of Palestinian, Syrian, Iranian and Israeli occupations.
I am certainly inspired by your conclusion that the lessons of war have not been learned by the Lebanese, if only it is to show the world that the selling of Lebanon to Syria will not bring about freedom for the hostages, nor change 20 years of Syrian tyranny. The death of Lebanon is not self-inflicted. It is the direct result of Syria's 15-year rape of the country under the watchful eyes of the United States.
 
YOUSSEF S. HITTI
Providence, R.I., Oct. 20, 1990

HEADLINE: The 1990 Elections: New York - House Races;
Easy Victories For Incumbents In the Congress

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL

 BODY:
New York's 34 incumbents in the House of Representatives were re-elected yesterday, many by overwhelming margins.
The results seem to have shown that two potential liabilities this year -- a downturn in the state's economy and association with the national budget stalemate in Washington -- apparently carried little weight with voters. While some voters might have been dismayed by current events, they clearly did not blame their elected officials. 
 Both parties held their seats, with the Democrats returning 21 representatives to Washington and the Republicans returning 13. In the New York metropolitan area, most incumbents had an easy time.
In the 6th Congressional District in Queens, the incumbent Democrat, the Rev. Floyd H. Flake, beat challengers from the Republican and Right to Life parties. With 46 percent of the precincts reporting, Mr. Flake had 68 percent of the vote.
 
Got 86 Percent Last Time
 In the last election, Mr. Flake received 86 percent of the vote. His standing may have suffered because of allegations that he had an affair with a church secretary, and because he and his wife face charges that they misappropriated money from Mr. Flake's church, the Allen African Episcopal Church in Queens.
In a closely watched race on Long Island, George J. Hochbrueckner, a two-term Democrat in the 1st Congressional District in Suffolk County, beat the Republican, Francis W. Creighton. With 86 percent of the precincts reporting, Mr. Hochbrueckner had 56 percent of the vote, to 35 percent for Mr. Creighton.
The district has voted Republican in the last two Presidential elections, and the national Republican Party had hoped to field a strong candidate against Mr. Hochbrueckner. But Mr. Creighton entered the race late and suffered from lack of money and poor name recognition.
In the 3d Congressional District, which includes parts of Nassau and Suffolk Counties, the Democratic incumbent, Robert J. Mrazek, beat Robert Previdi, a bank executive from Manhasset who ran on the Republican and Conservative lines. With 93 percent of the precincts counted, Mr. Mrazek had 53 percent of the vote, and Mr. Previdi had 43 percent. It was Mr. Previdi's second unsuccessful bid for Mr. Mrazek's seat.
 
Big Wins in Brooklyn
 Bill Green, a Manhattan Republican, easily won his eighth term in the 15th Congressional District, on the lower half of the East Side. With 53 percent of the precincts counted, he had 57 percent of the vote.
Also in Manhattan, Ted Weiss, a Democrat who has represented the 17th Congressional District on the West Side since 1977, soundly beat William W. Koeppel Jr., a Republican and owner and manager of his family's real-estate firm. Mr. Weiss had 80 percent of the vote and Mr. Koeppel had 16 percent, with 60 percent of the precincts counted.
Brooklyn's four Congressmen, all Democrats, had unusually strong showings with more than half the districts in the borough reporting results. Charles E. Schumer received 78 percent of the vote in his district; Edolphus Towns won 94 percent in his district; Major R. Owens captured 95 percent in his district, and Stephen J. Solarz had 80 percent in his.
The three representatives whose districts include Westchester County -- Nita M. Lowey, a Democrat, and Hamilton Fish Jr. and Benjamin A. Gilman, both Republicans -- were also re-elected, each receiving more than 60 percent of the vote in their races.

HEADLINE: Kahane Suspect Is a Muslim With a Series of Addresses

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER

 BODY:
The suspect in the slaying of the Jewish militant Rabbi Meir Kahane emerged yesterday as an elusive, Egyptian-born devout Muslim who kept to himself and worked for New York City repairing air conditioners in the Criminal Courts building.
The suspect, El Sayyid A. Nosair, was a man who left a string of addresses over the last three years, but kept a private post office box in a trading company called The Sphinx in the same building as the mosque he attended in Jersey City. 
 Another Egyptian man who lived at the Brooklyn apartment building listed on Mr. Nosair's city employment records abruptly departed from the building yesterday afternoon, carrying a suitcase, the superintendent of the building said. Law enforcement officials were raiding another address in Cliffside Park, N.J., last night.
The police were unable to establish a motive for the killing yesterday or to say whether it was linked to any organization. Heavily sedated and listed in serious but stable condition at Bellevue Hospital, Mr. Nosair could not be questioned until nightfall. As he came out of sedation, a law enforcement official said, he denied shooting Rabbi Kahane.
 
Police Cite Lone Gunman
 The rabbi, who founded the Jewish Defense League in New York City and became a force on the far-right fringes of Israeli politics until his Kach party was outlawed as racist for its anti-Arab stance, was gunned down in a midtown hotel on Monday night. He had just made a speech to a group called the Zionists Emergency Evacuation Rescue Operation. A bystander was also shot and wounded.
Mr. Nosair, identified by witnesses as the gunman, was in turn shot and wounded by a Postal Service police officer as he tried to flee.
"What we have and all we know is that we have a lone gunman who committed a homicide in New York," Chief of Detectives Joseph R. Borrelli told a news conference last evening.
Pressed as to whether Palestinian or other groups might have plotted the attack, Chief Borrelli said: "I'm going with what I know. And what I know right now is that we have a lone gunmen who committed a homicide."
As the police struggled through the day for leads, Rabbi Kahane was mourned in emotional services by tens of thousands of Jews who jammed a Brooklyn synagogue. And in Jerusalem, security forces were deployed across the city to deter violence as news of the rabbi's death spread, but no widespread unrest materialized. [Page B13.]
A law enforcement official said Mr. Nosair had in his wallet two advertisements clipped from Jewish newspapers: one for Monday night's event, the other for the Annual Jewish Overview Dinner at Le Chateau, 431 Avenue P in Brooklyn on Nov. 18. Also in his wallet were notes written in Arabic, which the police had not yet translated, the official said.
The murder weapon, a Ruger .357 magnum revolver with five shots fired, was recovered, the police said, but its identification numbers had been filed off, making it difficult to trace.
 
Children in Mosque School
 At various addresses yesterday, former neighbors remembered Mr. Nosair as a quiet man with an American-born wife, who had converted to Islam, and three small children. They said he kept to himself.
One important center of his life appeared to be the Masjid al-Salam mosque at 2824 John F. Kennedy Boulevard in Jersey City, which has 300 to 400 members. He had sent two of his children to the Al-Ghazly School, affiliated with the nearby Islamic Center of Jersey City, but the principal, Shaker al-Said, said Mr. Nosair took them out at the beginning of last year, saying he could not afford the tuition of $465 a month.
Another worshiper at the Jersey City mosque was Sultan Ibraham El Gawli, an Egyptian-born travel agent, who was arrested by United States Customs agents on Dec. 18, 1985 on charges of attempting to smuggle 150 pounds of powerful C-4 explosives, 100 blasting caps, remote detonators and a 9-mm automatic weapon with a silencer, to the Palestine Liberation Organization for use in Israel. Neighbors said he had served time in Federal prison and had recently been released.
 
Various Forms of Name
 Immigration and Naturalization Service records show that the 34-year old Mr. Nosair was born in Port Said and took American citizenship under the name of El Sayyed Abdulazziz El Sayyed on Sept. 27, 1989. But over the years, he had used variations of the name Nosir, Nosier, Nosair and Nasser on documents. He entered the country in New York City on July 14, 1981, the records show, and established permanent residency in Pittsburgh on April 7, 1983, when he married an American citizen. He had earned an engineering degree in Egypt.
Police officers who interviewed his wife, Caren Nosair, described her as a convert to Islam who had met Mr. Nosair in a mosque in Pittsburgh and kept "a truly religious household." A police officer said that Mrs. Nosair had not asked where her husband was going on Monday night because "she said she was a true Muslim and they never question their husband."
A spokesman for the New York City Department of General Services, John Beckman, said Mr. Nosair had worked for the city since April 1988 and was assigned to maintain heating, ventilation and air conditioning units at the Criminal Courts building at 111 Centre Street in lower Manhattan, at a salary of between $30,000 and $35,000 a year.
Mr. Nosair was carrying three New Jersey driver's licenses with different addresses, said Jersey City Deputy Police Chief John McAuley.
 
Changing Addresses
 One address was 143 Highland Avenue in Jersey City, a complex with 10 apartments, six of which are occupied by Moslem families.
A resident of the complex, Deborah Ragab, a 39-year-old mother of three, said: "It was a surprise to us, to everybody, if he did it. He was a quiet man. He has three children. He has responsibility."
Mrs. Ragab said she had spoken by telephone yesterday morning to Mrs. Nosair. "She was devastated," Mrs. Ragab said. "She had no idea what happened, she heard it from the news. She hasn't been able to talk to him since."
The family moved from the Highland Avenue address last April. On April 5, Mr. Nosair filed a change of address form at the post office directing his mail to a private postal box at 2824 Kennedy Boulevard, the same address as the mosque.
The box is maintained by the Sphinx Trading Company, which cashes checks and mails money orders for immigrants sending remittances back home. The office is located on the second floor of the building; the mosque is on the third.
Mr. Nosair's city employment records listed his address as 57 Prospect Park Southwest in Brooklyn and a telephone number for his wife as a contact. Telephone directories, however, show that number at that address listed in the name of Ibrahim Elgabrowny.
Neighbors in the six-story brick apartment complex said the Elgabrowny family kept at least six children locked inside Apartment 5C much of the time and that at least one called the authorities to express concern that the children might have been abused.
"Very rarely would you see them all together, but when I did it was like a family of ducklings," said Tommy Jasinski, an unemployed iron worker. "The head of the family first and then down the line."
A friend and neighbor of Mr. Elgabrowny, Fathy Hegazy, who lived with his family in Apartment 5B, was seen leaving the building carrying a suitcase yesterday afternoon, the superintendent, George Steelson, said.
