HEADLINE: (Class) War in the Gulf

BYLINE: By John Kenneth Galbraith; John Kenneth Galbraith is professor emeritus of economics at Harvard University.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE

 BODY:
The events of these last months in the Persian Gulf have brought to light a problem of the American democracy that all will, I cannot doubt, wish to see corrected once it is fully recognized. Deployed on the sands of Saudi Arabi and facing possible extinction, are young men and women drawn, in the main, from the poorer families of our republic.
We accept that our armed forces, with to be sure many exceptions, attract those seeking escape from an economically limiting family environment, no family at all or the handicaps of minority birth. It is to these, as all have observed, that the television commercials urging enlistment in the services have been directed. 
 Meanwhile it is the more fortunate and affluent of our citizenry who, while rejoicing generally in the rebuke to Saddam Hussein, remain substantially secure in their gasoline, fuel oil and other energy use and thus in their larger living standard.
It is my own good fortune to live in a relatively well-endowed community with an unusually large population of young men and women of combat age. The commitment of these favored young people to the armed forces is not great.
Knowing as one does the depth of the American devotion to democracy, this is not a situation which one can view with comfort. We are, as in the much regretted practice of the Civil War, hiring people from the lower-income classes to do our military service with its possibly heavy consequences. The affluent stand above and apart.
One obvious remedy would be to reinstate the draft with random selection and service on an economically indifferent basis. This would not, I think, be entirely practical; there could be an unseemly reaction.
Instead, let us establish a special volunteer service corps for the duration of the Middle Eastern troubles. These battalions, recruited at the universities and in the better suburbs, and from among the numerous young men and women now or recently at work in Wall Street, would provide opportunity for military service for those now so undemocratically exempted by their wealth or comparative affluence.
Parents who responded favorably to the Middle East initiative would, one hopes, encourage their sons and daughters to sign up. One thinks of possible names -- the Social and Economic Equality Corps, with SEEC as the innocuous acronym. When trained, these volunteers would go promptly into service on the desert sands. A large response to the SEEC would show that we are not risking the lives only of the poor for the gasoline the economically more fortunate consume and, in the words of President Bush, for the "way of life" which those with higher incomes especially enjoy.
A limited response, which is not entirely to be ruled out, would drive home the fact that we are, indeed, asking the poor to protect the rich. In the latter event it would be well that we restrain those who yearn to assail and punish Mr. Hussein by armed force, including those who seek "surgical" bomb strikes and other precipitating military action.
There would still be for those in our present armed forces that not wholly pleasant life on the sand. This, however, would have some of the aspects of any modestly paid occupation. At a minimum, those so engaged would not be getting killed while the economically and socially more fortunate escape.

GRAPHIC: Drawing

HEADLINE: Sudan's Famine Denials Take Anti-West Tone

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Nov. 2

 BODY:
Officials of the Islamic fundamentalist junta here continue to deny that the Sudan faces the possibility of a severe famine, with a strong anti-Western theme as their underlying message.
Dr. Hassan al-Turabi, head of the National Islamic Front, the main financial and political backer of the Government, said in a recent interview in a Government newspaper, "It is a blessing in disguise when people seek to withdraw financial and food supplies to the Sudan." 
 Dr. Turabi was apparently referringto the American decision last month to divert 45,000 tons of a 90,000-ton wheat delivery to protest the Government's restrictions on relief efforts.
The Sudanese Government later stopped much of the obstruction, and Washington went ahead with half of the delivery, but has yet to decide on the remainder.
Officials of the United States Agency for International Development say the Sudan could face food shortages that would leave eight to nine million Sudanese at risk of starvation.
For more than a month, Washington has been asking the Sudanese Government to declare a food emergency sothat Western donors can arrange the months-long logistics of shipping grain to the Sudan and then transporting it within the war wracked and virtually roadless country. the
Western officials say the food shortages will be the result of widespread drought, civil war and the Government's expenditure of meager foreign exchange on arms instead of agricultural input.
The Sudan has been locked in a seven-year civil war between the mostly Islamic Arab north and the largely Christian and animist African south. President Omar Hassan Ahmed al-Bashir accused United Nations officials last month of favoring the rebellious south in their distribution of relief supplies.
The United States and other donors insist that the Government publicly recognize its dramatic food shortage, and implicit in that insistence is the expectation that the Government will then cooperate with -- and not obstruct as it has done this year -- food distribution to areas of need and not just areas of its own supporters.
"We're saying: 'If you don't do this, we won't do this,' " said a senior Western official here. "We're using food as a weapon to feed."
Western officials say they are increasingly concerned about the fundamentalist Islamic takeover here of key Government sectors, including relief agencies.
The board of the Sudanese Red Crescent, a major organization for food distribution, was recently dismissed. A new president who is a member of the Islamic fundamentalist organization, the Muslim Brotherhood, was installed, the Western officials said.
 
Food Shortfall Acknowledged
 The most powerful person in the Relief Ministry, Ibrahim Abu Ouf, a former academic at the University of Khartoum, is also a member of the Muslim Brotherhood. He has told colleagues that for Islam to survive, the Sudan must manage on its own.
Mr. Ouf acknowledged at the United Nations in New York last month that the Sudan faced a food shortfall, but those present at the meetings said he devoted little energy to the question of how food would be brought in. He consistently asserted that the West hadsubstituted Islam for Communism as the favorite whipping boy and said that by harping on the food shortages, the West wanted the Sudan to look bad.
The Minister of Finance, Abdul Rahim Hamdi, has said it was "Zionist propaganda" to suggest the Sudan faced a famine.
In perhaps the starkest exposition of the anti-Western view, Fadlsaed Abu Ghozeiza, an organizer of a national political conference that last month chose Libyan-style popular committees as the new form of political organization, said it was all right if the West did not deliver food or other kinds of aid.
"We'll go back to the donkey," he said in an interview with a Western reporter. "It's easier for us than you. We don't have so far to go back."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: China's Press Casts a Cold Eye on U.S. Vote

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Nov. 7

 BODY:
Eighteen months after Chinese students fought and in some cases died for their vision of democracy, the official Chinese press is taking a jaundiced look at American electoral politics, suggesting that if this is democracy then it isn't really worth fighting for after all.
The newspapers here report that many Americans do not bother to vote and are disgusted with a system in which politicians care only for wealthy special interests. 
 "In that self-professed 'democratic' country, citizens don't want to exercisetheir sovereign rights," People's Daily said today in a front-page commentary. "What a great satire this is! Some people here admire America's 'electoral freedom' even more than the Americans do themselves. I hope that such people recover their senses."
The press had previously mostly ignored the American election. Tonight's television news showed only a brief film clip of people voting but announced no results. The commentary in People's Daily today was only the third reference to the election in the Communist Party newspaper in the last month.
The first reference was a fairly objective account of the campaign, but the second was a dispatch from the official New China News Agency published under the headline "Take a Look at American Electoral Freedom."
It said that for many years, fewer than half of those eligible have voted in Presidential elections and less than 30 percent in midterm Congressional elections. (In fact, the lowest figures in recent decades are 50.1 percent for a Presidential election and 36.4 percent for a midterm election.)
"Electoral participation this time may be lower than ever, because American voters are cold and apathetic, as well as a bit disgusted," the pressagency reported.
"The reason for the indifference," the report continued, "is that there is no genuine electoral freedom in America. Day by day, the people grow more displeased with machine politics and money politics."
Because publicity has been light, most Chinese seem unaware of the American election. And some say they are intimidated by the complexity of the United States' political system. In China, leaders constantly try to conceal the most fundamental disputes among themselves, so some Chinese are puzzled that American politicians go out of their way to magnify differences and insult each other.
There was much more coverage in China of the 1988 American election, partly because it was a Presidential race. The World Economic Herald,which is now banned, even published sympathetic accounts of the 1988 campaign and seemed to marvel that high officials like members of Congress must go before ordinary people and face their complaints.
One reason for the recent criticisms of the American political process may be that Beijing fears invidious comparisons with the Chinese elections that are being held in many parts of the country this year to select "people's deputies." In China, all candidates must adhere to the official line, and in any case the elected councils mostly just applaud the leadership and act as a rubber stamp for its decisions.
"I don't know much about your elections," said a worker in his 20's. "But ours are pretty pointless. We don't know the people on the ballot, and anyway it doesn't matter whom we pick."Today's commentary in People's Daily acknowledged that some Chinese "worship American democracy, to the point that they believe it is a model for a 'free and democratic system.' " The commentary then suggested that even Americans do not much like their system, and cited low voter turnouts and a survey in which more than 70 percent of those questioned felt that members of Congress were more interested in serving special interests than in serving the public.
"Everybody knows that the difference between the two American political parties lies in which fat cats they represent," People's Daily said. "Whichever party, it's all the same thing. That's why it's easy to understand why so many Americans don't support either party, and don't even bother to vote."

HEADLINE: THE 1990 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE;
South

 BODY:

ALABAMA
 Two-term Senator Howell Heflin, a 69-year-old Democrat, scored a solid victory over his underdog opponent, Republican State Senator Bill Cabaniss, 52. A generally conservative figure, Mr. Heflin took two notable steps that were welcomed by his state's substantial number of black voters: He voted last summer for legislation against job discrimination, and he came out against Robert H. Bork as a candidate for the Supreme Court.
The Republican Governor, Guy Hunt, 57, won re-election over Paul Hubbert. Democrats contended that Mr. Hunt's campaign had a racial component meant to stir his conservative supporters. The campaign included the airing of Hunt commercials that showed Mr. Hubbert with prominent black political figures. But Republicans argued that the view conveyed in those commercials was not racial but philosophical.
The Democrats retained control of the State Legislature.
 
ARKANSAS
 Bill Clinton, sometimes mentioned as a possible Democratic Presidential candidate, won a fifth term as Governor, beating Sheffield Nelson, a former executive at a natural gas company. Mr. Clinton, who promised to serve his full four-year term, benefited from a bruising Republican primary.
Senator David Pryor, the Democratic incumbent, ran unopposed, and the state's three incumbent members of the House of Representatives all won. In race for the open seat in the 2d Congressional District which includes Little Rock, former Representative Ray Thornton, a Democrat, soundly beat Jim Keet, a Republican State Representative.
Democrats held on to their overwhelming control over both houses of the Legisature.
 
FLORIDA
 Just two years after he left the Senate complaining of "burnout," Lawton Chiles won a decisive victory over the incumbent Republican Governor, Bob Martinez.
Abortion was a central issue in the race. Abortion rights supporters were upset last year when Mr. Martinez tried to have the Legislature place new restrictions on abortions. Mr. Chiles, a Democrat, reluctantly supports abortion rights. Mr. Chiles also won over some voters by limiting campaign contributions to $100 a person.
In another hotly contested race, Representative Bill Grant of Tallahassee was defeated by Pete Peterson, a Democrat who is a retired Air Force colonel. Shortly after his re-election in 1988, Mr. Grant switched parties and became a Republican, a move Mr. Peterson painted, apparently with success, as a breach of faith with voters.
Representative Craig T. James held onto his seat from the Daytona area despite a well-financed challenge from Reid Hughes.
In the race for the seat vacated by Representative Bill Nelson, an Orlando lawyer, Democrat Jim Bacchus beat William Tolley, the Republican candidate who opposed abortion. Abortion was a major issue in the race.
Under Congressional reapportionment next year, Florida could pick up as many as four seats in the House. After Tuesday's voting, Democrats were expected to retain control of both houses in the Legislature.
 
GEORGIA
 Lieut. Gov. Zell Miller, a Democrat, won the governor's race by defeating Johnny Isakson, the minority leader in the State House. The incumbent, Joe Frank Harris, was ineligible to run for a third term.
Representative Newt Gingrich, the House Republican whip who led a revolt against a White House-approved budget compromise, won a surprising narrow victory over David Worley. Mr. Gingrich is considered a major contender for the top House Republican leadership post. [Page B3.]
In another race Representative Doug Barnard Jr., a Democrat, won re-election to an eighth term despite his problems explaining his ties to savings and loan institutions. Mr. Barnard heads a subcommittee overseeing savings institutions, and he accepted $20,000 in contributions from Charles H. Keating Jr., indicted for his role in the savings and loan scandal.
Representative Ben Jones, a freshman Democrat who was an actor in the television series "Dukes of Hazzard," defeated John Linder, a conservative Republican state representative.
Democrats retained control of the Legislature. The state is expected to gain a House seat through redistricting.
 
KENTUCKY
 Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican, easily beat Harvey I. Sloane, a former mayor of Louisville. Mr. McConnell, a critic of efforts to limit how much candidates for Federal office may spend, raised more than $2 million in campaign contributions this year alone, much of it from political action committees representing companies and industries with business before his committees. Mr. Sloane raised more than $500,000.
Incumbents won all seven of their House races, and the Democrats retained control of both houses in the State Legislature. This could be critical since Kentucky may lose a Congressional seat and redistricting will be in the hands of a Democratic governor and Democrat-dominated Legislature.
 
 LOUISIANA
 Senator J. Bennett Johnston, a Democrat, won re-election last month after a fiery confrontation with Republican David Duke, a 40-year old state representative and former Ku Klux Klan leader who ran without his party's endorsement but picked up 44 percent of the vote in the Oct. 6 primary. Because Mr. Johnston won more than 50 percent of the vote in the primary, no runoff was needed.
In the Jefferson Parish runoff between two black Democrats, State Senator William J. Jefferson, 43, won the Congressional seat opened by the retirement of Democratic Representative Lindy Boggs. Mr. Jefferson, who has served in the Legislature for 12 years, will be Louisiana's first black Congressman since Reconstruction. He defeated Marc H. Morial, 32, a lawyer.
Democrats retained control of the Legislature, which will draw new Congressional districts because Louisiana is expected to lose a House seat.
 
 MISSISSIPPI
 Building on his reputation for assembling coalitions among Mississippi's diverse interests, 52-year-old Thad Cochran won a third term to the Senate, this time uncontested. He was the first Republican this century to win a Senate seat.
Democratic Representative Jamie L. Whitten, who represents the northern Mississippi home country of William Faulkner's writings including Oxford, easily won re-election in the First District, capturing 65 percent of the vote. He has been in the House now for 50 of his 80 years.
 
NORTH CAROLINA
 Despite polls suggesting a much closer race, Senator Jesse Helms easily defeated Harvey Gantt after a nasty Senate campaign. Mr. Gantt, a Democrat and former Mayor of Charlotte, had hoped to become the first black Senator elected from the South since Reconstruction. [Page B3.]
Political analysts said Mr. Gantt had been hurt by Mr. Helms's late television commercials portraying the Democrat as an advocate of racial employment quotas. Mr. Helms apparently also benefited from an unusually heavy voter turnout.
Representative David E. Price, a Democrat, was re-elected despite a well-financed campaign by a Raleigh businessman, John H. Carrington. Another incumbent Democratic House member, James McClure Clarke, was defeated in a close race against Charles H. Taylor, who benefited from growing Republican strength in the western North Carolina district.
North Carolina is expected to add one House seat next year. After Tuesday's vote, Democrats appeared likely to retain control of the Legislature, giving Democrats broad powers over the redistricting.
 
OKLAHOMA
 In a bitterly contested governor's race, David Walters used the 2-to-1 ratio of registered Democrats to Republicans to pull ahead of his opponents. A 38-year-old Roman Catholic, the Democratic candidate supported a woman's right to choose an abortion and took a hard line against new taxes.
The Republican, Bill Price, a former United States Attorney, received 36 percent of the vote, while a dark horse independent, Thomas Ledgerwood, garnered only a small fraction of the vote.
Senator David L. Boren, a Democrat, easily won a third term with a $1 million campaign fund and a popularity that crossed party lines.
 
SOUTH CAROLINA
 Republicans retained control of the Governor's mansion and Democrats kept their hold on both houses in the State Legislature, dividing control of the redistricting process.
Senator Strom Thurmond handily defeated Bob Cunningham, a retired intelligence officer nominated by the Democrats. At the end of his new term, Mr. Thurmond would be 94 years old and the oldest man ever to serve in the Senate.
Representative Butler Derrick, a Democrat, won his ninth term, despite Republican strength in neighboring districts. Representative Liz J. Patterson faced similar problems but defeated Ray Haskett, her Republican opponent.
Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr., the incumbent Republican, defeated Theo Mitchell. Race played a role in this election, with Mr. Campbell using his good working relationship with white state Democratic leaders to defeat Mr. Mitchell, who had hoped to become the first black to win a statewide election in South Carolina since Reconstruction.
 
TENNESSEE
 In this state, the anti-incumbent mood was more rhetorical than real. Senator Al Gore and Gov. Ned McWherter, both Democrats, won decisive victories. Mr. Gore beat William R. Hawkins, a Knoxville economist and a Republican, by a margin of 70 percent to 30 percent. Mr. McWherter easily beat Dwight Henry, a Republican state lawmaker.
All nine House incumbents were re-elected, including Harold E. Ford, a Democrat from Memphis, whose trial on Federal bank and mail fraud charges resulted in a hung jury in April. Democrats retained control of both houses of the Legislature.
 
TEXAS
 State Treasurer Ann Richards, a Democrat, narrowly defeated Republican Clayton Williams, a wealthy rancher and businessman, in one of the nation's most rancorous gubernatorial contests. Ms. Richards' victory was considered a defeat for President Bush, who campaigned hard in his home state. [Page B2.]
The race also was important because of redistricting: Texas is expected to gain three seats in 1992, and Democrats retained control of the Legislature.
Senator Phil Gramm, a Republican, easily won re-election in a well-financed campaign against State Senator Hugh Parmer, a Democrat. Chet Edwards, a Democratic state senator, defeated Hugh Shine, a Republican state representative, in the contest to succeed Representative Marvin Leath, a Democrat who is retiring. Representative Bill Sarpalius retained his Panhandle seat despite a strong race by Dick Waterfield, a Republican legislator.
 
VIRGINIA
 Senator John W. Warner easily won a third term, with no Democratic candidate in the race. Senator Warner's only opposition was Nancy B. Spannaus, a supporter of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., who was listed on the ballot as an independent and took only a small fraction of the vote.
Stan Parris, a 61-year old conservative Republican, lost his House seat to James P. Moran Jr., the 45-year-old Democratic Mayor of Alexandria. In Charlottesville, Representative D. French Slaughter Jr., a Republican, won his fourth term in Congress by defeating David M. Smith.
In the coming redistricting, which will be controlled by the Democrats, Virginia is expected to gain one House seat.

SECTION: Section B; Page 9; Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 2147 words

HEADLINE: THE 1990 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE;
West

 BODY:

ALASKA
 Running as an independent, Walter Hickel pulled away from a crowded field to establish an 8-percentage-point lead over his closest contender, Tony Knowles, the Democratic candidate.
Mr. Hickel, as a Republican, was Governor from 1966 to 1968.
The other candidates scrambling to succeed the retiring Governor, Steve Cowper, had similar lengthy political records. Mr. Knowles was Mayor of Anchorage and Arliss Sturgulewski, the Republican candidate, spent 12 years in the State Senate.
John S. Devens, the Democratic nominee for Alaska's sole seat in the House of Representatives, gave the Republican incumbent, Don Young, a tight race, but Mr. Young managed to overcome his opposition.
And Senator Ted Stevens, a Republican, was one of the first Alaskan candidates in this election to raise his arms in victory, defeating Michael Beasley, a Democat.
Marijuana is again illegal in Alaska -- voters passed a ballot measure that rescinds a law allowing private use of the drug.
 
ARIZONA
 J. Fife Symington, a Republican developer, and Terry Goddard, a Democrat and former Mayor of Phoenix, ran a hot and very close race for Governor -- one that may not be over.
Arizona law requires a majority vote, and it appeared yesterday that the number of write-in votes might keep both candidates below the 50-percent mark, requiring a run-off between the Republican and Democrat.
With about 90 percent of the ballots counted yesterday, Mr. Symington led by 4,527 votes. But Karen Osborne, an assistant secretary of state, said there were thousands of uncounted write-in votes for other candidates.
By a narrow margin, Arizonans rejected the designation of the Rev. Martin Luther King's birthday as a state holiday. The Democrats gained control of the State Senate, while Republicans run the lower house.
 
CALIFORNIA
 Dianne Feinstein, the former Mayor of San Francisco, lost the governor's race to Senator Pete Wilson, a Republican who was once Mayor of San Diego. [Page B2.] As Governor, Mr. Wilson may appoint someone to fill his seat in the Senate until a special election is held in 1992.
In an upset, veteran Congressman Charles Pashayan Jr., a Republican, was soundly defeated by the Democratic candidate, Calvin Dooley. But in two other tight races, the incumbents won: George E. Brown Jr., a Democrat, and Al McCandless, a Republican.
Showing their anger with politicians, voters narrowly passed Proposition 140, which prevents state officeholders from serving for more than eight years; it also caps legislators' office expenses and eliminates their once-lucrative retirement benefits. Voters defeated a more moderate proposition to limit terms and also defeated Big Green, an environmental plan that might have cost billions of dollars.
Democrats retained control of the Legislature, which will draw new Congressional districts as California gains several seats in the House.
 
COLORADO
 Republicans successfully reshuffled several seats and retained control of them all. Following a plan used in other states, the party recruited a popular Representative, Hank Brown, to run for the Senate seat left open by the retirement of William L. Armstrong, a Republican. Mr. Brown defeated Josie Heath, a former Boulder County Commissioner.
Mr. Brown's run at the Senate left open his Fourth District seat. The Republican candidate, State Senator Wayne Allard, defeated State Representative Richard R. Bond.
Incumbents in the state's remaining five districts all were re-elected, while Republicans retained control of the Legislature.
The Governor, Roy Romer, never faced any serious competition and easily defeated the Republican candidate, John Andrews.
Voters approved a ballot proposal to limit members of Congress from Colorado to 12 years in office, and state officials to no more than eight years, a law that legal scholars say may not withstand a constitutional challenge.
 
HAWAII
 Democrats, who have dominated this island state's politics, swept all the major offices. Senator Daniel K. Akaka, appointed to fill the unexpired term of Spark M. Matsunaga, who died in April, handily defeated Representative Patricia Saiki, a Republican. The G.O.P. had seen this race as perhaps its best chance to pick up a seat in the Senate. They hoped Ms. Saiki, a Japanese-American, could win a significant percentage of Hawaiians of Japanese descent, a group that tradtionally favors Democrats. But Saiki campaign officials said yesterday that Mr. Akaka had maintained support among this group.
Democrats won both races for the House, wiith State Senator Neil Abercrombie beating Mike Liu, leader of the Republicans in the State House, and former Representative Patsy Mink winning over former State Representative Andy Poepoe, a Republican.
Gov. John Waihee, a Democrat, easily won re-election, and his party retained substantial majorities in the Legislature.
 
IDAHO
 The incumbent Governor, Cecil D. Andrus, a 59-year-old Democrat, defeated Roger Fairchild, a Republican and former majority leader of the State Senate.
Mr. Andrus served as Governor from 1971 to 1977 and as President Jimmy Carter's Interior Secretary from 1977 to 1981 before becoming Governor again.
Earlier in the year he vetoed what would have been a highly restrictive abortion law. For his part, Mr. Fairchild was a declared opponent of abortion before winning the Republican nomination.
With Senator James A. McClure, a Republican, retiring, the race for his seat was between Representative Larry E. Craig, a Republican, and Ron Twilegar, a Democrat and former State Legislator. The victor was Mr. Craig. Larry LaRocco, a Democrat and stockbroker, won Mr. Craig's Congressional seat, defeating State Senator C. A. Smyser.
The Republicans will continue to control the State Legislature.
 
MONTANA
 Senator Max Baucus, a Democrat, easily won a third term against Lieut. Gov. Allen C. Kolstad, a Republican.
Senator Baucus shunned the campaign complacency of his former colleague, John Melcher, who ignored his 1988 campaign until the summer and was defeated by a little-known Republican, Conrad Burns. Mr. Baucus spent more than a year barnstorming the state and raised more than $2 million in his campaign. Mr. Kolstad evoked criticism in the environmentally conscious state last July by calling threats of acid rain and global warming "scare tactics."
Democrats won control of the Legislature.
Representative Pat Williams, a six-term Democrat who was co-author of a compromise measure that continued Federal financing for the National Endowment for the Arts, overcame a challenge by Brad Johnson, a former state party official who is an aide to Representative Ron Marlenee, a Republican who won re-election in the Second District. Mr. Johnson accused Mr. Williams of supporting pornography.
Reapportioning is expected to cost Montana one of its two House seats in 1992.
 
NEVADA
 Bob Miller, a Democrat who became Acting Governor two years ago, easily won his first election to a full term as Nevada's chief executive.
The 45-year-old Mr. Miller, also a former two-term district attorney from Las Vegas, replaced Richard H. Bryan, who was elected to the Senate in 1988. This time Mr. Miller easily defeated Jim Gallaway, a 50-year-old lawyer and former marine, who used his own considerable resources to finance much of his campaign. Mr. Gallaway stressed his "pro-business, anti-tax" stance and criticized the Governor for his anti-abortion position. Mr. Miller drew two-thirds of the vote.
Democrats gained control of the State Senate and held onto the House as well.
In the Second Congressional District, virtually the entire state outside the Las Vegas area, Barbara F. Vucanovich, the four-term Republican incumbent, easily defeated Jane Wisdom, a member of the State Assembly.
 
NEW MEXICO
 With the incumbent Governor, Garrey Carruthers, ineligible to try for re-election, former Gov. Bruce King was the Democratic candidate for the post. In an energetic race, he beat former State Representative Frank Bond, the Republican candidate.
The 66-year-old Mr. King, a rancher and businessman, was Governor from 1971 to 1974 and again from 1979 to 1982. In this year's campaign, he stressed education, the environment and economic development. To spur economic development, he called for steps to create more growth in the state's private business sector.
Mr. Bond, a 47-year-old lawyer and rancher with land interests, also stressed economic policies, calling for various measures to promote diversfied development and create additonal jobs in the state.
Senator Pete V. Domenici, a third-term Republican, crushed State Senator Tom R. Benavides, a Democrat. Mr. Domenici won almost three-quarters of the vote.
The Democrats retained control of the Legislature.
 
OREGON
 Senator Mark O. Hatfield withstood a stiff challenge from Harry Lonsdale, a Democratic businessman, to win a fifth term in office.
Secretary of State Barbara Roberts, a Democrat, will replace Neil Goldschmidt, the retiring Democratic Governor, after coasting to victory over Attorney General David Frohnmeyer, a Republican.
In the Fifth District, Mike Kopetski, a Democrat, defeated Representative Denny Smith, a Republican. Mr. Kopetski fell just 707 votes short of Mr. Smith two years ago.
But Democrats lost control of the State Assembly, thereby losing control of the redistricting process.
A measure to give parents tax credits if they send children to private schools was defeated 2 to 1. So were attempts to toughen the state's recycling requirements, to shut down its sole nuclear power plant, and to regulate land use more closely. Two measures restricting abortions also failed.
 
UTAH
 Representative Wayne Owens of Salt Lake City, who has been the only Democrat in Utah's delegation, defeated a challenge from Genevieve Atwood, a Republican who is a former State Representative.
Another Democrat, Bill Orton, will join the delegation, in the Provo seat left open by Representative Howard C. Nielson, a Republican who is retiring. Mr. Orton, 42 years old, a tax lawyer and first-time candidate, won in what is often called the most Republican district in the nation. He emphasized his conservative ideology, supporting a balanced-budget amendment, a smaller Federal Government and anti-abortion laws.
Mr. Orton's Republican opponent was former State Senator Karl Snow, a 60-year-old professor and administrator at Brigham Young University, who has been the subject of an investigation by The Provo Herald into his ownership of certain stocks and his business association with a convicted felon.
The State Legislature remains Republican.
 
WASHINGTON
 Representative Jolene Unsoeld, a freshman Democrat who was elected to Congress in 1988 by only 618 votes, defeated Bob Williams, a former State Representative, by 13,000 votes. Mrs. Unsoeld's narrow victory two years ago made her a premier target of Republicans in 1990. Mr. Williams accused Mrs. Unsoeld of being a typical "tax-and-spend liberal." She said Mr. Williams was anti-environment and conservative.
In another contest, Representative John Miller, a conservative Republican in his third term representing the First Congressional District in northern Seattle, defeated Cynthia Sullivan, a member of the King County Council. She said Mr. Miller had neglected local problems, including traffic congestion, and voted wrong on environmental issues. But his endorsement by the Sierra Club and the League of Conservation Voters deflated that issue.
Voters overwhelmingly rejected a sweeping environmental measure because, opponents said, they feared losing control over community issues. Voters in the Seattle-Tacoma area also rejected a proposed real estate tax increase to pay for the preservation of open land.
Democrats retained control of the State House and were in a close race to take control of the Senate.
 
WYOMING
 Alan K. Simpson, the powerful Senate Republican Whip, easily won re-election against a political newcomer. He soundly defeated Kathy Helling, a 32-year-old sociology major at the University of Wyoming who challenged Mr. Simpson's positions on economic development and energy policy. The outcome reflected local polls that showed Mr. Simpson to be Wyoming's most popular statewide official.
In Wyoming's sole Congressional district, Craig Thomas, the freshman Republican who replaced Dick Cheney when he was named Secretary of Defense, defeated Peter Maxfield, a Democratic lawyer and former dean of the University of Wyoming Law Schol.
In the race for governor, Mike Sullivan, a popular Democrat, won re-election with a 2 to 1 ratio. His Republican opponent, Mary Mead, is a rancher and daughter of former Gov. Clifford P. Hansen.
Republicans retain control of the Legislature.

HEADLINE: Sakaigawa Journal;
Faster Than a Speeding Bullet, It's Magnet-Train

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAKAIGAWA, Japan

 BODY:
For as long as Japanese have been riding trains, this country has harbored a dream: downtown Tokyo to downtown Osaka in an hour flat, a 325-mile journey in less time than most weary commuters spend getting to work each day.
Soon that fantasy will begin to roar through the hills of this sleepy town of grape-growers 80 miles west of Tokyo. A few months ago the Japanese Government declared, with some reluctance, that Sakaigawa would be the site of a $2 billion, 27-mile test track for a superconductive magnetically levitated train, a successor to Japan's bullet train. 
 Repelling magnets keep the train running on a bed of air four inches above the track. But no one will be floating on it until well past the year 2000, when the cost of the whole Tokyo-to-Osaka system will rival that of America's planned space station.
But in Japan trains are more than a way of getting people to Osaka, they are a way of getting people rich. And here in Sakaigawa, there seems to be no point in waiting.
 
Pass Through Tunnels
 Months before Sakaigawa was chosen as the site of the test track, and an unlikely one at that, since 85 percent of the trackbed will have to pass through tunnels in the mountains, land prices in this town of 4,400 doubled. There were competing sites for the huge test track, of course, but no savvy investor would look twice.
Little in Japan is coincidental, and the only thing speculators needed to know about Sakaigawa is that it is in Yamanashi Prefecture, the birthplace and home district of Shin Kanemaru. He is perhaps the most powerful politician in Japan, the leader of one of the Liberal Democratic Party's largest factions and one of the aging "dark samurai" known to pull the strings of the Government of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu.
"We often traveled to Tokyo to ask the Government's cooperation in placing the track in Yamanashi," Tatsuo Takeda, the president of the Chamber of Commerce in nearby Kofu City, said recently, spinning out his vision of how townspeople will one day leave their offices here at 11:30 in the morning and make it through the steep mountains in time for a noon lunch in Tokyo. "But we did not spend much money to attract the project.
"Why spend money," heasked, "if Mr. Kanemaru is here?"
 
Automated Golf Carts
 In fact, it is hard to miss Mr. Kanemaru's presence. The best place to view the test track site is from the hilltop Sakaigawa Country Club, a modern, high-tech resort where automated golf carts follow players across the links.
Mr. Kanemaru, as it happens, is club chairman, and there memberships go for around $160,000. One of his sons, the club management says, is a major investor. And the list of "honorary" members includes many of Japan's powerful, including Noboru Takeshita, the former Prime Minister and a Kanemaru ally.
None of this has stirred the slightest controversy in Japan, where it is accepted wisdom that the choicest pork is the kind that barrels along at several hundred miles an hour. There are legendary stories about how former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka arranged for the construction of a bullet train through his home prefecture, bringing sudden wealth to any town influential enough to get a station connecting it to the capital.
In Sakaigawa, Yuhei Fukasawa, the Mayor, is expecting nothing less than miracles, as he often tells Mr. Kanemaru at the club.
 
Taxes and Other Worries
 "We would like to have a residential area, just like Denenchofu," the Mayor said, referring to one of Tokyo's most fashionable. True, he added, some residents are worried about soaring taxes, and more than a few worry about the tracks' enormous magnetic fields.
"I have a few worries myself," he said. "But I am sure they will be alleviated."
No one questions that Japan needs a new bullet train line. The current one, which follows the ancient Tokaido path along Pacific coast from Tokyo to the tip of Kyushu, the southernmost of Japan's main islands, is 26 years old and bursting at the seams.
Its problem is that it is too convenient. Japan's economic boom and a ridiculously overtaxed airport system long ago made the the bullet train the most efficient means of business travel. Now on weekdays it is often hard to find a seat, and on peak weekends, the train often runs at 200 percent of capacity, and people stand in the aisles for hours.
 
The French Rivals
 Moreover, at its top speed of 145 miles an hour or so, it does not seem as fast as it did in 1964 -- especially compared with the 320 miles an hour posted not long ago by the Train a Grande Vitesse in France, which sends shivers through Japan's railroaders.
To minimize embarrassment -- and trim the current three-hour trip from Tokyo to Osaka -- faster trains will soon be put on the old track, despite fears that the bullet train's accident-free record could be jeopardized.
But those are stopgap measures. So long after America dropped out of the magnetic levitation race, Japan kept chipping away at it. And a few years ago the Governor of Yamanashi, Komei Mochizuki, a man who keeps two repelling magnets floating just above his desk, began touting the mountains west of Tokyo as the perfect place for a test track that later could be incorporated into the new line, an inland alternative to the current bullet train's coastal route.
"The advantage of tunnels is that you don't have to purchase the land," he said. "Property rights don't run that deep."
So Japan is embarked on building what may ultimately turn out to be the world's biggest subway system. The risk, of course, is that two cities will become one -- and that Japan, already far too Tokyo-centric, will grow more so.
But eventually Mr. Kanemaru and his fellow Liberal Democrats will no longer have to fight their way to the golf course. Speculators and city officials are already looking for the ideal spot for the station. The smart money, it seems, is within view of the first hole.

He is standing on a rooftop that overlooks the area where track will be built. (David E. Sanger/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Moderately Lower; Gold Prices Close Mixed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended moderately lower against most currencies in volatile trading yesterday, bouncing off early lows with a buying spurt prompted by saber-rattling over the Middle East. Gold prices were mixed.
Currency traders sold aggressively on concerns about a United States economic slump, which led to fears that the Federal Reserve would move to lower interest rates to stimulate business activity. Lower interest rates generally diminish the value of the dollar. 
 Also pushing the dollar down were the Democrats' gains in state and Congressional elections on Tuesday. Democratic economic policies are perceived to be more likely to lead to higher inflation, which erodes purchasing power and could make the dollar decline in value.
But heightened fears of war in the Persian Gulf sent the dollar bouncing back. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher told British lawmakers that Iraq would have to be removed forcefully from Kuwait if it did not leave peacefully.
 
 Dollar Still a Refuge
 "Dealers are still strong believers in the dollar as a refuge during times of uncertainty," said Robert Hatcher, a corporate dealer at Barclays Bank.
The dollar rose against the Japanese yen in New York, closing at 128.73 yen, up from 128.15 on Tuesday. In overnight trading in Tokyo, the dollar fell to 127.55 yen from 127.20 late Tuesday, and in London, it was quoted at 128.15 yen.
The British pound rose to $1.9690 in New York from $1.9657 late Tuesday, and in earlier London trading, sterling rose to $1.9760 from late Tuesday's $1.9635.
Against the German currency, the dollar fell to 1.4874 marks, from 1.4927. And it dropped below 5 French francs for the second time this week, ending at 4.9870 francs, down from 5.0055 late Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Tuesday's late rates, were: 1.2485 Swiss francs, down from 1.2545; 1,116.0 Italian lire, down from 1,121.0, and 1.1671 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1630.
Gold moved erratically in domestic trading. The November contract fell 30 cents an ounce, to $386.30, on the Commodity Exchange in New York, while the active December contract slipped 20 cents, to $387.90. The Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $386.70, up $1.10.
Platinum fell sharply on the New York Merc, erasing most of the gains posted in the two previous sessions. It settled $12.60 to $13.60 lower, with January at $419.10 an ounce.
In earlier trading in London, gold rose to a late bid price of $387.25 from $380.25 late Tuesday. In Zurich, it rose to $386.75 from $379.50 late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $2.51, to $383.64.
In London, silver bullion rose to $4.28, from $4.18 Tuesday.

HEADLINE: THE CREDIT MARKETS;
War Talk Hurts Treasury Prices

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Hawkish statements on the Middle East, a rise in oil prices and worrisome comments from a Federal Reserve Board governor combined to push down prices of Treasury securities and raise interest rates in rocky trading yesterday.
The session began placidly, with prices inching higher after news reports suggested that the Federal Reserve Board, concerned about weakness in the economy, might lower short-term interest rates again at a meeting next week. 
 But later, market participants were rattled and prices turned lower when warlike statements from a variety of Western leaders, including Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, began to appear on traders' computers screens. Those remarks sent oil prices up.
 
 Yield Was Expected
 But bond prices were down only modestly when traders placed bids at the auction of $11 billion worth of 10-year Treasury notes. Dealers said demand was fairly strong, and the bids produced an average yield on the new notes of 8.52 percent, in line with expectations.
The rate, which is down from the 8.77 percent average yield at the last 10-year note sale on Aug. 8, is the lowest yield on a 10-year note since the auction of Nov. 13, 1989.
Shortly after the auction results were announced, traders received another jolt when Lee Hoskins, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, said in a speech delivered in Akron, Ohio, that it would be a mistake for the Fed to lower short-term interest rates further now because that would probably fuel inflation.
"This is a testing time for the Fed," said Mr. Hoskins, an ardent inflation-fighter. "If the Open Market Committee tries to bring down rates now, it is likely we will revisit the 1970's."
Mr. Hoskins is a voting member of the Fed's policy-making Open Market Committee, which will meet next Tuesday to discuss the economy and monetary policy.
 
 'A Turbulent Day'
 "It has been a turbulent day," said Joseph Liro, a vice president and money market economist at S. G. Warburg Securities Inc. "The Hoskins remarks caused some selling and have put a little bit of a negative cast on the bond auction."
Today, the Treasury is expected to offer $10.75 billion of 30-year bonds in the last leg of its quarterly refunding auctions. In when-issued trading late yesterday, the 30-year bond was offered at a price to yield 8.69 percent, compared with 8.64 percent late Tuesday.
The selling pressure also had a negative impact on the new 10-year notes, which late in the day were offered at a price to yield 8.54 percent, compared with their auction level of 8.52 percent.
Declines in Long Issues
Long-term securities bore the bulk of the price declines in the secondary market for Treasury securities.
By late in the day, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 100 5/8, down 5/8 of a point, to yield 8.68 percent. Late Tuesday, the benchmark bonds were offered at a price to yield 8.63 percent.
Among Treasury note issues, the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered in late trading at 101 14/32, down 1/8 of a point, to yield 8.13 percent. The 7 3/4 percent two-year notes rose by 1/32, to 100 7/32, to yield 7.62 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were unchanged to down slightly. In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.07 percent, unchanged on the day. And six-month bill rates fell by 3 basis points, or hundredths of a point, to a late offered rate of 7.03 percent. Easing Is Foreseen
Despite the market's reaction to the comments of Mr. Hoskins, analysts said pervasive economic weakness made it likely that the Fed would move soon to push down short-term interest rates. Moreover, the inflation outlook is improving, the analysts argued.
"I believe the inflation picture is beginning to look much better, due to lower non-oil commodity prices and the slowdown in wage gains that we have seen," said Edward J. Hyman Jr., vice chairman of C. J. Lawrence Morgan Grenfell.
Maria Fiorini Ramirez, president of Ramirez Capital Consultants, said, "I don't think Hoskins represents the majority view" on the Open Market Committee. Now, Mrs. Ramirez said, "concerns about the economy are more important than worries about inflationary pressures."
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, participants said that prices of most issues were narrowly mixed.
More New Issues
No new issues of corporate bonds were priced yesterday, but fresh figures from Moody's Investors Service showed that such issues picked up during October.
Last month, new corporate issues rated by Moody's amounted to $6.6 billion, up sharply from the $4.87 billion in new issues during September and $3.83 billion in August. Despite the pickup, October's total was only about half the $12.5 billion issued in October 1989, and was about 4 percent below 1990's year-to-date monthly average, Moody's said.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, traders said that prices of most widely quoted issues ended down by about 1/8 of a point after moving higher early in the day.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Times to Sell 3 Papers

 BODY:
The New York Times Company said yesterday that it had reached a preliminary agreement to sell three of its regional newspapers to the American Publishing Company, based in West Frankfort, Ill.
Two of the papers are dailies in eastern Kentucky: The Middlesboro Daily News and The Harlan Daily Enterprise. The third, The Claiborne Progress, is a weekly in New Tazewell, Tenn. 
 The newspapers, which have a combined circulation of 21,000, were acquired by the Times Company in 1982, along with a number of other papers. The sale price was not disclosed.
John R. Harrison, president of The New York Times Company Regional Newspaper Group, told employees of the Middlesboro paper on Monday that a review begun last year of all the regional newspapers concluded that the three papers being sold would not provide an adequate return on investment in the current economic climate. He also said no other papers were on the market.
All three newspapers have been profitable and have performed up to expectations, according to Nancy Nielsen, a spokeswoman for The Times. "They are too small for a group our size," she said.
The company owns 32 other regional newspapers in California, Maine and a number of Southern states.
American Publishing operates 65 papers in 27 states. It is a subsidiary of Hollinger Inc., a Toronto-based company that owns 181 publications worldwide.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Seeking Safety In Money Funds

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
THE risk-averse buyers of money market funds are turning increasingly to the safest of such funds, giving up slightly higher yields for the safety of funds that are invested only in United States Government securities.
"There's a real flight to safety," said Hank Schmelzer, an executive vice president of New England Securities. "It shows the level of concern with what is going on." 
 Most of the cash in money market funds remains in those that have the option of investing in a wide variety of assets, including bank deposits and commercial paper, which are short-term loans to corporations. But those funds have been losing market share rapidly this year to funds that buy only Government securities.
The most restrictive of those funds, which buy only Treasury bills, had $26.7 billion in assets this week, up 70 percent from the end of last year and an increase of $653 million in the past week, IBC/ Donaghue's Money Fund Report said yesterday.
Assets of funds that are only slightly less conservative, investing in securities issued by Government agencies as well as in Treasuries, grew by 43 percent over the period, the report said.
By contrast, the assets of the broader group of funds that invest in the entire range of securities have risen just 12 percent in the period.
It is likely that the increased investment in the most conservative money market funds reflects growing public fear over the fragility of the financial system and worries about possible corporate defaults. But it has also come at a time when interest-rate differentials between funds have narrowed, meaning that relatively risky funds offer less of a yield advantage than they did formerly.
The surge in investments in Treasury funds may also be partly the result of nervous investors taking money out of bank accounts. Money market funds are used by many investors as substitutes for bank accounts, with many providing check-writing privileges.
By investing only in short-term securities, money-market funds are designed to assure that investors never take a capital loss. But losses are possible if a security held by a fund defaults.
There have been two significant defaults of commercial paper issuers whose securities were held by money market funds. The first default was by Integrated Resources Inc. in June 1989 and the second was in March, when Mortgage and Realty Trust was unable to meet its obligations. In each case, the fund sponsors made up the loss rather than allow the defaults to affect their customers.
Following those defaults, funds began culling securities that do not have the highest rating of the bond-rating agencies. That trend has been accelerated because of a rule proposed by the Securities and Exchange Commission that no fund may invest more than 5 percent of its assets in securities not rated top grade.
Martha Wittbrodt, the editor of IBC/Donaghue's Money Fund Report, said that 19 money market funds in June did not qualify for that publication's highest quality rating because they invested in paper that was not ranked in the top two grades by at least two rating agencies. Now there are two, she said.
One result of the flight to quality by fund managers has been that the spread of money market yields has narrowed. At the end of May, the average 30-day simple yield for all taxable money market funds, as computed by IBC/Donaghue, was 7.68 percent, 28 basis points higher than the rate on the average money market fund that invests only in Treasury securities. A basis point is one hundredth of a percentage point. By the end of September, that spread had fallen to 17 basis points. Since then, however, it has been growing again as some less creditworthy borrowers have been forced to pay higher rates. As of Monday, the spread was back to 23 basis points.
If that spread continues to widen, it will serve as an indication that concerns over credit quality are growing, as relative rates rise on all assets that lack an explicit Government guarantee. It will also make it more tempting for money market fund investors to give up a little safety in the hope of getting a higher yield.

GRAPHIC: Chart showing the combined market share of two types of taxable money market funds, based on assets. (source: IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report)

HEADLINE: Bush Administration Is Split On Taiwan's Joining GATT

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7

 BODY:
The Bush Administration is divided over a long-pending application by Taiwan to join the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the 100-nation agency that oversees global trade.
Taiwan's bid to join GATT is strenuously opposed by China, whose application for membership was put on hold after the June 1989 massacre of students at Tiananmen Square. The State Department is siding with China, unwilling to risk its support on several foreign policy fronts. One of five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council, China voted to impose sanctions against Iraq after its invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. 
 But Taiwan's application has the enthusiastic support of the United States Trade Representative, Carla A. Hills, as well as the major committees of trade and foreign affairs of the Senate and the House of Representatives.
"We have a unique opportunity to bring under GATT discipline one of the last major market-price-based trading entities outside the GATT system," Mrs. Hills said in a letter to the House Ways and Means Committee. She added that the admission of Taiwan would "greatly benefit U.S. commercial and trade policy interests and the international trading system as a whole."
 
 Baker Urges Caution
 Taiwan, the world's 13th-largest nation, as measured by trade, is the fifth-largest American trading partner. By joining GATT, Taiwan would accept obligations to comply with internationally agreed-upon trading rules. For example, it would be obligated to take steps to open its markets.
The Government of Taiwan has promised to provide $1 billion in aid to developing nations should it be admitted to GATT.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, in a letter to the Ways and Means Committee, said that while Taiwan's membership may be "desirable in principle," the "political questions involved require careful consideration."
The State Department said that some American allies share Mr. Baker's concerns, but it declined to name those nations.
Beijing has been supporting the Bush Administration's search for a peaceful settlement in Cambodia and Washington's position in the Persian Gulf crisis.
On Capitol Hill, Mr. Baker has opened the Administration to further charges of being soft on China.
Citing continued restrictions on political dissent in China, many lawmakers have been critical of the Administration's decision last spring to extend trade concessions to China for another year. The House voted overwhelmingly last month to take away those benefits; the Senate did not act, so the benefits continue.
 
 Lack of Atonement
 The House also approved an amendment sponsored by Representative Philip M. Crane of Illinois, urging the President to consider, in granting any new concessions to Beijing next year, the extent to which Beijing has moderated its position on Taiwan's GATT membership.
A senior Republican on the Ways and Means Committee, Mr. Crane argues that because of China's lack of atonement for the Tiananmen massacre and the enormous strides made by Taiwan in promotion of freedom and democracy, "we can no longer tolerate the Chinese Government dictating to us what our policy toward Taiwan ought to be."
China's position is that it is the legal government of Taiwan, which it views as part of China.
"The Taiwanese authorities have no right for accession to GATT on their own," said Li Songlin, chief of the public affairs office at the Chinese Embassy here. "Only after China resumes its status as a contracting party to GATT and with approval of the Chinese Government will it be possible to consider the question of Taiwan's application."
 
 Economic Motive Cited
 Sensitive to the objections from Beijing, Taiwan applied for GATT membership in January not as a sovereign government, but as the "Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu," all islands off the Chinese mainland. They were taken over when Chinese Nationalist forces of President Chiang Kai-shek withdrew from the mainland after the Communist takeover in 1949.
Taiwan officials say they have received favorable responses on the membership application from "nearly all GATT members."
A brochure issued by Taipei says the objective of GATT membership is "entirely economic," adding that "the territory has no wish to provoke or antagonize Mainland China through its GATT application."
Jeremy Shen, an economic officer at the Coordination Council for North American Affairs, which represents Taiwan in the United States, explained that because of Taiwan's growth as a trading power, GATT membership has become "an urgent matter."
Although Taiwan's trading regime conforms in many respects to GATT standards, the trade benefits it has granted and received over the years have all come through onerous bilateral negotiations.
But because its trading relations have become so extensive, the bilateral approach no longer meets Taiwan's needs, Mr. Shen said. Taiwan does business with more than 140 countries and trading areas. Its international trade totaled $118 billion in 1989 and its foreign reserves have grown spectacularly, to $60 billion.

HEADLINE: War Talk Pushes Oil To $35.31

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Spooked by tough talk from Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, the price of oil rose sharply yesterday. Traders also cited a variety of colorful rumors and further speculation about war.
Crude oil for delivery next month closed at $35.31 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, up $2.68, its sharpest gain in two weeks. 
 Oil products also jumped, with heating oil for December delivery gaining 6.33 cents, or $2.66 a barrel, to close at 92.71 cents a gallon, and unleaded gasoline rising 3.44 cents a gallon, to 91.19 cents.
The biggest factor in the oil gains was said to be a speech by Mrs. Thatcher on the floor of Parliament in which she issued a warning to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. "The implacable message of this House," she said, "must be: Either he gets out of Kuwait soon or we and our allies will remove him by force and he will go down to defeat with all the consequences. He has been warned."
 
 'A Matter of When'
 Whatever the reaction in Baghdad, oil traders in New York took notice, as did the stock and bond markets. The Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 44.31 points, to 2,440.84, and the benchmark 30-year bond fell and its yield climbed. [Pages D10 and D12.]
"The consensus is, it's just a matter of when we're going to war," said Peter Beutel, of the Pegasus Econometric Group, of Hoboken, N.J. Of the impact of the saber rattling on the oil market, he said, "We've heard it from our own Administration so many times that people on the trading floor were getting tired of it." But from Mrs. Thatcher, he said, it was new.
At the Institute for International Economics in Washington, Philip K. Verleger Jr., a visting fellow and commodities market expert, said, "The British seem to be the stalking horse for this thing."
"Logically, it's better to have someone else making the threats," he said. "Mrs. Thatcher's better at it than George Bush, and it's deniable; we can say, she was speaking for the British and not speaking for us, and it has the desired effect."
Some traders said President Bush appeared to have a freer hand now that Election Day has passed.
The trend in the market had been generally lower in the last few days, with oil actually dropping more than $2 on Monday after reports that production had returned to the level prevailing before the embargo was imposed against Iraq and Kuwait in early August.
 
 Red Adair Rumor
 But Stephen P. Piaso, a trader at Lehman Brothers, said after yesterday's close that "the war premium has returned to the market." Oil experts say that if supply and demand were the only factors, the oil price would be in the mid- to high-$20's, but that fear of war has pushed it higher.
Late in the trading session yesterday a rumor crossed the floor that the Pentagon had hired Red Adair, whose company extinguishes oil fires and caps blowouts, to go to Saudi Arabia to evaluate safety there. A switchboard operator at the Red Adair Company in Houston, who would not identify herself, said the company had had several calls asking about the rumor but had no comment.
Another rumor was that James A. Baker 3d, the Secretary of State, who was in Turkey and Moscow, yesterday, had sent a message to Mr. Hussein through the Chinese foreign minister that if Iraq did not pull out of Kuwait within two weeks, the United States would go to war. Mr. Baker denied it.
And finally, the market, which in the past has moved sharply on reports of Saddam Hussein's dreams, took its cue in part from the phases of the moon. Traders said that the new moon this weekend represented a window of opportunity for military action, with dark conditions favoring the United States.
 
 Worst-Case Estimates
 But several traders said that if war did come, their estimate of how high prices would rise was lower now than it had been earlier in the crisis. Nauman Barakat, at Merrill Lynch, said, "It will be very difficult for Saddam to take out the Saudi export facilities. Even if war were to break out, the runup won't be much more than to $50 or $55" in the price of oil.
"There is a considerable school of thought that the day war breaks out, you've got to sell the market because the worst case scenario has materialized," he said. "If the export facilities aren't damaged, then the market has seen the top."
Mr. Beutel said that fear of war had already pushed the market up substantially without any shooting. He referred to the possiblity that an actual war would not push prices higher as the "all-dressed-up-with-no-place-to-go scenario."

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Allies Tell Baker Use of Force Needs U.N. Backing

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 7

 BODY:
Midway through Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's tour of Europe and the Middle East, it has become clear that Washington's partners in the coalition against Iraq will not consider using military force unless it is authorized by the United Nations, American officials said today.
The officials said the Turkish Government added its voice today to those of the Bahrainis, the Kuwaitis, the Saudis, the Egyptians and the Chinese, with whom Mr. Baker met at earlier stops, saying that if the United States wanted to maintain the international consensus against Baghdad it must obtain the approval of the Security Council before undertaking any offensive military action. 
 A senior State Department official, briefing reporters after Mr. Baker's meetings with the Turkish leadership, said, "The reaction we are getting at every stop is that people agree on the centrality of the international consensus aligned against Saddam Hussein.",
"As we move forward," he said, "you want to maintain the international consensus to the extent possible and certainly further United Nations action would be a good measure of that continued international support."
 
Baker Heads for Moscow
 The Secretary of State left Ankara late today for Moscow, where he will try to persuade the Soviets to support United Nations authorization for a strike against Iraqi forces, if sanctions alone cannot dislodge them from Kuwait. After Moscow, Mr. Baker goes to London and Paris.
The senior State Department official said that while the Bush Administration insisted that, legally, it already has the right to use force under Article 51 of the United Nations Charter, for political reasons it will need to go to the Security Council for specific authorization.
Article 51 stipulates that a member of the United Nations can ask other members for help in resisting aggression against its territory. Article 42 allows the Council to order "action by air, sea or land forces" to enforce an embargo.
"Legally," the senior official said, "our position and the position shared by others is that Article 51 provides a sufficient basis under international law for further action."
But he added that a Security Council resolution authorizing some specific military action "would provide a firmer political basis," as had a Council resolution authorizing navies to interdict Iraqi shipping.
 
U.N. Action This Month Hinted
 "I think the idea is to try to maintain that international political consensus to the extent that you can, as you move further along into this crisis, " he said, "because it is the international solidarity in all its measures that is intended to have the effect on Saddam that would lead him to realize that the best means out is a peaceful withdrawal."
The official strongly hinted that the Administration would try to push through some type of United Nations authorization for the use of force this month, when Thomas R. Pickering, the American delegate, will take his turn as President of the Security Council. Whoever is President of the Council has a great deal of influence over its agenda.
"I think action at the United Nations Security Council during the course of the U.S. presidency is one of the issues being discussed at all of these stops," the official said. "I think we would want to have a good month in our term as President of the Council. Certainly we want the gulf to be the focus of our efforts."
Judging from what President Turgut Ozal of Turkey told Mr. Baker, the Iraqis will not be leaving Kuwait soon. Mr. Ozal, the State Department official said, informed Mr. Baker that while the sanctions were indeed pinching the Iraqi economy, Turks in Baghdad had reported that the pain was not enough to "alter Saddam's political calculations and lead him to withdraw peacefully."
"We are obviously not yet to that point," the official added.
Turkish Foreign Ministry officials were quoted as saying that Mr. Baker did not bring up the idea of Turkey's opening up a second front against Iraq, along their common border. President Ozal dismissed the idea as nonsense earlier in the week.
 
'Turks Are Pragmatic'
 American officials say the Turks are concerned that a war that devastated the Baghdad Government could lead to the breakup of Iraq and leave Turkey with a huge, fragmented country on its eastern border.
Turkey is also wary about taking actions against Iraq that will create permanent enmities between the two nations.
While the Turks have abided by the United Nations sanctions, losing an estimated $7 billion in revenues and remittances as a result, the coalition has not fulfilled its promises of economic aid except for $300 million from the Kuwaitis. Turkish officials made that point repeatedly to Mr. Baker.
"Some people say Turkey was too keen to join the sanctions and create a dangerous enemy out of Saddam Hussein," Ilnur Cevik, a columnist for The Turkish Daily News, wrote. "Turks are pragmatic. We know very well that when the gulf crisis is over and the marines pack their bags and go home, we will be left on our own to deal with its legacies. Therefore, we would like to remind them of these facts so that they too expect no more than what we have done so far. We do not want to be dragged into any military adventure."

GRAPHIC: Photo: James A. Baker 3d, left, meeting in Ankara yesterday with President Turgut Ozal of Turkey. Mr. Ozal's Government added its voice to those ofWashington's other allies in the Persian Gulf in saying that any use of force against Iraq should be approved by the United Nations Security Council. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
U.S. Aide Arrives in Syria for Talks on Gulf

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 7

 BODY:
Assistant Secretary of State John H. Kelly arrived unexpectedly in Damascus today for talks with Syrian leaders on the Persian Gulf crisis, officials said.
Mr. Kelly is accompanying Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d on a tour of the region. Officials said he would meet with the Syrian Foreign Minister, Farouk al-Sharaa.
Diplomats expected Mr. Kelly to face tough questions from Syria on increased American military and economic aid to Israel since the outbreak of the Persian Gulf crisis.
Syria became Washington's unlikely ally in the gulf crisis when it sent troops to join a United States-led multinational force in Saudi Arabia.
Officials said today that the Foreign Ministers of Egypt and Saudi Arabia, Esmat Abdel-Meguid and Prince Saud al-Faisal, would come to Damascus on Friday to discuss with Mr. Sharaa how to form a united Arab front against Iraq's occupation of Kuwait.
"The ministers are expected to reiterate that a peaceful settlement of the gulf crisis could never be achieved unless Iraq unconditionally pulls its forces out of Kuwait and the Kuwaiti Government is reinstated," an official said.
