HEADLINE: The 1990 Elections: Signals - The Message;
The Big Vote Is for 'No'

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

 BODY:
The nation's voters didn't much like the choices presented to them in Tuesday's midterm elections.
Only a third of those eligible to do so even bothered to cast ballots. On the face of it, those who did liked incumbents best, as long as they worked far away -- on Capitol Hill, not in the state capital. But while only one senator and about 15 representatives were unseated, dozens of others got the scares of their lives, and scores found their accustomed margins of victory cut. 
 Evidently unhappy with politics as usual, the voters liked independent candidates, beholden to neither party. They liked proposals that would limit the terms of legislators. They liked straight arrows and arrows once bent, now trying to straighten out.
They were less consistently enthusiastic about women and blacks as candidates. They were hostile to some, but not all, candidates and initiatives that they thought had cost them money or were likely to. With one big exception, they disliked people they found extreme in style or viewpoint, and they were put off by most candidates bearing the scent of scandal.
They were impressed by some big names but unimpressed by some of the very biggest, like George Bush and Mario M. Cuomo and Bill Bradley.
 
Dilemma for the Governors
 What they liked least was incumbent governors, those highly visible people who often face the dilemma, in these straitened times, of cutting services or raising taxes, with Washington providing less help than ever and asking the states to do more than ever to look after the unfortunate.
In the confusing welter of returns, those were the most evident of many patterns. By its very nature this midterm election was an imperfect national referendum, often dominated by personalities and local circumstances rather than overarching issues, full of exceptions and contradictions.
For Mr. Bush, who appeared at no fewer than 115 Republican fund-raising events this year, it was a bad day because he lost the governorships of two states that he coveted, Florida and Texas, and because his party's already feeble position on Capitol Hill was further weakened. A poll of voters who had just cast their ballots, taken by Voter Research and Surveys, showed that Republican House candidates lost the backing of about a third of the voters who said they had voted for Mr. Bush or for his predecessor, Ronald Reagan.
The poll also indicated that Democrats and Republicans split the white vote and the votes of men in the House races, which meant that women, blacks and Hispanic voters were crucial to Democratic success. Interviews for the survey were carried out across the country and involved 17,770 voters.
 
No Democratic Nirvana
 Mr. Bush could claim extenuating circumstances as he pondered the outcome, including the difficulty that almost all Presidents have faced in influencing the course of midterm elections, and the ineptitude of the Republican candidates in Texas and Florida, which wasn't the President's fault.
The final results hardly represented nirvana for the Democrats, either. They lost the biggest bonanza of them all, California, and they saw the Republicans sweep the contests for governor across a broad stretch of the still-pivotal Middle West -- Ohio, Michigan, Illinois, Iowa, Wisconsin, Minnesota -- one of the regions of the country where Presidential elections are won or lost.
Before the balloting on Tuesday, voters had told poll-takers and reporters and politicians themselves that they were disgusted, fed up, turned off.
But many of those voters said they liked their own Congressman or Senator, even if they found most politicians unpalatable. In the event, the power of incumbency for those on Capitol Hill proved considerable even in the face of populist rumblings. About 96 percent of House and Senate incumbents were re-elected; not many of the rascals were thrown out, for all the hulabaloo.
 
Some Shrinking Margins
 Of the 406 members of the House who won re-election, a tentative tabulation by The New York Times indicated, 102 of them -- about a quarter -- did so with less than 60 percent of the vote. Average margins were bigger in 1988 and 1986, about the same in 1984.
But there were a lot of close calls, for Representative Bill Dickinson of Alabama, a thoroughly entrenched Republican, who got 51 per cent this time and 94 per cent in 1988, and Representative Carl Perkins of Kentucky, a solidly established Democrat, and Representative Olympia Snowe of Maine, a seemingly secure Republican, both of whom barely scraped through to victory.
Of those House incumbents who actually lost, many did so because of scandals of various kinds. Representative Roy Dyson of Maryland, a Democrat, was linked to Defense Department scandals. Alleged sexual improprieties defeated Representatives Arlan Stangeland, a Minnesota Republican, and Jim Bates, a Democrat from California.
The multifaceted savings-and-loan scandal, which many had thought too complex for voters to understand, claimed a number of victims: Representatives Charles Pashayan Jr., a Republican, and Douglas H. Bosco, a Democrat, both from California, and Representative Denny Smith of Oregon. Two other Democrats, Representatives Frank Annunzio of Illinois and Doug Barnard Jr. of Georgia, both survived attempts to implicate them. Mr. Bates and Mr. Bosco held out hopes that absentee ballots, still to be counted, might save their seats.
 
Clean Is In
 A poll of voters in Ohio showed that Sen. John H. Glenn Jr., one of the five senators linked to Charles H. Keating Jr., the failed savings-and-loan tycoon, might have had trouble if his name had been on the ballot; 18 percent of the respondents said he should resign now, and 39 percent more said he should not seek re-election in 1992.
The other side of that same trend was the success of candidates seen as clean-cut, like William F. Weld, the boyish Brahmin Republican who was elected governor of Massachusetts, and Senator Pete Wilson of California, elected governor there, who described himself to a reporter not long ago as "a white bread kind of politician."
Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and Walter J. Hickel, both running as independents outside normal partisan combat, were elected governor of Connecticut and Alaska, respectively. Arne Carlson, a soft-spoken Republican who only re-entered the Minnesota governor's race in the final two weeks, was a similar case.
The exception was Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina, a Republican who ran a typically bare-knuckle campaign in which some detected racism.
 
Overcoming Problems
 Lawton Chiles, the governor-elect of Florida, has had problems with depression. Ann Richards, the governor-elect of Texas, who is the first liberal Democrat since Ralph Yarborough more than two decades ago to score a victory of comparable scope there, has fought a long battle against alcoholism. But both found ways to look squeaky clean, Mr. Chiles by spurning big campaign contributions, Ms. Richards by branding her rival as a mudslinger.
The survey of voters in Texas showed that 26 percent considered the Republican campaigner, Clayton Williams, the dirtier campaigner, as against 23 who thought Ms. Richards had earned that description, and 24 percent thought the two were equally dirty -- a narrow margin, but Ms. Richard's victory was narrow, too.
Ms. Richards was one of three women elected governor, but Dianne Feinstein, the Democratic nominee in California, lost, and Gov. Kay Orr of Nebraska, a Republican, failed in a re-election bid. Highly regarded Republican women in Congress from Rhode Island, Illinois and Hawaii, failed to unseat Democratic senators, and each of them was replaced in the House by a man.
 
Respected, but Defeated
 Harvey Gantt of North Carolina failed in the bid that would have made him the Senate's only black member, and two of three black Republican candidates for the House, all well thought of, also lost.
Taxes and the budget battle hurt a lot of people, starting with Mr. Bush himself and including Republican representatives who backed the budget deal, such as Peter P. Smith of Vermont and Jack Buechner of Missouri.
Nor did the Republican leadership of the House, which got itself into a tactical tangle during the budget deadlock, emerge unscathed. Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the majority leader, was unopposed, but his number two, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, won by fewer than 1,000 votes in a supposedly safe district, and Representative Guy Vander Jagt of Michigan, head of the campaign committee, was held to an unusually low 55 percent.
Term-limitation measures, implying lack of confidence in the system, passed in Colorado and California and Kansas City; environmental initiatives, indicating willingness to spend money for intensified government action, were beaten in California, New York and a number of other jurisdictions.
Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, apparently taken as a surrogate for Gov. Jim Florio, who pushed through record tax increases, barely survived, as did three House members in the state. Exit polls showed that taxes and the economy were major factors on the voters' minds.
But the pattern was uneven, here as elsewhere. Jim Edgar, a Republican who said he would perpetuate a tax surcharge for educational use, won the tight Illinois governor's race, and a tax-rollback initiative, widely denounced as unrealistic, went down to defeat by a big margin in Massachusetts.

HEADLINE: The 1990 Elections: New York - Bond Act
New Math on Both Sides of the Hudson;
Defeat of the Environmental Bond Act May Mean Higher Taxes in New York

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD

 BODY:
The defeat of the $2 billion environmental bond act on Tuesday leaves communities throughout New York State with few ways to pay for urgent and costly landfill and recycling programs, many of them required by law.
As a result, residents already confronting a weakened economy may be faced with higher local property taxes, increased fees or service cuts in some towns to pay for measures mandated by state law, like the closing of leaking garbage landfills. New York City and Long Island may be particularly hard hit in a region that has all but run out of places to dump its waste. 
 Assessing the loss, politicians and environmentalists said yesterday that voters apparently acted on their concerns about the cost of the bond act at a time of widening budget gaps in Albany. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo attributed the loss in part to the inability of bond act proponents to explain why borrowing would not be a burden.
State officials estimated that the measure would have cost each resident $7 a year during the life of the bonds, over as much as 30 years, far less, they said, than the cost of increased property taxes or fees. Interest on the $1.975 billion bond would have doubled the overall cost of the issue. The bond act had designated $525 million for landfill closings and recycling. Communities that had hoped to borrow from the state for sewage-treatment plant improvements will now have to look elsewhere. Some of the $800 million in the act for land purchases was intended to protect drinking water sources, efforts that will now be delayed or done at the expense of other programs.
Threats of property tax increases could also put pressure on state legislators to place another environmental bond issue on the ballot in coming years, or find other ways to pay for problems like garbage disposal.
 
First Defeat of the Century
 The bond act's defeat was embarrassing to Mr. Cuomo, who had made the measure a leading campaign issue, and the state's environmental community, which underestimated the extent of opposition.
Voters turned back the 21st Century Environmental Quality Bond Act by a narrow margin, 51 percent to 49 percent, or less than 70,000 votes of 2.6 million cast. In addition to land acqusition and landfill or recycling programs, money from the bond would have been used to preserve historic buildings.
This is the first environmental bond act of the century to be defeated, after nine consecutive approvals.
Upstate voters trounced the environmental bond act. Many residents rejected it because they feared money from the act would be used to buy private land for conservation in areas like the Adirondacks, opponents said.
 
'Nervous About the Future'
 New York City and Westchester County voted overwhelmingly in favor of the bond. But in Nassau and Suffolk counties, where proponents thought they could count on strong support, residents were much less enthusiastic than they were in 1986, when a $1.45 billion bond act on closing hazardous waste sites passed by margins exceeding 2 to 1. In fact, Long Island's diminished support for the environmental act accounted for the difference between its winning and losing.
In Suffolk County, the 1990 act won by only about 8,000 votes, 75,000 fewer than in 1986. In Nassau County, residents approved the 1990 act by 50,000 votes, but 40,000 less than the winning margin in 1986. The 1990 act lost by less than 70,00 votes.
Patrick G. Halpin, Suffolk County Executive, attributed the vote to residents' concerns about the economy. "People are very nervous about the future," he said.
He said defeat of the bond act is particularly costly to Long Island.
"People really didn't understand the relationship of the funding of the bond act and their local property tax bill," said Tony Bullock, East Hampton town supervisor. "The impact to local property taxes will be enormous."
East Hampton, for example, faces as much as $22.5 million in costs for closing landfills in the next few years, as required by the state, Mr. Bullock said. The town had hoped that the bond act would cover as much as half those expenses, he said. East Hampton's 18,000 residents cannot afford the property tax increases, which could exceed $1,000 per taxpayer, if they are required to pick up the slack, he said.
Also, setting up a recycling and composting plant will cost $7.5 million, and the town was expecting the bond act to cover as much as half of that, he said.
Other communities are also affected.
 
There Goes the Beach
 The bond act's defeat reduces the prospects for Erie County to develop a bathing beach near downtown Buffalo on Lake Erie and to renovate a house designed by Frank Lloyd Wright for use as a state historic site, said Richard Tobe, the county's commissioner of environment and planning. The beach project is estimated to cost $12 million, and the Wright renovation, several million. Neither were required.
Mr. Tobe also said the county had hoped for some bond-act money for improvements in aging sewage-treatment plants in the next 5 to 10 years.
He said local taxes cannot support such expensive projects. He said new construction might be halted to keep sewaage-treatment plants operating within design limits.
Albert F. Appleton, the Environmental Protection Commissioner, said New York City lost a lot when the bond was defeated.
Over all, officials estimate the city lost from $500 million to $700 million. It lost $100 million for an esplanade on the Hudson River; $100 million for recycling and landfill projects, and $100 million to $200 million for park programs, like the Staten Island Green Belt, a chain of parkland running through that borough. Several million dollars was also lost for sewage-treatment plants and medical waste disposal.
In addition, the city lost $100 million for land in the Catskill watershed area, where the city gets 90 percent of it drinking water. The Department of Environmental Protection has begun a watershed protection program, one piece of which requires buying land surrounding city reservoirs.
"Watershed protection has got to be the top priority," Mr. Appleton said. He said the program will have to be financed either through higher water rates or at the expense of other city environmental programs, like water main replacement and sewers and sewage-treatment plant improvements.
The city's recycling program could also be hurt. The Sanitation Department expected nearly $100 million for recycling demonstration projects, processing centers and programs to develop markets for recycled material, said Steven M. Polan, the Sanitation Commissioner.
"Many of these programs are not going to go away because the bond act was voted down," Mr. Appleton said. "All this has done is shift the debate back to the State Legislature, at the worst possible time."

HEADLINE: The 1990 Elections: New Jersey - A Governor's Response
New Math on Both Sides of the Hudson;
Hearing Tax Outcry in New Jersey Vote, Florio Says He'll Consider New Course

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
Seemingly chastened, Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey said yesterday that the near defeat of Senator Bill Bradley on Tuesday had sent a "humbling message" aimed at himself and his aggressive tax and social policies, and that he was opening his entire legislative program to revision.
That would include New Jersey's new school-financing law, which is shifting large amounts of state aid from rich school districts to poorer ones. 
 "I got the message; the results were really directed at me and the policies of my administration," Mr. Florio said. He said there was "great skepticism" among voters about whether his policies would meet their goals.
 
Bradley Feels the Anger
 In fact, political experts were saying that "skepticism" was an understatement of the wrath that had nearly ruined Mr. Bradley, who had long been New Jersey's most popular Democrat and who had been mentioned before Tuesday as a potential Democratic presidential contender.
"There is no support for the belief in redistribution of income if it means higher taxes," said Steven Salmore, a Republican political consultant and professor at Rutgers University. "I can see no other message than that."
At his campaign headquarters, Senator Bradley said that a little more than a week ago he sensed the anger of voters over taxes that led to his narrow margin of victory -- 55,180 votes out of 1.9 million cast -- over his Republican opponent, Christine Todd Whitman. [Page B16.]
Governor Florio's statement yesterday came months after his administration put through a host of liberal social programs, including the school-refinancing law. To pay for them and to balance the budget he pushed through $2.8 billion in tax increases.
In his own campaign last year, however, Mr. Florio had said repeatedly that he saw no need to raise taxes. When he did so after taking office, many New Jerseyans saw his approach as arrogant and willful. Even as his program was watched as a test of whether the public would support a liberal Democrat's plan to tax the rich to aid the poor, a broad tax revolt erupted at home.
Among New Jerseyans leaving voting places on Tuesday, four out of five disapproved of Governor Florio's fiscal policies, a poll by Voter Research and Surveys showed.
In a statehouse news conference yesterday, Mr. Florio said: "Last night's races brought home to me, somewhat dramatically, that I could have done a lot better in bringing people into the Democratic process. There is a need to look at everything we've done to make sure it achieves the goals and delivers on the promise."
Mr. Florio said the school-financing formula, which shifts hundreds of millions of dollars from New Jersey's wealthiest suburban school districts to less affluent cities and towns, was an "easily identifiable" issue in which the admininistration will work "to bring more people into the process."
 
Avoiding Specifics
 The Governor said he remained committed to his goals, but he added that none of his policies could survive unless people believed they would bring positive results.
At the same time, he and his aides avoided discussing what concessions they might make to their critics and, in particular, how they might agree on revising a host of tax increases, from a one percent rise in the sales tax to income tax increases for the wealthy.
Earlier this week, officials said, Mr. Florio instructed aides to begin reviewing the education and tax legislation for possible revisions. But the administration is also limited by an unexpected fall in tax revenues brought on by an economic slowdown, and by a state Supreme Court decision requiring increased aid to the state's poorest districts.
In addition to the near miss of Mr. Bradley's campaign, Mr. Florio saw a heavily financed Democrat lose a special State Senate election on the New Jersey shore, and he suffered the defeat of a $135 million bond issue that he had proposed to provide affordable housing.
Both the State Senate candidate, Edward H. Salmon, and the housing bond had been opposed by Hands Across New Jersey, a citizens action group formed in response to the Florio tax plan.
In the First Congressional District, in the Camden area -- which Mr. Florio had represented for 15 years and where Democrats outnumber Republicans two to one -- the Democratic candidate, Robert Andrews, won a race that politicians in his own party called disappointingly close.
 
'He Is Well Advised to Listen'
 Some Democratic officials who are looking ominously at legislative elections next year responded positively to the Governor's message.
" I think it is the wisest thing to do; when the public speaks, he is well advised to listen and listen well," said Robert C. Janiszewski, the Democratic Executive of Hudson County. "I think people in the party will welcome an opportunity to open up the dialogue. This election will prompt us all to re-examine where we are. That involves everything from soup to nuts."
Several Republican legislators and at least one founding member of Hands Across New Jersey reacted cautiously. They said they were encouraged by the Governor's words but would wait for him to take action, like moving to repeal his tax increases.
"If you are ready to fish, fish," said Garabed Haytaian, the Republican Minority leader of the State Assembly. "If you are ready to cut bait, cut bait."
 
2 Sides to Florio
 In recent weeks, as polls showed Mr. Florio's support among voters dropping, the administration has become sharply divided between two factions of advisers and, officials say, between two sides of Mr. Florio's personality.
On one side, Mr. Florio's Treasurer, Douglas C. Berman, and his Director of Communications, Jon Shure, have urged the Governor to continue speaking out on behalf of the tax program. Their advice resonates with a side of the Governor's personality, they said, that sees political issues as battles between right and wrong. At times Mr. Florio vowed to continue speaking out for policies on moral grounds even if the public rejected them.
Other advisers, including Mr. Florio's Chief of Staff, Joseph C. Salema, have urged Mr. Florio to stop trying to save the world and begin trying to save himself.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
U.N. Aide Fears Iraqis Can Militarize Medicine

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 7

 BODY:
A senior official in charge of enforcing economic sanctions against Iraq expressed concern today that Baghdad may be importing pharmaceuticals and other medical supplies that could be used in the manufacture of chemical or biological weapons.
The official, Marjatta Rasi of Finland, who heads the United Nations Security Council committee monitoring compliance with the trade embargo, said at a news conference that Iraq is bringing in "tons and tons of medicines it does not need." 
 She expressed concern that these medicines could include "dual purpose" pharmaceuticals that might be used to help Iraq's known program for manufacturing chemical and biological weapons in breach of the Security Council's total arms embargo.
Miss Rasi said her suspicions had been aroused because in some cases Iraq has imported sufficent quantities of drugs to last it for up to 10 years.
 
Experts Discount Threat
 But medical experts contacted by Reuters said such a threat is unlikely.
"Our people say the idea of using medications for making chemical weapons is not too plausible," said William Grigg of the American Food and Drug Administration. "It would be more probable if they were importing agricultural chemicals -- pesticides and the like."
Thomas Lemke, a chemist at the University of Houston, told Reuters that most medicines were too weak to be used to poison a water supply and too complicated to be broken down into their constituent parts.
As to building a biological arsenal from imported vaccines, "the answer is no," said Alan Goldhammer of the Industrial Biotechnology Association, a trade group. "The only thing it could conceivably be receiving would be vaccines, and they are either disabled or inactivated."
 
Treaty Being Prepared
 Miss Rasi said that negotiators preparing a treaty in Geneva to ban the manufacture or possession of all chemical weapons have also expressed concern to her about Iraq's continued large pharmaceutical imports.
But she said she had no clear evidence of sanctions violations and no firm numbers on the amount of medicine Iraq is receiving.
This is because the Security Council resolutions imposing trade sanctions on Iraq for its annexation of Kuwait specifically exclude medicines from the embargo as does the resolution extending this embargo to all air traffic.
Some countries have told the Security Council's sanctions committee they were sending in medicines when they asked its permission to fly planes to Baghdad to evacuate their nationals but usually without specifying exactly what these medicines were. So far the Council has authorized about 20 such flights.
 
Inspections Not Required
 But in addition, Miss Rasi said some nations, which she did not identify, appeared to be flying in supplies of medicine directly, merely telling the countries their planes fly over that they are carrying pharmaceuticals. As a result, the planes are not required to land for inspection to insure they are not breaking the trade ban.
Miss Rasi said she favored some tightening of the trade sanctions to make sure that only genuine medicines were sent into Iraq as well as steps insuring their use only for humanitarian purposes. The sanctions committee is expected to discuss the issue at a meeting here on Thursday.
Miss Rasi said that in other respects the trade embargo appeared to be working well and that the committee had still received no reports of any violations.
While a good harvest and the looting of supplies held in Kuwait has enabled Iraq to survive without great hardship so far, she predicted "a major grain shortage" by next spring as well as a general deterioration of the country's economy through lack of raw materials and spare parts.

HEADLINE: U.S. VIEW PREVAILS AT CLIMATE PARLEY

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, Nov. 7

 BODY:
United States negotiators today turned aside an effort to set specific targets for wealthy countries to reduce emissions of carbon dioxide, which is widely expected to cause a dangerous heating of the global atmosphere.
Instead, the 135 nations represented at the World Climate Conference ending here today adopted a declaration that urges countries to set targets, national programs or strategies to limit so-called greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide, but avoided further details. 
 Such gases are known to trap heat in the atmosphere, and their concentrations are growing. Many scientists expect that this will cause the global climate to warm substantially, but they disagree whether this has yet been demonstrated.
Despite pleas from scientists and politicians at the conference, two of the world's largest producers of the gas, the United States and the Soviet Union, refused to commit themselves now to cutting their output of carbon dioxide.
But the 10-day conference had other, immediate effects: it galvanized rich nations besides the United States into pledging cutbacks in their own carbon dioxide production, thereby putting new pressure on Washington.
The pledges will mean higher costs in the near future for cars, heat and electricity, and a rush to produce more efficient machines and appliances. Japan, Canada, Australia and New Zealand and 18 European nations have announced such plans to cut back carbon dioxide.
 
New Environmental Market
 The gathering also served to confirm that industries in the world's two strongest economies have been reading the trends correctly: companies in Japan and Germany are already racing to produce technology to match environmental concerns. Politicians and industry representatives from both nations said environmental policies are creating enormous new economic opportunities.
The Geneva meeting, held under the auspices of the World Meteorological Organization and the United Nations Environment Program, is a stage in the work toward a global convention on addressing climate change.
Although formal negotiations for the treaty do not begin in Washington until Febrruary, some industrial nations pushed here for strong language with specific targets applying to rich countries, who jointly account for 75 percent of the world's carbon dioxide, most of them by burning fossil fuels.
The United States succeeded in watering down key portions of the 30-point document adopted by consensus today. United States negotiators led an effort to include wording that emphasized the scientific uncertainties surrounding global warming and that evaded a commitment to channel new technology to protect the environment at almost no cost to poor nations.
The United States supporters most in evidence were oil exporters like Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and the Soviet Union, who like Washington argued that not enough was known to act now on climate change. Western negotiators had expected no pledges from the Soviet Union, the largest producer of carbon dioxide after the United States; its inefficient industries and economy would be unable to afford the investment in cutting back pollution.
 
China Opposes Cutbacks
 China, another large polluter, said it could make no cutbacks because that would mean it could not industrialize. "We need not cut back because our per capita emissions are very low," said a delegate. "An American uses 18 times more energy than a Chinese."
John Knauss, director of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, who led the United States delegation, said Washington had refused to set targets because "it does not believe in them," adding: "It's as simple as that. We are not prepared to guarantee our projections."
European governments agree that by raising taxes and using energy more efficiently they can cut back or reverse close to 20 percent of their carbon dioxide emissions over the next 10 years without impairing economic growth. Japan and other nations concur. But they concede that cuts beyond this target will become more difficult.
American officials here, however, questioned the European targets, which they characterized as political goals not easy to put into effect. European officials at the conference argued that the European Community's common strategy to cut pollution was prepared not just by environmental ministers, but also with energy ministers.
In Italy, Germany, the Netherlands and Great Britain, parliaments have already approved the program to cut carbon emissions. The agreement reached by European Community countries last week is binding, and all members are expected to submit their by the end of this year.
The intense haggling over the conference declaration, which lasted more than five days, has given a glimpse of how difficult it will be to reach an international accord on global warming. Many developing nations here fought against language that committed them to curbing population growth. Nations with tropical forests insisted on complete sovereignty.
As experts here last week debated scenarios of a world 50 years from now, delegates from African and Asian countries said they were frustrated because, they said, more study should be focused on dealing with extreme climate variations causing floods and droughts today.

HEADLINE: Advanced Chip Offered By Texas Instruments

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Nov. 7

 BODY:
Restoring a touch of pride for American makers of computer chips, Texas Instruments Inc. said today that it was delivering limited supplies of its model of the world's most advanced memory chip to some of its largest customers.
Samsung of South Korea and Hitachi and Toshiba of Japan have made similar announcements within the last two months, and NEC of Japan said it would begin small shipments of its dynamic random access memory chip that stores 16 million bits or two million characters before the end of the year. 
 Texas Instruments, one of the few American chip makers that did not quit making memory chips in the early 1980's, accounts for a big share of the nation's memory chip output. Japanese companies held 69 percent of worldwide memory chip sales in 1989, and American producers had 16 percent, according to Dataquest Inc., a research firm in San Jose, Calif.
 
 'Perseverance Has Paid Off'
 "It's nice to know that Texas Instruments' perseverance has paid off in being able to compete," said Ione Ishii, a Dataquest analyst who follows the industry. She said worldwide sales of 16-megabit memory chips would exceed $5 billion in 1994.
The executive directing Texas Instruments' production of the advanced memory chips, Lionel White, said in a statement that design engineers and computer industry managers say Texas Instruments has a slight lead over its foreign competitors in the race for high-volume production.
"According to our customers, these 16-megabit samples are the first they've seen that are based on a design developed for high-volume production," he said. Initial output of the chips will be from the company's newest semiconductor plant, in Avezzano, Italy. Other Texas Instruments plants in Dallas; Miho, Japan, and Taiwan will be equipped later to make the chip.
The International Business Machines Corporation and American Telephone and Telegraph Company have also spent heavily to develop and produce the 16-megabit chip, but virtually all of their output would be for their own products.
The 16-megabit memory chip is certain to lead to smaller and more powerful products in the computer and telecommunications industries, as well as find broader uses in aircraft, automobiles and other products. It is also a crucial technology being developed for high-definition television.
A single 16-megabit D-RAM chip the size of a fingernail can provide two million characters of storage in computers. That is about four times the total capacity of the I.B.M. and similar personal computers in the mid-1980's using as many as 20 chips.
 
 Agreement With Hitachi
 Texas Instruments has shared research in developing the 16-megabit chip with Hitachi through an agreement the companies signed in 1988. Stan Victor, a spokesman, said the Texas Instruments' chip was based on the company's own designs and manufacturing process.
In mastering the high-volume production process, Texas Instruments reduced the width of electronic circuits in the new chip to less than a one-hundredth of the width of a human hair, or nearly six-tenths of a micron.
Texas Instruments' shares gained 12.5 cents, to $25.75, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange today. The shares traded as high as $27.375 during the session but retreated during the market's broad selloff later in the day.

HEADLINE: Talking Deals;
Satellite TV's Appeal to Comsat

BYLINE: By Edmund L. Andrews

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WHEN the Communications Satellite Corporation bought a majority stake in the Denver Nuggets basketball team, a lot of people wondered why. Now, as the company contemplates investing $100 million in a new satellite television venture, the answer seems clear.
Robert J. Wussler, president of Comsat Video Enterprises and formerly the second-in-command at Turner Broadcasting System Inc., wants do with satellites what his former boss, Ted Turner, did with cable television. Mr. Turner, who owns the Atlanta Braves baseball team and Atlanta Hawks basketball team, has used his franchises as a cornerstone for sports programming over the TBS and Turner Network Television cable channels. 
 "Just as VCR and cable television were methods of distribution for the 1980's, we think direct-broadcast satellite is the technology of the 1990's," Mr. Wussler said in an interview.
But even the most charitable securities analysts are reserving judgment. Comsat's record is littered with earlier, botched attempts to enter new businesses, from satellite antennas to telephone equipment, that have cost the company hundreds of millions of dollars since 1980.
 Based in Washington, Comsat serves as the Federal Government's representative to Intelsat, the international satellite consortium owned by 119 governments, and its core business has been providing international communications through Intelsat. It is a strong business that earned $105 million on revenues of $280 million last year.
But with both its rates and profits are determined by the Federal Communications Commission, Comsat has repeatedly tried to move into less regulated areas.
A year ago, the company paid $18 million for a 62.5 percent stake of the Denver Nuggets. Company officials say the move was primarily intended to give them an entree in negotiating broadcast rights with other teams and leagues.
Comsat is now weighing an investment of $100 million to $125 million in a new direct-broadcast satellite company, the Skypix Corporation, of Seattle, its officials confirm. It wants to broadcast about 80 channels of programming, including 40 to 50 movies and a rich array of sports events, directly to households around the nation using antennas less than 2 feet in diameter. Viewers would be charged for each program they watch.
Skypix has spent $20 million developing its technology and estimates that it needs $200 million to $300 million more to bring the system to market. Comsat is reported to have signed a memorandum of understanding to invest a big chunk of the capital, provided Skypix can line up other investors and get the F.C.C. to approve its transmission technology. "We have made no firm commitments yet," a Comsat spokesman, Richard McGraw, said.
Mr. Wussler thinks satellite broadcasting has considerable appeal. He likes that direct-broadcast satellites can reach rural viewers who cannot be connected to cable television. Also, by using new transmission technologies, Skypix and other companies hope to send multiple channels of programming over a single satellite transponder, offering the promise of lower costs and greater variety in programming.
Two large rivals are developing their own satellite systems: Sky Cable, a joint venture backed by NBC, Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, Hughes Communications Inc. and the Cablevision Systems Corporation, and K-Prime Partners, a venture backed by several large cable television companies.
But analysts are dubious about Comsat's plans, given its record. At Comsat Video Entertainment, losses on a "pay per view" movie service for hotel rooms that began several years ago climbed to $18 million in 1989 from $5 million in 1987 and are expected to reach at least $25 million this year. Part of the trouble is that a software glitch allowed some customers to watch movies without being billed. But the more enduring problem is that Comsat Video lags the industry leader, Spectradyne Inc., in signing up hotel chains that cater to business travelers.
Also, in the early 1980's, Comsat sank $193 million into building two direct-broadcast satellites, only to stop the project amid poor market prospects. There have been other dead ends in manufacturing: Since 1987, the company has sold off or abandoned operations that made satellite dishes, earth stations, microwave amplifiers and a host of other equipment.
 After all this, some analysts contend that Mr. Wussler should stay closer to Comsat's core business, where demand is growing. "We urge our clients to sell their shares now, before Comsat management buries them even more with their next fiasco," wrote James M. McCabe, an analyst at Normura Securities, in a recent report.
Mr. McGraw of Comsat responded that his company would not make a rash move. "This is not a fly-by-night decision that Comsat is trying to make," he said, noting that it has been looking at direct-broadcast satellite for more than a year. "When we do make a decison, it will be one based on good market research and a good business plan that provides a good return for our shareholders."

HEADLINE: THE 1990 ELECTIONS: Governor's Race;
Cuomo, Omnipotence Blunted, Gets Back to Budget

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

 BODY:
On the heels of a successful, but still disappointing, re-election bid, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo returned to Albany yesterday to confront one of the most severe challenges of his tenure: how to balance the state budget when the nation is slipping into a recession, New York City is edging toward a fiscal crisis and voters in New York State appear to be fed up with tax increases.
Compared with other governors facing angry electorates, Mr. Cuomo emerged from Tuesday's vote relatively unscathed. In Rhode Island and Florida, for example, the incumbent governors were defeated. In Massachusetts and Connecticut, the incumbents did not even bother to run. 
 But for most of his eight years in office, Mr. Cuomo has enjoyed an image of near omnipotence that was sorely challenged by the election results. And both fiscally and politically, he is now heading into his third term in what is probably the weakest position he has been in as Governor.
 
'The Toughest Time'
 "I think this is the toughest time he's had to face," said the Assembly Speaker, Mel Miller, a Brooklyn Democrat.
The Governor, Mr. Miller said, "did not do so well" in the election. On top of that, he said, "I don't think the problems have ever been worse."
Mr. Cuomo, who under better circumstances rarely misses an opportunity to meet the press, was uncharacteristically silent yesterday on the subject of the election.
Through his press office, he issued a statement expressing gratitude toward his supporters, but acknowledging disappointment.
"Given the difficult challenges confronting local governments across the nation, and the anti-incumbent sentiment born of those hard times, the continued strong support of the voters was particularly generous," he said.
 
Many Reasons for Concern
 For Mr. Cuomo, the results of virtually every major contest in the state gave reason for concern.
In his own race, Mr. Cuomo showed unexpected weakness, receiving 53 percent of the vote against opponents who early on in the race had been dismissed as sure losers. Four years ago the Governor's total was 10 points higher.
"Clearly the Governor is still popular, but not anywhere near the numbers he had four years ago," said Lee Miringoff, director of the Marist Institute for Public Opinion in Poughkeepsie, which does frequent polling on state politics. "I think he was caught up in some of the same anti-incumbent buzz that affected other governors."
The Republican challenger, Pierre A. Rinfret, received 22 percent of the vote; the Conservative candidate, Herbert I. London, polled 21 percent.
The defeat of the proposed $2 billion environmental bond issue, which Mr. Cuomo had vigorously campaigned for and had become closely identified with, was not only a political setback for the Governor, but was also a significant fiscal blow. More than $60 million from the now nonexistent bond act money has already been committed, leaving the state further in the hole at a time it can ill afford more debt.
The failure of the Democratic Party to gain control of the State Senate represented another rebuke to the Governor. Mr. Cuomo had campaigned energetically for several Democratic candidates, only to have the Republicans pick up a Senate seat. They now control the Senate 35 to 26.
 
Tougher Budget Balancing
 Mr. Cuomo and the Senate Republicans have often been at odds over fiscal issues, and the Republicans' strong showing is likely to make the Governor's task of balancing the state budget, which at last count was $824 million in the red, that much tougher.
"The Senate can now make the argument: 'We're mainstream,' " said Mr. Miller.
Aides to Mr. Cuomo attributed much of Tuesday's results to low voter turnout in areas, particularly New York City, that have historically been the Governor's greatest sources of support. The environmental bond act, for example, received overwhelming support in New York City, but a disproportionately low turnout there gave a strong "no" vote upstate more significance.
Paradoxically, it was the weakness of the Governor's opponent that explains, at least in part, that shift in turnout.
Republican State Senate candidates, eager to avoid falling victim to Mr. Rinfret's erratic campaign, mounted vigorous "get-out-the-vote" efforts, while many city voters stayed home.
"The Governor was a victim of a weak opponent," an adviser to Mr. Cuomo said. "People didn't vote in the city because they thought the election was a done deal."
 
'A Very Clear Message'
 Unofficial results from the New York State Board of Elections, show that almost 55 percent of the eligible voters upstate went to the polls, compared with 35 percent in the city.
Republicans, however, dismissed the Cuomo administration's characterization of the results, interpreting the returns as a proof that voters were fed up with Mr. Cuomo's policies.
"People aren't happy with taxes; they aren't happy with crime," said the State Senate's majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, a Nassau County Republican. "I think it's a very clear message."
Republicans in Washington joined with Republicans in New York to pronounce Tuesday's results a sign of weakness that would dog Governor Cuomo in any Presidential bid.
"I think some of the luster is taken out of Cuomo's Presidential candidacy," said Roger Stone, a Republican political consultant. "It was a sort of hollow victory for him."
Democrats, however, said that whatever setbacks the Governor suffered were minor compared with those suffered by many other incumbents and would soon be forgotten, leaving Mr. Cuomo's national ambitions -- if he has them -- unaffected.
"I don't think anyone will remember this in two weeks," said Carter Eskew, a Washington-based Democratic consultant. He noted that whatever damage Mr. Cuomo had suffered as a possible Presidential candidate, President Bush, who campaigned hard for several losing gubernatorial candidates, had probably suffered more.
"You have to remember," he said, "while it may have been a mixed bag for Mario Cuomo, it also was a bad day for George Bush."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who was uncharacteristically silent on the subject of election results, taking a walk yesterday in Albany. (David Jennings for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Mayor to Seek Cuts to Close Budget Gap

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
In an important test of his credibility in the financial world, Mayor David N. Dinkins is to present today his plan for service reductions and other cuts that could mean several hundred layoffs to help close a gap of about $400 million in New York City's budget.
The plans call for closing two fire companies, cutting hundreds of school workers, including teachers, delaying recycling programs and eliminating 150 administrative jobs in the city hospitals, most of them through layoffs. They will also mean dirtier streets and parks, reduced library services and cuts in perquisites and aides for police and fire officials. 
 Up to the last minute, there was sharp disagreement on the impact of the cutbacks, with school officials contending that the $90 million in savings they were being asked to find would force the average school to lay off five to seven teachers in midyear, or the equivalent dollar value in other employees. The total for the city would be roughly 6,200 teachers, or the equivalent in less costly employees, said the deputy schools chancellor for operations, Stanley S. Litow.
 
'A Tragedy for Our Schools'
 Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez issued a statement yesterday saying that the Mayor's plan was "riddled with inaccuracies and terribly misleading to the public" and that the cuts were "a tragedy for our schools." He said that asking schools to make such reductions "is very unfair and a cruel message to our city's children."
But senior administration officials, while acknowledging some school layoffs could be needed, said they hoped most cuts could be made through attrition by not replacing workers, and by cutting more than the 200 workers in central headquarters jobs that schools officials have agreed to.
The Mayor issued a statement last night saying he regretted Mr. Fernandez's "intemperate comments" and urging him to use his "proven management and leadership skills" and "moral suasion" to make reductions that would keep layoffs to a minimum.
Final details were still being hammered out last night, even as Mr. Dinkins and his aides ended an unusual whirlwind round of advance briefings and meetings with business leaders, fiscal monitors and elected officials in an effort to assure support for their proposals for keeping the budget in balance for the fiscal year that ends June 30.
That support is needed because the city is to issue more than $2 billion in notes and bonds in the coming weeks. Last month, Wall Street rating agencies warned that the city's credit rating on its bonds might fall, forcing it to pay higher interest rates, if it did not act aggressively to cut costs.
But one key official, Peter F. Vallone, Speaker of the City Council, whose approval is needed to enact the budget modifications, was angered that the Mayor intended to brief him at 8 last night -- well after some private citizens had been briefed -- and he said he would skip the briefing and give the plan "deep analysis" today.
Mayoral aides allowed that cutting teachers, even through attrition, would be hard but neccesary, since the school system takes up one-quarter of the city's budget and has largely been spared the trims other agencies have been required to make in recent years.
 
Support at Stake
 The battle over the schools budget is a delicate political dance for Mr. Dinkins, who has dedicated his administration to children, and for Mr. Fernandez, who took office at the same time Mr. Dinkins did with a mandate to reshape the system. Neither can easily afford to lose the other's support, or the support of the Board of Education, whose president Mr. Dinkins appointed.
But Mr. Fernandez has told associates that City Hall is creating a job crisis in the schools to pressure the teachers' union into abrogating the recent 5.5 percent wage increase it won.
Mr. Dinkins's aides deny that, though he has been under pressure from fiscal monitors, since he agreed to the raise, and even yesterday his labor negotiators were struggling to reach settlements with other workers.
Mr. Litow said City Hall's proposed budget cut would mean that the city's 634 elementary schools and 178 middle schools would be forced to cut as many as five to seven teachers each and the city's 120 high schools as many as 20 teachers apiece.
District superintendents and high school principals could choose to make the cuts among other personnel -- administrators, school aides, guidance counselors, security guards, lunchroom workers and administrators -- instead of teachers. The ability to cut the teaching staff is limited by contractual ceilings placed on class size.
The plan to be outlined today is far from the last of the bad news likely to come from City Hall in the next several weeks. Mr. Dinkins must still grapple with the mix of greater cuts or new taxes that will be needed to close a gap of perhaps $2 billion for the fiscal year that starts next July 1. The administration said as many as 35,000 layoffs might be needed.
For now, several agencies were able to stave off deeper cuts. Mr. Dinkins allowed the Fire Department to trim 1 percent of its budget, or slightly more than $6 million, instead of the 2 percent, or $13 million target originally proposed, fire officials said.
The department will eliminate 55 chief's aides, who serve as drivers and on-scene coordinators at fires, freeing those firefighters for regular duty. It will also close two fire companies, though no firehouses, in undetermined neighborhoods, not the 18 companies that Fire Commissioner Carlos A. Rivera had warned might be closed.

HEADLINE: The 1990 Elections: Signals - The Outcome;
VOTERS OUST GOVERNING PARTY IN 14 STATES; CONGRESS IS SHAKEN BUT FEW ARE UNSEATED

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

 BODY:
A divisive, tumultuous midterm election has ended with a striking new class of governors, a strengthened Democratic majority in Congress and some ominous signals for President Bush and other potential candidates in 1992.
After days of strenuous campaigning in Sun Belt states where Republicans hoped to build on the Reagan legacy, Mr. Bush saw both his party's candidates and his prestige suffer in Tuesday's voting. 
 Democrats, picking up one Senate seat and eight in the House of Representatives, remained dug in on Capitol Hill, ready for two more years of assertiveness toward Mr. Bush. But they saw less than overpowering performances from two of the party's brightest Presidential hopes, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York and Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey.
 
Shifts in 14 Races
 In the biggest change on Tuesday, 14 of the governorships shifted from one party to another. Two of them went to candidates who ran as independents: Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut and, in Alaska, Walter J. Hickel, a former Interior Secretary.
Political strategists concluded that 1990 would go into the books as a difficult, unpredictable year in which voters decided to throw out some incumbents, shake up some others and might have done more if they had been offered a choice of stronger challengers.
"If Congressional incumbents read their re-elections as a vote for the status quo, they'll be sadly mistaken," said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic poll taker. "This was a year when it wouldn't have taken much to tip the scales."
 
Big Prize for G.O.P.
 Democrats made serious inroads into the Sun Belt, picking up the governorships of Florida and Texas. But Republicans managed to hold on to the biggest single prize, California, and also wrested two big Middle Western states from the Democrats -- Ohio and Michigan -- as well as the Democratic stronghold of Massachusetts.
The 36 governors' races provided the clearest reflection of this year's volatile electorate, which was buffeted by the threat of war in the Middle East and recession at home, angry at politics and politicians, worried about a range of local issues and grumpy over the President's backpedaling on his 1988 no-new-taxes pledge.
This restiveness left its mark on two potential Presidential candidates: Mr. Cuomo won re-election with just 53 percent of the vote against weak opposition, and Mr. Bradley barely survived a challenge from a little-known Republican, Christine Todd Whitman.
It was also reflected in the close calls many incumbents had on Election Day, including Representative Newt Gingrich, the second-ranking Republican in the House, who barely survived a challenge in his suburban Atlanta district.
Howard Schloss, a spokesman for the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, said the re-election margins for incumbents were lower than usual "pretty much across the board."
According to Common Cause, a Congressional watchdog group, the number of House incumbents re-elected with 60 percent of the vote or less was twice as high as the number in 1988.
 
96 Percent of House Members
 For all of that, 96 percent of the House members seeking re-election prevailed, down just slightly from the 98 percent rate of the past two election years. Still, some analysts said the voters' discontent boded ill for elected officials in 1992, when the redrawing of Congressional district lines and retirements will create the potential for sweeping change in the House.
Fred Wertheimer, head of Common Cause, said the 1990 election demonstrated how the advantages of incumbency, particularly the campaign financing system, can thwart an angry electorate bent on change. "The system blocked people from really beating incumbents," Mr. Wertheimer said. "Where the anger really played out was at the margins."
Democrats were eager to present the election results as a rebuff to President Bush. Ronald H. Brown, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, asserted, "More than anything else, this election has been a vote of 'no confidence' in George Bush."
But more damaging to Mr. Bush was the pervasive sense in his own party that the White House had jeopardized its candidates by mishandling the budget negotiations. Democrats used the budget talks to hammer the Republicans as the guardians of the rich.
 
'You Win Some'
 Mr. Bush spent a quiet day in the White House, while Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, tried to play down Mr. Bush's influence on the elections. "You win some and you lose some," Mr. Fitzwater said. "We campaigned hard in Texas and lost, campaigned hard in California and won."
Privately, some Republicans said they were relieved that the party came out as well as it did. "We've been through so much in the last couple of months, there was a palpable sense of relief that it wasn't worse," one Republican strategist said.
In briefings yesterday, Republican officials tried to put the best face on the midterm results. Representative Guy Vander Jagt, chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, said that Republicans had done well considering the losses often suffered by a President's party in midterm elections. "And we had U.S. troops in the desert and an economy on the brink of recession," Mr. Vander Jagt said.
Edward J. Rollins Jr., the Republican Congressional committee official who has clashed openly with the White House over the budget talks and their impact on Republican candidates, said, "I think it's important for the President to sit down with House Republicans and make peace."
Mr. Rollins said he believed that Mr. Bush was "extremely well-prepared to run for re-election in 1992," but also gave voice to the concern widespread among Republican strategists. Republicans, he said, need to pay attention to the voters, attracted in President Ronald Reagan's heyday, who have given them the margin of victory in many crucial elections, like blue-collar Democrats.
"Ten to 12 years of successes can leave you fat, dumb and happy," Mr. Rollins said. "We may have taken some voter groups for granted."
In the short term, Mr. Bush faces a Democratic Party emboldened by its victories on Capitol Hill and, even more importantly, by the whiff of Mr. Bush's vulnerability. "From Labor Day on, the noise you hear is the hissing of air coming out of his balloon," said Harrison Hickman, a Democratic poll taker. "This punctured the balloon of his invincibility."
 
Contrasts in Treatment
 There were many currents and crosscurrents in this election. The clearest contrast was between the beating that voters accorded their governors and the comparatively gentle treatment they gave members of the House and Senate.
"It's partly a story about the difference between executives and legislators," said Thomas E. Mann, director of governmental studies at the Brookings Institution, a Washington research group. "Executives are forced to make decisions and be held accountable for them, while legislators, particularly in a time of divided government, are often able to blur lines of responsibility and accountability."
It also reflects the two parties' long-range strategy: Neither anticipated the voters' angry mood this year and did the kind of aggressive recruiting of candidates that would have enabled them to take advantage of it.
Voter turnout in Tuesday's elections appeared to be the same as it was in 1986, when the level was the lowest in nearly half a century, said Curtis Gans, a voting analyst who is director of the Committee for the Study of the American Electorate. In 1986, 36.4 percent of the eligible voters went to the polls.
The Democrats pushed their majority in the Senate to 56 to 44, a change of just one seat from their previous 55-to-45 margin, with the upset of Senator Rudy Boschwitz, Republican of Minnesota. The Democrats also added eight seats to their already lopsided 259-to-176 majority in the House at the beginning of the term. Two of the House seats were vacated during the term, one by a Democrat and the other by a Republican.
Mr. Boschwitz lost at the hands of Paul Wellstone, an underfinanced political science professor whose campaign was emblematic of the outsider, insurgent appeals that popped up in the autumn of 1990. But most Senate incumbents beat back their challengers by sizable margins, including three Republican Senators, Jesse Helms of North Carolina, Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon and Mitch McConnell of Kentucky.
Democratic incumbents in contested races who also prevailed included Senators Daniel K. Akaka of Hawaii, Paul Simon of Illinois, Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island, John Kerry of Massachusetts, Jim Exon of Nebraska and Carl Levin of Michigan.
 
Impact on 1992 Races
 The Democrats' success on Tuesday means that Republicans will have a far more difficult time in regaining control of the Senate in 1992. The Republicans had hoped to pick away at the Democratic margin this year in advance of an all-out assault in 1992. Democrats have 20 members up for re-election in that Presidential election year, while the Republicans have only 14.
The races for governor were far more competitive. One of the most dramatic contests was in Texas, where Ann Richards, a Democrat, won a come-from-behind victory over Clayton Williams, the millionaire oilman whose rough-hewn style became more controversial than charming as the election went on. The election also saw a different kind of comeback story with Lawton Chiles, a Democrat who retired from the Senate two years ago, saying he was burned out, but returned to claim the governorship of Florida from the Republican incumbent, Bob Martinez.
Republicans captured the big prize of the night by winning California, where Senator Pete Wilson prevailed in a bruising battle against Dianne Feinstein, the former mayor of San Francisco. They also won an upset victory in Michigan, where John Engler ousted the Democratic incumbent, James Blanchard, and captured the governorship in Ohio, where George Voinovich defeated Anthony J. Celebrezze Jr.
This created an unlikely portrait of gains by Democrats in the Sun Belt and by Republicans in Democratic strongholds of the Middle West. But analysts cautioned that the governors' races were usually intensely idiosyncratic, a reflection of local issues and concerns rather than national trends.
This election year was widely expected to be dominated by the abortion issue, but it played out in far more complicated ways than it did in 1989. Both sides had victories to cite this week. Abortion rights supporters noted that the governorships in Florida, California and Texas were all won by candidates who support legalized abortion. The anti-abortion groups noted that candidates embracing their cause prevailed in the Kansas and Ohio governors' races, as well as in North Carolina's Senate race.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
EGYPT'S PRESIDENT CALLS FOR A DELAY IN ATTACKING IRAQ

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Nov. 7

 BODY:
President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt said today that the coalition allied against Iraq should wait "at least two to three more months" to determine whether the economic sanctions were able to force President Saddam Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait. But he warned President Hussein that if he did not pull his troops out, war was inevitable with "the greatest concentration of military force I have ever seen in this area."
"There will be no other way way out," Mr. Mubarak declared. "I am not bluffing. I don't think the United States is bluffing. How can Saddam Hussein make such a miscalculation of his situation? It is very dangerous for him, very dangerous. I wonder how he cannot realize that." 
 In an interview the day after he conferred alone with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d about the course of action to take against Iraq, the Egyptian leader said the time had come for the United Nations Security Council to approve a resolution authorizing the use of the military force to end Iraq's occupation of Kuwait if diplomacy failed.
 
Outlines of a Consensus
 His remarks were consistent with those of aides to Mr. Baker and of Saudi officials in Riyadh, who had met with Mr. Baker earlier. This seemed to suggest that a timetable was emerging by consensus, projecting possible combat early next year if there is not an Iraqi pullout by then. There also appears to be widespread agreement that an explicit Security Council resolution authorizing force should be adopted before military action is mounted.
[Further increasing Washington's pressure on Iraq to leave Kuwait, Pentagon officials said today they would add 100,000 troops to the force in the gulf region by the end of the year, bringing the number of American forces there to about 350,000. Page A15]
In the interview, Mr. Mubarak's sense of betrayal by Mr. Hussein and by King Hussein of Jordan came through clearly, and in effect, provided some of the emotional backdrop to his strong anti-Iraq position.
Mr. Mubarak, 62 years old, used the almost two-hour-long interview at the 19th century, Moorish-style Kuba Palace to send a plea and an urgent warning to President Hussein not to doubt the international commitment to liberate Kuwait. Mr. Mubarak said that as a military man since 1949, he understood all too well the consequences of a military clash.
"The problem of Saddam Hussein is that he is one man against the world and even against himself simply because he does not realize the real danger around him," Mr. Mubarak said. "And his entourage is not briefing him adequately."
In the wide-ranging interview in his ceremonial office, President Mubarak presented the most detailed account to date of his efforts to prevent the gulf crisis and later to resolve it. He discussed previously secret messages and other contacts with Iraq aimed, he said, at saving the man who had repeatedly misled and betrayed him. He sketched a terrifying portrait of Arab politics, including betrayals by Arab leaders who had previously called him their Arab brother.
And he categorically rejected accounts of the early days of the crisis, which were sympathetic to the Iraqi point of view, presented by King Hussein of Jordan in a series of interviews last month.
Desperate Search For a Way Out Visibly angered at the Iraqis as he recounted events before and after the crisis, Mr. Mubarak, a solidly built man, spoke in controlled terms, choosing his words carefully in English, gesturing broadly and emphatically with his powerful hands to underscore his determination.
He emphasized that after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, he had repeatedly tried without success to find a "face-saving" way out for Saddam Hussein. "I was trying to help him," Mr. Mubarak declared. Even today, he said, he would welcome the Iraqi leader in Egypt as part of an effort to find such a face-saving solution.
But he would not go to Baghdad on such a mission, he said, nor would he countenance any effort to permit President Hussein to withdraw less than totally from the sheikdom that his forces have occupied and plundered for the last three months. That is why, he said, he could not countenance a call last week by the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, for an Arab summit meeting.
"Why an Arab summit?" Mr. Mubarak asked. "What would we do there? We won't give a blessing for his occupation.
"That is what he wants," Mr. Mubarak said, referring to President Hussein. "I'll never give it to him. It's a matter of principle."
"We have done everything we can do," he added. "The answer from the Iraqi Government has been insults and dirty words against me. Either he doesn't realize the tremendous forces being arrayed against him, or his aides are misleading him or not telling him."
 
 Fate of Egyptians In Iraq Lamented
 The Egyptian President, who came to power after the assassination of Anwar el-Sadat in October 1981 and who is entering his 10th year in office, excoriated Iraq for its treatment of some of the million-plus Egyptians who have worked for years in Iraq, often in the military and in other vital jobs. After the Iran-Iraq war ended in 1988, he said, 300 to 400 Egyptians -- as many as 8 or 9 a day -- had been killed in incidents by Iraqis.
"They were returning them in coffins," the President said. "Hundreds and hundreds of coffins."
Since Aug. 2, he said, "some 270,000 Egyptians have returned from Kuwait and Iraq, many having lost all of their savings and possessions."
Eygpt had privately protested the deaths several times through the Foreign Ministry, Mr. Mubarak said, but he had not spoken out. "I kept silent," he said. "I closed my mouth. I didn't want to create problems for them or turn public opinion against them."
The President also disclosed that two weeks ago he had secured the return of 34 Egyptian pilots in Iraq after repeated and vociferous diplomatic protests. The Egyptians, who had been teaching and training Iraqi pilots, had been under house arrest since Aug. 2. All Egyptian military advisers have now left Iraq, the President said.
Mr. Mubarak said that military assistance to Iraq dated to President Sadat's time in office. During the Iran-Iraq war, he said, Egypt supplied "lots of assistance" to Iraq -- ammunition, guns, military hardware and defensive weapons. Given this extensive cooperation, the President said, he doubted that Mr. Hussein possessed, as he has maintained, medium- and long-range missiles capable of delivering chemical weapons.
"Those who have such weapons don't boast about them," he said.
While he refused to discuss Iraq's military potential in any detail, he expressed confidence in the coalition's ability to win any military confrontation with Iraq. "We know them," he said. "I am not afraid of them."
Asked whether, in the event of war, Egyptian forces would fight with the Americans, Mr. Mubarak replied: "We will fight with the Saudis. Our forces are coordinated with the Saudis."
 
 Help for the Saudis: Troops and Tanks
 Mr. Mubarak said that he had already sent to Saudi Arabia a division -- about 15,000 army troops -- and a battalion of Thunderball forces, roughly 400 special troops. He said he would send another tank division -- about 400 tanks and 7,000 men -- by the end of the month to bolster Egypt's presence in the kingdom.
An official close to the President also disclosed that soon after the invasion, Mr. Mubarak quietly sent 2,200 Thunderball troops to Saudi Arabia at King Fahd's request. Mr. Mubarak warned the Saudi King on Friday, Aug. 3, that two Iraqi brigades were heading for his border. The King then called President Bush, who confirmed the information on Iraqi troop movements.
"King Fahd immediately requested troops from both the U.S. and from Egypt, and both complied immediately without making any announcement," the official said.
Mr. Mubarak also dismissed reports of tension within the coalition against Iraq. Syria, he said, was now transporting more troops to the Saudi desert, and would not abandon the coalition despite its criticism of increased American arms shipments to Israel. "I know him very well," Mr. Mubarak said of the Syrian President, Hafez al-Assad. "He will stick with us."
Asked whether the nations allied against President Hussein could hold together for two or three more months in the face of Iraqi pressure to split the coalition and neutralize its members, Mr. Mubarak replied that the coalition would hold.
 
 Jordanian's Account Is Called Inaccurate
 His normally husky voice boomed with indigation as he disputed recent statements by King Hussein of Jordan that President Mubarak had undermined his peace-making efforts. In interviews last month, the King said that by condemning Iraq's invasion after the King had secured a pledge from Saddam Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait in exchange for an Arab meeting, President Mubarak had destroyed prospects for an early, peaceful solution to the crisis.
The Egyptian President's account of events before and after the crisis differed markedly in several important respects from the Jordanian King's. Mr. Mubarak said that he had been concerned for several months about growing tension between Iraq and Kuwait. On July 24, he went to Baghdad to assess Iraq's intentions. He said that Saddam Hussein had assured him unequivocally that he would not invade Kuwait. "He told me: 'I frightened them. They are terrified. I'm not going to do anything more.' "
King Hussein suggested that President Mubarak may have misinterpreted President Hussein's assurances. The King quoted the Iraqi leader as having told Mr. Mubarak that he would not act against Kuwait as long as negotiations to resolve their differences continued.
Mr. Mubarak bristled at this suggestion. "There was no misunderstanding," he said. "Those who told that to you were not there. This was a tete-a-tete discussion. I never tell lies. Had he said I will do nothing as long as the two sides are meeting, I would have said, and what will you do afterward? I would not just have left things like that."
Based on Saddam Hussein's assurances, he said, he flew to Kuwait to inform Kuwaiti officials of his discussions, despite President Hussein's request that his peaceful intentions not be passed on to them. He told Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, the Emir, and the Crown Prince, that "they had to do something for him," meaning for Saddam Hussein. Mr. Mubarak said he urged the Kuwaitis to "solve the problem over their borders and be ready to give him some money." The Kuwaitis, he said, did not reply, but he felt confident that they would try to settle things peacefully, he said.
Because of President Hussein's assurances, he said, "I was shocked, astonished when my aides called me at 5 in the morning to say Iraq had invaded Kuwait. "I was very offended, very upset."
 
 The 'Arab Brother' Would Be Upset
 On the day of the invasion, King Hussein flew to Alexandria, Egypt, where the two leaders met. "I told him that we had to find a face-saver for him," Mr. Mubarak said of Saddam Hussein. The King argued that their "Arab brother" in Baghdad would be "very upset" if Egypt or the Arab League foreign ministers who were meeting in Cairo condemned the invasion without giving him a chance to explain his case.
Mr. Mubarak said that "with great difficulty, I persuaded King Fahd and the others to postpone an Arab League vote for at least a day." He than proposed that King Hussein go to Baghdad and tell Saddam Hussein that he would call for a limited Arab summit meeting to resolve issues of contention between Kuwait and Iraq, if President Hussein would "whisper in our ears" that he was willing to withdraw his forces and restore the ruling family in Kuwait.
"King Hussein was hesitant," Mr. Mubarak recounted. "I phoned Saddam Hussein in front of him and told him of my proposal, and that King Hussein would visit him that night or tomorrow to explain further."
King Hussein's version of events is that on Friday, Aug. 3, he flew to Baghdad and secured a commitment from President Hussein to withdraw from most of Kuwait and to discuss other grievances at an Arab meeting on Sunday, provided the Arab League and its more influential members did not condemn his invasion or call for foreign intervention.
Mr. Mubarak's recollection differs. He said that King Hussein called him at 3:45 P.M. on Friday to say that President Hussein had agreed to the limited Arab summit and that he wanted it to be held on Sunday.
"I asked him: what about the two points?" Mr. Mubarak said, referring to the commitment to withdraw and restore the legitimate Government of Kuwait. He said the King told him: "I didn't discuss the details with him," referring to Saddam Hussein.
These two points were hardly details, he had replied. "How could I call for a summit," Mr. Mubarak continued, "under these circumstances?"
 
At Home, Pressures Of Public Opinion
 Egyptians, he said, were clamoring for a declaration condemning the invasion. "Everyone wanted to know what Egypt's position was. So I condemned it." Later that night, the Arab League foreign ministers took similar action.
Replying to King Hussein's assertion that on Sunday, Aug. 5, Iraq began withdrawing its forces, Mr. Mubarak declared: "There was no withdrawal. They were taking military and other equipment back to Baghdad."
On Monday, Aug. 6, Mr. Mubarak said that he summoned the Iraqi Ambassador to Alexandria to tell him to warn Saddam Hussein that his situation was precarious, that the whole world would be against him. "I said please tell that man I'm willing to do anything to save his face if he will withdraw."
At 2 A.M. on Aug. 7, the Ambassador flew to Baghdad to deliver the message. He returned later that morning with an Iraqi Vice President. "I told them again: We're trying to find a way out for you. If it would help, I would make an appeal in the name of Islam, whatever I could do to help.
"But he said that I had cut their throats," he said, quoting the Iraqi vice president. "I said how? He said by condemning the invasion. I told him it had been a matter of principle. Even if our brothers did that, Egypt would have to stand against that. People here felt it deeply; I couldn't risk our credibility by endorsing your invasion."
Mr. Mubarak said that no matter what he said, the Iraqi replied: "No, this is our land. Historically, it's ours. No. No. No. It's our land."
The Egyptian President said that despite the loss of $9 billion to $10 billion in revenue as a result of the gulf crisis, Egypt would not change its stance because the sovereignty of nations and nonintervention in the affairs of other nations were principles that had to be observed in the "new world order" evolving after the end of the cold war.
"I did what I had to do," he said.
