HEADLINE: Architect Picked for Newark Concert Hall

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, Nov. 7

 BODY:
In appointing an architect today to design the first major new East Coast performance hall in three decades, the New Jersey Performing Arts Center took a firm step toward creating a $70 million multi-use concert hall in downtown Newark.
It would be the first building of a Lincoln Center-like complex near Newark's central business district. However, it is intended to be less an isolated cultural enclave than many other urban performance centers, and more a fully integrated element of the cityscape. 
 "I hope this room will serve as the soul of the city, and as a catalyst for its continuing renaissance," said Barton Myers, a 56-year-old Los Angeles architect who was chosen to create the 2,700-seat hall.
The hall, to be completed in 1996, would be a home for music, dance and theater. It would also house the New Jersey Symphony and would include rehearsal spaces, restaurants and cafes. More important, said Newark's Mayor, Sharpe James, it would also be "a keystone for Newark's renewal over the next three decades."
The plan envisions the arts as a magnet to attract suburbanites to an urban core that has suffered severe erosion of its economic base, hoping that cultural offerings can succeed where traditional development has not.
 "For too long," Mayor James said yesterday, " the people of New Jersey have had to travel to New York or Philadelphia to participate in world-class cultural events."
 
Public and Private Money
 In the first stage of development, in addition to the $70 million for the performance hall, another $70 million will be required for site work, including the construction of a plaza and the refurbishment of a 1,100-space parking garage in Military Park. "We are aware that an evening at the arts center starts and ends in an automobile," said Mr. Goldman, "and this will be the best parking garage on the East Coast."
Only part of the money is in hand. Newark's business community has pledged $33 million toward the arts center's construction, and Gov. Jim Florio has pledged $20 million in low-interest bonds to buy the 12 acres of land and do site reconstruction.
The Federal Government has also committed $1.2 million to planning, design and construction of the outdoor spaces, said Lawrence P. Goldman, the president of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center. The remainder of the money will come from fund-raising efforts across the state, Mr. Goldman said.
 This year, the consulting firm of Hamilton, Rabinovitz & Altschuler, which estimated the economic impact of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan, predicted that the performing arts center might generate $1 billion in new economic development for New Jersey.
The arts complex, as originally proposed by Gov. Thomas H. Kean in 1987, would ultimately include the concert hall, a 3,000-seat opera house, a 1,800-seat music theater, a 600- to-750-seat dance and drama theater, and a 200-seat children's theater. The center is to be set in a new park sloping down to the Passaic River, with an open plaza larger than that at Rockefeller Center or Lincoln Center.
 
Hotel to Be Demolished
 The old Military Hotel in Newark is to be razed to provide part of the space for the concert hall, which would occupy two acres on Park Place and Saybrook Place across from Military Park. The 12-acre site for the entire arts complex includes the knoll upon which Newark's Puritan founders first set foot in 1666.
More than 4.5 million people live within 25 miles of the site, the study said, and predicted that 650,000 people would be drawn annually to arts events in downtown Newark by 2003 if the construction stayed on schedule.
Mr. Myers, a professor of architecture at the University of California at Los Angeles, was selected over three other finalists for the job: the architects Michael Graves of Princeton, N.J., Benjamin Thompson of Cambridge, Mass., and Cesar Pelli of New Haven.
Mr. Myers's firm was the principal designer of two new theaters at the Portland Center for the Performing Arts in Oregon, which includes a 2,700-seat concert hall, a 950-seat lyric theater and a 400-seat courtyard theater. Mr. Myers's firm also designed the $40 million Cerritos Community Arts Center in Southern California, a 1,800-seat multi-purpose hall scheduled for completion in 1991.
 
Works in Foreign Countries
 In addition, his firm has won the contract to design the $40 million United States Pavilion at Expo '92 in Seville, Spain. Mr. Myers is also the designer of the Citadel Theater in downtown Edmonton, Alberta, and he designed major additions to the Stratford Festival Theater, the national home of the Shakespeare Festival in Canada.
"Of course, no one building can turn a city around," said Mr. Myers, "but if done well, so it fits in with the community, it can make an important contribution to change."
The selection committee "did not want the center to turn its back, architecturally, to the city of Newark," said Mr. Goldman. "Though Kennedy Center is a wonderful place," he said of the arts complex in Washington, "it stands as an island that has nothing to do with the city around it."
At first, the selection committee "had in mind a hall like the Sydney Opera House, that would be instantly recognizable as a symbol of the city and of Australia as well," said Mr. Goldman. "However, Barton convinced us that an equally important goal was an arts center that would be welcoming and people friendly, and that would fit in comfortably and naturally with the fabric of the city."
 
'A Focus for the City'
 Mr. Myers said that it would take 20 to 24 months to design the hall, and that he would spend part of that time getting to know the city and New Jersey's arts groups. He said he would like the hall to be "a great room for the performing arts, a focus for the city." He added that in the other performance halls he has designed, "the lobbies are stages and the performers are the audiences themselves."
The multi-use hall, Mayor James said, will be the bridge between many of the cultural and business landmarks that are part of Newark's downtown revival.
They include the Newark Museum on Washington Street, with its recent $21 million reconstruction by Mr. Graves; the Gateway Center office complex where WNET, Channel 13, is, Symphony Hall and the bustling spaces of Newark's Pennsylvania Station, the railway hub for commuter and Amtrak trains to and from the rest of New Jersey and New York City.
 
Proximity to the Station
 The station, adjacent to Newark's Ironbound district with its Portuguese shops and restaurants, would be a 10-minute walk from the arts center.
The master plan for the entire Performing Arts Center, being designed by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill and James Stewart Polshek & Partners, is to be completed before the end of the year. More than $220 million would be required for the beginning phases of construction.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Barton Myers, who was appointed yesterday to design a $70 million concert hall for the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
Big East, Bigger Business

BYLINE: William C. Rhoden

 BODY:
The Big East Conference held its annual media day in New York City yesterday: same format, different players, same coaching alibis. But this year, one major player was not on hand. Dave Gavitt, the founder and commissioner of the Big East, resigned earlier this year to become the general manager of the Boston Celtics.
Gavitt's presence in the Big East was as imposing as that of Walter Byers in the National Collegiate Athletic Association. He organized and nurtured the concept of getting nine loosely organized institutions in the Northeast corridor to form a basketball conference in an instant talent cartel. 
 The conference has become a multimillion-dollar success and has come to epitomize the very essence of big-time basketball.
So Gavitt is gone and yesterday Mike Tranghese, a clever, cordial man who had been Gavitt's left and right hand, presided over his first media day as the Big East commissioner.
Tranghese has had a fierce baptism. One of the first challenges he faced was the threatened disintegration of the conference. With the recent scramble by college football powers to align themselves with better conferences to attract better television packages, some of the major independents joined leagues. Boston College, Syracuse and Pittsburgh, members of the Big East who who competed as independents in football, made noise about forming new affiliations.
Suddenly, the Big East, which seemed so invincible five seasons ago when three of its nine teams reached the Final Four, was in danger of being raided or deserted, unless the new commissoner made a bold move.
Tranghese resisted expansion at first. But when it became clear that the three football schools were unhappy with the Big East's focus on basketball -- and planned to do something about it -- the commissioner reached out and plucked the University of Miami. Effectively, that kept B.C., Pitt and Syracuse in the conference.
Yesterday, though, Tranghese conceded that the move troubled him and continues to trouble him because it violated the geographic integrity that had been a cornerstone of the Big East.
"The one hangup I had as we talked with Miami was this geographic incompatibility. But when I looked at it, I said if I don't take Miami and I lose Syracuse and Pitt, where am I going to get replacements?"
As schools and conferences make moves based primarily on economics, players are beginning to look more closely at sums of money passing over, around, behind and underneath them.
Nearly every coach at a major Division I program has a shoe and or clothing contract in which he is paid in exchange for the team's wearing a certain brand of shoes or in some cases uniforms.
Oliver Taylor, a junior guard for Seton Hall, said most players hardly question the practice. "All the players know is that these are a pair of sneakers that the team is wearing," he said. "They don't understand that these are shoes that you have to wear, regardless of whether they fit or not, because the coach has a contract with the shoe company."
Taylor recalled that last season some of the players didn't like the uniforms that the Pirates wore in a nationally televised game. Even though he said "it was like a commercial for Nike," Taylor assumed that since there was a contract between the coach and the company, they would simply go along.
"A lot of times, you're just thankful that you got a scholarship and you're saving your parents $18,000 a year," he said. "But I feel we should get more financial aid or benefits."
Many people are troubled by college athletes' asking for more. But at a time when athletic departments and coaches are making grandstand plays for revenue, athletes are developing a savvy business awareness at best, a pronounced mercenary attitude at worst.
What concerns Tranghese about the Big East's curious geographic meandering is a perception by the public that the conference is no longer what it purports to be. He complained throughout the interviews that reporters were so interested in disucssing the league's expansion that he hadn't even got around to discussing basketball.
"That's what I want to talk about, but it's naive," he said. "This is a big business, and that's why I'm being paid what I'm paid. But it's bothersome and it's a concern because people get turned off to it being viewed as just a business."
In fact, big-time college sports is precariously close to being viewed as a business by the Internal Revenue Service, which is already looking at the tax-exempt status of various college football bowl organizations. Soon, the I.R.S. will examine the relationship between the athlete and the university. If it is, in fact, a business, who is the employee who is the employer? And is the scholarship effectively a contract?
What's even more interesting is that the questions are not only being asked by outsiders, but increasingly by the troops.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
The Bush Victory

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The only time Richard Nixon quoted Walter Lippmann, not his favorite pundit, was the day after the midterm elections of 1970 in which the Republicans lost nine House seats.
"Walter Lippmann said that according to the rules of the political game as it has been played in this country for the past 50 years," said the President, reading from some gems of research I had handed him, 
 "When the party in power loses little if anything in an off-year election, it has to be called a victory."
History has repeated itself; the party in power in the White House has just lost nine House seats in the midterm election, not the usual 36. Therefore, according to the Lippmann Rule, President Bush has the right to call the 1990 results a victory.
But just let him try it. The mindset that drives most interpretations of the results envisions a wounded politician in the White House, coattails in tatters and inflated ratings plummeting, his plums ripening for plucking in 1992. Having taken credit for the rain, Mr. Bush is now getting blamed for the drought.
Clear your mindset. For a man about to be the first to occupy the White House during a wartime recession, George Bush is in pretty good shape.
In his defining domestic moment, he stripped his party of its philosophy by caving in on his tax pledge -- but disaster did not befall Republicans.
In pressing the advantage handed them by Desperation Darman, Democratic liberals reverted to the soak-the-rich pitch of their glory days -- but their retreaded fairness issue led to no day of glory.
In retrospect, Mr. Bush might wish he had stuck to his guns and fought this election on a taxing-vs.-spending theme; most returns show voter displeasure aimed more at increased taxes than unincreased services. But let's keep our sextant fixed on Lipp-mann's guiding star: massive erosion averted is midterm victory.
Another, crueler adage buttresses this wisdom, which I hope some pundit a generation hence will refer to as the Safire Rule of Relative Positioning: No politician is safely a success until all his potential opponents are failures. Consider the state of the '92 opposition in light of the '90 results.
With his campaign coffers overflowing, Mario Cuomo, who in his previous campaign won over 65 percent of the votes for Governor of New York, this time eked out a bare majority over a couple of relatively impoverished opponents; the much-derided Republican, Pierre Rinfret, stunned his scoffers by receiving twice as many votes as the pollsters predicted. The dismal Cuomo showing has forced the Governor's national boosters to eat humble pie with melancholy danish.
Equally heavily financed Bill Bradley, his aim fixed on the Presidential nomination, took his eye off the tax-cutting ball and dribbled away a big lead in New Jersey against an unknown. His disenthralled supporters say wryly he can no longer depend on a charismatic oratorical style alone.
Senator Al Gore won handily in Tennessee. But the issue he is counting on to catapult him to the nomination is global warming -- and environmentalists lost their "Big Green" push in California by 2 to 1, which greens everywhere consider a polit-ecological disaster. (However, if it's 90 in the shade in New York on New Year's Day -- keep your eye on Gore.)
Those eager to proclaim the President damaged in this election should turn to a Lincoln adage: You cannot beat somebody with nobody. This election may have diminished the Somebody, but it has surely slammed around the Nobodies.
Perhaps you are unsatisfied with the notion that not losing badly is really winning. Surely you cannot prefer drawing such lessons as "nobody won" or "everybody lost." Does the campaign result have any meaning?
Yes. Remember how the reformist goo-goos were bewailing the way incumbents could use perks and PAC's to keep themselves entrenched? They were right. And remember how all the pollsters and analysts were telling us how fed up the voters were with the budget messiness? They were right, too.
The inertial power of incumbency is still the Immovable Object. Resentment of deadlocking and secretive and promise-breaking politicians is the Irresistible Force. In the campaign of 1990, they met. Result: The little loss by the party in power has to be called a victory.

HEADLINE: Two Missing Landslides

 BODY:
Two of the Democratic Party's most promising candidates stumbled Tuesday on the road to the 1992 convention. In view of their overwhelming victories the last time each ran, landslides seemed certain for both Mario Cuomo and Bill Bradley. Both won; but, as Mr. Bradley might say about a sloppy basketball game, they "won ugly" -- and certainly not by landslides.
Running for a third term against Nobody and Another Nobody, Governor Cuomo collected only 53 percent of the vote, a stunning drop from 65 percent in 1986. Mr. Bradley, who won 64 percent of the vote in 1984, was returned to the Senate by a majority that was at most 51 percent. 
 Why? Surely one common thread was that neither conducted much of a campaign. Instead of grappling with real issues, they offered hollow virtues. Mr. Bradley's ads said more about Mikhail Gorbachev's economic problems than New Jersey's. Mr. Cuomo debated his adversaries on a Sunday afternoon, opposite a football telecast, and spent much of his time mocking them.
Mr. Cuomo's non-landslide has shaken his aura of invincibility and surprised New York's Republicans, who gave up before they started by nominating the embarrassingly unprepared Pierre Rinfret. Mr. Cuomo spent $4 million -- three times the combined expenditures of Mr. Rinfret and the Conservative candidate, Herbert London. Yet he failed to persuade New Yorkers to vote for the environmental bond issue he called his own, wrest the State Senate from Republicans and elect a Democratic Comptroller, Carol Bellamy.
One reason for the limp Democratic results is probably a poor turnout of, notably, Democratic voters. Only 34 percent of this year's vote came from overwhelmingly Democratic New York City. In 1986, the figure was 45 percent.
Mr. Cuomo himself offers voter discontent as the main reason, and there may be some truth to that. Even so, he's not likely to get far in a Presidential bid if his state fails to rebound. No fair-minded New Yorker would blame him for the state's economic plight. But only he has the authority to make the difficult decisions that are necessary but that he likes to avoid.
The same advice applies to Mr. Bradley, who suffered from the perception that he avoided tough issues. Voter fury about taxes surely accounted for much of the tide that nearly swamped the Senator. Voters seemed determined to punish someone for the record $2 billion tax increase the new Democratic Governor, Jim Florio, pushed into law in January.
Mr. Bradley amassed a $12 million campaign kitty, one of the largest in the nation. Yet with far smaller resources, the Republican candidate, Christine Todd Whitman, ran a brave and aggressive campaign and very nearly won.
The figures in both races are good news for President Bush; two of his most promising potential opponents are thus tarnished. But it would be glib to dismiss the 1992 chances of either the Governor or the Senator. The big question for the Democrats remains: Who would be more promising? Meanwhile, the voters made clear that both men have work to do.

HEADLINE: Syracuse Starts Long Road Back From Environmental Blight

 BODY:
To the Editor:
From Syracuse, you report (Oct. 17): "Just moments from the heart of downtown oozes Oil City, an industrial wasteland of oil tanks, junkyards, toxic dumps and corroded buildings hugging the shore of Onondaga Lake, itself a hazardous waste site."
And: "Now despite haunting environmental and economic hurdles, city officials and developers -- in particular, the Pyramid Companies, the mall-development giant based here -- have joined to remake the 800-acre eyesore into what they hope will be the city's salvation."
I would like to put to rest concerns your article raises about New York State's evaluation of actions on environmental problems and health issues at the new Carousel Center mall in Syracuse.
In addition to serving as a symbolic and substantive turning point in the reclamation and revitalization of the area, Pyramid's cleanup and construction in development of the mall -- with stringent regulatory oversight -- have had important environmental and public health benefits.
The actions Pyramid has taken to remove and remediate contaminants, and establish the physical structures of the mall, have rendered the site appropriate for its purpose.
The work is achieving the objectives of a standard cleanup action -- removal of the source of contamination and long-term isolation of low-level residuals. Over the last two years, more than 200 samples have been taken at the site. Only a handful showed isolated pockets of contaminants at levels of concern, and these have been removed and disposed of appropriately.
Although Pyramid still has to complete treatment of soils off the mall property, implement a landscaping plan and carry on long-term operation of ground-water treatment facilities, the company has indicated its commitment to these actions.
While the Department of Environmental Conservation's relationship with Pyramid has at times been contentious, our oversight role, together with those of other government agencies, insures that the mall will provide a safe environment for public use. With completion of this first step in reclamation of Oil City, we can see opportunity to bring back other properties in the area and even a restored Onondaga Lake.
 
THOMAS C. JORLING
Commissioner
Environmental Conservation
Albany, Oct. 20, 1990

HEADLINE: THE 1990 ELECTIONS: Ballot Proposals;
Voters Spurn Array of Plans For Protecting Environment

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

 BODY:
Environmentalists said yesterday that they had suffered major setbacks as voters in California and several other states rejected ballot proposals to protect air, land and water against pollution and the effects of commercial development.
Voters also spurned ballot proposals calling for tax cuts or limits on government spending in Massachusetts, Nebraska, Utah and Colorado. 
 But Colorado voters overwhelmingly approved a ballot measure to limit the number of terms of elected officials, including members of Congress, and California voters also approved a proposal to limit the number of terms of elected state officials. That vote was 52 percent to 48 percent.
In general, it was not a good year for ballot measures.
 
'Voters Are Uneasy'
 D. Reid Wilson, political director of the Sierra Club, said voters rejected nearly all environmental proposals on the ballot, including the "Big Green" initiative in California, sometimes described as the most ambitious environmental measure ever offered in the United States. A separate proposal to preserve forests in California, a stream-protection referendum in Missouri, a land use planning measure in Washington State, a recycling proposal in Oregon and an environmental bond issueof nearly $2 billion in New York also went down to defeat.
"Voters are uneasy about the unsettled state of the economy, about whether we will be at war or peace in the Persian Gulf," said Mr. Wilson, whose environmental group has 620,000 members, "and they are unwilling to reach out and embrace new programs, especially if they think there might be some economic consequence to it."
"Big Green," the nation's most closely watched ballot proposition, was "so comprehensive and far-reaching that it ended up uniting all the polluters," Mr. Wilson said. "Industry opponents of Big Green outspent supporters by a margin of more than 2 to 1," he said.
Jim Maddy, executive director of the League of Conservation Voters, a political action committee for the environmental movement, said some of the environmental proposals this year had invited attack because they were "unbelievably long and complicated, with pages and pages of fine print."
Kirk West, president of the California State Chamber of Commerce, said opponents of "Big Green" had "convinced the voters that it tried to do too much, covered too many subjects."
In New York, the vote rejecting the environmental bond issue left municipal officials around the state with the problem of finding money to pay for state-mandated landfill and recycling programs. Communities like New York City faced the prospect of having to increase property taxes and fees.
Here is a summary of results for other major proposals on the ballot on Tuesday:
 
Taxing and Spending
 Massachusetts voters rejected a major tax-cutting proposal, which would have required substantial cutbacks in social welfare services to residents of the state, which has been hard hit by layoffs and economic troubles. The proposal, sponsored by Citizens for Limited Taxation, would have nullified recent tax increases, cut the state income-tax rate and reduced fees charged by state agencies, forcing the state to slash more than $2 billion from its $13.4 billion budget next year.
Margaret Keiley, a psychotherapist interviewed outside her polling place in the South End of Boston on Tuesday, said that the state and the nation needed to revise their economic priorities, but that the tax-cutting measure was "just a mindless way" to do it.
Homeless people said they opposed the Massachusetts tax proposal because it almost surely would have forced the state to cut back social welfare benefits and shelters for the homeless.
John P. Keast, a policy analyst at the conservative Free Congress Foundation, who tabulated results of the statewide ballot measures, said: "People are looking at their pocketbooks more and more. Citizens are unsure of the impact of some of these tax initiatives. The average voter wants to be sure there are guaranteed government services if the economy gets any worse."
Oregon bucked the national trend and approved a measure imposing limits on property taxes. State officials predicted it would lead to substantial reductions in such taxes over the next five years.
But in other states, voters turned down ballot measures to cut taxes and spending. California, which started the nationwide tax revolt 12 years ago, rejected a proposal that would have made it much more difficult for state and local officials to raise taxes. Colorado defeated a proposal that would have required explicit approval from the voters for any state or local tax increase. Nebraska rejected a proposed amendment to the state constitution that would have limited increases in state and local government spending to 2 percent a year.
 
Abortion
 Abortion rights advocates fared well, defeating two Oregon ballot proposals to restrict access to abortion while prevailing in their effort to codify the right to abortion in Nevada.
Kate Michelman, executive director of the National Abortion Rights Action League, described the results as "important victories for the pro-choice community nationwide."
One Oregon proposal would have banned abortion, except where a pregnancy resulted from rape or incest or endangered the life of the woman. The other would have required doctors to notify a parent at least two days before performing an abortion on a minor.
The proposal in Nevada was put on the ballot by supporters of the right to abortion. Approval of that measure protects the current law, which permits a woman to have an abortion within 24 weeks after the start of a pregnancy. The referendum on Tuesday assures that Nevada cannot further restrict the right to abortion "except by a direct vote of the people."
 
Term Limits
 Oklahoma became the first state to limit the tenure of elected officials when it voted in September to set a 12-year limit on service in the State Legislature.
On Tuesday, Colorado voters decided to set limits of eight years' service for elected state officials, including state legislators. The measure also limits members of Congress from Colorado to terms of 12 consecutive years.
The measure won easily, by 71 percent to 29 percent. But Steven R. Ross, counsel to the Clerk of the United States House of Representatives, said that some of the restrictions were unenforceable because states could not legally go beyond the Federal Constitution in setting qualifications for service in Congress.
Terry Considine, a Colorado State Senator who led the campaign to limit terms, said: "All the people want this kind of change. They know the government isn't working the way it should." Term limits tell legislators they are under a deadline to get things done, he said.
Elsewhere on Tuesday, Californians approved stringent term limits for state officials: six years for members of the State Assembly and eight years for state senators, the governor and other elected state officials. President Bush supported the proposal.
Residents of Kansas City, Mo., limited City Council members and the Mayor to two consecutive four-year terms.
David B. Magleby, a professor of political science at Brigham Young University in Provo, Utah, who has studied ballot measures for a decade, said it was paradoxical that voters had supported such term limitation proposals, but "generally did not use the option they already have to limit terms directly by defeating incumbents."
 
Education
 Oregon voters rejected a proposal to provide a personal income-tax credit up to $1,200 a year for the costs of educating a child at home or in private secular or religious schools. Public school officials in Oregon and other states expressed relief that the proposal had been defeated, by a ratio of more than 2 to 1. They said it could have set a dangerous precedent for indirect public aid to private schools.
Even though the measure was defeated, its presence on the ballot put state education officials on notice that voters wanted better results from the public schools in return for increased spending.
Nebraska voted narrowly to retain a new school financing plan that seeks to reduce disparities in spending by rich and poor school districts. The plan, adopted in April, reduces reliance on property taxes, but will increase state income and sales taxes.
 
Other Measures
 In Florida, voters approved an amendment to the state constitution requiring buyers of pistols to wait three days before getting their weapons. Lawrence Pratt, executive director of Gun Owners of America, which opposed the requirement, said he doubted that it would reduce the crime rate.
Alaskans voted to re-establish criminal penalties for the possession or use of small amounts of marijuana.
Arizonans rejected a proposal to establish a state holiday marking the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. As a result, they may have lost an opportunity to bring the Super Bowl to their state in 1993. Paul J. Tagliabue, Commissioner of the National Football League, recommended today that the game be played elsewhere.
In the District of Columbia, voters rejected a proposal to give homeless people a legal right to overnight shelter. Opponents said the measure would have made "shelter on demand" an absolute right, draining city funds from other social service programs.
Residents of South Dakota turned down a proposal to limit gold and silver mining in the Black Hills. Arizonans and Minnesotans approved plans to dedicate part of state lottery proceeds to preserving the environment.
Seattle voters retained spousal benefits for unmarried companions of municipal employees. San Franciscans passed a less sweeping measure that allows homosexual couples to register their relationships with the city government, without obtaining the legal benefits of marriage.

HEADLINE: THE 1990 ELECTIONS: North Carolina;
Helms Kindled Anger in Campaign, And May Have Set Tone for Others

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RALEIGH, Nov. 7

 BODY:
It began as a clash of visions and personalities that seemed startling and new, but when it ended Tuesday, the bitter North Carolina Senate race between the Republican incumbent, Jesse Helms, and the Democratic challenger, Harvey Gantt, gave off the inescapable air of deja vu.
The polls indicate that Mr. Helms turned around a close race with a blitz of negative advertising in the campaign's final days, as he did in the past, creating a groundswell of support from white voters. But just as in the past, particularly in his 1984 Senate race against James B. Hunt, then the Governor, the tactics used by Mr. Helms could be the start of a political trend.
 
Helms Is Widely Imitated
 "The national implication of this race is that the cultural and racial issues Helms raised, such as homosexuals teaching in the classroom and racial quotas, are powerful weapons for the Republican Party," said Mike Donilon, the poll taker for Mr. Gantt. "People have to understand that the questions Helms raised in this election were not revisits to old cultural and racial issues. Instead, they raised some of the toughest battleground issues that will be fought out over the next few years." 
 Mr. Helms, who on Tuesday won a fourth Senate term by a margin of 53 percent to 47 percent, has always occupied an unusual position in American politics. He is at once a politician whose staunch conservatism is well outside the national mainstream and an innovator whose abilities in areas like fund-raising and negative campaigning have been widely admired and imitated. His race against Mr. Gantt, who would have been the first black elected to the Senate from the South since Reconstruction, showed both aspects of his career.
Mr. Helms, the conservative three-term incumbent, was trailing in the polls when he unleashed a barrage of advertising last week linking Mr. Gantt to homosexual causes and saying he supported racial quotas that benefited minority members over whites.
Most powerful was a television ad featuring a white job applicant crumbling a rejection letter as an announcer said the job was given to a less-qualified black because of job quotas, which Mr. Gantt supports. Mr. Gantt denies supporting job quotas.
 
Ads Brought Heavy Turnout
 Experts say Mr. Helms's ads, which were also on radio and in the press, had the effect of both winning over undecided white voters and generating enough enthusiasm among whites to create an extraordinarly heavy turnout, 60 percent of registered voters, comparable to that of a Presidential election.
A poll of 2,194 North Carolina voters condued by Voter Research and Surveys found that of those who decided late in the race, 61 percent went for Mr. Helms. Of those who voted for Mr. Helms, 8 percent said they made their choice last week. Of those who voted for Mr. Gantt, 4 percent said they made their choice last week.
 
Gantt's Message Turned Around
 Analysts say that Mr. Helms's ads and campaign speeches both played on racial fears and turned around Mr. Gantt's message of a worrisome, weakening economy by saying the problems were the results of blacks taking jobs from whites.
"I think that whites do not believe blacks when they say they're in favor of equal opportunity," said Ted Arrington, a professor of political science at the University of North Carolina at Charlotte. "I think whites believe blacks are in favor of equal results and quotas if that helps them get results. That may e unfair, but it's there. It was an issue that allowed Helms to bring race into the election in a way that wasn't offensive to many voters."
Mr. Arrington and others noted that Mr. Gantt's underdog campaign faced numerous other problems as well. He had never run statewide, he had lost his last election as the Charlotte Mayor, and Charlotte is viewed as a liability for Democratic candidates statewide.
Other than race, his biggest problem may have been that Mr. Gantt ran as a liberal, embracing the label more openly as the race wound down. His stands included increased spending for social programs, opposition to the deth penalty and support of abortion rights.
 
A Poll Leader in October
 The Voter Research and Surveys poll showed that 15 percent of respondents called themselves liberals, 44 percent moderates and 38 percent conservatives.
Still, Mr. Gantt was leading in the polls by as much as 8 points late in October. It is clear the polls overstated support for a black, as has happened in other races.
To most observers, Mr. Helms's victory was almost a carbon copy of earlier races in which he polarized the electorate and turned the election into an emotional value-laden choice between his view of North Carolina values and alien values. His vote margin in his four races has varied from 52 percent to 54.5 percent.
 
'Gave Them Plenty to Dislike'
 "Helms know what people dislike, and he gave them plenty to dislike," said Merle Black a professor of politics and government at Emory University. He said he doubted that Mr. Helms's polarizing political approach had much electoral appeal but that his issues, particularly racial quotas, could have broad appeal in more mainstream campaigns.
For North Carolina, the most immediate concern is healing the wounds from a polarizing election. And there were worries, thought none in the Helms camp, about the state's image after a racially explicit race.
For the Democrats, a more long-range question is whether Mr. Helms, who begins every race with more than 40 percent of the electorate adamantly opposed to him, can ever be beaten.
"You have to wonder if anyone can beat the guy in this state," said Thad L. Beyle, a political science professor at the University of North Carolina. "I don't know who else is out there and who would want to try it."

HEADLINE: THE 1990 ELECTIONS: Massachusetts;
Weld Reaffirms Pledge To Shrink Government

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Nov. 7

 BODY:
William F. Weld, the first Republican to win the governor's office in Massachusetts in two decades, today savored his narrow victory over John R. Silber and said his first priority would be to repeal a state sales tax on services passed only last summer.
But analysts here said the election was not so much an affirmation of Mr. Weld as a rebuff of Dr. Silber and his abrasive, confrontational style. 
 In a poll of people who had just voted, conducted by the Roper Organization for WCVB-TV in Boston, 51 percent of those who voted for Mr. Weld on Tuesday said they were actually voting against Dr. Silber. And in a poll conducted by Voter Research and Surveys, of 1,999 voters leaving the polls, 30 percent of the Democrats said they had deserted Dr. Silber for Mr. Weld, including 33 percent of those who identified themselves as liberal Democrats.
In a state where registered Democrats outnumber Republicans by 4 to 1, those defections were crucial for Mr. Weld's close triumph.
 
Short List of Priorities
 In a news conference hours after claiming victory early this morning, the 45-year-old Governor-elect outlined a program for a slimmed-down state government, in contrast to the approach of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, the Democrat whom he will succeed. "I believe in keeping the priority list short," Mr. Weld said.
In his victory speech last night he sounded a similar theme, saying, "I don't believe government should be about the miracle business."
Mr. Weld, a former United States Attorney, defeated Dr. Silber, president of Boston University, 52 percent to 48 percent.
The turnout of 70 percent, or 2.27 million voters, was a record for a non-Presidential election, according to the Secretary of State's office, topping the previous high of 2.14 million, set in 1962.
The large turnout reflected the enormous anger among Massachusetts voters, who have blamed Governor Dukakis and the Democratic-controlled State Legislature for an economy that has stumbled into recession and a prolonged state budget mess.
 
Tax-Cutting Move Defeated
 But despite this wrath, a tax-cutting referendum was defeated, 60 percent to 40 percent. The referendum would have forced the new governor to cut the $13.4 billion state budget by $1.2 billion next year and a further $2.4 billion in 1992.
Mr. Weld had strongly supported the ballot measure, while Dr. Silber had opposed it, making it a major part of his campaign. So the rejection of the tax-slashing plan by voters who also cast their ballots for Mr. Weld was seen as a further rebuff of Dr. Silber.
Lou DiNatale, a fellow at the McCormack Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Massachusetts in Boston, said the turning point in the campaign came last week, after the final debate between Dr. Silber and Mr. Weld -- a contest that by all accounts Dr. Silber won easily. Until then, Dr. Silber had been building a lead in the polls, and his aggressive demeanor seemed to fit the public's anger.
But on Thursday, in an informal family setting, Dr. Silber snapped at a popular local television news commentator, Natalie Jacobson, when she asked him to discuss his strengths and weaknesses. "You find a weakness," he replied hotly.
"That showed what people had been saying about Silber's temperament was true," said Mr. DiNatale. To compound his problems, in the same interview Dr. Silber suggested that working women who put their children in child care might be guilty of child neglect.
"The liberals stampeded," Mr. DiNatale said.
Asked today about the incident, Dr. Silber acknowledged that it was costly. But in a news conference he blamed Ms. Jacobson, saying, "She entered my house under false pretenses."
Dr. Silber also asserted that she had distorted the interview in the editing process; he made similar charges about the media throughout the campaign.
In his own news conference today, Governor Dukakis accused Dr. Silber of "blowing the election," saying he had the election all but locked up until his temper ran away with him.
"I'm tempted to say the incompetence of the past week was appalling," the Governor said, deliberately mimicking words that Dr. Silber often applied to him.
For Mr. Weld, the narrowness of his victory and the defeat of the tax-cutting petition he supported will only make his new job harder. Although he said today that he hoped to have a program of tax cuts ready by January, when he assumes office, it is unclear how far he will press to carry out plans he put forward in the campaign to shrink the state government.

HEADLINE: THE 1990 ELECTIONS
Four Issues and How They Played at the Polls Before Uncertain Voters;
Taxes: Voters Send Mixed Message

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY

 BODY:
The message voters sent politicians on taxes and the economy was a muddled one, reflecting discontent with the way economic policy is being run but offering no clear signal on how they would like to see Federal or local budgetary problems solved.
In six states, Massachusetts, California, Montana, Nebraska, Colorado and Utah, voters rejected ballot measures that would have limited taxes or new spending. But voters also rejected measures that would have increased sales or excise taxes, even when such levies were dedicated to popular causes like fighting crime or drugs. 
 "Who knows what it means?" said a Democratic strategist in the Senate. "I think it's pretty hard to find the common thread here. Look at Massachusetts. You have voters rejecting a tax rollback and then turning around and electing for governor the candidate who supported it."
Incumbent governors who entered office pledging not to raise taxes and then switched course paid a high price. In Kansas, the challenger, Joan Finney, a Democrat, ousted Gov. Mike Hayden; in Nebraska, Gov. Kay Orr, a Republican, lost to the Democrat, Ben Nelson, and in Florida, Gov. Bob Martinez, a Republican, was defeated by Lawton Chiles, a Democrat.
 A Close Call for Bradley
In New Jersey, Senator Bill Bradley, a Democrat, found himself the target of voters' anger at Gov. Jim Florio, also a Democrat, over large state tax increases. Mr. Bradley only narrowly beat back a challenge from a Republican opponent who had not been regarded as a serious threat.
But even campaigning against tax increases was no guarantee of victory. In Congressional races, voters punished incumbents who had supported the deficit-cutting package approved by Congress last month, as well as those who vigorously opposed it.
Voters in Illinois said no to the gubernatorial bid of Neil Hartigan, a Democrat who promised to cut taxes, and elected James Edgar, a Republican who emphasized the need for more spending for better schools. In the race for Texas governor, Clayton Williams, a Republican who made no tax increases a centerpiece of his campaign, lost to the Democrat, Ann Richards.
"Tax fairness was a pattern," said Robert S. McIntyre, director of Citizens for Tax Justice, a Washington-based research group that receives financial backing from organized labor. Mr. McIntyre cited victories in Minnesota by Paul Wellstone, a liberal Democrat, over Senator Rudy Boschwitz, a Republican; in Vermont by Bernard Sanders, a socialist, over Representative Peter Smith, a Republican, and in Iowa, by the incumbent Senator Tom Harkin over his Republican challenger, Representative Tom Tauke.
"There weren't that many candidates who ran on the tax fairness issue," he said. "But those who did proved for this election and for 1992 that you can run on it and win."
Kevin Phillips, a political consultant who has chronicled the rise and fall of the conservative movement, described the issue as tax populism and said that being on the popular side of it clearly aided liberal Democrats like Senator Paul Simon of Illinois and Carl Levin of Michigan whose re-election bids had seemed shaky early in the year.
A clearer pattern of voter sentiment on the economy might have emerged if the election had been held a week earlier, when Congressional machinations over the Federal budget were still fresh in the public's mind, Mr. Phillips said.
"If you had had the election on Oct. 29, before the President was able to get the soapbox to himself and begin focusing attention on the Persian Gulf, I think you might have seen Republicans lose one or two more Senate seats, maybe six more House seats and another governor or two," he said.

HEADLINE: THE 1990 ELECTIONS: What Went Wrong?;
Bradley Says He Sensed Voter Fury But It Was Too Late to Do Anything

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Nov. 7

 BODY:
Senator Bill Bradley said today that a little over a week ago he had detected voters' anger over taxes, the economy and the failure of elected officials -- including possibly himself -- to address the issues, but that it was too late to do anything about it.
Still, the Senator said, he was surprised by the narrowness of his victory Tuesday over Christine Todd Whitman. 
 "I got the message," Mr. Bradley insisted today at a news conference at his campaign headquarters here. "I got the message!"
But he still refused to talk about Gov. Jim Florio's $2.8 billion in tax increases, which sparked the voter anger in New Jersey that grew rapidly into a dislike of politicians in general, even Bill Bradley. It was the Senator's refusal to take a position on the Florio tax package that especially rankled voters, experts said.
 
Wide Lead Dissipated
 Two weeks before the election, Mr. Bradley had held a wide lead in the polls. But in the end he was saved only by a big Democratic vote from Hudson County.
His final margin of victory was 55,180 votes out of 1.9 million cast.
Shortly after Mr. Bradley began detecting signs of voter discontent, his ads on television abruptly turned negative. They attacked Mrs. Whitman's own record on taxes, accusing her of favoring tax increases when she was a Somerset County Freeholder.
 
Negative Ads Defended
 The Senator defended that decision today. "You hit me with an elbow, I return the elbow," the former Knicks star said. "Get an elbow, give an elbow."
Mr. Bradley, in an interview and later in the news conference, said his campaign staff did its last tracking poll -- a sampling of voter sentiment to detect shifts and trends -- on Oct. 26. That showed him with 58 percent of the vote, compared with 65 percent in his 1984 re-election campaign.
"Basically we picked up some problems," he said, "but frankly we didn't pick up as much in the poll as I picked up on the street campaigning."
Even then, however, he did not realize that the general anger and frustration and fear was focusing in large measure on him, in part because of television commercials that voters were perceiving as insensitive, arrogant and insulting.
 
Low-Key Campaign Backfires
 He was well ahead in polls, and there seemed little reason to change the low-key campaign: Bill Bradley walking on the beach; Bill Bradley, the former Knicks star, shooting a perfect shot on the court; Bill Bradley sitting back in his office and throwing up his heels onto his desk, shod in basketball shoes.
While people still liked Bill Bradley, they felt a bit betrayed. In interviews today, voters said that against the backdrop of the Mideast, the Federal budget deadlock last month and the local tax problems, Mr. Bradley's soft commercials were an insult and an embarrassment.
Allan A. Segal, owner of The Art Gallery in Newark, said Mr. Bradley stirred some resentment by running a campaign that ignored pressing current issues.
"There is so much going on in the world -- locally, nationally and globally -- and there he was in his campaign commercials playing basketball," he said.
Mr. Segal, who voted for Mr. Bradley in the past, said he voted for Mrs. Whitman this time "as a reprimand for his attitude."
 
Easy Victory Expected
 And yet it also appeared that many people who voted against Mr. Bradley to "punish" him did so only because they believed he was assured of victory in any case.
Even though he voted against Mr. Bradley, Mr. Segal said, he "was glad he was elected -- I didn't want to see him defeated."
Michael Kaye, Mr. Bradley's media adviser for all of his campaigns since 1978 and a close friend of the Senator, seemed near tears at one point in a hallway talk with reporters at campaign headquarters.
"Clearly the ads didn't address the issue," he said. " I'm not stupid. I'm not going to say the television was on target.
"No one feels worse about last night than I do, sitting there listening to people talking about these irrelevant ads. Did I sense the Florio thing was a problem? Yes. Do I think we we're dealing with it? No. I think we weren't answering it worth a damn."
 
Late Swing in Attitude
 Large numbers of voters seemed to throw their support to Mrs. Whitman in the volatile last week of the campaign, rejecting Mr. Bradley as they became more familiar with the campaign, said Janice Ballou, director of the Center for Public Interest Polling at Rutgers University.
Her widely respected poll had found Mr. Bradley leading by 26 percentage points in its last survey a week before the election.
But among people who identified themselves as very interested in the campaign, she said, Mr. Bradley led Mrs. Whitman by only 2 percentage points, a hint of things to come that Ms. Ballou said she and others had never published.
Her poll also found that a large majority of voters believed that Governor Florio's tax increases were an issue in the Senate election. "I want to kick myself," she said.
Interviews with voters as they left the polls on Tuesday showed that Mr. Bradley had lost the support of Republicans and independents who had supported him in past races.
 
Some Problem Was Expected
 Mr. Kaye said he and other Bradley advisers were well aware that the Florio tax increase would be a problem for the Senator, even though he had nothing to do with it. But he refused to discuss it, and he would not allow Mr. Kaye to address it in television ads.
"You reach a point where you quit -- especially when you're a friend of his, as I am -- you just quit pestering him," Mr. Kaye said. "Enough already."
"I never said to him, 'If you don't take a postion on this Florio thing, you're a fool,' but everybody knew it was going to cost him," Mr. Kaye said. "But I don't think anybody knew how much it was going to cost him."
Mr. Bradley said at the news conference that he was increasingly aware thatthe Florio tax increase was a major issue transferring voters' anger to him. He also was aware that voters were angry about things in general.
 
Too Late to Change
 "It was like dealing with the many-headed Hydra," he said. "Strike that," he amended, emphasizing that he thought the concerns were entirely proper.
But he said he could not change the thrust of his campaign at the last minute. "We had a strategy, and we used it," he said. "You can't change in the last five days of the campaign."
Indeed, even now, with the election over, he declined to talk about the Florio taxes. "I wouldn't talk about it during the campaign, and I don't think it's appropriate to talk about it when it's over," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "I got the message," Senator Bill Bradley said yesterday, referring to his narrow margin of victory. (Eddie Hausner/The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%);

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Chairman of USF&G Sets Early Retirement

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
Jack Moseley, chairman, president and chief executive of the USF&G Corporation, said yesterday that he would take early retirement. At the same time, the insurance company slashed its dividend and announced plans to reduce costs through layoffs.
Mr. Moseley, 59 years old, was not available for comment yesterday, said a spokeswoman at the company's Baltimore headquarters. She added that his move was a personal decision and not related to the dividend reduction and the layoffs. 
 Mr. Moseley plans to stay on until a successor is appointed. The board said it had selected a successor, "an executive of national stature," and would announce the appointment within a few weeks.
USF&G said that it had for two decades maintained the dividend and employment levels through all phases of the insurance-industry cycle, but it added: "The extended duration of the present trough in the property and casualty market and the economic uncertainty resulting from a general business downturn required these extraordinary actions."
The company cut its dividend to 25 cents a share from 73 cents yesterday and adopted a program to cut costs by $75 million. It also reported a third quarter loss of $15 million, compared with a deficit of $17 million in the period last year. On Tuesday the company's share price fell 10 percent on anticipation of the dividend cut. It closed yesterday at 11 5/8 on the New York Stock Exchange, down 5/8.
Mr. Moseley's decision to retire ends a 37-year career that began in Birmingham, Ala., where he started with the company as a trainee after graduation from Auburn University.
Moving up in the actuarial end of the business, he became vice president and senior actuary in 1969 and by 1978 was named president and chief administrative officer. He took over his current titles in 1981.
The company said yesterday that its capital-preserving moves would help to maintain its marketing programs and the quality of its customer service while helping to position it for the next upturn in the underwriting cycle.

HEADLINE: Lemuel Ricketts Boulware, 95; Headed Labor Relations for G.E.

BYLINE: By JOAN COOK

 BODY:
Lemuel Ricketts Boulware, a former vice president of the General Electric Company who formulated a new approach to union management contract negotiations in the 1950's, died yesterday in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 95 years old.
He was under a doctor's care and died at his home, a spokesman for the company said. 
 Mr. Boulware was vice president of employee and public relations at General Electric from 1956 to 1961, when he retired. He had been responsible for employee relations since 1947, a year after the company went through what it considered a disastrous strike,
He helped develop practices in the company's relations with employees, unions, stockholders, community neighbors and government at all levels through a program intended to inform these groups that General Electric was trying "to do right voluntarily."
 
 A 'Fair, Firm Offer'
In a bargaining policy that came to be known as Boulwarism, the company listened closely to union demands, examined the wages and working conditions of competitors, conducted extensive research on all issues and then put forward a "fair, firm offer," with nothing held back for future concessions.
Although General Electric was unhappy with the term "Boulwarism," calling it a "hostile label," the basic bargaining policy that it embraced became the hallmark of the company's dealing with its organized employees in the 1950's and 1960's.
Labor's view of the policy was summed up by Paul Jennings, president of the International Union of Electrical Workers. At a convention of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. in Atlantic City in 1969, he called the policy "telling the workers what they are entitled to and then trying to shove it down their throats."
After a nationwide strike in 1969 and various court decisions that went against General Electric, the company modified its approach the next year and Boulwarism largely faded from the scene.
 
 Views on Labor Relations
 Later, in discussing labor relations, Mr. Boulware said labor problems should be "thought out, not fought out." He also said compulsory union membership was "wrong in principle and bad in practice." He opposed third-party intervention in labor negotiations.
Mr. Boulware was born in Springfield, Ky., and graduated from the University of Wisconsin in 1916, where he was captain of the baseball team. After graduation he taught accounting and commercial law at the university. He also taught at the Plymouth Institute night school in Brooklyn and at Florida Atlantic University.
He served in World War I as an infantry captain, and in World War II he was operations vice chairman of the War Production Board, for which he was awarded the Presidential Medal of Merit and a Navy citation.
Before Mr. Boulware joined General Electric, he worked for five companies in a number of positions like accountant, purchasing agent, comptroller and factory and marketing manager. In 1935 he joined the Carrier Corporation as vice president and general manager. From 1940 to 1942 he was vice president and general manager of the Celotex Corporation in Chicago.
 
 Business and Professional Ties
 He joined General Electric in 1945 to head its affiliated manufacturing companies. While at G.E. he was a director of numerous companies, chairman of the Marketing Executives Society, director of the American Management Association and a member of various committees of the United States Chamber of Commerce, the National Association of Manufacturers and the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.
He was the author of two books. The first, "The Truth About Boulwarism" (1969; Bureau of National Affairs), using General Electric as an example, dealt with measures that business executives and their companies could use to gain public confidence and with steps to help workers understand business economics.
The second book, "What You Can Do About Inflation, Unemployment, Productivity, Profit and Collective Bargaining" was published in 1972.
Mr. Boulware's wife, the former Norma Brannock, died in 1987. There are no immediate survivors.

HEADLINE: Taiwan Beckons Foreign Investors, but Its Stock Market Slips

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan

 BODY:
At one time, the stock market here seemed to have no top, soaring ever higher and trading more shares than either the New York or Tokyo markets. Foreigners longed for a chance to join in the gains.
Now, certain foreign investors will get a chance to play the Taiwan market, one of the largest in Asia. But they may no longer be as interested. The economy here has deteriorated and the stock market index has fallen 80 percent from its peak in February. Trading has been listless. 
 But with stock prices depressed, securities officials say now is an ideal time to raise the standards of the market and give it an international base by bringing in foreign institutional investors.
"We want to improve the structure of the market," said C. P. Chang, chairman of Taiwan's Securities and Exchange Commission. "We don't want to rely on foreigners to help support the market. We want them to help us change the market structure."
 
Opening Up the Market
 The Government's executive branch is about to review a proposal to allow foreign institutions like insurance and investment-management companies to invest an aggregate of $2.5 billion in securities markets here. Investing may be allowed by early next year.
Foreigners can now invest in the market only through funds listed on other exchanges, like the R.O.C. Taiwan Fund or the Taiwan Fund listed on the New York Stock Exchange.
Taiwan's stock market has always been viewed as something of a gambling den, and there is a standard joke that R.O.C. should stand not for the Republic of China but for the Republic of Casino.
The wild gyrations in the market did not keep housewives and taxi drivers from investing in stocks. In fact, investing became so profitable that some workers quit their jobs to devote full time to the market. When the market dipped after a transaction tax was placed on each trade three years ago, investors staged protests in the streets, demanding that the Government compensate them for their losses.
 
Up Sharply, Then a Plunge
 This year, investors have been sobered by a market in which the index climbed 4,000 points in three months, to a closing high of 12,424.53 on Feb. 12, and then dropped to around 5,000 in June. After the Middle East crisis, the index tumbled to a record low of 2,485.25 in trading on Oct. 12, before rising again. [It closed on Thursday at 3,554, down 135.87 for the day.]
Some people say the plunge may help the stock market in the long run by getting investors to start looking at fundamentals.
Taiwan has one of the world's most computerized stock exchanges. It was able, for example, to execute trades of 2.1 billion shares in three hours last June 1. By comparison, daily volume on the New York Stock Exchange is typically about 150 million to 200 million shares, traded in more than twice that time period.
To some extent, this computerization has contributed to the market's volatility, making it possible for the index to move far and fast. But securities officials say there were economic reasons for the climb and fall.
 
An Economic Boom
 "The fact that the market here rose to 12,000 wasn't just because we had too much gambling spirit," said Chao Hiao-feng, president of the Taiwan Stock Exchange Corporation. "Our economic situation was unusually good and our reserves high. Under these conditions, the stock market had to rise."
Officials argue that Taiwan's economic boom, its strong trade surplus and foreign reserves helped drive the market up. Because of limits on money leaving the country, much wealth has been poured into the stock market.
But dramatic changes in Taiwan have contributed to the market's volatility. The economy started deteriorating this year in part because of the slowdown in the United States, Taiwan's largest trading partner, and in part because the Government tightened the money supply. Now, officials forecast that gross national product will grow by only 5.15 percent this year, compared with 7.33 percent in 1989.
There is also an increasing sense that the country's leaders lack a firm grip on the direction of Taiwan and that growing divisions between rich and poor have driven up crime rates. Capital has also started flowing out, with more than $10 billion leaving in the first eight months of this year. As a result, the stock market has declined, the officials say.
 
'Market Really Runs Itself'
 "We have much less institutional control here, so the market really runs itself," said Tracy Cheng, senior vice president at the Taiwan Stock Exchange. "Everyone talks about perfect competition and perfect markets. In Japan and the United States, there's really much more control than in the Taiwan and Hong Kong markets. It's really a freer market here."
For the most part, foreign investors say they are eager to invest in Taiwan. "I've been here four years waiting for this market to open up," said John F. Engle, president of Hoare Govett Securities Taiwan Ltd. "Fund managers cannot just close their eyes to Taiwan and hope it disappears."
In July, the market value of shares traded on the Taiwan stock market totaled $48.08 billion, higher than in London and only slightly less than in Frankfurt, according to statistics at the exchange here. London moved slightly ahead of Taiwan in August.
 
Curbs Set Up
 Still, there will be restrictions on foreign investments. Investors will have to apply for a permit to take $5 million to $50 million into the country. After receiving approval, they will have to take the money into Taiwan within three months, presumably so that the quota could be given to another applicant if they did not comply.
After criticism by the foreign community over some of the limitations, the Securities Exchange Commission made modifications. But foreign companies will still have to leave their principal in Taiwan, in cash or securities, for three to six months before they can take it out of the country again, and profits can be remitted only once in a calendar year.
"For a country coming out of a highly regulated environment, they are trying to be as liberal as possible, but they don't want to make mistakes," said Chang Liang, president of the Shearson-Global Financial Services Company in Taiwan. "They shouldn't rush for the sake of liberalization and then get everything thrown back in their face."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Moves Up Sharply; French Statement Is Factor

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar staged a sharp advance on world currency markets yesterday amid indications that there was some international support for a stronger United States currency.
Gold prices rose, reversing a downward trend in Europe. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $387.30 an ounce, up $1 from Wednesday. At the Republic National Bank, the late bid was $387.15, up 45 cents. 
 The dollar got help from a disclosure by the French Economics Minister, Pierre Beregovoy, that he had written to Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady recently asking for support in seeking coordinated action to prop up the dollar.
 
Meeting Is Requested
 Mr. Beregovoy, who spoke at a news conference in Paris, said he wanted the so-called Group of Seven leading industrialized nations to meet and address the issue.
"I don't think that the United States has an interest in the sustained and accentuated decline of the dollar," he said. A stronger dollar may also take some pressure off interest rates in France and improve the competitiveness of French companies abroad.
The president of the German Bundesbank, Karl Otto Pohl, said that a meeting of the Group of Seven was not necessary. A United States Treasury spokesman said in a statement that no meeting was planned. These reports pushed the dollar temporarily lower in seesaw domestic trading.
"The market is very nervous and is looking for any kind of intervention by the central banks," said Bob Morrissey, a senior trader at the Bank of Boston's office in New York.
Concern that tensions are heightening in the Persian Gulf region also helped the dollar recover to its session highs, said John McCarthy, chief dealer at the Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank in New York. The dollar is considered a haven in times of turmoil.
The dollar's biggest advance came against the Japanese yen. In New York, the dollar jumped to close at 130.35 yen, from 128.73 yen on Wednesday. Overnight in Tokyo, the dollar had risen to a closing 129.50 Japanese yen, from 127.55 yen at Wednesday's close. Later in London, it rose to 129.90 yen.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.967 from $1.976 late Wednesday. In New York, it cost $1.9625 to buy one pound, less expensive than Wednesday's $1.9690. Against the German mark, the dollar rose to 1.4930 marks, from 1.4874.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $385.75 an ounce, down from $387.25 late Wednesday. In Zurich, the metal fell to $384.75, from $386.75. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $2.67, to close at $386.31.

HEADLINE: Hong Kong Journal;
From One Who Suffered, Dire Words on China

BYLINE: By BARBARA BASLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Nov. 8

 BODY:
It was to be a private visit to Hong Kong, a rest after a grueling lecture tour of Japan. But once Nien Cheng agreed to sign copies of her book, "Life and Death in Shanghai," people here lined up by the hundreds in front of the little basement bookstore.
Many brought small gifts and anxious questions about their future under the Chinese. "People always ask me what I think will happen to Hong Kong in 1997, when the British turn it over to China," Mrs. Cheng said. "So of course I knew there would be questions here." 
 And Mrs. Cheng, a native of China, and one of the victims of its brutal Cultural Revolution, tells them candidly, "Hong Kong will be a very different place."
In an interview in her hotel room, overlooking the colony's spectacular harbor lined with gleaming skyscrapers, she said that under China, Hong Kong would no longer be a regional financial center. It will be a tense, repressed city where a black market in Hong Kong dollars flourishes, and corrupt officials hold sway through intimidation, she said.
 
An 'Inconvenient' Organization
 "They will leave the race track, because all Chinese like to gamble," she said. "And they will leave the golf courses because the top party people like the game. But they will not leave the Independent Commission Against Corruption.
"It's so inconvenient to have such an organization. People ask me if the wave of change and democracy which has swept over Eastern Europe will wash over China soon. I do not think it will, because Communism in China came from within, it was a national movement. In Eastern Europe, it was largely imposed on resisting nations with their own democratic traditions."
Moreover, she said, China's future generation of leaders, men and women now in their 30's and 40's, "are very troublesome."
"Many of these people were the Red Guards of the Cultural Revolution who left schools and training to rampage through China. I think these people will trouble China in the future because they know only how to torture and destroy."
Mrs. Cheng, a frail, elegant woman with a fierce sense of honor, endured six and a half years of solitary confinement in a Shanghai prison, from 1966 until 1973, after she was accused of being a British spy, a class enemy, during the turbulent and often terrifying days of the Cultural Revolution.
 
The Time of the Red Guards
 Born in Beijing in 1915, she was educated at an American college there and at the London School of Economics. Her husband was the general manager of Shell in Shanghai until he died of cancer in 1957, when the company hired her as an adviser.
In "Life and Death in Shanghai" (Grove-Weidenfeld), she describes daily life and then imprisonment during the time Mao's young Red Guards tried to purify China, smashing what was thought to be old, foreign and counterrevolutionary. A woman with Mrs. Cheng's background, with her Western tastes and foreign friends, was a prime target of the Cultural Revolution of 1966 to 1976.
Mrs. Cheng's account of her life and her daughter's death in Shanghai, first published six years ago, has been an international success.
She said that visitors to China have reported seeing black-market English versions of her book and around Shanghai three home-grown Chinese translations.
In fact, tourists now seek out spots Mrs. Cheng wrote about. When an American tourist asked a Chinese guide to point out the No. 1 Detention House in Shanghai, where Mrs. Cheng spent her years as political prisoner 1806, the guide said the place did not exist. "The tourist had a copy of my book, and she gave it to the guide, who took it home that night," Mrs. Cheng said. "The next morning the guide said she must not tell the others on the tour, but he would drive by the Detention Center. He said he would drive by, but say nothing."
When she was finally allowed to leave China in 1980, Mrs. Cheng left through Hong Kong. The Governor invited her to dinner, but she refused.
"I thought the Communists would say: 'We were right. Look at this woman, she must be a British spy. The moment she left China she goes to dinner with the Governor.' I didn't want to give them that satisfaction."
 
Lunch With the Governor
 On this trip, however, she agreed to have lunch with the Governor, Sir David Wilson, whom she knew when he was a diplomat in China. Asked if she would share her dark views of Hong Kong with him, she smiled and said: "I think it's embarrassing to talk about Hong Kong. We will talk about the European Community, Margaret Thatcher, old friends."
Mrs. Cheng said some business leaders she had talked to said they were optimistic about 1997. "A man said to me he hopes that if many well-educated, prosperous people stay, they might be able to influence the Communists," she said.
Then she leaned back in her chair, laughing gently and shaking her head: "You know, you can't influence the Communists. You see, that is too optimistic."
She said others in Hong Kong were too pessimistic. "They think the Communists will march into offices here with guns. But you know, they won't do that, they never did that. They take control in more subtle ways."
Mrs. Cheng, who became an American citizen recently, lives in Washington and since the success of her book has been lecturing widely.
Asked if she would ever visit China again, she shook her head: "No, I will not go back unless there are profound changes there. What would be the point?"
