HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Message to Iraq: The Will and the Way

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8

 BODY:
President Bush sought today to send an unmistakable message to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq that the United States had the will to go to war, that it would soon have the means to go to war and that a war, if it came, would inevitably inflict terrible damage on Iraq.
But Mr. Bush strongly hopes, his aides said, that a further show of strength will constitute such "a very strong signal, another strong signal" about the seriousness of American purpose that Mr. Hussein will pull out of Kuwait and make an offensive unnecessary. 
 It seemed no accident that the signal came in a week when Syria and Egypt both voiced their willingness to consider offensive military action against Iraq, when the Soviet Union opened the door slightly to that possibility and when Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, in a major debate in the House of Commons on Wednesday, delivered this bellicose message to President Hussein:
"Either he gets out of Kuwait soon, or we and our allies will remove him by force, and he will go down to defeat with all its consequences."
 
Praise for Thatcher
 For the first time, the President spoke not only of defending against "any further Iraqi aggression," but also of insuring that the United States and its allies had "an adequate offensive military option should that be necessary to achieve our common goals." He praised what Mrs. Thatcher had said.
But Mr. Bush did not intend to indicate that war itself was imminent, said senior Administration officials and diplomats of countries arrayed with the United States in the coalition against Iraq. They said that in the absence of the kind of flagrant provocation Mr. Hussein has so far avoided, like the killing of American hostages, the United States was unlikely to move to oust Iraqi troops from Kuwait before January or February.
Mr. Bush plans to spend Thanksgiving with United States forces in Saudi Arabia, and Presidents have usually felt it politic, where possible, to avoid military action with heavy casualties during the December holidays.
 
A New Phase
 "We have been saying for months that we would not exclude offensive action," a United States policy-maker said. "We have kept that option open. Now we are moving into a new phase, where we assemble the tools to make that option realistic. That, obviously, will take some time."
The announcement that more American forces would soon be dispatched to the Persian Gulf, including hundreds of tanks and three more aircraft carriers, was pictured by Administration officials as the essential military accompaniment to this week's mission by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to nations that the United States hopes would cooperate in any attack on Iraq.
But by making his move now, Mr. Bush is running the political risk that members of Congress, especially Democrats, no longer worried about jeopardizing their re-election by making comments that might seem unpatriotic, would feel freer to criticize his actions than they had before the election on Tuesday.
Shortly after the President had finished speaking, Senator Claiborne Pell, the Rhode Island Democrat who heads the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, issued a statement arguing that the United States should not "establish an offensive capacity in advance of a United Nations resolution authorizing offensive action," that "we should delay going to war until the economic embargo has been given a decent chance to produce results," and that "the President would be badly advised to go to war without a clear prior expression of Congressional support."
 
Baker Seeks Support
 "I am not yet persuaded that the expected gains from offensive action would be worth the likely high loss of American lives and greatly increased economic costs," said the Senator, a cautious politician who is unlikely to have spoken so forcefully unless convinced that many colleagues agreed with him.
But White House aides expressed confidence that most of Capitol Hill and most of the country would back the President, even though he has no intention of seeking prior permission of Congress if he decides to go to war. Important elements in this effort, one said, would be continued allied cooperation and working through the United Nations, although Mr. Bush said flatly today that the United States felt free to take offense action without United Nations authorization.
On his travels, Secretary of State Baker has been seeking support for a new United Nations resolution authorizing the use of force to carry out earlier resolutions calling on Iraq to withdraw. A European Cabinet minister, privy to Mr. Baker's discussions, said in a telephone interview that China and the Soviet Union had all but pledged they would not block such a move. Both are among the permanent members of the Security Council, with veto power.
 
A Shift by Moscow
 After a meeting in Moscow today with Mr. Baker, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the Soviet Foreign Minister, said that "a situation may emerge which effectively would require" the use of force -- a considerable departure from an earlier statement that the use of force would be "undesirable." But Qian Qichen, China's Foreign Minister, who met Mr. Baker in Cairo, has not publicly gone nearly that far, and Beijing is reportedly urging Washington to go slow.
At his own news conference this afternoon, after that of President Bush, Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney insisted that no decision had yet been made by Mr. Bush on whether offensive action should be undertaken. The question will not have to be confronted for some weeks because the last of the tens of thousands of troops and the armor and aircaft needed for an attack will not reach the Persian Gulf until early next year, military analysts said.
Clearly the President hoped to impress Mr. Hussein anew with the depth of the American commitment against him by making public the list of military units to be deployed, something that was not done at the beginning of the initial buildup, which has now reached 230,000. It is an awesome roster, including the battleship Missouri, the First and Third Armored Divisions and the First Infantry Division -- the "Big Red One" of Omaha Beach fame.
 
'The Game Is Up'
 "I would think that when he surveys the force that's there, this force that's going, what other countries are doing in this regard, he will realize that he is up against a foe that he can't possibly manage militarily," Mr. Bush told reporters this afternoon.
Offensive units will be ready just about in time to meet the specification outlined by President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt in an interview with The New York Times on Wednesday. Warning that unless Iraq pulled back war was inevitable with "the greatest concentration of military force I have ever seen in this area," he said the anti-Baghdad coalition should wait "at least two or three more months" to see whether economic sanctions forced Mr. Hussein to act.
"The point here is to try to convince Saddam, with this announcement, that the game is up and he should let go," an Arab diplomat said. "Then you wouldn't have to use the troops. But to make the threat credible, they have to be sent, and if you need them, you need them. There's no point in attacking before the ducks are in a row."

HEADLINE: ANGOLAN LEADER GLOOMY ON TALKS

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LUANDA, Angola, Nov. 7

 BODY:
President Eduardo dos Santos of Angola says that the prospects for ending his country's 15-year-old civil war soon appear bleak. He accuses Jonas Savimbi, the American-backed rebel leader, of negotiating in "bad faith" and says he doubts that a new round of peace talks, scheduled for next week, will yield anything positive.
In an interview Wednesday night, Mr. dos Santos contended that the United States was encouraging the rebel leader to continue fighting. The peace talks, the President said, were a "pretext," adding that Mr. Savimbi was still seeking a military victory. 
 "Up to now," he said of the rebel negotiators, "they haven't given any evidence that they're serious."
 
Dos Santos Blames U.S.
 Asked if this meant fighting would continue for the foreseeable future, he replied: "I'm pessimistic. I would like the war to end soon, but you have to be realistic in order to be able to lead, and the United States does not want to see this war come to an end soon. We have to get ourselves ready for that reality, because if the United States wanted peace in Angola, they would not go on giving weapons to Unita."
Since June, negotiators for the Luanda Government and the rebel group, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, have met four times in an effort to reach a political settlement. The fifth meeting is scheduled to be held in Portugal, Angola's former colonial ruler.
Mr. dos Santos said that Luanda had made major concessions since the negotiations began, notably the decision last month to transform its nominally Marxist-Leninist Government into one with a multiparty system. He also announced that general elections would be held at all levels, including the presidency, within three years of a peace settlement with Unita.
 
Election Issue Touchy
 Mr. dos Santos said the election timetable had become a major source of friction. The rebels, the President said, were insisting that elections be held within six months after a truce is signed, a proposal he dismissed as logistically impossible given the war-ravaged state of much of the country.
Reminded that there are some in the United States Congress, including his supporters, who have said that three years was too long to wait before elections are held, Mr. dos Santos said: "We know Angola and we know the Angolans and we want to be realistic." He added: "It's not up to the United States Congress to discuss whether elections should be held in one year, two years or three years."
Another divisive issue in the talks, Mr. dos Santos said, was whether guerrilla forces will be allowed to keep their weapons until elections are called. Unita, he said, had made this proposal a centerpiece in its bargaining position.
"Where in the world is there a political party that has been militarized?" Mr. dos Santos asked.
 
A South African Example
 "Im going to quote the example of South Africa," he continued. "One of the conditions the South African Government had demanded from the African National Congress is that they shouldn't let their armed men come into South Africa. So those who go in should go in disarmed. And no one in the world has disagreed with that position."
The 48-year-old Mr. dos Santos is a Soviet-trained engineer who has devoted his adult life to the ruling party, the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola. His tone was informal and he seemed relaxed during the 50-minute interview, but he showed occasional flashes of frustration and anger as he discussed the peace negotations and a wide range of other subjects.
Mr. Savimbi's rebel group -- by itself or in alliance with another rebel faction that has since become inactive -- has been fighting the leftist government in Luanda virtually since Angola gained independence from Portugal in 1975. Since 1985, the Central Intelligence Agency has provided increasing military aid to the rebels, now estimated at about $60 million a year.
Mr. dos Santos succeeded to the presidency in 1979.
He said that Cuban troops in Angola, a major barrier to the establishment of diplomatic relations with the United States, have been reduced from 50,000 in January 1989 to 12,000 today, adding that all the troops would be out by July 1991.
 
Mixed Economy Pledged
 The President repeated his party's pledge to gradually move away from a centralized economy. "Our aim is to create a mixed economy," he said, emphasizing that the bulk of the retail trade and small business sector would soon be privatized.
Did that mean, Mr. dos Santos was asked, that the state-owned press and radio and television stations would be turned over to private individuals? "No, we have no intention of privatizing the main mass media stations. Normally, that doesn't happen, even in the West." He promised, though, that under a new constitution being drafted, the tightly controlled press would have greater freedom.
Mr. dos Santos avoided a direct answer when asked if he personally still considers himself a Socialist. "We've said in the past and continue to say that capitalism does not solve all of the problems of the people. We're also aware that the model of socialism that was applied in the Eastern European countries could not solve all the problems of the people either."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Is the Deficit Cut A Serious Error?

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
AFTER failing time and again to work out a plan to eliminate the budget deficit during the years when the economy was climbing, the White House and Congress finally made a deal to cut the deficit by an estimated $40 billion in the next fiscal year and by $490 billion or so over the next five years -- just when most economists believe the economy is weak and falling into recession.
Is this, as some economists are saying, a horrendous blunder, comparable to the decision made by President Herbert Hoover to put through a huge tax rise, nearly doubling rates, as the economy was falling into the depths of the Depression in 1932?
Mr. Hoover's aim was to prevent inflation by closing the budget deficit when businesses were failing, unemployment rising and incomes falling, and the real threat was deflation. Fear of inflation, during a time of falling employment and prices, also greatly restricted the efforts of the Federal Reserve to make more money and credit available and to reduce interest rates. The perverse Hoover fiscal policy and timid Fed monetary policy, which allowed the money supply to shrink by one-third, as banks slashed their lending to business, deepened the Depression.
Are national leaders about to make the same mistakes and thrust the weakened American economy into depression? Should they just forget about reducing the structural budget deficit, regarded as a cause of big trade deficits, savings shortfalls, low capital formation and productivity growth, as well as weakened American competitiveness -- and instead focus on the short-run necessity of fighting recession by increasing the deficit through lower taxes and higher spending? C. Eugene Steuerle, who was Deputy Assistant Secretary for tax analysis at the Treasury Department before joining the Urban Institute in Washington in 1989, contends it would be a serious mistake to forget about reducing the debt burden, which has been growing faster, even in good times, than the national income, for the sake of using short-term fiscal policy to combat the recession.
Indeed, he maintains it is possible to achieve a fiscal policy that will meet both the objectives of short-term economic stabilization and long-term deficit reduction aimed at strengthening national economic growth. To get both, he calls for "automatic fiscal stabilization through the tax and transfer system" within the context of long-run fiscal balance.
To get greater fiscal responsiveness to short-run cyclical swings without sacrificing long-term economic stability, he calls for improving public insurance programs. The unemployment compensation system, traditionally the Government's chief weapon for providing anti-recessionary expenditures and insurance, has, he says become a "timebomb," because the system is so inadequately financed that a recession could make many state programs insolvent. Less than one-third of the jobless have received benefits in the last decade.
He would provide financing to unemployment compensation that would make it one of the strongest automatic stabilizers, increasing total demand when the economy slumps and decreasing it when the economy booms.
While improving the automatic stabilizers for short-term fiscal responses, he supports a long-run deficit-reduction target and would stick to it over the course of the business cycle. Negotiators of the recent budget deal, in Mr. Steuerle's view, "score fairly high marks on their overall deficit-reduction strategy, but score less well on their choice of specific cuts."
But if one relies only on the automatic stabilizers, rather than on discretionary changes in taxes or spending, to check a recession, will the economy fall into a depression?
Hyman P. Minsky, a visiting professor at Bard College of Columbia University and author of "Can 'It' Happen Again?" answers no -- because today's economy is far less vulnerable to deep depression. In 1929 the Federal Government constituted a mere 3 percent of the total United States economy; it now accounts for 25 percent, and its spending will be stable throughout the business cycle.
In addition, the Federal Reserve, in the event of crisis, would move in, as Professor Minsky says, "to flood the economy with reserves and to prevent a collapse of asset values."
After the New York stock market crash of October 1987, which swiftly spread to markets around the world, the central banks behaved as a close fraternity, and they are likely to do so in any future crisis. As the former Fed Chairman, Paul A. Volcker, put it in his 1990 Per Jacobson Lecture before the International Monetary Fund: "In a turbulent world, the importance of restoring a sense of stability is more clearly recognized."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 10, 1990, Friday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
The Economic Scene column yesterday referred incorrectly to Bard College, in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y. It is not part of Columbia University, although it was from 1928 through 1944. The column also omitted the title of Hyman P. Minsky, a Bard professor. He is a fellow at the college's Jerome Levy Economics Institute.

HEADLINE: Budget Jockeying Is Fight for Survival

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
In tangling so publicly with the Dinkins administration over his budget, Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez is fighting not only for the jobs of teachers but for his own credibility, and perhaps survival.
 If cuts of $90 million are made in midyear and another $250 million next year, Mr. Fernandez's long-heralded plan to allow schools to manage more of their own affairs and his promise to improve instruction and safety may be rendered hollow, some educators said. Giving committees of teachers, administrators and parents the chance to eliminate jobs and programs is as savory as offering the Titanic's deckhands the chance to captain the ship, the educators said. 
 Mr. Fernandez said that if teaching jobs are lost through layoffs or attrition on the order dictated by City Hall, he will be presiding over a school system experiencing massive disruption.
Teachers who leave in midyear will be replaced, not with new teachers, but with teachers pulled out of other classrooms. Some children would have their teachers shuffled several times. School amenities -- guidance counselors, advanced courses in science, foreign language classes, sports programs would, as Mr. Fernandez sees it, all suffer.
Mr. Dinkins yesterday released a revised economic plan that called for layoffs of 117 teachers and 1,072 non-instructional employees and the elimination, through resignations and retirements, of another 742 teaching positions and 328 other jobs. But Mr. Fernandez, who last week warned of as many as 4,400 layoffs, quickly replied that the attrition figures are unrealistic and that Mr. Dinkins's cuts would necessitate far more layoffs.
 
A Weakened Image?
 It is virtually impossible to figure out who is right about the impact of the budget cuts because everyone with detailed knowledge is aligned with one camp or the other.
City Hall officials believe Mr. Fernandez is engaging in doomsday talk about inordinate numbers of layoffs in order to generate public and political opposition to the cuts, with City Council hearings still ahead and with larger cuts of $243 million looming in the next fiscal year that starts July 1.
For Mr. Fernandez what is at stake is more than numbers, however. It is the reputation he brought from Miami last year as a man who saves troubled urban school systems.
Losing the budget battle would weaken Mr. Fernandez's once-invincible image in the public eye and, more important, in Albany.
The man who earlier this year got the State Legislature to dilute tenure for principals and abolish the Board of Examiners, the school system's licensing arm, would find it hard to win the third of his major initiatives -- a stronger role in the selection of district superintendents.
"Victories form the foundation for other victories," said Jerald Posman, a former deputy chancellor for finance. "A lot of what Fernandez was able to achieve was because there was an aura around him that he could make things happen, and if you suffer a major defeat like this, then the whole program you're putting forward is in jeopardy."
On a more brass-tacks level, Mr. Fernandez and his aides are being diverted from running the schools and worn down by the sheer time they have had to spend trimming the budget and meeting with Board of Education members and City Hall officials.
 
Doomsday Talk
 A good illustration of their distraction came on Wednesday when a task force on safety and discipline led by Laura Blackburne, head of the city's Housing Authority, issued a report that Mr. Fernandez's own aides found bland and did little to publicize.
Mayor David N. Dinkins and his aides said they are only trying to get Mr. Fernandez to make reductions needed if the city hopes to sell its bonds. They said the Board of Education has long been a refuge of waste.
Mr. Fernandez has his own explanation for Mr. Dinkins's motives. He has told associates that his agency is virtually being singled out for layoffs because City Hall has a hidden agenda: to pressure Sandra Feldman, president of the United Federation of Teachers, to abrogate the 5.5 percent wage increase she recently negotiated.
"They agreed to it," said one aide to the Chancellor of City Hall's role in the wage package. "Now their plan is to run away from the contract as far as they can go. They say we will stick them with $90 million in cuts and force Feldman to crawl up the steps of City Hall, saying, 'Don't lay off teachers. We'll take back 2 percent.' "
 
Bad Teacher-Student Ratio
 Is Mr. Fernandez being disingenuous and engaging in political gamesmanship when he cries about the impact of the cuts?
Robert F. Wagner Jr., former president of the Board of Education and the man who appointed Mr. Fernandez, said that New York City already spends less per child than most other localities -- $4,787 compared with a statewide average of $5,207. Noreen Connell, executive director of the Educational Priorities Panel, a coalition of advocacy groups, said New York schools have one teacher for every 15.7 pupils, the second worst ratio in the state.
By comparison, Westchester County has one teacher for every 12 students. The board's notoriously heavy headquarters staff has actually been cut from 7,700 in 1986 to 3,500 today, Mr. Wagner said.
Part of the division with City Hall also has its roots in personalities. There are reports of strains between Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel and Stanley S. Litow, deputy chancellor for operations. And Gwendolyn C. Baker, the current board president, although appointed by Mr. Dinkins, simply does not have the policy influence on him that Mr. Wagner had with Mayor Edward I. Koch, his close friend.
Ms. Connell thinks the donnybrook with City Hall may only be another sign that Mr. Fernandez is suffering a backlash among political officials to his efforts to limit the power of local school boards. She noted that Mr. Fernandez also did not do so well with legislators in Albany in June when he sought restorations to his state allocation.
"The people who are in the political world, in the clubhouse world, are going to get their nose out of joint when he shows up at budget time," she said.

HEADLINE: Consumers Slow Their Borrowing

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8

 BODY:
American consumers took out $3 billion more in credit during September than they repaid, using some of it to buy new cars but trimming the rate of credit growth from the summer months, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
"We're seeing a steady decrease in consumer credit, which is logical considering the circumstances that people are facing, including fears about losing their jobs," said Jean Sundrla, an economist with Evans Economics Inc. in Washington. 
 Installment credit expanded by $3.06 billion in August and by $4.73 billion in July.
Loans to buy new cars increased in September by $163 million after contracting by $1.51 billion in August and by $377 million in July, as people repaid more loans than they took out during the summer.
 
Incentives to Clear Lots
 But September marked the end of the 1990 model year, and dealers used a variety of incentives to clear their lots.
Prices have risen on many 1991 models. Although sales picked up in October, analysts attributed the gains primarily to rental car companies renewing their fleets and not to individual buying.
Ms. Sundrla said that there was likely to be an additional adverse impact from rising energy prices as the year went on, not only on car sales but also on general consumer confidence.
"Now is the time for people to be paying off their credit card balances rather than increasing them," she said, noting that if an expected consumer pullback occurred, it would probably deepen a recession that many expect to begin in the current fourth quarter and to continue into 1991.
Revolving, or credit card, credit grew in September by $1.91 billion, but that was much smaller than the increases in August and July of $2.35 billion and $3.78 billion respectively.
 
Bank Loans Slow
 Growth in other credit, a category that takes in bank loans but not home mortgages, slowed to a $1.15 billion rise from $2.03 billion in August.
Loans for mobile homes declined in September by $219 million after expanding during August by $180 million.
Before seasonal adjustment, the total of all consumer debts outstanding that are to be paid on the installment plan was $737.43 billion at the end of September, up from $734.51 billion at the end of August.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Excerpts From Bush's Remarks on His Order to Enlarge U.S. Gulf Force

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference at the White House today, as provided by the Federal News Service, a transcription company.
 OPENING STATEMENT
 On Aug. 6, in response to the unprovoked Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, I ordered the deployment of U.S. military forces to Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf to deter further Iraqi aggression and to protect our interests in the region. What we've done is right, and I'm happy to say that most members of Congress and the majority of Americans agree.
From the very beginning, we and our coalition partners have shared common political goals -- the immediate, complete and unconditional withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait, restoration of Kuwait's legitimate government, protection of the lives of citizens held hostage by Iraq, both in Kuwait and Iraq, and restoration of security and stability in the Persian Gulf region. To achieve these goals, we and our allies have forged a strong diplomatic, economic and military strategy to force Iraq to comply with these objectives. The framework of this strategy is laid out in 10 United Nations resolutions overwhelmingly supported by the United Nations Security Council.
In three months, the U.S. troop contribution to the multinational force in Saudi Arabia has gone from 10,000 to 230,000, as part of Operation Desert Shield. General Schwarzkopf reports that our forces in conjunction with other coalition forces now have the capability to defend successfully against any further Iraqi aggression.
 
Allied Consultations
 After consultation with King Fahd and our other allies, I have today directed the Secretary of Defense to increase the size of U.S. forces committed to Desert Shield to insure that the coalition has an adequate offensive military option should that be necessary to achieve our common goals. Toward this end, we will continue to discuss the possibility of both additional allied force contributions and appropriate United Nation actions. Iraq's brutality, aggression and violations of international law cannot be allowed to succeed.
Secretary Baker has been consulting with our key partners in the coalition. He has met with the Emirs of Bahrain and Kuwait, King Fahd, President Mubarak, as well as the Chinese Foreign Minister, President Ozal, Foreign Minister Shevardnadze, President Gorbachev. He also will be meeting with Prime Minister Thatcher and President Mitterrand. I have been heartened by Jim's appraisal of the strong international solidarity and determination to insure that Iraq's aggression does not stand and is not rewarded.
But right now Kuwait is struggling for survival. And along with many other nations, we've been called upon to help. The consequences of our not doing so would be incalculable, because Iraq's aggression is not just a challenge to the security of Kuwait and other gulf nations, but to the better world that we all have hoped to build in the wake of the cold war. And therefore, we and our allies cannot and will not shirk our responsibilities. The state of Kuwait must be restored, or no nation will be safe, and the promising future we anticipate will indeed be jeopardized.
Let me conclude with a word to the young American G.I.'s deployed in the gulf. We are proud of each and every one of you. I know you miss your loved ones and want to know when you'll be coming home. We won't leave you there any longer than necessary. I want every single soldier out of there as soon as possible. And we are all grateful for your continued sacrifice and your commitment. . . .
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
 Q. Mr. President, it sounds like you're going to war. You have moved from a defensive position to an offensive position and you have not said how many more troops you are sending or really why.
A. Well, I said why right now, and I hope that it's been very clear to the American people.
Q. Well is there -- are there new reasons that have moved this posture?
A. No, I'm just continuing to do what we feel is necessary to complete our objectives, to fulfill our objectives that have been clearly stated.
Q. Well, are you going to war?
A. I'm not -- we -- I would love to see a peaceful resolution to this question. And that's what I want.
 
Reason for Shift
 Q. What made you change from defense to offense?
A. I would like to see a peaceful solution to this question. I think Saddam Hussein should fully, without condition, comply to the U.N. resolutions. And if this movement of force is what convinces him, so much the better.
 
Embargo Time Limit
 Q. Mr. President, you said that -- you said last week that the sanctions haven't had the impact that you wanted. Some -- some members of the coalition are urging a go-slow approach. The President of Egypt says you've got to wait two or three months before you judge whether the sanctions have worked. Are you willing to wait that long?
A. Wait for what?
Q. To see if the sanctions have worked?
A. Well, we're -- well, I think from talking to Jim Baker and recently to President Mubarak that we are in total sync with him. But I hope that the sanctions will work within a two-month period. But I don't think we've got a difference with Egypt on this at all, Terry.
Q. The question is, how long are you willing to give ----
A. Well, I can't tell you how long. I'm not going to -- if I -- if I knew, I certainly wouldn't want to signal that to -- to Saddam Hussein.
 
Power to Attack
 Q. Do you feel that you are free to take offensive action without any kind of U.N. resolution authorizing it?
A. Yes. We have the authority, but we've -- we've been great believers in going to the United Nations. And I think one of the major successes has been the ability to have world opinion totally on our side because of U.N. action. The peacekeeping function of the United Nations has indeed been rejuvenated by the actions of the Security Council. . . .
Q. Do you yet have the support you need in order to secure an additional resolution from the U.N. Security Council to explicitly authorize the use of force? Do you now have the sufficient support on the Security Council ----
A. . . . I'd say we have not tried to specifically poll the 15 members -- or the other 14 members of the Security Council along those lines, so I can't answer whether we would or not.
 
Force's Transformation
 Q. Mr. President, what has happened in the last two weeks that has led you to put now an offensive force into Saudi Arabia?
A. Well, we have -- we have not only offensive but defensive forces there already. And what leads me to do this is just because I believe -- upon the advice of our able Secretary of Defense and others -- that this is in the best security interests of our people that are there and of the coalition.
 
Gorbachev's View
 Q. Sir, on your consultation that your Secretary of State is doing now in Moscow, could you just spell out for us what your understanding is, as of today, with Mikhail Gorbachev, on the use of force?
A. . . . I am convinced from what the Secretary has told me that we are on the same wavelength in terms of the objectives that I've spelled out here. But I can't go in -- with you into what the Soviet position will be on use of force or -- you know, I don't think they've been asked to send forces. Is that -- maybe I missed the question.
 
Shevardnadze Comment
 Q. [inaudible] Mr. Shevardnadze on the record today said that they too would not rule out the use of force, while they still wanted a peaceful solution. Does that at least help you send the kind of signal to Saddam Hussein that you're also trying to send here?
A. I think it's -- I think it is very helpful, but I think the signal of solidarity between the United States and the Soviet Union and the rest of the Security Council has already gone out. But no, I do -- I think that it is very helpful to have a position like that stated and restated, because that's the way the whole world feels, and it is good to have this solid front between ourselves and the Soviet Union.
 
War and Israel
 Q. . . . There have been complaints, observations, out of Israel that, were there to be offensive action, there needs to be coordination or some sort of chain of command involving the Israelis too, for they may end up being involved. To what extent are you communicating with the Israelis? And to what extent do you envision any role or possible role for the Israelis should this come to war?
A. Well, I think the whole world knows that the United States is -- has a very special relationship with Israel -- a strong relationship. I think we're in close touch with the key players there in terms of our objectives. And I think they've conducted themselves in a -- regarding all of this -- very well indeed. But I'm not going to discuss any more details than that. But I -- I feel that we're on a good wavelength there.
Q. Mr. President ----
A. We have some differences obviously. . . .
 
Gauging Hussein
 Q. Some of members of your Administration are convinced that Saddam Hussein will not move until he is -- until the 11th hour or 11:59, when he is totally convinced that you are about to use military force. Why is he not convinced now, do you think? Why -- how do you expect that you will be able to get to that 11:59 in a minute?
A. Well, I'm not sure I accept the 11:59 analogy, but if there has ever been any doubt in his mind about the seriousness of the West and of the other Arab countries and of the coalition -- put it that way -- I think that those doubts are rapidly being dispelled.
And I would think that when he surveys the force that's there, this force that's going, what other countries are doing in this regard, he will recognize that he is up against a -- just an -- a foe that he can't possibly manage militarily.

HEADLINE: Disney Profits Increase 9%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BURBANK, Calif., Nov. 8

 BODY:
The weakening economy slowed profit growth at Walt Disney Company to 9 percent in the quarter that ended on Sept. 30, the entertainment giant said today.
Michael Eisner, the chief executive, and Frank Wells, the president, said in a joint statement that theme park attendance had dropped off during the summer months. Operating income from the parks rose just 1 percent for the quarter, Disney said.
Recession fears and other concerns have caused investors to knock Disney's stock price down from a high of $136.50 a share in the last year to the $90 range in recent weeks. On the New York Stock Exchange today, the stock gained 12.5 cents, to $91.125.
During the fourth fiscal quarter, Disney earned $232.7 million, or $1.72 a share, compared with $212.7 million, or $1.54 a share, in the period in 1989. Revenue rose 27 percent, to $1.71 billion from $1.35 billion.

HEADLINE: Laventhol Paying the Price For Accounting Ambitions

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
Laventhol & Howarth, the nation's seventh-largest accounting firm, tried to take on the giants of accounting, landing such diverse clients as Jim Bakker's P.T.L. and the film maker Woody Allen.
Now, with the accounting industry in a downturn, the Philadelphia-based firm is paying the price for its ambitions. 
 A number of costly lawsuits, including a multimillion dollar suit involving the P.T.L., is eating into profits. Partners and employees are leaving at a rapid clip. And senior executives have appealed to employees and retired partners for ways to conserve cash.
In the few months since Robert N. Levine took over as the firm's chief executive, its partnership ranks have tumbled 15 percent, to 362. Some of these departures where part of Mr. Levine's austerity program, but a great many are ranking partners.
For his part, Mr. Levine said that talk of bankruptcy or dissolving the firm was premature. "We just have no intention of dissolving the firm at this time," he said. "Whatever you've heard is just part of a planning process that any good management would do looking to deal with an economy that is difficult. I can tell you categorically we have not prepared any papers."
Among the significant departures are Kenneth I. Solomon, Philip T. Winik and David Love, heads of the Chicago, Los Angeles and Boston offices, respectively. Former partners of the firm, who asked not to be identified, said these three offices alone contributed well over a third of Laventhol's profits in recent years.
Nor is the exodus slowing. Competitors report getting a large number of resumes from Laventhol partners. And other firms, convinced that Laventhol cannot enforce the promise that its partners make not to compete with the firm for two to four years, are raiding the firm's talent.
According to former Laventhol partners, Bjorn Hanson, one of the firm's leaders in its hospitality and lodging practice, is joining Coopers & Lybrand. One small Chicago firm seeking to increase its national profile, Altschuler, Melvoin & Glasser, has snared three of Laventhol's partners -- Sandy Morriss, Richard Goodman and Kenneth S. Pinsky -- in the last few weeks.
 
Smaller Clients Leave
 In recent months, a string of smaller audit clients including the Twistee Treat Corporation, American Screen Company, Southern Kitchens Inc. and Micros Systems Inc. have abandoned the firm. And Mr. Levine has acknowledged that the firm's troubles have cost it consulting business.
Though Laventhol's senior management has been insisting for months that the firm's problems were behind it, the strains of the last few months have clearly caught up with Mr. Levine.
Two weeks ago, the firm slashed the pay of its 3,500 employees by 10 percent for the next three months. Last week, in another step to conserve cash, Mr. Levine sought to defer until early next year the monthly payments to the firm's 115 or so retirees. The firm's national council, composed of 16 partners, met last week and rejected that suggestion. The checks went out on Friday.
"We have paid the full amount due our retired partners and we will pay everything due to them at the end of our distribution year at May 15, 1991," Mr. Levine said.
Laventhol is hardly the only accounting firm to be practicing austerity these days. But Laventhol entered this period of contraction weaker than many of its competitors.
 
Paid Out Over $50 Million
 The firm has agreed to pay more than $50 million in the last three years to settle various lawsuits accusing it of shoddy work. Though nearly every accounting firm is sued by disgruntled investors, Laventhol had more than its share of such lawsuits -- the price, some say, of an overly ambitious expansion plan that caused it not to be choosy enough about its clientele.
The firm audited the books of the Grabill Corporation, a Chicago real estate company run by William J. Stoecker. Laventhol reached a $30 million settlement last year with nine creditor banks who were defrauded when Grabill's assets turned out to be vastly overstated in what Mr. Levine called "the darkest day in the firm's history"
"I don't think anyone would deny the litigation has been a strain on the firm," said David Love, the former head of the Boston office who has been working as an independent consultant since taking early retirement at the end of June.
Besides the retirees, interested parties are monitoring the situation closely. According to former partners and people in banking, the firm has at least $80 million in loans outstanding to a consortium of banks that includes the Chase Manhattan Bank, where it has been classified as a problem account, and the Fidelity Bank of Philadelphia, which is owed more than $50 million.
The firm also has 5 to 15 years left on many of its office leases, which the partners would have to make good on if the firm ceased practicing.
 
Soft Real Estate Market
 "It's a mind-boggling kind of thing," said a former Laventhol partner who insisted on anonymity. "You've got enormous obligations there that really can only be serviced by continuing to practice, unless landlords agree to take back property, which in this soft real estate market is hard to do."
Just about the only group that would be well covered in the event of a financial disaster appears to be the investors who had sued Laventhol for its role in a group of Houston oil-drilling tax shelters that soured. The plaintiffs settled the case late last year for $13.5 million on condition that Laventhol pay $8 million up front and obtain a letter of credit from Chase guaranteeing the balance, in the event that the firm ran into subsequent financial problems.
"We hope that does not occur, but if it does, we did not want to be in a position of being a creditor with a big claim," said Richard Drubel, the Houston attorney who represented the plaintiffs in the class-action lawsuit.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Were Slow Last Month

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The nation's largest retail chains reported dismal sales results for October yesterday, dimming an already gloomy outlook for the Christmas shopping season.
Several companies, including Sears, Roebuck and J. C. Penney, said their sales dropped from levels of a year earlier as consumers, with an eye on the economy and the other on the Middle East, avoided buying anything they did not need. Wal-Mart, though, continued to go against the trend, posting strong gains.
 
No Buying Binges
 With Christmas less than seven weeks away, neither the retailers nor the analysts who follow them expect consumers to shift gears suddenly and go on big gift-buying sprees.
The holiday season will be "a much more frugal Christmas," predicted Thomas Tashjian of Seidler Amdec Securities Inc. in Los Angeles.
"They'll probaby be going in and buying the same number of items, but they're not going to pay as much," he said. "They're not going to buy $100 electronic toys for their kids."
The poor October sales, coming in the aftermath of disappointing showings in August and September, "reflect a recessionary psychology" among consumers, said Jeffrey Feiner, an analyst with Merrill Lynch.
Consumers cut spending as the economy weakened and after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 raised the specter of war, inflating prices of gasoline and heating oil.
The first items crossed off shopping lists were discretionary items -- furniture, some clothing and other extras that are the bread and butter of many large stores.
 
The Economic Effects
 If retailers have a tough Christmas, it could contribute to a further deterioration of the economy, since two-thirds of the nation's economic growth is generated through consumer spending.
Unsold goods on store shelves could also affect manufacturing, since if stores do not place new orders, factories will not need to provide as many products, possibly laying off workers.
A poor Christmas season could also be devastating for retailers, which depend on holiday shopping for about half their annual sales and profits. Last Christmas was a disappointment for many stores after they were forced to slash prices to attract customers.
Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, said its results from stores open at least a year, called same-store or comparable-store sales, fell by four-tenths of a percent last month from October 1989. The overall sales of the Chicago-based retailer dropped by 1.2 percent.
Analysts say comparable-store sales provide a more accurate assessment of a retailer's performance than overall sales. New stores tend to have extraordinarily strong sales that can skew a retailer's results.
One of the hardest hit last month was the J. C. Penney Company, which said its comparable-store sales fell by 6.3 percent from October of last year, while its overall sales dropped by 4.9 percent.
 
Limited's Mixed Results
 The Limited Inc., the nation's largest specialty-apparel retailer, reported that its comparable-store sales dropped by 1 percent as overall sales rose by 13 percent. Apparel stores were also affected by continuing warm weather in some parts of the country.
The May Department Stores Company -- the parent of such large department-store chains as Lord & Taylor, Hecht's, Filene's and Foley's -- said its comparable-store sales dropped by 4.4 percent, while its overall sales edged up by 1.1 percent.
But Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the big discount retailer, continued to outperform the rest of the retail industry, reporting that its comparable-store sales rose by 10 percent and that its overall sales rose by 25 percent.
Analysts are predicting trouble for some stores, especially those going into the Christmas season with high inventories and unexpectedly poor sales. These retailers are expected to be the first ones to mark down merchandise -- and see their profits evaporate.
 
Waiting for More Sales
 Markdowns set off a spiral of sorts as consumers, having seen one round of price reductions, wait for more merchandise to be reduced and end up forcing retailers to take further cuts. When one retailer lowers prices, it puts pressure on others to follow.
Mr. Feiner, the Merrill Lynch analyst, noting that profits during Christmas 1989 were hurt by markdowns, issued a warning about another disappointing season: "The end result could be further bankruptcies and-or consolidations in the industry."
Following are the overall domestic sales for October and sales for the first nine months of the year reported yesterday by some of the nation's largest retailers. Reporting periods vary slightly and not all retailers have the same fiscal year.
 
 Sears: Down 1.2 percent in four weeks ended Nov. 3, to $2.55 billion, comparing continuing lines only; up 2.5 percent in nine months, to $24.38 billion.
K Mart Corp.: Up 11.2 percent in four weeks ended Oct. 31, to $2.34 billion; up 11.8 percent in nine months, to $22.32 billion.
Wal-Mart: Up 25 percent in October, to $2.73 billion; up 26 percent in nine months, to $22.24 billion.
J. C. Penney: Down 4.9 percent in four weeks ended Nov. 3, to $1.31 billion; up 1.8 percent in nine months, to $10.31 billion.
Dayton Hudson Corp.: Up 16.7 percent in four weeks ended Nov. 3, to $1.13 billion; up 13.8 percent in nine months, to $9.70 billion.
May Department Stores: Up 1.1 percent in four weeks ended Nov. 3, to $708.6 million; up 8.2 percent in nine months, to $6.75 billion.
Melville Corp.: Up 21.9 percent in four weeks ended Nov. 3, to $690 million; up 12.7 percent in first 10 months, to $6.45 billion.
Woolworth Corp.: Up 4.2 percent in four weeks ended Nov. 3, to $375 million; up 7.7 percent in nine months, to $3.86 billion.
Limited: Up 13 percent in four weeks ended Nov. 3, to $380 million; up 17 percent in nine months, to $3.51 billion, excluding results of the Lerner Woman division that has been sold.
Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc.: Up 1.7 percent in four weeks ended Nov. 3, to $212 million; up six-tenths of a percent in nine months, to $1.88 billion.
TJX Cos.: Up 13.8 percent in four weeks ended Nov. 3, to $195.8 million; up 13.2 percent in nine months, to $1.75 billion.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
BUSH SENDS NEW UNITS TO GULF TO PROVIDE 'OFFENSIVE OPTION'; U.S. FORCE COULD REACH 380,000

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8

 BODY:
President Bush today ordered more than 150,000 additional American ground, sea and air forces to the Persian Gulf area, saying they were needed to provide "an adequate offensive military option" to drive Iraqi troops from Kuwait.
The move would nearly double the size of the American land and naval combat units in the area and give the United States a numerical advantage over Iraq in the most up-to-date tanks. 
 In making his announcement, Mr. Bush said the reinforcements were intended to increase pressure on President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to withdraw his troops from Kuwait, and to lay the foundation for an American attack should he continue to refuse.
 
The Military Option
 "I have today directed the Secretary of Defense to increase the size of U.S. forces committed to Desert Shield to insure that the coalition has an adequate offensive military option, should that be necessary to achieve our common goals," Mr. Bush said at a White House news conference. [Excerpts, page A12.]
"I think Saddam Hussein should fully without condition comply to the U.N. resolutions. And if this movement of force is what convinces him, so much the better," he said.
Before President Bush spoke, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union delivered Moscow's most explicit warning yet to Iraq, saying today in Moscow that the use of force to end the Persian Gulf crisis ould not be ruled out if diplomatic means fail. [Page A13.]
 
380,000 by Early Next Year
 The Pentagon declined to say exactly how many additional troops were being sent, but one Administration official estimated that the additional reinforcements would number more than 150,000. That would bring the total American force in the gulf region to about 380,000 by early next year.
Mr. Bush said he did not need United Nations approval to launch a military action against Iraq, but he indicated the Administration would seek out that support.
"Yes, we have the authority but we've been great believers in going to the United Nations," Mr. Bush said in a question-and-answer session after his announcement. Virtually all of Washington's partners in the anti-Iraqi coalition have said that any military action should be undertaken under the umbrella of a Security Council resolution.
The Security Council has adopted 10 resolutions against Iraq since Mr. Hussein's forces invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. One of the earliest measures, now three months old, provided for a comprehensive trade embargo and the blocking of all Iraqi assets abroad.
Mr. Bush refused to say when force might be used, but he indicated agreement with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, who said on Wednesday in an interview that two to three months more should be given to allow the sanctions against Iraq to work. If the sanctions fail, Mr. Mubarak said, war would be inevitable.
The new reinforcements mark the largest military deployment since the Vietnam War, in which American troops stationed in Vietnam reached a peak of 543,000, excluding naval forces offshore. The deployment is also large by NATO standards, roughly equivalent in number to the American forces stationed in Western Europe during the cold war.
 
3 Aircraft Carriers
 The additional forces -- which include three and one-third Army divisions, three aircraft carriers, another battleship, a large Marine expeditionary force of more than 30,000 men and more Air Force units -- would join more than 230,000 American soldiers, Marines, sailors and airmen in the region.
Although Administration officials previously outlined plans to send additional forces to the gulf area, saying two weeks ago that as many as 100,000 more troops might be sent, the decision today involves more troops and more armored units than expected. It is also the first time that Mr. Bush has explicitly threatened to to take offensive action against Iraq.
The decision appears to have the dual purpose of escalating the pressure on Mr. Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait and increasing military forces in the region to a level at which an attack against Iraqi troops would be more feasible.
 
1,200 More M-1 Tanks
 The Army divisions being sent will add more than 1,200 modern M-1 tanks to about 800 American tanks already deployed in Saudi Arabia. The new tank deployments would give the United States an advantage in the number of top-of-the-line battle tanks, although Iraq, which has thousands of old tanks, would still have an overall advantage in tanks.
The three aircraft carriers that are being sent will bring the total number of carriers in the region to six. The Navy has a total of 14 aircraft carriers.
Mr. Bush has also ordered that an additional battleship, the Missouri, join the Wisconsin in the Persian Gulf. With their 16-inch guns and land-attack cruise missiles, the battleships will figure significantly in the impressive American firepower in the region.
"There will probably be additional Air Force units also," said Mr. Cheney, adding that the precise units to be sent have not been determined. The United States has already stationed about 500 Air Force and Marine bombers, antitank aircraft and fighters in Saudi Arabia and other gulf nations, including a squadron of F-117 Stealth fighters, several dozen F-111F bombers in Saudi Arabia and about 20 B-52 bombers on the Indian Ocean island of Diego Garcia.
 
Rivaling Cold War Numbers
 With the dispatch of the additional divisions, the United States will have about as many troops in the Persian Gulf as it maintained in Europe for about 40 years to oppose the Soviet military. Even with the warming in American and Soviet relations the United States kept some 305,000 Army and Air Force troops in Europe.
General Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said at the news conference that two and a third of the Army's four and a third divisions in Western Europe were being sent to Saudi Arabia.
The decision to send large reinforcements to the region suggests that the Bush Administration wants to leave a credible threat that it will force a resolution of the crisis, either by coercing President Hussein to withdraw his troops from Kuwait or by launching an attack with its allies to do so.
President Bush asserted that the United States is receiving strong support from Western European, Arab and other members of the anti-Iraqi coaltion. Iraq has sought to divide the coalition, by releasing French and German hostages, for example, and some specialists question how long the alliance can hold.
 
Waiting for Cool Weather
 Some military specialists say that if President Bush wants to use military force it would be preferable to begin in the cooler winter months, before the Muslim holy visits to Mecca in the spring. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney declined to say what role weather or political considerations played in the decision to send large reinforcements now instead of waiting to see if the economic sanctions work.
 
No Upper Limit Yet
 Mr. Cheney declined to rule out sending still more troops, saying that no upper limit had been set on American deployment in the gulf. He said Congressional leaders had been notified of the additional reinforcements today before the announcement. Congress has insisted that it be consulted before force is used in the gulf, but the Administration did not seek to explain the scope of its planned reinforcement before lawmakers adjourned late last month.
While military officials say that a buildup would be needed to win a decisive victory and to limit American casualties in the event of war, some specialists said the new deployment would increase the risk of war.
"It is too big a force to sit on," said Thomas McNaugher, a military specialist at the Brookings Institution, suggesting that the United States would be unlikely to tie down such a force for a lengthy period.
The Administration's decision to continue the American buildup follows Iraq's move to expand its force in southern Iraq and Kuwait to some 430,000 and build elaborate fortications along the coast of Kuwait and the Saudi border.
In addition to more than 230,000 American forces deployed in the region, allies of the United States have stationed well over 100,000 troops in the area, and more forces, including an Egyptian armored division and a Syrian armored division are being sent.
The deployment of the three and a third Army divisions -- two and a third divisions from Germany and one from Fort Riley, Kansas -- is a major addition to United States armored capabilities in Saudi Arabia. Army figures show that the new units collectively have about 1,240 M-1 tanks, 750 of them new M1-A1 tanks, which have better guns and protection against chemical and biological attack.
The American expeditionary force currently has about 800 tanks. This includes about 700 Army M-1 tanks, some 150 of which are M1-A1 models, and 120 Marine M-60 tanks.
Mr. Cheney said the decision to add more forces was based in part on the assessment by the commander of American forces in the gulf region, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, of what would be needed to launch an offensive against Iraqi troops.
"The additional military capability that's now being added clearly will give us the ability to conduct offensive military operations, should that be required in the months ahead," Mr. Cheney said. He said it would be early next year before all of the forces activated today were sent to the Persian Gulf and were combat-ready.
The Pentagon is considering a plan to rotate fresh troops into the gulf region every six to eight months, but Mr. Cheney said a final decision had not yet been made on the policy. The 82d Airborne, which was deployed early in the conflict to get troops on the ground in a hurry, is expected to return to the United States so that the Army will have a quick reaction force for other possible crises and so the unit can continue its training. No announcement was made about the future of the 82d Airborne today.
In addition to adding more active-duty forces, Mr. Cheney also called up the first Army combat reserve units, about 15,000 men. The Marine Corps has mobilized about 700 reservists this week for combat roles. Three Army National Guard brigades from Georgia, Mississippi and Louisiana were called up and will be sent to train for several weeks at the Army Training Center in Fort Irwin, Calif.
Once the units have completed their training, Mr. Cheney said, the Pentagon will decide if they are ready enough to be sent to join front-line troops in Saudi Arabia.

HEADLINE: DINKINS ANNOUNCES JOB CUTS TO EASE BUDGET TROUBLES

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Facing New York City's deepening fiscal problems, Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that he would not hire workers to fill about 5,000 planned city jobs, would lay off at least 556 workers in schools, parks and hospital headquarters and make other cuts to keep the city budget balanced.
But the Mayor's announcement amounted to what he called "a downpayment" on the problems. He acknowledged that far more painful cuts were likely to be needed -- including perhaps 10,000 layoffs, as well as 10,000 jobs to be cut through attrition -- to help close an expected gap between revenues and expenditures of more than $1.6 billion for the next fiscal year that starts July 1. 
 The actions Mr. Dinkins outlined yesterday included scaling back school programs, delaying garbage recycling and closing two fire companies. They are intended to close a budget gap that he now estimates at $388 million for the current fiscal year, or a problem just one-fourth the projected size of next year's.
 
Cautious Support
 Fiscal monitors who had awaited the plan as a sign of Mr. Dinkins's resolve, in the wake of conflicting fiscal signals from City Hall a month ago, generally reacted with cautious support. The Mayor is to present his detailed plan for the next fiscal year in January.
"The major fiscal problem has always been fiscal 1992," said Allen J. Proctor, executive director of the State Financial Control Board, a watchdog agency. "One of the primary objectives of this modification was to deal with an important but not so fiscally focused problem, which is: does the Mayor have a comprehensive view of the problems he must deal with? This shows that the Mayor has indeed a firm grasp of the problems he must deal with, and he has articulated a sequence of events to provide solutions."
The latest moves, including the service cuts and efforts to maxmimize state and Federal matching funds for social programs, are expected to translate into savings that will help reduce the budget gap for next year by more than $300 million. Some of the actions taken now, especially those that do not involve trimming the work force, will not produce increased savings next year.
Mr. Dinkins also outlined a series of other tentative measures for next year, including stepped-up audits, reductions in debt service on city bonds, a proposal that the state assume $165 million in Medicaid costs, and $100 million in unspecified Federal action. Those move are intended to close $700 million more of the $1.6 billion gap, leaving only about $600 million still to be dealt with.
 
Elements 'Look Good'
 In a move that drew praise, Mr. Dinkins said he would increase the city's general reserve fund for unanticipated expenses to $150 million, from $100 million, using part of the one-time proceeds from the sale of a plot of vacant city land to the Federal Government for a new office building in lower Manhattan.
Hyman Grossman, a managing director of the Standard & Poor's Corporation, which last month put the city's bonds on a "credit watch" because of concerns about its economy and fiscal planning, said that he had not yet reviewed the plan in detail but that several elements "look good." He said those included increasing the reserve and the Mayor's outlining of $40 million in additional service cuts he would order if the situation worsened this year.
 
'I'm Not a Patsy'
 For now, the Mayor struggled to avoid deep cuts in direct services, though many of those services have been cut repeatedly in recent years. And Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez contends that Mr. Dinkins's demands for cuts in the Board of Education would lead to thousands of layoffs in the school system, not the few hundred that mayoral aides suggest.
Mr. Dinkins, who has dedicated his administration to children, acknowledged that the school cuts would be painful, but he said they had to be made one way or the other, and despite weeks of sparring, said he assumed that Mr. Fernandez did not question his determination. "I'm sure they recognize that I'm not a patsy," he said.
In other ways, Mr. Dinkins minimized the pain, cutting maintenance for swimming pools and beaches and tennis courts and closing all 33 of the city's mini-pools, for example, while planning deeper cuts in park maintenance only if conditions worsened. He will delay introduction of trash recycling in 10 districts but would reduce garbage collection only if the budget gap grew.
While Mr. Dinkins will leave unfilled through attrition or will eliminate through layoffs 5,400 jobs that had been planned, the part of the work force financed entirely by city money will still grow by more than 5,100 workers, to a projected 226,491 by next June. Over the last decade, the work force has grown by around 50,000 workers.
 
'The Right Direction'
 Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a private watchdog group financed by businesses, said the plan was a "step in the right direction, but not a big step." If tax revenues fall off more sharply than the city expects, he said, the budget "will have to be cut again, and valuable time will have been lost."
The city's Budget Director, Philip R. Michael, said the projected gap for the current year was based on an expected revenue shortfall of $180 million, especially in real-estate and income-based taxes, and $183 million in unexpected expenses.
Those expenses include an additional $59 million for welfare, $45 million for fuel and energy and $26 million to accelerate police hiring and pay other costs for Mr. Dinkins's anti-crime plan, for which the Mayor is still seeking $1.8 billion in special taxes over the next four years and whose approval is by no means certain.
Mr. Dinkins said it was too early to talk about what other taxes might be needed to keep the budget balanced next year, though he added that new taxes were a possibility.
As is usually the case with the city budget, Mr. Dinkins's plan was as notable for what it did not say as for what it did. Under pressure since agreeing to a 5.5 percent wage increase for teachers last month, the Mayor repeated yesterday that he would not use money directly from the city budget to grant raises of more than 1.5 percent to other unions still bargaining.
 
Harsh Criticism
 But the teachers' raise involved only 1.5 percent in previously budgeted funds, with the rest from excess pension funds and state aid to the Board of Education. That drew harsh criticism from fiscal monitors who said such money should be used to avoid service cuts or layoffs instead, but other unions have indicated that they, too, hope to use pension funds to support raises, and Mr. Dinkins has not ruled that out.
Yesterday, municipal union leaders seized on Mr. Dinkins's relatively moderate cuts to say that the administration's warnings of as many as 35,000 layoffs over the next two years had been vastly overstated.
"Clearly, the Mayor has come to our point of view," said Barry Feinstein, president of the 12,000-member Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. "We must deal with '92, but first you better take care of the contract for this year."
Mr. Proctor of the control board, while repeating his preference that any pension surpluses be used to close budget gaps, said the board recognized the city's prerogative to apply such money toward a labor settlement.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: Eye on Voters, Bush Resurrects Anti-Tax Pledge

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8

 BODY:
In a new twist to his political gyrations over taxes, President Bush promised today that he would never again break the no-new-taxes promise that he broke last summer in the Federal budget fight.
Beginning what he called the "remedial work" to reclaim his position in a divided Republican Party and heal his campaign wounds, Mr. Bush said he had "serious regrets" about "being forced" to abandon his central campaign promise to block any attempt to raise taxes. 
 In the first of two news conferences that highlighted a day of unusual Presidential visibility, he vowed that he would "absolutely" refuse to accept any increase in Federal income tax rates beyond those that he endorsed in the recent budget compromise.
 
A 2d Major Response to Vote
 Mr. Bush's latest vow on taxes, which was foreshadowed in a campaign appearance in Hawaii soon after the budget compromise was reached, was the second major political reaction to Tuesday's election results. Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey said on Wednesday that the narrow victory of his fellow Democrat, Senator Bill Bradley, had prompted him to reassess his state program raising taxes.
Mr. Bush said he had never dropped his personal opposition to tax increases, and he accused the Democrats of plotting more of them when the newly elected 102d Congress begins its work in January. "They're going to do it over my dead veto, or live veto, or something like that, because it ain't going to happen, I'll guarantee you," he said.
Mr. Bush's vehement assurances that he would fight any income tax increases carried some of the air of political uncertainty that led to his decision to give his blessing to a tax increase as part of the budget compromise this year.
"Can I make the promise I won't support them?" Mr. Bush said. "Absolutely. You know, sometimes you run into some realities. But I'm girding up my loins to go into battle to beat back the tax attempts that I think are coming. Because I think the American people are fed up with it."
 
G.O.P. Sighs of Relief
 Mr. Bush said his compromise on taxes was not to blame for Republican losses on Tuesday, which he said were not as bad as the governing party usually suffers in a midterm vote.
But he acknowledged that the issue proved to be damaging for some incumbent governors who had first promised not to raise taxes and then did so, and some Administration officials said Mr. Bush's efforts to reclaim the Republican anti-tax platform were inspired to some degree by those election results.
The President's remarks prompted sighs of relief from party strategists who had been urging Mr. Bush to resume the no-taxes campaign much earlier. "Praise the Lord," said one senior Republican strategist.
Another top Republican, Thomas H. Kean, the former Governor of New Jersey, said: "There's a strong economic and political argument that this was the last time you should raise taxes. And where the Republicans should be placed is just in that position, as people who are really against taxes unless they are the only possibility to avert fiscal catastrophe."
Mr. Bush and his aides sought to play down Republican election losses on Tuesday, but the President seemed eager to capture some political momentum while Congress was not in session and to rebound from the weeks in which the White House was left reeling by Democratic attacks and Republican rebellions.
Before the election, when Mr. Bush was under intense assault over the budget, he refused to answer questions from reporters when he announced the resignation of Labor Secretary Elizabeth H. Dole, the first Cabinet official to quit his Administration.
 
New Bias Bill Promised
 Today, announcing the resignation of William Bennett as director of anti-drug programs, Mr. Bush lingered for more than half an hour to answer questions about politics, taxes and his relationship with Congress.
The President sought to recover from his veto of the 1990 civil rights bill by promising to send a new jobs discrimination measure to Congress next year.
He promised to renew his campaign for a reduction in the capital gains tax. And after weeks of enduring Republican criticism that he was too reluctant to attack the Democrats and too quick to abandon his pledge of "no new taxes," Mr. Bush tried to make up ground on both issues.
Asked if he would continue to strive for bipartisan cooperation with Congress, Mr. Bush complained about Democrats who "went out and tried to bash the President" in the campaign. Mr. Bush, who has exercised his veto 16 times in less than two years, warned that he was "more determined than ever" to use that power against Congressional Democrats.
"I was elected to take this country in a certain direction and the liberals in the Congress want to take it in another direction," he said.
 
Some See 'Chilling' Lessons
 White House aides argued that Tuesday's voting results posed no threat to Mr. Bush. But some Republicans inside and outside the Administration worried that the President's lieutenants might be underestimating his political vulnerability, particularly if the economy takes a further downturn.
"The lesson for the Bush Administration is a little more worrisome than conventional wisdom would have it," said a White House adviser. "The fate of governors who lost after first promising not to raise taxes and then doing so is chilling."
Mr. Bush said he planned to meet with his economic advisers to discuss ways to counter what he called "a slowdown in this economy."
"I want to be sure that to the degree a President can do something to soften the blow or to stimulate economic growth that he tries to do it," the President said.
A White House official said Mr. Bush would meet at Camp David on Friday with Vice President Dan Quayle; Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady; Richard G. Darman, the budget director; John H. Sununu, the chief of staff, and Michael J. Boskin, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers.
With the Congressional elections over, the political focus now turns to the President's own future, an issue about which Mr. Bush was reminded today when Mr. Bennett, the outgoing director of drug policy, breached political etiquette and talked about Mr. Bush's re-election prospects in the morning news conference.
As Mr. Bush stood at his side, clearly uncomfortable, Mr. Bennett said: "It's my belief, Mr. President, you will conclude this term very successfully. You will be re-elected as President of the United States in 1992. And in 1996 you will be thanked by your countrymen for a profound and great service."
Mr. Bush himself refused to say whether he would seek re-election in 1992, although few in Washington doubt that he will run.
A few minutes later, Mr. Bush was asked for his reaction to the re-election margins of two Democrats who are being mentioned as possible 1992 Presidential challengers, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, who won by less than expected, and Senator Bradley in New Jersey, who narrowly won. Mr. Bush said nothing; he just stood at the podium, grinning broadly.

HEADLINE: Diner's Journal

BYLINE: By Molly O'Neill

 BODY:

Economic Stratagems
In the scramble to maintain their footing in a shrinking market, dozens of Manhattan restaurants are expanding their serving hours, opening second and cheaper restaurants or "down-menuing" with specially priced lunches and dinners.
The prix fixe seven-course dinner at Restaurant Lafayette, for example, is $95, but a streamlined sampling, a three-course lunch for $25, is now being served. Last week, the menu included starters like fresh shrimp in a spicy carrot-juice sauce, and pork cheeks pan-fried with a black-bean salad in an arugula vinaigrette. Main courses, like the cod cakes with an orange and basil oil, and the beef tenderloin stuffed with marrow and chive oil, were toothsome examples of the imaginative and energetic cuisine of the chef Jean-George Vongerichten. (Restaurant Lafayette, 65 East 56th Street; 832-1565).
Prunelle, the sleek, burled-wood-walled dining room, recently introduced a dinner menu that includes several homier French dishes -- and a $38 price tag for a three-course meal. Old-fashioned dishes like the onion soup and the cassoulet, as well as such contemporary fare as the scallops with a blini and three caviars, and the sweetbreads sauteed with wild mushrooms and wild rice, were all winners -- and the value is hard to beat in the tony, midtown restaurant league. (Prunelle, 18 East 54th Street; 759-6410).
Downtown, Anglers and Writers, an eclectic little storefront full of mismatched antique tables and china, fishing gear and lace doilies, is the winsome cafe-cousin of the Village Atelier restaurant. The owners, Craig Bero and his mother, Charlotte, serve good salads and sandwiches, a tender omelet and sturdy soups. It's hard to spend more than $10 for lunch, tea or dinner. And between the contemplative chamber music and the scratch of pen-to-notebook at the tables, the mood at Anglers and Writers recalls old Village Bohemia, an era when this kind of price and the ease to linger was not the exception but the rule. (Anglers and Writers, 420 Hudson Street, 675-0810).
 
The Changing Scene
 CLOSED: Huberts, a torchbearer of the New American cuisine that opened 15 years ago in Brooklyn, moved to the Gramercy area, and three years ago moved to Park Avenue.
NEW CHEF: Gerard Pangaud, who has moved from Aurora, Gerard's Place and La Belle Creole in the past year, is now chef of Le Comptoir, on East 67th Street.
