HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
In a School of Pain, Learning About Joy

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT

 BODY:

Road Song
By Natalie Kusz
258 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux . $18.95
In 1969, Julius and Verna Kusz made up their minds to pack their four young children and whatever essential belongings they could fit in their green Rambler station wagon and a 12-foot trailer, and break away from it all. The 1968 recession had cost Julius his computer job in Los Angeles, but it was just as well. 
 "They had come," their oldest daughter, Natalie, writes in "Road Song," her harrowing yet inspiring memoir of their adventures, ". . . to distaste for civilization -- for its people, its small and self-absorbed borders -- and to impatience as well, a churning in their bellies to be elsewhere, in places much newer and still greatly older than this."
Life in Los Angeles, with its pinochle parties and church potlucks, seemed tame to a man who had spent his childhood on the run from Poland to the Ukraine to America escaping Nazis and the Soviet secret police, and to a woman from Vermont whose idea of living was "giving birth in the rice paddies and getting on with the job." They had a yearning for what a member of the family would call, with breathtaking understatement, "real things." And so one day they packed and headed north.
"Our first months in Alaska, that one long summertime before I was hurt, were hard," Ms. Kusz begins, ". . . but they were also very grand, full of wood fires and campgrounds, full of people and the stories they told at night when we ate all together, full of clean dust that we washed from our bodies with water carried home from cold springs."
 At first, the hardness involved rough roads, the scarcity of work, the incredible cold, and having to live in the slightly expanded trailer. Then one afternoon, the author, 7 years old by then, came home from school to find her mother not yet back from errands. She made her way to a neighbor's house that was surrounded by underfed huskies on tethers. She walked a narrow path that went through them to the front door, and had all but made it, when she decided to forgive their straining and snarling by laying her mittened hand on the head of the last dog. Her mother found her in the snow a short time later, picked her up, held her close, and prayed that the mutilated child would die.
It is a grueling story, told unflinchingly and made all the more fearsome by being repeated from several points of view. Further terrible things followed. There were years and years of reconstructive surgery -- often pointless because the author's body mysteriously rejected many of its own grafts -- until Ms. Kusz would grow sick at the very smell of ether.
There were the teasings and tauntings of other children -- a boy once punched her just to see what would happen to one of her wounds -- until Ms. Kusz learned to defend herself, then went on the offensive, becoming so skilled at fighting that she was accepted among the boys. Then she fell in love and got pregnant at the age of 16, partly to prove that she was female after all.
And there were many more sufferings, as if the accident had happened to test and twist the family. "In fact later," Ms. Kusz writes, "when each of us had pursued our own talents and found joy in them, it astonished us all to sit as an adult family reminiscing and to notice how disastrously modified we could have become -- like bonsai trees pruned at the hand of a perverse and lunatic gardener, malformed, as we all indeed were in small ways, by the inexplicable meanness of outsiders; yet, though the world had often been unkind to us, there were people in it who along the way had asked us questions which, as we found that we had so few answers, began our fruitful looking inward at each other, small periods of asking which disturbed and made us glad, for we found that between us our memory confirmed things we each had not realized were well known already by the others."
 It is absurd to speak of the family's courage; their braveness bordered on the foolhardy. It is silly to credit the Kuszes with pushing life to its limits, because that was not entirely the point, and anyway life pushed back too hard, forcing them to the caverns of death, whistling in that darkness.
Yet something about "Road Song" inspires a joy in the reader: the songs the family always sang while traveling, "the tones directed by breath and sustained until our very bones and their hollows resonated and increased with the joy of them." Or the language that grew out of their injuries and their sense of music: "And whatever small hurts they had come through before had always been used up in language, modeled into words, described and dissipated like elaborate and temporal sand sculptures built up on the tide line and abandoned."
Or the lesson they learned from their sufferings: "that a life proceeded upward as a series of eras, like layers of the forest floor, built higher and settling in and covering one another, over and over, growth and sudden decay and new growth, world without end."
Natalie Kusz survived her accident and all that happened in its wake, even the failure of her ambition to become a doctor. Finally losing interest in anatomy, she switched her college major to literature, moved with the daughter, from that childhood pregnancy, to St. Paul, where she now teaches writing in a small college.
She stays in close touch with her family. "Remember, Tochka," her father tells her in the epilogue of her memoir, "after all the long work, we have what we need. We never were called to build kingdoms." She concludes: "My father means, and the rest of us concur, that hopes are white stones shining up from the bottoms of pools, and every clear day we reach in up to the shoulder, selecting a few and rearranging the others, drawing our arms smoothly back into air, leaving no scar on the water."

HEADLINE: N.F.L. Matchups: Week 10;
Wild-Card Race Gives Redskins And Eagles Plenty of Motivation

BYLINE: By THOMAS GEORGE

 BODY:
The Washington Redskins' rematch against the Eagles on Monday night at Veterans Stadium in Philadelphia probably won't affect the National Conference East title chase. The Redskins (5-3) have lost twice to the 8-0 Giants, and although Philadelphia (4-4) has a Nov. 25 home game with New York, it has already dropped a game to the Giants.
The Redskins and the Eagles concede that if the Giants lose half of their remaining eight games -- and if either Washington or Philadelphia wins its final eight and thus the division -- it would qualify as a miracle. 
 Three National Conference wild-card spots are up for grabs, however, and the Redskins and the Eagles figure prominently in that race. The game Monday will offer the same hard-nosed, big-play football that has always characterized the teams' meetings, but with a twist: at quarterback for Washington, Jeff Rutledge, who at age 33 is in his 11th season, will make his 12th National Football League start and his first since 1987. And the Rutledge-Randall Cunningham face-off at quarterback should change the game's complexion.
In the teams' first meeting of 1990, three weeks ago, Washington won, 13-7, in a defensive-minded tussle where the Redskins asked the quarterback, Stan Humphries, to keep things simple and protect the football.
Since losing Mark Rypien to a knee injury early in the season, the Washington head coach, Joe Gibbs, has wavered in his confidence in Humphries's ability to throw downfield accurately. Last Sunday, with Washington facing a 21-point deficit against Detroit, Gibbs tossed his inhibitions and Humphries aside. Rutledge entered the game in the second half and threw for 363 yards and a touchdown on a variety of intermediate and deep passes, and the Redskins ended up winning, 41-38, in overtime.
With the Eagles' offense fresh from a 48-point outing against New England, a game in which Cunningham accounted for five touchdowns, expect more points to be scored in this Redskin-Eagle game. Cunningham was sacked five times by Washington in the first game, but Philadelphia did not sack Humphries, and did not manage a turnover (the only time that has happened in Buddy Ryan's five-year reign with the Eagles). Rutledge, though mobile, is not as elusive as Humphries.
In Rutledge, Gibbs knows what he loses -- and what he gains. "He gets the ball very quick," Gibbs said. "He makes great decisions. He's got great timing and a feel for when to get it in there. And he has football awareness that makes him the kind of quarterback that can get things done. He's also extremely mentally tough. I don't think you'll intimidate him, which is the No. 1 quality I'd like to have in a quarterback."
 
LOCAL TEAMS

 
Giants (8-0) at Los Angeles Rams (3-5)
 The last time these teams saw each other, Flipper Anderson was racing with a football through the end zone, through a tunnel and into the locker room after his game-clinching 30-yard catch in the Rams' 19-13 overtime playoff victory last January in Giants Stadium. On Sunday, the scene is Anaheim Stadium, and the teams' fortunes have reversed.
In the Rams' losses, their defense has allowed 36 points to Green Bay, 27 to Philadelphia, 34 to Cincinnati, 38 to Chicago and 41 to Pittsburgh. With a balanced attack, the Giants hope to exploit the Rams, too.
 
Miami (7-1) at Jets (4-5)
 Giants Stadium was the site of Miami's only loss this season, but that was to the Giants.
Miami has allowed 17 or fewer points in five straight games. The Jets know they can play with the Dolphins, having led, 13-0, at halftime before losing, 20-13, in Miami on Oct. 7. Mark Duper was the hero, scoring on a 13-yard catch with 1 minute 3 seconds left.
This time, the wide receivers Al Toon (31 receptions, 14.5 yards a catch, 4 touchdowns) and Rob Moore (25 receptions, 16.7 yards a catch, 2 touchdowns) and the Jets' defense hope to shine. The last time Miami swept the Jets, in 1984, it went to the Super Bowl.
 
NATIONAL CONFERENCE

 
Atlanta (3-5) at Chicago (7-1)
 "We're where we want to be except for the record; we had hoped we would could accomplish just what we have and still be on the winning side," Jerry Glanville, the Falcons' head coach, said this week.
The Bears' head coach, Mike Ditka, does not believe his team or any other at present ranks with the Giants and the 49ers, "but at the end, maybe we'll be there," he said.
The running back Neal Anderson is everything to the Bears' offense, but Atlanta's No. 1 priority with an eight-man front is to shut him down. This matchup will reveal where the Bears' passing game stands.
 
Minnesota (2-6) at Detroit (3-5)
 Wayne Fontes, the Lions' head coach, is taking heat for staying with the shoot part of his run-and-shoot offense in the second half against Washington with Detroit leading by 21 points. Dropped passes and misfired ones saved time on the clock and helped the Redskins' comeback.
Rodney Peete, with an injured hamstring, is out at quarterback for the Lions. Bob Gagliano is ready, but this would be a good spot for Andre Ware's first start.
 
Tampa Bay (4-5) at New Orleans (3-5)
 Tampa Bay started fast, but is fading much as it did last season, when it began 3-2 and dropped nine of its last 11 games. The Buccaneers will try Chris Chandler at quarterback in place of Vinny Testaverde. New Orleans is a dangerous club when it holds on to the ball. The Saints often don't, however; they rank last in the league in takeaway-giveway differential at minus-14.
 
San Francisco (8-0) at Dallas (3-6)
 "Our players know that sometimes strange things happen," said Jimmy Johnson, the Dallas head coach. "Granted, it would be a strange thing if we beat the 49ers."
It would be especially strange because on Sunday night, Joe Montana will be passing against a secondary that had only one interception in its first six games. San Francisco beat Dallas last season with Steve Young at quarterback and won all five of the teams' meetings in the 1980's. But Dallas still leads the series, 9-8-1.
 
AMERICAN CONFERENCE

 
Seattle (3-5) at Kansas City (5-3)
 The Seahawks beat the Chiefs, 19-7, three weeks ago in the Kingdome, but they haven't won in Arrowhead Stadium in 10 years and have swept their divisional rival only once since, in 1978. Dave Kreig, the Seattle quarterback, had four passes intercepted in the first 1990 meeting, but the Seattle defense made three sacks, recovered three fumbles and limited the Chiefs to 69 yards rushing. But having toppled the Raiders last Sunday, the Chiefs are a stronger and more confident team now.
 
Denver (3-5) at San Diego (4-5)
 The toe and arch injuries on John Elway's left foot will slow him but not prevent him from starting at quarterback against San Diego, a team that hounded him last season as Denver produced only 16 points in both a victory and a loss to the Chargers. San Diego plays five of its last six games against divisional opponents, with Kansas City and Seattle up next.
 
Indianapolis (2-6) at New England (1-7)
 Can New England beat anyone? Of course it can. The Patriots' victory this season was against the Colts, in the second week, 16-14. The Patriots have beaten the Colts in 11 of their last 13 meetings. A Colt loss here and Ron Meyer could follow Bud Carson into unemployment.
 
INTERCONFERENCE

 
Green Bay (3-5) at Los Angeles Raiders (6-2)
 "This is a minor setback, nothing major at all," Jay Schroeder, the Los Angeles quarterback, said after the Raiders were beaten last Sunday by the bitter cold and the stingy Kansas City defense. The Raiders believe the bye week before the Chiefs game hurt their momentum. They look to rebuild it against a team they have dominated since losing Super Bowl II to the Packers in 1968.
 
Phoenix (2-6) at Buffalo (7-1)
 This game is a mismatch in every way. Buffalo has outrushed its opponents by 50 yards and Phoenix has been outrushed by 157 yards; Buffalo has allowed only 14 sacks, Phoenix 23. Bruce Smith and the Bills' defense present myriad problems for Phoenix, but tackling Thurman Thomas and Andre Reed will likely prove to be the Cardinals' biggest problem.
(The teams in the American Conference Central Division -- Pittsburgh, Houston, Cincinnati and Cleveland -- have byes this weekend.)

SECTION: Section A; Page 34; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 541 words

HEADLINE: The Halfway President

 BODY:
George Bush's Presidency approaches the two-year mark in disrepair. If Mr. Bush is interested in finding out why, he would do well to look not at Tuesday's election returns but at his own conduct before and during the midterm campaign. His problems, not entirely of his own making, include a faltering economy, the threat of war in the Persian Gulf and a restless Republican Party. But the greater difficulty is that he seems to have no governing style or strategy that could help him regain the initiative.
By themselves, the election results inflicted only marginal damage. Much has been made of Mr. Bush's failure to carry Republican gubernatorial candidates to victory in Florida and Texas; but these were idiosyncratic races, and in any case the Republicans captured statehouses in California and several key Midwestern states, including Ohio and Michigan. In effect, the G.O.P. traded the Sun Belt for the Rust Belt. 
 Mr. Bush's weak hand in the Senate and House is now weaker still; the Democrats picked up one Senate seat and eight House seats. But the history of midterm races says the losses could well have been greater. Moreover, no strong Presidential contender emerged in the balloting, and two formidable Democrats, Mario Cuomo and Bill Bradley, displayed unexpected weaknesses.
In short, nothing happened Tuesday to prevent Mr. Bush from offering intelligent, forceful leadership in the next two years, or from articulating goals and convictions and mustering a principled defense of what he wants to achieve. But that will require a very different George Bush from the one who's been floundering around the country for the past six weeks.
Mr. Bush's biggest mistake during the Great Budget Battle, for example, was not his decision to drop his "no new taxes" pledge, as Representative Newt Gingrich and other aggrieved Republicans contend. The fundamental error was his failure to make a persuasive case about why deficit reduction was more important than keeping his pledge on taxes. He then compounded that failure by flipping and flopping on capital gains and higher income tax rates. In the resulting confusion, he ceded the political and legislative initiative to the Democrats.
Mr. Bush's characteristic insouciance did little to dispel the confusion. When exasperated reporters asked him to explain his position on taxes, he replied, as he jogged along, "Read my hips." That stood as the silliest comment of the campaign until Mr. Bush topped himself a few days later with the assertion that Saddam Hussein was worse than Hitler.
This sort of hey-what's-wrong-with-a-little-confusion attitude stopped being endearing a long time ago, but Mr. Bush remains partial to it. Only yesterday, at a news conference, he gave a less than ringing endorsement to the budget agreement and pledged -- again! -- "no new taxes."
The news conference displayed a man who looked to Tuesday's election returns to tell him what he ought to be next week. What he ought to be is the President. The more complex his problems become, especially in the gulf, the more he will be required to state his aims clearly -- and engage himself, as he has so far refused to do, in the ardent persuasion that democratic politics demands.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Black History Is Central to American History

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You cast skeptical eyes on Afro centrists, who are "bringing tales of African kings and little-known black inventors, scientists and artists into the classroom" ("Inspirational Black History Draws Academic Fire," front page, Oct. 10). Traditional history has long relegated blacks, among others, to near invisibility, and many serious scholars are undertaking the task of restoring the balance. 
 Traditional history portrayed the peopling of America by the Spanish conquistadors, the French trappers and the arrival of Capt. John Smith and the Pilgrims, their descendants pouring through the gaps in the Appalachians and their descendants making their way in covered wagons to the other shining sea.
Bringing their British customs with them, the early colonists built a recognizable approximation of English society on these shores and founded a marchland of the European culture system on this continent.
For every white immigrant to the Western Hemisphere, four or five blacks were brought. Not until the middle of the 19th century did white immigration exceed black, making the hemisphere until that time (in the words of the economic historian David Eltis) an extension of Africa, rather than an extension of Europe. More of these blacks participated in the labor market, they worked longer hours, and what they produced was more valuable than free labor was able or willing to do.
It would be surprising if the world the immigrants founded was just like the one they left. The organization of society in England and Western Europe, based on a landed aristocracy and a free labor force, was never duplicated here. The British colonies in the North had no landed aristocracy, and without slaves there was none in the South and the Caribbean.
The simple farmers of British colonial America were hard pressed to do more than subsist and produce profitable export crops. The foreign earnings of British colonial America resulted overwhelmingly from the labor of plantation slaves. In the generation before the American Revolution, increasing numbers of slaves were dragged out of Africa, plantation crops poured out of the colonies, and with the earnings on these crops colonial merchants and planters, fishermen and farmers increasingly enjoyed imports of British goods.
The graceful Federal homes of New England merchants and the country houses of Georgian England owe a debt to the black slave, just as do the plantations and merchant houses of the Caribbean and the American South.
This is an example of the way traditional history has neglected the role of blacks in the growth of this country. We study African-American history not to assuage white guilt or to engender black pride, but to replace racist myths with a truer understanding of history.
 
BARBARA L. SOLOW
Cambridge, Mass., Oct. 23, 1990
The writer is an associate of Harvard University's W.E.B. Du Bois Institute for Afro-American Research.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: New York Needs Its Practical Nurse Programs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I am writing to comment on your report that the New York State Education Commissioner, Thomas Sobol, is closing practical nursing programs in New York City high schools because they are not "turning out enough students who could pass the state licensing examination for practical nurses" (news article, Oct. 20). 
 In my opinion, the commissioner should re-evaluate his decision one more time. These programs offer a free opportunity for a student who has the interest and caring instinct to learn about nursing and to graduate with a marketable skill. This results in a more goal-oriented high school experience -- of great need in a time of increasing dropout rates and unemployment.
It is true that licensed practical nurses may not have very expanded roles in hospitals. Yet they function very well in nursing homes and in caring for those in the home. The palliative caring skills of practical nurses can come in handy with patients whose conditions are not serious and don't require the advanced care of a registered nurse.
I am a graduate of the practical nursing program at Hillcrest High School. I passed the licensed practical nurse state boards, recently graduated with a Bachelor of Science and am a registered nurse at a leading New York City hospital. I feel this program gave me a taste of nursing at an early time, which helped me set my future goals with more certainty.
Possibly the entire program can be gone over carefully to identify the true flaws that result in only a 47 percent passing rate among graduates. In this time of hospital overcrowding and of a nursing shortage, we must strike up an interest in nursing early in life, and these programs offer an excellent opportunity to do so. The high school practical nursing programs are much too valuable to those who can really blossom in them to be closed.
 
MELISSA HAMMOND
New York, Oct. 24, 1990

HEADLINE: Shots in Red Square Are Echo of a Thriving Market in Arms

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 8

 BODY:
The daily newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda recently sent reporters out shopping for guns to dramatize the flourishing Soviet black market in arms.
After pricing weapons ranging from homemade zip guns to an imported Uzi automatic, they bought three grenade launchers to illustrate their front-page story. The newspaper said it turned down an offer of a tank at $10,000. 
 The account of the spread of weapons, published Tuesday, seemed prescient a day later when a man fired a sawed-off shotgun during the Revolution Day parade on Red Square, within earshot of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
The K.G.B. announced today that criminal proceedings had been instituted against the gunman, who was identified as Aleksandr Shmonov, 38 years old, an unemployed fitter from Leningrad, Tass reported. An investigator said Mr. Shmonov had spoken in detail about the shooting, which the K.G.B. formally charged was a violation of the state law against the assassination of state figures.
There was no further detail offered of why this particular charge was used, or how specific Mr. Shmonov might have been in talking with K.G.B. interrogators.
 
The Biggest Puzzle
 Much about the shooting remained a mystery today, including the gunman's intended target and his state of mind, which was reported to be the subject of a psychiatric examination. But for those who have watched the growing confluence of guns and grievance in the Soviet Union, the biggest puzzle was why it had not happened sooner.
The new gun culture of the Soviet Union may be unremarkable by the standards of New York or Los Angeles, but in a society long regarded as an efficient police state the spread of weaponry in private hands has fascinated the press and alarmed the public as one more symptom of a system in breakdown.
"We never imagined that in principle anyone wanting a gun and having good money can quickly arm himself with the weapon of his choice," said the report in Komsomolskaya Pravda, the latest in a yearlong series of press reports about where guns come from, where they go, and what to do about them.
In the gun trade, the Soviet press has discovered one aspect of Soviet life where the market, unfortunately, works. Outside the law, the one law that is well observed is the law of supply and demand, and the liberation of the Gorbachev years has generated both.
The police attribute the growing demand for guns in part to the criminal rackets that thrive in the interstices between the dying state-run economy and the fledgling private enterprise legalized by Mr. Gorbachev's economic changes.
Favorite rackets include trafficking in stolen state property, extorting protection money from successful new entrepreneurs and profiteering in scarce goods, plus such conventional criminal enterprises as drugs and prostitution. As their businesses have become more lucrative and competitive, the racketeers have armed themselves to protect their turf, creating a spinoff trade in the tools of violence.
 
Less Fear of the Police
 With even entry-level thugs increasingly carrying firearms, the fear of crime has grown faster than crime itself. The anxiety is stimulated by frank and sometimes sensationalist crime reporting in the liberated press.
"Where can I buy a little pistol?" a woman inquired in a phone call to Komsomolskaya Pravda, the day after three thugs robbed her in broad daylight by the monument in Sverdlovsk Square.
Another factor has been the unleashing of ethnic rivalries, especially in southern republics. In Georgia and the combat zone along the border between Armenia and Azerbaijan, it is de rigueur for a nationalist politicians to have a group of gun-toting bodyguards at his side.
The rising fear of crime and ethnic hatred has been matched by a declining fear of the Government's deterrent powers. The police state depended not only on a large, ruthless and well-equipped police force, but also on the terrified compliance of the citizenry. That fear has largely dissipated, and nothing else -- respect for the rule of a gentler law, for example -- has yet replaced it.
A man might have to be crazy to brandish a shotgun on Red Square -- as Vladimir A. Kryuchkov, the K.G.B. chief, suggested Wednesday night after the gunman was arrested -- but not as crazy as before.
There are many sources to satisfy the demand for firearms, and they have expanded with the times. Soviet press estimates of the number of weapons in private hands range from 50,000 to 500,000.
 
Where the Guns Come From
 Many weapons were already in the hands of hunters and veterans returned from the bazaars of Afghanistan. Soviet newspapers say another common option is to buy or steal guns from police, military and security guards.
In regions of ethnic strife, looting of police and military arsenals has become rampant, sometimes reportedly with the complicity of sympathizers on the inside. Still more weapons have been misappropriated from weapons plants or from factories responsible for melting down old armaments.
"Then we must remember the so-called search groups that proclaim their good intention of locating and reburying the remains of soldiers killed during World War II," Komsomolskaya Pravda said. "In fact they are looking for, and finding, well-preserved weapons and ammunition of the war era."
The Soviet authorities say that liberalization of foreign travel has also opened up channels for the import of arms.
Komsomolskaya Pravda suggested that the Government exercise the only clout that counts in marketplace.
"We see only one way out: buying the weapons from the population," the newspaper said, proposing establishment of a state emergency fund to purchase weapons anonymously.
"Money," said the newspaper, "still has more power than the Interior Ministry and the K.G.B."

HEADLINE: Eastern Europe: An Update

 BODY:
BULGARIA
Nov. 10, 1989: Todor Zhivkov, long-time party leader, is replaced by Petar T. Mladenov, who also becomes head of state on Nov. 17.
 
Jan. 16, 1990: start of round-table talks between the Government and the opposition.
 
Feb. 6, 1990: the opposition party U.D.K. rejects participation in the Government.
 
PUB-DATE: June 10, 1990:
 
PUB-DATE: July 6, 1990:
 
Aug. 1, 1990: Parliament names Zhelyu Zhelev, leader of the opposition Union of Democratic Forces, the country's first non-Communist President in four decades.
 
Looking Ahead
 
The Government rationed fuel in mid-October. Basic foods like cheese, sugar and oil are obtainable only with special tickets. The United States said in September it would supply 100,000 tons of corn until the end of the year.
 The Government says that items like socks, rain coats, matches and heating fuel will not be obtainable in winter, and it has announced that it will scrap subsidies on food. Some estimates say that 60 percent of trade is carried out on the black market.
 The outlook is especially bleak because Bulgaria has hardly any hard currency left and there are no conmpetetive industrial goods or raw materials that it could sell in the West.
 
CZECHOSLOVAKIA
 
November-December 1989: Democratic movement under leadership of Vaclav Havel's Civic Forum forces the hard-line Communist leadership to withdraw from power.
 
Dec. 12, 1989: Marian Calfa becomes Prime Minister of a government made up predominantly of non-Communists.
 
Dec. 28, 1989: Alexander Dubcek, leader of 1968 liberal movement, elected Speaker of the Parliament.
 
Dec. 29, 1989: Mr. Havel elected President.
 
June 8-9, 1990: first free elections in Czechoslovakia since 1946, sweep Civic Forum and its Slovak sister organization, Public Against Violence, into power.
 
Looking Ahead
 
The planned economy is to be transformed into a market system by the end of 1991. The Government does not expect economic growth next year. All prices will be freed and Government subsidies ended as of 1991.
 Czechoslovakia wants to become a member of the European Community and the European Commission will submit a draft association agreement with Czechoslovakia, Poland and Hungary to its member governments by the end of this year.
The Government has said Czechoslovakia will lose about $2 billion because of the Persian Gulf crisis.
 
HUNGARY
 
Sept. 19, 1989: the ruling Communists and the opposition agree on constitutional changes, the creation of a multiparty system and free elections for 1990.
 
Oct. 8, 1989: the Communist Party is divided in a liberal wing and an orthodox wing, which form the Socialist Party (liberals) and the re-founded Hungarian Socialist Workers' Party (orthodox).
 
March 25-April 8, 1990: elections and run-off elections for parliament, in which the opposition United Democratic Front won.
 
PUB-DATE: May 24, 1990:
 
Sept. 28, 1990: Hungary and the Soviet Union agree on withdrawal of Soviet troops.
 
Looking Ahead
 
Unemployment may rise to 250,000 or 5 percent of the work force in the next three years, according to some estimates. The inflation rate may reach 35 percent in 1991, according to Government projections. The Government also says exports to other nations of the former Soviet bloc will drop by about 30 percent next year, and general exports may decrease by 5 percent.
 The Government expects the Gross National Product to decrease by 5 percent next year.

Jan. 1, 1990: economic reforms lead to drastic price increases.

Government and World Bank projections say that unemployoment could rise to 1.5 million, about 10 percent of the work force by the end of the year.
 Polish officials have said the country is likely to loose about $2 billion because of the gulf crisis.
 Lech Walesa will run agains Mr. Mazowiecki for President in elections set for Nov. 25.
 
ROMANIA
 
Dec. 17, 1989: Army opens fire on demonstrators in Timisoara and Arad. Protests soon spread to other cities.
 
Dec. 22: Nicolae Ceausescu, party leader and head of state, resigns and flees. The Front for National Salvation takes power.
 
Dec. 25, 1989: Mr. Ceausescu and his wife Helena are executed by order of a military tribunal.
 
Dec. 26, 1989: Ion Iliescu, a former member of the Communist Central Committee, becomes President.
 
PUB-DATE: May 20, 1990:
 
PUB-DATE: June 13, 1990:
 
Looking Ahead
 
There is widespread fear that the coming winter will bring severe hardship. Fuel is already scarce. On Oct. 3, a Government spokesman announced an austerity program for industry, which is using 84 percent of the domestic energy output, so that more energy can be used for heating during the winter.
Western estimates say unemployment could rise to 350,000 at the end of 1990. According to Government predictions, unemployment in Romania will rise to up to 1 million, or 9.5 percent of the work force, in 1991.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Last Word on Taxes? Don't Hold Your Breath

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8

 BODY:
The monumental Tax Reform Act of 1986, with its lower rates, fewer brackets and closed loopholes, was supposed to stay intact for many years, giving businesses, investors and ordinary families a stable tax system they could depend on to make financial plans.
But the politicians who called it the tax law to end all tax laws should have known better.
Last month, Congress used the deficit-reduction legislation to overhaul the system again. The rate on the highest incomes was raised to 31 percent, itemized deductions and personal exemptions were limited in a way that pushes that rate even higher, and the capital gains rate was capped at 28 percent, among other measures. 
 This time, no one is even pretending that the changes will be much more permanent than a soap bubble.
 The final T in the budget legislation had not even been crossed when a senior White House official summoned reporters to the Roosevelt Room to say -- not for attribution, of course -- that one of the first measures President Bush would offer next year would be to cut the capital gains rate.
That proposal will join many others on a full tax plate.
Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, predicts that the phasing out of personal exemptions and the 3 percent reduction in itemized deductions for upper-income taxpayers will prove so complicated that there will be pressure to change the new system.
The majority leaders in Congress, Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, say the 31 percent top rate is still too low. "I don't think we ought to view this as some ending of the debate," Mr. Mitchell declared just before Congress adjourned.
Republicans like Senator Steve Symms of Idaho, a member of the Finance Committee, say they may press for tax cuts next year as an economic counterweight to the recession they expect.
Liberal Democrats promise that H.R. 1, the number assigned to the first bill introduced in each Congress, will be given in January to a bill to place a stiff surtax on people who earn $1 million a year or more.
Popular business tax breaks like the credit for research and development expenses and the deduction for employee tuition were extended for only a year, and it is unthinkable that Congress will allow them to expire at the end of 1991. The same is true of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's pet amendment to give a break to wealthy collectors who give artworks to museums.
Lobbyists for the real estate industry will be out in force. Ever since 1986, the industry has griped that Congress treated it unfairly by taking away cherished tax shelters. This year, with real estate going bust in many parts of the country, the industry got more than half the members of the Ways and Means and Finance Committees to sponsor the favorable tax treatment it wants. And realtors greased the way for 1991 by giving hundreds of thousands of dollars to lawmakers' campaigns.
So there will be plenty of talk about taxes next year. But whether much will happen is another matter.
President Bush said today that his concession on taxes this year was a one-time-only slip and that he would "absolutely" oppose further new taxes. After the pounding he took over supposedly favoring tax relief for the well-to-do, the President will have to think more than twice before throwing his full weight behind a capital gains cut.
And the timing may not be right for the Democrats' push for a surtax on incomes over $1 million. Good policy or not, soaking the fat cats has so much political appeal, especially in a sour economy, that many Democratic strategists are suggesting that the debate be postponed until 1992, the Presidenial election year.
Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, says he expects tax issues "to slip off the front pages for a year."
But many other experts disagree. C. Eugene Steuerle, a senior tax policy official in the Reagan Administration who is now an economist at the Urban Institute here, compares the tax law to his daughter's room. When he makes her clean her room, Mr. Steuerle says, the mess disappears temporarily. But he is under no illusions that it will stay neat very long.

HEADLINE: Rodrigo Moynihan, 80, a Pioneer Of Abstract Painting in England

BYLINE: By JOHN RUSSELL

 BODY:
Rodrigo Moynihan, a painter and teacher and a co-editor of Art and Literature: An International Review, died Tuesday in London after a long illness. He was 80 years old.
Mr. Moynihan became known in the 1930's as a pioneer of English abstract painting. He later became an associate member of the Euston Road School in London and excelled as a painter of still lifes that were remarkable for their dignity of touch and tone. 
 He was in the British Army from 1940 to 1943 and was appointed an official war artist after being injured. His unsparing though compassionate account of army life in its gloomier aspects was lightened by a memorable portrait (done in the line of duty) of a young woman soldier.
After the war, he taught at the Royal College of Art, where he was professor of painting from 1948 to 1957. He was much in demand for portraits (notably of Princess Elizabeth, the future Queen, in 1946, and of Prime Minister Clement Attlee in 1947).
 
Large-Scale Portraits
 Mr. Moynihan also rose to the challenge of the large-scale group portrait in "Teaching Staff of the Painting School, Royal College of Art" (1947-52) and the larger "Editors of Penguin Books." As documents of postwar English life, they have a permanent value.
In 1957, when he was clearly destined for the topmost ranks of the British establishment, he decided to put his private self above his public self and resigned from both the Royal College of Art and the Royal Academy, of which he had been made a full member in 1954. He left England and lived and worked in Paris, Provence, New York and Canada.
With his second wife, the painter Anne Dunn, and with the American poet John Ashbery and Sonia Orwell, he edited the quarterly review Art and Literature from 1964 to 1968. It drew with notable discernment on contributors in England, France and the United States.
Neither in London nor in New York was there an immediate welcome for the radical abstract idioms that he explored after his break with English officialdom. But in 1971 he began to paint large-scale still lifes of whatever happened to be lying around in his studio. Neither set up nor "arranged," these were subjects, taken at random, that he endowed with a paradoxical monumentality.
 
Celebrated Sitters
 Later in the 1970's he also returned to portrait painting, and before long had a whole new reputation in that field. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, the novelist Anthony Powell, the painters Francis Bacon, William Coldstream and Lawrence Gowing and the economist F. A. Hayek were among his sitters in London.
In 1978 he had a retrospective exhibition at the Royal Academy in London, which re-elected him to membership in 1979. From 1980 his work was shown to general admiration at the Robert Miller Gallery in New York. His 80th birthday, three weeks ago, was marked by ceremonies both at the Royal Academy and at the Tate Gallery.
Rodrigo Moynihan was born in Santa Cruz de Tenerife, Canary Islands, on Oct. 17, 1910. He was the son of Herbert James Moynihan, a fruit broker, and Maria de la Puerta.
In 1918, his family moved to London and then to Madison, Wis., where he attended high school. Incipient literary ambitions were abandoned during the winter of 1927-28, which he spent in Rome. Painting came first with him thereafter, and in September 1928 he enrolled at the Slade School of Fine Art in London.
In 1931 he married Elinor Bellingham-Smith, later to become a distinguished painter of landscape. In 1960 he married Anne Dunn, who survives him, as do two sons, John and Daniel.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Rodrigo Moynihan (John Cheim/Robert Miller Gallery, 1984)

HEADLINE: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
Straw's $20 Million Burden

BYLINE: By DAVE ANDERSON

 BODY:
His father was George Sisler, a Hall of Fame first baseman for the St. Louis Browns who twice batted over .400. Dick Sisler was a first baseman whose three-run homer off Don Newcombe of the Brooklyn Dodgers on the final day of the 1950 season won the National League pennant for the Philadelphia Phillies. In that economy, his highest salary was $18,000.
"It doesn't bother me when I see the players making the big money today; more power to 'em," Sisler said after his recent retirement as a minor league hitting instructor for the St. Louis Cardinals. "But now it's like, 'Who can make the most money?' That's the motivator." 
 In all the debate on today's sports millionaires, nobody has summed it up better. In other eras, sluggers talked about trying to hit the most home runs, trying to drive in the most runs, trying to win the batting title. Pitchers talked about trying to win 20 games or trying to have the lowest earned run average.
But for too many baseball players now, and for too many professional athletes, it's trying to make the most money. As soon as another player attains a new million-dollar plateau, they want to renegotiate. As if the numbers on their paycheck are the only numbers that reflect their accomplishments. Or their stature.
That's why the Mets won't miss Darryl Strawberry that much. And that's why the Los Angeles Dodgers, who have invested $20.25 million in him, won't be helped that much. Straw always resented his being expected to carry the Mets; in his naivete, he has even talked about how his burden would be lighter with the Dodgers.
Maybe Straw thinks he's going home to play for Crenshaw High School, as he did as a teen-ager. Maybe he thinks the Dodger fans aren't going to expect $20 million worth of home runs.
Whatever Straw thinks, he will discover that his burden will be even heavier in Dodger Stadium. His new manager, Tommy Lasorda, is already hyping him as a slugger "that can literally carry a ball club." Please erase that tape before Straw hears it. Or before he strikes out and the fans dare to boo him.
"If you get the money," Reggie Jackson has said of Jose Canseco's $23 million contract, "you can't say, 'I don't want the pressure.' "
Not that Darryl Strawberry didn't deserve big money. But money seemed to be the only straw that stirred him. When the Mets offered only a three-year, $9.1 million contact, he pouted. When the Mets' general manager, Frank Cashen, proclaimed that Straw was not worth $5 million a season, he felt "insulted." He wanted "Canseco money."
In the end, the Dodgers didn't consider him a $5 million man either. His deal averages $4 million a season.
Not bad for having carried the Mets for only one-fourth of their season: in 39 games from May 26 to July 13, Straw batted .383 with 18 homers and 42 runs batted in as the Mets ascended briefly into first place before settling into second place.
"I like what I see here," he said during that hot streak, glancing around the Mets' clubhouse. "And I want to be part of it."
But as soon as the Mets broke off negotiations on July 13, apparently he didn't like what he saw and he didn't want to be part of it anymore. His average, which coincidentally had soared to .308 that same day, started dropping to .277, with 37 homers and 108 runs batted in.
Anyone who blames the Mets' front office for not signing him in July should also consider blaming him for cruising after the negotiations broke off. If he had carried the Mets to the National League East title, their front office might have paid him more than the Dodgers did.
Like too many athletes today, Straw was more concerned with his contract than with carrying his team.
It's easy to cherish Straw's hot streak shortly after Bud Harrelson succeeded Davey Johnson as manager. But in his other 113 games before and after that streak, he batted a mortal .239 with 19 homers and 66 runs batted in. He hit some important September homers but for the final week he was in the clubhouse with a bad back.
Another thought: will he miss Dr. Alan Lans, the Mets' counselor who suggested his four-week stay at the Smithers Institute for alcohol-abuse early this year?
 As for the Mets, yes, they need a slugger now. Tom Brunansky, George Bell and Rob Deer are free agents. So is Kirk Gibson, although he'll be 34 in May and he's damaged goods.
No matter how the batting order is retooled, the Mets might be no worse and maybe better. The other hitters won't be waiting for Straw to carry them when he resented the responsibility of being expected to carry them.
And now that Darryl Strawberry is a $20 million man, will he able to do what he has never wanted to do: carry the burden of carrying his team?

HEADLINE: The National Ends Its Sunday Issue

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD

 BODY:
Feeling the pressures of a sagging economy, The National, the fledgling sports daily, said yesterday that it would stop publishing a Sunday issue and that it was undergoing some management changes.
The moves raised renewed questions about the long-term prospects for the newspaper, the first attempt at a nationally distributed daily that covers only sports. Since its debut on Jan. 31, The National has grown more slowly than anticipated, and despite some high-priced writing talent its editorial content has drawn a tepid response from some readers. 
 With the elimination of the Sunday paper, after publication of the Nov. 25 issue, The National will appear only on weekdays; it has never published on Saturdays. A spokesman said that Sunday circulation had been running about 225,000, significantly below the 275,000 weekday average, and that there had been distribution problems with the Sunday issue. What is more, the paper said it wished to marshal its resources to concentrate on faster expansion to other cities.
In another sign of dissatisfaction, three of the paper's seven managers were dismissed on Thursday, including the circulation director, the finance director and the assistant publisher. Replacements were not named.
In addition, an executive associated with the primary backer of The National will soon be brought in to preside over day-to-day operations, which had been the province of Peter O. Price, the president and publisher. The new executive is Jaime Davila, the group vice president of Univisa Inc., a diversified Los Angeles media concern owned by Emilio Azcarraga, a Mexican communications executive who heads the partnership that operates The National. Mr. Davila will retain his position with Univisa.
The paper said Mr. Price, a former publisher of The New York Post, would retain his titles, though his Manhattan office would be given to Mr. Davila. Mr. Price will move to the nearby advertising office.
Mr. Price declined to comment yesterday. A spokesman for the paper would not detail the reasons for the managerial changes and said other executives were not available to comment.
The spokesman said the end of the Sunday paper was not expected to lead to editorial layoffs, since the staffing would be necessary as the paper moves into new markets. Others at the paper said, however, that a small number of jobs might be eliminated. The paper employs about 200 on its editorial staff.
 
 'Probably Inevitable'
 "The Sunday closing was probably inevitable in view of the current weak advertising climate," said John Reidy, a media analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham. "This was the hardest issue to make work because you don't get people traveling around to their various endeavors, as you do during the week."
The National was initially distributed in three cities -- New York, Chicago and Los Angeles -- and has expanded to six others: San Diego, San Francisco, Dallas, Detroit, Boston and Miami. The Miami edition began publishing on Wednesday.
Next month, an edition is scheduled to begin in the Washington-Baltimore area, followed by Philadelphia in January and Atlanta in February.
 
 Gains From Daily News Strike
 But expansion has come more slowly than planned. Initially, the paper's executives hoped to be in 15 cities by the end of this year. In April, Mr. Price revised that to 12 cities with average circulation approaching 400,000. The ultimate circulation goal is one million.
Executives did note that they had captured some added circulation in the last few weeks as a result of the strike at The Daily News in New York. They insist that the paper remains viable and that Mr. Azcarraga has approved its budget for next year. He has said he is prepared to invest $100 million over five years.
The paper would not estimate how much of that amount had been consumed so far, though John Morton, an analyst with Lynch, Jones & Ryan in Washington, said, "It's probably going much faster than they thought."
Since the paper was first announced, many media analysts and editors have questioned whether enough readers and advertisers would support a national sports daily.
 
 Average of 5 Ad Pages
 Advertising pages have hardly been bountiful, though the paper's executives maintain that they have surpassed their modest early predictions. They said that The National had averaged about five pages of advertising in each issue and that they had forecast about four when the paper was started. The National generally runs 38 to 48 pages.
Editorially, The National has drawn mixed reviews. The paper said it was chiefly bought by men between 18 and 34 years old with median incomes of more than $34,000. Though the paper has been enterprising in some of its features and news articles, some readers have said it does not provide enough fresh material that cannot be found in the sports pages of general daily papers or in USA Today, a chief rival.
"The summaries and the box scores are really outstanding," said Gabe Buonauro, the sports editor of The Record in Bergen County, N.J. "As far as the editorial content, I'm not overwhelmed."
Frank Deford, a much-admired writer at Sports Illustrated before he joined The National as its editor, was traveling yesterday and could not be reached for comment.
The paper said that when the Sunday issue ended it intended to enlarge its Friday and Monday papers to more than 60 pages.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The National is stopping Sunday publication and will appear only on weekdays. Peter O. Price, left, is president and publisher of the all-sports paper, and Frank Deford is editor in chief. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Oil Declines $1.64, to $33.89; Selloff Follows Iraq Rumor

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Oil prices fell sharply near the close of trading yesterday on a rumor of an Iraqi coup.
Oil had already been moving lower, as traders decided they had bid prices too high Thursday on erroneous speculation that President Bush was about to announce steps leading to an immediate conflict in the Persian Gulf. 
 "People aren't expecting any gunfire until next year now," said Thomas P. Blakeslee, an energy analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc. in Hoboken, N.J.
The coup rumor floated in with about a half-hour left to trade, pushing the already depressed price down an additional 60 cents.
 
 One Trader's Reaction
 "That probably just fueled things a little bit," said Ed Kevelson, a trader at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.
Crude oil for December delivery settled at $33.89 a barrel, down $1.64, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Contracts for delivery in later months all closed more than $1 lower.
For the week, crude fell 11 cents a barrel for next-month delivery.
Oil opened lower yesterday as traders decided they had overestimated the impact of a news conference President Bush had given the evening before.
During Thursday's session, oil shot up as traders speculated that Mr. Bush's statement, which came after the market closed, would include either an ultimatum to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq or a vow to airlift supplies to the American Embassy in Kuwait.
Mr. Bush instead said he was substantially increasing the American military presence in the gulf, which traders had already anticipated.
"I think people were expecting some type of ultimatum, and what they received was the same old thing," Mr. Blakeslee said.
 
 Worried About Weekend
 Traders at the New York Mercantile Exchange have recently been wary about entering the weekend with speculative positions, so some of yesterday's selloff came as they sold oil contracts.
The decline in crude oil also dragged down the price of refined products traded on the exchange.
Wholesale home heating oil dropped 4.06 cents, to 90.24 cents a gallon for December delivery, while December wholesale unleaded gasoline fell 2.28 cents, to 88.23 cents a gallon. Contracts for later months were all lower for both products.
For the week, heating oil rose 2.82 cents for next-month delivery, while unleaded gasoline fell 0.98 cent.
Natural gas prices were lower or unchanged yesterday, with December delivery contracts falling six-tenths of a cent, to $2.429 for 1,000 cubic feet. For the week, next-month contracts for natural gas were up 7.1 cents.

HEADLINE: Interest-Rate Drop Pushes Dow Up 44.80

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
A strong decline in interest rates, plus the prospect of more to come, lifted the stock and bond markets sharply yesterday.
Trading was slow but the advance carried the Dow Jones industrial average ahead 44.80 points, to 2,488.61.
Heavy declines on Tuesday and Wednesday, however, toppled the Dow's performance for the week to a loss of 2.23 points. 
 Abby Joseph Cohen, market strategist for Goldman, Sachs & Company, attributed yesterday's strong showing partly to "the hope that we're closer to a resolution in the Middle East." President Bush has just ordered more than 150,000 additional American troops to the Persian Gulf.
 
 Favorable Price Report
 But Mrs. Cohen said that more important yesterday was the decline in interest rates stemming from the better-than-expected report on the Producer Price Index.
The Labor Department said the index climbed 1.1 percent last month after rising 1.6 percent in September and 1.3 percent in August. But the report showed no rise in core producer prices, excluding food and energy.
"Equity investors are doing the natural thing," she said. "Lower interest rates are good for stocks. However, I think it's a mistake because interest rates are falling due to a weak economy.
"A weak economy is good for bond prices but not for stock prices and that's because pressure on the economy means pressure on corporate profits."
Mrs. Cohen said she looked for a further market decline: "I think that while investors are focusing on the positive aspects of lower interest rates, stock prices can rise somewhat. However, I don't think it's sustainable. Corporate profits will continue to be weak and continue to come in lower than expectations."
Traders turned yesterday to all the usual suspects in explaining the market's rise. With the likelihood that war, if it indeed comes, may not come until after the holiday season, crude oil prices fell sharply, sliding $1.64 a barrel, to $33.89.
Some said that because of the admittedly sluggish economy and almost daily signs that it was weakening still more, they were looking for the Federal Reserve to take action soon and cut rates.
The most likely time, they said, could be soon after next Tuesday when the Fed's Open Market Committee discusses monetary policy. What to do about interest rates is expected to be high on its agenda.
Interest-sensitive stocks, including banks, savings and loans, and utilities, moved sharply higher yesterday along with drugs, high-tech stocks and oil and oil-service stocks.
 
 An Extensive Rise
 The rise was extensive, spreading broadly and, for a change, into the smaller issues.
Trading slowed to 145.2 million shares, from a thin 155.6 million on Thursday.
A solid 1,123 stocks, of the nearly 2,000 on the Big Board, rose and only 453 fell. While the Dow's 44.80-point gain meant more than a 1.8 percent rise, the S.&P. 500 rose 1.99 percent, or the equivalent of 49-point jump in the Dow. The Nasdaq composite index, heavily weighted with smaller high-tech stocks, climbed 1.7 percent, the equivalent of about 39 points on the Dow.
I.B.M., to which hundreds of traders look for leadership, jumped 2 3/4, to 110 1/4, its high for the day. It was the Big Board's most active stock, with 2.3 million shares changing hands.
Not far behind, Honeywell rose 2 1/2, to 89 5/8; Compaq Computer 1 3/8, to 49 1/8; Digital Equipment 1, to 49 3/8 and Motorola 1 3/8, to 55 5/8. On Nasdaq, Apple Computer topped the actives, rising 1, to 35 1/2, on 1.8 million shares.
 
 Gains for Banks
 Among the banks, BankAmerica rose 1 1/4, to 22 1/4; Wells Fargo 2 5/8, to 49 3/8; J .P. Morgan 1 1/4, to 40 1/2; Mellon Bank 1 1/4, to 21 5/8; Bankers Trust New York 1 1/8, to 35 and First Chicago 1, to 15. Golden West Financial, the savings and loan, rose 1, to 21 5/8.
In the utilities, Citizens Utilities rose 1 1/2, to 22 1/2; Hawaiian Electric 1 3/8, to 29 1/2; Central and South West 1, to 43 1/8; General Public Utilities 3/4, to 46, and Duke Power, the fourth-most-active Big Board stock, up 1/4, to 30 3/8, on nearly two million shares. Southwestern Public Service, ninth most active, rose 3/8, to 28 3/4, on 1.5 million.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drops in a Slow Day; Fears Over Economy Cited

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell broadly in slow trading yesterday, largely amid concerns over the United States economy.
Gold fell in slow domestic trading, depressed by a lack of volatile news about the Middle East standoff, analysts said. It fell $2.50 an ounce, to $384.80, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. The Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $384.40, down $2.75. 
 With New York currency markets closed Monday, in observance of Veterans Day, traders stocked up on the dollar in advance of a possible heightening of tension in the Persian Gulf during the three-day weekend.
The dollar is generally viewed as a relatively safe investment in turbulent times. In addition, traders said, possible oil shortages could hurt Japan's economy and help diminish the yen's value against the dollar. But before the day's end, currency trading in New York had slowed considerably.
Analysts said that a big influence on the dollar was an earlier Labor Department report showing that the nation's "core" inflation rate -- the Producer Price Index minus food and energy costs -- remained unchanged in October from the month before.
 
Lower Rates Expected

Investors sold on this sign of moderating inflation, seeing it as giving the Federal Reserve some room to ease interest rates to stimulate economic growth. Lower interest rates can have a chilling effect on the value of the dollar.
"You're starting to build up a fairly reasonable case for at least a quarter of a percent cut," said Robert Hatcher, a corporate dealer at Barclays Bank P.L.C.
In New York, the dollar dipped to 129.70 yen, from 130.35 yen on Thursday. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar rose by 1.00 yen, to 130.50. Later, in London, it was quoted at 129.75 yen.
In New York, he British pound rose to $1.9655, from $1.9625 on Thursday. In London, the pound was quoted at $1.9670, unchanged from late Thursday.
Against the German currency, the dollar fell to 1.4870 marks from 1.4930.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, were: 1.2499 Swiss francs, down from 1.2535; 4.9940 French francs, down from 5.0105; 1,119.00 Italian lire, down from 1,122.75, and 1.1683 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1694.
Gold prices fell in early trading in London to a late bid of $384.75 an ounce, down from $385.75 late Thursday.

HEADLINE: Jersey City Complex Owners Default on Their Mortgage

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
In an indication of the New York region's weakening real-estate market, the owners of the huge Newport development in Jersey City have defaulted on a $150 million mortgage for four apartment towers, New Jersey state officials say.
The partners in the development team include Samuel J. LeFrak and his son, Richard, whose real-estate holdings are among New York's most substantial. The complex on the Hudson River waterfront, which includes apartments, a shopping mall and offices, has been a centerpiece in efforts to redevelop the riverfront.
Many owners of rental apartment buildings, squeezed by the economic retrenchment and a dearth of young, high-salaried tenants, are finding themselves burdened by falling rents and high turnover. 
 Last July, Milstein Properties, a family-owned business that is also among the region's wealthiest and most respected developers, defaulted on a $100 million mortgage for the Normandie Court, a large rental complex on East 96th Street.
Richard LeFrak, the president of the Lefrak Organization, said that his development group had lost $12 million to $14 million on the Newport apartment complex over the last few years. The group also includes Melvin Simon & Associates of Indianapolis and the Glimcher Company of Columbus, Ohio.
Mr. LeFrak said there had been a lot of turnover and that rents were below projected levels, making it difficult to pay the mortgage. He said his group hoped to maintain ownership and to reorganize the financing for the four towers, which have 1,504 apartments altogether.
 
'Misjudged the Growth'
 "This is symptomatic of all these new projects," Mr. LeFrak said. "All of us somewhat misjudged the growth that was going to occur in the metropolitan area."
"We're in a market in which there is a tremendous amount of turnover, which is a result of the loss of jobs in the financial community," he added. "This job is directly affected by that."
The state agency holding the mortgage for Newport, the New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency, has agreed to try to negotiate refinancing with the developers and the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, which insured the mortgage. State bonds were sold in 1985 to finance the mortgage.
Federal officials are reviewing a proposal from the developers, said a H.U.D. spokesman, Bill Glavin.
New Jersey declared the owners in default last week, after they had missed a $1.1 million payment due on Oct. 1 and had failed to pay the full amount due the previous month. The default was first reported in The Bond Buyer, a trade publication.
In a statement, the state agency said the developers had not been timely in their mortgage payments since last May. It also said the developers had indicated last month that they would make no more payments.
New Jersey has not defaulted on the bonds, the agency said, and the mortgage is fully insured by the Federal Government. Mr. LeFrak said the developers' default will not affect tenants or services at Newport.
Mr. LeFrak also said the default would have no impact on the rest of his family's real-estate empire. "I don't want people to confuse this with a LeFrak corporate obligation or a LeFrak personal obligation or a project that is 100 percent LeFrak financed," he said.
The nature of Newport's corporate structure left none of the developers personally responsible to cover the apartment towers' operating losses, but they chose to do so anyway, Mr. LeFrak said.
"Faced with the current market, it's just good sense to see if some kind of a repackaging can be done," he said. "If we can come up with some restructured form of financing, we're confident that the project over time will be financially healthy."
"We've always been associated with successful things," he added, "and I'm sure we'll get this thing on track, too."

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
U.S. Envoy to U.N. on Center Stage

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 9

 BODY:
America's United Nations representative, Thomas R. Pickering, celebrated his 59th birthday on Monday by taking the president's chair at a Security Council meeting for the first time since the Persian Gulf crisis broke.
The occasion was a formality. The Council convened merely to retain United Nations military observers serving in Central America. 
 But the remainder of the United States' monthlong stint in the rotating presidency -- each of the 15 Council members holds the chair for one month at a time -- promises to be more trying, for Mr. Pickering will be struggling to preserve the Council's unified approach on Iraq's invasion of Kuwait as that unity comes under pressure from several directions.
Mr. Pickering says that United States policy toward the gulf crisis is in "a holding pattern" while Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d confers with America's allies in the gulf as well as with Soviet and Chinese leaders about the crisis. But Mr. Baker's aides say a consensus is emerging that Washington should soon seek a new Security Council resolution authorizing the use of force when they deem that sanctions have failed to free Kuwait.
 
A Constantly Active Man
 A tall, balding, constantly active figure with large gold glasses, Mr. Pickering brings to his task a bluff manner, a reputation for effectiveness, a taste for cordless telephones and what Edward C. Luck, head of the American branch of the United Nations Association, calls "a boyish enthusiasm" for the task at hand. He has a self-effacing wit and the professional diplomat's ability to listen, or at least give the impression of listening, to another's point of view.
Over the years, Mr. Pickering has also won a reputation for being tough-minded in a number of difficult posts. In El Salvador in the early 1980's, probably his most difficult assignment, he was given the task of cutting down the power of the right-wing death squads and found himself marked for assassination. When he was named by President Bush to the United Nations assignment, after a grueling few years as Ambassador to Israel, Mr. Pickering had no way of knowing in 1989 that he would be thrust 18 months later into the forefront of American policy making.
Since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, he has shepherded the Council through a total of 10 resolutions condemning Iraq's takeover and imposing economic sanctions on Baghdad by comfortable margins with never less than 13 of its 15 members in favor.
More important than his work in the Council has been his voice in policy-making circles, where he has repeatedly called for long-range planning on the Persian Gulf going beyond today's tactics, and his advocacy of going step-by-step through the Council even when some others in Washington argued for unilateral American actions.
 
Relies on Personal Contact
 The two odd members out, Yemen, one of the Arab League countries that refused to condemn the invasion, and Cuba, "present problems but not unmanageable ones," Mr. Pickering said. They have abstained on three resolutions, and voted jointly against one, while Cuba opposed another.
To preserve this coalition, Mr. Pickering says he relies heavily on "a lot of personal contact," particularly with the representatives of the nonaligned countries who are often given "loose instructions by their capitals which allow them flexibility."
But also important is what he calls "the reinforcing alliances" he seeks to create within the Council's membership. First, agreement must be forged with Britain, France, the Soviet Union and China, the other permanent members with veto powers. Then he seeks to draw in the other northern members, Canada, Romania and neutral Finland.
Once this bloc is formed the three African members espousing nonalignment, Zaire, Ivory Coast and Ethiopia, face strong pressure to agree as well, as do Malaysia and Colombia, who have voted with the permanent five all the time so far.
 
Strains Starting to Emerge
 But this month, with sanctions largely in place, strains in the alliance are starting to emerge.
On Wednesday, the Security Council started debating the recent violence in the Israeli occupied territories, with many members saying it cannot punish Iraq for annexing Kuwait while turning a blind eye to Israel's annexation of Arab lands.
The United States can always use its veto to protect Israel. But Mr. Pickering also knows that his freedom to use that veto is restricted by the need to preserve the American-led Arab coalition against Iraq for as long as the Gulf crisis lasts.
Meanwhile, four of the Security Council's seven nonaligned members -- Malaysia, Colombia, Yemen and Cuba -- have introduced a new peace plan of their own, apparently trying to foreclose any move toward war now that economic sanctions are in place.
 
Calls Tensions Inevitable
 Finally, Iraq is seeking to divide the coalition ranged against it by asking the United Nations General Assembly to declare the foreign military build up in the gulf "a threat to Arab and international peace and security."
Mr. Pickering sees such tensions as inevitable and concludes that the majority in the Council "requires constant attention."
To that task he brings the professionalism of a Foreign Service officer who is only the second career diplomat selected straight from the Foreign Service to be entrusted with a post most Presidents have reserved for political appointees. The other was Charles W. Yost, who served from January 1969 to March 1971.
The choice of a career diplomat, many here thought, reflected the new President's personal interest in the organization, which stemmed from his own experience as the United States representative from 1971 to 1973.
 
Relationship With Baker
 But when President Bush gave Mr. Pickering the job 18 months ago, the new envoy was not given the Cabinet seat many of his predecessors enjoyed, thus reducing his personal prestige and influence in Washington, though other diplomats say he has partly compensated for this through competence and an easy relationship with Mr. Baker.
Indeed, many see the fact that he is not seeking to advance a political career as a positive advantage that allows the United States Mission to run at a smoother pace than was sometimes the case in the past.
A graduate of Bowdoin College in Brunswick, Maine, the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University and Melbourne University in Australia, Mr. Pickering has long been recognized as an exceptionally able diplomat destined for the top.
Before coming to the United Nations he had already showed himself to be an effective diplomat in a number of sensitive posts around the world. He was Ambassador to Jordan from 1974 to 1978 and then Ambassador to Nigeria before going to El Salvador and Israel.
 
Holds a 'Premoniton'
 Mr. Pickering says he has never asked why President Bush chose him, although he admits to having a "premonition" that his Central American and Middle Eastern experience would become useful, "which has been amply justified."
A serious-minded person who colleagues sometimes find humourless, Mr. Pickering is married with a son and daughter and gives archeology as his hobby. The United Nations, of course, denies him the chance to go "visiting sites and collecting shards and things." But even if it didn't, the Security Council would, with its frantic schedule since the gulf crisis began.
He acknowledges the strain this puts on everyone "especially spouses who don't know what's going to be canceled." But so far he hasn't missed one of his own dinner parties in the apartment on top of the Waldorf Towers that serves as his residence.

HEADLINE: Brazil Under Pressure to Ease Stance on Debt

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Brazil, the developing world's biggest debtor, is under increasing pressure from commercial bankers and American and other officials to take a less adamant stand in crucial debt talks. They are pressing Brazil to begin paying some back interest.
Bankers on the negotiating committee, which quickly rejected Brazil's first debt-reduction proposal last month, have made a counterproposal that would require that roughly a third of the $8 billion in unpaid interest be paid by the end of the year. The rest would be converted to long-term loans and added to the existing debt. 
 And bankers do not want to begin negotiating a cut in the country's $60 billion in debt to them until the arrears issue is resolved. Incuding governmental and bank loans, Brazil's overall debt is about $113 billion.
 
 Discussions on Aid
 In addition, a banker said yesterday that there were discussions in Washington about delaying or stopping some payments to Brazil from the World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank if the country continued to stall on interest payments. Brazil has refused to make any payments this year and has limited interest payments next year to no more than $1 billion.
The negotiations have also been complicated by another issue: the Brazilians' refusal to pay the expenses of bankers for travel to the talks, lawyers' fees and some food.
Some bankers seem less confident now that the Brazilian Government, facing new problems with its economic program, is ready to make the compromises needed to reach an agreement on reducing the country's debt.
This is a reversal for many who had applauded the economic program that President Fernando Collor de Mello began this year and those who thought last spring and summer that the debt talks could move ahead.
"Inflation is going through the roof again," said one banker involved in the talks. "It was close to 15 percent last month and could be close to 18 percent to 20 percent this month. That could blow the economic program through the roof."
These renewed economic problems -- and the apparent political need at home for the Collor Government to look tough in these debt negotiations -- is leading some bankers to conclude that the Government will not negotiate seriously.
The Bush Administration has been putting pressure on Brazil to make a better effort to begin paying some of the unpaid interest. Officials of the United States Treasury, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund have indicated that they will delay final approval of Brazil's $2 billion standby loan until some action is taken. Initial approval came this summer.
 
 More Talks on Tuesday
 Brazil's negotiators are scheduled to meet again with the bank advisory committee on Tuesday and William R. Rhodes, senior executive-international at Citibank, said he expected a reply then. Citibank, a Citicorp unit, leads the negotiating panel.
Except for Argentina, Brazil's is the last major debt-reduction negotiation under the Bush Administration's debt policy, which was announced in March 1989 and named for Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. Its aim was the voluntary reduction of the developing world's debt burden, which totaled $1.3 trillion.
But while the outlook for Brazil may be deteriorating, some bankers see improvements in Argentina, where recent statistics show that inflation may be finally coming down. In addition, on Thursday, the Government finally signed the papers that split the country's telephone company into two privately held companies, the first big privatization project completed under the Government's economic plan.
Bankers will meet with the president of Argentina's cental bank on Wednesday to begin a general discussion about debt talks. And some bankers, who had not been optimistic about the success of Argentina's economic program or debt negotiations, are now less worried.
