HEADLINE: Producer Prices Post 1.1% Jump

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Prices at the producer level, a prominent inflation gauge, jumped more than expected in October as oil prices continued to escalate, but economists generally took the numbers in stride.
The advance in the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods was a high 1.1 percent, the third consecutive month with a rise above 1 percent. Economists noted, however, that the Labor Department's report today showed no change in producer prices when energy and food, which are subject to big gyrations, were excluded. 
 The report, in fact, was seen by many as strengthening the case for the Federal Reserve to push short-term interest rates down another notch to counter what is widely seen as incipient recession.
 
 Reaction in the Markets
 Financial markets rallied today, apparently in expectation of lower rates. Oil prices fell, with the contract for December delivery down $1.64, to $33.89 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. [Page 32.]
"The flat core rate ought to cool off some of the inflation psychology that's flying around out there," said Ron Schreibman, vice president of the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors, a trade group whose members pay the prices measured by the index for finished goods. Those prices are one step removed from the consumer level.
The core, or underlying, rate is what remains when economists strip away volatile components, generally energy and food, that can mask the basic inflation trend. Oil prices have doubled since August even though the loss of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil has now been entirely offset by higher production elsewhere.
 
 Fed Committee to Meet
 Analysts said the lack of any underlying inflation at the producer level last month would certainly be noted by the Fed's Open Market Committee when it meets on Tuesday to decide on monetary policy tactics for the next five weeks. It was thought quite possible, however, that the committee's 11 voting members would decide to defer any rate cuts until they see what happened to inflation last month as measured by the broader Consumer Price Index. Unlike the producer index, the consumer index includes services and imported goods.
The general expectation is that the rise in consumer prices approached 1 percent last month, with the underlying rate climbing about half as much as the overall index.
Although there is wide agreement that factors like drought and the risk of war do distort price data, there is considerable resistance among economists to the notion of entirely disregarding these special factors when assessing inflation risks.
The soaring price of oil, for example, has a powerful effect on sentiment and forces people to react "just as though it's permanent," contended Paul W. Boltz, vice president and financial economist at T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore. Even though the higher prices of such goods may be the result of special or "artificial" factors, consumers do pay those higher prices, adding to pressure to try to recover this lost purchasing power through higher wages.
On Tuesday, the department reported that hourly compensation increased at a 4.4 percent annual rate in the third quarter, down from a 5.4 percent rate of increase in the second quarter, an indication that worrisome wage pressures are not imminent.
Today's report showed that the finished-goods index rose two-tenths of 1 percent when only energy -- rather than energy and food -- was excluded. The energy component, which accounts for 9.2 percent of the index, climbed 8 percent in October after jumping 13.8 percent in September and 9.5 percent in August.
The two other principal indexes of producer prices, those covering goods at the intermediate and crude stages of production, were also driven sharply higher last month by energy.
Intermediate goods rose 1.5 percent, but just four-tenths of 1 percent without energy; crude goods rose 8.7 percent, but two-tenths of 1 percent without energy. Excluding both food and energy, intermediate goods rose moderately while crude goods fell considerably, the department said.
In the production of, say, clothing, raw cotton would be considered a crude material, a bolt of cloth an intermediate material and a suit or dress the finished goods.
All three stages have posted overall increases of more than 1 percent for each of the last three months.
Among finished goods, the 8 percent rise for gasoline and 15 percent rise for heating oil was considerably less than in August and September, but food rose nine-tenths of 1 percent after falling by that amount in September. Higher prices were posted for beef and veal, pork, eggs, and fresh and dried vegetables; prices fell for processed chickens, roasted coffee, fish, dairy products and shortening and cooking oils.
Prices of passenger cars fell 2.7 percent, but without seasonal adjustment they rose 6.2 percent.
Among intermediate goods, where energy components climbed 8.4 percent, nondurable manufacturing materials, like paints and fabrics, rose 1.3 percent, while prices of items for making durables were unchanged.
In crude goods, prices turned up for food and feeds after falling for two straight months, but basic industrial materials, like copper scrap and iron and steel scrap, fell far more than in September. Energy goods soared 18.7 percent last month after a 12.4 percent rise in September and a 25.5 percent rise in August.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Buildup in Gulf Seen as a Signal On Use of Force

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
President Bush ordered more troops to the Persian Gulf because the threat of economic strangulation is not swaying President Saddam Hussein of Iraq and he did not want to wait a year or more for sanctions to cripple the Iraqi economy, a senior Administration official said today.
The official, who insisted on not being identified, suggested that Mr. Bush wanted to bring the crisis to a turning point by the spring, either by giving Mr. Hussein the final push he needs to leave Kuwait on his own and adhere to United Nations Security Council resolutions, or by putting the United States and its allies in position to drive him out if necessary. 
 Mr. Bush has not given up on sanctions, the official said, or made a final decision to go to war. But he said: "We're not prepared to give this guy unlimited time, whoever's side time is on. Clearly, sanctions are not at the point where he is seriously constrained."
 
A Strong Signal to Hussein
 The United States policy could result in a decision by Mr. Hussein to test whether Washington is bluffing and force the United States to a critical decision about whether to attack Iraq and if so, on what scale. Officials briefing reporters did not address the question of whether it was possible that the United States might back down if there was no change in the situation in coming months.
One official said not one of the diplomatic missions to Iraq undertaken so far by representatives of Egypt, Syria, the Soviet Union and other countries had produced any evidence that the sanctions were having a psychological effect on Mr. Hussein.
"There's no one who has come back with any -- any -- sense that Saddam Hussein is wavering, changing his mind or anything like that, that there's any hope in that regard," he said. "Some want to keep trying and say we haven't exhausted all the possibilities, but even those desperately wanting to find some avenue like that have not said they've found any light in Saddam Hussein."
Mr. Bush's decision to send more troops to the Persian Gulf was thus intended to send Mr. Hussein a strong signal that the United States was not only prepared to carry out its threat of using force if needed but also was capable of inflicting devastating damage on Mr. Hussein's forces.
"One of the things that we want to do is convince him that we are in fact serious," the official said.
 
Consultation With Congress
 He added: "We still hope he will come to his senses. We hope that this will be an additional influence. I'm not prepared to take the next step and say we are going to launch an attack on such and such a day. That's the ultimatum, and we haven't come to that."
Congressional reaction to Mr. Bush's announcement on Thursday was muted. But the increased deployment did draw quick criticism from at least one member of Mr. Bush's party.
"While the President has taken great pains to consult with the Soviets, the Syrians, the Egyptians, the Saudis, the French, the Germans, the British and with the many others at the United Nations, his Administration has failed to adequately consult with the American Congress," said Representative William S. Broomfield of Michigan, the senior Republican on the House Foreign Affairs Committee.
Mr. Broomfield, who is generally reluctant to criticize a Republican President on matters of foreign policy, added in a written statement: "The President's decision to add more American troops to the force in the gulf may have been the right thing to do military and diplomatically, but his failure to consult broadly with Congress could eventually serve to undermine his policy."
 
Pressure to End Crisis
 Thomas S. Foley, Speaker of the House, said Mr. Bush had done a better job of consulting with Congress than virtually all of his recent predecessors but quickly added that lawmakers had not been informed of the additional deployments in advance.
"The recent troop increases were not the product of consultation," he said.
Although Administration officials professed surprise at suggestions that Mr. Bush had not adequately explained his gulf policy, the White House made senior officials available to reporters to discuss the new deployment orders. Mr. Bush also scheduled a meeting for Wednesday with Congressional leaders from both parties and the heads of committees dealing with national-security issues.
The senior official indicated that Mr. Bush had come under pressure to speed the conclusion to the gulf crisis because of Mr. Hussein's troop buildup, his attempts to divide the coalition ranged against him and the increasing difficulty of keeping large numbers of troops in the desert without actually using them.
 
Strained U.S. Embassy
 The United States is under additional pressure to force Mr. Hussein out of Kuwait quickly because the besieged American Embassy in Kuwait is running out of food. It may not be able to hold out even as long as it takes to get the reinforcements to the gulf, the official said.
Meanwhile, he said, Mr. Hussein is "still playing games and some of them with some skill to try to divide the coalition, create trouble and so on and so forth, as if time is on his side."
The Muslim holy period of Ramadan in March and the pilgrimage to Mecca in June, known as the Haj, are likely to increase the political problem that the presence of American troops has already created in Saudi Arabia, the official said.
 
Religious Aspect a Factor
 Those events "tend to underscore the religious aspect of it and one of Saddam Hussein's themes of course is that the Saudis are defiling the Holy Land" by allowing American and other Western forces onto their territory, the official said.
"I wouldn't say there is any indication that Saddam's themes are necessarily working," he said, "either that this is a U.S.-Israeli plot against the Arabs or that the Saudis and their Egyptian colleagues are desecrating Muslim shrines. But they are factors one has to take into account."
The official said, "All of these things indicate that waiting to starve him out may not be the way to go."
 
Brandt and Hostages Arrive
FRANKFURT, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt arrived here from Baghdad today with at least 174 Westerners whose freedom he had sought in talks with President Hussein.
The former hostages, detained since Iraq overran Kuwait on Aug. 2, included three Americans, one of whom had been shot in the arm by Iraqi troops in Kuwait on Sept. 5.
The wounded man, Miles Hoffman, 33 years old, of Columbus, Ga., had been working for the Kuwaiti Government. The other Americans were identified as Don and Brenda Swanke of Westlake Village, Calif. All three had been held at strategic sites as "human shields" to deter attack by United States-led multinational forces stationed in the gulf.

HEADLINE: Electronics Business Longing for a New Hit

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
For the second consecutive year, electronics retailers see little hope for a bright Christmas. With no new hit products to lure consumers and competition growing from Sears and Montgomery Ward, a fresh wave of store closings is expected by early next year, industry executives and analysts say.
Store executives say they do have a few strong-selling products, some surprisingly so, given consumers' wariness about a recession. 
 The camcorder is one. As these video cameras continue to shrink, their sales continue to grow. Compact disk players and cellular phones are also selling well. While prices are falling on these items, they remain at the higher end of the cost spectrum.
In fact, camcorders are contradicting a longstanding truism of the consumer electronics business, which says that a product must cost less than $500 to have mass-market potential. Consumers are buying large numbers of camcorders at nearly $1,000 each.
Now, if someone decides a product is a necessity, "price does not seem to be an object," said Marvin M. Stern, vice president for home appliances and entertainment at Sears, Roebuck & Company.
But those are the exceptions and they are coming up short against several factors that are tightening the squeeze on retailers. "The industry is going to go through a couple of very lean years," said Barry Bryant, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities.
 
 Setbacks for Regional Chains
 Several regional chains, like Crazy Eddie and the Federated Group Inc., have filed for bankruptcy, been sold in pieces or gone out of business in the last year or so. They were unable to hold on now that more than two-thirds of the nation's households have videocassette recorders and microwave ovens.
The stepped-up competition comes at an especially bad time for retailers like Highland Superstores Inc. and Fretter Inc. These mid-sized chains are once again entering the crucial holiday selling season of the notoriously hit-driven electronics business with no hits to drive up badly needed sales.
While the prospect of competing against Sears may not strike terror in the hearts of many retailers these days, the giant retailer has been able to take advantage of its size in selling color televisions, portable stereos and VCR's.
Sears's crosstown rival, Montgomery Ward & Company, has also had considerable success with its Electric Avenue format, a glitzy island of neon and stereo equipment plunked down inside regular Ward's.
After years of explosive gains fueled first by VCR sales and then microwave ovens, growth in the consumer electronics field has flattened to around 2 percent a year. Last year, sales were $32.3 billion, according to the Electronic Industries Association in Washington, compared with $30.8 billion the year before.
Even the industry powerhouse, Circuit City Stores Inc., is feeling the pinch. On Tuesday, when the Richmond company reported a 7 percent drop in comparable-store sales for October, the stock fell to a 52-week low of $10.375. The shares closed yesterday at $10.875, up 87.5 cents.
 
 Clout in Retailing
 Camcorders show how Sears has gained clout in electronics retailing.
Last year, Lee Schoenfeld, marketing vice president for the Best Buy Company, a Midwestern chain based in Minneapolis, received some disturbing information. "Believe it or not, we are getting beat by Sears" in the camcorder business, Mr. Schoenfeld said he had been told by an employee. Sears was heavily promoting its $1,000 private-label LXI brand.
"It was an example of where they were able to use their buying power to have a better price," Mr. Schoenfeld said. "Last year they basically drove the camcorder business." Best Buy estimates that Sears now controls about 20 percent of the camcorder market, a number Sears does not dispute.
Sears began shifting to its Brand Central department, selling name- brand and private-label consumer electronics, in August 1988, but just recently completed installing the section in all its stores. The company does not give separate sales figures for that department, but said that a $2 billion number cited in a trade magazine, HFD, was in the ballpark.
 
 Power of Consumer Fear
 "They've made a very competitive market that much more competitive," Martin Brochstein, senior editor of Television Digest, another trade magazine, said of the emergence of Sears and Ward's.
Sears's selection is usually more limited and its prices tend to be higher than those at the speciality stores. But George Rosenbaum, president of Leo J. Shapiro & Associates Inc., a Chicago market research firm, said that Sears's traditional strengths, the service system, the credit program and the willingness of the company to stick by what its sells to keep long-term customers, help neutralize the price and selection issues.
"Winning against the superstores becomes symbolically a very important step forward in the renaissance of Sears," Mr. Rosenbaum said.
Right now the industry's most formidable foe is consumer fear about the weakening economy.
G. Lee Thompson, the chairman and chief executive of the Smith Corona Corporation, said the weakening economy would quicken the rate of consolidation in the industry. "It is survival of the fittest," he said. "Anytime there are difficult economic times, the weaker players get weeded out."
Mr. Bryant of Prudential-Bache said that fierce price cutting had made margins for electronics products among the lowest in the industry, leaving no room for missteps in a recession.
But perhaps the industry's biggest problem is the lack of any hot new products.
Retailers are gazing wistfully at the horizon, awaiting some major new category, like high-definition television, or HDTV, that will provide a fresh spurt of growth. Mr. Bryant of Prudential-Bache calls HDTV "the light at the end of the tunnel." Digital audio tape players, which are now available, also hold some promise.
The mood at the 47th Street Photo store a few blocks off Manhattan's Times Square is typical. "There's no silver bullet coming down the pike," said Mark Gross, a salesman at the bustling retailer. "That's been the problem in this industry for the past couple of years," he said. He bemoans the lack of a VCR-type hit, saying, "That's what got the electronics industry through the last recession."
VCR's were introduced a decade ago, and Mr. Gross, who was a rabbi in the early 1980's, said that the desire to have one was so great that the subject came up in counseling sessions.
"The choice at that time was having a child or getting a VCR," he joked.
For now, replacement sales are the chief source of revenue for retailers. Consider the television set. Although more than 98 percent of households in the country own a color or black and white set, the industry continues to sell more than 20 million new ones a year.
 
 A Zero-Sum Game
 Still, industry officials eagerly await the next technological breakthrough. Replacement sales are essentially a zero-sum game, while VCR's and microwaves were entirely new categories.
"When a new electronic product like the VCR comes along, you have the pie enlarging very quickly," said Mr. Rosenbaum of Leo J. Shapiro & Associates. He added that a hot product could obscure a lot of mistakes by retailers. It forgives overexpansion, he said, and "it forgives even retailers who are mediocre."
The next few months are not likely to be so forgiving. Mr. Stern of Sears said, "There are too many stores and not enough customers."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Stores like this Sears Brand Central outlet at the Cross County Square mall in Yonkers, which had very few customers yesterday afternoon, are part of the growing competition facing electronic specialty stores. But the outlook for the Christmas selling season seems disappointing for the retailing giants as well as for the smaller chains. (Alan Zale for The New York Times) (pg. 31); chart: percentage of Americans that own various electronic products (Source: Electronic Industries Association) (pg. 33)

The Economy
 Producer prices jumped 1.1 percent in October, the third straight monthly rise, as oil prices continued to escalate. But economists noted that the Labor Department's report showed no change when energy and food were excluded. [Page 31.]
Electronics retailers see little hope for a bright Christmas for the second straight year. With no new hit products to lure consumers and competition growing from Sears and Montgomery Ward, a fresh wave of store closings is expected by early next year. [31.]
Transportation Secretary Skinner concluded two days of talks with top airline executives aimed at assessing the damage caused by higher fuel costs. [31.]
 More than half of the 42 fraud charges filed against Keating and three other former Lincoln executives are too vague to be brought to trial, a California state judge ruled. [33.]

 Markets

HEADLINE: Every Other 14-Year-Old, Armed

 BODY:
Teen-agers in New York City have never had so many guns with so much killing power. Informed estimates of the number of illegal guns on the street run into the hundreds of thousands. "If you're asking me if every 14-year-old has a gun," a police officer recently told The Times, "the answer is no. Does every other 14-year-old have a gun? The answer is yes."
These are no longer cheap "Saturday night specials" but powerful 9-millimeter semiautomatics, machine pistols or military assault rifles worth hundreds of dollars affordable with drug money. 
 Recent articles in The Times documented official concern about the alarming "new gun culture" among New York City teen-agers. With easy access to firearms, adolescents all too predictably adopt them as status symbols and toys. Once in hand, the guns, increasingly, are used. Last year 66 percent of homicides were committed with firearms, compared with 58 percent in 1980 and only 19 percent in 1960.
Now the challenge is to limit the access to guns in the face of a powerful black market and continuing political neglect. It will not be easy. New York City has some of the toughest gun control laws in the country. But they are thwarted by illegal traffickers who earn hefty markups on weapons imported from states with lax rules. The popular Mac-10, for example, which retails for $500 elsewhere, may sell for three times as much in New York City.
Given enough political determination, this deadly market can be disrupted. Unlike the drug products that originate in Andean mountains or Asian poppy fields, beyond easy reach of American law, guns are made and distributed by legitimate American businesses fully subject to U.S. Government regulation. Illicit gun trafficking would be severely inhibited by laws that institute rigorous procedures for monitoring of gun shipments and sales, and ban civilian purchases of military weapons altogether.
Yet Congress cravenly ducks the issue. The gun lobby furiously resists any serious effort to keep guns out of young criminals' hands, apparently to protect the industry's interest in such sales. After a session marked by increasing debate over reasonable new gun laws -- supported by large popular majorities -- the House adjourned without even bringing them to a vote.
That leaves local officials to their own devices, and New York's Police Commissioner, Lee Brown, is off to a thoughtful if limited start. Last summer he formed a police task force to work with Federal agents against gun traffickers. The group has already made 28 arrests. Now he supplements that effort with a new crackdown on New Yorkers who hold Federal gun dealer licenses for dubious purposes.
Such licenses, relatively easy for individuals to obtain from Washington, allow receipt of bulk purchases from gun makers and other exemptions from Federal limits. The police count more than 1,000 such Federal licenses issued to New York City residents, but only 32 dealers have also obtained the license required by the city to sell handguns.
Mr. Brown plans aggressive measures to determine whether the remaining "dealers" are using their Federal licenses to obtain guns that they then dispense illegally in the city. Citing a little used state law, he has also instructed some 3,000 cargo carriers to hold gun shipments headed for city addresses while police verify whether the recipients are licensed to possess guns.
Those are laudable steps, but are they enough to quench so thriving a black market? Much will depend on whether the police can muster sufficient resources to make the innovative strategies work. Even in a time of severe budgetary stringencies, the department has little choice but to try.

GRAPHIC: Graphic: "Shot Dead" shows percentage of homocides committed with firearms in New York City for years 1960, 1970, 1980 and 1990. (Source: New York City Police Department)

HEADLINE: Taiwan: Too Big to Ignore

 BODY:
Taiwan is now one of Asia's most powerful industrial and trading economies. It is America's sixth-largest trading partner, doing more business with this country than France or Saudi Arabia and twice as much as mainland China. Taiwan has become a major global investor; its companies now buy out American businesses.
Yet in the eyes of official Washington, and of most other governments, Taipei scarcely exists. 
 When Washington belatedly recognized the People's Republic 12 years ago, it accepted the proposition then put forth by both Beijing and Taipei that there could be only one China. But in reality, there remain two Chinas. America's traditional one-China policy is ripe for critical review.
The one-China fiction grows increasingly hard to justify as Taiwan deepens its economic relations with the outside world and China turns its back on market reforms. After last year's bloodbath in Tiananmen Square, no one imagines an easy fusion of the two Chinese states any time soon.
Taipei's application to rejoin the capitalist world's main trade organization, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, has already set off a debate within the Bush Administration. Carla Hills, the Trade Representative, supports Taipei's bid. But the State Department, reluctant to upset Beijing and perhaps endanger its cooperation against Iraq, resists.
Taiwan was a founding member of the Trade Agreement in 1947 but was forced out in 1971 when the People's Republic assumed China's seat in the United Nations. Its return would automatically subject Taiwanese trade to the world's agreed trading ground rules. That can also be done, as now, by a network of bilateral agreements.
Ultimately, GATT membership is symbolic and political. But it is just for symbolic and political reasons that the U.S. should now look with favor on Taiwan's readmission. There is no doubt about Taiwan's commitment to a market economy, a standard condition for GATT membership. And, unlike mainland China, Taiwan is now committed to democracy.
There are obvious problems. Beijing insists on subordinating Taiwan's application to its own membership bid. But that may not prove insuperable. Both Chinas now participate in the Asian Development Bank, with Taiwan accepting the designation "Taipei, China." That formula honors the fiction of one China while acknowledging the reality of two regimes. Taipei would re-enter GATT as the "Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu."
Washington is not obliged to humor Beijing's desire to deny the reality of two Chinas. Especially on economic matters, the U.S. holds far more cards than the People's Republic, and can afford to put American interests first. Those interests are served by maintaining normal diplomatic and economic relations with mainland China. But they are also served by dealing with the reality of Taipei.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: International Monetary Fund Helps Preserve the Environment

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Readers alarmed by decimation of tropical rain forests should not be deluded by full-page advertisements of the Rainforest Action Network in your newspaper and others charging that the International Monetary Fund is one of the "world's leading architects of environmental destruction" (Oct. 15). I will reply briefly -- if only to minimize the felling of trees for newsprint.
The I.M.F. is composed of 154 member countries and is the world's central monetary institution. It was created 45 years ago for the promotion of international trade and economic growth by helping countries to stabilize their currencies, battle inflation and build sound economies. More than 60 countries are receiving or negotiating I.M.F. assistance. Some 30 are African nations seeking to reverse a tragic fall in per capita income over the last two decades; in Latin America, many countries now have a chance to grow out of debt, and remarkable progress is being made in Eastern Europe, all in cooperation with the I.M.F.
The I.M.F. also assists its members to improve their economic efficiency. By helping countries move from state-run to market systems and reduce their foreign debt to sustainable levels, it contributes to laying the foundation for long-term sustainable growth. It is such growth that will eventually prevail against poverty and in some ways help the environment, too. The fight against poverty is the only way to avoid a situation where people are driven to destroy irreplaceable environmental assets, such as rain forests. The I.M.F. coordinates advice and support with other international agencies with environmental concerns and expertise.
Economic change and transformation are not costless. The I.M.F. encourages countries to develop social safety nets so that the more vulnerable segments of the population can, to the extent possible, be protected against the inescapable hardship of economic adjustment.
The advertisement and solicitation were inaccurate in suggesting that I.M.F.-supported programs are financed solely by United States taxpayers. The United States and 153 other members own shares in this cooperative institution; these pooled resources are used to extend credit and technical assistance to member countries in need. By making a contribution to the financial resources of the I.M.F., each country -- including the United States -- also establishes a right to draw on the institution, which it can exercise when a need arises.
An increase of the I.M.F.'s capital base is indispensable to enable it to face the unexpected needs of its members, such as those brought on by the Persian Gulf crisis. The best prospect for preserving the environment worldwide is to be found in encouraging and assisting countries to develop their economic potential, not by attacking as convenient targets agencies like the I.M.F. and the World Bank that are dedicated to that goal.
 
AZIZALI F. MOHAMMED
Director, External Relations Dept. International Monetary Fund
Washington, Oct. 24, 1990

HEADLINE: Woman With a Shovel Gets Ready to Govern

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
For months it's been shovels: shovel pins on her lapel, shovels in her hands, shovels in campaign speeches that said a mere broom wouldn't be enough to clean up City Hall. Now the question is whether Sharon Pratt Dixon, Washington's Mayor-elect, can turn her winning metaphor into a workable government.
The corks from the victory-night champagne bottles had barely stopped popping when Ms. Dixon began work on that formidable task. 
 She met with John Wilson, the new chairman of the City Council, to discuss ways of cutting a 1991 deficit projected at $200 million. She met with Eleanor Holmes Norton, the District's new delegate to Congress, and announced a strategy for seeking more Federal funds.
A 46-year-old political newcomer, Ms. Dixon also gave the first hints of her taste in government aides, appointing a 27-member transition team headed by Vernon Jordan, a corporate lawyer who is a member in good standing of the Washington establishment.
 
Declawing Her Predecessor
 At the same time, she continued battling her predecessor, Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., whom she had blamed for many of the city's problems. Pledging to make good on her promise to clean house, Ms. Dixon asked for the resignation of all 170 of his political appointees, fearing that otherwise Mr. Barry would grant them Civil Service protection to prevent their dismissal when she takes office in January.
She also called on the City Council to pass a law that would curtail Mr. Barry's ability to dispense last-minute favors by awarding contracts or giving his aides raises or promotions.
Mr. Barry said Ms. Dixon's requests were unnecessary because he had no plans for such machinations in the last two months of his administration. But she was unwilling to take him at his word. "I wouldn't have urged emergency legislation if I didn't think it was at least a potential problem," she said at a news conference.
The week's problems may be only a taste of things to come, as Ms. Dixon takes command of a city with empty pockets, a flabby midsection, surging needs and a tattered national reputation.
She has promised to cut a government work force that grew 25 percent in Mr. Barry's 12 years in office, even as the population shrank. She has also promised compassion. Despite the bureaucracy's enormous growth, the District has enormous unmet needs.
 
Dropouts, Murders and Blight
 It has the highest infant mortality rate of any city in the country. Its public housing stock includes 2,500 boarded-up units. Its ambulances are known for getting lost while answering emergency calls.
Its schools are near the top in dropout rates and close to the bottom in scores on the Scholastic Aptitude Test. Its murder rate has helped keep tabloid television in business.
Like other mayors, Ms. Dixon will have to conduct her fiscal balancing act during an economic slump that brings revenue down while accelerating need. But unlike other mayors, she will also have to contend with a Congress that has control over her budget and what many here regard as a penchant for micromanagement.
Ms. Dixon faces these challenges with more than mere talk of shovels. On Tuesday, in her first run for elective office, she captured 86 percent of the vote, a record for a mayoral election in Washington, and carried all 140 precincts. That left little question about her mandate.
As the first black woman to head the government of a major city, she comes into office with immediate national stature. And she will put it to work in a city that completed its repudiation of the previous era by handing Mr. Barry, who has been convicted of drug possession, a pink slip rather than the City Council seat he sought.
Ms. Dixon also carries into office a newcomer status that is a mixture of insurgency and establishment. She was the first candidate in the mayor's race, the first to call for Mr. Barry's resignation, and a clear underdog. More than any other candidate, she stood for change.
 
Outside, but Hardly Unknown
 But she was not unknown. A lawyer who was most recently a vice president of the Potomac Electric Power Company, she served as campaign manager for Patricia Roberts Harris, a former Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, in an unsuccessful 1982 campaign against Mr. Barry. And she has served as treasurer of the Democratic National Committee.
"She sort of invented herself as an outsider, and the public bought it," said Mark Plotkin, a political commentator on WAMU-FM, a public radio station.
While her campaign message was a blunt "clean house," it has often been unclear what type of people or programs she plans when the renovation is through. One clue was this week's appointment of Mr. Jordan, a former head of the National Urban League.
"I wasn't against the establishment itself," she said at a news conference Thursday when asked about Mr. Jordan's appointment. "I felt it needed a new thrust."
She said the transition team would try "to tap into dimensions of this town that have never been tapped into." Many of her campaign aides are young and new to city politics.
Having won over the public, Ms. Dixon and her aides must now win the city's politicians and bureaucrats.
She set to work on the first task the day after the election by meeting with the new chairman of the City Council. Throughout the campaign, Mr. Wilson, a longtime Councilman who was neutral in the mayoral race, said he envisioned new influence for the body. And as head of both the Council and the Revenue and Finance Committee, he will wield much of that influence.
Mr. Wilson has said he favors a tax increase. Ms. Dixon has said she does not.
The City Council with which she will deal also includes two of her defeated rivals in the mayoral race.
As a newcomer to the District government, Ms. Dixon will need to motivate the bureaucracy she campaigned against. Her talents in this regard are unknown. While she is often called smart and determined, she has not worked in government and has never run a large organization.
On her most specific pledge -- "to cut 2,000 mid-management-level paper pushers" -- she can expect a fight. Civil Service protections make cutbacks tough.
But so, the recent evidence suggests, is Ms. Dixon.

HEADLINE: Why Keep Yugoslavia One Country?

BYLINE: By Jeri Laber and Kenneth Anderson; Jeri Laber is executive director of Helsinki Watch; Kenneth Anderson, a lawyer, is a member.

 BODY:
Polat, a remote village in Yugoslavia's troubled Kosovo province, is too small to appear on our map. Until the ghastly events of Sept. 13, its name was virtually unknown. We went to Polat in early October to investigate reports of violence by the nationalist Serbian government against ethnic Albanians. We returned with serious doubts about whether the U.S. Government should continue to bolster the national unity of Yugoslavia.
A brilliant autumn sun lit the dry, brown cornfields and tree-covered hills of Polat, but the village was in mourning. Its residents -- several hundred ethnic Albanians living at subsistence level -- described how, in the predawn hours of Sept. 13, they had awakened to the barking of their dogs, looked out and saw Serbian government tanks in their small courtyards. 
 Without warning, soldiers and police began firing automatic weapons, shattering windows and stuccoed walls. Besim Latifi, a 22-year-old law student who had come home to help with the harvest, opened his door and was met with a volley of bullets that killed him on the spot.
No one saw what happened to Skender Munolli, 34, whose battered corpse was released to his family a few days later with one bullet in the hip. According to their families, neither young man had had any previous trouble with the police. In addition to the two killings, more than 30 men and women from Polat were beaten and taken off to a jail, where they were tortured for about 24 hours; one young man was forced to lick his own blood from the floor.
Kosovo is a province within Serbia, the largest of Yugoslavia's six fractious republics. Kosovo's population -- more than 90 percent ethnic Albanian -- is united in a predominantly nonviolent struggle to become independent. In July, after the Kosovo Assembly defiantly declared its independence, the Serbian government suspended Kosovo's parliament and government; at least 10 members of the assembly have been arrested or are being sought.
Slobodan Milosevic, the Serbian Socialist (formerly Communist) Party's demagogic leader, has said that Serbia will pay any price to maintain control of Kosovo, the birthplace of Serbian culture. He is engaged in a calculated policy of colonization that includes relocating Serbians to Kosovo.
An estimated 30,000 Albanians have been removed from their jobs in Kosovo. Several hundred Albanian doctors and medical workers were fired summarily; some were taken away in handcuffs from the hospital, even out of the operating rooms. The Albanian-language press and radio have been abolished. In schools, Albanians are segregated from Serbs.
Kosovo's capital, Pristina, is an occupied territory, with military checkpoints everywhere. Houses are searched without notice, and people are arrested arbitrarily. In the past year and a half, more than 60 Albanians were killed by police. "We live under glass," an unemployed Albanian professor told us. "I don't know what it is like to laugh. How long can I tell my children to be patient?"
Kosovo is not the only troubled area within Yugoslavia. We visited villages in the Croatian Republic where the tension is equally high; an armed minority composed of Serbs has declared autonomy within Croatia. Franko Tudjman, the nationalist President of Croatia, has said that his government will "invite our entire people to take to arms" if Croatian sovereignty is threatened.
The Slovenian Republic's government, which has also declared its sovereignty, has already taken control of its own defense forces in direct defiance of the central government. Borislav Jovic, head of the Yugoslav government, recently acknowledged that civil war was looming on the horizon.
Yugoslavia was long the darling of the U.S. State Department. A Communist country independent of Moscow, it was our Communist country as distinct from theirs. Seen as a buffer straddling the East-West divide, it has received most-favored-nation status and has been exempted from any serious scrutiny of its many human rights abuses. But the revolution against Communism that swept through Eastern Europe left an ideological vacuum in regions that are now veering away from a center that cannot hold.
The U.S. Government cannot stop that process, even if it leads to inflaming old border disputes between Yugoslavia's nation-states and its larger neighbors. Yet we continue to give economic support to a federal Government in Belgrade that is apparently too weak to speak out or act against those who are committing human rights abuses.
Why not acknowledge the Government's impotence and offer aid to those republics that will protect the rights of all their citizens? We might be able to help them in a peaceful evolution to democracy.
There is no moral law that commits us to honor the national unity of Yugoslavia. But there are laws, both moral and statutory, that commit us to deny aid to governments that oppress.

HEADLINE: The Two Faces of Southern Populism

BYLINE: By Dan T. Carter; Dan T. Carter, a professor of history at Emory University, is a fellow at the National Humanities Center.

DATELINE: DURHAM , N.C.

 BODY:
George Wallace, that Southern ghost of elections past, still haunts us as we enter the 1990's.
If Guy Hunt's re-election campaign as Governor of Alabama was a kinder and gentler version of the politics of race, Jesse Helms's senatorial campaign in North Carolina offered a chilling reminder that the old-time religion of "Nigger! Nigger! Nigger!" can still bring out the frightened faithful. Both victories vindicate those Republican strategists who have always wanted to exploit the racial fears so skillfully aroused by Mr. Wallace in his Presidential campaigns of the 1960's and 70's. 
 It is a strategy that seems particularly suited for our increasingly subliterate television culture. In that world in which each new day begins afresh -- without past, without future -- 30-second appeals to glandular reflexes ("quotas," "parasitic underclass") are infinitely more accessible than complex discussions of race relations or economic exploitation. The current economic downturn makes such squalid appeals to scapegoating even more effective.
What we should not forget is that this is neither something new nor the last word, but the latest chapter in a century-old struggle between two quite different strands of Southern populism.
Mr. Wallace began his career in 1946 as a down-home social democrat with little enthusiasm for race-baiting. To be sure, when hebecame the high priest of racial segregation in the early 1960's, he brought to Alabama a level of vindictiveness that left wounds still unhealed. And his Presidential campaigns gave voice to some of the darkest fears and hatreds in American society.
But when the number of black voters in his state passed the 300,000 mark in the early 1970's, the Alabama Governor reversed direction and embraced black voters and politicians. Political opportunism is not an edifying spectacle. Compared with the unwavering racism of Mr. Helms, it has its charms.
In some ways, George Wallace was simply returning to his political roots, as one of the proteges of a Southern populist who spent his career fighting for, rather than against, civil rights: James E. (Big Jim) Folsom.
Through two terms as Governor of Alabama and 40 years of campaigning, Folsom evolved his political catechism: governmental laissez-faire inevitably allowed the powerful to prey upon the weak; adequate welfare programs were the fundamental obligation of a democracy; women were entitled to full equality; the state of Alabama should guarantee black citizens equal justice, equal opportunity and complete access to the ballot box; there were no problems that couldn't be solved by a "good strong purgative of pure unadulterated democracy."
In the end, Folsom's personal failings (too much whisky, too many women, too few honest friends) were as conspicuous as his 6-foot 8-inch frame and his size 16 shoes. His challenge to Mr. Wallace collapsed in the 1962 governor's race when he appeared on statewide television too drunk to recognize his own children. When he ran for governor against Mr. Wallace in 1974, he got less than 5 percent of the vote.
And now, as the economy falters and the bills for Ronald Reagan's fantasies come due, the voices James Folsom fought are returning to join the David Dukes. The politics of victimization are over, we are told. Now black Americans can once more take their historical place as the scapegoats of a troubled society.
Folsom had seen it all before. The "Ku-Kluxers, the race-baiters, and some of the selfish interest groups" would always be present, he warned in 1949. They would be "spreading their filth, their lies, their old and ancient hatreds . . . trying to boil up hatred by the poor white people against the Negroes . . . trying to keep the poor white from progressing by keeping the Negro tied in shackles."
Still, I take heart from the only conversation I ever had with James Folsom. He was nearly blind and occasionally confused as we sat and talked in a truck-stop restaurant outside Cullman, Ala. But he retained an almost childlike faith in the same voters who had rejected him. The working people of this country would eventually see through this "blasphemous smoke screen" of racial hatred, hepredicted in our talk. And they would understand that the promise of this nation lay in the challenge of guaranteeing "equal justice, equal opportunity and equal freedom for every man, woman and child."
That's a far cry from the "populism" of Jesse Helms.

HEADLINE: A Bad Year for Buchanan

BYLINE: By Hugh Brogan; Hugh Brogan, a reader in history at the University of Essex in England, is the author of "The Longman History of the United States."

 BODY:

AMERICA IN 1857
A Nation on the Brink.
By Kenneth M. Stampp.
Illustrated. 388 pp. New York:
Oxford University Press. $29.95. 
 KENNETH M. STAMPP is by common acclaim the dean of historians of the Civil War era, and the long and honorable list of his works more than justifies the title; but not since "The Era of Reconstruction" (1965) has he used the narrative form. Now that it is becoming so academically fashionable, he has perhaps decided to show the young how an old master can handle it; and the result is a triumph of the historian's craft. The argument underlying this chronicle of one year could not be stated more modestly, but almost every detail contributes to it; and the cunning structure of the narrative, which amounts to a carefully calculated arrangement of details, will compel readers to discover Mr. Stampp's thesis for themselves and make it their own.
The argument, to be sure, is neither new nor obscure. Kansas in 1857 was a territory ready to become a state. The urgent question was, should it be admitted to the Union with the proslavery, ill-drafted constitution that an unrepresentative handful of extremists had cobbled together at Lecompton, Kan., late in the year? President James Buchanan, by insisting on the Lecompton constitution, split his party and opened the way to disaster. In Mr. Stampp's opinion, his mishandling of the Kansas crisis was the fatal step that made disruption of the Union, and therefore civil war, all but inescapable. But each generation must learn the ancient truths for itself. It need only be added that Mr. Stampp's style is as clear and plain as his knowledge is great. "America in 1857" is a book from which even scholars can learn, which nonhistorians can enjoy, and which Civil War buffs will certainly relish. It may even please unreconstructed rebels, for it shows, as definitely as these things can ever be established, that the great blunder over the Lecompton constitution was Buchanan's own work, not that of his Southern friends and colleagues.
If the book has a weakness, it is that it starts a little too quietly. This is not a usual fault in books about the coming of the Civil War. Mr. Stampp's taste is perhaps a little too good for his own interest. A touch of the drum and the trumpet, or at least some lively pages about the election of 1856, might have hooked readers more certainly than the somewhat humdrum account of politics and society in early 1857 with which the volume opens.
So it becomes a reviewer's duty to advise all such readers to persevere. They will be rewarded by plenty of excitement from the day of Buchanan's inauguration onward, and they will find that, in retrospect, even the opening chapters have importance. For one of Mr. Stampp's themes is that in the spring of 1857 the Republic's prospects were blooming. Even the Dred Scott decision, made that year, was not sufficient to revive the passionate disputes of 1856, and although there was a financial crash in the autumn, we now know, if the people of the time did not, that the economy was to make a rapid recovery. In short, Buchanan had to work really hard to wreck things.
If, as is only fair, we judge him by the foreseeable consequences of his actions, he must without question be rated the worst American President, his only competitor being Andrew Johnson, whose faults of character were very similar. The preceding Administration of Franklin Pierce had belatedly put an end to violence in "bleeding Kansas"; the Democratic Party had pledged itself to free elections in the territory; the South was by no means united in resistance to that pledge because it was so evident Kansas was going to be a free-soil state.
Had Buchanan stuck to his own express commitments, the Kansas question would have been laid to rest and the Democratic Party, united, would have been in excellent shape to fight the 1860 election, which everyone knew would be crucial. Mr. Stampp explicitly denies that such an outcome would have ended the great controversy over slavery; he does not pretend to know what would have happened if the Republicans had lost in 1860; but the outcome could hardly have been worse than what, thanks to Buchanan, actually did occur. So the responsibility borne by the 15th President was a heavy one. He chose to recommend the fraudulent Lecompton constitution to Congress, and in so doing broke his word and split his party beyond recovery. Three years later, a Republican victory came, followed by secession and war.
No evidence -- diaries, letters, memoirs -- shows us Buchanan's inner life (presumably he had one). He was a secretive man, and has himself to blame that posterity must interpret him entirely by externals. But the evidence deployed by Mr. Stampp leaves little doubt about Buchanan's motives. His long experience in public life had made him superficially one of the best trained of all Presidents: he had been a senator, Secretary of State, a minister abroad (his successor could only boast of two undistinguished years as a Congressman). In reality his career seems to have taught Buchanan's narrow mind only inapplicable lessons, such as the duty of strict party loyalty in all circumstances, the power of patronage, the importance of Presidential rigidity.
HE had been a follower of Andrew Jackson, and Stephen A. Douglas had to point out to him that "General Jackson is dead"; in any case, no one was ever less like the intuitive, impetuous Jackson than the dully obstinate Buchanan. "General Jackson could be coaxed from his purpose" said Buchanan's Secretary of War, "but . . . Mr. B. could neither be coaxed nor driven." In 40 years of politics, Buchanan did not learn to respect the honest concerns of his opponents, or indeed of anyone but himself and those who agreed with him completely; nor did he ever see that opinions, on their own, are unsafe guides to action. He was a doughface, a Northern man of Southern opinions; and he explicitly blamed the Kansas disturbances not on the handful of proslavery conspirators who began them but on the great mass of antislavery settlers in the territory. So he had no qualms of conscience about trying to override the settlers' democratic rights.
He saw that the crisis in Kansas had to be ended for the sake of the Union; he supposed that the way to do it was by backing the proslavery minority, which was prepared to stick at nothing, whether force or fraud, to get command. All this is contemptible enough; but the amazing thing is that this seasoned politician actually persuaded himself that his course of action was the most prudent and patriotic one. His judgment was as bad as his political morality.
Perhaps they amounted to the same thing. Slavery corrupted the minds of all its supporters. Buchanan's misjudgments were no worse than those that eventually precipitated the South into secession and armed rebellion. What needs explaining is how America came to be saddled with such an incompetent President. Mr. Stampp does not discuss this; perhaps the time has come for another look at David Donald's suggestion that an excess of democracy was at work. At least there was too much party-politics-as-usual. James Buchanan, a man of mediocre character, limited abilities and illiberal opinions -- which, without his noticing, had grown dangerously obsolete -- had by 1856 built up an irresistible claim on his party. He looked like a statesman, but, in Charles Francis Adams's phrase, he was no more than a musty old conservative. His country paid the price.

HEADLINE: Trouble in Murder City

BYLINE: By Laura Green; Laura Green, who grew up in Detroit, is an editor of the forthcoming "Reinventing Home," a collection of essays on the role of the home in people's lives.

 BODY:
DEVIL'S NIGHT
And Other True Tales of Detroit.
By Ze'ev Chafets.
240 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95. 
 IN 1967, a race riot ended a Detroit that once looked as if it would go on forever. Seemingly as content as a cat, Detroit was a town of Irish political control and Polish food, of snug brick houses under sprawling maples, a place whose assembly lines guaranteed a good living. In the next two decades it changed from a fairly prosperous city of nearly two million to a poor, nearly all-black town of not quite one million as whites fled to the suburbs, taking their business and investment with them. Whites held the economic reins, blacks assumed political control and a deep animosity began to mark city-suburb relations.
Detroit became the city where blacks really did call the political shots. It also became Murder City, with abandoned neighborhoods, empty stores and an annual three-day Halloween arson explosion that draws firebugs and fire buffs from all over the state.
In "Devil's Night" -- what Detroiters call the night before Halloween -- Ze'ev Chafets, a writer who grew up in one of Detroit's industrial suburbs before emigrating to Israel, has tried to chronicle the city's new life through a Greek chorus of office holders, policemen, rock musicians, drug addicts, mothers, convicted criminals and community workers.
Even for a town that takes church services so seriously that a newspaper once rated sermons like restaurants, this is quite a choir. A Chaldean grocer, standing by his fully loaded gun rack, tells how he locks shoplifters in his basement just beyond reach of his Doberman. An expensively dressed prophet solicits $10 and $20 bills from his poor congregation. A suburban Grosse Pointe matron suggests an innovation in crime coverage. "Why not have a new society page for criminals?" she asks. "If you want to see who shot whom, just turn to Section D." Mayor Coleman Young curses the suburbs and charms his constituents while his counterpart in Hamtramck, a town within the Detroit city limits, sympathizes with him, charging that suburbanflight stripped the city clean. "They even took the ball teams," he notes.
The voices in Mr. Chafets's book rock with a modern assonance befitting Motown. Yet, despite his sketches of a city in sullen confrontation, sort of a Midwestern Middle East, he never quite makes clear that Detroit was destined for hard times no matter who sat in City Hall. Suburban flight was well under way by the mid-50's and, to official outrage, city planners predicted in the mid-60's that business would move north of the city limits.
Even without white flight, Detroit still would have declined from its boom days. The internationalization of the automobile industry choked off the well-paid blue-collar jobs that supported generations of unskilled laborers and propelled their children into the middle class. Detroit has always been a city of industry, not of institutions, and its one-industry status made it particularly vulnerable to boom and bust cycles. The auto companies themselves played a part in the city's current failure to thrive. With the notable exception of the Ford family, the town's corporate leaders came late to civic leadership and did not really get involved until after the riots.
Though Mr. Chafets captures the city's voices, much of what they say is hardly unique to Detroit. Newark has vacant lots. Washington has crack houses. Parts of New York City have infant mortality rates comparable to those in third world countries. And though the author does not mention it, every aging city that is trying to stay vital has a constant tension between money put into downtown and money needed in the neighborhoods.
Still, Mr. Chafets captures the feel of the city; his vignettes are as entertaining as the little grace notes of a fine gospel song. He evokes the nostalgia (he calls it "the white man's malady") for the days when Martha Reeves, Smokey Robinson and Berry Gordy put Motown into the national consciousness, the feel of working on the assembly line in the big Dodge Main or Ford Rouge or Pontiac plants. And he captures the sense of a bellwether black community in charge, on the edge of change, trying to reconstruct a city on the ropes.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 66; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 948 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy

BYLINE: By GEORGE JOHNSON

 BODY:
EDEN CLOSE, by Anita Shreve. (Signet, $4.95.) When a New York City advertising man goes home to attend a funeral in the upstate farming community where he was raised, he falls back in love with Eden, the girl next door, who was raped and blinded when she was a teen-ager. Last year our reviewer, Carolyn Banks, called this an "evocative and moving novel. . . . Its insights are keen, its language measured and haunting."
ALMOST HUMAN: A Journey Into the World of Baboons, by Shirley C. Strum. (Norton, $12.95.) An anthropologist who spent 15 years studying monkey culture in Kenya, Shirley Strum found that male baboons often use finesse instead of aggression to win the hearts of females. In 1988 our reviewer, Kelly Stewart, said the author is "at her best when she dons her 'baboon spectacles' and describes what she sees. Selecting particular stars from her study troop of 60 animals, the Pumphouse Gang, she recounts anecdotes and mini-sagas from their lives in a socially complex, Machiavellian world." The result is "an entertaining and readable account of what life is like, not only for baboons, but for those who watch them."
THE GROTTO, by Coral Lansbury. (Ivy, $5.95.) Banished from Sicily to the Australian outback, Gwen Harcourt di Marineo, the daughter of archeologists, finds comfort in the ancient myths that preoccupied her as a child. Last year our reviewer, John Mortimer, said, "What gives 'The Grotto' its power is the presence of the old gods, shadowy as an undeveloped photograph, in the back of our minds, however far we may have traveled from the coasts where they were born."
COMPOSING A LIFE, by Mary Catherine Bateson. (Plume, $8.95.) The anthropologist daughter of Margaret Mead and Gregory Bateson tells the story of five extraordinary women, including herself, who have learned to think of life as an improvisational art. "She has an extremely interesting mind and the ability to express herself with extraordinary literary felicity," Jane O'Reilly said here last year.
AFTER YOU'VE GONE, by Alice Adams. (Fawcett Crest, $4.95.) These short stories are about people -- mostly professional women -- adjusting to the loss of lovers and friends. "I was struck by Ms. Adams's facility as a writer," Ron Carlson said here last year. Her stories have "a kind of knowing familiarity with estrangement and the blessings of time."
THE AMBITION AND THE POWER, by John M. Barry. (Penguin, $12.95.) A journalist granted close access to Jim Wright, the Speaker of the House who was forced from office in 1989, argues that Mr. Wright's accusers were less disturbed by his ethical lapses than by his effectivess and power. The book "spurs us to reflect on such things as the debasement of Congress in the 1980's and the periodic transformation of much of the American press into a school of circling, bloodthirsty sharks," Ronnie Dugger said here last year.
LEADER OF THE BAND, by Fay Weldon. (Penguin, $7.95) An astronomer named Starlady Sandra, discoverer of the planet Athena, runs off with a jazz musician named Mad Jack. Last year our reviewer, Robert Ward, said the heroine is "funny, charming and brilliant" though the novel as a whole is more clever than deep. Penguin has also republished Fay Weldon's earlier novel PRAXIS ($7.95), the story of Praxis Duveen, whose experiments with prostitution, incest and finally murder culminate in her anointing as a hero of the women's movement. In 1978 our reviewer, Katha Pollitt, said the book is "often dazzling, pointing up the mad underside of our sexual politics with a venomous accuracy for which wit is too mild a word."
PANATI'S BROWSER'S BOOK OF BEGINNINGS, by Charles Panati. (Houghton Mifflin, $8.95.) Where did ice cream and Islam come from? How about the typewriter, the Torah and the Tootsie Roll? When this quirky 427-page encyclopedia was published in 1984, The Times's Christopher Lehmann-Haupt said he came away from the book "bubbling with new information." "There are still people around who don't know that the Baby Ruth candy bar was named after President Grover Cleveland's daughter or that one of the earliest television broadcasts introduced Kate Smith singing 'When the Moon Comes Over the Mountain.' "
KISSES OF THE ENEMY, by Rodney Hall. (Fireside/ Simon & Schuster, $10.95.) In the not-too-distant future, the C.I.A. plots to turn Australia into a police state. "Shuttling between fantasy and grim realism, Mr. Hall projects a shocking picture of his country's future in a high-flying mixture of farce and fury, paranoia and verbal pyrotechnics," Pearl K. Bell said here in 1988.
SOMOZA FALLING: A Case Study of Washington at Work, by Anthony Lake. (University of Massachusetts, $11.95.) A former State Department official says that the classic conflict between political appointees and career foreign service officers led to the confusion that allowed Nicaragua to fall to the Sandinistas. "Mr. Lake's worthwhile study persuasively shows that it is State Department experts . . . who provide the rational equilibrium between technical experts and the idealistic policy makers," Pamela S. Falk said here last year. " 'Somoza Falling' is worthwhile reading for everyone interested in how the many decisions that become American foreign policy are made."
ONE STEP AHEAD IN CHINA: Guangdong Under Reform, by Ezra F. Vogel. (Harvard University, $12.95.) In 1987, a Harvard professor of international relations spent seven months in southeast China, trying to learn what economic and social reform in this industrial region said about the future of the country. Last year our reviewer, Alan S. Cohen, called the book "necessary reading for all Americans with an interest in China."

SECTION: Section 6; Page 22; Column 3; Magazine Desk

HEADLINE: On Language;
Isn't It Rich?

BYLINE: BY WILLIAM SAFIRE

 BODY:
"DON'T TAX YOU, don't tax me," goes the doggerel that former Senator Russell Long used to enjoy quoting. "Tax that feller behind the tree."
After months of peering and pointing, "that feller" turns out to be the rich. Who are they? 
 Some statisticians arbitrarily choose a family income of $80,000 a year as the affluence line (which I have just coined on the analogy of the poverty line), but magazines like Forbes and Fortune prefer making judgments of wealth on the basis of what people have rather than what they earn: $260 million is Forbes's cutoff this year for its "richest 400" list, though most people would apply the word rich to any old multimillionaire.
(There's a word that's fading fast in an era of megabucks. A nuance of its meaning is expressed in this joke: "My friend Sam is a multimillionaire." "No, Sam may be a millionaire, but he's nomultimillionaire. How much does he have in cash?" "Ten thousand dollars." "You're right -- he's a multimillionaire.")
In the Depression years of the early 30's, the rich was a term used by socialist and populist politicians as an epithet, especially in promoting progressive taxation. The first citation of the slogan soak the rich is from James P. Warburg's 1935 book, "Hell Bent for Election," in which President Franklin D. Roosevelt was charged with "being 'clever' when he tried to steal Huey Long's thunder by suddenly coming out with his 'soak the rich' tax message."
The use of quotes around the phrase suggests an earlier usage, perhaps by Huey Long, the Louisiana Governor, whose slogan was "Every Man a King"; Joe Klein of New York magazine informs me that the phrase was associated with Fiorello La Guardia's campaigning in the early 30's. If anyone can find a specific citation earlier than 1935, send it in; phrasedick immortality awaits.
When turned into a compound adjective, the slogan becomes an attack on the attack: a soak-the-rich scheme uses the phrase as a device to damn those who would unduly penalize the wealthy.
What's the difference between rich and wealthy? Webster's New World Dictionary holds that rich "is the general word for one who has more money or income-producing property than is necessary to satisfy his normal needs; wealthy adds to this connotations of grand living, influence in the community, a tradition of richness."
Perhaps that synonymy is true when the words are used as adjectives -- a rich family has to wait until its money ages before it becomes a wealthy family -- but when used by politicians as nouns, the wealthy is not nearly as rich a target as the rich. You never hear of "the filthy wealthy," or "get-wealthy-quick schemes." In any populist coupling of the needy and the greedy, it's the rich -- not the wealthy -- that gives a stump orator more polemical satisfaction. Today, the wealthy are spoken of with less of an envious sneer than the rich.
Affluent is a bookish term, given a high-domed academic air by John Kenneth Galbraith's "Affluent Society," and its subsequent alliterative use in "the age of affluence." No sloganeer would offer "soak the affluent" (although "marinate the affluent" might go as a bumper sticker in some hyper-educated, low-income areas along the Charles River).
How do rich people describe their own economic circumstances? Out of modesty, a repugnance for ostentation or a desire to hide from the revenooers, most would demur from any identification as being rich or wealthy, reserving those words for those nouveau-riche showoffs down the street with the opulent life style. The preferred admission, rather than assertion, of high economic status is "I'm well-to-do." A New York Times editorialist, sensing the political heft in the harsh word rich, wrote of the budget agreement: "Well-to-do families will pay more for Medicare, setting a constructive precedent."
Curiously, rich has long had a slang sense of "paradoxical, rich in irony" (using rich there to mean "full of, abundant in"). Stephen Sondheim's lyric to "Send in the Clowns" begins "Isn't it rich," meaning "catch this irony" or "isn't this something to make you shake your head in amused dismay."
Although rich is a term wriggled away from by those in the moneyed class who are loaded (a slang term that carries a connotation of admiration), the same rich is mandatory in all commercials for coffee. Copywriters can leave out full-bodied and try any number of synonyms for delicious, but skip rich and the client is sure to invite in a new agency. (The Squad Squad will find "invite in" redundant, but it is an acceptable shortening of "to ask someone to come in and deliver a presentation to a client that expects rich in every commercial.")
 
Mare Nostrum
 "IN YOUR COMMENTARY," wrote Habib Ladjevardi to Dan Rather of CBS, "you said that the President would be speaking on the situation in 'the Arabian Gulf, also known as the Persian Gulf.' I believe this is the first time that any of the networks have referred to the Persian Gulf as the Arabian Gulf."
Mr. Ladjevardi, associate director of the Center for Middle Eastern Studies at Harvard, noted that the term Arabian Gulf was the choice of the late President Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt and is now commonly used by Iraq's Saddam Hussein. "I am puzzled," he wrote, "by the introduction of the term Arabian Gulf by an American broadcasting company at this particular moment in history, especially since it coincides with your return from a visit to the Middle East."
When a copy of this note was vouchsafed to me by one of my academic moles, I queried CBS News. The network researcher tried National Geographic, which lists only Persian Gulf, but hit pay dirt with Webster's New Geographical Dictionary, which lists both Persian Gulf and Arabian Gulf as the same body of water.
"Our position is that Arabian Gulf is acceptable," says a CBS spokesman, Tom Goodman, "as long as we also explain that it is the Persian Gulf that's being identified. Persian Gulf is the standard name, and it requires no further explanation."
That's odd; it's like saying "Gotham, also known as New York City."
It strikes me that Saddam Hussein does not want to admit that the gulf in question has a special association with Persia, also known as Iran, a nation with which he just fought an eight-year war. The object of that war was access to that waterway; Iraq, having gained substantial access through Kuwait, has given back the narrow access it had won from Iran. By calling it the Arabian Gulf, Mr. Hussein (as The New York Times likes to refer to Saddam) lays linguistic claim to it on behalf of Arabs -- and Iranians are Persians, not Arabs. Mr. Rather apparently did not want to take sides and introduced this note of confusion into the nomenclature.
If history is used to decide the name, CBS is aware of the ancient appellation: Sinus Persicus, for "Persian bend." In the interests of peace and amity, I have a suggestion: how about the Gulf of Kurdistan?

SECTION: Section 2; Page 36; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1214 words

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
In Beverly Hills, A Theme Park For Rich Adults

BYLINE: By Paul Goldberger

DATELINE: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.

 BODY:
IF JUDITH KRANTZ HAD DESIGNED Disneyland, it would have turned out like Two Rodeo Drive. Whatever else can be said about this super-upscale shopping mall, whose first stores opened last month, it is surely the ultimate synthesis of the major Southern California fantasies: Disneyland crossed with Rodeo Drive. This place is not really a mall at all; it is more a kind of theme park for rich adults, a grown-ups' version of Disneyland's Main Street in which the attraction is not fake Victorian buildings filled with souvenir shops but architecturally ambitious stone and brick facades housing expensive and status-y boutiques.
 The first impulse is to dismiss this $200 million shopping complex as nothing more than the hopelessly silly expression of Beverly Hills hedonism. Well, it is the hopelessly silly expression of Beverly Hills hedonism, but it is also quite a lot else. And the more time you spend walking around it, the more seriously you begin to take it, both as a work of design in itself and as the manifestation of certain ideas that tell us a great deal about Los Angeles's yearnings.
 
 The complex, which occupies 1.25 acres at the intersection of Rodeo Drive and Wilshire Boulevard across the street from the Regent Beverly Wilshire Hotel, was designed by the architectural firms of Kaplan McLaughlin Diaz of San Francisco and Brand & Allen of Houston. But the basic concept came from the prime developer, Douglas L. Stitzel of San Francisco, who envisioned filling this trapezoidal site with a huge structure that would look to the pedestrian not like a single building but like a pair of streets lined with shops.
 Let it be said at the outset: this is one of the best pieces of stage-set architecture since Disneyland. The architects and Mr. Stitzel have come up with a series of shop fronts that meander through architectural history, with brief stops in classicism and the Beaux-Arts, a quick detour to a kind of Mediterranean architecture, and then a long, lingering stay in the Art Moderne of the 1920's and 30's. That style, a kind of stripped-down, simplified classicism enlivened by Art Deco touches, yields a section of the complex for Tiffany & Company that is a knockoff of Tiffany's great limestone store on Fifth Avenue, this version contorted in shape to meet the unusual angle of the site. But Art Moderne's 1930's-style mix of dignity and verve feels just right for Beverly Hills -- there is plenty of the real thing in the older shops nearby, like I. Magnin and Van Cleef & Arpels -- and it is interpreted inventively here.
 Actually everything is interpreted inventively here: that's the reason it is impossible not to like Two Rodeo more than you expect to. It's just too well done. If the concept of the place seems disingenuous, the reality is not. Two Rodeo is hardly innocent -- it is knowing and calculated in its manipulation of architectural sentiment -- but it does it so well that you are willingly swept up into its game. This is a place to wallow in, whatever your views of consumerism and the culture of Beverly Hills.
 The overall layout is ingenious. Mr. Stitzel realized, as all retail developers do, that the money in retail projects lay in ground-floor space. He also knew that there wasn't room for enough ground-floor space on this small site to justify the price of $500 per square foot of potential rentable space he would eventually pay. (Originally a hotel had been planned, until community protests led the City of Beverly Hills to rule out tall buildings on this site.) Mr. Stitzel's economic and architectural solution was elegantly simple -- to contort his retail complex into a structure that would have two separate ground floors.
 The first ground floor is on Rodeo Drive itself, in a row of storefronts that looks essentially like any row of elegant, older retail buildings on Madison Avenue in New York . The gimmick is in what is behind these storefronts, a new, curving street, called Via Rodeo, that slopes upward so that the ground floors of its buildings are actually the second floors of the buildings facing Rodeo Drive. Via Rodeo, which is paved with stone and lined with ornate, old-fashioned lamps, is a full story above Rodeo Drive. It begins as a gentle slope at one end of the project; at the other end, it descends to Wilshire Boulevard in the form of a grand marble staircase flanked by a fountain.
 Is this Beverly Hills pretending to be Italy? Of course it is. For all its existence Beverly Hills has pretended to be someplace else. That is why it feels like Beverly Hills: because this place is trying so hard to feel like somewhere else, we know we are really in Southern California. But this aspiring slice of Rome, mixed with a hint of New Bond Street, the rue Faubourg St.-Honore and Madison Avenue -- not to a mention a whiff of the Belgian Village from the 1964 New York World's Fair -- is so exuberant and so earnest in its fakery that if it seems cynical in concept, it comes off as endearing in actuality.
 Underneath the whole thing is a parking garage, naturally, and not just any old parking garage. This one offers a circular entrance and valet parking by attendants in spiffy suspenders who, after taking your car, point your way toward a marble lobby and elevators up to Via Rodeo. The elevators open into a Mediterranean-style tower set into a mock-Italian piazza that is at the highest point of the project, from which visitors can either saunter down the gentle slope of Via Rodeo or descend the marble staircase to Wilshire Boulevard.
 What could be more perfect? At Two Rodeo Drive, you can drive your car right into a real urban experience. From valet parking to street life -- here is the dream of the 20th century fulfilled. After all, if only there were valet parking underneath Madison Avenue, New York might be more bearable.
 There never will be valet parking underneath Madison Avenue, of course, because life doesn't work that way. Madison Avenue, the rue Faubourg St.-Honore and the other great shopping streets of the world are real places, with real histories that have grown and developed over time. They possess the authenticity of real cities, but also the harshness, the inconvenience, the difficulty of real places. Two Rodeo Drive is altogether different, an exercise in make-believe -- a private realm, like Disneyland, in which everything can be made seductively perfect.
 Twenty-five years ago, in a remarkable essay entitled "You Have to Pay for the Public Life," the architect Charles Moore observed that Disneyland, though a private place, was the ultimate piece of public architecture in Southern California, since it was the one place in that land of freeways and detached houses in which it was possible to have a conventional urban experience. The same can surely be said of the Two Rodeo Drive complex: for all its falseness, it represents a yearning for urbanity, a desire to make a place that, however suburban it may be in reality, at least feels like a city. Mr. Stitzel wanted to build a real urban street, not a covered suburban mall, and on some level or other he has succeeded. It is a particular paradox of Beverly Hills that it takes a stage set to convey a sense of real urbanity.
