HEADLINE: WINTER IN THE SNOW;
Stretching Dollars on the Slopes

BYLINE: By STANLEY CARR

 BODY:
NOW that the economy has turned chilly, ski resorts across the country are concentrating less on expansion and investment -- popular words in ski country in the 80's -- and more on attractive pricing to please skiers with tighter belts. A flurry of discounts, deals and packages indicates that budget conscious skiers can do well shopping around and bargain hunting in the coming season.
One strategy for cutting costs is to plan a vacation during the shoulder or value periods, which are before Christmas, some weeks in January -- with dates varying from mountain to mountain -- and the latter part of the season. At these times lodging and packages that include lodging and lift tickets are cheaper. Prices are generally lower in midweek than on weekends. At many mountains, first-time skiers qualify for free or discounted group lessons and rental skis, poles and boots. In New England several areas are offering a free lesson and rentals during the week of Dec. 15 to 21. 
 One trend at many resorts is offering free accommodations and lift tickets for children when their parents take rooms and buy lift tickets. More and more skiers are renting condominiums on or near the slopes and squeezing in another couple of guests in, say, a one-bedroom unit.
Most major ski centers now have toll-free 800 central reservation numbers that are sources for price-cutting packages that may not be listed in brochures. Packages can include everything from lodging to rented skis, and sometimes air fare, at far lower cost than when the components are purchased separately. Taos in New Mexico has a seven-night trip with air fare from New York at $1,698 that would be between $350 and $450 more if an individual pulled arrangements together.
Consumer ski organizations and ski clubs with discount plans for members are other avenues to cost cutting. At many places members get discounts of $2 to $4 a day on lift tickets and reductions at hotels and restaurants that are generally 10 to 15 percent but sometimes much higher. Discounts are usually lower during peak times and on weekends and holidays. Among these consumer ski organizations are:
The American Ski Association, 64 Inverness Drive East, Englewood, Colo. 80112 (800-525-7669 or 303-397-7669), which issues the SkiAmericard, good for reductions on lifts, lodging, ski rentals and dining at about 300 resorts and for some air fares. The card costs $30 a year for the first purchaser in a group or family, $15 for the second and $10 for each additional. (The association also offers a ShredAmericard used by snowboarders at the same prices.)
The United States Recreational Ski Association, 1315 East Pacifico Avenue, Anaheim, Calif. 92805 (714-634-1050), acts as a watchdog for skiers' interests as well as offering discounts at more than 100 ski areas. Members get $5 off lift tickets and reductions on lodgings at some resorts and on some packages. A membership card costs $34, $60 for two, or $75 for a family.
Ski Card International, Box 3369, Evergreen, Colo. 80439 (800-333-2754) offers cardholders discounts on lifts, lodging and other resort purchases, a $50 rebate on some Continental Airlines ski packages and 15 percent off some ski trips to Europe. In fall and winter the Ski Card costs $40 for the first purchaser, $35 for the second, $30 for the third; in spring members may renew at half price.
National Ski Card, Box 17574, Denver, Colo. 80217 (303-825-0944), charges $6.95 for its book of discount coupons for lifts, lessons and other ski costs at hundreds of ski areas. At Breckenridge, Colo., cardholders get discounts on the lifts every day of the season, from $7 a day in peak weeks to $14 in off-peak. At Stratton Mountain in Vermont, lifts are reduced $5 or $7 a day.
Dan Ferley, president of National Ski Card, said reductions on lodgings are as high as 50 percent at some locations. His organization, which also runs a discount travel company offering ski packages with cut-rate air fares, had 890,000 members in the 1989-90 season, he said.
Linda Ekanger, of the American Ski Association, estimates that less than 20 percent of Coloradans who ski pay full price for lift tickets, and says out-of-state skiers are increasingly picking up on the in-state deals.
One of the most popular ways Coloradans save is by buying Gold C books every fall. The books, which cost $9 apiece, are fat with coupons offering savings of 20 to 50 percent on one-day lift tickets, ski equipment, lessons and lodging at nearly 20 Colorado resorts. The books, which are sold locally, usually as part of various fund-raising events, are also available from Gold C Saving Spree, 1670 York Street, Denver, Colo. 80206 (303-388-4668). Gold C charges $1 for postage or $2 for priority mail.
Safeway and King Soopers supermarkets, Vickers gasoline stations and Pizza Huts in the Denver area sell lift tickets at selected ski areas that are reduced by $2 to $5 a day. Tickets purchased from the supermarkets are fully refundable if they are not used, unlike those purchased in multiday ski-lift packages. For store locations and the ski areas discounted, call Safeway at 800-444-3211 or 303-843-7600, or King Soopers at 303-698-3454 or 3470.
The following survey presents a selection of discounted packages and rate reductions at ski areas in the Northeast, West and Canada.
 
THE WEST
 
CALIFORNIA
SQUAW VALLEY USA
Squaw Valley, Calif. 95730
800-545-4350, central reservations; 916-583-6955, snow conditions
 Cutting Costs:: Although the resort has a reputation for Olympic caliber racing, beginning and intermediate level skiing is available, and a Fun in the Sun program gives first-time skiers free lifts, lessons and rental equipment on weekdays in nonholiday periods. The instruction is given at several checkpoints spread out at the top of the cable-car run. There's a similar program on weekends costing $20 a person.
The Squaw Valley Hostel, scheduled to open at Thanksgiving within walking distance of the lifts, will offer dormitory-style lodging with 95 beds at $15 a night and $5 extra for linens. There are a few small rooms for 2 to 4 people and some larger ones sleeping 20 to 25. Bathrooms are shared.
Discounts are offered on lift tickets purchased midweek or in multiday packages. Usual cost: $38, full-day; $26, half-day; children 12 and under and skiers 65 and over, $10; cable car or gondola ride for nonskiers, $10 and $5 for children.
Modeled after European resorts, Squaw Valley USA offers two villages at different elevations, both overlooking Lake Tahoe. Six peaks and 4,000 acres of open bowl are served by 32 lifts, including a 150-passenger aerial cable car, the six-passenger Super Gondola and 3 high-speed quads.
With a lift capacity of 47,000 an hour, the resort guarantees no waiting in line -- or your money back. The vertical drop is 2,850 feet and the longest run is three miles. Ski season is mid-November through May.
What's New: The Resort at Squaw Creek, a 405-room deluxe lodge at 6,200 feet, opens Dec. 14. Prices start at $195 a night for two. A triple lift connects the new resort to the Squaw Valley ski complex, where eight new trails for intermediate skiers have been added. The Olympic Ice Pavillion, an Olympic-size outdoor ice-skating rink at the top of the cable car, at 8,200 feet, offers two hours of skating for $5. Two heated tennis courts have been added adjacent to the rink.
 
COLORADO
ASPEN
Aspen Skiing Company, Post Office Box 1248, Aspen, Colo. 81612.
800-262-7736, information and reservations; 303-925-1221 for snow report
 Cutting Costs: This season the Aspen Skiing Company raised the cost of a one-day lift ticket to $40, securing Aspen's reputation as the most expensive place in the country to ski. The new lift price is a $4 increase over last season. But hold on -- reputations are not all that they seem, even in Aspen. "You can pay $40 a day," says an Aspen official, "but only if you are dumb." In one break from past years, Aspen is hawking the discounts more and the deluxe a little less, and reflecting a current trend at many resorts, the latest innovations at Aspen are more likely to be related to pricing than to slopeside technology.
For the first time, skiers aged 70 and over and children under 6 can ski free. A six-out-of-seven-day lift ticket costs $216, or $204 if purchased in advance for the value season, which is the same price as last year. The best way to ski for less in Aspen is to vacation during the "value season," which occupies a full 50 percent of the ski year -- the weeks before Christmas, the month of January and April. The resort recently published its "Insiders Tips for Experiencing Aspen on a Budget" to help visitors find the affordable. To receive this listing of moderately priced lodgings and restaurants, write to: Terri Hart Roberts, Aspen Skiing Company, at the address above.
Another way to cut costs is to purchase a SkiAmericard, which offers discounts on lodging, equipment and food in the Aspen area (and at many other Colorado ski resorts).
Skiing in Aspen offers the opportunity of skiing on one or all of four distinct mountains: Aspen Highlands, Aspen Mountain, Buttermilk and Snowmass, 12 miles down valley. Aspen Mountain, which rises to an elevation of 11,212 from its base 3,267 feet below, is rated for intermediate and expert skiers only. Beginners and low intermediate skiers head for Aspen Highlands, which has a vertical drop of 3,800 feet, or Buttermilk, which has a summit at 9,900 feet and a vertical drop of 2,030 feet.
 
COPPER MOUNTAIN
Post Office Box 3001, Copper Mountain, Colo. 80443
800-458-8386; snow report, 303-968-2100
 Cutting Costs: The official lift price is $33 for adults and $16 for children, but the Gold C coupon book includes many discounts for Copper. The books, which cost $9 apiece, offer savings of 20 to 30 percent on lift passes, rentals, lessons and food. The books are sold locally as part of fund-raising events but are also available from Gold C Saving Spree, 1760 York Street, Denver, Colo. 80206 (303-388-4668). The SkiAmericard, which earns a $7 discount on an adult lift ticket and reductions at some lodgings and restaurants, is also honored at Copper.
The resort offers several new packages allowing children under age 12 to ski free -- from opening day until Dec. 14 and from Jan. 2 to Feb. 14 -- if they share a room with parents who buy lift tickets. Skiers aged 60 to 69 can get a lift pass for $20; those over 70 ski free.
Seventy-five miles from Denver and just off Interstate 70, Copper Mountain is a favorite of Front Range residents because of its fairly long runs and accessibility. The mountain rises to a summit of 12,360 feet from its 9,600-foot base, with a vertical drop of 2,760 feet. The longest run is 2.8 miles. There are 20 lifts, including two high-speed quads and six triple chairlifts. The resort includes a Club Med.
What's New: Copper is nearing the end of a five-year, $40 million expansion, which this season includes the opening -- in February -- of the Day Lodge-Conference Center housing meeting rooms, cafeteria and lounge.
 
PURGATORY-DURANGO
Post Office Box 666, Durango, Colo. 81302
800-525-0892 for all reservations and snow report
 Cutting Costs: Purgatory-Durango, which normally draws skiers from the Southwest, offers seven-night, six-day or five-night, four-day package trips that include air fare between Denver or Albuquerque and the Durango airport, about 45 miles from the slopes. Air fare from Denver, lodging in the town of Durango (25 miles from the mountain), lift tickets and transportation to and from the Durango airport start at $365 a person for seven nights and go up to $558 for slopeside accommodations. A five-night plan with air fare between Albuquerque and Durango costs from $257 a person, with lodging in Durango, lift tickets and transfers. Also, by making arrangements through the toll-free number, skiers save 20 percent on lessons and equipment rental. Limited discounts on lift tickets and lessons are available with the Ski-Americard. The posted lift ticket price is $34, $17 for children and $20 for seniors.
Tucked into a seam of the San Juan Mountains in southwest Colorado, Purgatory-Durango is as far off the beaten track as Copper Mountain is right on it. The area boasts no high-speed quad chairs; since there are never any lift lines, says a resort spokesman, Purgatory does not need the machinery to move people up quickly. Trails are somewhat narrower than at other areas, which enhances the scenery and the solitude without making skiers feel like they are skiing down a chute.
The mountain's base is 8,793 feet, and rises to 10,822. The longest ski run is two miles.
 
SNOWMASS
c/o Aspen Skiing Company, Post Office Box 1248, Aspen, Colo. 81612
303-925-1220 for information, 303-925-1220 for snow report
 Cutting Costs: Price reductions are offered through SkiAmericard. The resort is also discounting lessons at its Family Ski School by 10 percent for four or more family members.
At the base of Snowmass Village is the Snowmass Lodge and Club, with indoor tennis, pool and fitness center, and a special offer of lift tickets. The club's rates begin at about $150 a night in value season and $225 in peak season and include two to six free lift tickets per day, depending on the number of bedrooms in the unit.
Although Snowmass is owned by the Aspen Skiing Company, its distance from Aspen, the town, and the vast, open terrain make it a ski area unto itself. It is also one of the largest mountains, with a lift capacity of more than 20,000 people an hour via three fast quad lifts, two triple chairs, nine double chairs and two platter pulls.
Snowmass Mountain rises to a summit of 11,835 feet, from a base at 8,220 feet. Its longest run is 4.1 miles. Nine percent of the terrain is rated for beginners, 51 percent is for intermediates, and the remaining 40 percent for the advanced.
What's New: Added this season is a half-pipe for the growing number of snowboarders.
 
VAIL
Post Office Box 7, Vail, Colo. 81658
800-525-2257 or 303-949-5750 (extension 4030 for reservations)
 Cutting Costs: To reduce expenses at Vail it is best to schedule a seven-night, six-day stay before Christmas, during January, or in early spring. The cheapest package during these times is $518 a person, including lodging, lift tickets, taxes and ground transportation from Eagle County Airport.
The official one-day adult lift ticket price is $38, but the multiple-day packages reduce the price to $35 a day. Skiers aged 65 to 69 ski for $28 a day, and skiers over 70 ski free.
Discounts on lift tickets on certain days -- savings of $12 to $18 for an adult and $6 for a child -- are available with Gold C coupon books. The books, sold locally for $9 and are also available from Gold C Saving Spree, 1760 York Street, Denver, Colo. 80206 (303-388-4668). They are also good for discounts on cross-country skiing fees.
Vail, the largest ski area on a single mountain in the United States, has a lift capacity of 35,820 skiers an hour. The mountain's base is at 8,200 feet, its top elevation is 11,450, for a vertical rise of 3,250 feet. The longest run is 4.5 miles.
What's New: Beginning Dec. 15, American Airlines will fly daily, nonstop 757's from Chicago and Dallas to Vail's Eagle County Airport, enabling skiers originating their trips in the East to miss the snarls at Denver's Stapleton Airport and the 100 miles of driving between Denver and the resort.
As with many other ski resorts, there has been little in the way of slopeside improvements at Vail or its sister resort Beaver Creek this year. The relatively modest addition of a half-pipe at both Vail and Beaver Creek is good news for snowboarders. Four new lodges are opening at Beaver Creek: Beaver Creek Lodge this month, Camberley Club Hotel in December, and Borders Lodge and St. James Place in February.
 
IDAHO
 
SILVER MOUNTAIN
610 Bunker Avenue, Kellogg, Idaho 83837-2200
208-783-1111; snow report, 800-678-8633
 Cutting Costs: The Coeur d'Alene Resort, a half hour's drive from the slopes, offers some good deals on lodging for visitors to Silver Mountain, opening this month -- the first new major ski area in the United States in a decade. The midweek package at $109.99 a person includes two days of lifts and lodging for two nights, Continental breakfast, bottle of champagne and transportation to the mountain. On weekends a similar two-night package is $149.95. A five-day package at $289.95 a person includes lifts and lodging and similar extras. The Holiday Inn in Coeur d'Alene offers a $108 two-night lifts-lodging plan that comes with Continental breakfast and transportation to the slopes. The Wallace Inn has two-day lift-lodging plans priced from $124.50 a person midweek, and $134.50 weekends.
A gondola running for 3.1 miles moves skiers between the town of Kellogg and the ski area on Kellogg Peak, which is in Idaho's northwestern panhandle. (The gondola was funded in part by a $6.4 million Federal grant aimed to rejuvenate this economically depressed, former silver mining town.) Four chairlifts serve 43 runs on 2,000 skiable acres. The mountain, which encompasses the former Silverhorn ski area, is rated 15 percent beginner, 45 percent intermediate and 40 percent advanced. Along with the downhill runs are meadows left untouched for powder hounds.
 There is limited lodging in the small town of Kellogg. Many visitors will choose to stay in the Coeur d'Alene, a larger community at the edge of a 26-mile-long lake, 30 minutes from the slopes.
Daily lift tickets (9 A.M. to 10 P.M.) are $26; $19 for juniors aged 7 to 17, college students and people 65 and older. Half-day tickets are $19, and $15 for juniors, college students and seniors. Children 6 and under ski free.
 
SUN VALLEY
Sun Valley, Idaho 83353
208-622-4111; for reservations at Sun Valley Company properties, 800-786-8259; or for other properties in Sun Valley or Ketchum, 800-634-3347
 Cutting Costs: Parents should take their teen-agers because at Sun Valley the Kids Stay and Ski Free program is open to children 17 and younger. A maximum of two children per parent can ski and stay free when a family lodges in a participating hotel or condominium from Nov. 22 to Dec. 23, Jan. 1 to Feb. 9 and March 17 to May 1. At lodges in Ketchum the youngsters' program is limited to skiing -- not staying -- free.
Sun Valley's seven-night theme-week packages used to be limited to groups. Now they are open to individuals. The $320-a-person Prime Time Special from Jan. 5 to 12, for skiers aged 60 and more, includes lodging, a five-of-six-day lift ticket, Big Band dinner dance and a race. The It Happened in Sun Valley package, Jan. 12 to 19, is just for singles. Rates start at $326 a person for lodging, lifts and parties. Packages also start at $326 for Winter Carnival, Jan. 19 to 26, the resort's major winter festival; and Western Ski Club Week (open to anyone), from Jan. 26 to Feb. 2, with its barn dance and country swing lessons.
Sun Valley's first poster, showing a man stripped to the waist skiing in sunny weather, popularized the resort to a wealthy crowd who loved "roughing it" -- as long as there were luxuries like wind-protected outdoor pools, fine dining and an orchestra playing nightly. You can still find these amenities, along with modernized access to spectacular skiing in several vast bowls and many challenging trails. A few years ago, Sun Valley replaced several aging lifts with high-speed quads. Today, 10 lifts march up the main mountain, 3,400-vertical-foot Baldy; another 4 are strung on Dollar Mountain (628 vertical feet), popular with novices.
Lodging is grouped in four loose pods. Most of the more luxurious accommodations are in Sun Valley, a village a short shuttle-bus ride from the slopes. There's also lodging at the base of the Warm Springs lifts, at the base of Dollar Mountain (a short ride from Baldy) and in Ketchum.
Daily lift tickets are $38; $21 for children, $22 for those 65 and older on Baldy; $21 and $15 for children on Dollar. Half-day tickets are $28; $15 for children on Baldy; $21 and $15 for children on Dollar. On Baldy, six-of-seven-day tickets are $198, $102 for children,
What's New: New this year, from Dec. 15, is daily Skywest Airlines service between Salt Lake City and Sun Valley. The four daily round-trip flights on Skywest are timed to connect with Delta Air Lines flights into Salt Lake. This season Sun Valley regulars will notice changes on the Warm Springs side of Baldy Mountain. The Limelight chair was removed and the Limelight run recontoured, part of the Hemingway trail was reshaped and Cozy was lengthened. A computerized snowmaking system was installed and the man-made snow should enable an earlier opening of more terrain.
 
NEW MEXICO
 
TAOS
Taos Ski Valley, N. M. 87525
505-776-2291; reservations, 800-992-7669 or, in state, 505-776-2233
 Cutting Costs: Skiers get 20 percent off lifts, lodging and ski school from Nov. 25 to Dec. 21, and from March 31 to April 7, at some properties in the valley, including the Hotel St. Bernard. Other reductions are available at other lodges, among them Hotel Edelweiss and Thunderbird Lodge. From Jan. 5 to Feb. 2, visitors get approximately 10 percent off five- and six-day lift-lodging-lessons packages at participating lodges. The most popular packages in the valley include seven nights' lodging, three meals daily, six days of lifts and half-day lessons. The lodges in the town of Taos offer nightly rates or lift-lodging packages of from three to seven nights. Round-trip flights between major cities and Albuquerque and a rental car are included in many packages.
A visit including round-trip air fare from New York with seven nights' lodging at the Thunderbird, three meals, car, lift tickets and lessons in regular season will cost $1,698 a person, with taxes and gratuities. Three nights' lodging and three days' skiing without the extras and not including tax is $177 a person, double occupancy.
Perhaps the best small resort in the United States, Taos melds exhilarating skiing and ski-school classes that even advanced skiers like to attend, with a taste of Southwestern food and art. Condos and small hotels snug up to the slopes that sprawl across one of the mountain peaks enclosing this box canyon. Eight chairs and two surface lifts open up the slopes, bowls and chutes on 2,612-foot vertical mountain. There are wide-open intermediate trails, but Taos's fame comes from the advanced terrain covering 51 percent of the mountain.
Most guests eat meals where they are staying and spend the week in ski school with the same group. But if you're the type of vacationer with a high-energy apres-ski level, stay in the town of Taos, 25 minutes down the canyon past the Taos Pueblo. There's bus service to the ski valley for skiers who don't want to drive themselves.
Daily lift ticket rates are $32, and $17 for children 12 and younger; half-day rates are $20 and $12 for children. Skiers aged 65 to 69 pay $10; those 70 or older ski free. Multiday lift tickets (three days or more) are $29 a day and $15 for children.
What's New: A new chairlift, Seventh Heaven, stretches from the top of chair 7 on the mountain's backside to the top of chair 6 at the summit. Now skiers on the backside can ride to the summit and ski down the front side; before they had to make a long traverse around the base of the mountain. Snowmaking has been added around the top of chair 7 as part of a long-term plan to insure top-to-bottom coverage.
 
OREGON
 
MOUNT HOOD MEADOWS
Post Office Box 470, Mount Hood, Ore. 97041-0470
503-337-2222; snow conditions, 503-227-7669; hotel reservations, Mount Hood Recreation Association, 503-622-3162
 Cutting Costs: For $39, skiers can skip driving to the mountain through the Bus-Lift program (503-287-5438). The package is available on weekends and holidays, November through February, and includes a round-trip bus ride from five Portland locations -- the city is 67 miles to the west -- and an all-day lift ticket.
Lift tickets are $25 a day; $29 day-night (until 10 P.M.); $18 half-day (Monday and Tuesday); children, $15; seniors, half price on all tickets. Ticketmaster and ski shops sell Express Tickets for $24 for the day-night session. Group rates for 25 people start at $21.
For $84 on weekdays, The Inn at Cooper Spur, in the town of Mount Hood, offers cabins and lift tickets for two. The Resort at the Mountain, in Welches, offers a double room, with two lift tickets and free shuttle, for $106. Timberline, a 50-year-old rustic hotel, is the only overnight resort lodge on the mountain. A room for two costs $105.
The resort, on the southeast slope of Mount Hood, offers a no-frills approach to skiing. There are no snowmaking machines, just 2,150 acres of natural snow-covered terrain, a panoramic view of the Cascade Mountain Range, and 26 kilometers of Nordic trails that wind past lakes, frozen waterfalls and streams.
It is the largest and most diverse of three resorts on the mountain -- the others are Timberline and Ski Bowl -- with nine lifts carrying 14,400 skiers an hour. The vertical drop is 2,777 feet, and the longest run is three miles. Vouchers are available for the other two resorts. The ski season is mid-November through mid-May.
Two large day lodges house snack bars, sports shops, lounges and restaurants. The Finish Line Bar and Grill features an 18-by-120-foot glass wall with a view of the summit. The Try Before You Buy Demo Center allows sampling of equipment from a variety of ski, boot and snowboard manufacturers.
What's New: A slow-development policy means few changes from year to year. All three resorts prefer to maintain a back-to-nature ambiance.
 
UTAH
 
SNOWBASIN
Post Office Box 348, Huntsville, Utah 84317
801-399-1135; snow report, 801-399-0198
 Cutting Costs: On the slopes, Snowbasin offers a package for never-ever skiers that offers group lesson, lift and rentals for $12 from Nov. 26 to Dec. 23 and $15 the rest of the season.
At the Jackson Fork Inn, at the base of the mountain road, $450 buys five days' lifts and four nights' lodging for two people in a room with a jacuzzi bath. Packages at the Wolf Lodge Condos in Odgen Valley, 10 miles from Ogden, start at $395 for two for four days of lifts, three nights' lodging and a rental car from Salt Lake City airport. Lodging in Odgen ranges from under $30 at a Motel 6 to the Radisson Suite Hotel's $385 package for two consisting of lift tickets for five days, four nights' lodging in a two-room suite and full breakfast.
There are attractive lodging rates in Salt Lake City, about an hour and a half from the mountain. Room rates at the Doubletree are $89 a night on weekdays, $69 on weekends, and include a full breakfast. Rooms at the Marriott go from $125 on weekdays and $88 on weekends. At Little America Hotel and Towers, rates are $95 on weekdays, $85 on weekends. At the Howard Johnson Hotel at Temple Square rooms start at $52. Nendels Inn rooms cost from $42 to $52. Many of the hotels and motels in Salt Lake City offer packages with lodging and lift tickets at several nearby ski areas.
Snowbasin is what skiing was about before glitz was added to the sport. Although the trail map lists only 39 runs, most of the 2,400-vertical-foot mountain is skiable. Five chairlifts reach the trails, bowls and glades of fir and aspen. On a clear day, your ski tips will frame the jewel called Pineview Reservoir, set in the unpopulated Odgen Valley 1,000 feet below.
Snowbasin was an area for Ogden residents until the opening of Trappers' Loop Road (State Route 167) shortened the drive from Salt Lake City. Now Salt Lake skiers who hate crowds come here, especially on weekends, when a lift line of a dozen bodies affronts the regulars.
There are no accommodations at the slopes, and limited lodging and night life in the Ogden valley. Many skiers stay in Ogden, 25 minutes away, or Salt Lake City. Visitors need a car to visit Snowbasin.
Snowbasin's daily lift tickets are $21, $15 for children 11 and under. Half-day tickets are $17, $13 for children.
 
SNOWBIRD
Snowbird Ski Resort, Snowbird, Utah 84092-6019
800-453-3000, central reservatons; other information and snow report 801-742-2222
 Cutting Costs: Children 12 and under, lodging in their parents' room, ski free when the parents buy lift tickets -- one child per adult ticket. The American Express lift and lodging packages start at $44 a person, double occupancy, a day during the "value seasons" from opening day to Dec. 20, and April 5-27. The Chickadee chairlift, which serves beginners' terrain, is always free. The Snowbird Host program offers free two-hour tours during which guests are shown runs and lifts best suited to their abilities.
The Snowbird resort's base village is a 20th-century creation: a concrete citadel guarding a narrow gap in Little Cottonwood Canyon. Access to the runs stretching up the side of the canyon is aboard a cable-car tram and seven chairlifts. While many first-time visitors feel that the slopes, especially the difficult runs under the tram, look "heart-stoppingly" steep, there are miles of intermediate trails reached by the chairs.
Toward the end of the day, skiers often fill the massage rooms in the Cliff Spa at Snowbird, which offers a range of treatments including herbal and parafango wraps.
Unspoiled Alta ski area, noted for a cheap lift ticket ($21), is three miles along the canyon via shuttle bus. The Mormons' Temple Square and other downtown Salt Lake City sights are a 30-minute bus ride in the opposite direction.
Snowbird's all-lift tickets, which include use of the tram, are $35; chairs only, $28. Children 12 and under and people 62 and older pay $20 for an all-lift ticket; $15 for chairs only. Half-day tickets (morning or afternoon) are $28 all-lifts; $22 chairs only. Children and older people pay $15 all-lifts; $13 chairs only. Skiers 70 and over ski free.
What's New: This winter there's a new run for intermediate skiers in the Tiger Trail area off the Gad II lift. Improved grooming and better signs will make it easier for intermediates to ski from the tram, down a trail that crisscrosses advanced terrain so they can watch expert skiers' styles. All Snowbird guests can use the indoor tennis and racquetball courts at the recently purchased Canyon Racquet Club.
 
THE NORTHEAST
 
MAINE
SUNDAY RIVER
Post Office Box 450, Bethel, Me. 04217
207-824-3000; reservations, 800-543-2754; 207-824-6400, snow reports
 Cutting Costs: Skiers on a budget can head for the Snowcap Lodge, a dormitory with 164 bunks within walking distance of the lifts. Blocks of bunks are often allocated to groups; the remainder are available at $20 a person a night in midweek and $25 on weekends. Each of the lodge's rooms, which have four to eight bunks, has a shared bath.
The ski area is introducing a number of cost-cutting packages, ranging from weekend and ski-lift inclusive cut-price deals to 10 percent off for residents of Connecticut during its school vacation week.
Condominium accommodations near the trails, from studios for two people to three-bedroom units for up to eight people, are offered. A package combining a room with lift tickets can be set up for a two- , three- or four-night weekend, or a five-night midweek package for adults or juniors (ages 6 to 12). Sunday River's Perfect Turn Discovery package and its Guaranteed Learn-to-Ski program are also being offered as ingredients of plans. The Perfect Turn program offers intensive lessons to smooth a participant's skiing in his or her choice of terrain: steep or deep, bumps or boulevard. The learn-to-ski program offers lessons that the instructors say will insure that the neophyte can ski independently after one day.
To put all this into perspective, consider a family of four: a once-good skier who hasn't skied much lately; a spouse who has never skied, and their two children, aged 8 and 10. They decide on a three-day weekend in a one-bedroom condo for four. The cost for one adult will be $211, plus a $15 supplement for a Perfect Turn clinic to sharpen rusty skills. For the spouse it will be $211 plus a $115 supplement for a full three days of the Learn-to-Ski program. Condo and lift rates for the children will be $171 each, plus a supplement of $109 each if they are enrolled in the Mogul Meister program, which offers all-day coaching and teaching at any ability level, plus lunch.
The family may also find its own lodging in the Bethel area through the Bethel Reservation Service (207- 824-3585).
If the family has time for only one day's skiing, their lift tickets will cost the adults $31 for a weekday or $36 for a weekend day or holiday. Juniors ski for $20 daily, weekday or weekend. Half-day tickets, going into effect at 1 P.M., are $22 or, on weekends and holidays, $25 and $15 for juniors. A family from Connecticut that takes its ski week Feb. 10 to 15 -- during Connecticut's school break -- will get an extra 10 percent off the cost of a package that includes condo and lift tickets.
What's New: Four trails were added to the snowmaking system this past summer. The area set up a new Guaranteed Learn-to-Ski center and expanded the handicapped skiers' program, with more staff members and a new building. And for those who don't cook in their condo kitchens, it is opening two new family restaurants: Rosetto's, in the Whitecap base lodge, serving Italian specialties, and Saturday's, in the South Ridge base complex, offering Mexican dishes.
 
MASSACHUSETTS
 
BRODIE MOUNTAIN
Route 7, New Ashford, Mass. 01237
413-443-4752
Cutting Costs: One of the the best ski deals in the Berkshires is at Brodie Mountain, with its four-day, three-night nonholiday midweek package at $179.50 a person and $135 for children 12 and under. Accommodations are at Brodie's Kerry House and Dublin Motel at the foot of the slopes or at the Carriage House at the Brodie Mountain Racquet Club, a mile to the north on Route 7. As the regular one-night midweek room rate is $60 for two, the package plan, according to Brodie, saves about $55 a person, compared with the cost of buying the components separately. The plan, good for Monday through Thursday only, includes lodging, four days of lift tickets (regularly $25 a day), a welcoming wine and cheese party on the opening Monday evening, breakfast each morning, an apres-ski cocktail in the Blarney Room, a group lesson and a discount at the indoor tennis and racquetball courts. The price includes taxes and tips.
Brodie, with four double chairlifts and two rope tows serving its 25 slopes and trails, has a vertical drop of 1,250 feet, the greatest in the Berkshires. The area is open daily from 9 A.M. to 11 P.M.; half of its trails are lighted and, for the first time, the snowmaking system covers 100 percent of the terrain. There is also a full-service cross-country ski center a mile to the south.
John Koch heads the ski school, with lessons in downhill, telemark and cross-country skiing, including the skating stride. There are two large base lodges, one housing the Blarney Room, the largest ski-area cocktail lounge in New England, seating 500 people. There are also hook-ups for 250 campsites for recreational vehicles adjacent to the lower Tipperary Trail.
The Williams College ski team trains at Brodie and holds its winter carnival there each February. Brodie's Jim Kelly Invitational Pro Giant Slalom is the oldest continuously-run pro ski race in the nation and its 25th running will be held on March 10, the start of the area's annual St. Patrick's Festival continuing through March 17.
Lift tickets: weekends and holidays, $30 for a full day, $26 half-day (1 to 5 P.M.); juniors, $25 and $21. Weekdays, $25 and $23; juniors, $20 and $18. Twilight (3 to 11 P.M.): $23 for everyone; night tickets (7 to 11): $15 for everyone. Four-hour tickets, which can be purchased at any time before 1 P.M., are $23.
Ski, boot and pole rentals: $20 and $15 for juniors. Group lessons: $15; private, $30.
What's New: Snowmaking expansion this past summer included the novice Tipperary run, which can also be fun for the advanced. The expanded network means that all 17 miles of trails can be covered with machine-made snow. To manicure its snow, machine-made or natural, Brodie has acquired additional grooming equipment.
 
NEW YORK
 
GORE MOUNTAIN
Post Office Box 470, North Creek, N.Y. 12853
518-251-2411; snow conditions, 518-251-2523 or 800-342-1234 in New York State
Cutting Costs: Through the winter, this Adirondacks ski area 40 miles north of Glens Falls is offering a midweek rate for daily lift passes of $24 for adults and $17 for juniors (age 12 and under). Bigger savings can be realized during early- and late-season periods (from opening day after Thanksgiving to Dec. 21 and from March 18 to closing) when the prices drop to $18 and $12. Through the winter, new skiers can use three novice lifts on the lower mountain and take an hour-and-a-half class lesson for $25.
Gore is one of the few areas in the country offering train packages, but after leaving the train at Albany skiers must rent a car and drive for about 90 minutes. There are two-night weekend all-inclusive packages for $251 a person and five-night midweek packages for $341. These include round-trip rail fare from Grand Central Terminal to Albany, two or five nights' accommodations, three or five days of lift tickets and taxes and gratuities. Northstar Tours (800-338-8898) is making the arrangements.
The mountain's lift ticket prices for weekends and holidays are $30 and $19 for juniors. People over age 70 ski free on all lifts, and youngsters of 6 and under ski free on novice lifts. Citizens 62 to 69 years old pay the same rates for lift tickets as juniors 12 and under.
What's New: Around the base of the mountain, Gore has maintained 11 kilometers (6.8 miles) of cross-country trails since the early 60's. This year these trails were regraded to make them more user friendly. On the mountain, many trails were widened and regroomed.
For youngsters 2 to 6 years old, an all-day Dino-mite program has been expanded to include rental equipment, lunch and supervised play for $51.
The snowboard program, introduced last season, has been expanded and includes a demonstration center with 50 K2 and Burton boards to rent plus instruction.
SKI WINDHAM
Post Office Box 459, Windham, N. Y. 12496
518-734-4300; snow reports, 800-729-4766; lodging, 800-729-7549
Cutting Costs: To attract more skiers during midweek periods, Ski Windham in the northern Catskills has created several new packages under the title Weekday Advantages. The Business Ski Escape, for instance, is a lift ticket, one and three-quarter hour group lesson, buffet lunch, apres-ski drink and use of the Commerce Club, an office with business services in the base lodge, for $37 a day. The same items bought individually would cost $60 to $65.
A Ladies' Day with similar features and a 50 percent discount for one nonskiing child to spend the day in the Children's Learning Center costs $36. On nonholiday weekdays, people over 65 can ski at half price, while children 12 and under ski free. What's New: The 72,000-square-foot base lodge, new last season, has been fine-tuned with decorating and changes in service features. The full-day program with two two-hour lessons, lunch, lift ticket and supervised indoor activities costs $55, while a half-day with one lesson, lift ticket and indoor activities is $33.

CANADA
 
ALBERTA
 
BANFF-LAKE LOUISE
Banff National Park, Box 1085, Banff, Alberta, Canada T0L 0C0
403-762-4561 or 800-661-1363 for reservations and information, including snow conditions
 Cutting Costs: Three ski centers and two towns make up this winter resort region in Banff National Park west of Calgary. The slopes at the three -- Lake Louise, Sunshine Village and Mount Norquay -- total about 4,000 acres, which are usually covered with dry, light powder, which is traversed by the occasional elk as well as skiers.
The first saving -- prices are in United States dollars unless otherwise stated -- comes from the exchange rate, with the Canadian dollar trading at about 87 United States cents. An adult (18 plus) full-day lift ticket at Lake Louise, the most expensive center, at $34 Canadian, is $29.60 United States. Half-day (from noon) is $26, and $14.80 after 2.30 P.M. Youth (age 13-17) and student (18-25) lift tickets are $26 for the day, $23 half day and, after 2.30 P.M., $10.45. Children (6-12) are $7 at all times; those under 6 ski free. Five-day adult tickets are $133; five-day tickets for youths and students are $122. Children pay the day rate. Mount Norquay has night skiing (4 to 9 P.M. Wednesday to Friday) at $8 for all ages except children under 12, who pay $4. Tri-area lift tickets, which come with most packages, cost about $28 for adults and $14 for children a day. Rentals for skis, poles and boots range from about $56 for seven days at Sportsrent, a store in Banff, to $39 for three days at Lake Louise ski area.
Packages combining accommodations and lift tickets, offered by tour companies and hotels, are money savers. Packages of Ski Banff-Lake Louise, which represents the three centers, start at $348 a person in double occupancy, including six nights at the castle-like, 850-room Banff Springs Hotel, a five-day tri-area lift ticket, shuttle bus service between hotel and slopes and a one-night pass for Norquay.
The largest center of the three is at Lake Louise, a few minutes' drive from the town of the same name and a half hour from Banff. The center boasts 45 runs and a vertical drop of 3,257 feet. Sunshine, 15 minutes from Banff, offers 62 runs, a vertical of 3,514 feet and the region's only on-hill accommodations. Sunshine Village Inn, 7,000 feet up, is reached by a three-mile gondola lift from the valley floor. The ski area's snowfall averages 30 feet a year, the heaviest in the region.
As for cross-country, trails start in the towns and continue into the back country. Lake Louise leads the downhill centers with 30 miles of marked and groomed trails.
What's New: Mount Norquay has developed 70 acres of intermediate slopes served by two new quad chairs.
Lake Louise ski area runs a nursery for children aged 18 days to 18 months. Hours: 8 A.M. to 4.30 P.M. Cost: $17 a child a day. Day care is available at all the centers for children aged 19 months to 6 years. Hours: 8 A.M. to 5 P.M. The cost varies from $2 an hour at Lake Louise to $2.60 at Mount Norquay and $4.35 an hour at Sunshine Village. Junior ski camps, for children 6 to 12, are available at Sunshine and Lake Louise (both at $27 a day) and on weekends and holidays at Mount Norquay ($30).

SECTION: Section 2; Page 4; Column 4; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 356 words

HEADLINE: MOVIE RATINGS;
An X Is Bad For Business

 BODY:
To the Editor: Janet Maslin's statement that "for a little-known independent film, after all, an X isn't necessarily bad for business" is wildly inaccurate. Why, pray tell, have a number of respected American independent distributors like Miramax filed expensive lawsuits in the past year to have X ratings of high-quality films like Almodovar's "Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!" overturned? And why did the distributors of Wayne Wang's "Life Is Cheap . . . but Toilet Paper Is Expensive" advertise their film in The Times with their own A rating rather than the Motion Picture Association of America's X rating?
The answer is simply economic. For better or worse, an X rating has become synonymous with pornographic, and, just as The New York Times does not carry ads for sexually explicit films, many theaters around the United States will not show films rated X. If the recent campaign for a change in the ratings system is any indication, most American independent distributors (not to mention film artists) find an X rating extremely bad for business; there are even some who suspect that the many X ratings given to American and foreign independents by the M.P.A.A. are part of a general Hollywood effort (strenuously denied by M.P.A.A. head Jack Valenti, of course) to drive the independents out of the American film marketplace.
Seen in this light, the NC-17 rating given to Universal's "Henry and June" (after a number of independents had failed to persuade Mr. Valenti to change the system) is proof that Hollywood itself believes that an X rating is bad for business. Indeed, it is hard to imagine any pundit in the American motion picture industry agreeing with Ms. Maslin's astounding assertion that "the idea that an X is bad for business only makes sense when it comes to big-budget films that are destined for multiple shopping malls."
As an independent film maker who has watched American independent film production dwindle to near extinction, thanks to the vertical integration of the Reagan era, I feel that the future of the American independent film is worthy of serious debate.
 
THEODORE FOLKE
Westport, Conn.

SECTION: Section 12NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 2059 words

HEADLINE: Flood Tunnel Plan: A State-U.S. Split

BYLINE: By States News Service

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A CONGRESSIONAL plan for a $1.2 billion tunnel to end flooding in New Jersey's Passaic River Basin has pitted Washington lawmakers against state legislators worried about costs and environmental impact.
New Jersey members of Congress, led by Representative Robert A. Roe, Democrat of Pompton Lakes, see the tunnel as the best plan to emerge from 50 years of debate over how to end chronic flooding in the Passaic River Basin. Flooding in the 10-county region has led to 29 deaths in this century -- five of them since 1983 -- and causes an average of $100 million in damage a year. 
 But state legislators say New Jersey cannot afford to pay its share of the cost -- at least $150 million over the next 10 to 20 years. State Senate and General Assembly members are considering a resolution that would ask the Army Corps of Engineers to study alternatives. And environmentalists have begun an aggressive campaign to block tunnel construction, which they say will destroy wetlands and deplete ground water in the region.
 
A Communication Gap
 The clash reflects a communication gap between Washington and New Jersey, with members of Congress asserting that tunnel opponents are misinformed, while critics say that members of Congress are out of touch with residents back home.
The tunnel debate also raises a broader question facing the Corps of Engineers as it enters the environmentally sensitive 1990's: Should the Government try to control nature or leave it alone?
"Either this flood tunnel is going to provide relief by the year 2000, if it ever gets built, or it is going to be the biggest mistake we've ever made," said State Assemblyman Gerald H. Zecker, Republican of Clifton. "I don't know."
The 20.1-mile tunnel, which would begin at Pompton Lakes, would carry floodwaters from the basin's upper reaches in southern New York State to a discharge point at Kearny Point on Newark Bay. The original design called for the pipe to funnel waters between dikes and levees at Nutley, but New Jersey's Federal lawmakers scrapped that plan after residents objected.
The tunnel's genesis dates to 1939, the first year that Congress authorized funds to study flooding in the Passaic River Basin. That same year, the Corps of Engineers proposed its first flood damage reduction plan. But that plan, like others proposed in 1948, 1962, 1969, 1972 and 1973, died because of public opposition. Like the criticisms today, the major objections were cost and environmental factors.
In 1976, Congress directed the corps yet again to study flooding in the basin. After reviewing more than 150 alternatives, the corps singled out 35 economically feasible plans, and in 1984 state officials selected the tunnel option for further development. Gov. Thomas H. Kean endorsed the plan formally in 1988.
After still more tinkering, task forces and public hearings, Congress authorized $890 million for the tunnel in the final hours of its session last month. The project was approved as part of a broader Water Resources Development Act and now needs only President Bush's signature to clear its last legislative hurdle in Washington. Congress also approved a financing measure in October that sets aside $5.8 million for tunnel design work in 1991.
Mr. Roe describes the plan as "an extraordinarily productive environmental program," saying that the tunnel bill protects 5,200 acres in a permanent "wetlands land bank." Mr. Roe also has the backing of Representatives Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of Englewood, and Dean A. Gallo, Republican of Parsippany-Troy Hills. Senators Frank R. Lautenberg and Bill Bradley, both Democrats, also endorse the plan.
But environmentalists, led by the Passaic River Coalition, an anti-tunnel group, protest that construction will destroy up to 900 acres of freshwater wetlands that provide a sanctuary for North American plants and animals. Corps officials have promised to replace or revive the wetlands, but environmentalists say that such mitigation efforts are rarely successful.
"I say this project is going to be the geologic and the hydrologic equivalent of the Hubble Space Telescope -- a fiasco," said William Neil, assistant director of conservation at the New Jersey Audubon Society. "If we approve it and it goes through, we are going to have enormous regrets, environmentally and financially."
Environmentalists also fear that the tunnel will disrupt the river bottom and cut into ground-water recharge areas for North Jersey aquifers, threatening drinking water supplies for millions of residents. Critics said other major corps projects in the Mississippi Delta and the Florida Everglades had failed miserably.
In Florida, state and Federal officials estimate it will cost $93 million to $276 million to undo the environmental damage caused by a canal the corps dug through the Kissimmee River in 1971. The Tennessee Tombigbee Waterway, constructed in 1971 to provide inland navigation in Alabama and Mississippi, also has destroyed much of Louisiana's most fertile wetlands, Mr. Neil said.
"Nationally the corps is having a change of heart," said Mr. Neil, noting that the Government is moving away from large public works projects. "And that's why this project is such a dinosaur."
Corps officials counter that the tunnel does not compare with earlier projects, and that it complies with 1976 legislation establishing more stringent environmental guidelines.
Phyllis Kronick, a spokeswoman for the corps' Passaic River Division, said that state legislators' call for further study made little sense, since the corps examined 150 alternate flood control projects in the 1980's.
Department officials are now taking a fresh look at the project. Gov. Jim Florio is withholding judgment until Congress authorizes funds for actual tunnel construction. At that point, the state would be required to provide its share of the money.
 
Corps to Pay for Maintenance
 The tunnel will have no effect on ground water, said Ms. Kronick, who complained of "an enormous amount of misinformation" among residents. She said there were errors in literature disseminated by opponents of the project, including the claim that New Jersey will pay some $2.1 million a year in tunnel maintenance. In fact, the Water Resources Development Act now directs the corps to shoulder all maintenance costs.
"There's always fear," she said. "And unfortunately, the people who have been against the project have been very skillful at playing on those fears."
Beyond environmental concerns, however, many state legislators say New Jersey simply cannot afford the project. The state is technically responsible for 25 percent of the tunnel's $1.2 billion cost, or $300 million. But Mr. Roe said New Jersey would get credit for half that sum in exchange for lands donated to the project, bringing the state's share to $150 million.
"I see little or no hope of the state coming up with the funding to match the 25 percent share," said State Senator Gabriel M. Ambrosio, Democrat of Lyndhurst and author of the Legislature's resolution opposing the tunnel. "We just have other problems and other concerns that make this beyond our capacity to approve at this time."
Already mired in local tax and budget woes, state legislators believe that tunnel cost estimates are outdated and will dramatically rise during construction. A cheaper, more environmentally sound alternative, they argue, would be to buy out the estimated total of 744 homes in the floodway, at a cost of about $150 million.
"This is a particularly good time to undertake a buyout because of the decline in real-estate values throughout New Jersey," said Assemblyman Thomas J. Duch, Democrat of Garfield.
Tunnel advocates counter that a buyout would do little to protect residents from a 100-year flood -- a term used to describe a flood of major proportions -- like the 1903 "flood of record," which caused $1.9 billion in damage and killed 15 people. Flooding in April 1984 cost the state $370 million and forced the evacuation of 9,400 people.
 
Wide Displacement Seen
 An effective buyout would cost closer to $4 billion, the corps estimates, and displace virtually the entire town of Lincoln Park, to say nothing of streets, shopping centers and jobs.
"The buyout is environmentally the best alternative, but it has the serious problem that it would dislocate 50,000 families, result in the loss of thousands of jobs and cost between $3 billion and $4 billion," Mr. Torricelli said. "It simply is not economically viable."
<> <>
Moreover, many residents do not wish to leave the area, despite the risk of flooding. The state's last attempt at a buyout, in 1984, led to the sale of only 58 properties, which were not demolished for five years. Hundreds of residents have joined a pro-tunnel coalition called Protect, or the Passaic River Organizations to Encourage Construction of the Tunnel, which its chairman, Joseph B. Wiley, said has 10,000 people.
Herman Hy Nadel, a Republican Councilman in Lincoln Park, said: "Even if homes were purchased, you are taking people out of a community that they want to live in and displacing them. And that is ludicrous. This is their roots. This is their way of life."
 
'Most Frightening Moments'
 Tunnel advocates' most compelling argument comes from flood victims themselves. Marina Porter of Lincoln Park recalls the night in April 1984 when she was trapped in her home with three children under the age of 9. Mrs. Porter, whose husband had been unable to reach home, waited six hours for a rescue crew that arrived at 4 A.M. Meanwhile, the water in her basement rose to within two inches of her living room floor.
"Those were the most frightening moments I have experienced in my life," Mrs. Porter said. "We were taken in a small motorboat through the streets that I had driven down the previous morning -- except that all we could see of the streets were the tops of the street signs."
Mrs. Porter and her children wound up in a local elementary school with hundreds of other displaced families, and eventually returned home. But tunnel advocates note that some flood victims have not been so lucky.
"It's important to remember that people have been killed," Mr. Torricelli said. "In this decade, to lose lives in a suburban area like New Jersey to flooding is inexcusable. And it's not just the loss of lives. Millions of dollars in property also have been lost."
 
'A Very Powerful Force'
 Some tunnel opponents accuse Mr. Roe and others in Washington of pandering to construction and labor interests, which strongly endorse the plan.
"The pure economic, utilitarian argument for what this tunnel will bring is a very powerful force right now,"said Mr. Neil, of the New Jersey Audubon Society. He said the tunnel project would be the largest public works project ever built in the state.
Mr. Roe denied that jobs were his motivation for seeking the tunnel. The plan reflects decades of debate, he said, and has a long history of support from New Jersey governors before Mr. Florio.
"When you work on something for 30 years," Mr. Roe said, "it's obvious that you are not thinking of the job end of it."
 
'Agony People Go Through'
 Philip Beachem, executive vice president of New Jersey Alliance for Action, said of Mr. Neil's comment, "I don't think that the people who make those kinds of comments have spent time in a flood in that region, or have seen the agony that the people and families go through."
The alliance is a nonprofit coalition of government and business interests dedicated to infrastructure improvements.
If state officials kill the current tunnel plan, Mr. Beachem said, similar plans are not likely to arise. The project is on its third go-round in Congress, and tight Federal budgets are eroding support for major public works projects.
But environmentalists would not be sorry to see the tunnel go. They argue that the homes, shopping centers and businesses in the Passaic River Basin should not have been built there in the first place. Nature should be allowed to take its course, said Marie Curtis, a spokeswoman for the New Jersey Environmental Lobby.
"We see people constantly trying to improve on Mother Nature," she said. "And what we find is that we pay more in the end."

HEADLINE: New Airline Terminal Is a Hard-Won Victory

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON

 BODY:
ERIC LANGELOH, Westchester County's Commissioner of Transportation, has about two dozen architects' renderings in his office of proposed new terminals for the county's airport, right across the state line from Greenwich. The earliest drawing is "dated 1946, the year I was born," he said.
It may seem to Mr. Langeloh and other county officials that they have been dealing with the issue of a new airport terminal for most of their lives. 
 "You're looking at 45-odd years worth of people planning and arguing and debating," Mr. Langeloh said. "For it finally to get out to the public and for the public to say 'Yes, let's do it,' that's a major accomplishment."
Last week, in a $21 million bonding referendum, Westchester voters provided the go-ahead for a 41,000-square-foot replacement terminal. But just barely. The proposal was approved by a slender margin of 84,077 votes in favor and 79,587 against, or 51.37 percent to 48.63 percent.
 
What Happens Next
 The approval sets several events in motion, with the terminal's construction being the final, rather than the initial, accomplishment.
"Within 30 to 45 days," Mr. Langeloh said, "we'll be letting bids on the first phase, which is the access roadwork, an interior road system that will cost $5.7 million and represent a year's worth of work beginning next spring."
The road will be rebuilt from "where you currently pick up your parking ticket," he said. It will be redesigned, "so that you'll be able to go directly to the terminal for drop-offs or to a new parking structure," the second airport project.
The three-story, 1,200-space garage will be built for $17 million by a developer after public bids. That should be completed by the spring of 1992, when construction of the two-level terminal will begin. It should be in use by the spring of 1993.
The struggle against the proposed terminal, fought by elected officials and homeowner groups in nearby communities in both Connecticut and New York, dominated the final weeks of the election campaign.
Supervisor Donald B. Gioffre of Rye, N.Y., a leader in the effort to defeat the terminal plan, was diplomatic in defeat as he described the next stage of the struggle over what opponents still feel is an inevitable expansion of the airport. But he was still angry over the loss itself.
"Since the people have voted, it is only right to respect that vote," he said. "The county has offered to cooperate with us, so we will hold it accountable for its word that the terminal will cost only $21 million, that it will guarantee a continuation of the nighttime curfew, and that it will maintain a passenger cap of 234 passengers per half-hour."
 
A Reminder on a Pledge
 The county has also pledged to keep "larger and noisier planes away" from the airport, he said.
And finally, he said, "I hope we don't see the area around the new terminal magically transformed into additional apron space for aircraft."
Mr. Gioffre expressed bitterness about what he felt was a massive, government-financed campaign to enlist support for the referendum.
Peter W. Delaney, Westchester's General Services administrator, headed the campaign in support of the proposal under County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke. Mr. Delaney said that $50,000 was raised privately and that $100,000 was spent by the county in supporting the referendum.
The $150,000 total was "absurdly low for at least four mailings, brochures and other material that appeared throughout the county," Mr. Gioffre said. "The Town of Rye spent $3,000 on one mailer, done by myself and others and mailed locally." Larger amounts were spent by others opposing the referendum.
Mr. Delaney conceded that unions, private businesses and others likely to benefit from a modernized airport were pressed into service to support the referendum.
 
'We Knew We'd Be Blitzed'
 "Those who opposed the referendum had an emotional issue on their side," Mr. Delaney said. "So we knew we had to win at least 65 percent of the vote outside the airport area, where we knew we'd be blitzed with 'no' votes. We barely made it."
Mr. Delaney said he and others in Westchester County government had "tried to talk the County Executive out of going to a referendum, but he felt he had no choice."
He recalled that Mr. O'Rourke said, "If we go to the people and do it right, we'll win and that will settle it."
 
Two Issues Faced Head-On
 Mr. Delaney said the narrow victory came about after "taking two issues head on: payment and expansion."
"We addressed the argument that it would cost more than the $21 million," he said, noting the county's position that increased revenues would more than cover the costs. The county campaign also disputed inferences that the terminal was a wedge to allow expanded operations at the airport.
Mr. Delaney said the county enlisted the help of pilots who use the airport, having them visit nursing homes and other places where the elderly congregate to persuade them of the referendum's benefits. "The elderly generally vote negatively on bond issues," he said.
 
Linking Airport to Jobs
 Corporate leaders were given placards and other visual material to display to their employees, "who were told that it was in their own best interests to support a more modern airport facility in Westchester," Mr. Delaney said. "We suggested that they link the economic vitality of their company with their employees' jobs."
Mr. Gioffre said he had no intention of initiating any legal process that would impede the airport project, but that he and others would carefully monitor the progress of the improvement plan.
Mr. Langeloh said the county, for its part, would work publicly on each stage of the program and would confer frequently with the county's Board of Legislators, which had requested an informal oversight role.

HEADLINE: After the Vote, Practicality May Temper Independence

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
AFTER Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s landmark victory last week, the political parties that he tore asunder began picking up the pieces. In just seven weeks, Mr. Weicker will become the state's first independent governor since Alexander H. Holly's election on the eve of the Civil War, and both Democrats and Republicans say they have little time to dwell on what might have been.
Mr. Weicker and the 187 members of the General Assembly -- most of whom opposed him, at least publicly, in the campaign -- will be thrown together, for better or worse, until the end of next year's legislative session. And while beautiful music may emerge from the union of a former United States Senator with a reputation for going his own way and a legislature full of people who had hoped to see someone else as governor, the initial prospects for harmony are dismal.
With unemployment and business bankruptcies rising, tax revenues falling and a recession apparently looming, Mr. Weicker will take office facing challenges that pale beside the questions about how effectively he will be able to govern as an independent.
The most immediate issue facing him is a state budget deficit that is projected to be about $400 million in the year that ends June 30. The projected shortfall in the next year could reach $1 billion or more in a budget of just over $7 billion. Between January and June, when the regular legislative session ends, those budget holes -- caused by the sharp falloff in tax revenues over the last year -- must be filled through spending cuts, tax increases or some combination. Legislative leaders say that almost all the options are unpleasant, and that under such a cloud, even a governor who had a majority party behind him in the General Assembly would see strife.
For Mr. Weicker, the era of initial good will that is expected between the new Governor and the legislators will probably be even more brief.
"The state of Connecticut is in such dire shape, I don't think the honeymoon can last long," said State Representative Edward C. Krawiecki Jr., a Republican from Bristol who is a deputy minority leader in the House.
State Representative Richard O. Belden, a Republican from Shelton who is also a deputy leader in his party, said of Mr. Weicker, "He's got to get moving."
Still, leaders of both parties insisted they would approach things with an open mind, bearing no grudges that could mire the budget debate in a battle of spite.
"I'm waiting to see exactly what happens," said the House Speaker, Representative Richard J. Balducci, a Democratic from Newington. "But I'm sure we are willing to sit and negotiate and do what is necessary. He is the man the people of the state have elected as Governor. We are going to have to work with him to the best of our ability."
Mr. Weicker, a 59-year-old former Republican Senator who was defeated in his bid for a fourth Senate term in 1988 by Joseph I. Lieberman, a Democrat, got only 40 percent of the 1.1 million votes cast in Tuesday's election. But with three main candidates, that was enough. The second-place finisher, United States Representative John G. Rowland, a Republican from Waterbury, got 37 percent, while the Democrat, United States Representative Bruce A. Morrison of Hamden, received just 21 percent. A fourth candidate, Joseph A. Zdonczyk of the Concerned Citizens Party, got 2 percent of the total.
The election crushed the hopes of the Republicans, who had seen themselves capitalizing on the deep decline in popularity of the Democratic incumbent, Gov. William A. O'Neill, who chose not to run for a third term. And it nearly crushed the Democratic Party. Had Mr. Morrison received 10,000 fewer votes, he would have dropped below the threshold, 20 percent of the votes cast, that would have relegated the Democrats to minor-party status under state law, equal to the Libertarians or the Socialist Workers. New Democratic candidates would have had to submit petitions just to get their names on the ballot.
 Democratic and Republican leaders said that communication will be vital to the relationship between the Weicker administration and the Democratic-controlled legislature. If Mr. Weicker at least tips his hand about his legislative agenda, the leaders said, some obstacles could be removed and some compromises reached without waging a full battle on every point.
In the legislative elections, the Democrats picked up one seat in the House of Representatives, raising their margin to 88 to 62. The Republicans picked up three seats in the Senate, narrowing the Democratic margin to 20 to 16.
 
Partisan Comments
 But no one expects the situation to be entirely painless. Whether an administration is headed by an independent or the truest party believer, partisan digs will still be part of the system.
On the day after the election, for example, Mr. Belden was asked at a State Capitol news conference whether he believed Mr. Weicker's proposals on the state budget would cause divisiveness in the Republican Party or in the State House of Representatives.
"I didn't realize he had taken a stand on that," Mr. Belden said with a deadpan expression.

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: Eleanor Charles

 BODY:

TRACY IS ON HIS WAY
 He was originally called "Plainclothes Tracy," but the fearless detective with the razor sharp profile and snap-brim fedora was renamed "Dick Tracy" when his creator, Chester Gould, sold the comic strip to the Chicago Tribune-Daily News Syndicate in 1931. The rest, as they say, is history, and it will be re-told in a comprehensive Dick Tracy Exhibition opening today through Feb. 24 at the Museum of Cartoon Art in Rye Brook.
 On loan from Matt Masterson, a pre-eminent Dick Tracy collector and old friend of the late Mr. Gould, are more than 80 of the original strip drawings. In them are at least 100 of the familiar characters with grotesque faces and names to match. They include Flattop, Pruneface, Measles, Gargles and Itchy, among others. Their fame and influence as mirrors of the American crime scene became so pervasive that Gould was pressured by his editors to tone down his depictions of torture, murder and depravity during the decade preceding his retirement in 1977.
 In addition to the artwork there will be a display of Dick Tracy toys, comic books, premiums, movie posters, dolls, figurines, games, puzzles, detective kits, trading cards and wrist radios -- all acquired by Larry Doucet and Bill Crouch, co-authors of a publication called "The Authorized Guide to Dick Tracy Collectibles." The two men will be guest speakers on Dec. 2 at 2 P.M.
 The museum, on Comly Avenue, one mile south of the King Street Exit of the Hutchinson River Parkway, is open Tuesdays through Fridays from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., and Sundays from 1 to 5 P.M. Admission is $3 for adults; $2 for students and the elderly; and $1 for children. For more information, call 939-0234.
 
THE SCAPEGOAT
 A book by Aranka Siegal for young people, "Upon the Head of the Goat: A Childhood in Hungary, 1939-1944," won the Newbery Honor Book Award in 1982. Its contents provide the basis for her talk, "Learning Not to Scapegoat," to be delivered at a luncheon meeting of the Scarsdale Congregational Church Guild at noon Tuesday.
 In her book, published in Manhattan by Farrar, Straus, Giroux, Ms. Siegal recounted her experiences from the age of 13, when she was rounded up with her sister by the Nazis, separated permanently from the rest of her family and deported first to Auschwitz and then to Bergen-Belsen concentration camps. The two girls were rescued by the Swedish Red Cross and they emigrated to the United States in 1948.
 A passion for literature that led to her career as a writer was instilled when Ms. Siegal was 12 years old and the Nazi-controlled Hungarian Government banned Jewish children from attending the public schools. She compensated as much as she could by reading every book her family owned or that she could get otherwise.
 Now a Westchester mother of two grown children, she continues to write about children who must come to terms with their prejudices and understand the meaning of scapegoating. Admission to the luncheon is $3. Call 723-0430 or 723-2111 for reservations.
 
INSULATING TIPS
 Mildew, peeling paint, drafts and high heating and air-conditioning bills can all be signs of poor insulation and poor air circulation, which the Cornell Cooperative Extension of Westchester County can help eliminate.
 In two seminars this week, James McCarty, housing specialist in the department of design and environmental analysis at Cornell University, will discuss the theoretical aspects of the problem, the development of various products to assist homeowners and proper installation techniques that will insure long-term solutions.
 The first session is scheduled on Wednesday at 7:30 P.M. at 214 Central Avenue, White Plains. Call 682-3074 for reservations or more information. A second identical seminar will be held Thursday at 7:30 P.M. at Guideposts in Carmel. The phone number there is 628-0454. Admission to either program is $3.
 
THE NEWEST MUSEUM
 Can seven plugged-in television sets make a robot in the shape of a man? Yes, they can, and Nam June Paik made one this year. The piece is among more than 100 objects, paintings, sculptures, photographs, pieces of folk art and decorative art on display in "The Technological Muse," an exhibition opening today at 2 P.M. in the new Katonah Museum of Art.
 This inaugural show at 22 Jay Street, marks the former Katonah Gallery's move from its quarters in the village library to its own building, designed by Edward Larrabee Barnes. The 37-year-old institution will not keep a permanent collection, but will mount five major exhibitions a year.
 A sampling of the extraordinary range of material in the new show, spanning 150 years in all media, includes photographs of the Civil War; "Arms Chair," an upholstered easy chair by Paul Ludick decorated with a fringe of revolvers; a four-foot cadmium-yellow icebag by Claes Oldenburg; paintings by Winslow Homer; a 1915 piece by Marcel Duchamp called "Large Glass or the Bride Stripped Bare by Her Bachelors Even" in oils and wire on glass; and a 1906 "Little Nemo" newspaper cartoon strip by Winsor McCay.
 Every Sunday at 3:30 P.M. one of the artists featured in the exhibition will give a talk. Joseph Maresca is today's speaker. The museum is open free of charge Tuesdays through Fridays from 1 to 5 P.M., Saturdays from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. and Sundays from 1 to 5 P.M. Docent tours are conducted at 2:30 P.M. Tuesdays, Thursdays and Sundays. Call 232-9555 for more information.
 
TRADING WITH ISRAEL
 "How to Succeed in Business With Israel" is the subject of a forum to be held from 8:30 A.M. to 2 P.M. Tuesday at the White Plains Hotel. Organized by the World Trade Club of Westchester, the Westchester County Office of Economic Development and the United States-Israel Economic Forum, the program will provide nuts and bolts advice from senior executives, government officials and legal experts on how to conduct trade with Israel.
 Among the speakers and panelists are Edward J. Borrazzo, president of Loral International of Yonkers; Shimon Bartzill, first vice president of Bank Leumi Trust Company of New York; Meir Buber, Consul and Trade Commissioner to the United States Trade Center of Israel, and Joseph E. Schoonmaker, vice president of Chase Manhattan Bank. Cheri Laustaunau, director of the Israel Information Center of the United States Department of Commerce, will deliver the keynote address.
 A $50 fee includes program materials, light breakfast and lunch. For reservations or more information, call 948-6444.
 
TAX STRATEGIES
 Julian Block will conduct a three-session course on "Saving Money: Tax Strategies for 1990" at the Center for Continuing Education in Mamaroneck High School, on Palmer Avenue from 8 to 10 P.M. Mondays beginning tomorrow.
 Mr. Block is a tax expert and author of several books on tax preparation. He has taught tax planning at the university level and he manages to reduce complicated tax laws into understandable language. (He has no connection with the H&R Block tax-preparation company.)
Tuition is $45, or $24.50 for people older than 65. Call 698-9126 to register or get more information.
