HEADLINE: Campus Life: Mount Holyoke;
Students Rally To Overcome Discrimination

DATELINE: SOUTH HAD LEY, Mass.

 BODY:
Led by the As sociation of Pan-African Unity, the black student group on campus, several Mount Holyoke student organizations joined with college administrators in a rally on Friday calling for the college to acknowledge that discrimination exists on campus and to combat it.
"We must understand the distortion of what it means to be African-American, Hispanic or whatever minority, and to begin to learn from those distortions," Rochelle Calhoun, associate dean of students, told about 150 students, faculty members and administrators.
Echoing that call, Taifa Smith, a sophomore economics major from Philadelphia and a spokeswoman for the Association of Pan-African Unity, said, "We have to understand how people's actions affect different groups." 
 The rally was in response to an incident two weeks ago in which a male Hispanic visitor in Mead dormitory urinated on the door of two black women. It is unclear whether the incident was a result of racisim, sexism or was simply a drunken act. Dormitory residents who were witnesses, including the two women who were the hosts of the dormitory party the man had attended, denied knowing about the incident and did not assist campus security guards in their investigation.
 
 President Was Appalled
 At a student senate meeting last week and in a letter to the college community, President Elizabeth Kennan decried the incident and the students' response.
Saying that "the act in question was barbaric," Mrs. Kennan wrote: "The victims recognized racism through the incident and its immediate aftermath. Their floor-mates initially did not. Students in Mead by their own processes have come to understand that the evaluation of an event does not depend on intention alone. An act can be degrading, even destructive, to others whether or not it is intended to be so."
Mrs. Kennan added that "shared understanding and mutual action in defense of another's rights is a necessary part of our lives together."
At the Student Senate meeting, she also said that the college security department would determine how to prevent similar incidents in the future.
 
Said They Didn't Know
 Students, campus security workers and the dean of students office said the incident involved at least one Coast Guard Academy cadet. Mount Holyoke has not released the name of the student.
Students agreed that the cadet had been drinking at a post-party celebration in Mead. At about 2:30 A.M., he urinated on the door of Angela Lemond, a sophomore English and theater major from Spring, Tex., and her roommate, Angela Hull, a sophomore sociology major from Lewiston, Me. They were in their room at the time. When security officers tried to investigate, other residents of the dormitory floor said they had no information.
By about 3 A.M., the dormitory's head resident, who had been alerted by Ms. Lemond and Ms. Hull, was looking for the cadet when Holyoke students and the man's fellow cadets brought him forward. When questioned about his actions, the man became verbally abusive, students who witnessed the exchange said.
At a floor meeting that night, Ms. Lemond and Ms. Hull questioned why fellow residents had not come to their aid.
 
Why Didn't They Do Something?
 Ms. Calhoun, the associate dean, said that when the hosts of the post-party were questioned by the dean's office, they acknowledged that they had known what the cadet had done but, because he was the friend of a friend, they had not known whether they would be held responsible for his actions. Ms. Calhoun added that the students could not explain why they had done nothing when the cadet became verbally abusive to a fellow member of their dormitory.
The dean of students, Sheila Murphy, said in an interview that Mount Holyoke had complained to the Coast Guard Academy, and that the academy was investigating. Ms. Murphy said that academy officials had told her that the cadet had been involved in other incidents and had been restricted to campus. By coming to Mount Holyoke, he had violated that restriction, she said.
The cadet's hosts, by witholding information from security officers, violated Mount Holyoke's social honor code, and disciplinary action has been taken against them, the dean's office said. The office of the dean of students said that the discipline involved community service.
Mead dormitory has announced that it will conduct workshops this week to deal with issues raised by the incident. "We need to address the issue that there is racism on Mount Holyoke's campus," Ms. Lemond said. "It can only be dealt with if people are open."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Joking Aside, Maybe It's Just a Yuppie Recession

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
INVESTMENT bankers are being laid off.
That fact may not strike terror into the hearts of middle America. It may even seem encouraging to some who associate the hordes of suspender-clad young M.B.A.'s with the financial excesses of the 1980's that left the economy fragile and businesses unable to pay their bills.
But on Wall Street, there are few things as horrifying, and not just because of the suspicion it will be difficult to train such people for productive work. The old joke, about a recession meaning your neighbor is out of work and a depression arriving when you lose your job, may help to explain the dismal economic forecasts now pouring from brokerage houses.
If so, then perhaps there is reason to hope that all is not as bad as it seems, that, as Prudential Bache's Ed Yardeni puts it, "to a large extent, this is a yuppie recession" that won't have a cataclysmic effect everywhere else in America, even if the New York economy is in for a rough spell.
One measure of Wall Street's mood is in the earnings estimates issued by brokerage house analysts. Since Iraq invaded Kuwait and recession woes started to escalate, analysts have been vying with each other to see how fast they can slash forecasts. In October, reports Rick Pucci of Institutional Brokerage Estimate System, an index of earnings estimates for companies in the S.&P. 500 showed that for every estimate raised, almost four were lowered. The ratio, of 0.26, was down sharply from September's 0.39.
Mr. Pucci sees hope in those figures, simply because the analysts, as a group, have a record of being wrong whenever they are so unanimous. In the decade that the statistic has been kept, the only other times the index got so low were in July 1982 and January 1985. In the first case, the bull market of the 1980's was about to begin; in the second, the first significant correction of that bull market had just ended. On the other hand, it was up to 1.49 in August 1987, just before the crash.
That is not the only reason to hope that, in the stock market at least, the worst is over. Renewed hopes for Fed easing played a role in Friday's rally, which almost offset earlier weakness and left the Dow Jones industrial average down just 2.23 points for the week, to 2,488.61.
"If the Fed really is coming around now to recognizing that the economy is falling into a recession, we'll have a big drop in interest rates that I think will revive consumer spending by the first quarter," said Mr. Yardeni. "The recession is almost over." He thinks stocks and bonds can advance even if the real estate market remains depressed for several years.
Long-term interest rates have been declining, but not as much as might have been expected, given the dramatic rally since the end of September in the Dow Jones utility average, which has a reputation as a leading indicator of bond prices. But last week that index slipped 2.6 percent, giving back a third of the advance.
If the utilities do not start moving up again, the hopes for the entire market may be premature.

HEADLINE: Coaxing the Stanford Elephant to Dance

BYLINE: By GLENN KRAMON

DATELINE: STANFORD, Calif.

 BODY:
NOURISHED over the years by affluent and well-insured patients, the Stanford Medical Center has expanded in the past decade from a single large building into a leading example of what some health-care experts call the medical-industrial complex. It now covers an area almost as large as the adjacent century-old central campus of Stanford University. And bulldozers and cranes are still roaring, at work on new laboratories and a new children's hospital.
 The setting seems far removed from the financial woes of inner-city hospitals and indeed much of the rest of the nation. Nearby houses commonly sell for $700,000, even in the current real estate slump. Across the street from the hospital is a tony shopping center with a Saks, Neiman-Marcus and Nordstrom. So exclusive is the area that, as one young doctor put it, "an internist's salary is becoming a second income -- you can't live on it." 
 Yet amid this extraordinary prosperity and even as the new buildings rise, the financial foundation of this big medical complex is showing serious signs of cracking. The chief reason is that cost-containment pressure by medical insurers has begun to take hold with a vengeance. It came first from the Government, which has limited payments for Medicare and Medicaid patients as it tries to reduce its deficit. Now it is coming as well from insurance companies and from private employers, which ultimately pay medical bills for almost everyone else, and are balking at the rapidly rising cost. The insurers are issuing this warning: Offer competitive prices or we will provide financial incentives for the people we cover to go elsewhere for treatment.
 Private health insurers in big California cities are at the forefront of this new cost-cutting drive, but similar efforts are under way in areas as diverse as Minneapolis, Phoenix, Denver and Washington.
 "What you're seeing in California and the San Francisco area is an advanced case of what's coming to the rest of the country," said Charles O. Schetter, of the health-care practice at McKinsey & Company, consultants, in Los Angeles. "As costs continue to rise but payers get smarter and smarter at managing medical costs, the inevitable squeeze will force hospitals to adapt how they're operating."
 
Some Hard Questions
 These developments are forcing some soul-searching questions: Can a medical center, particularly one so important to teaching and research, be treated as just another supplier? Will academic institutions like Stanford, which find it especially hard to compete on price because of their higher costs, lose patients to other hospitals and doctors? And will they therefore come up short in their roles as leaders in the advancement of medicine? Or have such hospitals indeed expanded too quickly and become bloated and badly in need of the discipline of a business?
 Stanford is now, in fact, attempting to behave in a more businesslike fashion. It is moving to cut expenses, to lower fees, to offer and market new treatment programs and to improve service as never before. To focus on the task, the hospital has brought in Kenneth D. Bloem, who came from the University of Chicago last fall with a reputation for turning around a financially troubled medical institution.
Mr. Bloem, who is 44 years old, likens the pressure on Stanford and other medical centers to that on airlines and banks in the past decade. "The climate is very tough," he said. "It's an industry perceived to have overcapacity -- that is, excess beds and a surplus of physicians. It's a buyer's market."
He outlined Stanford's strategy this way: "To find areas of inefficiency or duplication, to eliminate costs associated with them, and with the savings to strengthen existing programs and invest in new programs that are best mounted by a top research institution, programs that bring advances as quickly as possible from the bench to the bedside. This will allow us to better compete for patients."
 The sharp cost-cutting at the hospital began in earnest in April. The hospital eliminated 384 jobs, as part of an effort to reduce its $320 million annual budget by about $30 million. The layoffs cut 17 percent of management positions and 9 percent of staff positions -- among them, nurses, technicians, clerks, secretaries and marketing people.
 Administrators concede Stanford and others like it share some of the blame for the budget strains they are under. Before the price of health care reached its current crisis levels, these institutions added layers of employees and operated their programs with a rather lofty inattention to costs. Reputation, it was assumed, would bring in the patients.
 In trying to adjust to the current fiscal demands, great teaching and research institutions like Stanford have more at stake than others.
On one level, the medical center is just a business. Its hospital, clinic and medical school had revenues of about half a billion dollars this year.
But on a higher plane, it is more than that: Stanford claims the first successful heart-lung transplant, the first synthesis of biologically active DNA in a test tube and the first report of successful use of proteins called monoclonal antibodies to treat cancer. Just two weeks ago, Stanford doctors transplanted part of a mother's lung to save her dying 12-year-old daughter. A recent survey of 400 doctors by U.S. News and World Report ranked Stanford as one of the best in cancer, cardiology, otolaryngology and pediatrics.
 
Where It Will Hurt
 "To the extent that it suffers financially, its research and education programs will ultimately suffer," said David G. Anderson, a principal at APM, a New York consulting firm.
 More layoffs are expected, and some doctors and nurses there are worried. "My concern is that the cuts are being made in the wrong place, like a surgeon making an incision on the wrong side of the body," said Dr. Norman Shumway, Stanford's most prominent heart surgeon. "They should be cutting out more of the middle-management core."
 Donalda Dunnett, a representative of the nurses' union at Stanford, acknowledged that the medical center's administrators have tried hard to help the nurses. But, she said, "The nurses think the cuts have made it more difficult for them to deliver the quality of care they're accustomed to." She worries about response time in routine cases, and emergencies.
 The cost-cutting pressure from private and public insurers is all the more difficult for Stanford Medical Center because it is a private, nonprofit institution that receives no tax money and must rely almost exclusively on patient revenues, tuition, gifts and research grants. What is more, the Government is pressing Stanford to reduce what it charges for overhead costs, like the use of campus buildings, in Federally financed research projects.
Like many academic medical centers, Stanford is saddled with a high proportion of patients who have no health insurance at all, people who come from far beyond the wealthy Palo Alto area on the assurance that the university hospital feels an obligation to care for them.
In addition, even those with state-Federal Medicaid insurance are now costing Stanford a fortune, according to medical center figures.
Stanford reported losses of $200 a day this summer on Medicaid patients. And that did not include administrative costs and debt obligations, which account for about half of total costs, said David S. P. Hopkins, director of corporate affiliations and policy. All told, Stanford reported providing $44.8 million in uncompensated care in 1989.
 
The Ills of Medicaid
 As California and the Federal Government negotiate harder bargains, a growing number of other hospitals and doctors are steering away from Medicaid patients. "None of us will see those patients anymore," said an internist in the Stanford area who spoke on condition that he not be identified. "The only thing we can do to make sure they get care is to dump them on Stanford." The number of Stanford's patients on Medicaid (or Medi-Cal, as it is called in California) has risen 35 percent in two years to 27 percent of all patients. Stanford is now moving to limit the number of uninsured and Medicaid patients it accepts from distant areas.
Like other medical centers, Stanford is also faring worse with Medicare, for people 65 and older or disabled. The Government has limited what it will pay for all kinds of treatment, and even stiffer limits seem likely. All told, the collection rate for Stanford physicians on Medicare, Medi-Cal and indigent patients is now about 63 cents on each dollar billed, down from 80 cents five years ago, said Donald B. Tower, executive director of the Stanford clinic.
<> <> Hospitals and doctors have historically compensated for losses on the poor and the elderly by raising rates for those covered under private insurance plans paying the full price.
 It is this practice that private insurers are now fighting, using their large size to press for discounts. "Employers like Hewlett-Packard are becoming sophisticated health-care consumers and aggressive contractors," said Donald Kennedy, president of the university and chairman of the hospital board. "They can shop around and move their patients."
 Given this climate, "we have hardly any full-paying patients left -- only about 18 or 19 percent," Mr. Tower said of the Stanford clinic. With so few patients left to pay full price, Stanford has sharply increased fees for those who still do. Undiscounted room rates jumped 23 percent in 1989 and 14 percent the year before.
 Other hospitals in the area have a similar problem. But Stanford's teaching and research and consequent larger staff all contribute to even higher overhead. As a result, "other hospitals can beat you on price," Mr. Kennedy said. A room in a Stanford surgical ward this summer cost $583 to $1,226 a day, compared with $500 to $650 at competitors.
 Like many academic medical centers, Stanford falls victim to its own raison d'etre: training new doctors through its medical school. Many graduates set up shop in competing hospitals, clinics or free-standing surgery centers. "Stanford is expert at transferring expertise to people who then compete with it, but at lower prices," said Sheldon King, president of the Cedars Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles and a former president of the Stanford hospital.
 
 Growth of Competition
 Perhaps the most conspicuous example has been the cardiac-surgery program established by Dr. Shumway and others when the hospital opened at Stanford in 1959. "At that time, there was no cardiac surgery between San Francisco and Los Angeles," Dr. Shumway recalled. "But when coronary-artery surgery, a relatively simple operation, became more common in the 70's, a lot of our surgeons went off to neighboring hospitals and became millionaires, taking with them a lot of the patients who used to come to Stanford."
So Stanford loses many of its bread-and-butter cases -- not only heart surgery but also gall-bladder removals, simple births and other common operations. And it is left with the costlier, more unpredictable ones for which competing hospitals might not be equipped -- like emergency cases of multiorgan failures.
 Complicating Stanford's predicament is that in the San Francisco area, medical networks, like the huge Kaiser Permanente program, are more popular than almost anywhere else in the country. These health maintenance organizations are using low rates and improving reputations to steal the income-producing insured patients from Stanford in a big way.
To win back some of that business, Stanford too must offer discounts -- directly to employers or through contracts with H.M.O.'s. Stanford is also being pushed into keeping more patients out of the hospital or to shorten their stays. So the patients who do qualify for hospital stays are sicker on average than they used to be -- and more costly to care for.
<> <> With so much lower-priced competition, and with the new emphasis on using hospitals less, Stanford, for all its prestige, is actually now finding itself strapped for patients. Twenty-five years ago the hospital was so full that doctors fought for operating rooms. Today, 25 percent to 30 percent of its 663 beds are empty.
This has a direct effect on the ledger. Five years ago, net revenues from operations exceeded expenses by $17 million. A loss of $14 million was projected for the fiscal year ended Aug. 31, but the budget cuts reduced it to $1 million. This fiscal year, a $2.4 million loss on operations is projected. Doctors at the center's outpatient clinic are being squeezed as well.
 In such an environment, Stanford has found it increasingly difficult to attract talented faculty physicians, the kind who bring medical advances and impart wisdom to the 1,900 students, postdoctoral fellows, interns and residents at the medical center.
 
Specialty Care
 Trying to increase its base of patients, Stanford is beefing up in areas in which local hospitals would find it difficult to compete -- planning to add transplants of the kidney, liver and pancreas, for example. It is expanding its pain-management center and establishing a psychiatric unit, and will consolidate its pediatric programs in the new children's hospital.
 But price matters too. This summer, Stanford raised its room rates 6 percent more, but the increase was well under the rate of medical-cost inflation. In the spring, it opened a post-operation recovery unit with beds at a far lower daily rate than in other wards. It has also opened a lower-priced unit for patients awaiting placement in a nursing home.
 Even with such offerings, Stanford will not attract enough patients unless more doctors start referring them. So it has recently begun to hire doctors whose main focus is patient care and teaching, as opposed to laboratory research, in the hope that they will bring in badly needed business. The medical center has also increased financial incentives for faculty physicians to see patients.
 Stanford is also working on its reputation for service, Mr. Bloem said. And it is joining other hospitals in seeking to reverse the trend of lower reimbursement for Medi-Cal and Medicare patients, and in pressing for coverage of people now uninsured.
 Still, Stanford's administrators agree that America's hospitals must become more businesslike. Otherwise, their more esteemed medical mission will fail. And that would be a tragedy, for an oft-forgotten reason: Medical advances, like the coming cures for severe disorders caused by flawed genes, can in many cases not only improve or save a life but also significantly lower the cost of health care. Mr. Kennedy acknowledges that many factors figure in cutting hospital costs. But he emphasized: "Only if the most innovative institutions survive will we eventually take medicine to a more cost-effective level."
 
 
 
SOCKING IT TO THE INSURED
 LIKE most hospitals, Stanford Medical Center plays the game that medical economists call cost shifting. The numbers are startling.
In round figures, it goes like this: When Stanford has to perform a Caesarean section on a poor patient with no health insurance, it does so and records a loss of, say, $3,000. If Medicaid chips in, the loss may shrink to $1,500 and if the woman is covered by some private insurance, at a discount, the loss may be only $500.
Now, the key move: A fully insured woman -- no discounts involved -- is given a bill of $12,000 for a Caesarean that cost Stanford $7,000. This makes up for the $5,000 loss on the other patients.
The more expensive the operation, the higher the stakes. For, say, a $39,000 triple bypass, the insurance company of a nondiscount patient is billed $80,000.
 
THE PRIVATE-SECTOR SQUEEZE
 MANY employers, concerned about medical costs, now offer their workers financial and other incentives to choose doctors and hospitals that agree to a lower price. For example, for employees in certain areas, the Hewlett-Packard Company will cover 90 percent of the cost of an operation at a hospital with which it has negotiated a discount, but only 70 percent at other places, like Stanford, where it has not. Employees are protected by a cap of $1,250 on what they must pay for medical care in a year, but their out-of-pocket expenses can rise by hundreds of dollars if they opt for lower coverage.
What is more, Hewlett-Packard, like many employers, now provides incentives beyond money: "We give our employees a list of doctors and hospitals and tell them that we have selected them based not only on price but on quality of care," said Susan D. Moriconi, Hewlett-Packard's health-benefits manager. "And we know that our employees hate the paperwork of medical bills, so the providers take care of that."
Employers have particularly strong leverage in negotiating a favorable price in the Stanford area because competition for patients is rife. The Bay Area has more physicians per capita than almost any other area. And "every local hospital has expensive technology," said David Korn, dean of the Stanford Medical School.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Lessons From the 20-Year Averages

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
IN this bear market, one place to look for guideposts is history. A sharp-eyed student of past market behavior just might find some clues to the time when stocks, whose long-term values have been enhanced by the sharp drop in prices, will be real bargains again.
Goldman Sachs International Ltd. of London, led by Jeffrey M. Weingarten, its chief strategist, recently conducted such an exercise by reviewing market statistics going back 20 years. Goldman's conclusion, based on market levels at the end of October, was that stocks are still overvalued. Only when the markets decline a further 15 percent, the Goldman researchers said, would bargains reappear. 
 The Goldman forecast offers a very cautious approach for investors at a time when war jitters in the Middle East and the increasingly uncertain outlook for the world's economy make investing in stocks even riskier than usual.
To be sure, Goldman could have chosen a smaller slice of history as its guide -- specifically, the bullish 1980's -- and reached a much more sanguine conclusion: that stocks may be attractive right now. But it rejected that approach because it felt the decade's climb was an unrepresentative episode.
In any event, the slide in world stock markets in the last two weeks -- representing a drop on average of 3 percent -- has already accounted for some of the decline that the Goldman researchers said was needed for a turnaround, making the negative picture they painted look less bleak.
This latest fall in stock prices, which followed a sharp rally in October, is the second swing down in the wake of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August. The markets in Italy, Norway and Sweden have fallen to new lows for the year and others, including Japan, Germany and Spain, are nearing new troughs.
A revived threat of a war with Iraq, and the higher oil prices that that fear engenders, have had much to do with the new slump. The feisty words of British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher to Parliament on Wednesday intensified the war fears. On Thursday, the Bush Administration announced plans to add about 150,000 troops to the forces gathered in Saudi Arabia, giving the United States the option of launching an attack against the Iraqis rather than just defending against one.
The stronger draft of an economic downturn has also had its impact. October employment figures in the United States signaled a weaker economy and made a recession seem even more likely. Forecasts for Europe and Japan, where growth is still expected, have been reined in. And each week seems to bring another round of downward revisions in earnings forecasts.
Goldman's analysis, pegged to market levels on Oct. 24, uses several measures, including price/earnings ratios and dividend yield, to determine whether stock markets are overvalued or undervalued. Stocks become attractive again when they are undervalued. Using averages for these and other measures over the last 20 years, the Goldman researchers concluded that the major markets around the world, except for Italy, were still too expensive.
In Japan, the average price/earnings ratio was 46.5 percent higher than the 20-year average. The ratio was also higher in the United States (by 22.2 percent), the Netherlands (14.1 percent), Britain (3.2 percent) and Switzerland (2.1 percent). Overall, the markets were about 14 percent overvalued, excluding Japan, whose traditionally overvalued stocks push the world average to 37 percent.
The comparison of dividend yields produced a similar conclusion.
But the slide in prices in the last two weeks has made some of the valuations look better. Using P/E ratios and dividend yields through Thursday, Japan dropped to an overvaluation of 36.6 percent and the Netherlands to 8.5 percent; Switzerland actually showed an undervaluation of 2.8 percent. And dividend yields in six of the eight countries studied are now better than, or equal to, the 20-year average. Two weeks ago, only three were better than the average.
Using 1982 to 1989 as the base period makes a turnaround seem already at hand. Except for the United States and the Netherlands, all the P/E ratios become undervalued, for example.
Goldman rejected this analysis, however. "We feel the 80's were an abnormal period of equity performance and so it is not a good base," said Paul Feldman, a Goldman strategist.
But that does not mean that such figures won't be used by others arguing that it is time to jump back into stocks.
Mr. Feldman acknowledged that the latest market decline has improved the dismal picture that came from using a 20-year base period.
But given the risky situation in the Persian Gulf and the shaky outlook for the economy, Mr. Feldman said he could not lift the caution flag just yet. Still needed, he said, are signs that the economy is "looking right again" and reliable numbers that show stock market prices are clearly cheap again.
"I don't think that will be that far off," he said. "Maybe nine months away."

HEADLINE: The Spinoff Stratagem

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

DATELINE: WALTHAM, Mass.

 BODY:
THOUGH analysts may be impressed with how rapidly the Thermo Electron Corporation has been growing, George N. Hatsopoulos has a more ambitious perspective. Thermo Electron's founder and chief executive believes his 36-year-old company would be a $7 billion business, roughly 10 times its current size, if he had been running it in Japan instead of here in suburban Boston.
Mr. Hatsopoulos envies the access Japanese executives enjoy to cheap capital for investment in new ventures. Not only are Japanese interest rates lower, but Japanese companies are able to raise money by selling their stock at prices that Americans would regard as wildly inflated.
"A new venture here has to have twice the rate of return it would need in Japan to pay off," grumbled Mr. Hatsopoulos recently. 
 If any executive in American industry has demonstrated how to brood constructively rather than cower in the face of such discrepancies, it is Mr. Hatsopoulos, a 63-year-old Greek immigrant who has fashioned Thermo Electron into an unusual mini-conglomerate of high-technology businesses. A sampling of the Thermo product family: small power plants that burn agricultural waste; trucks designed to incinerate petroleum-soaked soil; bomb detectors; more than 100 types of instruments to monitor environmental contamination; dressings for wounds, and gas-fired air conditioners.
The common theme for most Thermo products is that they represent gambles on innovative technology to attack potentially huge markets in socially important areas, like the environment. Lately, the company has been bouncing from success to success while many of its more famous neighbors in the high-tech corridor surrounding Boston report slumping earnings. On Thursday, it reported that earnings in the quarter ended Sept. 29 rose 35 percent, to $9.5 million, while revenues jumped more than 27 percent, to $181 million.
A mechanical engineer by training who taught thermodynamics courses at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology during the company's early years, Mr. Hatsopoulos began worrying about the cost of capital nearly a decade ago. Thermo Electron stumbled into an earnings downturn as recession gripped the country, but Mr. Hatsopoulos wanted to forge ahead with investments in a number of technologies he believed would become useful for dealing with the world's energy and environmental problems. And he wanted to do it without borrowing heavily.
Mr. Hatsopoulos, who cultivates a wide circle of influential friends in government, industry and academia as part of his effort to anticipate business opportunities, delved so deeply into capital formation issues that he eventually became recognized as one of corporate America's leading experts on the subject. In 1982, he joined the board of the Federal Reserve Bank in Boston and served a two-year stint as its chairman that ended last year.
"I learned some things from him, and I never had a quicker student," said Lawrence H. Summers, the Harvard economist, who was one of the first experts Mr. Hatsopoulos turned to for help. "Today, he's right at the research frontier in this field and in a better position than most academics to say where theory meshes with experience."
THE research also led Mr. Hatsopoulos and his younger brother John, the company's chief financial officer, to gradually invent Thermo Electron's unique corporate structure. Starting in 1983, Thermo Electron has repeatedly set up pieces of the company as separate businesses and sold anywhere from 10 percent to 40 percent or so of their shares to institutional investors or the public at large. The goal was to give investors a chance to bet directly on the development of various pieces of Thermo Electron's broad technology base and to establish a clear market value for the strongest subsidiaries, which in turn raises the value of Thermo Electron shares.
"Spinning off some of our best divisions gives investors a simple picture," said Mr. Hatsopoulos.
It also allowed Thermo Electron to give managers stock options in their businesses, an incentive that is widely recognized as a heady stimulant for most executives. In addition, the option packages have helped Thermo Electron recruit and hang on to talented executives who wanted to run their own show. And dealing with outside shareholders helps groom potential successors for the top jobs in the company, according to Mr. Hatsopoulos, who says he hopes to stay at the company's helm another 10 years.
About 850 of the company's 5,000 employees are in various option plans and 95 percent of all employees are shareholders, according to John Hatsopoulos. The company has to grow to make those investments attractive because George Hatsopoulos is dead set against paying dividends.
Thermo Electron's spinoff strategy is by no means unique. Waste Management Inc., for example, won applause on Wall Street for selling 20 percent of its hazardous waste handling subsidiary, Chemical Waste Management Inc., to the public. But no company has taken the strategy as far as Thermo Electron.
THERMO ELECTRON's publicly traded subsidiaries currently include: Thermo Instrument Systems Inc., a leading supplier of environmental monitoring equipment, as well as engineering and testing services; Thermo Process Systems Inc., which makes high-temperature metal treatment equipment and waste incinerators; Tecogen Inc., which makes gas-fired equipment ranging from experimental auto engines to energy-saving air conditioners marketed by the Carrier Corporation and small-scale cogeneration systems that simultaneously generate electricity and steam heat, and Thermedics Inc., which makes a number of medical products and has been a pioneer in the development of supersensitive devices to detect explosives and drugs.
Through Thermedics, Thermo Electron also controls Thermo Cardiosystems Inc., which makes implantable pumps that keep damaged hearts beating regularly until patients can receive transplants, and Universal Voltronics Inc., which makes equipment to convert electricity supplied by utilities to currents and voltages used in industrial and military tasks with unusual power needs.
The next Thermo "pup," as analysts call the spinoffs, is likely to be Thermo Energy Systems Inc., which makes other cogeneration equipment, waste heat recovery systems and power plants fueled by alternate energy sources like agricultural wastes. Thermo Electron sold a 10 percent stake in Thermo Energy to institutional investors in Europe last summer for $8.5 million and hopes to have a public offering next spring.
The private placement reflected the strong following the company has built up overseas as part of its effort to court longterm investors. Well over 80 percent of the debt of Thermo and its spinoffs is potential equity, in the form of debentures that are convertible into stock in the parent company or the various spinoffs, and more than half the convertible debt has been placed in Europe. Foreign investors now hold 35 percent of the parent company's shares, according to John Hatsopoulos.
The Thermo spinoffs account for more than two-thirds of the company's sales. The most obvious drawback of the strategy is that accounting costs and other administrative expenses are relatively high, reflecting the extra filings required by the Securities and Exchange Commission and multiple annual reports. Each company has its own board of directors, but making sure that all dealings between the subsidiaries are fair to each company's shareholders is no mean feat.
"We don't make one move without the blessing of the legal department," said John Hatsopoulos.
The strategy also results in frequent profits from stock sales that make earnings look stronger than the actual results from the operating companies. At times, some analysts believe, investors have bid the price of the company up higher than its operating achievements warrant.
"But Thermo has a relatively low degree of risk for a high-tech company," said Otis Bradley, who follows the company and its offspring for H. C. Wainwright & Company, a Boston brokerage. "They have always had a fetish about maintaining a strong balance sheet. And they seem to get a strong market position in almost everything they do."
THE spinoff strategy has led some observers to describe Thermo Electron itself as a venture capital holding company, a research and development firm, or, in the word's of one analyst, a "perpetual idea machine." Such views square with Mr. Hatsopoulos's track record of pursuing many intriguing-sounding concepts in the belief that a few will become commercially successful enough to compensate for the disappointments.
Thermo Electron existed in its early years entirely on research contracts from government agencies and industry groups like the Gas Research Institute. Last year, more than half of Thermo Electron's $45 million research budget was financed by outside sources.
But Mr. Hatsopoulos's goal is to lead a multibillion-dollar company. With that in mind, the company sticks to projects where it can retain the right to commercialize the results.
"We have been working 25 years on artificial heart projects that we expect to bear fruit in the next three years, but the $70 million that has been spent was N.I.H. money," said Mr. Hatsopoulos, referring to the Federally funded National Institutes of Health. "That's the advantage of working on socially important technologies."

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
A Well-Informed Lucky Break

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
THE Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and some very astute investors do not see eye to eye on when to buy and sell banks.
At today's depressed levels, the shares of some major banks are starting to attract some notable bargain-hunters, including Warren Buffett, the legendary chairman of Berkshire Hathaway in Omaha, and the Loews Corporation, the corporate flagship of the savvy Tisch family in New York. 
But in this buyer's market, the F.D.I.C. is selling. Specifically, the agency is selling its stake in the Bank of Oklahoma, which it bailed out in 1986. Despite the current grim market for banks and an auction that featured a bit more uncertainty than seems necessary, the F.D.I.C. last month agreed to sell its stake in the bank for $61 million.
The price was close to the bank's book value and, although it was less than half the $130 million the agency invested in the bailout, it was far higher than anyone expected. A lucky break? Well, the successful bid was submitted by George B. Kaiser, an astute Tulsa oilman who served on the bank's board of directors, headed its audit committee and is familiar with the bank and its market. Clearly, Mr. Kaiser thinks he got a bargain. Which suggests that the F.D.I.C. -- and, thus, the public -- might not have.
Like many banks in the oil patch, the Bank of Oklahoma blossomed in the heady days of the late 1970's. In 1984, BancOklahoma Corporation, the bank's parent, doubled its gamble on the state's giddy economy by reaching beyond its Tulsa base to buy Fidelity Bank in Oklahoma City -- just as the boom disintegrated. Oil prices fell, natural gas prices fell and, soon, real estate prices and local payrolls fell. "Loan delinquencies, bankruptcy filings and mortgage foreclosures rose to unprecedented levels," the parent company recalled in a recent proxy report. The holding company's stock plummeted.
By 1986, the Oklahoma City bank was in danger of failing. In November that year, the F.D.I.C. propped it up with the $130 million in assistance. As part of that package, the Oklahoma City bank was merged with the Tulsa bank, with the agency getting preferred shares convertible into a 99.99 percent ownership stake in the merged institution. The remaining sliver of equity was left to BancOklahoma shareholders.
Unfortunately, the rescued bank did not live happily ever after. The local economy continued to decline and the bank undertook the bitter task of winnowing new problems from its portfolio and bolstering its reserves. It fell into arrears on its preferred share dividends and on loans from other banks. Last year, it managed to restructure its debts, with its creditor banks agreeing to new terms and the F.D.I.C. agreeing not to convert its preferred shares into common shares until at least March 1990.
But the Federal agency declined to hold onto those shares until the bank could benefit from the restructuring. As the market for bank shares sagged, it sought bids for its stake. And after ruminating a bit, Mr. Kaiser decided to submit one. He resigned from the BancOklahoma board last January and submitted his bid in August.
The bid's size surprised even the top executives of the bank, although the bank has been profitable since its restructuring and its loan portfolio is growing steadily healthier. "This is a much higher amount than anyone thought he would pay," said Leonard J. Eaton, chairman and chief executive. "But obviously, this is the dominant banking franchise in the state of Oklahoma. If it continues its progress, the potential is there for profit."
Mr. Kaiser says that his bid was "about 50 percent community concern." He explained, "We need a locally concerned bank. But obviously, I would not enter into the transaction if I didn't think it would be profitable." He thinks the Oklahoma economy is turning around and that real estate values are low enough to attract cost-conscious businesses even in a recession.
Mr. Kaiser conceded that his optimism is based partly on his intimate knowledge of the bank he is buying. "I suppose I was more comfortable with the Bank of Oklahoma because of my familiarity with the institution," he said. But he noted that other potential bidders had access to ample information throughout the bidding process.
One piece of information, however, was not available to any bidder, including Mr. Kaiser. Federal bank examiners visited the bank during the bid period, but their findings were not available before the bid deadline in August. Although the regulators apparently found no new skeletons, the timing may have clouded the bidding. "I think there's no question that, given the 'reg-phobia' of a lot of people in the industry, that added a lot of uncertainty," said Mr. Eaton. "I know that it was a major consideration for at least one potential bidder."
The F.D.I.C. refused to comment on the auction's timing, and Mr. Kaiser said he did think he would have faced more competition in the bidding if the report had been available, or if the agency had waited to sell until the current anti-bank hysteria subsides.
In any case, Mr. Eaton and others associated with the bank agree that Mr. Kaiser's price is a very good one, even if a better one might have been possible later. And rather than taking the bank private, as he once planned, Mr. Kaiser will offer some sort of equity stake for holding company shareholders. Any deal that emerges from those negotiations, of course, will reflect the current depressed price of the company's stock, despite Mr. Kaiser's faith in the bank's future.
"I guess the F.D.I.C. just decided it wanted to sell," said Mr. Eaton, who will relinquish his post to Mr. Kaiser and take early retirement when the deal is completed. "The bank is improving. In a normal world, one would have expected that, down the road, they might have been able to get a better price. But they got a very good price, and given the uncertainties, I'm not entirely sure I wouldn't have made the same decision."

HEADLINE: Business Diary: November 4-9

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
From London to Cairo: A March Toward War?
 
The week's events seemed as carefully orchestrated as a Sousa, or maybe a James A. Baker 3d, march: Tuesday, the British Foreign Minister warned that time was running out for President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. Wednesday, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt said war was inevitable unless Iraq withdrew from Kuwait in two or three months. Thursday, President Bush ordered at least an additional 150,000 troops to the Persian Gulf. And, in Moscow, the Soviet Foreign Minister sounded a softer but still harmonious note by admitting the possible use of force. Traders, who sent the price of oil below $32 a barrel on Monday, raised it to $35.53 after President Bush spoke. On Friday, oil finished at $33.89, as market participants decided that armed conflict was unlikely for the rest of the year. William L. Randol, an analyst at First Boston, figures that oil supplies will be tight enough to keep prices at about $30 through the winter. He adds another $5 or so for rising fears of war. "It's workable if nothing goes wrong," he said. "But the history is that things do go wrong."

The Non-inflationary Recession
 
The brighter side of this economic slowdown is that it is keeping higher energy prices from raising the cost of much else. Producer prices rose 1.1 percent in October, after even higher increases the two previous months. Take out food and energy, and core producer prices in October were flat. Economists say that, with a recession more likely, only a few industries like airlines can raise their prices. Joseph Carson, senior economist at Chemical Bank, said higher energy costs will show up instead in reduced corporate profits, wages and employment. If the last two oil price shocks increased inflation, "this one may be more deflationary," he said. "The pressures to discount prices because of a weakening economy appear to be winning out."
 
'Big Green' Wilts
 
Messages from a restive electorate: Let environmental issues wither, but let the tax battles resume. California's "Big Green" ballot proposition, described as the nation's most comprehensive environmental program, united many industries to help bring about its defeat. New York State turned down a $2.1 billion environmental bond act, leaving communities to pay for mandatory recycling and search for new landfills. While Republicans limited their off-year losses on Capitol Hill, Democratic gains in state capitals give them an advantage in redistricting come 1991. Voters handed over governorships to different parties, or independents, in 14 states, causing some governors to reconsider increased taxes. President Bush tried on Thursday to retread his no-tax pledge for the future -- "It ain't going to happen, I'll guarantee you," he said. Democrats, sensing the President's weakness, talked of reviving their proposal for a surtax on the wealthy.
 
An Early Christmas
 
No wonder their wreaths and tinsel and tree ornaments are already up. The department stores desperately want Christmas shopping to begin. The nation's major retailers reported an awful October, with sales down 1.2 percent from last October at Sears, Roebuck, and down 4.9 percent at J.C. Penney. But at Wal-Mart, sales were up 25 percent.
 
A Legal Cartel for Airlines
 
To some travelers, it seems that the airlines are behaving like the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. The International Air Transport Association agreed last week to raise fares 4 to 8 percent, after authorizing raises in the same range about three months ago. Washington has given United States airlines antitrust immunity for taking part in the group. Consumer advocates growled, but analysts said the airlines are sharing the pain. "There is absolutely no gouging taking place," said Paul Karos, an analyst at First Boston. "The industry isn't coming close to recovering its fuel cost increases." The nation's airlines have also raised domestic fares about 9 percent since the gulf crisis began. With the economy weakening, Mr. Karos said, the airlines are unlikely to push prices higher unless there is war.

 
 
COMPANIES

 
Volvo's Car-Crushing Ads Backfire
 
The roof has caved in on Volvo's advertisements. The Swedish company tried to dramatize the safety of its cars with commercials showing a monster pickup truck, emblazoned "Bear Foot," crunching a row of cars and leaving only the Volvo intact. A dramatization it was: the Volvo roof was reinforced; the roof on another car weakened. When charged with false advertising by the Texas Attorney General, Volvo promised not to make unverified safety claims but said its advertising agency, Scali McCabe Sloves, had acted without its knowledge. Volvo ran disclaimers in several newspapers, while one executive bemoaned the public's failure to get a joke.
 
Twisted Market
 
The bond market's byzantine mechanics: A ratings downgrade for Citicorp debt on Monday raised prices for other issues, without hurting Citicorp itself. Citicorp's firmness was simple: traders had anticipated the downgrade, by Standard & Poor's. But investors did not let the misfortunes of the nation's largest bank holding company scare them into dumping other bonds. Instead, they bid up other issues, saying they expected a recession, with interest rates bound to fall. Then, on Wednesday, Citicorp tried to raise investor confidence in its own securities by deciding to redeem $275 million in preferred stock.
 
 Darryl Defects
 
It's bad enough that several investment banks are talking about leaving New York City. But last week, Darryl Strawberry decided to move his business from New York to Los Angeles. The Mets offered their leading home-run producer $15 million for four years. Like some Wall Street managing directors who earn almost as much, he felt abused, maligned and cheated. "I don't think the front office of the New York Mets appreciated Darryl Strawberry," he said. And so to the Los Angeles Dodgers for the chance to play in his hometown at $23.5 million for five years. "I couldn't sleep," said Tommy Lasorda, the Dodgers manager. "I was so excited." Lasorda might not sleep much come this spring, either, because now he has to manage a guy whose temperament makes a Salomon bond trader seem blissful and serene.
 
In Brief
 
The Nieman-Marcus Group will not carry the General Cinema label. The General Cinema Corporation withdrew its $240 million, $14.40-a-share offer for the 40 percent of the retailer it doesn't own after several shareholders filed suits saying the price was too low.
 
The Burger King Corporation helped end a boycott by a religious group with newspaper advertisements last week boasting of the company's support for "traditional American values on television." The group accused Burger King of sponsoring shows having "gratuitous sex, violence and anti-Christian stereotyping.
 
Prudential-Bache is laying off as many as two-thirds of its investment bankers as Wall Street firms continued to retrench.
 
 
INTERNATIONAL


Seoul Races to the Soviet Union
 
The first brand name that passengers arriving at Moscow's international airport see is not Marlboro, Pepsi, or Sony, but Samsung, emblazoned on every luggage cart. South Korea is rushing to secure a place in the Soviet market before the Japanese arrive. While the Japanese try to settle a territorial dispute with the Soviets, South Korea has re-established diplomatic relations, arranging to buy Soviet raw materials and offer steel and electronics in return. On Monday, Ju Young-Chung, the chairman of the huge Hyundai industrial and construction group, met with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev at the Kremlin. The South Korean press reported that Mr. Gorbachev asked for Hyundai's help in developing the Soviet Far East and easing shortages of consumer goods. Mr. Chung asked Mr. Gorbachev to help improve relations between the two Koreas. Progress on both fronts is likely. South Koreans hope to give their products the same cachet in the Soviet Union that Sony has in the West. One immediate problem with selling consumer goods to the Soviet Union, says Robert K. Kim, vice president of the Korea Fund, which invests in Korean securities: "The Russians can't pay for them."
 
Bringing Phones to Poland
 
Poland wants the fruits of its newly free markets to include a $15 billion telephone system by the turn of the century. The Government intends to abandon the state monopoly on domestic phone service, opening the field to Polish and foreign competitors. Communications Minister Jerzy Slezak said on Friday that the new communications system would increase the telephone count from 3.8 per 100 people to 30 in 10 years. Some 7,000 Polish villages are now without service. The Soviet Union has 15 phones per 100 people; the United States has about 50. Two American companies, which the Polish Government refuses to name, are among the five vying to set up a cellular network to serve 200,000 users.

HEADLINE: Selling a Free-Trade Pact With Mexico

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH the Bush Administration will only begin negotiating a proposed free-trade agreement with Mexico this spring, Safi Qureshey, the chief executive of AST Research Inc. in Irvine, Calif., is already anticipating the wider opening of a major market for his computers. "We see a tremendous potential there," Mr. Qureshey said.
That is the kind of enthusiasm that Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher wanted to hear as he traveled the country recently, seeking support for the free-trade proposal. But if the Administration is to successfully negotiate a pact with Mexico that can win ratification by Congress, Mr. Bush and Mr. Mosbacher will also have to address the concerns of business owners like Rito Gutierrez, the president of Cal-Art Sportswear in downtown Los Angeles. 
 Mr. Gutierrez believes that an agreement would mean a "slow death" for his business by increasing competition from garment factories in Mexico, where wages are a fraction of those in the United States. "The apparel industry here, and particularly the sewing contractors, are virtually going to be put out of business," he said.
The proposed agreement with Mexico, which would eliminate almost all tariffs and other trade barriers, would aid the United States as a whole, and particularly border states like California and Texas. American companies seeking higher sales in Mexico or easier access to its cheap labor, as well as firms that facilitate or finance trade, would be clear winners.
But there would also be losers in the United States. Companies in many industries would face new competition from Mexican and American firms making their goods in Mexico. Some workers would see their jobs go south. And the losers could do more than gripe. Some, like organized labor and the textile and steel industries, could exert enough political clout to impede or derail an agreement.
MOREOVER, a free-trade accord with Mexico, formally proposed by President Carlos Salinas de Gortari to President Bush this summer, would be far more complex than a similar arrangement that took effect with Canada last year. Talks are likely to take years. Mexico's wages, education levels, regulatory climate and political system are far different from those in Canada and the United States. The Mexican plan could have a far-reaching impact on other issues like the environment and immigration.
PRESIDENT BUSH strongly favors a trade accord with Mexico, the nation's third-largest trading partner, after Canada and Japan. It would go a long way toward the Administration's goal of creating a hemispheric free-trade zone. Agreements with Canada and Mexico would establish a North American free-trade zone 25 percent larger than the European Community.
American critics of such a deal say they fear the flight of manufacturing and agriculture to Mexico, where low-wage workers are plentiful and environmental controls and labor regulations are looser. The dangers to the United States economy would increase, these critics say, ifPresident Bush followed through with his proposal to extend free-trade agreements throughout Latin America.
"The primary benefit which U.S. firms can gain from freer trade with Mexico, the Caribbean and Latin America is the opportunity to move production to locations where wage, benefit and regulatory costs are a fraction of those at home," said Richard Rothstein, an economist with the Economic Policy Institute, a Los Angeles research group. "Seduced by our own propaganda about the superiority of a free market, we are in danger of negotiating Mexican and other Latin American free-trade agreements which destroy American jobs and undermine environmental and labor standards for those who remain," he told a California state legislative committee recently.
Bush Administration officials, including Mr. Mosbacher, disagree. They say the benefits to the overall economy in the United States would outweigh the risks of lost jobs and evasion of environmental rules. An accord would improve the Mexican economy, they say -- and aid the United States by providing a vibrant market for its products and services.
These officials say Mexico is committed to bringing its environmental and other regulatory standards into line with those in the United States. And as new jobs are created in Mexico, they say, wages there would rise, reducing the differential with the United States. "An agreement would help Mexico, and that's great," Mr. Mosbacher said during a recent interview in Los Angeles. "But it will also create jobs and opportunities here in the U.S."
Both the opportunities and the risks of a free-trade pact are clearly visible in California, with its diverse economy and its close ties to Mexico.
To exporters, Mexico is an increasingly promising market. As part of his plan to open the Mexican economy, President Salinas has over recent years considerably reduced tariffs and attempted to lower daunting bureaucratic barriers to the sale of foreign goods.
As a result, companies like AST are starting to push into the market. AST recently opened a Mexico City office, with sales of $1 million worth of computers in the last six months -- a relatively modest amount, but 10 times as much as the company had ever sold in Mexico before.
FETZER VINEYARDS of Redwood Valley, Calif., is also watching Mexico closely. Foreign wine sales in Mexico have long been dominated by European vintners. But Gus Furtado, Fetzer's export manager, said that as tariffs on American wines have fallen, California vineyards have become increasingly interested. A free-trade agreement would permit California wines to become more competitive, he said. The company expects to sell 2,000 cases of wine in Mexico this year, up from 200 last year. "We see a great opportunity down the road for that market," Mr. Furtado said.
There could also be benefits to companies that want to assemble more of their products in Mexico. Under existing agreements with Mexico, American companies can ship components, free of the usual tariffs and duties, to plants for assembly by low-paid Mexican workers. With a free-trade agreement, more American companies, squeezed by competition to keep costs low, would likely do assembly work in Mexico. Some would also move entire manufacturing operations to Mexico, instead of simply sending components over the border. In some cases, American jobs would be lost. But without greater access to Mexican workers, companies would just shift production to other sources of cheap labor, especially in Asia.
Mattel Inc., based in Hawthorne, Calif., said that under a free-trade agreement, it would substantially increase its Mexican operations. Mattel already has two plants, in Tijuana and Monterrey, which produce 35 percent of the toys it sells in the United States. Mattel produces no toys in the United States -- the rest of its work is done mostly in Asia -- so the agreement would not result in the loss of manufacturing jobs in this country.
IN fact, Mattel said, increased operations in Mexico would benefit the American companies that supply virtually all the parts and equipment -- including plastics, dyes, machinery and packaging. -- used in the Mexican factories.
By eliminating tariffs, an agreement could also help some major California agricultural and food companies that have begun growing crops and processing food in Mexico and shipping them to the United States. But smaller farmers and produce growers in California fear that they would be at a severe disadvantage if imports increased because of Mexico's lower labor costs and looser rules on pesticides. Mexico is making the greatest gains in exporting fruits and vegetables that are labor-intensive, like vine-ripened tomatoes, which must be harvested by hand.
Mexican officials say they are tightening environmental restrictions, but many experts in the United States doubt that Mexican standards will become as strict as those in California any time soon. "Every year Mexico is competing with us more and more in fresh produce," said Roy Motter, one of the owners of Brawley Farms in the Imperial Valley east of San Diego. "We're concerned about the playing field being level."
The primary concern for small manufacturers is the dramatic wage differential. Ho Fat Seto, who owns the Ho Fat jeans-making factory in Los Angeles, said he must pay his 68 employees a minimum of $34 for an 8-hour day. His competitors in Mexico, he said, pay their workers roughly $3 for a day that may run much longer.
So far, he said, Mexican companies have not been able to take full advantage of lower wages because their garment factories have a reputation for producing shoddy goods and failing to meet schedules. American manufacturers don't count on these handicaps persisting. "Sooner or later the Mexicans will be successful," Mr. Seto said. "The labor situation in Mexico is already killing our business, and free trade will affect it even more, that's for sure."
 
 
CONTROLLING IMMIGRATION
 A FREE-TRADE agreement with Mexico, some experts say, could accomplish what the 1986 overhaul of the immigration law did not: slow the flow of illegal aliens into the United States.
Economists say the agreement would create many new jobs in Mexico and push up wages. With better jobs at home, fewer Mexicans would risk crossing the border. "To the extent that a free-trade agreement reduces the real wage differential between Mexico and the U.S. over a long period of time, it could have a very significant deterrent effect on future immigration," said Wayne Cornelius, the director of the Center for U.S.-Mexico Studies at the University of California at San Diego.
But the deterrent might not take effect for years, perhaps a decade, because it would take that long for new jobs to be created. The agreement could actually increase the flow of illegal immigrants, at least temporarily.
"If an agreement produces a general stimulus to the Mexican economy, it may give some Mexicans who had been planning to emigrate the financial means to do so," Mr. Cornelius said, "and to the extent that it stimulates the U.S. economy, it may encourage Mexicans who legalized under the 1986 immigration law to bring their dependents in."
It also remains unclear whether diminished immigration from Mexico would be an advantage for the United States. Reduced migration might ease the strain on social services, but it would also shrink the pool of low-wage workers that many manufacturers and farmers in the United States rely on to remain competitive.

HEADLINE: All About/Cruise Lines;
A Deluge of Growth in the Floating Vacation Market

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
EVERY Sunday, newspaper travel advertisements bring a reminder that cruise ships have armed themselves for competitive battle. For example, seven-day cruises to the Caribbean that normally cost $1,800 are discounted to $1,000, airfare included. Those who shop around can pay as little as $700.
And more is on order. This year, 13 ships with 11,000 berths are being added to the cruise line fleet operating primarily out of North America, expanding capacity by 15 percent. The largest, Carnival Cruise Lines's Fantasy, has 2,025 berths -- more than many of the old ocean liners and all but the largest hotels. 
 Common sense would indicate that rapid expansion and the onset of a recession guarantee that the industry will sink. But cruise line executives have not built their fortunes on pessimism and doubt. Indeed, some say a recession will only add to the business coming their way. Bob Dickinson, a senior vice president for sales and marketing at Carnival, said that travelers will be attracted to cruise packages because they usually are all-inclusive -- air fare, lodging and food. "In tough economic times," he explained, "people want to know what they are getting into and how much they have to lay out."
 
PLAYING THE RECESSION
More Berths, but Higher Air Fares
 Through the last decade, the outlook for the cruise business has been as sunny as the Caribbean skies. Although most companies are private and need not release figures, analysts say industry revenues and profits have been growhing consistently.
Industry executives say they have just begun tapping the market. Mr. Dickinson estimates that only about 6 percent of all American vacation travelers have tried a cruise. The Cruise Lines International Association, a trade group, says the market for cruises in North America could reach $55 billion to $60 billion a year -- 10 times the level of sales today.
Growth is limited only by space on board, said Michael G. Mueller, an analyst for Montgomery Securities. Cruise lines "have always been able to fill up the new capacity," he said. Demographic trends are also on the industry's side, he added. "As more people get older," he explained, "they have more disposable income."
One other favorable current is the weak dollar. Some travelers, discouraged by the cost of visiting Europe, might settle for a Caribbean cruise instead.
Of course, not everyone believes the industry can sail through a recession, especially not smaller operators with aging ships.
Larry Fishkin, president of Cruise Line Inc., in Miami, which buys wholesale blocks of space then retails the berths to passengers, said that several small operators had called him in alarm over low bookings. Mr. Fishkin can offer little comfort. Autumn is always a slow season, with price breaks the norm, but he has found that discounts are especially deep this year. "I've seen prices for this period as low as I've seen them in seven or eight years," he said. Carnival was offering a rate of $695 for a seven-day cruise to repeat customers, he said.
Sally Smith, an analyst with Alex. Brown & Sons, said that the industry is being squeezed from two sides. Cruise operators, who usually buy plane tickets in bulk, are unable to pass along the entire 15 percent fare increases levied by airlines since August, when the Middle East crisis sent fuel prices soaring. The ships' own fuel costs have risen, too, but these usually account for less than 5 percent of their expenses.
Ms. Smith said that the demand for cruises grew straight through the last recession, in 1982. But she added that the industry then had far fewer berths to fill, and that few new ships were built during the recession.
To carry the expected traffic this time around, and provide more diversions, the latest ships are also some of the largest. The industry has been spending lavishly, on ships that can cost more than $200 million each. Industry analysts say the berth count will keep growing, by about 13 percent in 1991 and 9 percent in 1992 before retreating to a 4 percent gain in 1993. Possible overcapacity is unlikely to affect anyone's plans in the near term. It takes three or four years to build a ship, and halting construction is difficult and expensive.
 
WHAT'S IN A CRUISE?
Everything for The Middle Class
The cruise industry has changed immeasurably since the era of the really grand ocean liners. Back then, a cruise was the first-class way to reach a holiday destination. As recently as 20 years ago, about 500,000 people annually, most of them rich, took cruises of three days or more .
Now, the ships are destinations in themselves. Several lines run cruises to nowhere, with passengers staying on board. About 3.5 million people are expected to sail from North American ports this year. .
The man largely responsible for lowering the gangplank to the vacationing masses is Ted Arison, who founded Carnival Cruise Lines in 1972, beginning with one old ship, the Mardi Gras, during an energy crisis. To save on fuel, the ship traveled slowly, stopping at few ports.
To keep his customers happy about spending so much time on board, he installed a casino, a disco, a movie theater and two nightclubs. Who had time to long for Caribbean ports? Low prices and aggressive marketing helped persuade the middle class to clamber aboard.
Carnival's acquisition of the Holland America Line last year raised its revenues to $1.15 billion. The four other companies that, with Carnival, dominate the North American industry are Kloster Cruise Ltd., which owns Norwegian Cruise Lines, Royal Cruise and Royal Viking; Princess Cruises; the Royal Caribbean Cruise Line, and Chandris Fantasy Cruises.
Next for the industry? Estelle Lessack, for one, whose Travel Trends agency in Fort Lee, N.J., handles cruises on most lines, said the idea for most is to have a cruise for every taste. "So much is being offered on the cruise ships that it just about takes in everybody," she said.
 
TO MAXIMIZE RETURNS
Keep Them Aboard, Spending $50 a Day
With extra capacity visible on the horizon, the cruise ships are piling on the attractions, adding more sports, health and social programs than ever. Norwegian Cruise Lines boasts that golf and tennis pros will help passengers with their games. Net-draped driving ranges are available on board and golf courses and tennis courts, on shore. Others offer "spa cruises," with special wieght-loss, cholesterol-lowering diets and fitness programs in elaborate gyms.
For sports fans who want to see the stars in the off-season, Norwegian also plans to bring football and baseball players on board special cruises next year. Some lines have specialized in attracting older women, often widowed. Its ships are well stocked with hired men, most of them excellent dancers.
Cruise lines are also trying to earn more from passengers once they board by multiplying the opportunities for them to drink, shop and gamble. Many spend about $50 a day, which helps compensate for cruise discounts.
To spread the news, advertising budgets are substantially higher. And then there is one more audience the lines try hard to satisfy. They make sure that travel agents have special incentives to recommend a cruise. Besides requiring minimal effort to book, the commissions, at the larger agencies, tend to be 13 to 15 percent, 3 to 5 percentage points higher than for airlines and land-bound hotels.
 
 
>ON THE PRINCESS, WHO NEEDS A PORT?
 PETER and Ivonne West of Chicago hardly cared when, on its inaugural cruise, the Crown Princess had to steer clear of a hurricane and through some Caribbean storms. They gambled in the casino, danced in the discos, window shopped the boutiques around the three-story atrium and sampled six kinds of caviar at the ship's wine and champagne bar.
The Crown Princess, placed in service in September by Princess Cruises, belongs to a new generation of huge ships that aims to keep passengers so well entertained they have no time to yearn for the next port.
Longer than three Manhattan blocks and taller than a 13-story hotel, the ship cost more than $200 million. It has room for 1,590 passengers in cabins that are spacious by the industry's cramped standards.
The Crown Princess looks as though it was sculpted, not built, to resemble a dolphin gliding through the waves. The architect, Renzo Piano, also designed the arresting Pompidou Center in Paris.
Mr. Piano topped the ship with a glass dome 19 feet high, enclosing a palace of drinking, dancing and gambling. Not that passengers lack alternatives; among the 7 other cafes and bars, one called Kipling's is a cross between disco and tropical inn, with floor-to-ceiling mirrors, a raised stage for dancing, leather and rattan furniture, ceiling fans and potted plants.
Mrs. West, 33, sells insurance, and her husband, 41, drives a truck -- occupations that place them in the moderate-income group the cruise lines want to attract. They are veterans of many cruises, but the Crown Princess left them impressed. "It's a beautiful ship," Mrs. West said. "It's certainly big." But not even the biggest.
On the days they ventured outdoors, Mr. West shot skeet while his wife lounged on the deck, taking occasional dips in both pools.
They did have a few disappointments -- an indifferent waiter, a disc jockey who played the wrong music. No matter; they agree that they would eagerly go back.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
America Is Still a Land of Opportunity

BYLINE: By HENRY TASHIMA; Henry Tashima is president of the Minolta Camera Company, Osaka, Japan.

 BODY:
I OFTEN get the feeling that the United States has lost some of the confidence it once had. America's perception of its economic vulnerability is reflected in the success of such books as "The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers" by Paul Kennedy, "The Reckoning" by David Halberstam, "Buying Into America" by Martin and Susan Tolchin, and numerous public opinion polls. But the United States is still the richest country in the world. The American people still enjoy the highest living standard of any people and the United States still plays a dominant role in the world economy.
America's gross national product far exceeds that of any other nation. Last year, it was $5.17 trillion. Its nearest rivals were Japan, at $2.82 trillion, and West Germany, at $1.5 trillion. Manufacturing continues to account for about 24 percent of the United States G.N.P., as it has since the 1960's. And the United States controls more than 60 percent of the world's computer industry and is the leader in supercomputers, computer software and microprocessors. Over the past two decades, the American share of total world exports has been fairly consistent at 17 percent. 
 Importation of foreign cars to the United States continues to increase, particularly from Japan. But the General Motors Corporation is No. 1 and Ford Motor Company is No. 2 in world auto sales, assets and profits. Both companies earn more than half their profits overseas.
Nor are America's big auto makers alone. The foreign operations of American companies account for more than $1 trillion in annual sales, roughly four times the total export of goods made in the United States and about seven to eight times recent American annual trade deficits.
Just about everyone in the world seems to recognize the fact that the United States is by far the world's most appealing land of opportunity -- everyone, that is, except Americans. Tourism and immigration are up, reflecting the high level of esteem in which the rest of the world holds the United States.
There are many reasons for this. The United States has the natural resources, the technological capabilities and the dedicated work force to cope with changing economic conditions. The country is unique in its ability to recognize, acknowledge and solve its problems.
The political and economic ideals that the United States has upheld are taking hold elsewhere, even in countries that once attacked the American way of life. Without American help, Japan could never have made the recovery it did after the war.
As Europe, Asia, and the rest of the world all move toward greater economic freedom and political unity, we must not lose sight of the role played by the United States. The whole world is in its debt. It is time for America to recognize the economic role it plays in the world.
