HEADLINE: About Cars;
Acura's NSX: All-Aluminum Exotica

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
WHAT is so amazing about Acura's new NSX is not its blinding speed or the ripping mountain-lion snarl of the engine when you put your foot into it. What is so amazing is not the complex suspension that makes the NSX handle as well as anything yet put on the road. Nor is it the fact that hungry customers are pushing and shoving to pay double the car's sticker price.
No, what is so surprising about this tiger, this first true exoticar from Japan, is that it is such a pussycat to drive. The NSX is maybe the best sports car that ever was, but it behaves with all the civility of a Honda Accord -- which with good reason has become America's top-selling automobile. 
 Acura is Honda's luxury division, and the NSX is the world's first all-aluminum production car. It is also Honda's laboratory for technology, and it demonstrates what can be done when a major manufacturer puts its effort into making a super-car that refuses even a nod at the usual eccentricities.
 The NSX is many things, the first of which is gorgeous. When you cast eyes on it, it occurs to you that this is too much of a museum piece to put out there in the cut and thrust of traffic. What a shame to treat it like an automobile. It is a Ferrari, but better.
Then you get into it, and you know how much better. There is cream-colored leather, accented by hides that are dyed black. There is stitching, but without the quaint handmade look of a Maserati. The gauges are round and readable and everything is the way you think a car should be. It is the car that some of us drew in junior high school, the one that nobody ever built.
But you'd better be feeling sociable when you get behind the wheel, because everybody from dowagers in Lincolns to punks in primered Novas will engage you in conversation. I was not 10 minutes into the car, sitting at a traffic light, when the police went by, stopped, backed up. Normally, a serious uh-oh.
But all the Sir wanted to know was how I liked it, how long I'd had it, how fast was it. Good luck, he said.
The car was red, very. With a black roof. And I quickly realized that a trip in the NSX, despite its hot-rod capabilities, is often slower than that same trip in more boring machinery. The troopers give chase just to lay hands on the pretty flanks, just to look at the car up close.
But close or far, that body is sculpture. It is formed entirely of aluminum, as is every major component, and the elimination of iron and steel has cut the weight by 40 percent. The NSX weighs only 3,010 pounds, and that minimal avoirdupois has been wind-funneled and otherwise honed for quickness and fuel efficiency.
The aerodynamics are particularly noticeable in the passenger compartment, and airflow has been managed so well that driving with an open window is not much different than driving with the window closed, yielding only a quiet breeze.
Everything is of a piece, one part sweeping into the next. The large rear window curves into hind quarters that make one think of nothing so much as a quarter horse (or a Ferrari.) And the back window pops open so you can lift the huge rear package shelf for access to the engine.
The 3-liter V6 is mounted transversely and drives the rear wheels. It is compact, with aluminum block and heads, and its double overhead cams operate four valves per cylinder, generating an incredible 270 horsepower.
Honda has been successful in Formula One racing, and its experience -- and some racing parts -- have gone into the Acura's engine. Acceleration from zero to 60 is on the order of 5.6 seconds, and the NSX has a top speed of 168 miles an hour.
All the same, the car's light weight and technology conspire to provide an economy rating of 19 m.p.g., city, and 24, highway, good enough to avoid America's gas-guzzler tax, which will be doubled under the new Federal budget plan, rising to $1,000 from $500.
For all its deftness, the car feels surprisingly heavy, and part of that is a lack of power steering. That frivolity is available, however, if a buyer shuns the five-speed stick and opts for the four-speed automatic, although it is hard to see why anyone would.
The stick is stubby and leather-covered (what else?) and the shifter's throws are short and tight. The three-spoke wheel also lends a no-nonsense air to driving. It is leather-wrapped but hard and unpadded, and it feels much like the wheel in a Formula Ford. There is, of course, an air bag in the hub, and Honda has announced that all its products will have bags for both driver and passenger by the fall of 1993.
 Safety has also dictated massive disk brakes that are hooked to a four-channel antilock system, and the same computer that controls braking is in charge of traction control, automatically reducing engine power whenever it senses imminent wheel spin. That means that you can't twitch the rear end out, even in hard driving.
However, if you feel a sincere craving to steer with the accelerator, you can turn the system off with the push of a sensibly hard-to-get-at button up by the 185-m.p.h. speedometer. The other gauges are a 9,000-r.p.m. tachometer with a 7,900 redline, and meters for oil pressure, temperature, volts and fuel. The controls, like the rest of this car, are pretty much perfect, and the NSX is the first car that I have seriously considered running away with.
Apparently, a lot of people feel that way, and would-be buyers are queuing up with obscene amounts of cash in hand. Honda last week raised the sticker for the second time this year, pushing it from the original $58,000 to $61,000, but that is laughable, given the going price.
Most American dealers have received only one or two of the cars thus far, and a lot are keeping them for themselves. Those who aren't are selling them for $75,000 to $80,000, and private speculators are offering them at well over $100,000.
In Japan, the NSX costs even more, and there is a waiting list in the homeland of almost three years. But 17 lucky residents of Hiroshima won't have to wait that long. They won a recent lottery, and the prize was permission to buy the cars for a paltry $65,000.

LENGTH: 980 words

HEADLINE: Voters in Westchester Approve Air Terminal

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON

 BODY:
ERIC LANGELOH, Westchester County's Commissioner of Transportation, has about two dozen architects' renderings in his office of proposed new terminals for the county's airport, right across the state line from Greenwich. The earliest drawing is "dated 1946, the year I was born," he said.
It may seem to Mr. Langeloh and other county officials that they have been dealing with the issue of a new airport terminal for most of their lives. 
 "You're looking at 45-odd years worth of people planning and arguing and debating," Mr. Langeloh said. "For it finally to get out to the public and for the public to say 'Yes, let's do it,' that's a major accomplishment."
Last week, in a $21 million bonding referendum, Westchester voters provided the go-ahead for a 41,000-square-foot replacement terminal. But just barely. The proposal was approved by a slender margin of 84,077 votes in favor and 79,587 against, or 51.37 percent to 48.63 percent.
 
What Happens Next
 The approval sets several events in motion, with the terminal's construction being the final, rather than the initial, accomplishment.
"Within 30 to 45 days," Mr. Langeloh said, "we'll be letting bids on the first phase, which is the access roadwork, an interior road system that will cost $5.7 million and represent a year's worth of work beginning next spring."
The road will be rebuilt from "where you currently pick up your parking ticket," he said. It will be redesigned, "so that you'll be able to go directly to the terminal for drop-offs or to a new parking structure," the second airport project.
The three-story, 1,200-space garage will be built for $17 million by a developer after public bids. That should be completed by the spring of 1992, when construction of the two-level terminal will begin. It should be in use by the spring of 1993.
 The struggle against the proposed terminal, fought by elected officials and homeowner groups in nearby communities in both Connecticut and New York, dominated the final weeks of the election campaign.
 <> <> <> <> Supervisor Donald B. Gioffre of Rye, N.Y., a leader in the effort to defeat the terminal plan, was diplomatic in defeat as he described the next stage of the struggle over what opponents still feel is an inevitable expansion of the airport. But he was still angry over the loss itself.
"Since the people have voted, it is only right to respect that vote," he said. "The county has offered to cooperate with us, so we will hold it accountable for its word that the terminal will cost only $21 million, that it will guarantee a continuation of the nighttime curfew, and that it will maintain a passenger cap of 234 passengers per half-hour."
 
A Reminder on a Pledge
 The county has also pledged to keep "larger and noisier planes away" from the airport, he said.
And finally, he said, "I hope we don't see the area around the new terminal magically transformed into additional apron space for aircraft."
 Mr. Gioffre expressed bitterness about what he felt was a massive, government-financed campaign to enlist support for the referendum.
Peter W. Delaney, Westchester's General Services administrator, headed the campaign in support of the proposal under County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke. Mr. Delaney said that $50,000 was raised privately and that $100,000 was spent by the county in supporting the referendum.
 The $150,000 total was "absurdly low for at least four mailings, brochures and other material that appeared throughout the county," Mr. Gioffre said. "The Town of Rye spent $3,000 on one mailer, done by myself and others and mailed locally." Larger amounts were spent by others opposing the referendum.
Mr. Delaney conceded that unions, private businesses and others likely to benefit from a modernized airport were pressed into service to support the referendum.
 
'We Knew We'd Be Blitzed'
 "Those who opposed the referendum had an emotional issue on their side," Mr. Delaney said. "So we knew we had to win at least 65 percent of the vote outside the airport area, where we knew we'd be blitzed with 'no' votes. We barely made it."
Mr. Delaney said he and others in Westchester County government had "tried to talk the County Executive out of going to a referendum, but he felt he had no choice."
He recalled that Mr. O'Rourke said, "If we go to the people and do it right, we'll win and that will settle it."
 
Two Issues Faced Head-On
 Mr. Delaney said the narrow victory came about after "taking two issues head on: payment and expansion."
"We addressed the argument that it would cost more than the $21 million," he said, noting the county's position that increased revenues would more than cover the costs. The county campaign also disputed inferences that the terminal was a wedge to allow expanded operations at the airport.
Mr. Delaney said the county enlisted the help of pilots who use the airport, having them visit nursing homes and other places where the elderly congregate to persuade them of the referendum's benefits. "The elderly generally vote negatively on bond issues," he said.
 
Linking Airport to Jobs
 Corporate leaders were given placards and other visual material to display to their employees, "who were told that it was in their own best interests to support a more modern airport facility in Westchester," Mr. Delaney said. "We suggested that they link the economic vitality of their company with their employees' jobs."
Mr. Gioffre said he had no intention of initiating any legal process that would impede the airport project, but that he and others would carefully monitor the progress of the improvement plan.
Mr. Langeloh said the county, for its part, would work publicly on each stage of the program and would confer frequently with the county's Board of Legislators, which had requested an informal oversight role.

HEADLINE: A Better Way to Reward Quality

 BODY:
To the Editor:
There is a basic flaw in the administration of the Malcolm Baldrige National Quality Awards described in "The Baldrige Badge of Courage - an Quality" (Oct. 21). The article says awards are limited to two companies in each category. If the purpose of these awards is to upgrade product quality throughout American industry, this limitation defeats that end.
The British have done it much better with their BS 5750 Quality Award, chartered by the Government and administered by the British Standards Institute. Under the BSI program, a company fills out a relatively simple form which covers some two dozen criteria: not only activities directly related to quality assurance, but also other aspects of company operations like management philosophy and employee training.
Applicant companies are inspected onsite. If they pass, they receive the award and can use its symbol in promotional materials and advertising. Recipients must be reinspected periodically to maintain their qualification. A major incentive to qualify is that most companies and the Government now limit purchases to vendors who have proved, through receipt of the award, that their products meet high standards.
The BS 5750 award has now been accepted as the model within all European Community countries for a similar program, designated the ISO 9002 award. It is run by the International Standards Organization for all types of industries. The standards for both the BS 5750 and ISO 9002 awards are strictly enforced, impose no limit on how many companies may qualify. The Baldrige awards, on the other hand, give both a publicity and bottom-line coup to one or two well-heeled companies (its application takes hundreds of hours to complete and requires a hefty accompanying fee) rather than encouraging quality raising at all levels of industry.
 
THEODORE LUSTIG
Morgantown, W. Va., Oct. 26

HEADLINE: Food Airlifts Called Insufficient in Ethiopia Region

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 10

 BODY:
Daily airlifts of food for the besieged town of Asmara, the Eritrean capital, and the immediate countryside are proving insufficient to keep the million people in the province under Ethiopian Government control from starving, relief officials say.
Severe malnutrition among young children rose sharply last month, and their health was likely to deteriorate further because of crop failure in the area for the second year in a row. 
 "People are getting weaker, and there is zero harvest right now," saidWillard J. Pierson, the mission director of the United States Agency for International Development in Addis Ababa. The daily airlifts by C-130 aircraft from Addis Ababa to Asmara, financed by Western governments, were only able to carry enough food for quarter rations, he said.
The drought cycle in the Horn of Africa in recent decades has been about once every decade. But the cycle compressed in the 1980's to every several years, and this year the rains failed again, making it back-to-back years of drought in northern Ethiopia. The rains have also failed in the northern Sudan, where about one million tons of relieffood will be needed to avert large-scale starvation, United States and United Nations officials say.
A United Nations report said this week that at least three million people in Ethiopia would be at risk of hunger because of the meager harvest. About 600,000 tons of food would be needed in northern Ethiopia, much of which is under rebel control, the report said.
Asmara, a palm-tree lined, Italianate city from the colonial days of Eritrea, has been under siege since the rebel Eritrean People's Liberation Front took the seaport of Massawa on the Red Sea in February. The only way to reach the million people in the remaining triangle of land in Eritrea that is still controlled by the Government of President Mengistu Haile Mariam is by air, Mr. Pierson said.
For months now, two chartered C-130's from a company called Trans Afrique have been making four trips a day to Asmara from Addis Ababa carrying grain and cooking oil at a cost to the Western donors of $500 a ton, a sum that Mr. Pierson described as very high for relief food. The donors have spent $14 million for the food lifeline so far, he said.
Diplomatic efforts to persuade the rebel front to allow the port of Massawa to be opened for humanitarian food deliveries to Asmara and the vicinity have failed. Part of the strategy of the rebels appears to be either to starve out or to capture Asmara, which their leader, Isais Afewerk, has described as the ultimate prize of their three decade-long struggle to win the independence of Eritrea from Ethiopia.
The rebels have been shelling the airport at Asmara but concentrating on the military section of the tarmac, thus not interfering with the relief flights, Mr. Pierson said.
The director of Catholic Relief Services in Addis Ababa, John Wiater, said that during a visit to Asmara and outlying villages last month he saw significant increases in malnutrition, increased susceptibility to malaria because of poor health, and severe water shortages in Asmara.
A survey of 1,500 children in four Asmara feeding centers in October had found 19 percent in "grave" condition, compared with 3.5 percent in September, Mr. Pierson said.

HEADLINE: Rentals Flourish as Home Sales Slow

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
IN the New York region's troubled home market, the rental alternative is becoming an increasingly attractive temporary haven for many would-be sellers and buyers. Among them are Samuel and Giedra Trocone, who see the should-we-sell-should-we-buy dilemma from both sides.
The Trocones went house-hunting in New Jersey's Morris County in preparation for a move from Connecticut this year and found a real estate market as unsettled as the one they were leaving behind in Stamford. 
 Owners in New Jersey, the Troncones found, were lowering their prices every few weeks. But rather than viewing these reductions as a golden opportunity, the Troncones took them as a warning sign.
"We had sold our house in Stamford," said Mr. Troncone, an executive with a telecommunications company, "so we were very open to the idea of buying. But I was not comfortable with the drop in property values. With the region's economy in the shape it's in, I didn't see a reason to join in the fall."
The Troncones parked the equity they got out of their Stamford house in a bank account and decided to rent rather than buy. They are paying $1,900 a month for a two-bedroom colonial they found in Mendham, N.J. The owner, who is on assignment overseas, has given them a one-year lease with a one-year renewal option.
The Troncones are not alone. Throughout the New York region, many families who had been looking for a house or apartment to buy, and many who will not sell at the lower prices they can get, are stepping out of the market temporarily and retreating into the relative safety of rental arrangements. Most see renting only as a safe port in a storm; they fully intend to return to owner-occupancy when the market settles.
But while renting can bring temporary protection against the uncertainties of the market, real estate professionals warn that there can be powerful disincentives in such a move. Some owners find that the rent they can get may not fully cover mortgage payments, property taxes and the costs of maintenance. They also face the problem of finding reliable tenants who will pay the rent on time and take good care of their property.
Those who rent after selling must be careful not to lose the capital gains rollovers and profit exclusions the Federal Government allows only to homeowners. They must bear the costs of moving and setting up a home in accommodations they will not be in very long. And for some, the personal anxiety of living half-settled in temporary quarters may weigh as heavily as the financial considerations.
Jean and Hank Barletta took a month-to-month lease in a condominium development in Summit, N.J., after selling their house in Madison. They want to buy another home in Madison and are renting until they find what they feel is the best house for the $250,000 they have to spend.
Mrs. Barletta said that after having a house, living in a two-bedroom apartment with their two young boys, Robbie, 6 years old, and Ryan, 3, has not been easy.
"Our children are very active," she said. "We don't have the space we need. The walls are thin. Our neighbors know we are here."
Another drawback of their current living arrangement is that the apartment they rent is being offered for sale.
"Not only do we have people coming through to see the apartment," she said, "but we will have only two months to move out if it is sold. If we have not bought a house by then we will have to rent again."
One sign of the shift in the rental market, realtors say, is that many of those who have put homes up for rent are owner-occupants rather than investors. "In the past,"said Robert Abbott, a broker with the Wyckoff, N.J., office of Coldwell Banker, "the majority of the rentals were from investors or developers who could not sell new condominiums. But there are many more homeowners listed with us now."
The statistics of one Multiple Listing Service in Westchester County clearly reflect the trend.
In October 1989, the listing service that covers mid-Westchester County in the vicinity of White Plains showed 377 one-family houses for rent. Last month, the same board had 547 one-family homes for rent. In that same period, the number of apartments for rent -- many of them individually owned condominiums -- went from 150 to 240.
The service's statistics for its member brokerage offices for the six months preceding each Oct. 20 show an increase in rental transactions from 165 in the earlier period to 281 this year.
"I don't believe that our listings represent any more than 20 percent of what is available for rent in Westchester County," said Gilbert Mercurio, executive vice president of the Westchester Board of Realtors, which operates the Multiple listing service. "For one thing, rentals represent a tiny portion of the transactions our office handles. We are still primarily a service for residential sales. But I do think our rental figures reflect the market trend. There has definitely been an increase in rental activity."
People in the market for houses, town houses and apartments have a wealth of options ranging from studios renting for $500 a month or less to large suburban homes or estates in exclusive communities where owners are asking $10,000 a month.
"Home rentals in the suburbs used to be few and far between," said Joyce Jones, a marketing consultant to Coldwell Banker in northern New Jersey and Westchester County. "And often they were not in the best condition. Sometimes they were problem properties or homes that were rented until their owners could complete divorces. Now the rentals come in all price ranges in all communities."
Many who have put their homes up for rent, like Edna and Douglas Robbins, have done so as a last resort. The Robbinses recently decided, after trying for two years to sell, to try renting their home in Florham Park, N.J.
"WE started asking $342,000," said Mrs. Robbins, "We've just come down to $269,000 and we don't want to go lower than that. So we will rent with the option to buy. But that will only be if a buyer does not come along first."
Mrs. Robbins said that now that their children are grown and on their own, she and her husband find their four-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath house too large. They want to move to a small house on the Jersey Shore. If no buyer of their current house comes forward, they will seek to rent it for about $1,700 a month.
Over the last two years, the Robbinses -- like others trying to sell homes -- put time and money into repairs and refurbishing.
"We pulled up the blue-and-green carpeting because the color scheme was dated," Mrs. Robbins said. "We painted the walls white and moved out some of the furniture. I hope our latest concession makes a difference because I don't know what else we can do."
In New York City, too, many would-be sellers have been getting into the rental market, and some real estate brokerage companies whose businesses were strictly sales operations until a year or so ago are elbowing their way onto the rental scene.
In the last year, companies that deal with properties mainly at the upper end of the Manhattan market, among them William B. May and Halstead Properties, have started rental divisions. They have been motivated, their principals say, by the fast income from the fees collected when rental deals are completed as well as by a desire to maintain relationships with potential sellers and buyers.
"Every week," said Lisa Schlussel, who heads the new rental division of William B. May Company, "we are getting more calls from owners on Park, Madison and Fifth Avenues who say they are now open to the idea of renting."
Ms. Schlussel described her company's territory as the Upper East Side between 60th and 90th Streets, from Fifth to Lexington Avenues.
Halstead Properties has put two rental specialists in each of its three offices -- at 1065 Madison Avenue, between 80th and 81st Streets, Columbus Avenue between 79th and 80th Streets and 451 West Broadway near Prince Street in SoHo.
"We are putting money into canvassing, research and training," said Clark Halstead, the company's owner. "This is not a temporary move for us. I think the demand for rentals at the high end will survive even after the sales market comes back."
Mr. Halstead said that his company will bolster its new rental division with a rental management service that will cater to both owners-in-residence and investor owners.
In the luxury market, apartment owners who try to rent often find themselves in competition with developers of newly built condominium and cooperative units who cannot find buyers. As a result, rents have been falling. Nevertheless, brokerages in the city and suburbs report no lack of tenants willing to pay high rents for the flexiblity of living in homes they do not own.
Brokers and agents say well-priced rentals in good locations can snapped up in a matter of hours. Some agents say they have been surprised by the rents owners are getting.
"We recently rented a town house on 18th Street between Second and Third Avenues which I originally expected to go for between $6,000 and $7,000 a month," said Anthony Czebatul, a sales associate with Eychner Associates, a brokerage firm which handles sales and rentals in Chelsea, Greenwhich Village and SoHo. "But the family renting it now is paying $8,000 a month in rent."
IN another Greenwich Village rental that Mr. Czebatul handled, a two-bedroom apartment on West 12th Street between Greenwhich Avenue and West 4th Street went for $1,800 a month even though similar apartments in the same building went renting for $1,400 until this fall.
Ms. Schlussel, of William B. May, said that in setting a market rent homeowners can use the same strategy they would employ for pricing a home for sale.
"The same things that make an apartment a desirable purchase also apply to rentals," she said. "Owners need to find out what similar apartments or homes in their neighborhood have rented for and use that as their guide. As more homes and apartments are put on the market as rentals, this is easier to do."
Ms. Schlussel added that many co-op boards continue to resist sublets by their tenant-owners. This gives owners of condominiums and town houses an advantage.
"Town-house owners don't have to get board approval," she said, "so if they are in good condition and the rent is right, they can rent fairly quickly."
Many who have sought rentals in Manhattan are newcomers to the city, like Robert Neborak and Therese Esperdy, who see themselves as renters only for the short-term.
The couple, who rent a one-bedroom apartment in the East Village, moved from the Philadelphia area about 18 months ago, not long after they were married.
"We looked for something to buy," said Mr. Neborak, a landscape architect with his own business. "but nothing we saw really wowed us and prices were still pretty high. Sellers were not being realistic."
Another factor in their decision to rent rather than buy was that both Mr. Neborak and Ms. Esperdy own homes in Pennsylvania that they have not yet sold.
"Renting is new to us," he said. "It is not something we want to do. But for now it is the best way to deal with our situation. We didn't see the advantage of owning three homes in places where the markets are depressed." They can afford to wait for the market to rebound because they both have tenants in their homes in Pennsylvania.
"We pay $1,400 a month in rent," said Mr. Neborak. "The rents we are getting for our homes in Pennsylvania cover our expenses, but we don't see a profit at that end."
But for some renters, the strategy of renting rather than buying offers only short-term protection from the market's downward drift.
The Troncones, for example, may resume their house-hunting next winter. Without buying another primary home, they risk losing the capital gains rollever that lets them postpone paying tax on their profit by applying that gain to the purchase of another home. The Internal Revenue Service gives sellers 24 months to reinvest in another prime residence before the tax becomes payable.
"Right now," said Mr. Trancone, "we are reconsidering the economy of renting versus purchasing. We would like to divert the money we spend on renting to a purchase. The deciding factor will be the economy. If the market drops further because of fear of a recession, it would be better to wait and see. However, if the economy stabilizes, it may be more economical to purchase. We just have to keep our eyes on the market."
 
RENTAL IMPLICATIONS FOR PERSONAL INCOME TAX
 WHEN owners convert their primary residences into rental properties, the rental income they receive is taxable like all other forms of income. However, they may deduct mortgage interest, property taxes, agent's fees, repairs and other costs of operating the property. The policy applies to all kinds of homes, among them single- and two-family houses, condominiums and cooperatives.
In addition, owners who rent out their homes for more than a year may be able to claim a depreciation allowance on the property. In some circumstances, resident shareholders in co-op buildings who rent their apartments can claim for tax purposes their share of the co-op corporation's depreciation.
On a subsequent sale, however, any capital gain on the property will be fully taxable unless the residence again qualifies as the owner's primary residence. However, a home can qualify as the owner's prime residence even if he is renting it, as long as he is also making efforts to sell it. Once the sales effort is abandoned, however, a home being rented looses its status as a prime residence.
If a homeowner decides to move back into a home that has been a rental property, he can re-establish prime residency the day he moves back if the purpose is really to live in the home again and not to qualify for the postponement of tax in a sale. Owners who intend to take the one-time, $125,000 exclusion of gain allowed to homeowers, however, must be 55 years or older on the date of sale and must have lived in their homes for three out of the previous five years.
While most tax isssues affect owners, a tenant who had sold a home before becoming a renter may also be affected by the tax rules. For example, the tax code says those who profit from the sale of a prime residence must postpone paying the gains tax if the profit is reinvested in another prime residence within 24 months of the sale of the first residence. But if a new prime residence is not bought within two years, any capital gain on the sale of the former home will be fully taxable.
Because of the many complications of the tax rules, owners who want to rent and former owners who move into rentals should consult an accountant or a lawyer. Among useful bulletins available free from the Internal Revenue Service are "Residential Rental Property" (IRS publication #527) and "Tax Information for Homeowners and Owners of Condominiums and Cooperative Apartments," (IRS publication #530).
 
HOW THE RENTAL FEE WORKS
 WHEN a real estate company serves as matchmaker between a tenant and the owner of an apartment or house, it is entitled to a fee for the service. There are no city or state regulations that set these fees; they are entirely negotiable.
According to rental agents, the current range of what is considered a fair and competitive fee runs from one month's rent to 15 percent of the first year's rent. The fee for an apartment renting for $1,600 month would be $1,600 to $2,880.
For as long as anyone can remember, the rental market in New York City has been so tight that is has been understood by all parties that the fee would be paid by the tenant. But the current abundance of rental housing -- primarily at the luxury level in new buildings -- has turned the tables. Many agents now are suggesting that owners of studio or one- or two-bedroom apartments in high-rise buildings who want to rent quickly offer to pay all or part of the fee.
Most housing listed with real estate agencies is unregulated. But in New York City, some landlords of rent-stabilized housing list their units with agencies when they become available. The fee system is the same as for free-market housing, although the rent stabilization code prohibits a landlord or anyone connected with him, like a managing agent or superintendent, from collecting a fee in connection with the renting of a unit. In practice, however, high fees or key money payments, though illegal, often are demanded for attractive stabilized apartments with below-market rents.
Currently there is an abundance of residences listed for rent in newspaper classified ads that include the words "NO FEE." This means the owner is trying to rent without an agent or an agency is being used and the owner has agreed to pay the fee.
Owners seeking to rent have the option of using the open listing system or giving one agency an exclusive listing.
According to Kimberly Fitzgerald, who is in charge of the rental division in the Coldwell Banker office in White Plains, with an open listing a property becomes available through several agencies. When a residence is rented, the office that makes the deal collects the fee, which is ususally paid by the tenant.
When an owner gives a real estate office an exclusive, the contract specifies that any rental agreement be made through that office, with the owner paying the fee. Ms. Fitzgerald says that in many of these arrangements, the agency with the exclusive will share the listing with others, which increases the exposure for the residence.
One service of a real estate agency is helping the owner determine if a potential tenant will be responsible.
"It is the owner who determines what the requirements will be," said Ms. Fitzgerald. "They say what will be needed in terms of employment, credit checks and whether the tenant must have written references." -- SHAWN G. KENNEDY

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Low-Income Housing;
New York's Push Into Rental Production

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
GIVE it a long and complicated title and slide it through the Legislature without much controversy and the general public may never know it's there.
But the $128 million Turnkey-Enhanced Housing Trust Fund Program is not only there, but even up and running in New York State. It got its push two years ago from Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Alexander B. Grannis, a Manhattan Democrat who is the long-term chairman of the Assembly's Housing Committee and a booster of subsidies to produce low-income housing. 
 It is a statewide grant program that has begun to produce debt-free new or gut-rehabilitated rental units under nonprofit management for the homeless and low-income households. Since the grant pays the full cost and is not even partially repaid by mortgage debt, the subsidy per family is extraordinarily high -- perhaps $11,000 per family a year in New York City new construction. Beneficiaries' rent covers operating costs and property taxes, which are often abated.
Now, as Governor Cuomo prepares for his third term, he will have to decide how much new money to seek to keep the housing coming and the management machinery running. It was an achievement of Richard L. Higgins, who this month is leaving Cuomo administration for private life after two years as Commissioner of Housing and Community Renewal, that it became possible to translate legislative authority into a working program.
After three rounds of competitive bidding, $122 million has been committed to 35 developments statewide, with 1,360 apartments. Twelve of the projects are in New York City, of which seven will be new buildings, with a total cost of $68 million. Much of the construction has already begun. Some is complete.
Selected sponsors -- in New York City usually a private builder allied to a small nonprofit housing company -- get a state commitment for a permanent mortgage before construction starts and use it to find private construction financing. The builder and lender assume the risk of completing the building within budget. When they finish, they "turn over the key" for occupancy.
In New York City, the total development cost of each gut-rehabilitated unit is averaging about $93,000. The full cost of each new unit is about $115,000. The costs include an operating reserve fund of 5 percent.
From the standpoint of housing policy, there is an irony in this program. Government is advancing this most generous of all housing subsidy programs at the very time when far less costly means might be used to save existing, privately owned, low-income housing units. But that would mean a new rent increase to pass along the costs to tenants, or a new shallow-subsidy program -- perhaps in the form of expanded tax abatements for the elderly -- or both.
Lately the Community Preservation Corporation, the bank consortium that is a major lender to private multifamily rental housing in New York City, has been warning of the threat of a new wave of housing abandonments in the 90's. The key factors are an upsurge in water and sewer charges and in property taxes. If a there are additional fuel-oil costs this winter, mortgage delinquencies and abandonments could follow rapidly.
The water and sewer charges and the higher taxes are felt more keenly in poor than in middle-income neighborhoods, the report noted. Since the buildings will be charged for water on the basis of actual rather than estimated use, those occupied by large families will get the heaviest blow. Overoccupancy abounds in low-income buildings.
AS for property taxes, they are a result of rapidly rising assessments. The cumulative assessment increase in rent-stabilized buildings citywide over the last three years has been about 40 percent, the Community Preservation Corporation says. But in the southeast Bronx it was 90 percent; in the Highbridge and Morrisania sections of the Bronx it was 55 percent and in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, it was 50 percent.
One cause is that assessments in rentals have been affected by the prices paid by speculators planning co-op conversions. Most such conversions failed or never started, but the sales prices raise assessments anyway.
The corporation calls for unspecified measures to ease the impact of reassessment policies on the low-income rentals and "mitigate the regressive effect of water metering on poorer communities."
Fifteen years ago the failure to establish timely policies to assist privately owned rental housing led to the housing losses that the state's turnkey program is now helping to correct. The visual evidence is striking, for example, on East Second Street between Avenues A and B on the Lower East Side. Among the several city-financed rehabilitations completed or under way on the street there is a state turnkey-assisted project. It includes three 1898 tenements at 195-99 East Second Street and two adjoining buildings at 8-12 Avenue B.
The project has a history. Long-term tenants of the tenements struggled to get help for the building after the owner abandoned the buildings. They succeeded in getting a $1 million Congressional demonstration grant to assist rehabilitation. But what has finally put the nonprofit sponsor over the top financially has been a $3.2 million commitment under the turnkey program. It will create 34 apartments, 10 of them for families nominated by agencies assisting the homeless and the rest from a waiting list of people with incomes of about $20,000 a year.
The total project has 48 apartments. Unlike other turnkey projects, this development will have some private mortgage financing. The nonturnkey tenants may include some of the original tenants. Community organizers put together the Lower East Side Mutual Housing Association, which hired Eric Kolbe, a housing professional, as its executive director. It is the nonprofit sponsor of the project, and it hopes to do others.
In mutual housing, tenants pay a membership fee of $2,500 when they move in and participate in management decisions. "We will suspend the fee for people earning under 80 percent of median income," said Mr. Kolbe, "but when their wages reach that level we'll get the payment over time for their apartments." Mayco Construction Company, a small general contractor, has begun the $4.63 million rehabilitation.
A development cost of $96,400 a unit to revive severely deteriorated 92-year-old buildings would strike many construction people as obscene. It is done because of the strong community pressures for rehabilitation at any cost on the Lower East Side.
Other turnkey projects are totally financed by the state. Typically, 30 percent of the tenants are homeless families and 70 percent families with incomes up to 80 percent of the median, which usually means households of $20,000 to $25,000.
This month the state turnkey program took another forward step when work began on the first of the new, rather than rehabilitated, buildings planned under the program. This is a 76-unit, six-story rental at 939-53 East 174th Street in the Bronx, in a busy location near Southern Boulevard and Boston Road. The sponsor is the Mid Bronx Desperadoes Community Housing Corporation in partnership with Procida Construction Company.
Mr. Higgins, in an interview, said: "In New York City we can't buy land. Elsewhere we could pay up to 20 percent of the project cost for the land." That confined its use mainly to properties already owned by the city, usually in the poorest neighborhoods. Also, he said, the requirement that 30 percent of the tenants be at welfare-rent levels and the rest at no more than 80 percent of median income sharply restrains the locations of turnkey activity.
But the program has the advantage of getting public officals and their procedures out of the construction process itself. The state cares only that the building meets the plans and specifications. For a state agency that developed a reputation for being unable to spend the housing dollars appropriated to it, it is no small achievement to get project commitments for $128 million in low-income nonprofit-sponsored housing developments. But it has also been an extravagant use of subsidy money.
In new construction this will become even clearer than in rehabilitation, as property owners, including the city, try to realize the value of their property when they sell. Also, the city's own snail-like site-acquisition processes will impede any broad use of the system for new construction. In the end, turnkeys are likely to be occasional demonstration projects, doing little to meet the larger issue for lower-income housing, centering on preserving existing stock.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Banking Chambers;
Finding Tenants to Fill the Temple-of-Finance Voids

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
A TRIP to the bank once meant a journey into a Roman temple or a Florentine palazzo or -- at least -- a generously proportioned and luminous contemporary space with high ceilings and huge windows. Today, a trip to the bank usually means a moment or two at something not much larger than a telephone booth.
Technology, plus a change in the way banks present themselves, plus shrinking budgets for expensive real estate have left a number of big banking spaces vacant. 
 Because they were meant to be showcase tenants at high-profile locations, the banks' emptiness is that much more conspicuous.
Chase Manhattan has left a large space at the Avenue of the Americas and 47th Street. Irving Trust has left the blockfront space one block north. A former Manufacturers Hanover branch at Fifth Avenue and 57th Street has been vacant two years. And a Goldome branch in the Helmsley Building, Park Avenue and 46th Street, is momentarily empty.
Morgan Guaranty has moved its tellers downstairs from what was once a well appointed public banking room on the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and 44th Street. Bankers Trust has vacated its space entirely on the other side of the intersection.
Meanwhile, the Landmarks Preservation Commission has proposed to designate several significant interiors: the former Greenwich Savings Bank (now Crossland Savings) at Broadway and 36th Street, the Manufacturers Hanover branch at Fifth Avenue and 43d Street and the former Central Savings Bank (now Apple Bank) at Broadway and 73d Street. Whatever else happens, it is clear that spaces like these will not be built again.
"The temple quality or the church-like quality of a bank's central office is a thing of the past," said Robert H. Dugger, chief economist for the American Bankers Association, based in Washington.
"Corporate presentation is still very important," he said, "but the old-style Temple of Finance aura is no longer appropriate in today's financial environment. It reflects a static, heavy corporate presence which is simply not consistent with the demands for flexibility, adaptiveness and speed in modern finance. These latter qualities are what banks want to convey in their corporate image. Now you have this cross-current of corporate image joined with the facts of financial technology and cost minimization concerns and they add up to significant reductions in space needs."
"It's a very difficult problem dealing with bank spaces," said Elizabeth Rodgers, of Rodgers & McCauley, a retail consultancy with offices in New York and Philadelphia. "They tend to have very large square footages. They have gigantic ceiling heights, which makes them extremely difficult to divide up, because you get terribly vertical spaces. They were built around safes that were put in the basement as the building went up. Whoever re-leases them has to find a creative new use for the safe -- or a creative way around it."
"The first thing everybody jumps on are restaurants," Ms. Rodgers said, "because they can take 10,000 square feet and they like high ceilings. But there is a problem. Generally, owners like to put something in the space that keeps the image of the building and does not hurt office leasing. Restaurants present their own set of problems, with venting, odors and garbage. And you have to be willing to make a fairly sweetheart deal because the restaurant market is off."
The president of the Fifth Avenue Association, Tom Cusick, is optimistic about empty banks. "I predict they won't last long," he said. "They're very desirable spaces. I think they'll probably be replaced by retailers which is going to help the avenue."
One of the most obvious vacancies is the 12,000-square-foot space left a year ago by Bankers Trust at Fifth Avenue and 44th Street, in a building owned by Silverstein Properties. The floor has been kept open to view -- not hidden behind drawn curtains or painted windows -- and large signs proclaim: "Outstanding Retail/Bank Space Available." Larry A. Silverstein said through a spokesman that he would not discuss the space because it is under negotiation.
The former banking room at Morgan Guaranty, across the street, is going to be renovated and used by the bank, according to a spokesman, although it has not yet been decided exactly in what form.
THE JMB Realty Corporation has just taken possession of the 10,000-square-foot space that the Chase Manhattan Bank used to occupy in a two-story wing of the former Celanese Building, 1211 Avenue of the Americas.
"We'd like a dry-goods, upscale retailer," said Joseph Wright, senior vice president of JMB. "This is the most prominent piece of retail space on the Avenue of the Americas. It's the beginning of Rockefeller Center.
"I don't envision a restaurant there," he said. "Keeping in mind that this is the beginning of Corporate Row, we're going to be very particular about the retail tenant we ultimately select. We have 45 floors we have to be concerned about, with tenants who will walk past this retail space every day."
In the McGraw-Hill Building next door is a 19,000-square-foot space left by Irving Trust. A spokesman for the Rockefeller Group, Vincent E. Silvestri, said that the space was still under lease to the Bank of New York (with which Irving was merged in 1988) and that Rockefeller Center and the bank were "in dialogue" with prospective tenants.
The Manufacturers Hanover space in the Daiichi Fifth Avenue Building, at 57th Street, has been vacant since 1988. The Daiichi Real Estate Company of New York has received inquries from other banks but is "not interested," said Leo Henriquez, vice president of Daiichi America. Instead, the owners are talking to a retailer, he said.
An 11,000-square-foot space in the News Building, at 42d Street and Second Avenue, was converted this year from a Citibank branch into a Sam Goody record store.
"We had a head start and knew it was a unique space," said Barbara Winter, general manager of the News Building and a vice president of LaSalle Partners, the Chicago-based firm that manages the property. She said management benefited from advance notice from Citibank and had engaged in "very active, aggresive" leasing.
"A bank was an obvious choice," Ms. Winter said, "and we definitely surveyed them, but we didn't think they'd be very likely candidates. I've observed what everybody else has observed: Due to technological changes, they need less space. And I saw a fair amount of vacant bank space myself." Because Manufacturers Hanover does not want to foreclose the possibility of reusing or even subleasing its airy, voluminous, second-floor space at Fifth Avenue and 43d Street, it is opposed to the proposed landmark designation of that International style building. Completed in 1954 to designs by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, the bank has the most visible vault in New York, at street level behind a window facing the avenue.
"DESIGNATION would make it exceedingly difficult to get any economic benefit from recapturing that space or re-leasing it," said Gary Roboff, vice president of distribution services in Manufacturers Hanover's regional banking group.
The palazzo-like Central Savings Bank of 1928 was designed by York & Sawyer, architects of the Greenwich Savings Bank of 1924, which is also on the landmarks agenda, and the Bowery Savings Bank at 110 East 42d Street, which is not. The exterior of Central Savings was designated in 1975. Its huge, vaulted interior is now being considered.
Apple Bank, the Central's successor, has taken good care of this property, even forgoing bullet-proof Plexiglas that would have obscured the wrought-iron work in the tellers' station. But the bank is opposed to designation, although willing to talk with the commission about regulatory guidelines.
"The designation will extend to tellers' cages, work stations and the arrangement of offices," said Shelly S. Friedman of Brown & Wood, lawyers for the bank. "The impact of designation on all of these should be discussed prior to designation."
"The banking floor is the guts of that building's functions," Mr. Friedman said. "The commission may have designated the dining floor of the Four Seasons or Gage & Tollner's, but they didn't designate the kitchen, which is the business center."

HEADLINE: China Gains in Mideast Crisis But Loses Cold War Benefits

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Nov. 10

 BODY:
Less than a year and a half after China's leaders sent tanks and machine guns to crush the Tiananmen democracy movement, Western sanctions are being dismantled and China is regaining status in the international community.
Japan is resuming subsidized loans to China. The European Community last month lifted economic sanctions against China. A group of American Congressmen is expected in Beijing this month for the first time since the crackdown. Countries like Saudi Arabia and Singapore have in the last few months established diplomatic relations with Beijing. 
 "China has withstood the international anti-socialist environment and safeguarded the socialist system," crowed the official New China News Agency.
 While most of the world has suffered from the gulf crisis, China has been a beneficiary. Scholars, diplomats and Chinese themselves say China benefited in two ways: Saddam Hussein's behavior gave the West a new enemy and China won gratitude for its cooperation in imposing sanctions against Iraq.
 
'Best of All Worlds'
 "The gulf crisis accelerated a process that was already under way, of them waiting us out," said a Western diplomat in Beijing. "It's the best of all worlds for them, because they'be been able to reintegrate themselves with the West without sacrificing any third world credentials to do it."
Yet there are signs that over all China is a loser in the geopolitical reordering that has accompanied the end of the cold war. China has lost the leverage it had in playing the Soviet Union and the United States against each other, and its leaders may also be at a disadvantage in an environment in which nuclear weapons matter less than economic strength.
"People don't pay much attention to China any more," a European ambassador said the other day. Most experts agree that China matters less than it used to -- a proposition that drives some Government officials here to alternate between despair and fury. Visiting Americans these days are sometimes greeted with almost obsessive explanations of why China is still of fundamental importance to American interests.
 
Never Much of a Threat
 The West's sanctions were never threatening to China in any fundamental sense. The sanctions included delays in new World Bank loans, a freeze on most military cooperation, and a halt to most high-level exchanges. Ordinary imports from China were never curbed, and in fact they have risen sharply: China's trade surplus with the United States could exceed $10 billion this year, up from $3.5 billion in 1988, before the crackdown.
Military cooperation remains on ice, but World Bank loans are gradually being resumed, and high-level exchanges are increasing. Zhu Rongji, Shanghai's mayor, visited the United States this summer; Wan Li, the head of China's legislature, will tour Great Britain this month; and Wu Xueqian, a politburo member, is leaving in a few days for Tokyo.
"The pace is very slow, but I can see that the direction is toward improvement in relations" with the West, said Yuan Ming, an international relations expert at Beijing University.
In any case, sanctions affected China's relations with only a relatively small number of countries. Most of China's neighbors were uncritical of its behavior and continued to do business with China as before.
In some respects, China now has broader international support than ever: Saudi Arabia and Singapore have newly established diplomatic relations with China, while Indonesia has resumed ties. South Korea will open an office in Beijing very soon, and would like to establish diplomatic relations.
"We were never so upset about the crackdown," said a diplomat from an Asian country that has its own human rights problems. "It's their business."
 
Communist Legitimacy Eroded
 This is not to say that the crackdown on the democracy movement was painless, for the killings of peaceful protesters deeply eroded the Communist Party's legitimacy at home and among Chinese overseas as well as in the West. But some Chinese officials say the hard-liners probably regard the foreign sanctions as an acceptable price to pay, given that their alternative may have been loss of power. The price may be acceptable even if, as many believe, the Government's relations with the West will never again be as warm as before.
"Things will return to business as usual, but that emotional enthusiasm for China won't come back any time soon," a Western diplomat said.
One reason is that while the Bush Administration is gratified by China's cooperation in the Security Council, China's critics are less impressed. Their quarrel with Beijing was not about diplomacy, but about human rights, and they see no fundamental easing of the domestic repression.
While the Bush Administration is expected to favor further dismantling of sanctions, Congress may have other ideas. John T. Kamm, president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Hong Kong, expects Congress to make a new attempt next year to end China's Most Favored Nation status. He also is bracing for an effort to establish a code of conduct for American corporations dealing with China.
"We may well find ourselves in a position where Japan and the European Community are lifting sanctions, and we're adding sanctions," Mr. Kamm said.
 
Mutual Resentment and Suspicion
 China wants a resumption of cooperation with the West, but it is wary that too much interaction might again lead to unrest. The resentments and suspicions are mutual and may slow the reconciliation on both sides.
A classified Communist Party document, obtained from a well-connected Chinese in Beijing, conveys these apprehensions. The document, an analysis of international affairs published at the end of last year by the Central Committee Propoganda Department, warns that "the struggle between the two systems" will be prolonged and intense.
"Since the appearance of the first socialist state in 1917, this kind of struggle has never ceased," the analysis reads. "It only varies in its form, intensity and the tactics employed. Now the struggle has entered a new stage, and the struggle will be sharper, more complex and more intense than before. We must be highly vigilant."
While most nations are celebrating the end of the cold war, China has been saying, even before the invasion of Kuwait, that the new environment is not so wonderful after all.
 
Emerging Regional Powers
 One difficulty for China is that a multipolar world is likely to see the emergence of new regional powers including Japan, South Korea, Vietnam, India and Indonesia. China has had wars or bitter disputes with each of these countries in recent decades.
"They've always hailed, in theory, the emergence of a more multipolar world," said Harry Harding, a China scholar at the Brookings Institution in Washington. "But now that it's finally happening, the problem for China is that its relations with many of these emerging poles are rather strained."
Chinese leaders are most anxious about the rise of Japan, which they remember fighting in the 1930's and 1940's, and they often regard Americans as naive in playing down Japan as a military and strategic threat. Some Chinese are even warning that the Soviet Union and Japan could form a threatening alliance in the Pacific, creating a reason for cooperation between the United States and China.
China has clearly lost leverage in that it can no longer play the United States and the Soviet Union against each other. But Mr. Harding says that in a larger sense China has fewer cards to play in a world in which money increasingly seems to matter more than guns.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 1; Column 3; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
BAKER TRIP SHOWS COALITION DISCORD ON WAR WITH IRAQ

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 10

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's weeklong talks with America's main partners in the coalition against Iraq has demonstrated that there are some very obvious differences over when, and even if, a military operation should be carried out against Iraq, senior Administration officials said today.
Indeed, if there is one overarching lesson from Mr. Baker's eight-country tour, it is that the coalition against Iraq remains solid -- as long as the military option is not imminent. But the closer Washington edges toward using military force, the more the small differences that now exist between coalition partners could develop into major cracks.
Administration officials say they do not think President Bush has decided whether or not to go to war. But his decision to send more than 150,000 more troops to the Arabian Peninsula was interpreted by American marines in Saudi Arabia today as a strong signal that an offensive was growing nearer. [Page 14.]
 
Making 'All Options Credible'
 Mr. Baker in effect acknowledged the problems of maintaining the coalition at his closing news conference in Paris, after his talks with President Francois Mitterrand, when he said, "As we wrap up this trip, I feel that we have a very strong consensus on our collective aims, and on the need particularly to resist partial solutions and on the need to work together and stay together in this coalition and on the need to make all of our options credible, if we are to succeed." 
 But when the Secretary was pressed as to whether there was agreement on the means, particularly when to use the military option, for achieving the aim of a total Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, he answered:
"There are some differing views with respect to some of those issues, but generally speaking there is an extraordinary unanimity, and cohesiveness. There are differing opinions with respect to how long it would take sanctions to work. Indeed, there are some different opinions on whether sanctions are already having some bite."
 
Two Camps in Coalition
 Mr. Baker visited with the leaders of Bahrain, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Turkey, China, the Soviet Union, England and France, and while no one can predict exactly what he will tell Mr. Bush when he reports on his trip in the Oval Office, American officials made clear the following points will almost certainly have to be included.
First, two very loosely defined camps within the coalition are clearly emerging: the front-line states immediately adjacent to Iraq and those a long way from the missiles of the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein.
For the front-line states, particularly Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Syria and Kuwait, there is only one preferred option -- war -- and the only question is whether to do it sooner rather than later, American officials say. This is because these countries have totally exposed themselves by openly coming out against Mr. Hussein, and if he is not destroyed and if his country is not demilitarized, he will destroy them.
As such, these nations see the American military buildup as the prelude to a hoped-for military solution.
For those farther away -- the French, the Soviets, the Chinese and even the Turks -- a very different cost-benefit analysis is being made, American officials say. As these nations assess the costs and benefits of alternative strategies, the majority sentiment is that the low costs and potentially high benefits of trying to force Iraq out of Kuwait with sanctions and increased saber rattling are far preferable to the potentially uncontrolled costs and uncertain benefits of actually going to war. All of these nations feel they can live with a Saddam Hussein contained within his borders.
As French television reported on its evening news Friday night: "Alas for Baker, China is very hostile to any military scenario. Now that a conflict seems quite possible, the French are against it. At the end of September, the supporters of a military intervention were even with the pacifists. Now the latter are clearly a majority. They favor a negotiated solution."
Mr. Baker was worried about the French tilt away from a war option before he visited Paris, and he apparently heard nothing to reassure him.
 
Intimidation Favored
 The Soviets, the French and the Chinese, American officials believe, prefer to see the American military buildup more as a useful tool to intimidate Iraq into a peaceful settlement, rather than something actually to be used.
The second point Mr. Baker brings back from his trip is that when President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt said the decision to go to war should not be made for "two to three months" more, officials say he was voicing the sentiment of virtually everyone Mr. Baker spoke with. The exception was the exiled Emir of Kuwait, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, who told the Secretary that he would prefer to see his country liberated "yesterday."
But here again, there are revealing nuances. Leaders of some nations, particularly the Egyptians, Saudis and other gulf Arabs, prefer to give sanctions more time so they would be better able to justify a war to their own Arab publics when it comes, by saying they gave Mr. Hussein every opportunity for a peaceful solution.
Others, such as the French, Soviets, Chinese and Turks, prefer to give more time in the hope that it might change Iraq's behavior or allow for a coup and spare everyone a war.
 
No 'Partial Solutions'
 Third, broad agreement still exists in the coalition against any "partial solutions." At every stop, when Mr. Baker or his aides summarized his discussions, they reported that their interlocutors assured them that they were firm on the point that Iraq must unconditionally withdraw from all of Kuwait. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union, in particular, stressed the importance of Washington's and Moscow's staying totally in step at every stage.
This was reassuring to the Bush Administration, after a month in which some ambigious statements by senior Saudi and Soviet officials had prompted the worry that some of their key allies were ready to make a deal with Iraq. Mr. Hussein has not offered a deal, and whether this solidarity will hold up if he does, remains to be seen.
Fourth, despite the 10 United Nations resolutions and despite the huge buildup of military force, both Soviet and Arab leaders expressed the sentiment that Mr. Hussein has not gotten the message yet. Their consensus was that the Iraqi leader, while he may recognize that he is up against a formidable opponent, still apparently believes that he can split the coalition or make deals, as evidenced by his bartering of hostages last week with German and Japanese envoys.
As a senior Administration official remarked, it is not yet clear, despite all the steps taken so far, that Mr. Hussein's "antennae will be set in a receive mode, or not."
 
Support for More U.S. Forces
 Fifth, as a result, Mr. Baker found no opposition, and much support, for the Administration's decision to make the military option more credible by sending 150,000 more combat troops, hundreds more tanks and three more aircraft carriers. Everyone agreed that unless Mr. Hussein believes that war is imminent, he will not seriously consider unconditional withdrawal.
Mr. Baker also said he had made significant progress with the allies toward coordinating logistics and command plans in the event that there was a military operation.
It has never been clear whether Mr. Baker was collecting opinions on his mission last week, or advocating his own. He has been a voice for caution in Administraton debates from the beginning of the crisis.
Sixth, before any force is actually exercised, there appears again to be a general preference that it be done through the framework of the Security Council, so it will have the broadest political support.
But again, there were important nuances. American officials felt that the British, the Saudis, Kuwaitis and other gulf Arabs were perfectly ready to see military force used without a Security Council blessing, but were of the view that if it was important to Washington, it was fine with them.
 
No Push for U.N. Measure Now
 The Chinese, Soviets, Turks and French, however, clearly felt that a Security Council resolution authorizing force was a necessity, because it would give them both political cover if war comes and a greater say in the timing and scope of any combat. Still, none of them publicly indicated any desire to see such a resolution now, because it would bring the war option that much closer.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Gulf Crisis Produces Surge of Egyptian Confidence

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Despite its ailing and heavily indebted economy and lingering Arab resentment of its decade-old peace treaty with Israel, Egypt is experiencing a surge of self-confidence with the Persian Gulf crisis and what Egyptians see as their pivotal role in Arab efforts to end Iraq's occupation of Kuwait.
"Egypt is up now," said Taseen Bashir, a former Government official. 
 "There is no doubt that Mubarak has benefited from this," Adel Hussein, the editor of Al Shaab, an opposition daily, said of President Hosni Mubarak.
Cairo's active role against Iraq is the result of a shrewd calculation of its political and financial interests, reinforced by Mr. Mubarak's palpable bitterness over what he calls President Saddam Hussein's deception about his intention to invade Kuwait.
 
Dividends for Egypt
 Mr. Mubarak's stand has produced dividends for Egypt. First and most important, the United States and several Arab nations have agreed to cancel at least $14 billion in military debt -- about 25 percent of Egypt's overall debt. France and other European states have promised to consider similar action.
The debt forgiveness will substantially reduce the hundreds of millions of dollars in interest payments that Egypt has had to shoulder for its whopping $50 billion debt. Washington's decision to cancel $7.1 billion in military debt, for example, means a savings of some $700 million a year in repayments. Few diplomats expected that Egypt would have been able to make the payments.
"For the first time in years the cold hand of death is not at the throat of the Central Bank," a senior diplomat said.
Saudi Arabia and other Arab nations have pledged new financial aid. While the exact figure is not known, Makram Mohammed Ahmed, chief editor of Al Musawar, a semi-official magazine, said that Riyadh has promised to finance major new Government development projects and that $500 million of a Saudi commitment of $1.5 billion in aid has already been received.
The United Arab Emirates is said to have pledged $600 million in aid, and the Gulf Cooperation Council, a military and political group made up of Saudi Arabia and smaller gulf states, is reported to have pledged between $1 billon and $2 billion in development aid during Mr. Mubarak's tour of the Persian Gulf in late October.
 
A Windfall From Oil
 As a modest oil exporter of about 200,000 barrels a day, Egypt is enjoying a windfall of about $100 million a month from the recent surge in oil prices, an Egyptian official said.
The funds will help to offset an estimated $4.5 billion in lost revenue stemming from the gulf crisis and the expected decline of Egypt's three largest sources of foreign currency. They are remittances from as many as 4 million Egyptian workers in the gulf, 270,000 of whom have returned from Iraq and Kuwait; tourism, which Mr. Mubarak said was off by 80 percent, and Suez Canal revenues, which are expected to decline by about 20 percent, or $300 million.
Diplomats also said Egypt and the International Monetary Fund would soon conclude an agreement after protracted negotiations aimed at reducing Cairo's huge food subsidy program and social-welfare budget. They said such an accord would provide new standby credit, enabling Cairo to reschedule part of its remaining debt.
 
Mubarak Given High Marks
 Egypt's political high is not only the result of the financial relief. Since the country has often been on the verge of economic catastrophe for the past 150 years, political stability and confidence matter enormously here. And Mr. Mubarak, while not viewed as a charismatic figure in the Egyptian tradition, is nevertheless given high marks by a wide cross-section of Egyptians for his political stewardship, and specifically for what analysts called his "principled" stand on the gulf.
One reflection of Mr. Mubarak's popularity is his decision not to use the crisis to postpone the parliamentary elections later this month. His National Democratic Party is expected to win the overwhelming number of seats in Parliament, particularly because several major opposition parties, citing unfairness in the election system but privately fearful of being trounced, are boycotting the election. Still, some members of parties that are ostensibly boycotting the contest are running as independents.
Throughout his tenure before the gulf crisis erupted, Mr. Mubarak's unflamboyant and cautious policies were credited with gradually building bridges to other Arab states that had ostracized Cairo over its peace treaty with Israel. Egypt has restored diplomatic ties throughout the Arab world and has been allowed to rejoin Arab organizations like the Arab League.
Mohammed Abdel Moneim, the presidential press secretary, said Mr. Mubarak's stance on the gulf crisis had shown that "it's not Israel that can be counted on in an inter-Arab confict."
"Now the whole world -- the U.S., Europe, and even the Arabs -- realize that a strong Egypt is a great stabilizing element in the region," he said.
Still, Egyptian analysts and diplomats see problems ahead. Many fear that Mr. Mubarak may use the temporary financial relief to postpone unpopular but vital changes that must be made if Egypt is to develop and attract foreign and domestic investment. "Hosni Mubarak is still very cautious, and most of his aides are mediocre," Mr. Bashir said. "There is very little land reform, very little perestroika."
 
A Stultifying Bureaucracy
 By all accounts, Mr. Mubarak has made little headway in lessening the stultifying impact of Egypt's bureaucracy.
Rules are still rules in Egypt, whether or not they make sense. Several opposition newspapers recently noted, for example, that thanks to Egypt's unflagging adherence to bureaucratic procedures, thousands of traffic policemen were now sweating through their workdays because rules required them to switch on Nov. 1 from their white cotton summer uniforms to winter wear -- heavy woolen outfits -- even though temperatures last week soared into the upper 80's.
Mr. Ahmed of Al Musawar said Egypt faced an increased threat of terrorism because of its position on Iraq. Rifat Maghoub, the Speaker of Parliament, was assassinated last month with his driver and bodyguards at midday in front of a luxury hotel. Although the attack has been attributed to a domestic Islamic extremist group -- 10 of whose members have been arrested -- Mr. Ahmed said the security police believed that Iraq, among others, has begun pouring money into Egypt to foment terrorist actions.
Several analysts complained about widespread apathy over the coming elections, lack of trust between the Government and the public, an aging and ineffective opposition, and a political system that had little place for younger, vibrant people.
"The same old tired faces are still with us," said Walid Kazziha, a political science professor at the American University of Cairo. "They push old ideas and new places for themselves. What we have here is democracy by default. The problems have become so enormous and unmanageable that the central government can no longer control things anymore."
 
Worry About the Military
 Mohammed Sid Ahmed, one of the country's liveliest intellectuals and opposition figures, said he was concerned that the gulf crisis might bolster once more the role of the military in public life. "Nasser, Sadat, and Mubarak were all military men," he said. "Mubarak has yet to name a vice president, so we don't know whether he, too, will be military. I fear that army is reacquiring status at the expense of the civilian structure."
This trend would be reinforced, he warned, if there were a war in the gulf.
Finally, while most analysts agreed that Mr. Mubarak had become more confident because of the crisis, several expressed concern that he was becoming slightly "pharaonic," like Gamal Abdel Nasser and Anwar el-Sadat, his predecessors. .
"Egypt does not need another pharaoh," Mr. Bahir said. "They're mummified, and I want them to stay that way. I'll take a living president who recommends and suggests, not one who only knows how to give orders."
