HEADLINE: Japanese Labs in U.S. Luring America's Computer Experts

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA

 BODY:
To the dismay and chagrin of many scientists, leading Japanese computer and electronics companies are opening laboratories in the United States to do basic research, luring some of the most creative American computer scientists to work for them.
Some researchers and economists see this as a direct threat in the one area of computer science where Americans still have a distinct advantage. These critics say the Japanese effort could reduce the quality of research at universities and damage the competitive position of the United States in a critical field that frequently devises the striking innovations that translate into tomorrow's products. 
 But others say the competition for the relatively few stars in the field of theoretical computer science is natural and could be beneficial for science.
 
An 'End of the World' View
 "People's reactions to this vary from those who say the Japanese are wasting their money because they don't know what to buy to those who say it's the end of the world," said Dr. Charles Ferguson, an analyst at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who studies the computer industry. "I think it's closer to the end of the world."
Japanese companies have not focused on basic research, said Seigi Hinata of the Japanese Consulate in New York. "But increasingly we are putting more efforts, more investment, into basic research," he said. And much of that effort in computers apparently will take place in the United States, using American scientists.
The NEC Corporation has opened a research laboratory in Princeton, N.J. Matsushita is going to open one next year near San Francisco. Canon is starting one in Palo Alto, Calif. Mitsubishi is talking about starting one near the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge. American scientists say they have also received job feelers from administrators at two other Japanese companies, Fujitsu and Ricoh, that have told some computer scientists that they are considering starting laboratories in this country.
 
Sites Near Universities
 The Japanese companies are considering sites adjacent to universities with leading computer science departments, where theoreticians have developed startling ways to solve difficult problems. These can translate into practical products like high definition television or programs for the next generation of computers.
When they approach scientists from these universities and from places like A.T.&T. Bell Laboratories, the Japanese offer very high salaries and an opportunity to work with the most advanced computer technologies, which even the best universities cannot afford.
In return they get scientists who are the best in the world.
"The Japanese have not generated world-class theoretical computer scientists," said Dr. Ronald L. Graham, a research administrator at A.T.&T. Bell Laboratories. "The world players are in this country."
Some researchers fear that by hiring America's senior scientists, the Japanese are depleting an already sparse supply of experts. Computer science is a young field with few leading researchers, said Dr. Robert Sedgewick, chairman of Princeton's computer science department. "I'm talking about less than 50 people that everyone could endorse," he said.
The loss of senior academic scientists to Japanese research laboratories could greatly hurt the universities, Dr. Sedgewick said, especially if the top scientists turned around and hired some of their colleagues to join them.
 
Best Ideas Will Be Patented
 Another concern is that although the Japanese companies say that much of the work will be published in scientific journals, they also acknowledge that they will claim patents on the researchers' best ideas. As a result, American scientists could end up helping Japan compete economically against the United States.
On the other hand, said Dr. Robert Lawrence, an economist at the Brookings Institution in Washington, the Japanese laboratories may ultimately be good for American science, bidding up the price for researchers and making universities and industrial laboratories strive harder to make their jobs attractive.
Dr. Lawrence said he found the strong reaction to the Japanese efforts puzzling. "There has been a lot of condemnation of the Japanese for not engaging in enough research and development in this country," he said. "People have criticized their foreign investment as only bringing in screwdriver tasks," meaning that the Japanese have invested in factories. But now, as they invest in research, they are criticized. "They're damned if they do and damned if they don't," Dr. Lawrence said.
 
Mohammed Comes to Mountain
 But administrators at several American reserach laboratories affiliated with industry said they feared that the Japanese may have an unbeatable strategy.
"I think they're extremely clever," said Dr. Ram Gnanadesikan, an assistant vice president for mathematics, communications and computer science research at Bell Communications Research, the division of the Bell operating companies that were split off from A.T.& T. "The United States still has the advantage in software research and development. So rather than try to duplicate that in Japan, they've come to us and are starting labs where the human resources are located. It's like Mohammed and the mountain."
American scientists say they are awed by the salaries that Japanese firms are offering. "They're paying substantially more than any other job in academics or industry," said Dr. Thomas Leighton, a computer scientist at M.I.T. who has had informal, preliminary talks with Mitsubishi.
Dr. Leighton, Dr. Graham and others said the Japanese companies offer salaries that are 20 percent to 30 percent higher than the best offers the scientists could get from universities or American laboratories. Researchers said typical offers were more than $250,000 for senior scientists and about $70,000 for people with fresh Ph.D.'s from leading universities. "We just can't compete with salaries," said Dr. Joseph Traub, a computer scientist at Columbia University.
 
An American Recruiter
 Many American computer scientists say they are intrigued with the Japanese effort and are not averse to working with Japanese companies. Matsushita has even enlisted an American computer scientist, Dr. Michael Harrison of the University of California at Berkeley, to help recruit America's brightest.
"They came to me a year ago and said they wanted to start a research lab in the states," Dr. Harrison said. He said he had already established a relationship with Matsushita when the firm invested in his company, Cayenne Software, so he was favorably inclined.
Matsushita officials told Dr. Harrison that "they wanted a laboratory so good in computers and software that it would realize the promise that Xerox could have had if it had carried through its program," Dr. Harrison said. He referred to Xerox Palo Alto Research Corporation, known as Xerox Parc, which is legendary in the industry.
Scientists there came up with major creative ideas but failed to follow through by developing products. The concepts behind the MacIntosh computer, for instance, were developed from Xerox research, he said, but ended up being marketed by Apple Computer Inc.
Dr. Harrison said he believed the Japanese laboratories would ultimately help American research. The Japanese "will bring their technology over here and that will improve our technology," he said.
Matsushita is negotiating to persuade Dr. Richard Lipton, a 44-year-old star of Princeton's computer science department, to head its laboratory. Dr. Lipton, who has spoken at length to the Japanese, said he was seriously considering the job.
 
New Technology Is a Lure
 "A lot of us are interested in working with state-of-the-art technology," he said. "We don't really get access to it when we are at a university. We tend to work with things that are a generation behind."
Dr. Lipton said the salary being offered was attractive, although he declined to say how much it was. "Obviously, the salary is an issue," he said. "A lot of that has to do with incentives to make you move."
Dr. William Gear, who was hired away from the University of Illinois to be vice president for computer science research at NEC, said he was attracted to the Japanese company because it offered an opportunity for long-range research, without constantly searching for financing. University research is tied to Federal grants, which run for just a few years.
Even American research laboratories have been focusing on short-term goals, Dr. Gear added. "In earlier years, one would look to Bell Laboratories or I.B.M. or Xerox Parc for longterm research. But the amount of that seems to be lessening," he said.
 
Some Are Reluctant
 Not everyone who was approached by Japanese companies leaped at the opportunity, although those interviewed asked not to be identified because they did not want their current employers to know they were entertaining outside offers.
One computer scientist at a university said he turned down NEC because he would have been uncomfortable working for a Japanese company. "I am a refugee," he said, "and I feel a great debt to the United States."
These reluctant scientists may be exceptions. Dr. Harrison said that although he had tried to keep a low profile word was out that he was helping Matsushita recruit, and that he has been getting calls from job-seekers.
"There are a lot of unhappy campers at Xerox Parc," Dr. Harrison said. "Some are very, very aggressive. One guy calls me every couple of weeks."

HEADLINE: SUNY Chief Weighs Spring Tuition Increase

BYLINE: By SAMUEL WEISS

 BODY:
Faced with the prospect of a new round of budget cuts, the Chancellor of the State University of New York is considering recommending an increase in tuition of $50 to $100 for the spring semester, university officials have said.
Tuition for the university system, the nation's largest, is $1,350 a year for state residents. It has not been raised for New York students since 1983, and has never been raised in the middle of an academic year. 
 Any tuition increase would need the approval of the Legislature and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, as well as the SUNYboard of trustees. Opposition from the Governor has prevented increases in the last two years. But Mr. Cuomo indicated several times during the course of his re-election campaign that he might agree to an increase now because of the state's budget problems.
University officials who declined to be named said that administrators have for several months been discussing a possible tuition increase of several hundred dollars a year, starting next September. But recently, the officials said, Chancellor D. Bruce Johnstone's staff has begun planning for an increase of $50 to $100 for the spring semester to help offset an anticipatedcut in funds for the current fiscal year, which ends March 31, as the state tries to reduce spending to close a growing budget gap.
 
Administration Seeks Cuts
 On Oct. 30, the Cuomo administration projected that the state would spend $824 million more than it expects to take in for the current fiscal year, and the Governor ordered a general freeze in state hiring and awarding of contracts. The state's budget director, Dall W. Forsythe, also directed all state agencies to submit plans last week for cuts totaling 3, 5 and 7 percent of their budgets. University officials have declined to divulge details of their plan.
In an interview last week, Dr. Johnstone refused to disclose what the university's plan would contain but acknowledged that there had been "a lot of discussion" about a possible spring tuition increase. He said the issue would be raised at a meeting of the university's trustees on Thursday.
Dr. Johnstone said a recommendation for a mid-year increase would depend on the size of the budget cut sought by the state, a decision expected to be made in the next few weeks.
"If you're discussing budget cuts of $25 million, $30 million or $45 million," he said, "it becomes preferable at some point to start talking about a tuition increase rather than something like faculty layoffs."
Judith Krebs, the president of the State University Student Associationand the student representative on the university's board of trustees, said she expects that "the university's response will include a request for a tuition increase." She said she objected to making students bear the brunt of the state's economic difficulties.
University officials noted that the state's contribution to the current SUNY budget of $1.49 billion is already $39 million less than last year's, and said that a 3 percent to 7 percent cut would represent a further reduction of $35 million to $75 million. A tuition increase of $100 would make up about $14 million in revenue, they said.
If the university's trustees approved a spring increase, it would still have to be authorized by the Governor and the Legislature, which is expected to be called into special session sometime in December to deal with the growingbudget problems.
Spokesmen for Governor Cuomo, Assembly Speaker Mel Miller and Senate Majority Leader Ralph J. Marino all declined to comment on a possible tuition increase.

HEADLINE: GUATEMALA BALLOT MARKS WATERSHED

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GUATEMALA, Nov. 10

 BODY:
Barring a collapse brought about by the wave of political violence now afflicting Guatemala, the general elections on Sunday and the inauguration of a President in January should mark a democratic watershed: the first transfer of power from one elected civilian to another in the country's history.
That would be a significant step for the United States-backed effort to end a tradition of military dictatorship and build a working democratic system. 
 But Western diplomats say the political violence illustrates President Vinicio Cerezo Arevalo's failure to gain control over the armed forces and end the institutionalized terrorism that limits political expression to the right and the extreme right.
"The only left here is in the mountains," said Juan Francisco Alfaro, secretary general of the Confederation of Guatemalan Union Groups, the largest labor organization in the country, in referring to a three-decade-old guerrilla movement.
 
Only Hints at Reform
 Most leading candidates have announced ambitious programs to stabilize the foundering economy. But they have not dared to do more than hint at plans for demilitarization, agrarian reform, population control or land redistribution. Such programs would address the problems most often cited as the causes of the pervasive poverty and political repression that have led to two decades of war and bloodshed.
The results have been growing apathy and hopelesses in the face of growing violence, a resurgent guerrilla movement and corruption by the ruling Christian Democrats. Increasingly, Guatemalans equate democracy with anarchy and yearn for the strict hand of military government.
"People are asking themselves: Is this what we wanted? Is this the system we fought for?" said Edmond Mulet, a senior opposition deputy. "There's enormous frustration. In only five years the whole system is besieged. Whatever happened to our dreams?"
In a startling turnaround from the national jubilation that greeted Mr. Cerezo's 1985 election, polls now find a five-point preference for military regimes over democratic governments. But the army, which squashed two right-wing coup attempts against Mr. Cerezo, is expected to accept any of the three leading candidates.
 
A Wealthy Front-Runner
 Polls show that the front-runner is Jorge Carpio Nicolle, a wealthy newspaper publisher and founder of the National Center Union. In an effort to broaden his appeal in the private sector, he enlisted as his running mate Manuel Ayau Cordon, a businessman who started as a presidential candidate of the far-right National Liberation Movement.
Senior members of the National Center Union have acknowledged that it was unlikely that the ticket could win the absolute majority needed to avoid a runoff in January. That has made the campaign into a scramble for second place between Alvaro Arzu, the wealthy former mayor of the capital and the ex-president of the National Liberation Movement, and Jorge Antonio Serrano, an evangelist and the president of the council of state during the regime of the dictator Gen. Efrain Rios Montt.
 
The General's Reputation
 Mr. Serrano has benefited from the collapse of the general's own candidacy, which ended last month when the Supreme Court upheld the constitutional provision barring former dictators from power. In the most obvious sign of the country's disillusionment with democracy, the general was until then the front-runner, even though thousands of civilians were killed during his rule in the early 1980's. But his 16-month tenure is now remembered more for stability than for bloodshed.
The national dissatisfaction seems to have buried the chances of Alfonso Cabrera Hidalgo, the candidate of the ruling Christian Democrats, who by law may not renominate the President. Mr. Cabrera's campaign has faltered since he was stricken with pancreatitis earlier this month.
Mr. Cerezo spent his first two years as President pushing demilitarization and Guatemala seemed to be fertile soil for democracy. But Guatemalan politicians say their President appeared to give up and became content to finish his term. He stopped going regularly to his office, and his aides were replaced by girlfriends who surrounded him in what has been described as "a thicket of pretty legs."
Violence began to mount. In the first nine months of this year, there were 276 political murders and 145 disappearances, according to the congressionally appointed Human Rights Ombudsman.
Mr. Cerezo has described the human rights abuses as the final spasms of a dying era. But many Guatemalans blame the President, saying he allowed himself to become a captive of the army. They note the military staffs his country estate, providing even the servants. When aides went to see him there earlier this year, they said they were required to park their cars and ride the last two miles on Army buses.
"He became the caged pet of the army," Jorge Skinner Klee, a senior opposition Congressman, said.
But some diplomats say Mr. Cerezo came to rely on the army because it is the only bureaucracy that works. He asked civilian aides two years ago to prepare his position papers for a summit meeting in Mexico. They never produced. Finally, he turned to the army. It had a series of detailed plans on his desk within a week.

HEADLINE: THE 1990 ELECTIONS;
Governors Facinga Fiscal Squeeze and Tough Choices

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
Governors elected this week on a wave of popular discontent over rising taxes will soon be squeezed by fiscal pressures even more severe than those that forced their predecessors to increase taxes.
The successful candidates for governor face bigger fiscal problems than their predecessors for three reasons. The economy has slowed to a standstill. Congress has just imposed new spending requirements on the states as part of a vast bill intended to reduce the Federal budget deficit. And voters in many states have made clear that higher taxes are unacceptable. 
 Under a policy of "new federalism" championed by Presidents Reagan and Bush, the Federal Government has heaped responsibilities on the states in the last 10 years. But the recent economic slump has depleted state coffers of the revenue needed to carry out the responsibilities.
 
More Tax Increases Likely
 "President Reagan transferred the authority and the responsibility and the fiscal burdens to the states, and the governors were forced to raise taxes," said Larry J. Sabato, a professor of government at the University of Virginia.
Steven D. Gold, director of the Center for the Study of the States at the State University of New York in Albany, predicted that "there will be a large number of state tax increases next year," even though voters dislike them. Governors will cut some state programs, but will face irresistible demands for new state spending on Medicaid and prisons, he said. The nation's war on drugs has filled state prisons far beyond the capacity for which they were designed.
Twenty-six states increased taxes for this fiscal year. State officials estimated the new taxes would generate $10.3 billion in additional revenue this year. New Jersey, New York and Massachusetts will account for half the extra revenue.
 
Six Incumbents Defeated
 Six Governors, including four in the Middle West, were defeated, and taxes were a major issue in most of the 14 states where control of the governor's mansion shifted from one party to another.
Even in New Jersey, where the Governor was not on the ballot, voters angry over $2.8 billion in state tax increases took out their wrath on Senator Bill Bradley, who won re-election by a slender margin. In other states, voters punished candidates for governor whom they associated with higher taxes.
Raymond C. Scheppach, executive director of the National Governors' Association, said, "Voters' amorphous frustration about the Federal budget deficit and taxes gets translated to the state level because voters hold state officials more accountable than members of Congress."
 
Governors Feel Voters' Wrath
 That analysis is supported by the results of Tuesday's elections. The success rate of incumbents seeking re-election was 97 percent for members of the United States Senate and House of Representatives, but only 74 percent for governors.
William F. Weld's first step after being elected Governor of Massachusetts was to call for repeal of a sales tax enacted under Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, a Democrat who did not seek re-election. Mr. Weld, a Republican, reaffirmed his campaign pledge of "no new taxes" and said he had won because of his promise to bring "tax relief to the working men and women of Massachusetts."
A major factor in the defeat of Gov. Bob Martinez in Florida was his position on taxes. Mr. Martinez, a Republican, was badly hurt by his support in 1987 for a new tax on advertising, construction and other services. He reversed himself and won repeal of the tax, but allowed increases in the sales tax and other levies.
Republicans blamed for higher taxes in Kansas and Nebraska lost bids for re-election as governor, and a taxpayer revolt helped bring down a Democrat who had served two terms as Governor of Michigan.
In Kansas, Gov. Mike Hayden, a Republican, presided over a revision of property tax laws that sent tax bills soaring in many parts of the state, and the successful Democratic challenger, Joan Finney, exploited voters' anger over those tax increases.
 
'Don't Be Fooled Again'
 In Nebraska, Gov. Kay A. Orr was held responsible for increases in the state income tax. The Democratic candidate, Ben Nelson, charged that Mrs. Orr had reversed a no-tax pledge, and he told voters, "Don't be fooled again."
The successful candidate for governor in Ohio, George V. Voinovich, derided his Democratic opponent, Anthony J. Celebrezze Jr., as "Tax-Hike Tony." He charged that Mr. Celebrezze favored a "billion-dollar tax increase." Mr. Voinovich, a former Mayor of Cleveland, seized on comments by Mr. Celebrezze to suggest that the Democrat would repeal a 1976 law protecting Ohio homeowners against property tax increases resulting from inflation in property values.
In Michigan, the Republican candidate, John Engler, unexpectedly defeated Gov. James J. Blanchard, whom he accused of having presided over an increase in property tax assessments. Mr. Engler promised to cut property taxes by 20 percent, saying people deserved to "keep more of what they earn."
In Rhode Island, voters ousted a three-term Republican Governor, Edward D. DiPrete, who had reversed himself on a pledge of no new taxes. With the state's economy in a tailspin and unemployment rising, the Democratic challenger, Bruce G. Sundlun, won handily with 74 percent of the vote.
 
Illinois Is an Exception
 Illinois was one of the few states where voters rejected a candidate for governor who promised tax relief. They chose Jim Edgar, a Republican, over Neil Hartigan, a Democrat, even though Mr. Edgar said he would try to persuade the State Legislature to retain a 20 percent surcharge on state income taxes.
Mr. Hartigan tried to exploit anti-tax sentiment and said the surcharge should be allowed to expire in June 1991. Mr. Edgar said he did not want the surcharge to expire because public schools and colleges desperately needed the money.
Candidates who rejoiced over election returns this week will soon anguish over state finances. Gerald H. Miller, executive director of the National Association of State Budget Officers, said: "There is an immense squeeze on state government. The governors are being asked to put a size 10 foot in a size 8 shoe, and it doesn't work."
"The economy is in a recession," Mr. Miller said. "State revenues are down. But demands on the expenditure side of the budget are up because states serve the poor, and in a recession there are more poor. At the same time, we are being asked to serve more people because of mandates from the Federal Government."
 
Costs of Medicaid Increase
 The National Conference of State Legislatures says the Federal budget bill signed Monday by President Bush will increase state costs by $17 billion over five years, in part because it requires states to expand Medicaid, already one of the largest and fastest-growing programs in state budgets.
Medicaid, which provides health care for 24 million low-income people, is financed jointly by the Federal Government and the states. It accounted for 12 percent of all state spending, was the second biggest component of state budgets, after education, and grew 19 percent in the fiscal year just ended.
The president of the National Conference of State Legislatures, Lee A. Daniels, who is also leader of the Republican minority in the Illinois House of Representatives, complained that "the Federal solution is to send the bills for deficit reduction to the states."
States are supposed to be partners in the Federal system, but "we were not at the bargaining table in the budget negotiations, and now state and local governments are being forced to pay the price," Mr. Daniels said.
 
'Invading State Revenue Bases'
 The Speaker of the Maine House of Representatives, John L. Martin, a Democrat who is president-elect of the state legislators' group, said the Federal Government was "invading state revenue bases" by increasing excise taxes on gasoline, cigarettes and alcoholic beverages.
Under former President Ronald Reagan's proposal to realign Federal and state responsibilities, Federal officials were to consult more closely with state and local officials, and Washington was to help finance programs sent back to the states by giving up certain excise tax revenues. Governors say they got the new responsibilities, but no more revenue and no closer consultation.
A survey of the states, issued last month by the National Governors' Association, found fiscal distress spreading westward from the eastern United States.
Mr. Gold of the State University of New York said, "Trends in state tax revenue suggest that many states are in recession or skating on the brink of one."
Corporate profits are considerably lower than last year, and 29 states report declines in corporate income tax collections, Mr. Gold said. The other major sources of state tax revenue, the personal income and general sales taxes, are bringing the states less money than expected because wages, salaries and consumer spending for goods and services of all types have grown much less than expected, he added.
Governors facing painful choices might look to Virginia for guidance. There, Gov. L. Douglas Wilder, a Democrat, is laying off state workers, canceling pay raises, deferring construction of public works and cutting state aid to local governments and private museums.
"He has been adamant from his first day in office -- no tax increase," said Paul W. Timmreck, State Secretary of Finance. " His emphasis is entirely on cutting spending."

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
A Marine General Speaks To Troops of an Offensive

BYLINE: By JAMES LeMOYNE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: IN SAUDI ARABIA, Nov. 10

 BODY:
A senior American military commander here told his troops today that it is now possible that they will launch an offensive against Iraq in the months ahead.
The statement, by Maj. Gen. Robert M. Johnston of the Marines, a leading member of the American command in Saudi Arabia, was repeated by other senior officers today as they reacted to President Bush's decision to send at least 150,000 reinforcements to Saudi Arabia "to provide an adequate offensive military option" if economic sanctions against Iraq are deemed insufficient. 
 Speaking on the 215th anniversary of the founding of the Marine Corps, General Johnston said the President's decision to send additional units, and not to permit any rotation of the 230,000 American military personnel already here. meant that now "we may indeed have to concern ourselves with an offensive option" against Iraq.
It appeared to be the first explicit acknowledgment by an American officer that the former limited goal of defending Saudi Arabia was giving way to a new imperative to prepare a possible attack. Since they first arrived here in August, American commanders have denied making any offensive preparations.
 
Comparison With Vietnam
 Addressing the assembled ranks of the First Marine Division headquarters battalion, General Johnston warned his troops that they faced "a whole new ball game" and that a war in this region could be more difficult than the war in Vietnam.
"The prospect of offensive combat is going to be the greatest challenge that Marines have seen in many decades," he said. "We are going to need everything we have if we go to war against the Iraqis."
Under military rules, the precise numbers and locations of American units cannot be reported. But the Marine forces visited today are among the most forward-deployed combat units in the Saudi desert.
General Johnston and other senior officers said they had not yet fully informed American troops here of the decision not to permit any units to rotate home as reinforcements come in.
"We just got the message last night," said another Marine commander, Brig. Gen. Mike Myatt. "I think it's going to have a sobering impact."
 
Stiffened Resolve?
 When asked their reaction to the decision to send reinforcements without rotating soldiers home, several marines seemed surprised but also relieved at what they interpreted as a stiffening of resolve.
"That tells us one thing," said Cpl. James M. Capps of the Third Marine Regiment at a base far out in the desert. "If they say it's an offensive, we're ready to go."
It was an acceptance of battle echoed by several marines who said they would rather fight than sit in the sands indefinitely.
"We know a war is a war," said Sgt. Frank Huerta, 28 years old. "Some of us won't make it back. But we say, 'Let's do it so the rest of us can get home.' "
As he spoke, a combined British and American military band was playing "The Marine Hymn" while officers used a combat knife to cut a birthday cake emblazoned in red letters spelling out former Marine battlefields: "Wake, Tarawa, Iwo Jima, Vietnam." Each marine ate a piece of a similar cake in a ceremony repeated across the desert today among more than 40,000 men sent here with the First Marine Expeditionary Force.
 
An Important Ingredient
 General Johnston, a 30-year veteran, told the marines that the First Expeditionary Force would be "the pointed end" of any offensive against Iraq.
When asked what he thought their reaction would be to the policy of not rotating them home, he said: "I'm sure it's not going to thrill a lot of people, but we're mature enough to carry out the mission."
Mood matters in war, where the battle in men's minds and hearts is as important as the weapons they wield. By that measure, there appears to be a marked change from two months ago in the marines met today at several bases across the desert.
They complained very little. Some admitted fear and many said they wished they were home with those they loved. But they had a quietness about them and a tautness.
"We think we're ready," said Pvt. Lionel Tetreault, 20. "We all want to do well, but you can't tell how you're going to do until you're in it. That's just how it is."
 
Desert Turns Cooler
 Several marines said they are grateful to have had three months to grow used to the desert, which has become agreeably cool with the approach of winter.
At another ceremony, Brig. Gen. Thomas B. Draude told the men of the First Battalion of the Third Marine Regiment that they must now prepare "to go in harm's way."
"Things are a little different than they were a week ago," General Draude said, elaborating on the sober tone of his statements.
After the general spoke, a Marine chaplain led a brief prayer.
"Father, we have come to this desolate and forbidding place from comfortable homes," the chaplain said, his head bowed toward troops who listened with rifles slung over their shoulders. "We stand on the brink of war," the chaplain said. "We pray for peace."

HEADLINE: Neighborly S.&L. Is Pinched by the Times

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRATTLEBORO, Vt.

 BODY:
George Bailey lives.
Bailey, as movie fans know, was the main character in the 1946 classic "It's a Wonderful Life." Portrayed by James Stewart, he heads a savings and loan that invests in the good folks of Bedford Falls while resisting the temptation of greed. 
 That fable is being played, for real, in this picturesque New England town where 36-year-old Robert E. Schrull heads the Brattleboro Savings and Loan Association, doing battle as an old-time home mortgage lender.
In the movie, Mr. Bailey's faith and honesty were rewarded at Christmastime when the townspeople rescued his little savings institution with cash -- an early savings and loan bailout. Mr. Schrull's institution is in better shape. But it remains to be seen whether his story will have an ending as happy as George Bailey's.
As Mr. Schrull is finding, it is is not easy running a savings and loan that stayed honest and stuck to its original purpose when many others did neither. Depositors are pulling out their money -- nearly $4 million by last tally -- in part, Mr. Schrull thinks, because of the bad image of the industry. Federal regulators are inundating Mr. Schrull with red tape and stiff new assessments. A downturn in the New England economy means fewer people want mortgages. And bankers and Washington politicians are saying that community institutions like this one are a dying breed -- too small and specialized to compete.
Vermont has only four savings and loans and none got into trouble, unlike those in Texas and points west. Yet Mr. Schrull, who drives a Jeep with the license plate "THRIFT," feels the heat. He recalls telling a California couple visiting a nearby country inn that he ran a savings and loan, and the wife replied, "Oh, you're a crook." Then there was the evening he dined at the bar at the Lobster Pot, a politicians' hangout in Montpelier, the state capital, and overheard patrons lambasting the savings and loan industry. He never told them what he did.
Mr. Schrull is fighting back with a combination of clever marketing and rock-solid adherence to the principles of community banking befitting George Bailey.
"It may be surprising," Mr. Schrull said in his office on Main Street, "but there are a few small honest community institutions left."
Just recently, Mr. Schrull opened a branch at the local high school using students as tellers. He gives a $5 savings account to every baby born in town so that "no one is born broke in Brattleboro." And, like George Bailey, he relishes making "heart" loans to local borrowers who may have a blemish or two on their credit rating but are otherwise solid citizens. He said only one of these had gone bad in 10 years.
"I know it sounds corny, but there needs to be a segment that focuses strictly on housing loans," he said. "I'm content to do that, even if we don't make as much money as we could. If we pool our money here in Brattleboro, we can help Jane or Joe buy a house, and I haven't taken my eye off that focus."
That plays well in this town of about 12,000 in the heart of southern Vermont's ski country. "Bob Schrull and his bank give people here personal attention," said Linda Dirks, head of the Brattleboro Chamber of Commerce. And Chester Dix, who operates Stockwell's General Store in West Brattleboro, terms Mr. Schrull "a very brilliant young man."
"It's local people investing local money in his bank," said Mr. Dix, who had an account at Brattleboro Savings and Loan, founded in 1912, when he was a child and now accepts deposits for the institution at his store. "It's not a commercial enterprise. It's like it's ours."
Mr. Schrull's notion is to cement his ties to the community and make money on the difference between what he pays local depositors and what he lends to others to buy their homes. A native of Stamford, Conn., and a graduate of the University of Massachusetts, he came to Brattleboro Savings more than a decade ago, having decided to live in Vermont and make a career in banking. He started as marketing director and was picked by the institution's elderly president as heir apparent.
 
No 'Junk Bonds'
 Throughout the 1980's, when savings and loans were freed to invest in all kinds of high-flying businesses, Mr. Schrull resisted temptation. He chose to build up the savings and loan's cash reserves rather than grow quickly through risky investments. He never bought "junk bonds," did not make loans on commercial real estate and shunned taking deposits from outside the Brattleboro area. "It just didn't seem like things we should do," Mr. Schrull said. "I just said no."
Instead, he opened branches in country stores, vowed never to get rid of the passbook and real, live tellers, and made mortgages with a personal touch. "If it makes sense, I'll make a loan," Mr. Schrull said. "A lot of other banks forget about the average Joe Six-Pack."
He held his own by offering depositors a slightly higher rate than did rival banks. As a mutual savings and loan, Mr. Schrull's institution gives its profits back to depositors in the form of higher rates and retains what is left as earnings.
 
'Heart' Loans
 He also competed through his "heart" loans that other banks might not touch. Unlike many other savings and loans and banks, he never bunched his mortgages into packages and sold them to outside investors. This, too, limited his growth because when loans are packaged and sold, an institution can make more loans without encroaching on regulatory limits. However, it enabled him to offer specialized loans -- on offbeat properties or to trustworthy people with a spotty credit history.
As a result, 90 percent of Mr. Schrull's assets are invested in first mortgages on homes in the Brattleboro area, far more than the 70 percent requirement in the Federal bailout legislation.
 
Strong Numbers
 To a large extent, his down-home strategy has paid off. Brattleboro Savings and Loan has grown to $35 million in assets from $8 million 10 years ago. Its cash reserve is strong and the association's return on equity -- the amount earned on the bank's capital -- is 15.02 percent, about twice the national average.
Now, with his cash base secure, Mr. Schrull wants his institution to grow but finds it cannot. Given the softness in the New England economy, fewer people are buying homes. And depositors are slowly but steadily withdrawing their money.
Mr. Schrull is not sure why, although he knows that many New England banks are seeing the same trend as the economy weakens and depositors dip into their savings. But he wonders whether the stigma of being a savings and loan is contributing. Profits, around $170,000 a year in the mid-1980's, fell to about $160,000 in 1989, but are expected to rise to more than $200,000 this year because overhead was reduced.
 
Washington Pressures
 Mr. Schrull feels that forces in Washington are against him. Many politicians and banking experts are saying the days for small-town institutions are numbered because big commercial banks can do the job just as well. "There is no rationale, five or ten years from now, to having a separate thrift industry," said Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat who is an influential member of the House Banking Committee.
The 1989 bailout legislation also brought in a platoon of fresh regulators from the newly created Office of Thrift Supervision, along with a new annual assessment -- $16,300 for Brattleboro Savings and Loan -- to cover the cost of this new regulation. This comes on top of an insurance premium -- $47,000 in Brattleboro's case -- that must be paid to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which also examines Mr. Schrull's institution.
 
A Waste of Time
 Mr. Schrull thinks the Office of Thrift Supervision regulators only duplicate the F.D.I.C., but less efficiently. He recalls once spending three weeks writing a computer program they wanted only to have them change their minds.
Ralph Gridley, the agency's director in Boston, said Mr. Schrull's comments were "not surprising."
To get out from under the Office of Thrift Supervision, Mr. Schrull is trying to convert his institution into a state savings bank, but his application is still pending. Even if it is approved, he plans no changes.
"I want to have the same mission of making money the old-fashioned way," said Mr. Schrull, who lives with his wife and two small children in a modest Cape Cod house in nearby Putney.

HEADLINE: THE 1990 ELECTIONS;
California Politicians Reel After a Vote Limiting Terms

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 8

 BODY:
On the same day they returned most incumbent legislators to office, the people of California voted to throw them all out, approving a ballot measure on term limits that exploded like an antipersonnel bomb in the Capitol here.
The ballot measure, Proposition 140, which was approved Tuesday by a vote of about 52 percent to 48 percent, sets limits on the tenure of officeholders in the nation's most populous state and cuts the budget of its Legislature by nearly half. 
 Ballot measures limiting the number of terms of elected officials, which are viewed here as a protest against Washington as much as against local politicians, were also approved on Sept. 18 in Oklahoma and on Tuesday in Colorado.
At the same time in California, 87 out of 92 legislators who were running for re-election were returned to office.
Barring a successful challenge in the courts, the new law will force all 120 incumbents in the State Senate and State Assembly to give up their seats over the next eight years, and the ranks of the 3,200 professionals who make up their staffs will be severely thinned.
 
What the Law Does
 The law limits the 80 members of the Assembly to three two-year terms and the 40 State Senators to two four-year terms. The Governor and other elected statewide officials are already limited to two four-year terms.
It also removes legislators from a state pension system that has been paying retired legislators up to 67 percent of their salaries.
Supporters argued in the campaign that entrenched legislators, under the thrall of special interests, had reached a state of gridlock on issues like crime, transportation, taxes, public finance and the environment.
"Somebody has got to just blow the whistle and say, 'Time out -- all you guys have just got to go home,' " said Lewis K. Uhler, president of the National Tax-limitation Committee, a private lobbying group, who helped draft the measure.
 
An Opposite View
 But the men and women who spend their lives in the complex system of government took an opposite view, saying it would leave the Legislature shorn of its most experienced people.
"It means the quality of legislation will deteriorate, we are going to lose good people, the Legislature is going to have a more difficult time doing its job and the public is going to suffer for it," said Cliff Berg, executive officer for the State Senate's Rules Committee. "It will strengthen the ability of the Governor and the executive branch and the lobbyists and the special interests and the bureaucracy to dominate policy decisions."
The powerful, longtime legislative leaders who were the lightning rods for public anger in the campaign vowed to fight back in the courts, contending that term limits are unconstitutional because they deprive people in legislative districts of the right to choose their own representatives.
These leaders, David Roberti, President pro tem of the State Senate, and Willie Brown Jr., the Assembly Speaker, have held sway over the Legislature for a decade. Both are Democrats.
Lawsuits over the issue may take years, and political analysts say that until they are resolved, the cuts in legislative staffs may have to proceed when the law takes effect next July.
The vote has devastated morale among staff members who have made a career of preparing and analyzing legislation and who provide expertise on issues ranging from the economy to social services.
"People are really depressed," said Steve Larson, the staff director for the State Senate's Budget and Fiscal Review Committee, who has made legislative work a 20-year career. "It's funny: you go up to meetings and your mind just wanders off. You ask yourself, 'What does this really matter?' "
John Griffing, chief consultant to the Joint Legislative Budget Committee, compared the mood with the sense of doom he had encountered as an economist observing plant closings. "People here feel like they've been kicked in the teeth," he said. "It hurts. It hurts your pride."
He added: "We all have complaints about the Legislature. It's a difficult place to operate -- it's this huge committee. But it's the way we make public policy in the United States. So people who get in and figure it out and make it work take a lot of pride in the work. And then when the public turns around and slaps them down, it hurts."
 
Unpredictable Consequences
 Eugene C. Lee, a professor of political science at the University of California at Berkeley, said it remained unclear just what the voters had in mind, apart from sending an angry message.
He said the consequences of that message are unpredictable. "In a very fundamental sense," he said, "we don't know what we're getting because this is an experiment."
And in this sense, said Hal Dash, president of Cerrell Associates, a consulting firm, "it's the ultimate abuse of the system -- it's reform gone amok."
One effect of the law, Mr. Dash said, will be a Legislature of newcomers and lame ducks. "It's going to create the ultimate revolving door," he said.
Among other effects, Mr. Larson said, is that the new law will rob the Legislature of its most experienced and skilled members.
"In the budget process, experience gives you a tremendous leg up," he said. "You know what's a bad idea when you see it. You know where the bodies are buried. You know what's going on in terms of the bureaucracy and the administration."
 
Other Likely Effects
 Other possible effects of the legislation were being discussed here today.
The measure, which has the effect of weakening the legislative branch, will give more power to the already dominant executive branch. Relations with the incoming Governor, Pete Wilson, will be particularly strained because he endorsed it.
In addition, the makeup of future legislatures is unclear. Proponents of term limits say a clean sweep will make room for more women, minority leaders and "citizen legislators" who are closer to their constituencies. But opponents say it might discourage the most-qualified candidates, who could not accommodate six- or eight-year mid-career sabbaticals.
Paradoxically, the law might enhance the job security of incumbents who seek re-election after their first terms. Rather than mounting expensive campaigns against them, challengers may simply wait until their term limits have been reached.

HEADLINE: SCRANTON MAY CUT WORK FORCE 50%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SCRANTON, Pa., Nov. 10

 BODY:
 This city, hometown of Gov. Robert P. Casey, is facing a fiscal crisis, and the Mayor says it could reduce the municipal work force of 650 people by about half, with the layoffs starting as early as next week.
The Mayor, James Connors, offered that forecast Friday night, only hours after unions representing the city's firefighters, police officers and public works employees had rejected a health-benefits proposal intended to save the municipal government $1.5 million. 
 Mr. Connors said that the city had enough money to meet only its payroll for this week and that in light of the unions' rejection, the layoffs appeared imminent. He said that although he would search for other options, tax increases would not be among them.
"At some point," he said, "someone has to represent the citizens, someone has to represent the taxpayers."
The layoffs could mean the loss of 100 firefighters, 70 police officers, 30 clerical workers and 78 public works employees.
 
Bond Sale Was Blocked

The financial crisis was spawned when a Lackawanna County court refused last week to allow the city the rare step of selling $4.5 million in bonds to finance payroll expenses. The city had assumed approval of the sale when it enacted its current budget.
Eugene Carroll, president of the Fraternal Order of Police local here, said his membership had voted against the city's health-care plan by 111 to 16. Mr. Carroll called the plan a "giveback" and a violation of the union's contract.
When asked what advice he would give to the city's residents, who may see a drastic shrinking of their police force, he said, "Buy a gun, lock your doors, and keep your children off the street."

HEADLINE: Angel Island Journal;
Saving Voices of the Other Ellis Island

BYLINE: By KATHERINE BISHOP, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANGEL ISLAND, Calif. Nov. 8

 BODY:
Paul Q. Chow re members that when he first learned in school of the great flow of immigrants from Europe to America through Ellis Island, he went home and asked his mother where their people arrived in this country.
He recalls how she became upset and replied in a hushed tone: "Angel Island. Shhhhhh." 
 For a long time, the small boy believed there was a place called Angel Island Shhhhhh where 175,000 people of the ancient Pearl River villages were welcomed to the new land they called "Golden Mountain."
It would be many years before he learned about the immigration station on this island in San Francisco Bay that was not a reception center but rather a place of detention and potential deportation from 1910 to 1940. It was here that officials and immigrants played out a complex dance, tens of thousands of times: the officials charged with enforcing laws aimed at keeping most Chinese out, and the immigrants trying to circumvent those laws.
The immigration station was closed 50 years ago this month. Mr. Chow and other Americans of Chinese descent are trying to raise money to restore it as an important if painful history lesson. Their task is made more urgent by their wish to preserve hundreds of Chinese poems written on or carved into the walls of the men's barracks by anonymous authors expressing their anguish.
"The generation that went through it wants to forget it," said Mr. Chow, a 62-year-old retired worker with the state transportation department. "It's the first and second Chinese-American generations that says, 'This was shameful and you put my parents or grandparents through this and it should not be forgotten.' "
The first wave of Chinese immigration occurred after the discovery of gold in California 141 years ago. Here they worked for 12 cents an hour laying the tracks of the Central Pacific Railroad and reworking the gold claims abandoned by white miners.
Dismissed from their jobs on completion of the transcontinental railway in 1869, they were bombed and lynched by people who blamed them for the high unemployment that followed the Civil War. The racist fury culminated in the passage of the Chinese Exclusion Act in 1882: the first law denying naturalization to members of a specific ethnic group.
But a window reopened when the fire that followed the 1906 San Francisco earthquake consumed records of the births and businesses of Chinese. Residents of Chinatown came forward to claim fictitious children in China and received documents that allowed whole villages of relatives and strangers, the "paper sons and daughters," to come to America.
But when they arrived at Angel Island, they were separated by sex and penned in into cramped barracks, then subjected to intense questioning. Some were kept here for a year or more, and stories, not confirmed by island records, say some hanged themselves rather than face deportation.
Mr. Chow's father arrived in 1922 with his own mother, who had been born in the United States but had lost her American citizenship because she married a Chinese national. They were detained on the island for six weeks and were freed after paying a bribe of $550, Mr. Chow said.
The 750-acre island became part of the state park system in 1965, and the immigration station was scheduled for demolition until a park ranger noticed the Chinese characters inscribed on the barracks walls. Asians pressed for preservation of the inscriptions, and the State Legislature created a study commission headed by Mr. Chow.
Other Asian-Americans have worked to keep the memories from dying. In 1980, 135 of the poems were translated and collected by Him Mark Lai, Genny Lim and Judy Yung in a book, "Island," and in 1988, Felicia Lowe made a documentary film, "Carved in Stone."
The poems show that some of the detainees considered returning to China. Others spoke philosophically of their detention. And there are rare sparks of anger. A poem signed "One From Taishan" reads:
It is unbearable to relate the stories accumulated on the island slopes.
Wait till the day I become successful and fulfill my wish!
I will not speak of love when I level the immigration station!
"We are happy with the idea of having money to restore it," said Gregory Picard, chief ranger for the Marin District of the State Department of Parks and Recreation, which administers the island. But with a $16 million projected shortage in their budget this fiscal year, "if money doesn't come from outside sources, it won't come at all," he said.
It is this reality that helped turn Mr. Chow into what he calls "the poor man's Lee Iacocca," attempting to raise $3 million to rehabilitate the station in a low-budget version of the Chrysler Corporation chairman's efforts on behalf of Ellis Island.
He is also driven by the memory of bringing his father to the station in 1975. He said his father, then 75 years old, entered the gutted men's barracks and walked immediately to the place where his bunk had been.
"It was the first time I ever saw my father cry and the first time I ever put my arms around him," Mr. Chow said.

GRAPHIC: Map: San Francisco Bay , indicating Angel Island. (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: PUBLIC & PRIVATE;
Nixon's The One

BYLINE: By Anna Quindlen

 BODY:
On Halloween night one of the neighborhood dads was dressed as Nixon. The mask was lifelike, down to the 5 o'clock shadow, and the costume was exact: dark suit, white shirt, quiet tie. As he shepherded his children down the street he flashed me the double V with his upraised hands, the Nixon digital signature that was so near to the peace sign and yet so far.
"Terrible costume," I said. 
 "I know," the counterfeit replied in a credible imitation of the Nixon voice, the voice that would have belonged to a basset hound had Watergate been an animated cartoon instead of an American tragedy.
There are so many obvious reasons for the current anomie of voters, from a crippled economy to the rotten campaigns to a feeling of the same old guys doing the same old things. But I keep thinking that if a political psychoanalyst put some of us on the couch, some of us who make up that bulge in the population known as the baby boomers, the doctor would find a buried key in the past to our immutable distrust of elected officials. And the key would be Richard M. Nixon.
Need I modify him? For those of us who grew up in his shadow, he will always have only a surname, as the truly famous do. Once, playing some trivia game, an opponent drew the question "What is Richard Nixon's middle name?" and we became irate. Surely there could be no one in their 30's, no one who had known moratoriums and student strikes, who could not reply "Milhous," who did not know the significance of Whittier College, who could not tell you what event took place on Aug. 9, 1974.
Nixon was our introduction to government. He taught us that politicians were always other, people deeply unlike ourselves. Our parents believed we would outgrow our dislike of him, just as we would outgrow rock-and-roll. They were wrong on both counts. It is commonplace to think that the pivotal leader of our formative years was John F. Kennedy. But Kennedy was never much more than fleeting myth, the epitome of what might have been; Nixon became what was.
When we think of the war, when we think of the draft lottery, when we think of the enemies list and the President bugging himself, even when we think of the mothers who said, "If that skirt was any shorter you'd be naked" and the fathers who said, "You can cut that hair or you can find another place to live," hovering over all is Nixon. The image of him walking on the beach in a suit and lace-up shoes became a metaphor for everything we hated. He was the ultimate adult at a time when adult had become the greatest pejorative.
You can get a good argument going at a liberal gathering these days about who was more pernicious, Richard Nixon or Ronald Reagan, the canny lifelong politician or the vague, paternalistic pitchman. Ronald Reagan's winning nowadays. But then something happens to remind you that, in terms of sheer symbolism, there's no contest: Nixon's the one.
A few days ago the people who run the Nixon Library announced that they were postponing display of those two definitive Watergate tapes, the ones we shorthand "cancer on the Presidency" and "stonewall it." The library director said they had other, more pressing business -- expanding the display of Pat's gowns. It seemed so Nixonian, that decision, burying harsh realities beneath a patina of appearance. "So it still goes on the way it was," said one political scientist of the suggestion that sequins are more historically significant than obstruction of justice.
It leaves a peculiar mark on people, when the most memorable political figure of their youth is best known, not for something like "The only thing we have to fear is fear itself," but for the disclaimer "I am not a crook." I will never forget watching the resignation speech on TV, in an apartment building occupied by Columbia University faculty and students. At the words "Therefore, I shall resign the Presidency effective at noon tomorrow" I could hear faintly the sort of cheers and clamor that are audible at midnight on New Year's Eve.
Last year I was having my photograph taken by a famous photographer, a man with a ponytail and a liberal sensibility. And he told me of taking Richard Nixon's picture. He said that before they began, the two chatted, and that he was struck by how smart and personable the man was. Suddenly he could understand how history might rate the former President's achievements more judiciously and his place in history more favorably than we ever could. Finally they were ready to start, and the photographer looked through the lens for the first time.
"Suddenly," he recalled, "I saw Nixon."
There was no need for him to say more.

HEADLINE: Too Far Too Fast in the Gulf

 BODY:
President Bush has supplanted a defensive strategy in the Persian Gulf with what sounds like a unilateral declaration of offense. Pleading a need to provide an "adequate offensive military option" against Iraq, Mr. Bush has ordered 150,000 additional U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia. And now the Pentagon has decided not to rotate the troops already there until the crisis ends.
All told, the buildup would double the combat units already deployed -- and increase the risks of a war the President insists he does not seek. So fundamental a change in U.S. strategy cries out for something more than a cursory announcement to startled reporters. 
 At home and abroad, President Bush has won impressive support for a collective policy of threatening the economic strangulation of Iraq. Now, patience frayed, he has suddenly doubled the military stakes. Why the abrupt shift? Why move so fast before existing measures have had time to work? And why move so far without first winning Congressional support -- and the moral and legal heft of a United Nations resolution authorizing the use of force?
 Mr. Bush's best argument is that the alliance needs to convince Saddam Hussein that he has no choice but to submit to U.N. demands for an unconditional pullout from Kuwait. It makes tactical sense to persuade Iraq that the allies aren't bluffing. But Saddam Hussein can read the world press. Mr. Bush's announcement seems meant to sound tough abroad, but at home his aides are quick to assure Americans that there's little chance U.S. forces will go to war.
Mr. Bush's new threat would be more credible if it grew out of open debate in America and formal U.N. support that seems within diplomatic reach. Secretary of State Baker seems to have succeeded in his present mission to persuade the coalition partners to press harder on Baghdad. He has been notably less successful in persuading them to send more forces to serve in Saudi Arabia.
The gravest danger is that the buildup will create irresistible pressure for war. The new forces will be in place by January. They will require the mobilization of yet more reserves. Once these vast forces are deployed, it will be hard for Mr. Bush to remove any troops before achieving his objectives without appearing weak-kneed. The disruption of American lives and the economy can only add to the pressure to get things over with.
War with Iraq would be costly, with Americans bearing the heaviest casualties. The political risk of an Americanized war is that the Arab world would not soon forgive or forget destruction inflicted on fellow Arabs. Even in defeat, Saddam Hussein could enjoy a victory, as Arabs in the streets proclaim him a martyred Saladin.
As Americans learned in Vietnam and the Russians learned in Afghanistan, the consequences of a foreign war are only conjectural until the shooting starts. It should be the goal of diplomacy to use the threat of war to prevent war, not hasten it.
If this is Mr. Bush's purpose, he needs the understanding and support of the American public. His purpose is surely justifiable; Saddam Hussein's aggression cannot be allowed to stand. But when Mr. Bush dictates a new offensive policy with barely a nod to Congress or the public, he shows more imperial impatience than unified strength.

HEADLINE: The Drug Czar's Coherent Legacy

 BODY:
It's not clear how much praise William Bennett, the nation's first drug czar, deserves for glimmers of hope that the nation's crack epidemic may have peaked. But there is no denying the intelligence he brought to a tormenting struggle marked by ignorance and confusion.
The Office of National Drug Control Policy, created by Congress in 1988, always suffered from inflated expectations. There are no quick or dramatic solutions to the nation's nightmarish crack problem, and in any case, the czar, a mid-level official, is in no position to order around members of the Cabinet. Nor can he command more resources than a President is willing to provide. 
 Thus Mr. Bennett filled much of his time traveling nationwide to deliver relentless anti-drug lectures. And his tendency to shoot from the lip brought justified criticism. Even in the press conference to announce his resignation last week, he could not resist calling Representative Charles Rangel a "gasbag."
But those who dismissed Mr. Bennett as a publicity seeker overlooked an important point: The former Education Secretary had done his homework. He brought a capacity for thorough study and rigorous analysis to the daunting complexities of drug abuse and trafficking.
He quickly recognized the inefficiency of Reagan-era border interdiction tactics that had hogged a huge portion of Federal spending while yielding minimal results. He understood the importance, and cost-effectiveness, of community policing to reclaim neighborhoods ravaged by drugs.
Critics asserted that he neglected treatment. But if he hesitated, it was as an academic aware of research showing some approaches more effective than others. During his regime, Federal money for treatment nearly doubled to $1.5 billion.
That it didn't rise more was in part because Mr. Bennett also saw the genuine possibilities of attacking the drug supply at its source with military and economic aid to producer countries. With the Governments of Colombia and Bolivia mounting aggressive campaigns of their own, that made sense.
During Mr. Bennett's 19-month administration, statistics began to reveal tantalizing signs of progress. Monitors of drug-related emergency room visits and urine tests of criminal suspects showed declining cocaine use. And in the Andes, thousands of farmers sought help to shift from coca to other crops. Prices of finished cocaine in U.S. cities began to climb while purity fell.
None of this signaled anything like victory -- drugs continue to blight lives and communities across America. Nor is a favorable turn of the statistics necessarily the result of Federal policy. Apparent peaking of demand for crack may reflect no more than the natural limits of a market.
But Mr. Bennett still can claim credit: after years of official bewilderment, he and his staff brought hardheaded coherence to thinking about drug abuse.
With public attention shifting to the economy and the Persian Gulf, the next drug czar may find it hard to gain a hearing. That would be too bad. If anything, the encouraging statistics argue for an intensified effort. But at least the next czar, and the nation, are left with a solid intellectual base.

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Michigan;
Frank Discussion Of Sex Problems Draws Hundreds

DATELINE: ANN ARBOR, Michigan

 BODY:
Sororities and fraternities at the University of Michigan held two Sexual Awareness Days last month that attracted more than 300 members who held frank discussions on a variety of subjects often avoided on college campuses.
 Among the topics were methods for preventing date rape, resources available to vicitms of sexual assault, and alternatives to sexual intercourse as a preventive to A IDS, including abstinence. Representatives from each of the universities 38 fraternities and 20 sororities participated in the program, held in the Sigma Chi fraternity house.
 
 "Part of the goals of the Greek system should be to educate members on every type of social issue. That includes sexual awareness," said Scott Edwardson, co-chairman of the event. "As far as I know, we are the only Greek system in the country to run this type of program with a campuswide involvement."
 The program, the second one at Michigan, was not intended to reach all fraternity and sorority members directly, said the initiator, Eric Reicin, a senior from Highland Park, Ill., who is majoring in international economics and political science. "We want everyone to learn something today and go back and share it with their fellow members.' he said. "In the future we hope to offer smaller and shorter programs for each house that we can individually tailor to meet its particular needs."
 
'It Shows That We Care'
 Organizers reserved the first day's program for new sorority and fraternity members and pledges. Juniors and seniors attended on the second day.
 Mr. Edwardson, a junior from Kalamazoo, Mich., who is majoring in industrial operations engineering, said, "This may not combat the negative image of fraternities, but it shows that we care."
 Counselors from the university's Sexual Assault Prevention and Awareness Center helped small groups discuss methods for preventing date rape. Many of the groups concluded that when couples communicate their expectations for the evening effectively, date rape is less likely. Others decided that avoiding potentially dangerous situations was the best defense.
 Discussion leaders added that the center's 24-hour telephone line was available to all sexual-assault victims and that a team of two counselors, both women, could be dispatched to the scene of an assault quickly.
 Sylvia Hacker, an assistant professor of nursing, led a discussion centering on the AIDS virus.
 
Some Are Troubled
 After her speech, Ms. Hacker said, "I thought the audience was extremely receptive." But some participants were troubled by the program as a whole.
 "I was happy to see that people are aware of these issues," said Colleen Clinton, a junior graphic-arts major from Farmington, Mich., "but I was really disappointed that there was such a high ratio of women to men. A lot of men came downstairs for the free pizza and went right back upstairs."
 Sean Deegan, a junior from Ann Arbor, Mich., who is majoring in English, said, "Some people took this seriously, and most didn't. For the most part, you can tell they didn't because so many people left early."
 The fraternity's front room was packed to capacity for both days' opening lectures but was only about half full for the final workshops.
 But some participants delcared the day a success.
 "Absolutely, this program made a difference," said Jeffrey Kirschner, a freshman from Villanova, PA. "We weren't pounded with, 'This is bad, this is bad,' like in high school."
 Lisa Hart, a nursing major from Farmington Hills, Mich., said: "I learned a lot of things I thought I knew already. The people who are here wanted to be here. It's not easy to give up a Sunday afternoon in college."
