SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week In Review Desk

LENGTH: 2283 words

HEADLINE: Crystal Unclear;
Will Tuesday's Disaffection Become Rejection At the 1992 Polls?

BYLINE: By R.W. APPLE Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IT is a mistake to try too hard to project the results of midterm elections forward two years to the next Presidential election. Inevitably, the context changes. The issues come and go.
Between now and 1992, for example, the economy will either emerge from its difficulties or it will not. The perilous situation in the Persian Gulf will either be resolved or will become much worse. In any event, issues like those, plus some others that cannot be foreseen now, are likely to dominate the headlines and shape the results in the next White House race, not the budget tangle or President Bush's flip-flops. 
 Four Presidents since World War II have won an election, then seen their party lose seats in the House of Representatives two years later, then run again -- Dwight D. Eisenhower, Richard M. Nixon, Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan. Two of them, Eisenhower and Carter, lost ground in the Senate as well.
But there was no correlation at all between what happened to them in the midterm balloting and what happened when they sought re-election. In fact, the two biggest losers -- Eisenhower, with a deficit of 18 House seats, and Reagan, with a loss of 26 -- were two of the biggest second-term victors of the era.
Still, there was remarkable agreement among political professionals last week, after an election in which the President's Republicans lost a senator and eight seats in the House, that something new was afoot, even though for the fourth straight election more than 95 per cent of House members who sought re-election were successful. That something was real, deep dissatisfaction with Washington.
Among others, Edward J. Rollins Jr., the co-chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, said that he expected the disaffection "to grow rapidly, not to go away, over the next two years."
Roger Ailes, who made Mr. Bush's 1988 television commercials and is often credited with electing him, said that "a sleeping giant has awakened." The voters, he said, are "trying to tell the politicians that there are things they don't like, and they may be on the verge of seizing control of the political process for the first time in many years, by voting with their heads instead of just their hearts."
The message was muffled this time. Most incumbents won, but their margins of victory were smaller, and even some of the big names were shaken. "Because of the disparity in financial resources and all the structural advantages of incumbency," said Peter Hart, a leading poll taker for Democrats, "the message arrived by second class mail, not by fax or Federal Express. But in 1992, in a Presidential year, rebellion could explode. The problems are there -- the economy, war and peace, the political system."
Interviews by The New York Times and CBS News with voters leaving the polls all across the country last Tuesday certainly suggest that the electorate is more than superficially miffed with politics as it is now practiced. Fully 76 per cent said they were dissatisfied with the way Congress was doing its job, 71 per cent said they thought there should be a limit on how many terms members of Congress could serve, and 65 per cent said they trusted the government in Washington "to do what is right" only some of the time or never.
Mr. Bush did better, getting a 59 per cent approval rating, but that didn't help the Republicans much, the survey showed, because 64 per cent said the President was not a factor in the way they voted for House candidates. He campaigned for Republican gubernatorial nominees in Florida and Texas, two of the three key states in this campaign, and worked hard for Senator Rudy Boschwitz of Minnesota; all three lost. Only the victory of Republican candidates for governor in the Midwest and Senator Pete Wilson's triumph in California, the single most important battleground of 1990, eased the pain.
The 1992 contest is getting under way later than any in two decades. But begun it has, with the creation of an exploratory committee last week by friends of Gov. Douglas Wilder of Virginia, which raised the possibility that the Democrats might have two black hopefuls. The other possibility would be Jesse Jackson, who gained his first elective office last week as an unpaid District of Columbia "shadow Senator."
Real action, however, will probably not start until early next spring, less than a year before the caucuses in Iowa and the primary in New Hampshire.
Among the Democrats who regularly crop up on lists of potential Democratic candidates, a pair of northeasterners, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York and Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, stubbed their toes with less than impressive victories. Mr. Bradley's best-known expertise is in the politically perilous field of taxation, so he may have some trouble clawing his way back, and Mr. Cuomo faces the prospect of a fiscal crunch in Albany that may force him to do things, like raising taxes or cutting services or both, that would make it hard for him to sell himself to the nation, if he decides to try.
Governors are on the line every day in this time of unpalatable choices, and they have fewer resources at hand, partly because the Reagan Administration curtailed the flow of Federal money to state capitals, partly because the economy is shrinking. This year, 14 governorships shifted from one party to another; two years from now looks like an inopportune moment for governors to be seeking the Presidency, although Gov. Bob Casey of Pennsylvania impressed a lot of people with his million-vote victory margin.
For all that, and despite his failure to break the Republicans' hold on the state Senate, Mr. Cuomo is counted the favorite by most Democratic professionals, not least because of his ability to make at least some liberal ideas palatable to the middle class. He sounded every inch the candidate in an interview with The Associated Press on Friday, criticizing Mr. Bush for not "sending the same kind of energy into the economic struggle as he's sending over to the sands of Arabia."
A pair of Southern Democrats, Senators Al Gore Jr. of Tennessee and Sam Nunn of Georgia, won easily, and kept their positions near the top of the list. Senator Charles S. Robb of Virginia is another possibility from that part of the country, which seems certain to produce at least one active candidate.
Senator Robert Kerrey of Nebraska, a nascent dove on Iraq who won the Congressional Medal of Honor in Vietnam, might be propelled by events into the race, and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri is another Midwestern possibility if Congressional leadership does not prove to be a stigma. Lloyd Bentsen, the 1988 Vice Presidential nominee, will be 71 years old in 1992, but he is lean and fit, and if the recession proves severe, his expertise as chairman of the Senate Finance Committee could help.
Mr. Bush will almost certainly draw opposition in the primaries. Richard A. Viguerie, the conservative money-raising expert, announced the day after the election that "the inquest begins now" in the Republican party. But Jack Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, says he isn't interested, so the challenge is likely to be more irksome than truly threatening, more like that of John Ashbrook against Richard Nixon in 1972 than that of Ronald Reagan against Gerald Ford in 1976.
One lesson drawn by many conservatives from the election results was that the President should never have abandoned his "no-new-taxes" pledge. So he went right back to it at a news conference on Thursday, as a first step in what he termed the "remedial work" facing himself and the Republican party. "He's lost some of his credibility in the last month or so," said John Sears, who managed Mr. Reagan's 1976 effort. "He has to be sure in the next couple of years that when he takes a position, he stays with it. Otherwise he'll end 1992 in a bad way."
To put the same point in other words, the campaign just ended proved Mr. Bush vulnerable. It suggested strongly that the issues are there for the Democrats to exploit, if they can find an effective standard-bearer and unite behind him. More than that about the 1992 race it is difficult to say, except perhaps to recall that at this stage in 1970 Edmund S. Muskie looked like a sure thing and at this stage in 1974 few people knew Jimmy Carter's name.
 
SOME WINNERS AND LOSERS
 
There's a reason that the national parties poured millions of dollars into state-level races this year: where seats in the House of Representatives are to be gained or lost after the census, the party in charge of the state is in charge of the new Congressional map. Following are the projected gains and losses in seats from the nation's 13 largest states, based on preliminary Census Bureau figures, and results from last week's voting.
 
California: +7
 
Pete Wilson's victory keeps governorship in Republican hands, insuring opposition to the Democratic-controlled Legislature. State Republicans are still mindful of losses after the 1980 Census, when Democrats had the governor's seat, too. Partisan clashes this year were muted, however, as the moderate Mr. Wilson faced the moderate Dianne Feinstein.
 
New York: -3
 
The only question was whether Pierre A. Rinfret, the reluctant Republican candidate, would finish ahead of the Conservative Party's Herbert London, thus keeping the Republicans on the second row of state ballots. He did. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo won with a disappointing 53 percent and will once again face a Republican Senate. The Assembly remains Democratic.
 
Texas; +3
 
Ann Richards, the Democratic half of one of 1990's nastiest campaigns, took the Governor's seat away from the Republicans in her narrow, come-from-behind defeat of Clayton Williams, a businessman and political newcomer. The Democrats control the Legislature, too, so they should have an easy time drawing new Congressional districts to their liking.
 
Florida; +4
 
In a race that the Republican Party fought hard, Democratic former Senator Lawton Chiles unseated Gov. Bob Martinez, who had switched parties several years ago. Democrats control both houses of the Legislature as well and will control redistricting, although the electorate is increasingly Republican, particularly in the fast-growing coastal areas of the state.
 
Pennsylvania; -2
 
Gov. Bob Casey, a Democrat, defeated State Auditor General Barbara Hafer with 68 percent of the vote, the largest margin in half a century. The vote bolstered Democrats but failed to wrest the Senate from the Republicans. The Democrats' stronghold, Philadelphia, is shrinking, and an ugly fight over new districts in the area is anticipated.
 
Illinois; -2
 
The governorship remains in Republican hands, after an odd race in which an anti-tax Democrat from Chicago, Neil Hartigan, lost narrowly to a pro-choice, downstate Republican, James Edgar, who pledged more money for schools. But Democrats continue to dominate both houses of the General Assembly, insuring a rough reapportionment battle.
 
Ohio; -2
 
The Republicans took over the Governor's seat as former Cleveland Mayor George V. Voinovich defeated State Attorney General Anthony J. Celebrezze. Republicans control the Senate and the Democrats the House. The 1982 redistricting was bipartisan, but with a Republican Governor now, the process figures to be more contentious.
 
Michigan; -2
 
As in Ohio, Republicans gained leverage. The Democratic Governor, Jim Blanchard, unexpectedly lost to John Engler, a conservative state legislator. The Legislature remains split, portending a tough reapportionment fight. The Detroit metropolitan area, where Republican suburbs surround a Democratic city, is expected to lose at least one seat.
 
New Jersey; -1
 
Gov. Jim Florio, who sailed into office last January and promptly pushed tax increases through, was the focus of nearly every race. The Democrats paid for the voters' anger at the Governor -- Senator Bill Bradley barely won, and Republicans gained in local offices -- but they still control the Legislature and can probably minimize their losses in reapportionment.
 
North Carolina; +1
 
This year, all attention was on the Senate race as Harvey Gantt, former Mayor of Charlotte, lost a heated contest to the incumbent, Jesse A. Helms. Republican Gov. Jim Martin was not up for re-election. Democrats control the Legislature, but Republicans have a strong presence, especially in counties where growth would logically place a new Congressional seat.
 
Georgia; +1
 
Democratic Lieut. Gov. Zell Miller comfortably defeated Johnny Isakson in the Governor's race, although Mr. Isakson's 45 percent was the strongest gubernatorial showing in years for a Republican. The Democratic Legislature should dominate redistricting, but the fastest growth is in Atlanta's Republican suburbs and a new seat there may be unavoidable.
 
Virginia; +1
 
Democrats are firmly in charge. The Governor, L. Douglas Wilder, took office in January and has been widely popular. The party also controls the Legislature. On Tuesday, one of the state's 10 Congressional seats changed hands; Stan Parris, a conservative Republican from the Washington suburbs, lost to James P. Moran Jr., the Mayor of Alexandria.
 
Massachusetts; -1
 
Registered Democrats outnumber Republicans by four to one, but in the Governor's race many defected from John Silber to the milder-mannered Republican, William F. Weld. Mr. Weld will be at odds with the Democratic Legislature on many counts, including his promise to roll back taxes; the voters turned down a tax-cut proposition on Tuesday.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 3; Column 1; Week In Review Desk

HEADLINE: The World;
Among War's Problems: It Would Be A Hard Sell

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: TAIF , Saudi Arabia

 BODY:
IF Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's visit to the Saudi desert last week demonstrated anything about America's ability to go to war against Iraq, it is that the Bush Administration could still face a tough time justifying the costs to the American people.
If war breaks out, the Administration's political Achilles heel could well lie in the stark contrast Mr. Baker was exposed to: The American troops he visited Sunday are dug in on the harsh Saudi desert floor, while the Kuwaiti ruling family he visited Monday is ensconced in the Presidential Suite of the Taif Sheraton Hotel. In wartime, it could be difficult to explain the contrast between American troops in camouflage garb fighting in the desert and white-robed Kuwaitis sitting around hotel lobbies in Taif, Paris, London, Geneva, Monaco and Bahrain, sipping coffee and applauding the liberation of their homeland by others. American officials say only 3,000 of the 700,000 exiled Kuwaitis are among the troops on the front lines in the desert. 
 "I know, I know," said a senior Administration official traveling with Mr. Baker. "That's why if the war starts it has to go well for us from the very start, and by well I mean it has to be over fast. We will have to show discernible progress every day. Otherwise . . ."
Secretary Baker, when asked about the contrast, began by saying how moved he was by the four Kuwaitis he met in Taif who had been tortured by Iraqis. Then, however, he quickly added: "It's important to realize that our forces are there for a number of reasons. We've talked about the importance to Americans -- the average, everyday American -- in terms of what will happen to his pocketbook, to his standard of living, to his life style, if a dictator succeeds in putting himself astride the economic lifeline of the industrial world."
 
Too Many Reasons to Fight?
 Mr. Baker's answer only seemed to underscore a problem that has bedeviled the Administration's gulf policy from the start -- the difficulty of explaining quickly and simply what Americans are being asked to fight for. While Mr. Baker's answer suggested that a main reason was economic, he touched a different theme in addressing the troops earlier last week. Then, all he said was that they were fighting for "American values," particularly the principle that aggression should not be allowed to pay. And President Bush himself, at different times, has advanced a number of reasons for the American commitment: to defend Saudi Arabia, to defeat a dangerous dictator, to preserve economic stability and to preserve "our way of life." While on the campaign trail the President ruled out oil as a reason, but at the news conference on Thursday at which he announced an expanded buildup with an ability for attack, he acknowledged that "oil is part of it, but it is not a main reason -- a main reason we are there is to see that aggression is unrewarded."
These explanations have several fundamental weaknesses that some officials acknowledge are a source of worry. To begin with, many of these explanations are disconnected from the immediate concerns and lives of Americans; much as the troops in the desert seem out of their element, many of these explanations seem somehow artificial and out of context. A visitor to the troops is struck by how utterly alone the troops appear. When Mr. Baker went by helicopter to visit the First Cavalry Division, he flew for an hour over nothing but empty sand, and at the base camp all that could be seen in any direction was sand, sand and more sand. When reporters asked a handful of First Cavalry soldiers what their mission was, each gave a different answer -- protect oil, protect Saudi Arabia, defeat Saddam Hussein, smash Iraq, free Kuwait. There was no single gut reason -- no "Remember Pearl Harbor" -- that all intuitively grasped, identified with and could rearticulate. When they said, "We have a job to do," it seemed that they were motivated more by a sense of professional duty than a heartfelt commitment.
In fact, the United States has not made it a practice to go to war -- particularly on this scale -- just to uphold the principle that aggression never pays. When Vietnam invaded Cambodia and when Turkey invaded Cyprus, the United States did not commit troops, because no larger interests were at stake. Even in World War II, America did not become engaged until people who shared democratic values -- the French and British in particular -- had fallen or were in mortal danger.
In the gulf, President Bush cannot argue that the United States is protecting other democracies, because Kuwait and Saudi Arabia are feudal societies. The other larger interest -- oil -- is one the President is reluctant to articulate, officials say, because many people would find the use of American troops to fight over resources mercenary. Thus, the Bush Administration falls back on the admired, but somewhat abstract, principle that aggression must never be allowed to pay.
When Mr. Baker used the argument about aggression, the troops all seemed to nod in agreement and applaud. But when he was done, the soldiers still had a variety of explanations to offer, rather than a simple and compelling message that they had clearly taken to heart.
The second difficulty with the Administrationi's arguments is that Mr. Bush has made the restoration of the Kuwaiti ruling family an important goal -- not because he is enamored of them, but because their return would be the proof that aggression brought Mr. Hussein nothing. If the al-Sabahs go home, Mr. Bush wins; if not, Mr. Hussein wins, at least something.
That means, though, American officials acknowledge in private, that the symbol for the triumph of American principles is the restoration of feudal rulers who don't share democratic values.
As long as there is no shooting, and American troops are just defending Saudi Arabia and suffering sunburns, these questions and contradictions can be expected to remain largely in the back of people's minds. But if Americans shed their blood to evict Iraqis from Kuwait, and if the fighting is protracted, that could quickly change.

PUB-DATE: November 11, 1990

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 4; Week In Review Desk

LENGTH: 1753 words

HEADLINE: The Nation: Measuring the Pain;
Why It's Too Soon To Predict Another Great Depression

BYLINE: By LEONARD SILK

 BODY:
ONE big reason for the angry mood of many voters last week was pain in the pocketbook, actual or expected, from sinking incomes, lost jobs, failing businesses, higher fuel prices and rising taxes. Even more disturbing than the perceived pain was a gnawing anxiety that the American economy might be headed not just for another brief recession, the 10th of the post-World War II period, but for a real depression.
Despite the headaches that are the hangover of the wild excesses of the 1980's, the United States economy has not yet cracked, nor is it inevitable that it will. But those who believe that anxiety is warranted say the nation's weakened financial structure might buckle if the economy goes into steep decline. James J. O'Leary, economic consultant to the United States Trust Company of New York, ticks off some major areas of stress: 
 As corporate profits decline, heavy interest payments on outstanding debt are increasing the risk, or reality, of business failures and creating rising losses for lending institutions. Cost-cutting and layoffs are the order of the day. Productivity is picking up, but the job losses and falling incomes are chopping into sales.
* Many commercial banks and life insurance companies are experiencing high and rising delinquency and foreclosure rates, and losses on their mortgage and business loans. Declining real estate prices in some areas are increasing the losses.
* The junk bonds issued during the go-go years, now gone, are raising grave problems for the corporations that used them to finance mergers and acquisitions, and for the people and institutions that acquired the bonds.
* Belatedly reacting to the savings and loan debacle, the Federal Reserve, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Comptroller of the Currency are tightening credit standards, especially on commercial mortgage loans. Banks and life insurance companies are far less willing to make such loans, except on terms that better reflect the risks. Bond rating agencies are lowering the ratings of some commercial banks and insurance companies, making it costlier for them to borrow. The slowing economy and the falling dollar, now at its lowest level ever against the German mark and Swiss franc, are stanching the flow of foreign capital to the United States. An enormous credit crunch looms.
If that were the whole story, one could title it "The Great Depression of the 1990's" and send it to press. But it is not. Even if fullscale war were to break out in the Persian Gulf, it seems unlikely that it would become the kind of protracted and ruinous event that would inflict lasting damage to the American or world economy.
As Adam Smith wrote in 1776, "There is a lot of ruin in a nation," and the country has learned a lot since 1776, and particularly since 1929-1933, about how to prevent economic collapse.
Most important is the lesson that the fiscal and monetary powers of the Federal Government and the Federal Reserve System can be used to maintain the overall level of national income and prevent even the most severe financial shock from bringing the economy down.
Black Monday in October 1987, when the Dow Jones industrial average fell over 500 points, demonstrated the point. After the New York stock market crashed, and closely linked foreign markets crashed as well, the Federal Reserve and foreign central banks made sure that enough money was available for banks to take care of their customers. So businesses kept borrowing and investing, consumers kept borrowing and spending, and the economy continued to expand.
In the United States, the gross national product, the total output of goods and services, continued to rise through 1988, 1989 and well into 1990, though at a slower rate. It was still expanding in the third quarter of 1990.
Nevertheless, many economists and noneconomists alike think that the longest peacetime expansion, dating back to November 1982, is finally over. The consensus view of the Blue Chip Economic Indicators survey of 55 leading economists for November is that real G.N.P. will decline at annual rates of 0.8 percent in the current quarter and 0.6 percent in the first quarter of next year. Two negative-growth quarters in a row would, by a common definition, make for a recession. Three-fourths of the economists surveyed expect the recession to last only two or three quarters, and an even larger majority -- 82 percent -- expect it to be relatively mild.
Are the economists, most of whom switched to their "mild" recession forecast only after Iraq invaded Kuwait and oil prices shot up, still too blithe? Many noneconomists think the situation is worse than the economists are saying. A psychotherapist asks if she shouldn't put all her dollars into Swiss francs, so the family doesn't lose all its money as her father did in prewar Germany. A journalist and his wife decide to scale back and delay the renovation of the second floor of their house. A political pollster says the economy will be the big issue in 1992.
Economists define the "misery index" as the sum of the unemployment and inflation rates. Unemployment held at 5.7 percent last month, but was up from a low of 5.2 percent last March, and the inflation rate, measured by the consumer price index, is running at 5.5 percent over last year. Objectively, the country has seen much worse. But misery is a subjective thing, and the classic popular definition is, "A recession is when you are out of work, and a depression is when I am out ofwork." The mind has its reasons, but so has the stomach.
Business people register a great depression when their own businesses fail, and the failure rate is up sharply this year. Dun & Bradstreet reports that in the first nine months of 1990 business failures increased 14.5 percent over 1989.
The failure story varied greatly, however, in different parts of the country. In New England, deep in its own recession, the number of business failures leaped by 192.8 percent. In the Middle Atlantic States, also hard hit, failures were up by 64.6 percent in the first nine months of this year. But on the Pacific Coast, business failures were down 3.5 percent, and in the East North Central states, which include Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, Michigan and Wisconsin, they were down 8.5 percent. Some could still argue that the United States economy was experiencing what once was called a rolling readjustment, with some regions and industries down while others were still up, and each area taking its turn sequentially. By this reckoning, the Southwest and Midwest have largely taken their lumps, while the Northeast and Middle Atlantic States are in the midst of their agony.
These shifts also reflect differences by industry. The liabilities of failures in finance, insurance and real estate totaled $28.3 billion in the first nine months of this year, while failures in manufacturing were $4.1 billion and in mining just $287.5 million. The intensity of the current depression psychology may be subjectively affected by the fact that hard-hit New York is the financial and media capital of the nation, with Wall Street having laid off more than 75,000 employees since the crash, advertising off sharply, and The Daily News in the midst of a bruising strike.
Whether the country is on the verge of a depression is, however, another question. The answer will depend on national and international monetary, fiscal and trade policies. And right now the answer looks relatively reassuring. There is every reason to expect that, with the budget battle over and worries about recession rising, the Federal Reserve will ease money and keep nudging interest rates down, which should help housing, autos and other durable goods, and help brace falling consumer confidence. The Fed will need the cooperation of the other major central banks, especially the German Bundesbank and the Bank of Japan, if it is to follow this course without driving the dollar down too fast and far.
The cheapening of the dollar against the mark, the yen and other currencies should help strengthen United States exports and help offset any further decline in domestic production. It would help greatly if America's partners in Europe and Asia keep expanding and open their markets more widely to American manufactured goods, farm products, intellectual property and services. A successful outcome of the Uruguay Round of trade negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which are expected to conclude before the end of the year, would do a lot to ward off the threat of recession or depression.
The threat will also likely be parried by falling oil prices, as a result of Saudi Arabia's decision to increase its oil production sharply, with output having already risen to 8.2 million barrels a day and scheduled to rise to 8.5 million barrels a day early next year. Further, the price should be pushed down by overall levels of supply and the declining world demand for oil. Of course, war in the gulf would wreck that hopeful expectation. Last Wednesday, hawkish comments by Margaret Thatcher, the British Prime Minister, were enough to send oil prices shooting up $2.68 a barrel, the sharpest gain in two weeks. But if war is avoided, a reversal of oil-price inflation promises to strengthen business and consumer spending on other goods and services. Even at recent oil prices, business investment and consumer spending have held up remarkably well. The danger of a heavy wave of inventory cutting by American industry is not large; business has been holding inventories tight to conserve cash and keep down costs. The stability of the economy in the third quarter reflected this determination of industry to stay lean, mean and competitive.
The most serious problem hanging over the United States economy remains the huge debt burden. Total debt outstanding has reached $12.5 trillion, compared with just $2 trillion a decade and a half ago. If the American economy keeps growing, that enormous debt, four-fifths of it private and the rest public, can be handled. The grave danger of a steep recession is that it could create a huge wave of defaults that would threaten to wreck the financial structure.
This is why the nation's money managers hope to sustain the slow expansion, if that is still possible -- or, if it is too late, to keep the recession brief and mild, while laying the groundwork for a stable recovery. A rise by any other name would smell as sweet.

HEADLINE: In McCarthy Era, TV Networks Cowered;
'The White Case'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Warmed-Over Smear" (column, Oct. 29) Anthony Lewis calls attention to the accusations made more than 40 years ago against Harry Dexter White, once a Treasury official. The "White case," it seems, has once again been given sensationalized publicity in Time magazine.
Thoughtful observers have long come to regard the so-called McCarthy era as a shameful period in our nation's past. They know that during the late 1940's and for more than a decade after, the reputations and often the lives of thousands of innocent citizens were ruined by irresponsible accusations of disloyalty.
Harry White was an early victim of McCarthyism. If Americans recognize the name at all, they probably have heard only the accusations that he was a highly placed spy and a traitor to his country.
We think it pertinent to remind readers of the following:
* Despite years of close surveillance by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which included shadowing and wiretaps, the evidence produced against White never consisted of anything more than the unsubstantiated allegations of two F.B.I. informers unknown to the accused (including Time magazine's own Whittaker Chambers).
* As Mr. Lewis remarks, the members of a grand jury who examined this evidence found it so flimsy that they failed even to bring an indictment against White.
* Just three days before his untimely death -- a direct consequence of his persecution -- the ailing White appeared before the House Committee on Un-American Activities at his own request to clear his name. There, on Aug. 13, 1948, he vigorously denied the charges against him. He defended himself as ably as was possible for a man forced into attempting to prove a negative and denied even the elementary right to confront his accusers. Anyone interested in learning what sort of man Harry Dexter White was need only read the statement of his creed in the transcript of his testimony that day.
It is pertinent to recall White's outstanding contributions as Assistant Secretary of the Treasury and as author of the original plans for the International Monetary Fund and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (the World Bank). As a distinguished civil servant and a brilliant economist, Harry White served his country well.
We reaffirm that we are proud to be his daughters.
 
RUTH LEVITAN
JOAN PINKHAM
Stamford, Conn., Nov. 1, 1990

HEADLINE: The Region;
Worse Than Cuts And Layoffs? More Taxes

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
MAYOR DAVID N. DINKINS warned that he had "some bad news and some worse news" last week as he outlined the cutbacks needed in New York City's budget to keep it balanced this year and next. He said it was too early even to talk about what new taxes might be required.
Yet those taxes could be the worst news of all in a stagnant economy and in the wake of last week's elections, which saw the defeat of a $2 billion environmental bond act in New York State and the near defeat of Senator Bill Bradley in New Jersey, in a backlash over Gov. Jim Florio's aggressive tax policies there. 
 To close a gap of $388 million between expected revenues and expenses in the current budget, Mr. Dinkins announced immediate cutbacks in services, from parks to schools, and the layoff of more than 500 workers. But he said far deeper cuts, and perhaps thousands of layoffs, would be needed to close a gap of at least $1.6 billion in the fiscal year starting July 1.
The state's problems may be even deeper, with a probable budget gap for this year of at least $900 million, and another of between $2 billion and $3 billion for next year. In the last two years, City Hall and Albany have already raised taxes by more than $3 billion, so the choices for the future are tough.
"I think that anyone who doesn't view the election results and understand that voters were sending a clear message is living in Never-Never Land and doesn't understand reality," said Herbert E. Berman, chairman of the New York City Council's finance committee. "The region is in a recession, and the worst thing for local businesses now would be an increase in taxes."
Mr. Berman, Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone and other city officials do not rule out some tax increases, especially if they are reserved for financing specific needs, like law enforcement. But they stress that the easy options have already been used up.
 
'The Last Resort'
 "We've picked all the low-hanging fruit already," said Carol O'Cleireacain, the city's Finance Commissioner. "If we're going to start going after more taxes, then we've got to sit down in coordination and say which is more reasonable for us to go after at the state level, which at the local level and so forth.
"I think it's safe to say that the tax component of any gap-closing will be the absolutely last resort," Ms. O'Cleireacain said.
Before the election, some city officials and fiscal experts had said there was probably room for one more round of substantial state and city tax increases next spring. Privately, city officials now say they could not conceive of their own tax proposals exceeding a few hundred million dollars, which would come on top of a record $800 million increase this year.
The tax that experts most often point to as ripe for increase is the property tax on one- , two- and three-family homes. Historically, this class of taxpayers has been shielded, while commercial property taxes rose faster. The City Council alone has the power to raise property taxes, one of the very few categories over which it has sole control.
But raising these taxes next year would be particularly problematic, because the Council districts are to be redrawn under the new City Charter, and in a special election all 35 seats will be up for grabs and 16 new seats will be added, not only threatening incumbents but reshaping the entire local political order.
"That's clearly an issue," Mr. Berman said. "The political process is there."
Yet there appears to be some public support for higher taxes. A telephone poll of 766 city residents conducted before the election by the Marist Institute of Public Opinion found that 54 percent supported raising taxes to balance the budget, compared to 25 percent who favored cutting services. For the same purpose, 61 percent favored higher taxes, compared to 23 percent who favored layoffs.
If the taxes were for specific needs, the support was greater, with 62 percent agreeing that an increase in property taxes was a good way to finance Mr. Dinkins's proposal to hire thousands of additional police officers and expand the criminal justice system.
The poll also found that 76 percent of New Yorkers supported Mr. Dinkins's call for a payroll tax to help finance the same program, while 83 percent favored his proposal for a 25-cent surcharge on lottery tickets. The poll had a sampling error of plus or minus 4 percentage points.
 
 'Difficult Balancing Act'
 "Public opinion seems to suggest," Lee M. Miringoff, director of the Marist Institute, "that there is an understanding -- not an eagerness, but an understanding -- that when taxes are earmarked for specific purposes, that might be a way to go."
Yet the tax proposals for the anti-crime plan either face tough sledding or are considered dead in Albany and the City Council. And many fiscal experts, business people and even some advocacy groups oppose dedicated taxes, on the grounds that once a tax is reserved for a certain need, advocates of other needs will press for special taxes too, thus weakening the general ability of government to gather resources and spend them as needed.
"When you're the highest tax jurisdiction in the United States, raising taxes is always a gamble," said Ronald K. Shelp, president of the New York City Partnership and the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry, which last year gave state leaders a list of taxes it said could be raised.
But, he added, given the recent record increases, "and when you're in an economic slowdown and you have other jurisdictions around the country courting your businesses, raising taxes is not just a gamble, it's betting against yourself."
On the other hand, Mr. Shelp said, businesses, like everyone else, also care "about housing, public education, quality of life and the rest -- you've got a difficult balancing act."

Fife, Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero, Bill Lynch, and Budget Director Philip R. Michael. (Neal Boenzi/The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 3; Page 5; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1932 words

HEADLINE: Enduring, Not Always Endearing 'Wall Street Week'

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD

DATELINE: OWINGS MILLS, Md.

 BODY:
"NOW Lou should walk into the studio in 5 or 10 minutes," announced the technician. "As soon as Lou walks in, please stay in your seat and keep quiet. Try to keep all your laughter to yourself if he says something funny. And no eating or smoking."
The faces of the small audience lifted in attention and, sure enough, in 10 minutes Louis Rukeyser loped in. He gave a winsome smile and got himself into position. Some last-minute makeup was patted on his nose.
"Do we have liftoff?" Mr. Rukeyser asked.
"Let's go," someone said. 
 And so it was once again time to tape "Wall Street Week," that animated, occasionally impertinent Friday-evening dissection of the economic landscape. As always, the improbable setting was the studios of Maryland Public Television in the town of Owings Mills, outside Baltimore.
The program, which celebrates its 20th anniversary on Friday with a festive episode at Tavern on the Green in Manhattan, has been one of the most popular and robust public affairs shows on national television, and it has done a lot to spawn other business programming. Along with success, however, has come a fair amount of vitriol. Any number of viewers and guests find the program irksome and complain of its game-show feel and question its stock-picking wisdom.
With public television audiences lately migrating to other television choices, the show's popularity has shrunk, though not as much as many other public TV offerings. "Wall Street Week" is carried by 318 stations (including Channel 13 in the New York area), but its ratings the last two years have settled at their lowest point in a decade. According to the Public Broadcasting Service, the show averaged a 2.8 rating (which equates to about 2.6 million homes) the last two seasons, after rising as high as 4.3 in the 1982-83 season.
Besides the anniversary program, a one-hour special will be broadcast on Nov. 19 crammed with clips from the 20 years: the time when a hunter shot out the video feed and viewers saw no picture; when Milton Friedman was asked what he would replace the Federal Reserve with and he said, "A computer," and when a guest named Adriaan Schrikker, asked if he had any stock tips, dug out a slip of paper and rattled off 66 names, in alphabetical order.
SINCE the program's inception -- the idea came from the offhand suggestion of a Baltimore broker -- the host has been Mr. Rukeyser, a former newspaperman and network newscaster who was the first economics commentator at ABC. A large-framed, dapper man of 57 with wavy white hair and an impish grin, he is probably best known for his wisecracks and his incurable addiction to egregiously bad puns. (He once told a gas-and-electric analyst he would now turn him over to his utility infielders.)
The half-hour show is split into several segments: some remarks by Mr. Rukeyser, market chatter with three panelists, questions from viewers and finally an interview with a special guest.
For his work, Mr. Rukeyser earns about $300,000 a year, which is significant money but a fraction of what he pockets on the lecture circuit. He delivers about 40 speeches a year on the economy at $25,000 a talk, and fills up idle time writing books and a newspaper column. There has been a certain amount of financial journalism in his blood, for his father, Merryle, was an economics columnist, and one brother, William, had been managing editor of Fortune and now is editor in chief at Whittle Communications.
During its protracted run, "Wall Street Week" has made stars out of any number of guests and panelists previously well known only to their immediate family and their dentists. Monte Gordon, the director of research at the Dreyfus Corporation and a panelist since 1982, says, "I get recognized in bus lines. I get recognized when I'm eating in restaurants. There's a lot of psychic satisfaction to being on the show."
Some on Wall Street regularly pester their publicity agents to mount an assault on Rich Dubroff, the producer who picks guests. One hopeful broker once offered to send Mr. Dubroff a supply of his favorite liquor to help the process along. Mr. Dubroff reported the broker to his branch manager.
Len Kessler, a publicist for Lee Laino Associates, figures that a mutual fund manager who appears on the program could reap millions of dollars in new business. So how badly do people want to get on? "It's spelled k-i-l-l," Mr. Kessler says. One publicist says that he was offered $25,000 by a client if he got him on the show and knows of a colleague who was dangled $50,000. Neither got on.
But the program is by no means universally adored. " 'Wall Street Week' is too oiled," says Louis Ehrenkrantz, the research coordinator of Ladenburg Thalmann. "It's too reminiscent of a game show. It's even got it's own Vanna White. It's also got too much of the unction of the old French court."
Robert Nurock was a panelist on the first show and eventually designed the program's Technical Market Index, a stock market indicator. He freely admits his fame from the program enabled him to start his own investment advisory firm, Investors Analysis Inc., in Paoli, Pa. But after 19 years of appearances, Mr. Nurock quit in October 1989, contending that his views were being muffled.
"The show has become more show business than anything else," Mr. Nurock says. "I think it has lost a lot of its appeal to anyone who is interested in anything other than entertainment. It has become more mainstream and representative of the Wall Street establishment. It doesn't provide much insight to investors beyond the obvious."
For his part, Mr. Rukeyser feels that Mr. Nurock's forecasts had been off target in recent times and he grew embittered.
Though many guests have great fun, appearing on the program is not always an experience you would like your mother to see. Some individuals wobble out of the studio feeling as if they had been caught in a cement mixer. Letters to the program make it clear that many viewers own no stocks but tune in for what can seem like a financial version of professional wrestling.
FOR instance, Robert Prechter, editor of the Elliott Wave Theorist, a monthly market newsletter, has been on several times and, during his last appearance in 1988, got put in some pretty painful holds. "He came on lying," Mr. Rukeyser says. "He just denied the things he had said. And we had to point it out. He misunderstood and thought the program was for his own glorification."
"That's just the typical Rukeyser pathology," Mr. Prechter shoots back. "He would rather use the big lie story than admit a mistake. Rukeyser keeps claiming he represents the little guy and he's right. But the little guy is himself."
It isn't at all necessary to appear on the show to get a little mutilated. Earlier this year, P. Q. Wall, a Denver newsletter writer, was the subject of a profile in Barron's. The article mentioned that Mr. Wall had once written that Mr. Rukeyser resembled a "wax museum caricature of George Washington." That Friday, Mr. Rukeyser began his show ridiculing Mr. Wall and adding him to the list of "discredited gloomy gurus." Mr. Wall thinks the trigger was the wax museum analogy. But he's not too mad. "I'm basically an Irish Santa Claus," he says. "But I don't think Rukeyser gets too deeply into the cycles of the financial markets."
Of guests resentful of their treatment, Mr. Rukeyser responds: "My job is to be there for the viewer, not to massage the ego of some fat cat guest. The ones who are sensitive are the guys who say they called the last 42 turns in the market and who think they're the Lord incarnate."
Whatever emotions it incites, the show has been proficient at attracting money for itself. More than half of its annual budget of nearly $2 million is met by grants from Prudential-Bache, Travelers and the Enron Corporation. The rest flows from fees paid by stations for broadcast rights. Much of those fees are in turn underwritten by brokerage firms and banks.
It was late now, the night's taping finished, and Mr. Rukeyser and Mr. Dubroff repaired to a conference room with several others to watch a videotape of the show. Mr. Rukeyser nibbled on raw carrots and clutched a stopwatch to time each segment.
Mr. Rukeyser grumbled that a panelist took a whole minute to answer a question, and then watched, with growing mirth, the interview with special guest Richard H. Jenrette, the chairman of the Equitable Life Assurance Society. During the interview, Mr. Rukeyser repeatedly pointed out that Equitable seemed to be riddled with problems, while Mr. Jenrette essentially insisted that the world couldn't be more wonderful.
WATCHING Mr. Jenrette reply to a question about recent bad publicity -- "I would say the stories are greatly overblown" -- Mr. Rukeyser couldn't refrain from sniggering.
When Mr. Jenrette remarked, in dead seriousness, "Everybody has a bad year now and then," Mr. Rukeyser broke out in laughter.
On the tape, Mr. Rukeyser asked when things would improve for Equitable. Mr. Jenrette said, "Let's come back in a year and I'll give you a good report."
"Yeah, right!" Mr. Dubroff said.
"Would you buy a used GIC from this man?" Mr. Rukeyser said, referring to a popular insurance industry product known as a guaranteed investment contract.
"After looking at his company, division by division," Mr. Dubroff said, "I wouldn't buy anything from this man."
The room filled with laughter.
(In subsequent discussion, Mr. Jenrette was not joyous. "If you go on a show, you have to expect tough questions," he said, "but I felt there was unfair characterization of the company's overall position.")
After tending to assorted matters, Mr. Rukeyser left the studio at 10:30 for a late dinner. Over wine and lobster, he said he was still a long-term optimist on the stock market and that his aim was "to educate people to get rich slow."
He said he would keep doing the show as long as the audience wants him to and as long as it's fun. Time, perhaps, for Mr. Jenrette to make many additional appearances.
 
 
CAVEAT INVESTOR
 QUITE a few viewers see "Wall Street Week" as a way to get rich, or at least a little more comfortable. There has long been evidence of a pickup in trading volume of stocks mentioned on the program on the Monday following its airing. For some years, however, the actual wisdom of the stock recommendations has invited sharp differences of opinion.
Several studies have been done of the performance of stocks mentioned on the show, the most famous by Norman Fosback, the editor of Market Logic, a newsletter. In studies he did in the mid-1980's, he concluded that buying activity on the Monday after a show caused recommended stocks to advance an average of some 2 percent. Within a few months, however, he found that the prices settled back to their old levels.
(Some years ago, Barron's suggested that the best way to profit from the show would be to find out who upcoming guests are, read what they've been promoting in their research reports and then buy some of those stocks before the program.)
Louis Rukeyser, the program's host, dismisses Mr. Fosback's studies as "full of baloney," and insists that Mr. Fosback is miffed because he had never been invited to be on the show.
"He's totally off the wall," Mr. Fosback replies.
Mr. Rukeyser is adamant about pointing out that no one should trade stocks solely based on "Wall Street Week." "Anyone who is looking for a tip on a hot flier is in the wrong pew," he said. "You should use the name as a suggestion to do some homework."

HEADLINE: Judge Harold Stevens, 83, Dies; First Black on Court of Appeals

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO

 BODY:
Harold A. Stevens, the first black to sit on New York State's highest court and a former State Assemblyman, died on Friday at his home in Harlem. He was 83 years old.
Justice Stevens died of a heart attack and was pronounced dead at Harlem Hospital, said a friend and fellow jurist, Justice E. Leo Milonas. 
 Justice Stevens represented the 13th Assembly District in Albany from 1947 to 1950. He resigned from the Assembly after his election to the Court of General Sessions, his first judicial position.
In 1955, he was appointed Justice of the State Supreme Court by Gov. W. Averell Harriman. He was subsequently elected for a 14-year term.
 
First Black in Judicial Posts
 In 1958, he was named Associate Justice of the Appellate Division of the New York Supreme Court. In 1969, he was appointed Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division's First Department, where he helped supervise a reorganization of the court system and was the guiding force behind a program to build new courthouses.
He was named to the highest court, the State Court of Appeals, in 1974 as an interim appointment. The next year he was redesignated Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court. He retired in 1977.
He was the first black to hold each of these positions.
As a judge, Justice Stevens created "sentencing panels" to review cases to avoid sentencing disparities that often reflected differences in race and economic status. He also directed a procedure to mediate medical malpractice cases and ease court crowding.
 
'No Voice of Protest'
 Harold Arnoldus Stevens was born in 1907 on a 1,000-acre farm owned by his father on John's Island, S.C. Justice Stevens graduated from Benedict College in Columbia, S.C. and obtained his law degreee from Boston College in 1936. In a 1958 interview, he said he had decided to become a lawyer after a 1926 incident in which a black woman and her two brothers, accused of killing a sheriff, were dragged from the county jail in Aiken, S.C., towed through town behind a car, shot and mutilated.
"There was no voice of protest raised," he said. "Then I was inspired to study law because it was our best bet to eliminate things like this."
A convert to Roman Catholicism, he received the Papal Pro Ecclesia et Pontifice medal in 1954 from Pope Pius XII for his interracial work.
He also served as special counsel to President Roosevelt's Committee on Fair Employment Practices, and was credited with forcing a hearing on efforts by Southern railroads and white engineers to oust black firefighters from their long-held jobs.
A World War II veteran, he received many awards and honorary law degrees, including one from the University of South Carolina in 1988. The school expelled his grandfather in the 1890's after a segregationist Governor, Wade Hampton, decided that no black would graduate from college in his state, said Justice Milonas.
Justice Stevens is survived by his wife, the former Ella C. Myers; a brother, John Stevens of New York City, and several nieces and nephews.

HEADLINE: Businesses Confront Office Wastepaper

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

DATELINE: ARDSLEY

 BODY:
THE same week McDonald's announced it would do away with its plastic foam hamburger box because "our customers just don't feel good about it," a broad spectrum of county businesses sent 70 representatives to a conference here to learn about protecting the planet by improving the disposal of office waste.
The Ciba-Geigy Corporation, which collects an average of 10 tons of recyclable material each month in the county, was the host for the seminar, sponsored by the Westchester County Association, the county government and Inform, a nonprofit environmental-research group based in Manhattan.
A series of speakers from industry and government outlined what they perceived as a growing crisis and then spoke about the role businesses played in generating waste and in disposing of it.
 
The Waste Stream Is Growing
 "It is a crisis," emphasized Constantine Sidamon-Eristoff, administrator of Region 2 of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, an area that includes Westchester. "Since 1960, the waste stream has been growing faster than the population."
Nationally, he said, "we're generating 160 million tons of garbage a year and nearly a third of the country's 6,500 landfills are expected to close within two years."
So any effective strategy for managing waste, he concluded, must rely heavily on reducing waste and recycling it.
S. J. Schulman, president of the Westchester County Association, a business group, urged companies to take the lead in recycling efforts and suggested why: "One-third of the waste in Westchester is generated by business. If recycling fails, it means that more money will have to be spent on building a capital facility to handle it" like another garbage-to-energy incinerator.
 
Handling Government Paper
 The county built the incinerator in Peekskill that now handles much of the 371,00 tons of waste generated in Westchester a year. But it does not now have the money for a similar effort, said County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke. "The 1991 budget is edged in black," he said. "We have to conserve what we have. Therefore, getting business involved in recycling becomes doubly important."
The county became committed to recycling two years ago, Mr. O'Rourke said. "Nothing produces paper like government and that is why legislation requiring government to use recycled paper is especially important," he said. "It helps create a market for recycled products."
Every month, 682 tons of paper from 185 companies in the New York City region are being recovered, according to the State Legislative Commission on Solid Waste. The efforts of businesses and government in Westchester set a good example for the country, said Joanna D. Underwood, president and founder of Inform.
"Recycling is a basic way of making businesses more efficient," Ms. Underwood said. "It is a process that doesn't call for any new technology. Only simple mundane steps are required, such as collecting waste and finding buyers and carters for materials."
One Westchester example cited at the conference was the Reader's Digest in Chappaqua, which has announced that it saved $100,000 a year in disposal costs because of its waste program.
"New industries, which use recycled materials to make their products, are then created," said Ms. Underwood, who added that the recycling of waste products is itself now an industry, and one that has provided jobs for semi-skilled people and handicapped workers.
 
Waste Law Going into Effect
 But aside from any potential economic incentives, waste management will become the law of the land, said Janet L. Matthews, legislative director of the New York State Legislative Commission on Solid Waste.
"Waste reduction is a priority of New York State," she said. "By 1992, separation of waste materials" -- plastics, glass, cardboard and paper -- "is mandated. Our goal is to increase recyclable materials by 40 percent and reduce waste by 10 percent."
State grants and loans are available for recycling programs, Ms. Matthews said, adding that the state is depending on the private sector to use secondary materials and recover materials from waste.
National goals, Mr. Sidamon-Eristoff of the E.P.A. said, call for a 25 percent reduction in the waste stream by 1992. This would be achieved by reduction and recycling, reversing the trend of increased waste production; by improving solid-waste management practices and by the development of needed landfills, municipal waste combusters and secondary markets to handle waste.
The conference's host, Ciba-Geigy, takes an "aggressive approach" to reducing the production of waste at its manufacturing plants, research laboratories and office buildings, said Richard Barth, Ciba-Geigy's president and chief operating officer.
"So far this year in the county, we have averaged 10 tons of recyclable materials a month," he said, "helped by the active participation of our employees, who have made recycling a natural part of their daily routine."
 
Employee Understanding Is a Key
 Thomas Bianchi, manager of engineering and maintenance, shared some nuts and bolts details of the Ciba-Geigy program with the seminar participants. What's needed, he said, is manpower, space, a budget and knowledge of the recycled materials market.
Mr. Bianchi said his company had carved out space for recycling stations throughout its 60-acre site here. "They're used mostly for paper and glassware collected from labs," he said. "For the first eight months of the year, we've collected 80 tons of paper, which is the equivalent of 400 trees, or 200 barrels of oil, which would heat 20 houses in New York State for a year."
Up-front costs include the labor of the 13 people needed for the recycling program. "We've realized $1,200, paid to us for recycled items," Mr. Bianchi said. "But the real results are down the road in the form of a sharp drop in disposal costs."
<> <> But the sharp drop in disposal costs is linked to finding markets for the recycled material, and that can be a problem, said James J. Hogan, director of resource management for the County Department of Public Works.
"What recycling actually means is selling recycled material to 'end users' who will make something of it," Mr. Hogan said. "But the problem is, the end user isn't always sure of a reliable supply of material. A mandatory recycling program is needed to insure the end user that he'll have his materials."
The county, Mr. Hogan said, is stimulating the markets for recycled materials by buying recycled products and by helping end users, like a company that is processing mixed plastic materials. "We're helping them find a site for their plant," he said.
The County Recycling Office has set up a hot line -- 285-2588 -- for businesses seeking recycling information.
Carl LaCavalla, vice president of Suburban Carting in Mamaroneck, a commercial transporting company, said carters have become solid-waste consultants and have begun to form recycling companies because "it's adapt or die."
"But recycling will cost business money," Mr. LaCavalla said, because the marketing structure "is not there."
Most wastepaper, which is the largest recycled item, is going overseas to Pacific Rim countries, he said. "The only way it can get used up here is to create a market. Wastepaper used to bring $40 a ton; now we have to pay $40 a ton to get rid of it."
He criticized the county, saying it had no good solid-waste management program in place. "We know garbage," he said. "We know small and large businesses must be part of the waste-management plan. Right now, it's a gloomy picture."
But to help them become part of the solution, the conference's participants each received a Business Recycling Manual. The manual, commissioned by the Westchester County Association, prepared by Inform and produced by Recourse Systems of Cambridge, Mass, delves into such topics as designing waste-management programs, teaching employees, negotiating with carters and dealing with special materials. To obtain a copy call 285-2532.

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND Q&A: HAROLD E. ADAMS;
A 30-Year Veteran in the Many Efforts to Combat Drugs

BYLINE: By PHILLIP LUTZ

 BODY:
AFTER more than 30 years in the drug wars, Harold E. Adams, Commissioner of the Nassau County Department of Drug and Alcohol Addiction, says the efforts are largely imagery.
Mr. Adams, the only commissioner since the department was created in 1972, says addiction is as widespread and community resistance to treatment centers as pronounced today as when he began his career. Apathy toward and denial of the problems, he contends, are as prevalent as ever among some parents and school administrators.
Despite his strong support of anti-drug laws, Mr. Adams says that the long-term solution, if there is one, lies not in largely ineffective law-enforcement measures, but in emphasizing treatment and education.
Mr. Adams, 59 years old, began his career in 1958 as a parole officer, rising to supervisor. In 1969, he became a supervisor of after-care services for the state's old Narcotics Addiction Control Commission. In 1970, he became director of a mental-health clinic in the East New York section of Brooklyn.
A consultant to Federal and state agencies, Mr. Adams, in his $96,000-a-year position as Nassau Commissioner, supervises a $40 million budget that pays for 175 programs treating 25,000 people a year.
A native of Brooklyn, Mr. Adams lives with his wife in Roosevelt. They have one daughter, a doctor in Manhattan.
Q. How have the problems of chemical dependency evolved over the years, and what is the outlook for continued high levels of drug use?
A. It's cyclical. We've gone through a lot of different eras in this department. We've had the high incidence of heroin abuse, the LSD scares, PCP -- all types of periods where one drug or another seems to be most popular.
There's always a new drug. If you go through the history of this country -- starting with the Civil War veterans addicted to morphine and right through cocaine, marijuana and LSD -- there is always a different drug. The popular drug now, and the one creating so many problems, is cocaine and its derivative, crack.
Q. Is there any satisfactory way to treat crack addiction?
A. People are still learning, us included. One thing we've learned is that this population needs services very specifically developed to deal with that type of addiction. We find that residential treatment has to be more intensive, but on a shorter-term basis.
Q. Hasn't the typical course of treatment at Topic House, the county-run residential treatment center in Plainview, been relatively long term? Does this show a change in philosophy?
A. It does. Topic House has been basically a long-term facility where people have been in treatment for a year to 18 months, with 14 to 16 months a good average. We've been trying to revise that program to deal with the new addiction.
You have to understand that we still have only one residential treatment center in Nassau County, Topic House. It had a capacity of 75, and recently expanded to 88.
Just because we're dealing with the crack addiction there doesn't mean that heroin addiction has gone away. Heroin addiction is very much part of the scene. Crack is getting a lot of the publicity, but there has been an upsurge in heroin in recent months.
Q. Your department recieved $3 million from the Federal Government last year to expand outpatient, methadone maintenance, day treatment and residential services. You had been having some problem finding space for the residential beds, and the financing was to run out at the end of September. What happened?
A. We've been very successful in all the areas, with the exception of residential. We've asked that we be given more time for the residential phase and that the money originally awarded be diverted into day treatment, methadone and outpatient services, so that we wouldn't lose the money and, at the same time, would get an extension to develop additional residential treatment slots.
We've been meeting with the county administration on this, and we're hoping that we'll be able to increase our residential treatment capacity by the middle of next year.
In the interim, we've entered into a contract with a private organization called Mediplex, which runs short-term residential programs at two places near Albany and a third place in Pennsylvania that are pretty well suited to cocaine and crack addiction.
Individuals in need of short-term treatment come through our inpatient unit and are placed immediately into treatment at one of those facilities, with the idea that they'll be receiving clinical treatment.
Q. What are the prospects for being able to improve inpatient residential treatment?
A. That very issue is now under discussion with the county administration. Because of the "not in my backyard" syndrome, if we're really going to do something, the answer is going to have to be on either county- or state-owned property, where a facility can be converted, utilized or built.
We're exploring a plan possibly to do that on county property. That plan has not been fully developed yet. But we hope that by the middle of next year we will have a facility that will allow us to increase our residential capability by providing what I would call, for want of a better word, a halfway house for those individuals who come through Topic House, successfully complete the treatment phase and are being moved back into the community.
Q. Is there a specific site or building in mind?
A. No. Right now, the county is reviewing a couple of options. Originally, we had a Topic House at Mitchel Field in mind, but I don't think that's going to be a site location.
The decision has not been made as to what county properties might lend themselves to that.
Q. The Governor had been talking about a major expansion in the number of treatment beds. Is anything likely to come of that?
A. No. In my opinion, that's not going to happen any time in the near future because the state faces on a statewide basis the same problem we face locally. That is, where do you put these programs? The state is going to have to take the lead and make its facilities available for these programs.
Q. Your department provides individual counseling in a one-dormitory 60-bed treatment unit in the county jail. What are the prospects for expanding the number of people who are treated?
A. My department has the responsibility for providing services only to the D.W.I. population in the jail. The substance-abuse program is run by the jail itself. We work cooperatively with them, but we do not run the program.
Two things have happened that I think are significant. First, at the Sheriff's request, my department will be conducting intensive training programs for the jail staff that's going to be providing services.
Second, my department, working cooperatively with the jail, has submitted a propoal -- and early reaction has been favorable -- to the Federal Government for a $4.1 million grant for three components: One for the expansion of women's and children's services and two for services under the criminal-justice system.
The other criminal-justice component is probation. We're working very closely with the Probation Department in providing services for those individuals who are mandated into treatment by the courts.
Q. How useful is it to arrest users of drugs, considering that so many are being referred for treatment?
A. The law is the law, and people who violate it should be arrested, whether they're using drugs or breaking into houses. The law really is for possession and sales, although they go hand-in-hand with usage.
We are working with the County Court and Probation Department to develop programs for those caught up in drug sweeps. We feel we can develop a program that will see to it that those individuals who, after evaluation, are found not to present a problem, can be referred into the treatment network. Let's face it. The jails are overcrowded, and we have to look for alternatives for those individuals who don't pose a threat and are interested in trying to change.
Q. What do you think of the spending priorities among anti-drug agencies? Would it be better to spend more on treatment than on law enforcement?
A. My feeling is that the drug war, or wars -- and I've been a part of just about every one -- are mostly imagery or public relations. The one we have currently is a good example.
The so-called war on drugs, whose centerpiece was going to be Washington, has shown no significant changes a year later. The priorities have to be looked at and changed.
The prevention and education initiative has been greatly underfinanced over the years, not only on the Federal level, but on the state level as well. The reason for this is that it is very difficult to graphically illustrate that prevention and education work.
It takes time to work with kids and, hopefully, have an effect on their lives. But it's not dramatic -- not like having a big drug bust in which everyone gets his picture taken with great quantities of heroin or cocaine there. That appeases the public, but it does not really do anything in terms of eradicating the problem.
Q. How do you react to the questioning of the value of drug education by William Bennett, the President's Director of Drug Control Policy?
A. I find that very interesting in coming from the former Secretary of Education. The public has been misled. The current Administration's drug war has not really succeeded, and I think that part of the problem has been that there has been a lot of emphasis on the law-enforcement part of it and not enough emphasis on the treatment and prevention and education part of it.
Q. Would the decriminalization or legalization of certain drugs reduce the street crime tied to drugs?
A. Not in my opinion. That's a cop-out. The problem with our society is that we look for instantaneous cures. There is no such animal.
We have to be prepared to deal with a 50-year-old problem with long-term solutions, not short-term fixes. We have to deal with the reasons people use drugs, Unemployment, housing, lack of educational, vocational and professional opportunities. Suddenly saying that now it's legal for people to use drugs, and taking the street value out of it, is not going to solve the problem.
One of the things that concerns me is that there are still school districts in which the school administrations, board and possibly the parents have their heads in the sand, figuring this is a problem that does not affect them. There may be 10 or 12 districts where we feel this is a problem, and we're going to have to try to implement some program to get them involved in their communities.
One of the problems is that some of these districts feel that if they get involved with my department, this is an indication, an acknowledgement, that they have a serious problem. Nothing could be further from the truth. We have to dispel that myth.

HEADLINE: 'Lost' S.& L. Money Is Still Out There

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"No Taxes Needed in Savings and Loan Bailout," Robert Eisner's Oct. 10 letter, provides a neat demonstration of the dangers of metaphorical reasoning in economics. Professor Eisner argues that printing new money to bail out savings and loan depositors would be noninflationary, because the new money would merely replace money "lost" by the savings and loan industry. The argument assumes there is no difference between money "lost" as a result of bad loans and money lost in a fire.
But there is a big difference: money lost in a fire is gone for good, whereas money lost through bad loans (like money lost in casinos) is lost to someone, for example, borrowers and those whose goods are purchased with borrowed funds. The billions "lost" by the savings and loan industry have not gone up in smoke, but have wandered somewhere beyond their lenders' reach.
Professor Eisner's argument, in short, makes as much sense as the claim that breeding new kittens to replace all "lost" cats will not increase the cat population. The claim is true if the "lost" cats have all died, but false if they have merely wandered away. Dollars wander away all the time, but they seldom die unless the Federal Reserve chooses to kill them.
 
GEORGE SELGIN
Assistant Professor of Economics
University of Georgia
Athens, Ga., Oct. 11, 1990

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: New York City Is Hurt But Still Has Reserves;
Entertainment: Still a World Stage, But With Problems

BYLINE: By William H. Honan

 BODY:
Broadway, the arts and tourism still command a world spotlight, and in the last 10 years they have nearly doubled the number of people they employ -- to more than 50,000. But economic problems have led to worries about the future.
 Airport and Amtrak arrivals are up this year, and in the first six months of 1990, attendance at tourist attractions remained level with 1989.
"There are five billion people on the planet," said Marshall E. Murdaugh, president of New York City's Convention and Visitors Bureau. "Almost half of them speak some English, and most of those want to visit New York."
And Martin E. Segal, chairman of the New York International Festival of the Arts, said New York remained "the place where artists come to gain worldwide recognition."
"If the arts continued to flourish in London during the blitz," he said, "you can bet they will continue here."
But the restaurant business is down, as many New Yorkers are eating out less frequently. More than 130,000 people are employed at restaurants and bars in New York City, a slight decline from 1989.
 
'Things Are Good,' for Now
 Although 9 of the Shubert Organization's 17 theaters are dark at the moment, Gerald Schoenfeld, the chairman, said the shows that were running were highly profitable. "Things are good," he said.
Yet Mr. Schoenfeld took a dimmer view of the future. "If the performing arts are going to survive, there will have to be major adjustments in work rules, salary scales and city policy toward theater buildings, which cannot now be operated profitably," he said.
Off Broadway producers expressed some optimism, saying that an economic downturn was more likely to hurt large, expensive Broadway productions.
And at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, William H. Luers, the president, noted, "An institution like ours does well when things get tough -- we're cheap."
On the negative side, Mr. Luers said, 20 percent of the museum's support comes from the city, and "when the city is forced to cut its budget, arts institutions are sure to suffer."
Mary Schmidt Campbell, the Commissioner of New York City's Department of Cultural Affairs, warned of "a decentralization and gradual diffusion of cultural institutions away from New York." She said this could occur because of "an unusual confluence of events" -- including the 1986 Tax Reform Act, the 1987 stock market crash, political challenges to the National Endowment for the Arts, the flattening of corporate sponsorship and the economic problems of the city.
"We can't be complacent," she said, "We've got to be resourceful."

HEADLINE: New York City Is Hurt But Still Has Reserves;
Wall Street: A Pivotal Role, Even in Bad Times

BYLINE: By Leslie Wayne

 BODY:
There will always be a Wall Street.
 For nearly two centuries, New York City has been the financial capital of the nation and one of the pillars of the world's financial system. And despite the current gloomy atmos phere -- punctuated by huge layoffs at brokerage houses, declining business and the collapse of several firms -- many people say New York's securities industry is not threatened.
Still, Wall Street may never quite return to the manic 1980's, when it helped propel the city's and the nation's economies.
"I see an industry that has grown almost exponentially for the last decade and accumuluated a head count that cannot be sustained," said Samuel L. Hayes 3d, a finance professor at the Harvard Business School. "But to be at the cutting edge of investment banking, it means being on the cutting edge of market intelligence, and that's not easy from Dubuque."
The turning point for Wall Street came with the stock market crash of Oct. 19, 1987. Since then, employment has fallen by about 27,000 people, to 137,000, and it continues to plummet. Large firms like E. F. Hutton & Company and Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. are now history. And other major firms like Morgan Stanley & Company have talked about moving to the suburbs.
Professor Hayes doubts that any leading firm will leave the city -- largely because most high-profit lines of business depend on the personal interaction of skilled financiers.
 
'A Lot of Consolidation'
 But "it will be different," said Lowell L. Bryan, a director at McKinsey & Company, adding: "Wall Street will never have as many highly paid people as in the past decade. We will see a lot of consolidation. Technology will continue to replace people."
Wall Street has taken hits besides the '87 crash. Many of its businesses, like money market funds, have turned into high-volume, low-margin ventures, and deregulation has brought in tough competition from commercial banks.
Fortunately, opportunities have emerged from foreign demand for access to American markets and from the growing market for financial ventures that cross international borders. "Wall Street would be a lot smaller if it were not for globalization," said Robert S. Salomon Jr., a managing director at Salomon Brothers.
But over all, Wall Street seems to be looking toward a quieter future. "The 1980's was a period of excess that is unlikely to be repeated," said Michael Goldstein, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company.
