HEADLINE: Pillars Under Stress: New York's Economy - A Special Report;
New York City Is Hurt But Still Has Reserves

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Every so often, New Yorkers find themselves whistling past the graveyard. A recession sets in. Longstanding economic ills, masked during good times, recapture attention. And the city seems to be fading, perhaps irreversibly, as a great financial headquarters and as the center of creative industries.
This is one of those moments.
The question is, will the city pull out, as it always has, with most of its economic pillars in place, or is it sinking into permanent decline?
 
Some Surprising Strengths
 A close look at various segments of the economy of New York City and the interconnected suburbs finds some surprising strengths -- through public-works projects, Wall Street's resilience and in the entertainment industry, for example -- and little evidence of irreversible decline. But almost all of the great enterprises that have made this metropolitan area, with its 19 million people what it is, are facing complicated problems. 
 Some of these industries -- banking, retailing and network television, in particular -- may well emerge as permanently slimmed down from their 1980's levels, forcing many people to find work elsewhere or in other fields.
The securities industry, which helped drive the boom of the 80's, seems destined to remain headquartered in New York, as a major world force. Indeed, despite the recent layoffs, the investment houses are larger in numbers of people employed than they were when the boom started in 1982 -- although Wall Street will probably not generate in the 90's the kind of wealth that made tens of thousands of New Yorkers rich in the 80's.
 
Adjusting to the 90's
 Other industries that have historically drawn wealth to the city also seem to be adjusting to the 90's, more or less successfully. The entertainment industry in many ways is hotter than ever. But rising costs and America's growing regional entertainment threaten its prosperity. Almost all the nation's leading advertising agencies are still in New York. But some production operations are moving out, also because of rising costs. And the nation's large book publishers are clearly anchored in Manhattan. But they no longer generate new jobs.
In an odd way, an important positive factor in the New York area economy at present is public spending, even in the midst of budget crises here and almost everywhere in the nation. Not in decades has so much money gone for public works in the area -- airports, highways, bridges, sewers, subways and other projects. Roughly $12 billion will be spent in the metropolitan region in the current fiscal year.
Such government outlays are a healthy counterforce to a 43 percent decline since 1987 in the value of new private construction, a decline related to the sharp drop in real estate prices.
Government has also been a stronghold for new employment. Today, the metropolitan area's various governments employ 1.2 million people, half of them within New York City, out of a total work force of 7.6 million, half of which is also within the city. While nearly every industry in the private sector has been reducing payrolls since spring, government hiring has risen, maintaining an annual growth rate of 20,000 people since 1987.
But the growing shortage of tax revenue threatens the public sector as an important economic stimulus. In fact, Mayor David N. Dinkins's announcement on Friday that more than 10,000 city jobs are to be eliminated represents the first major reversal of the government hiring trend since 1982.
 
An Army of Immigrants
 The New York economic machine has also been getting a powerful push from its army of immigrants. By most estimates, people born abroad now constitute 30 percent of the city's population of more than seven million, a huge source of labor and entrepreneurial energy. Immigrants have been especially well represented in manufacturing jobs, although these jobs have been disappearing from New York City for 40 years. In apparel making, one of the two large manufacturing industries left (the other is printing), immigrants constitute an estimated 40 percent of the 100,000 workers.
Because of its long decline, manufacturing has ceased to be thought of as a reliable underpinning. Yet it still gives work to 350,000 people within the city -- and a million in the metropolitan area -- putting the city and its suburbs among the nation's six largest manufacturing centers.
There are those who believe New York cannot permanently remain vibrant without a reversal in the decline of manufacturing, a decline often attributed to adverse government policies and high operating costs. Labor costs were part of the problem in earlier times, but have become less of an issue in recent years, notwithstanding the current strike at The Daily News, where costly work rules are at issue.
 
Powerful Stimulus Is Gone
 Some urban experts argue that manufacturing is essential to provide the economic diversity needed for sustained growth. That concern was forgotten in the 80's. The Wall Street boom, the corporate takeovers, the huge flow of foreign investment into the United States, with New York City as the gateway, seemed to lift all boats. In fact, most of New York's income growth went to Wall Street's people, while the average earnings of others barely kept up with inflation.
Wall Street's powerful stimulus is gone now. Still, many experts maintain that the framework remains -- not only the bankers, lawyers, accountants and brokers that make New York a world financial center, but also the theaters, museums, orchestras and artistic groups that sustain the city as the nation's cultural center.
The problem lies in keeping this structure in place during the recession. No single industry is likely in the 90's to generate the good times that Wall Street made possible in the 80's.
But many experts note that the city government's finances are in far better shape than they were in the 70's, when New York nearly went bankrupt, and thus public spending, even in the current budget crisis, is in a better position to help minimize the recession's impact. Others argue that manufacturing is not likely to decline as sharply in the 90's as it did during the city's last recession, from 1969 to 1977.
If hope, then, for the future is alive, there is equal realization that the next few years will be hard. "My guess is that we are in for a long recession," said Ray Horton, an economist and the president of the Citizens Budget Commission. "But some sort of hot thing will probably come along, and you and I will say, 'Why did we not see it?' "

HEADLINE: Uncertainty At Computer Exposition

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 11

 BODY:
Amid a mixture of glitz and uncertainty, Comdex/Fall, the world's largest annual exposition of computer products, opens here Monday for a weeklong trade show expected to attract 100,000 buyers and sellers, nearly a fifth from overseas.
The glitz, impressive even by the standards of this neon-washed desert city, is provided by 1,800 companies, from the International Business Machines Corporation to tiny start-ups hoping for a big break. The First Interface Group of Needham, Mass., which produces the Comdex shows, said the exhibitors will fill more than a million square feet of display space and will demonstrate an unusually large number of new products. 
 The uncertainty arises from how well those new products will sell if the economy falters, as many people here expect.
 
 'Like Christmas Shopping'
 "From a product standpoint, this is the most interesting and exciting Comdex in several years," said Lissa Morgenthaler, senior analyst for the California Technology Stock Letter in San Francisco. "It's a little like Christmas shopping for me, but the companies will be feeling a fair amount of trepidation."
"Excitement isn't always what a company wants," she noted. "Certainty is sometimes better."
Among the new products are miniature portable computers that match the power of desktop PC's, software applications designed to take advantage of the Microsoft Corporation's DOS-Windows operating system, storage devices that can hold billions of characters of data, and powerful Unix-based work stations, which will compete with both conventional PC's and more costly minicomputers and mainframes.
Dealers at the show will be wrestling with fundamental changes in the way businesses now shop for PC's. As small computers become more powerful and complex, and as networked PC's become more important, the traditional retail channels are being squeezed by specialized dealers and warehouse-style discounters.

HEADLINE: Freedom Bank's Failure Hits Harlem Like a Death in the Family

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

 BODY:
The failure of the Freedom National Bank of New York last week was more than just the demise of another shaky financial institution. It was also a symbolic blow to Harlem, where the bank was based, and marked the end of an idealistic venture begun during the height of the civil-rights movement.
"This is devastating to our community and the city," Representative Charles B. Rangel said in an interview. The Congressman, whose district includes Harlem, is working with Mayor David N. Dinkins and a group of black clergymen in a last-minute effort to rescue Freedom, which was one of America's largest black-owned banks. "Symbolically, it's a terrible blow, becausethis was a black bank formed by Jackie Robinson that was more sensitive to the businesses and people in this community." 
 Many depositors have come to the heavily guarded bank, and learned that the F.D.I.C. plans to begin issuing refund checks for deposits up to $100,000 at the 125th Street and the Flatbush branches beginning tomorrow.
The bank, which had $101.9 million in assets and two branches in Brooklyn, had been riven by internal power struggles and had lost money in the last few years due to an increasing number of defaults on bad loans. Yet, many black political and business leaders, as well as many of the bank's 22,000 depositors and 97 employees, were shocked and saddened when agents of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation descendedon the bank's main office at 275 West 125th Street on Friday afternoon.
"It makes me feel helpless, like I've been robbed," said Abiodun, a poet who had an account with the bank. "It's a step backward for the empowerment of black people."
Abiodun stood in front of the bank, whose windows were plastered with notices from the F.D.I.C. and the Comptroller of the Currency and whose offices were swarming with 60 F.D.I.C. employees over the weekend. "Freedom Bank," he said, "is now an enslaved bank."
"I'm sick," said Emily Ricks, a real-estate broker who was a shareholder in the bank. "I've had money in Freedom from the beginning, and we have mortgages with it. Ilose and Harlem loses."
The Rev. M. Moran Weston, who in 1949 helped found Carver Savings, a black-owned savings and loan based in Harlem, said: "Freedom is a loss to the entire African-American community, because of the importance of having black institutions involved in economic activities."
Freedom was founded in 1964 by a group of investors that included Jackie Robinson and Dunbar McLaurin, a lawyer, at a time when there were almost no black-owned lending institutions and it was difficult for many blacks to obtain loans from large banks.
"The idea was that the cultural heart of black America should have a commercial bank," said the Rev. Wyatt Tee Walker, a former chairman of Freedom's board and the pastor at Canaan Baptist Church of Christ. "Many small businesses and churches in Harlem bought stock in the bank -- not with the idea that they'd reap any benefit, but rather that Freedom would be a financial resource for people in the minority community to get loans."
After a shaky first decade, the bank's fortunes improved under Hughlyn F. Fierce, an executive with Chase Manhattan Bank who was brought in to serve as Freedom's president for two years. He helped rescue it in 1975, at a time of plunging assets and mounting losses, by getting 11 large banks to invest a total of $4 million. Freedom became consistently profitable around 1977, when Sharnia (Tab) Buford was named president, and its net return on assets was one of the highest of any New York bank in the early 1980's.
Despite its financial success, the bank always attempted to balance fiscal prudence and profitability against its founders' goal of helping small businesses and home-buyers in black neighborhoods by offering low-cost loans. The bank also provided financing for redevelopment projects.
 
A Greater Responsibility
 "We had to be businesslike and our credit criteria couldn't be different from banks downtown," Mr. Buford recalled. "But we also had a greater responsibility because we were chartered as a minority bank. We had to empathize with the customer."
Mr. Buford was ousted in 1986 in a power struggle, and critics such as Mr. Walker say that those who succeeded him were too ambitious.
"They pointed the bank in a different direction, expecting bigger profits, and they wanted to multiply its assets five or six times," Mr. Walker said. That, he added, "contributed to its demise."
In 1988, yet another management team, led by George A. Russell Jr. and Isaiah Robinson Jr., took over, but was unable to attract enough new investors or staunch the bank's growing losses. Freedom lost $1.9 million in 1988 and $2.8 million last year, according to David M. Barr, an F.D.I.C. spokesman. This year's losses were expected to exceed $2 million.
 
Contacted Scores of Banks
 Last month the Comptroller of the Currency, who regulates national banks, notified the F.D.I.C. that Freedom would have to close, Mr. Barr said. "We began contacting scores of banks locally and nationally for a bidder, but none came forward to buy Freedom."
Harlem clergymen and political leaders, including Mr. Walker and Mr. Rangel, appealed yesterday to the city's financial community to help resurrect the bank with an infusion of at least $6 million before a deadline of 9 A.M. tomorrow, when the F.D.I.C. begins paying depositors.
To save the bank, investors would need to obtain a bank charter or an existing bank would have to work out a way of taking over Freedom's assets or deposits from the F.D.I.C.
Supporters of the bank are seeking to extend the deadline to Friday.
 
Rescue Efforts

"Had this been a white bank of comparable size and circumstance, the decision to shut its doors would not have been made so precipitously," Mr. Walker said at a news conference in front of the bank yesterday.
About $2 million had been pledged by last night, said Eugene Webb, a Harlem realtor and a member of Freedom's board of directors, who said that he believed that enough money could be raised to reopen the bank under a new charter.
If the rescue effort is unsuccessful, the bank's supporters said that they would consider establishing a new bank, but that the country's current economic problems would make that difficult.
"It will be a profound tragedy and a stunning defeat for the people of Harlem, especially in view of the coming depression," said Wilbert Tatum, the publisher of The Amsterdam News, a weekly newspaper based in Harlem. "There has to be a move within the community to bolster its financial health, because help won't come from the outside."

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Egypt Angry at Former Arab Allies

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Nov. 9

 BODY:
In a reflection of the bitterness that Egypt holds toward former Arab allies over the Iraqi seizing of Kuwait, senior Government officials here have traced the Iraqi invasion to what they call a conspiracy more than a year old involving Jordan and Yemen as well as Baghdad.
In interviews this week, a senior official described the framework of what he charged was an intricate conspiracy among the three countries to isolate Saudi Arabia and enable Iraq to seize not only Kuwait but also the United Arab Emirates. The official said that efforts to secure Cairo's acquiesence in this culminated last February in what he characterized as a not-so-subtle attempt to bribe Egypt. 
 The senior official, whose account was elaborated on by other officials, offered only circumstantial evidence and no documentation or other hard evidence to support the charges.
The belief in a conspiracy is widely held by Egyptian officials, reportedly even by President Hosni Mubarak, and reflects the bitterness and suspicion that Egypt harbors toward the three countries with which it was closely aligned only three months ago. Since Egypt is at the forefront of Arab opposition to the seizing of Kuwait, this belief also complicates efforts to devise an "Arab solution" to the gulf crisis.
 
Secret Contacts Described
 In interviews, the senior Egyptian official and others, all of whom spoke on condition that they not be further identified, described a series of heretofore secret contacts and efforts by King Hussein of Jordan and President Ali Abdullah Saleh of Yemen to transform the Arab Cooperation Council, an economic and political group consisting of Iraq, Egypt, Jordan and Yemen, into a military organization.
Egyptians now say that the council, whose members are situated around Saudi Arabia, was an important vehicle through which Iraq attempted to neutralize Cairo and dominate the Saudi Government in Riyadh.
King Hussein and other Jordanian officials have vehemently denied the Egyptian charges, as has the Yemeni leader, but the conspiracy plot has gained wide currency in countries that oppose President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. Jordan and Yemen have both expressed considerable sympathy for Iraq, trying to adopt what they call a "neutral" stance by condemning both Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and the presence of American forces in the gulf.
The Arab Cooperation Council was launched in Baghdad in February 1989, ostensibly to foster economic cooperation among Iraq and nations had strongly supported Iraq during its war with Iran.
But, the official said, even before its formal creation, King Hussein, the group's prime mover, repeatedly tried to broaden its mandate by turning it into a defense and security group, with its own integrated military and intelligence structure.
The Egyptians said the aim was to use the council to enmesh Cairo in military and political entanglements with Iraq that would limit Egypt's flexibility and effectively neutralize it after the invasion.
 
Jordanian's First Approach
 Late in 1987, King Hussein initially discussed the idea of the council with President Mubarak, according to the Egyptian account. The King presented it as an Arab version of the European Community. But he also said it should have a military component, a suggestion that immediately aroused Mr. Mubarak's suspicions, the official said.
Mr. Mubarak asked King Hussein whether he had discussed his concept with King Fahd of Saudi Arabia. "Riyadh might have some objections to an alliance of countries that did not include it but that shared its borders, particularly if such a group had a military dimension," the official said.
The official said that King Hussein told Mr. Mubarak that the Saudis had approved the idea. Later that day, the official said, Mr. Mubarak called King Fahd, who became agitated when he heard of the plan for a military alliance, insisting that King Hussein had not mentioned it. The Saudi ruler immediately sent an envoy to Cairo to discuss the proposal.
The Egyptian President told the envoy that he would insure that the group would not evolve into a military organization and that it "would never be used as an ax against Saudi Arabia," the official said.
When Mr. Mubarak toured gulf countries in January 1989, he found that King Hussein had also failed to mention the proposed defense dimension of the council to any head of state there, the official asserted.
When the agreement to form the council was launched at a signing ceremony in Baghdad in February 1989, the Prime Ministers of the member nations were summoned to a meeting shortly before midnight. Until 3 A.M., "they kept pushing for a military clause in the agreement," the official said, referring to Jordan, Yemen and Iraq. But Mr. Mubarak had instructed his Prime Minister to refuse; the next day, the ceremony took place without a military dimension in the agreement.
 
Two Version of Agreement
 In July 1989, the four leaders met again in Alexandria, Egypt, to approve the council's new charter. Mr. Mubarak again found himself under pressure to add a defense and security component to the group's mandate, the official said. Moreover, the official said, Mr. Mubarak found that two versions of the charter agreement had been prepared. Only when Egypt refused to sign the military version was a second version produced and signed, the official said.
At the first anniversary of the council's creation in February 1990, the leaders met privately. King Hussein said that Jordan and Iraq intended to propose the creation of an "Arab cooperation fund" to channel at least $5 billion a year in aid from the gulf oil states to poorer Arab nations.
King Hussein told Mr. Mubarak that "Egypt would get the lion's share," the official said. But Mr. Mubarak refused. "Egypt will not appear to be begging for money from other Arabs," Mr. Mubarak was quoted as having replied.
The official said that after the invasion, Mr. Mubarak concluded that the fund proposal was an attempt to bribe Egypt into condoning a long-planned aggression against Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates. The official noted that Iraq's bellicose speeches in the months preceding the invasion were directed at both countries. But unlike Kuwait, the emirates asked the United States for a show of support; joint maneuvers were held in the Persian Gulf in July.
The official said that Mr. Mubarak also became suspicious of the council forum because President Hussein rarely voiced proposals to which Egypt objected. "King Hussein always seemed to be carrying the message for him," the official said. Mr. Mubarak began to feel isolated in the council.
At an Arab League meeting in Baghdad in February 1990, Mr. Mubarak's feeling of exclusion intensified. The leaders were in bungalows near one another, the official said. Mr. Mubarak saw King Hussein and Saddam Hussein "walking and talking in the garden. Then President Hussein would visit President Saleh of Yemen." But he did not pay a special visit to Mr. Mubarak, the official said. When Mr. Mubarak inquired why not, President Hussein replied that he thought Mr. Mubarak had already left the gathering.
 
Visit by Iraqi's Brother
 The final example of what the official called "Iraqi duplicity" involving the council occurred 10 days before the invasion. On very short notice, President Hussein's brother, the chief of Iraqi intelligence, arrived in Cairo to propose an intelligence-sharing arrangement between Egypt and Iraq and then other council members. Egypt said no.
"In restropsect, it was obvious that military cooperation was to be the sine qua non of the A.C.C.," the official said. "It really persuaded us that the aggression against Kuwait was long-planned, and that members of the A.C.C. were part of this conspiracy."
King Hussein, who has repeatedly denied any advance knowledge of the invasion, denied in interviews last month having participated in such a conspiracy. He confirmed that he had proposed a military dimension for the council, but said he quickly dropped it when Mr. Mubarak objected.
He did not understand, the King said in a telephone interview on Friday, why Egypt and Saudi Arabia had found the idea of a military component for the council so threatening.
The King said he had hoped that the Arab Cooperation Council would foster cooperation and even greater unity between Arab states and Egypt, which had been long ostracized over its peace treaty with Israel. "There was no conspiracy," he declared.
President Saleh of Yemen also denied in an interview two weeks ago having participated in any conspiracy. "What is the basis for these charges?" he asked with extreme agitation. "Where is the proof? Where is the evidence? I have been direct in all my dealings with Arab states. No one can say anything else."

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Nunn, Citing 'Rush' to War, Assails Decision to Drop Troop Rotation Plan

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
The chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee today criticized the Bush Administration's decision to drop its plan to rotate troops in Saudi Arabia, saying that it puts the United States on too fast a track toward war.
Senate Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who heads the committee, said that the decision to drop the troop rotation plan was a "mistake." He said that the move unduly limited the United States' options and added that President Bush should consider reversing it. 
 The abandonment of the rotation plan reflects the Bush Administration's apparent decision to speed up the timetable for resolving the Persian Gulf crisis, by persuading Iraq to withdraw its troops or by using force to drive Iraq out of Kuwait.
In addition, the decision not to rotate troops in itself appeared to add to the pressure to resolve the crisis soon before the morale of American and allied soldiers deteriorates.
 
Debate on Force Intensified
 In the wake of the earlier Administration decision to heavily reinforce United States forces in Saudi Arabia, the move to cancel troop rotation has intensified the policy debate over the question of when and whether military force should be used.
Critics of the Administration's apparent direction note that the Washington kept troops in Europe for 40 years before the decline of the Soviet economy encouraged Moscow to start withdrawing its forces. They say that it is too late to save Kuwait from destruction at the hands of the Iraqis and too soon to tell if economic sanctions will force Iraq to remove its forces from Kuwait. Why not wait a year or more for the economic sanctions to work before ordering an attack that would led to American casualties? some critics ask.
"The first thing the President has to say is why we're in such a hurry," Senator Nunn said on the CBS News program "Face the Nation."
"I haven't been told the reasons why we have to rush this thing," Mr. Nunn said. "Why not let the embargo work?"
 
'A Host of Questions'
 "It's one thing to say it's important -- and it is important -- that Kuwait be liberated and that we're going to use economic sanctions to do so," Senator Nunn added. "It's another thing to say that America is going to take on the mission -- with some help, but not a lot of help -- to confront Iraq and to liberate Kuwait. That's a different mission and raises a host of questions."
While the Bush Administration says publicly that it has not given up on economic sanctions, a senior Administration official who asked not to be identified said that the Administration does not want to wait a long time to see if they will work.
The senior official added that Arab resentment against the American military presence might grow if the United States keeps large number of troops in Saudi Arabia for a prolonged period. The official also expressed concern that American fighting men might lose their edge and that the multinational coalition arrayed against Iraq might unravel if the crisis remained unresolved for an extended period.
Beyond that, the official said it was necessary to send more than 150,000 troops to the region and move toward a quicker resolution of the crisis to shock President Saddam Hussein of Iraq into taking American threats to use force seriously.
 
Aspin Supports Administration
 In a sign of the sharpening divisions over Adminstration policy, Representative Les Aspin, the chairman the House Armed Services Committee, split with Mr. Nunn, his Senate counterpart, and voiced strong support for the Administration decision to send reinforcements to the Persian Gulf and to cancel plans for rotating troops.
"I think the combination of sending more troops and the no rotation policy says the critical crunch point comes sometime between the end of January and probably the first of March," Mr. Aspin, a Wisconsin Democrat, said on the ABC News program "This Week."
"Somewhere in there is the time that there will be a decision made, probably an ultimatum delivered to Saddam Hussein, and if he doesn't respond, I think it probably means war," Mr. Aspin added.
Asked if whether the United States ought to go to war if Iraq refused to withdraw its troops from Kuwait, Mr. Aspin said: " I think that we definitely will, if there's no progress, and I think that's the right policy to adopt."
 
No Explanation, Nunn Says
 In contrast, Mr. Nunn complained that President Bush had not yet provided an explanation of how American military forces might be used in the gulf.
He said, "Getting bogged down in a ground war there is the last thing we want, and plays right into Saddam Hussein's hands and makes our logistic difficulties, which are already present, much more difficult."
Offensive action against Iraq, Senator Nunn said, "is something the military were not given to begin with and were not prepared for."
"And I think the President has a real obligation here," he added, "to explain why liberating Kuwait is in our vital interest."
 
Role of Congress Asserted
 Mr. Nunn said that Congressional leaders were notified before the Administration decided to send massive reinforcements to the Gulf and were not consulted until the decision to end rotation and send more than 150,000 additional troops was made. He said that he and other Congressional leaders would meet with Mr. Bush and Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney this week.
Senator Nunn and Representative Aspin agreed that the Administration should seek Congressional approval if it decided to wage war against Iraq.
Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, the Maine Democrat, said that the Administration had informed him that no decision has been made to attack Iraqi forces. The Senator added that any such action would require a formal declaration by Congress.
If the President decides to attack Iraq, Senator Mitchell said, "he must come to Congress and ask for a declaration."
"If he does not get it, then there is no legal authority for the United States to go to war," he added.

HEADLINE: SUNY Campus in Cornfields Cultivates an Ivy Reputation

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENESEO, N.Y.

 BODY:
In the Genesee River Valley, the ivy-covered buildings of the State University of New York's College of Arts and Sciences at Geneseo soar startlingly out of the surrounding cornfields.
So, in recent years, has SUNY Geneseo itself, becoming one of the nation's most selective, highly regarded public colleges. 
 How the school accomplished this says much about the course of higher education in the 1980's, particularly the power of marketing and national publicity, and the growing appeal of the relatively low tuition at public colleges. But its setbacks also suggest the problems ahead for public colleges.
 
Lobbying for a Tuition Increase
 Geneseo succeeded by becoming more exclusive, educating the middle class rather than the working class, in part by offering these students a tuition bargain. Yet its success has not protected it from the budget problems facing public universities across the Northeast. Facing cuts in academic departments and programs, its students andfaculty members are trying something rarely done in higher education, public or private. They are lobbying for a tuition increase.
"Our tuition is too low -- it's terrible -- and the whole system could collapse," said Ron Herzman, a professor of English. "We have a chance to really be good, to be as good as some people say we are, and it could go either way."
School officials set out in the late 1970's to reverse declines in applications and standards by shoring up marketing, making academic programs more rigorous and becoming choosier about admissions.
"We hypothesized that there was a niche in the market for a small selective liberal arts college that might represent a reasonable alternative for the best and brightest kids whose parents didn't want to spend $20,000 a year," said William L. Caren, a former dean of admissions.
Tuition is now $1,350 a year, and room and board bring costs to about $6,500. SUNY officials said last week that Chancellor D. Bruce Johnstone is considering asking the Legislature for a tuition increase of between $50 and $100 for the spring semester to head off the effects of a new round of budget cuts.
SUNY Geneseo has strengths, starting with a Gothic-style campus bordered on one side by a Main Street listed on the National Register of Historic Places. In the 1970's, it had some solid departments, and one of the system's least-tenured faculties, leaving room for new talent.
The administration began emphasizing teaching over research, and stressed the humanities, rich in required readings from Plato to Shakespeare to Freud.
The admissions office wrote to high-school guidance counselors, sent recruiters across the state, urged students to visit the campus and added an essay requirement to the generic SUNY application. A new poster showed two students under a Gothic arch and read: "A Touch of New England in Western New York."
 
Ranked 2d After New College
 Then in 1986 Money magazine included Geneseo in an article on state colleges titled "Ten Colleges With an Ivy Twist." National publicity continued, and this fall the "Money Guide: America's Best College Buys," ranked Geneseo second among public colleges nationwide, behind only New College, which is part of the University of South Florida, in Tampa.
As applications grew, admission became tougher. The college accepted less than a third of the 9,296 applicants in 1988, compared with 78 percent of the 4,378 in 1979. The high-school grade average of incoming freshmen rose to 92 this year from 84 in 1979, while the average score on the Scholastic Aptitude Test rose to 1160 from 990.
"The whole thing has just gone off the charts," said Geneseo's president, Dr. Carol Harter.
David Truax, the university's associate vice chancellor for access services in Albany, said, "People in SUNY's central administration marvel at what Geneseo has been able to accomplish."
Allan W. Ostar, president of the American Association of State Colleges and Universities in Washington, said: "It's not just the cost. Even more to the point is the growing recognition of the increasing quality of an institution like Geneseo."
 
Not Worth $16,000 More
 Cost, however, is a major factor for both students and the ratings, which are unpopular among many educators who believe they serve mainly to focus attention on a narrow range of schools.
"The rankings reflects the new mentality of students and parents, which is that they are looking for the best education for their dollar," said Christine R. Paulson, a research policy analyst for the Education Commission of the States in Denver.
Jeff Fenton of Webster, N.Y., transferred from a community college to Geneseo in September, turning down Cornell and Brown.
"What those schools held over Geneseo was that they had better buildings on campus and more diversity in the student body, and that didn't seem worth the extra $16,000 a year," said Mr. Fenton, who expects to spend about $6,500 this year on tuition, room and board, fees and expenses.
The change in Geneseo's mission has also transformed the student body. While 10 years ago most students were the first in their families to attend college, now most are the second or third generation. While most have grants, loans or jobs, a majority come from families with incomes over $50,000.
New York's university system does not recruit out of state, and so Geneseo's students are overwhelmingly from New York. But the college draws students from 59 of the state's 62 counties, a broad reach for a SUNY campus. While Monroe and Erie Counties, to the immediate north and west, account for 25 percent of the freshman class, Suffolk County on the east end of Long Island sends 11 percent.
 
'I Miss Steelworkers' Kids'
 Changes in the demographics are cause for some misgivings.
"The downside for me is that the people who come here are a little too suburban and homogenized," said Prof. Ron Herzman of the English department. "What I miss are the kids of Buffalo steelworkers who didn't know they were smart till they got here."
Dr. James H. Willey, a music professor, said: "Today's students are very bright and interesting. But sometimes, when I see a student driving a BMW, I say, 'Ah-hah!' They can have the expensive car because their parents are saving money on college."
Officials defend both their product and their consumers. "The fact is most of our students couldn't afford a Cornell or a Brown," the provost, Donald S. Spencer, said. "And a liberal arts education should not be limited to the most affluent in our society."
 
9 Percent Are Minorities
 Administrators say a priority is attracting a better racial, ethnic and socio-economic mix without lowering standards. The student body is still overwhelmingly white and Protestant or Catholic. Nine percent of this year's 1,135 freshmen were minorities.
"Those improvements have to be redoubled," Dr. Spencer said.
Despite SUNY's guiding principle of accessibility to all high school students, officials in the central administration say there is room within the system for a University Center, like Binghamton, which has long been highly competitive, and now a college like Geneseo. Many campuses, especially the community colleges, have open admissions.
 
Money, the Grim Reaper
 The entire state university system in New York has benefited from the growing cost-consciousness of families as the state has held tuition steady since 1983. The share of all New York high school graduates who applied to at least one of 49 of the system's campuses including Geneseo rose to 41 percent last year from 29 percent in 1979.
The lack of money looms as a sort of grim reaper. In the 1980's, as Governor Cuomo kept tuition flat, Geneseo cut maintenance workers, raised the student-faculty ratio and, to save on fuel, turned down the heat, even bursting the pipes in one dormitory.
A tuition increase alone would not solve SUNY's budget crisis, administrators say, since a $100 hike generates only about $10 million. SUNY's budget gap for next year is estimated to be between $300 million and $400 million.
So far, Geneseo has spared its academic program. But officials expect large cuts that could mean the loss of departments and faculty members. "There isn't any fat left," Dr. Spencer said. "The students at Geneseo would welcome a tuition increase if they knew the money would go into the instructional program instead of a black hole in state government."

GRAPHIC: Photo: David Tamarin teaching his humanities class outdoors at State University of New York's College of Arts and Sciences at Geneseo. The school has become one of the country's most highly regarded public colleges. (Phil Matt for The New York Times) (pg. B4)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
New Rate Cut By Fed Panel Is Predicted

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Credit market analysts say they expect the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee to approve another cut in a key short-term interest rate when the policy-making group meets in Washington tomorrow.
Deep-seated concern about inflationary pressures is likely to prompt at least two committee members, F. Lee Hoskins, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, and Wayne D. Angell, a governor of the Fed, to oppose the move. 
 But private analysts say mounting evidence that the economy may have slipped into a recession will probably sway the majority to approve a cut in the overnight Federal funds rate to 7.5 percent, from its current 7.75 percent target rate.
 
 'Early Stages of Recession'
 "I would be very surprised if the Fed didn't ease," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Bank. "We are in the early stages of a recession, one whose mildness or severity is still in question. And the lack of economic activity will help to fight inflation."
A cut in the funds rate would be the second in less than a month. Responding to a Federal budget package that earmarks close to $500 billion in savings over the next five years, the Fed reduced the funds rate in late October by 25 basis points.
Though they would welcome it, another quarter-point cut in the funds rate would come as no surprise to market participants. Moreover, commercial bankers said last week that a cut of that size would probably not be large enough to prompt banks to reduce their prime lending rate, which has stood at 10 percent since early January.
Yet, if history is a guide, a drop in the funds rate to 7.5 percent should lead to a cut in the prime rate. In the past, banks have tended to reduce their most visible rate when the gap between the prime and their own cost of funds is about two percentage points.
Cynthia Latta, a senior financial economist at DRI McGraw-Hill, the economic forecasting firm, says the spread between the rates is already unusually wide.
Using a weighted average cost of funds that includes three-month Eurodollar rates, three-month certificate of deposit rates and Federal funds, Ms. Latta said the spread between those costs and the prime was now 225 basis points. Normally, the spread is about 175 basis points, she added.
 
 Abnormal Problems Cited
 Bankers acknowledge that the differential is wider than normal. But they add that at this juncture financial problems within the banking system are decidedly abnormal and therefore warrant a wider spread.
"In general, I don't think you will see the banks react favorably" to a quarter-point cut in the funds rate, said Alan C. Lerner, a managing director at the Bankers Trust Comapny. "In normal times it might be enough to get the prime down. But right now the banks want to build back profit margins."
Mr. Lerner and others said a move by the Fed to cut the funds rate to 7.25 percent, either all at once or in two moves, would almost certainly lead to a cut in the prime rate to 9.5 percent.
"If you wanted to get a quick and dramatic reduction in the prime, you would have to cut the funds rate by 50 basis points," said another banker, who spoke on condition that he not be identified.
 
 Spur for Decline in Rates
 Confidence that the Fed will move soon to ease credit conditions was a driving force behind the drop in short- and long-term interest rates last week. By late Friday, yields on 7 3/4 percent two-year notes, a good proxy of market expectations about the Fed's intentions, had fallen to 7.59 percent. Bond yields, more sensitive to longer-term economic fundamentals, stood at just over 8.6 percent late last week, down from 8.69 percent on Nov. 2.
A drop in the prime would make borrowed money more affordable for a wide range of businesses and consumers who have loans that are based on movements in the prime. But economists said that in the current climate a half-point cut would probably not noticeably increase loan demand, or the willingness of banks to lend.
"A rebuilding of household balance sheets, which shows that consumers are less willing to borrow, and tightening up on bank lending standards makes the economy less sensitive now to a drop in interest rates" than previously, said Gary Schlossberg, a vice president and senior economist at the Wells Fargo Bank in San Francisco.
 
 Need Seen for New Drops
 As far as debt-strapped corporations are concerned, long-term money market interest rates will have to fall a bit further before any benefits can be realized, said Robert A. Schwartz, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company. "Long rates have come down quite a bit over the last month to six weeks," he added, "and we are getting to the point where corporations are thinking not only about refinancing long-term debt but about paying down short-term debt."
Nevertheless, Mr. Schwartz said, long-term rates would need to fall "at least" another 25 basis points before major refinancings would begin.
Aside from watching the Fed, during the course of this holiday-shortened week -- the bond markets are closed today in observance of Veterans Day -- fresh economic data will probably be the primary focus for market participants.
 
 Further Evidence Expected
 Analysts expect that both the figures on retail sales, expected on Wednesday, and those on industrial production, due tomorrow, will provide further evidence that the economy weakened considerably in October. Those statistics may impress Fed governors, but analysts said a move to lower the funds rate will probably be delayed until after October consumer price data are released on Friday.
As with the October producer price report released last Friday, market particpants will probably place more importance on the "core" rate of consumer price inflation -- the rise in prices excluding food and energy -- than in the overall index.
Economists said it was unlikely that the core measure of consumer price inflation behaved as well as the core producer price index did last month.
Excluding food and energy prices, the producer price index was unchanged in October. Due to service-sector inflation, most analysts are forecasting that October consumer prices rose by about three-tenths of a percentage point, the same rate of increase recorded in September. An increase of that size should not be enough to prevent the Fed from easing policy, the economists added.

HEADLINE: Japanese Give in Grudgingly On a New Way of Shopping

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 11

 BODY:
A few months ago the Summit supermarket and department store in Nakano, a quiet neighborhood on the west side of Tokyo, posted notices that it would stay open an hour later every evening, until 7 o'clock.
Within hours, the store was mobbed by owners of small shops, who carried protest signs and shouted accusations that Summit was being deceitful. The crowd kept up its protest until the store's management came out to negotiate. 
 "They acted without talking to us," said Michihisa Ando, who owns a small camera store a few blocks away. "That is why we got so mad."
Throughout Japan, battles over hours, floor space and other matters are beginning. They involve large stores, maverick mid-size stores like Summit and the traditional family-owned businesses that have long dominated retailing in Japan. The instigator of this turmoil is the United States.
Washington has long complained of Japanese barriers to trade, and after years of resistance, Japan agreed earlier this year to drastically weaken the power of small shopowners to keep bigger competitors out. That has radically improved the economics of opening large stores here.
 
Outcome is Unclear
 But it is not clear whether large stores, once they open, will sell many more imported goods than small shops, or whether they will help drive down the cost of consumer goods, thereby increasing consumption, the premises that underlay America's demands for change. For one thing, with a few exceptions like Toys "R" Us and Tower Records, the big retailers now rushing into previously off-limits neighborhoods are largely owned by Japanese, not Americans.
The agreement to foster competition was a important concession Japan made after Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu and President Bush, in talks in Palm Springs, Calif., last spring, broke the deadlock in trade negotiations between the countries.
The countries held negotiations with the unwieldy name of the Structural Impediments Initiative, signifying that the Governments were trying to resolve underlying conflicts in how the national cultures and economies work. In the talks, Japan agreed, among other things, to toughen its antitrust enforcement and loosen the relationships among Japanese companies that exclude outside suppliers. The United States vowed to cut its budget deficit, increase savings, and improve education in hopes of making its economy more competitive.
Without question Japan's antiquated and inefficient retailing system, in which wholesalers sometimes send a truck to deliver five boxes of detergent and the abacus still reigns supreme, is an area in which one can starkly see the results of America's endless trade talks with Japan.
Already, there are groundbreakings all over the country for shopping malls and large stores.
"I think we are beginning to prevail," a Japanese partner of Toys "R" Us said the other day, after a meeting in the Tokyo suburb of Chiba, where plans for a giant toy store were described to a sullen but largely uncomplaining group of local merchants. "I think they are coming to see the big stores as inevitable, maybe even beneficial in some neighborhoods."
Beneficial is not how Ryusuke Shinoyama, who heads the association of shopowners in Nakano, would describe the changes. "It is certain that the number of large-scale retailers will be increased," Mr. Shinoyama said at a gathering of shopowners at a sushi shop in their neighborhood. "But it is also certain that Japanese local society will be destroyed. You already see it happening."
With the supermarket and the smaller shops all staying open until 7 P.M. an uneasy truce now prevails in Nakano, whose business district, like those of most Tokyo neighborhoods, is centered on the Japan Railways station. Most shopowners are older people who rebuilt the neighborhood after it was flattened by American bombs near the end of World War II. They sweep the streets in front of their stores, and greet weary returning workers with cries of "okaeri nasai," roughly "welcome home."
And most of them play by Japanese retailing's unwritten rules: no big sales promotions that lead to price wars, no negative advertising, and limited introductions of products, which might disrupt the "orderliness" of neighborhood markets.
Then came Summit Stores Inc., a mid-size supermarket chain. It is owned by the Sumitomo Corporation, a subsidiary of the huge corporate group that includes the Sumitomo Bank and manufacturing companies.
"We knew right away that it would be big trouble, and there was opposition immediately," said Mr. Ando, who has already seen much of his camera business drawn away by big stores in Shinjuku, a giant Tokyo shopping center a few stops away on the train.
The shopkeepers took advantage of the law that American negotiators finally succeeded in modifying earlier this year: the Large-Scale Retail Store Law, which requires neighborhood approval for any store larger than 600 square yards. The 1.3 million owners of small stores form the bedrock of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party and they feared little retribution, until American complaints gave Government bureaucrats and large department stores the excuse they were waiting for.
Though Japan's complex distribution system is often blamed for the inefficiencies of the retail market here, and the resulting high prices, manufacturers themselves play a significant role. The high prices Japanese pay at home in effect subsidize the competitive prices Japanese manufacturers offer elsewhere.
Japanese consumers rarely complain about the prices they pay for Japanese-made goods. But they vote with their travel budgets. Many Japanese return from vacations and business trips with Japanese-made goods that they bought for perhaps a third less overseas.
Summit wanted to open in Nakano in 1981 or 1982, but the negotiations dragged on until 1987. To reach agreement, the company offered numerous concessions. It reduced its floor space. It agreed to close 48 days a year, rather than its original plan of 29. It agreed to shut each night at 6 P.M.
"Still, the influence was greater than we thought," said Mr. Shinoyama, the head of the Nakano shopowners' group. Within three years of Summit's opening, seven or eight nearby stores, most selling meat and vegetables, closed or rented their locations to other retailers, he added.
 
The American Goals
 Still, what remains unclear is whether all this change is achieving the goal the United States had in mind: lower prices, increased consumption and a narrowed trade gap.
Masafumi Jimbo, the manager of the Summit store, said he had made space available for imported products, like Levi's jeans. "We have definitely been told that we are to promote the sales of imports," he added, as his assistants entered stock data on a computer network. That, in turn, may force the local shopkeepers to stock imported goods as well.
The pressure to allow in imports has been so strong that efforts to slow stores like Toys "R" Us are faltering. The toy chain has announced plans to open more than 100 stores in Japan, starting with four next year. Its partner is perhaps the most successful retailer in Japan, the licensee for McDonald's restaurants, which owns prime retail sites and holds a major stake in Toys "R" Us Japan.
For a while, after owners of toy stores in Nigata Prefecture, an important farming belt, mounted repeated protests, it looked as though the toy chain faced years of negotiation. But Toys "R" Us is learning how to play the game Japanese style. It is putting most of its big stores in largely undeveloped neighborhoods, near highways and inside shopping malls -- away from local shops. It is holding community meetings to explain its plans. And it has learned how to apply political pressure.
The Japanese, ever attuned to symbolic messages, saw the future when the wife of Japan's trade minister returned from a visit to Washington not long ago laden with gifts -- all bought in a shopping spree at a Toys "R" Us store.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

ECONOMY
New York City's economy has some surprising strength and shows little evidence of irreversible decline. Still, most of the enterprises that built the city face complicated problems. [Page A1.]
Big military contractors seem to be immune to punishment when they cheat the Government. Though many Pentagon suppliers have been convicted of fraud, none have been barred from more Government work. [A1.]
Commodity futures traders say they help the oil industry to cope with price swings. They made their case at the opening here of the annual convention of the American Petroleum Institute. [D2.]
 
INTERNATIONAL
The Japanese are giving ground grudgingly in retailing. Small shops are fighting to preserve their domination in the face of challenges from large stores and pressure from the United States. [A1.]
Haagen-Dazs is taking on the land of napoleons and eclairs. Its new French shops are part of a $50 million campaign by the American ice cream maker to expand European sales. [D8.]
 
THE MEDIA BUSINESS
The Tribune Company has resisted investment banking logic. The owner of The Daily News has not expanded television business. [D1.] In its battle with strikers, The News has turned to sidewalk hawkers to sell the paper. [B1.]
All-sports radio stations are considered AM radio's best chance for building a base among males listeners. WFAN in New York is now one of the area's most successful radio stations. [D1.]
Entertainment Weekly is showing new energy and confidence after a shaky debut earlier this year. The magazine has a new design and a new, more mainstream direction. [D6.]
Time Publishing is testing a new magazine on the newsstands. A glossy life-style publication, Martha Stewart Living, will be available today, with a second test planned for the spring. [D6.]
The TV networks seem to have cut the volume of their outcry against new Nielsen findings. Bill Carter: Television. [D6.]
The oldest advertising agency in Japan has been concentrating on its Asian base, but is now opening offices in Eastern Europe and expanding its U.S. operations. Kim Foltz: Advertising. [D7.]
 
COMPANIES
Trans World Airlines has proposed buying Pan Am for $150 million in cash and $300 million in securities. [D1.]
The chairman of Microsoft, William Gates, promises to begin a "crusade" for a new way of using computers. The company wants to increase the range of information accessible from desktop personal computers. [D1.]
Citicorp is trying to sell about $1 billion of convertible preferred shares in a private sale in Europe and the Middle East. [D5.]
The failure of the Freedom National Bank of New York was more than just the demise of another shaky financial institution. It was the end of an idealistic venture begun during the height of the 1960's civil-rights movement. [B1.]
 
TODAY'S COLUMNS

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
KING OF MOROCCO ASKS ARAB SUMMIT

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 11

 BODY:
King Hassan II of Morocco called today for an emergency Arab summit meeting to avert a war in the Persian Gulf.
In a speech broadcast on the Moroccan radio, King Hassan, whose deployment of 1,200 troops was among the first Arab commitments to defend Saudi Arabia, warned that a conflict was drawing near and that he was willing to be the host of an Arab summit meeting within the next week "to give peace a last chance." 
 "A war between Arabs is drawing near, and the drums of war are beginning to throb," he said.
In its initial reaction to the King's call, Iraq's official press agency criticized Morocco for failing to consult with Baghdad before making its proposal. But the statement said Iraq might attend such a meeting if it was consulted about the timing, location and subjects to be discussed, and if these included discussion of the Arab-Israeli dispute.
"The proposed summit should not be part of efforts to prepare the political theater as a cover for American aggression against Iraq and the Arab nation," Baghdad declared.
 
Little Other Arab Reaction
 There was no immediate reaction from other Arab states to the Moroccan proposal. But earlier this week, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt rejected a proposal by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union for an Arab summit meeting. In an interview, Mr. Mubarak said that the Arabs were too divided for such a session to be productive, and that supporters of Iraq were likely to try to turn it into a forum for sanctioning Baghdad's seizure of Kuwait.
The Iraqi leader, President Saddam Hussein, said today that Baghdad was ready to enter a dialogue concerning "the requirements for security in our region" provided the Palestinian question was included in the discussions.
Mr. Hussein's latest repetition of the terms under which he is ready to discuss the crisis came in an interview with the Independent Television News of Britain, which broadcast segments of the interview tonight in London. The interview took place today before King Hassan's call for an Arab summit meeting.
There was no immediate reaction from nations opposing Iraq. But the United States and other members of the coalition that have sent forces to the gulf to confront Iraq have previously rejected negotiations before a total and unconditional Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. They have also rejected any linkage between efforts to settle the gulf crisis and the Arab-Israeli conflict.
 
Chinese Confers in Baghdad
 In Baghdad today, Foreign Minister Qian Qichen of China held two round of talks with his Iraqi counterpart, Tariq Aziz. The Iraqi press agency said that in their second meeting, the Foreign Ministers had "exchanged views on regional conditions and ways to find a peaceful and comprehensive solution to the problems in the region." It gave no details. Mr. Qian is expected to meet with Mr. Hussein.
Iraqis have attached high priority to the Chinese visit, seeking to dissuade China from supporting any United Nations resolution that would authorize the use of force if diplomacy and economic sanctions do not persuade Iraq to quit Kuwait. As one of the five permanent members of the Security Council, China has veto power over its resolutions.
President Mubarak and American officials who met with Mr. Qian have said China would not use its veto to block such a resolution. But Chinese officials have said "detailed consultations" are needed before they would support a Security Council resolution to use force.
Before leaving Amman for Baghdad today, the Chinese Foreign Minister was quoted by Reuters as telling reporters, "I think that the armies stationed in the gulf are too many -- in a way more than necessary."
 
Tough Statement by Briton
 But Britain's Defense Secretary, Tom King, said today while en route to Saudi Arabia that Britain was considering sending additional forces to the gulf. Britain has sent close to 15,000 troops plus air support to Saudi Arabia.
Mr. King, reacting to Mr. Hussein's interview, said he saw little new in his statements. He said the Iraqi leader was "trying to divide the alliance."
In an interview with Independent Television, Mr. King added that Mr. Hussein had to withdraw from Kuwait or face war. "We are not bluffing," he said.
Iran announced today that it would hold its largest air and naval exercises in the gulf next month. Iran's naval commander, Ali Shamkani, was quoted by the Iranian press agency as saying that more than 50 ships, hundreds of small boats and helicopters would take part in the maneuvers in the Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Foreign Minister Qian Qichen of China with his Iraqi counterpart, Tariq Aziz, on arrival in Baghdad. Iraqis have attached high priority to the Chinese visit, seeking to dissuade China from supporting a U.N. resolution that would authorize the use of force in the gulf. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Newspaper to Cut Staff

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 11

 BODY:
The Daily News in Los Angeles will lay off 4 percent of its workers in a cost-cutting move, its publisher, David J. Auger, said last week. The newspaper, based in the San Fernando Valley, employs about 1,200, indicating that about 48 employees will be let go. The Daily News has offered a voluntary early retirement plan to some employees, Mr. Auger said. He attributed the layoffs to the economic downturn that has hurt newspapers across the country.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
A DEBATE UNFOLDS OVER GOING TO WAR AGAINST THE IRAQIS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11

 BODY:
After 14 weeks of proceeding virtually unchallenged at home, the United States policy in the Persian Gulf has become the focus of a national debate. Political and government leaders and prominent academics are examining the question of whether the country's interests in the region are worth defending in a war with Iraq.
Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, the Democratic Party's leading spokesman on military matters, joined the other voices today in suggesting that President Bush was moving too quickly down the road to war and should be more patient to see if the United Nations-imposed sanctions would work.
 
Questions Halt to Rotation
 Mr. Nunn said the Administration had made a mistake in canceling a plan to rotate home some of the troops now in the gulf. It marked the first time a leading Democratic Party figure had directly criticized Mr. Bush's handling of the gulf situation. [Page A15.] 
 And in the last few days, voices as disparate as those of the conservative Roman Catholic Archbishop of Los Angeles, Roger Mahony, and the liberal historian Arthur Schlesinger Jr. have questioned the Bush Administration's means or its ends in the gulf crisis. The Cato Institute, a libertarian public policy research group in Washington, issued a report saying that America has no vital interest in the gulf worth going to war for, certainly not oil.
 
Democrats Are Cautious
 The Democratic leaders on Capitol Hill are proceeding cautiously. They want neither to give Mr. Bush a blank check for military action nor to appear to be undermining him in a foreign confrontation. In a joint statement, the House Speaker, Representative Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington, and the majority leader, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri, said, "We urge the President to explain fully to the American people the strategy and aims that underlie his decision to dispatch additional forces to the region."
Democratic leaders say they recognize that if American military action is to be debated before it is taken, that debate must begin soon, and certainly no later than the return of Congress in January. But at the same time, they worry that such a debate would send a message of division to Baghdad, making it appear that Democrats had undercut the essential purpose of the military buildup: to persuade the Iraqi leadership that America is united and unwavering and that the only choices are withdrawal or war.
The issue was largely avoided in the recent session of Congress and in the political campaign that ended last week. But the issue came into sharper focus as Mr. Bush embarked on a new phase of his gulf policy after the election, announcing reinforcements of the American troops in the Saudi desert to a level that will reach nearly 400,000 with the purpose of convincing President Saddam Hussein of Iraq that the United States is ready for war.
Whether he will succeed in convincing Americans as well is another matter, political and government leaders say. In and outside Washington, there are expressions of concern that Americans have not fully explored whether the human and financial costs of war in the gulf, not to mention the potential political consequences in the Middle East, are worth the hoped-for gains.
 
New Critics Emerge
 Through most of the gulf buildup, criticism of the military intervention was confined largely to what Vice President Dan Quayle referred to last week as the "isolationists" of the Republican Party.
In explaining the motives for American action, President Bush has stopped emphasizing the need to protect oil supplies, an issue he once cited along with the need to resist aggression. He now concentrates on opposing aggression, comparing Mr. Hussein to Hitler. There are critics of both rationales, and a fear of repeating the Vietnam experience -- suffering great loss of life for little purpose.
Already, political leaders in both parties have warned the White House that while Mr. Bush has a national consensus for the steps he has taken so far to defend Saudi Arabia and isolate Iraq, that may not hold for a costly offensive to drive the Iraqis from Kuwait. There is criticism from his own party on Capitol Hill that the President has done a better job of consulting with the United Nations than with the Congress and the American people.
"I think all of us who have just been out on the campaign trail are impressed that the support for the President is broad, but also very thin," said Representative Lee H. Hamilton of Indiana, a senior Democrat on the Foreign Affairs Committee. "And there's a great deal of uneasiness about all of this. They do not want American casualties. They feel that very, very strongly. No one wants American casualties."
In a letter to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, Archbishop Mahony, chairman of the international policy committee of the United States Catholic Conference, wrote, "Our country needs an informed and substantive discussion of the human and ethical dimensions of the policy choices under consideration."
 
Beginnings of Partisan Division
 One-third of voters surveyed on Election Day opposed American military action that would produce heavy casualties, a level of opposition reached during the Vietnam War only after several years of fighting. The survey also found the clear beginnings of the sort of partisan division that tore the country during Vietnam: two-thirds of those opposing American action in the gulf, and in particular, black Americans, voted Democratic. But more than half of those who say the nation should persevere even in the face of many casualties voted Republican.
In writing that war was simply the continuation of politics by other means, Clausewitz, the Prussian military strategist, expanded on the crucial link between the two: "Since war is not an act of senseless passion but is controlled by its political object, the value of this object must determine the sacrifices to be made for it in magnitude and also in duration. Once the expenditure of effort exceeds the value of the political object, the object must be renounced and peace must follow."
What then is the nation's political object in the gulf, and what level of sacrifice is it worth?
The Administration has given different answers to this question. Soon after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, Mr. Bush said: "Our jobs, our way of life, our own freedom and the freedom of friendly countries around the world will suffer if control of the world's great oil reserves falls into the hands of Saddam Hussein."
 
'Fight Isn't About Oil'
 But more recently the Adminstration has abandoned -- indeed rejected -- this suggestion that the gulf confrontation is a modern day spice war, a defense of crucial economic interests. Mr. Bush returned to the image of America as the defender of freedom, the central argument in support of every other war America has fought in this century.
"The fight isn't about oil," Mr. Bush said during a pre-election campaign swing. "The fight is about naked aggression that will not stand."
"We can only presume that this line has been taken because some pollster had told the President that the public would not support sacrifice of American lives to secure Mideast oil and that he'd better start talking on a moral basis if he wanted to make hay with voters," said Ted Van Dyk, a Democratic analyst of economic and political events.
Mr. Van Dyk suggested that Mr. Bush's current rationale was inconsistent with past American policy toward Iraq.
"Fact is," he said, "Saddam Hussein has been acting like a mini-Hitler for many years. We, in fact, supported his invasion of, and war with, Iran."
"We are engaged only because of oil, as we should be," Mr. Van Dyk continued. "But to deny that self-evident fact was to further shake our partners' confidence in the President and to disturb thinking people here. You can be sure we wouldn't have a platoon on the Kuwaiti frontier if the resource in the region was guano."
 
How Much Oil, and How Vital?
 But there are conflicting views over whether Middle Eastern oil is a vital American interest. Statements that Saddam Hussein could end up controlling 40 percent of the world's oil reserves are true, but largely irrelevant, The Cato Institute argues in its report, written by Christopher Layne, a Los Angeles attorney, and Ted Galen Carpenter, the institute's director of foreign policy.
Oil reserves, they argue, are a geologist's concept, a measure of how much oil lies beneath a piece of land. "The pertinent question is how much control Iraq could gain over current world oil production," they wrote. "Even a worst-case scenario does not support the Bush Administration's panic-mongering. Iraq's conquest of Kuwait gave Baghdad control over 7 percent of global production. If Saddam were to take over Saudi Arabia, that figure would increase to only 15.7 percent."
Michael Mandelbaum, director of East-West studies at the Council on Foreign Relations and a professor at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies, argues that this is still a substantial fraction of world production. "Oil is power," he said, and it matters who holds that power, since Mr. Hussein would use it to expand his military strength and thus his influence in the region.
Mr. Schlesinger argued that the sanctions addressed this problem by cutting off Iraq's oil revenues. He and others also challenged the notion that the United States could, or should, be the deterrent to aggression throughout the third world.

GRAPHIC: Photo: An Army mechanized infantry unit training in the Saudi desert. A debate has begun to emerge over whether the protection of American interests is worth the cost of combat with Iraq. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times) (pg. A14)

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
'The Unknown War,' On the Korean Conflict

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
The cold war may be over in Europe, but the political frost is still on Korea. How that nation came to be divided, why it remains so and its prospects for reunification after almost a half century are among the matters addressed in "Korea: The Unknown War." Most of its six hours, however, are given to an eventful account of the war itself.
 The series, which begins tonight from 9 to 11 on Channels 13 and 49 and continues into tomorrow and Wednesday, has already been criticized for a revisionist tone that is unduly kind to North Korea and gives insufficient credit to American forces in the field. The writers have complained in turn that the original script has been changed under pressure from such critics. I must leave that quarrel to the specialists. To this congenitally suspicious reviewer, however, the documentary, produced by Thames Television of Britain in association with WGBH, Boston's public station, is filled with sharp and memory-jogging details and does not seem to be pushing any extreme line at the expense of the record. 
 The opener, "Many Roads to War," concentrates on the few years between Korea's liberation from Japan, its traditional enemy, after World War II and the outbreak of hostilities in 1950. It is presented as a case history of how conflicts within a small country can influence relations among great powers.
 The series is rich in newsreel clips from both North Korea, which came under Soviet occupation in 1945, and from South Korea, which was occupied by the United States, and in the recollections of players on both sides. The division at the 38th parallel, recalls Dean Rusk, who was then Assistant Secretary of State for the Far East, was arbitrary and assumed to be temporary.
 In both sectors indigenous leaders congenial to the occupying powers took over: The Communist Kim Il Sung in the North, the conservative nationalist Syngman Rhee in the South. Neither proved to be a model democrat -- though the series takes care to distinguish between the totalitarian North and the authoritarian South; both made claims to the entire country and used postwar tensions between East and West to advance their ambitions.
Military feints came regularly from both sides of the 38th parallel. The withdrawal of American military forces from the South in June 1949, followed by a speech by Secretary of State Dean Acheson that was interpreted as placing Korea out of America's "defense perimeter" in the Pacific may have been taken as an invitation to invasion by the heavily armed North. The comments of former American and Soviet officers and diplomats suggest that the superpowers, whose concerns were mainly centered on Europe, would have been content to leave their bellicose Asian clients to their own devices, but were too deeply entangled to walk away.
Both sides said they were taken by surprise. Whoever started it, this became the first war to be fought by the United Nations, then pro-West, under the leadership of the United States. In a revealing interview, a Soviet official tells of his surprise that his country's U.N. delegation, which had been boycotting the Security Council over its refusal to admit China, did not return to block the U.N. action. He calls it a "stupid error."
The series relies, on camera and off, on Bruce Cumings, a professor of history at the University of Chicago, as its major consultant. Tonight's two-part program ends with the Communist victories, including the fall of Seoul, in the early weeks of the war, preparing the way for Gen. Douglas MacArthur's spectacular landing at Inchon in September 1950.
Veterans from both sides are heard tomorrow and Wednesday in an account of the crossing of the 38th parallel by the U.N. forces, which prompted a powerful counterattack by Chinese "volunteers." Also covered are President Harry S. Truman's dismissal of MacArthur for going public with his proposal to attack mainland China; the brainwashing of American prisoners of war, and the charges, orchestrated by the world political left, that the United States was using germ warfare. (No definitive conclusion is offered on the accuracy of those charges.) The final program deals largely with the truce of 1953. By this account the deadlock at the prolonged negotiations was broken by President Dwight D. Eisenhower's leaked threat to use the atomic bomb.
The end of the war left Korea as divided as it was at the start. In the years since, of course, South Korea has become an economic wonder, whose relations with the North are still far from warm. Viewers with a memory of television's treatment of the Vietnam War may find themselves wondering how matters might have turned out if Americans at home had been a nightly audience to scenes from the bitter battlefield of Korea.
 
Korea
The Unknown War
A six-part documentary series produced by Thames Television in association with WGBH-TV, Boston; Austin Hoyt of WGBH and Phillip Whitehead of Thames Television, executive producers. At 9 tonight on Channels 13 and 49.
