HEADLINE: Review/Opera;
Ravel and Sendak, Affectionately Paired

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL

 BODY:
The double bill of Maurice Ravel's entire operatic output -- the witty "Heure Espagnol" of 1907 and the enchanting "Enfant et les Sortileges" of 1924, each about 50 minutes long -- finally made it on Saturday to the New York City Opera, where it will run with alternating casts through Sunday afternoon.
Directed by Frank Corsaro and designed by Maurice Sendak, the children's book illustrator, this production was first seen at the Glyndebourne Festival Opera in England in 1987 and 1988. The sets and costumes were purchased by the City Opera and intended for last fall. A labor dispute forced the company to cancel its 1989 fall season and postpone this production until now. 
 What finally arrived onstage at the New York State Theater on Saturday, with one cast in the afternoon and the other in the evening, has its distinct charms, both as a production concept and as performance. It is an honorable, affectionate look at Ravel. But it cannot be said that the more ambitious of the productions, of "L'Enfant et les Sortileges," comes close to New York's closest standard of comparison, the Metropolitan Opera's version of a decade ago, with David Hockney's visionary decor.
The problem in both operas lies more with Mr. Sendak than Mr. Corsaro, who handles stage action deftly apart from his lingering predilection for extraneous mime figures and bits of business. Mr. Sendak's book illustrations, surely familiar to most people, involve large, cartoonlike creatures and a muted color palette. Translated to the stage, in this and his other operatic designs, the same techniques look blunt and unevocative -- cute, often, but remiss in illusionist mystery.
"L'Heure Espagnol," a sexy comedy involving a clockmaker in Toledo, Spain, his rambunctious wife, two aspiring but silly lovers and a brawny muleteer, was placed in a cheerful but oddly dingy setting, with none of the vibrant colors, strong contrasts and visual elegance implied by the Spanish setting and Ravel's music.
It was odd, too, that Mr. Corsaro chose to make the clockmaker, who is referred to as a "ridiculous husband" in the final ensemble, into a benign overseer of the action, with all the characters his mechanical confections. Nothing in the libretto by Maurice Le Grant, who wrote under the name Franc-Nohain, suggests such an inflation of stature.
"L'Enfant et les Sortileges," Colette's fable of a naughty child who is punished when furniture, toys, animals and plants come to life to chastise him, was presented in an ingenious combination of film, slides, sets and animated props. Here Mr. Sendak's childlike cartoons worked more appropriately, if without Mr. Hockney's glowing magic.
But there were technical problems. Ronald Chase's film jiggled continuously, calling attention to itself; perhaps in Glyndebourne's far smaller theater, this problem was less severe. Sometimes the film effects were delightful, as in dancing fire and the manic numbers accompanying the torments of Arithmetic. But too often, even with a covered orchestra pit, they further diluted the colors; even the sparkling stars and comets at the end looked fuzzy and dim.
Still, there is plenty left to enjoy in the operas themselves, these productions and the musical performances, and Cori Ellison's sure supertitles contribute to the audience's pleasure.
For the comparison shopper, the Saturday evening cast, with Anna Steiger as the flirtatious wife in "L'Heure Espagnol," is preferable to the matinee cast. But those who have already bought tickets for the afternoon cast need not feel cheated. Its principals are all good and sometimes better; there is plenty of overlapping in the many small roles in "L'Enfant," and the refined orchestral playing and idiomatic conducting of Guido Ajmone-Marsan are common to both casts.
Miss Steiger, the daughter of Rod Steiger and Claire Bloom, had sung Concepcion at Glyndebourne and was making her City Opera debut. She brought a fuller, sweeter, more easily produced soprano to the part than Kathryn Gamberoni, and an earthier wit to her acting. The evening cast also offered the richly comic Don Inigo Gomez of Joseph McKee, funnier and better sung than that of Jan Opalach.
Kevin Anderson and Michael Rees Davis were about equal as Gonzalve, the impossibly poetical poet. And while Jonathan Green as the clockmaker (a surer singer than John Lankston) and Robert Orth as the muleteer (more macho-looking than Richard Byrne) in the afternoon were better, and while the afternoon cast seemed slightly more at ease with the French, the balance was still tipped decisively toward the evening.
In "L'Enfant et les Sortileges," the evening cast was again superior, though not so markedly. Julia Parks was a shorter (and hence more believably boyish) Child than Robin Tabachnik; Michele McBride sang more dulcetly as the Princess than Young Ok Shin, Mr. Roth and Byrne were about equal in their triple roles, and Lisa Saffer, with her crystalline coloratura, made a more striking Fire and Nightingale than Virginia Sublett.

HEADLINE: After Rape Charge, 2 Lives Hurt and 1 Destroyed

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SOUTH KINGSTON, R.I., Nov. 11

 BODY:
A University of Rhode Island fraternity held a time-honored college rite two weeks ago: a Saturday night bash at the fraternity house with plenty of beer and a throng of young women.
But what happened at the Tau Kappa Epsilon house the night of Oct. 27 and in the following days has rocked this sedate campus of 10,000 students. An 18-year-old freshman told the police that a man raped her at the party while at least five other men watched. 
 On Oct. 31, Dave Lallemand, 19, was arrested and charged with rape. Held for a week without bail, he was released Wednesday when the woman testified at a bail hearing that she was not certain that Mr. Lallemand had assaulted her because she had been drinking heavily the day of the party.
Even as the woman testified, 20-year-old Michael Lindell lay dying in a nearby hospital after shooting himself in the head at his family's home in Pawtucket hours before he was scheduled to meet with the state police to discuss what he saw that night in the fraternity house. The former University of Rhode Island student, who had attended previous parties at the fraternity house, died Wednesday night.
 
Sympathy for 'Three Victims'
 "There really are three victims, and I feel sorry for them all," said Sandra Wall, a student from Pawtucket who went to high school with Mr. Lindell.
Investigators have declined to say whether they see a link between the incident and the suicide of Mr. Lindell, who Miss Wall said had personal problems. Mr. Lindell is believed by the authorities to have been one of the five in the room at the time of the incident.
The twists and turns of the case have been played out against rising reports of sex crimes on campuses across the country. Earlier this year, for example, six students at St. John's University in New York, including five members of the lacrosse team, were accused of sexually assaulting a female student.
Although no definitive statistics on campus rape exist, anecdotal evidence suggests that it is occurring more often these days, partly because universities are doing a better job of compiling data and because women are coming forward more often to press charges.
 
More Relaxed Rules
 Some university officials here believe that more relaxed rules on campuses have made sexual assaults more common. Those changes in rules helped create dormitories shared by both sexes, prompted the lifting of curfews and resulted in looser drinking practices, all of which have played significant roles in campus sexual assaults. Few schools seem immune to the problem, university officials said in interviews last week. The University of Rhode Island, despite its quiet setting, is no exception.
The Tau Kappa Epsilon party began on a crisp Saturday evening in the fraternity's sprawling three-story, 18-bedroom home, with a spacious living room and a large-screen television set.
The woman arrived about 9:30 P.M. with another woman after drinking earlier in the day, according to a statement she gave the police.
The woman, who lives in a university dormitory and returned to campus late last week after going to her parents' home in Massachusetts, could not be reached for comment. But in her statement to the police, she said she went upstairs because she became bored with the party downstairs. Once she arrived in a third-floor bedroom, she told the police, a man she would later identify as Mr. Lallemand, who is 6 feet 7 inches tall, began pawing her. She said that when she tried to push him away he forced himself on her.
 
Student Is Defended
 She told the police that two or three other men who were present tried to prevent her from dressing after the assault. She said another man whom she did not know picked her up, put her over his shoulder and carried her to her dormitory.
The incident shocked students and prompted about 200 women to stage a vigil last week demanding more safety measures. The incident also elicited a defense of the young woman, despite questions raised publicly by some students about her judgment.
Some said the real victim was Mr. Lallemand, a first-year student who is trying to join the fraternity. Neither he nor his family could be reached for comment, but the student maintained his innocence in published comments after his release.
 
Bad Feelings Remain
 Taillights on the cars of some fraternity members have been smashed and the word "rapist" scrawled in lipstick on their car windows. Other members have been shunned by the university community. In a move that especially hurt the fraternity, the organization was banned from holding social functions until state and university investigations are complete. "There are questions still hanging in the air," said Michael P. Brady, the fraternity's president and a senior economics major from Albany. "We don't know what happened, but I can say that Dave is 100 percent innocent."
Mr. Lallemand is one of 21 underclassmen trying to join the fraternity in the pledging process, which requires the student to wear a fraternity pin and perform services for members. The woman told the police that her assailant wore a pledge pin. While viewing 21 photographs of the pledges, she identified her assailant as Mr. Lallemand, who she said had introduced himself as "Dan."
The case unraveled Wednesday, when the woman testified that she could no longer say with certainty that Mr. Lallemand had assaulted her. She testified that she went blank for a time and that she remembered waking up on a couch before a man whom she did not know carried her back to her dormitory.
In investigating the incident, the second reported sexual-assault case on the campus this fall, the state police began interviewing five or six other men believed to have been in the room when the attack occurred. One of them was Mr. Lindell, who attended the university last year but had since left the school. The former high school football player had attended several fraternity parties because of hometown ties with at least one fraternity member, said friends of Mr. Lindell.
 
Was Not a Suspect
 Last Tuesday, hours before he was to have been questioned by the police, Mr. Lindell used a gun belonging to his roommate and shot himself. Lieut. Brian R. Andrews, chief of the Rhode Island state police's detective unit, said Mr. Lindell was not a suspect. But he said the turn of events will make the case more difficult to solve because of discrepancies in the accounts given to the police by 18 people who were at the fraternity house.
The state police are to confer with the State Attorney General's office on Wednesday, when a decision is expected to be made to refer the case to a grand jury, Lieutenant Andrews said.
The incident occurred even as university officials have tried to exert more control over student life. Freshman are warned during orientation about campus rape. University officials, noting that 70 to 80 percent of disciplinary problems are alcohol-related, said the incident may prod efforts to create an alcohol-free campus.
